title: About New York; A Boy, a Bully And Cries Unheard
description: HERE is Joey Bari in the third grade. Small, very small, for his age, and with a habit of putting gel in his hair because he worships Elvis. Being raised by a newly divorced mother who can no longer afford to send him to parochial school. Loves baseball.

title: High-Tech Voting System Is Banned in California
description: California has banned the use of more than 14,000 electronic voting machines made by Diebold Inc. in the November election because of security and reliability concerns, Kevin Shelley, the California secretary of state, announced yesterday. He also declared 28,000 other touch-screen voting machines in the state conditionally ''decertified'' until steps are taken to upgrade their security.

title: Keeping a Full Plate; Calling Games All Day, an Iron Man Among Umpires
description: Butch Krichman was the kind of obsessed child who made a ball field his home from morning until night. If he couldn't find a team to play with in his Jersey Shore universe, he'd draw a box with an X on a concrete wall, measure off 45 feet and hurl a rubber ball against the wall just to hear its comforting thump.

title: Merger of 2 Health Plans Getting Regulatory Review
description: New York State regulators are studying the potential impact of the proposed merger between UnitedHealth Group and Oxford Health Plans, and the American Medical Association is calling for federal regulators to review the combination's effect on competition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: Filling In, a Pianist Pleases Many Fans of an Ailing Argerich
description: The countless fans of Martha Argerich, an astounding though sometimes erratic pianist prone to bad nerves and health problems, are never completely surprised when she misses a concert. Scheduled to play four performances of Schumann's piano concerto with the New York Philharmonic this week, she withdrew, citing illness (a bronchial infection, an orchestra official said). Stepping in on short notice was the Canadian pianist Louis Lortie, who recently replaced Ms. Argerich for performances of the Schumann in San Francisco.

title: Another Leap by China, With Steel Leading Again
description: When Mao Zedong ordered communities across China in the late 1950's to set up backyard kilns and rapidly increase steel production as part of his Great Leap Forward, the results were disastrous. The country turned out millions of tons of useless substandard steel, while millions of people starved as distracted farmers neglected their fields.

title: The New Drug Discount Cards
description: Elderly and disabled Americans will be able to sign up starting Monday for the first tangible benefit to emerge from the Medicare prescription drug program approved by Congress last year. It is a drug discount card that is supposed to reduce drug prices by 10 to 25 percent for cardholders as a stopgap measure until the full prescription drug benefit kicks in on Jan. 1, 2006. How great the savings will turn out to be in practice is a matter of conjecture, but the cards will at least provide a projected seven million beneficiaries with group purchasing power like that long marshaled by big health insurance plans.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: United Nations: Peacekeepers For Haiti
description: The Security Council unanimously backed a peacekeeping mission of 6,700 soldiers and 1,622 police officers for Haiti to succeed the United States-led interim force that has been there since February. The new multinational force, to be led by Brazil, is to take over on June 1. Despite a request from Secretary General Kofi Annan to give the force a two-year mandate, the Council decided to review the mission after six months. United Nations diplomats have had difficulty assembling the force, but Stuart Holliday, an American envoy, said, ''We think that this will be an important step in getting potential troop contributors to come forward.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

In ''10.5,'' a two-part mini-series about a huge West Coast earthquake, Beau Bridges plays the president of the United States with the kind of lip-biting valor (''then reschedule the German Ambassador, my people come first, John'') that comes dangerously close to the parodies his father perfected in films like ''Airplane!'' and ''Hot Shots!''

description: Several members of the jury in the Jayson Williams manslaughter trial here said that they were persuaded by the defense team's argument that the shooting of a chauffeur inside Mr. Williams's house was an accident, even though they ended the trial deadlocked on a charge of reckless manslaughter.

title: Sex And The Cities
description: Sex is pretty elemental. We share the same basic biology. We watch nationally broadcast TV shows and movies designed for international audiences. You'd think you'd be able to drive across a few neighborhoods in this country and come across reasonably similar sexual behavior patterns. But you'd be wrong.

title: John Harry Niemeyer, 95; Headed Bank Street College
description: John Harry Niemeyer, president emeritus of the Bank Street College of Education in Manhattan, died on April 19 in the Florida Keys. He was 95 and had moved there from Greenwich Village four years ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bank Giant Posts Profit
description: Singapore Bank DBS Group Holdings, Southeast Asia's largest financial institution, said that net profit in the first quarter rose 80.1 percent, to 488 million Singapore dollars ($286.6 million), as the region's growing economies helped it generate higher interest payments and stockbrokers' commissions. Singapore's government controls 27 percent of DBS through its investment arm, Temasek Holdings. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: The Federal Election Commission voted to block a payment of matching funds to the Rev. Al Sharpton's presidential campaign after it had previously approved giving him the money, nearly $80,000, commission officials said yesterday. The decision may be the first time the commission has rescinded a decision to pay matching funds.

description: CULLMAN--Joseph F. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened at the death of beloved Joe, bereft and dispirited by the painful loss of Joan just six weeks ago. Joe avidly seconded Joan's devoted commitment to Lincoln Center Theater and was wonderfully supportive and enthusiastic about the plays. Joe's autobiography, aptly titled ''I'm a Lucky Guy'', sums up Joe's sense of how his life turned out. Those who knew him well and enjoyed his friendship and generous spirit were also ''lucky guys''. We send condolences to Joe's family and colleagues. John B. Beinecke Chairman John Chalsty President Andre Bishop Artistic Director Bernard Gersten Executive Producer

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank Posts Profit
description: Germany's largest bank, Deutsche Bank, posted a first-quarter profit and stronger-than-expected revenue, helped by fixed-income revenue, which grew 7 percent from 2003's first quarter. Net profit rose to 941 million euros ($1.1 billion), up from a loss of 219 million euros a year ago, and pretax profit rose from 234 million euros to 1.56 billion euros. The chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said the group was ''making good progress'' toward a 25 percent pretax return on equity for 2005. Despite the good news, the share price fell by 2.2 percent in Frankfurt. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Bush Voices 'Disgust' at Abuse of Iraqi Prisoners
description: President Bush said Friday that he was deeply disgusted by reports that Iraqi detainees were abused by American military police, and he vowed that any soldier found to be at fault would be punished.

title: Chrebet Returns to Practice, But Is No Longer a Starter
description: The lightheadedness still comes sometimes, a reminder of the murkiness that enveloped his mind for weeks. It was not until February that Wayne Chrebet was even sure he wanted to play football again.

description: Snarling the tone of its inquiry into Gov. John G. Rowland, the House committee leading the investigation on Friday asked its lawyer to draft an article of impeachment accusing Mr. Rowland of obstruction for failing to comply with repeated requests and subpoenas to produce personal financial records.

description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that Lynne F. Stewart, a civil rights lawyer who is accused of helping one of her clients conduct terrorist activities from prison, cannot represent herself at trial, and that the trial will take place before an anonymous jury.

description: When the Mets left Los Angeles late Thursday night, they were positively giddy. A team with eight regulars from Southern California, including four from San Diego, acted as though it were headed home.

description: With a potential $10,000 salary bonus riding on her pupils' scores, a Queens elementary school principal interfered with the grading of last year's statewide reading test, city investigators said yesterday. They said she had demanded that the papers of low-performing fourth graders be re-scored with an eye toward raising their grades.

description: Though it is neither their purpose nor their charge, the jurors in the insurance case involving Larry A. Silverstein, the commercial leaseholder at the World Trade Center site, may be reshaping the future of Lower Manhattan.

description: Google's public offering statement reads like part financial document, part populist manifesto, emphasizing the company's intention to stay true to long-term values, not just short-term profits. Equally unusual is the company's decision to sell shares to investors through a public auction.

title: KEYSPAN PROFIT UP ON HIGHER NATURAL GAS SALES
description: The KeySpan Corporation, the biggest seller of natural gas in the Northeast, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 1.8 percent from a year earlier amid higher sales and a rate increase in Boston. Net income per share was unchanged at $1.53 from a year earlier, said KeySpan, which is based in New York. Profit rose to $246.2 million, from $241.8 million, a year ago. The per-share earnings reflect payment of dividends on preferred stock. Shares of KeySpan rose 62 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $36.15.

To imagine the outrage the incident has provoked, Americans need only imagine how they would feel if they saw pictures of American soldiers being treated in a similar way.

title: GLOBAL CROSSING STOCK TUMBLES ON AUDITOR MOVE
description: Shares of Global Crossing, the fiber optic network operator that exited bankruptcy in December, fell as much as 23 percent yesterday after Grant Thornton withdrew its audits for the last three years. Global Crossing shares tumbled $2.85, to $7.15. The stock has dropped 68 percent this year through yesterday. Without audited financial results, the shares are likely to be delisted from Nasdaq, one analyst said. The company disclosed Grant Thornton's move in a filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Global Crossing is based in Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: VW Says That Profit Fell 87% in Quarter
description: Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, said Friday that its first-quarter profit fell 87 percent despite a rise in sales because of higher costs to introduce new models, incentives to aid sales of the Golf and currency shifts.

title: PepsiCo Is Told It May Face S.E.C. Complaint Over Kmart
description: PepsiCo Inc. said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission might bring a civil complaint against two of its divisions, which the agency contends assisted improper accounting at the Kmart Corporation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Surgery Kills Star Of Documentary
description: A 57-year-old Swiss woman, Rosmarie Voser, whose quest for a heart transplant had been documented in a television news series died in a Zurich hospital after transplant surgery because the donor organ had the wrong blood type. Hospital officials said the cause of the mistake was not known. Prosecutors said they had opened an investigation. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: North Korea Accepts Aid From South Korea
description: Hours after receiving the first known cargo flight in its history from South Korea, North Korea promised Friday to allow South Korean Red Cross trucks to roll across the demilitarized zone. The two unusual concessions underlined how the humanitarian emergency after last week's train blast was opening doors in North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GITTLER, ROBERT D., MD.
description: GITTLER--Robert D., MD. On Thursday, April 29, 2004 in New York. A man of great intellect, love and compassion, Bob will be deeply missed by his loving wife, son, daughterin-law, grandsons, and many dear friends. During a distinguished career, Bob practiced medicine for 40 successful years, a physician who found great pleasure in his work and his patients, many of whom count themselves among his lifelong friends. He served as the Deputy Chief Police Surgeon to the City of New York and taught at two hospitals and one medical school in the metropolitan area. Bob shared the joys of traveling and a love of France with his love, companion, and wife of 44 years, Rosalie. He enjoyed many hours at the bridge table with good friends. He was devoted to his son, Andrew, who returns that love and devotion always. His grandsons, Daniel and Evan, loved their Poppa dearly. Services on Sunday, May 2nd, 12:45 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Reports Profit
description: The French telecommunications equipment company Alcatel reported its first profits in three years for the first quarter, and raised its outlook for 2004. Alcatel's net income grew to 134 million euros ($161 million) for the first quarter of 2004, in contrast to a 461 million euro ($552 million) loss for the period last year. The company's sales dropped 3 percent to 2.74 billion euros this year. At constant exchange rates, sales grew 2 percent, the company said. The company's performance was built on better performances in most of its markets, particularly in its mobile communication department, where sales grew to 70 million euros in the first quarter of 2004, up from 15 million euros a year ago. title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: APPEALS COURT RULES AGAINST NAZI GUARD A federal appeals court upheld a judge's decision to strip John Demjanjuk, a retired autoworker, of his citizenship, saying the government had proven Mr. Demjanjuk had been a guard at Nazi death camps. The Justice Department said it would begin the process to force Mr. Demjanjuk, who was born in Ukraine, to leave the United States. The unanimous ruling from the three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit said the government had provided "clear, unequivocal and convincing evidence" of Mr. Demjanjuk's service. Mr. Demjanjuk, 84, who lives in the Cleveland area, has said he is the victim of mistaken identity, and his family vowed to challenge the ruling. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Terra Lycos May Sell Unit
description: Terra Lycos, the Internet arm of the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefnica, is considering the sale of the Internet portal Lycos US as part of a strategic shift in its operations but ''no definitive decision has been made,'' said Telefnica's chairman, Csar Alierta, left, at a shareholders meeting, in answer to rumors about a sale. ''Terra networks is currently undergoing a process of analysis and revision of select operative units,'' a regulatory filing with the Spanish stock market commission said. Telefnica bought Lycos US in 2000 for 12.56 billion euros, but since then, the company's value has shrunk sharply, a company spokesman said. Telefnica is bolstering its Spanish- and Portuguese-language operations, as evidenced by the purchase in the works of all Bell South's assets in Latin America, Mr. Alierta said. Telefnica will nearly double its stake in its Portuguese partner, Portugal Telecom, from 4.7 percent to 8.17 percent, he added. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: AMGEN WINS APPROVAL TO USE ARTHRITIS DRUG FOR PSORIASIS
description: Amgen, the world's biggest biotechnology company, won approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to sell its arthritis drug Enbrel as a treatment for the skin disease psoriasis. The medicine was introduced in 1998 for use in rheumatoid arthritis, a crippling joint disease. The F.D.A. approved the drug for moderate to severe cases of psoriasis, said an agency spokeswoman, Lenore Gelb. The decision may help Enbrel sales rise as much as 38 percent, to $1.8 billion this year, from $1.3 billion last year, Amgen has said. The F.D.A. confirmed the approval after the market closed. Shares of Amgen, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., fell $1.71, or 2.9 percent, to $56.41.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Anti-Semitic Vandalism At Cemetery
description: Vandals scrawled swastikas and Nazi slogans overnight on 127 graves in an isolated Jewish cemetery in Alsace, near France's border with Germany. France's president, Jacques Chirac, expressed ''horror'' over the incident and said that, ''in the name of French, I want to express my emotion in face of abominable and intolerable acts that I solemnly condemn.'' The number of anti-Semitic attacks in France has sharply risen in recent years, and many are thought to be conducted by gangs of French-Arab youths. But the attack in Alsace deviated from usual patterns -- along with swastikas, the vandals painted slogans in German, including ''Jews out'' and ''One People, One Reich, One Fuhrer.'' The French authorities said they also found graffiti including the dates ''30 April 1945'' and ''30 April 2004.'' Hitler is generally believed to have committed suicide in his Berlin bunker on April 30, 1945. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: FORMER T.W.A. EXECUTIVE IS HIRED BY DELTA AIR LINES
description: Delta Air Lines named Michael Palumbo, a former Trans World Airlines Inc. executive, as chief financial officer yesterday, as the carrier tries to stem losses totaling $3.3 billion the last three years. Mr. Palumbo, 57, succeeds M. Michele Burns, 46, who quit two weeks ago to join the Mirant Corporation, a power producer, said Delta, which is based in Atlanta. Mr. Palumbo spent seven years at T.W.A. and was the airline's chief financial officer from 1999 to 2001, when it was bought in a bankruptcy-court auction by the AMR Corporation.

title: Williams Guilty of Cover-Up, But Not of Manslaughter

He was convicted of four other lesser charges that he had covered up his involvement in the February 2002 shooting.

The men -- Niall Connolly, Martin McAuley, and Jim Monaghan -- will repay the Irish authorities for the bail, which is necessary because Colombia's state prosecutor is appealing the verdicts. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Soldiers Honored, Soldiers Dishonored
description: The sight and sound of today's youngsters suddenly curious about the meaning of those gold stars of six decades ago is at least as poignant as the sprawling new World War II memorial that opened to visitors this week on the Washington Mall. The west wall of the circular neo-Classical tribute is dotted with 4,000 gold stars. This is the symbol that marked the humble window flags of so many, many families who sacrificed sons and daughters in that global war -- one star per lost soul. But at the memorial, big as it is, each star must represent 100 dead. It is stunning to see a new generation do the math and visualize the scale of the nation's pain in a time that is all too fast becoming the long-ago.

The company is based in San Ramon, Calif.

title: HELEN OF TROY WILL BUY OXO INTERNATIONAL FOR $275 MILLION
description: Helen of Troy, which makes Vidal Sassoon hair care products, has agreed to buy OXO International for $275 million from the WKI Holding Company to add products that include kitchen gadgets and garden items. Helen of Troy shares rose 13 percent. OXO is forecast to have more than $100 million in sales in the next 12 months, and Helen of Troy raised its profit estimate because of the deal from $2.50 to $2.70 a share from as little as $2.30 in the year ending next February, the company said yesterday. Helen of Troy, based in El Paso, will gain consumer brands including OXO and Good Grips. OXO's 500 consumer products also include automotive and storage goods. WKI Holding is selling OXO to invest in its main kitchen lines, including Pyrex, Revere and Corelle, the company said. The proceeds will also be used to pay down debt and cut interest costs, said WKI, which is based in Reston, Va.

A black garbage bag stuffed with blankets, baby clothes, and toys took up most of the dusty backseat of his Pontiac. In later years Vaca would study psychology to, as he said, "determine where sickness ends and evil begins."

title: Singled Out
description: I recently helped my healthy 26-year-old stepson apply for an individual health policy. As we filled out the forms, I was suddenly grateful that he is a stoic kind of guy who rarely goes to doctors and hates taking medication, even when he has a legitimate complaint. He was accepted at the lowest rate, no questions asked. But your article made me wonder what the legions of teenagers currently on antidepressants or getting treatment for A.D.H.D. will face when their parents' health insurance no longer covers them and they find themselves filling out those forms a few years from now. What a paradox, that in the rush to medicate our children, our society has perhaps created a time bomb of future uninsurables branded with the ''previously diagnosed conditions'' label at the tender age of 23.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Millionaires Gather

The weather was strangely balmy for April, and the puffy cumulus cloud I exhaled hung motionless in the humid air. The scent was rich and chocolaty, as though someone had lifted the lid on a Whitman Sampler. It was the tantalizing aroma of a Kool Mocha Taboo.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column of this section on Dec. 15, 2002, about the America's Cup, credited it erroneously with a precedent. It is the world's oldest sailing trophy, first awarded in 1851, but not ''the oldest trophy in sport.'' The Scorton Silver Arrow is considered the oldest, awarded annually in an English archery tournament since 1673. (The error also occurred in sports articles on Jan. 10, 2003; Dec. 22, 2002; May 10, 1992; Dec. 25, 1983; Sept. 27, 1983; Sept. 25, 1983; June 12, 1983; and Jan. 16, 1983; as well as editorials on May 19, 1992, and Jan. 21, 1987; also a Travel article on Sept. 4, 1983, and the Saturday News Quiz on June 18, 1983.) title: Baltimore

title: The World; Babel, a New Capital For a Wider Continent
description: ONE lesson offered by the Book of Genesis is that when ''the whole earth was of one language and of one speech,'' things got done. And when the Lord disapproved of the grandiosity of the resulting Tower of Babel, his way of scattering those engaged in the project was to ''confound their language, that they may not understand one another's speech.''

title: You Want Liver Failure With That?
description: THE filmmaker Morgan Spurlock kicked off his career with ''I Bet You Would,'' a proto-reality show on MTV that dared the man on the street to suffer through some mild humiliation (in one memorable episode, a leather-bound biker accepted the dare to ride his bike down a popular strip wearing a tutu and pink leotard). More recently, in a karmic payback of sorts, Mr. Spurlock dared himself to eat nothing but McDonald's for 30 straight days, shunning most exercise while gorging on burgers with special sauce and downing 42-ounce Cokes. Mr. Spurlock, a onetime ballet student who lives with his vegan-chef girlfriend, documented the results in ''Super Size Me,'' a film that won the documentary directors award at Sundance and opens on Friday. To discuss the implications of his one-man fast-food fest, Susan Dominus visited Mr. Spurlock in his SoHo office.

title: Fixing Nemo
description: Dr. Helen Roberts was about to make the first incision in what should have been a standard surgery -- a quick in-and-out procedure -- when she froze. ''Bonnie,'' she said, turning to her anesthesiologist, ''is she breathing? I don't see her breathing.'' Roberts's eyes darted around the room. ''Grab the Doppler,'' she told her other assistant. ''I want to hear her heart. Bonnie, how's she doing?'' Bonnie pushed up her purple glasses, leaned over the surgery table and lowered her face inches from the patient to watch for any signs of breath: nothing. ''She's too deep,'' Roberts said, ''go ahead and give her 30 c.c.'s of fresh water.'' Bonnie picked up an old plastic jug filled with pond water and poured two glugs into the anesthesia machine. Seconds later, a whisper of a heart rate came through the Doppler. Bonnie wasn't happy: ''We have gill movement -- but not much.'' Then the Doppler went silent and she reached for the jug. ''Wait,'' Roberts said. ''We have fin movement . . . damn, she's waking up -- 30 c.c.'s of anesthetic.'' Roberts sighed. ''She was holding her breath,'' she said, shaking her head. ''Fish are a lot smarter than people give them credit for.''

It's actually more a matter of weeks than minutes, and yes, I'm keeping count, but the particulars don't make much difference because it's clear to me that whenever 50 shows up -- it could be tomorrow or two years from now -- it comes as a blow to one's perennially youthful psyche, as impossible to grasp about one's own sprightly self as it seems perfectly plausible when it comes to other people.

title: HOSPITAL ERROR REPORTS
description: Governor McGreevey signed a law last week that would give hospitals more confidentiality when notifying the state of serious mistakes. The law, the Patient Safety Act, is intended to encourage reporting of errors. While the state currently requires that hospitals disclose mistakes, they have been loathe do so because of fear of malpractice suits. The new law requires that the information go to the state and to patients and their family members rather than the public. State health officials, however, will pass on findings of willful misconduct or negligence to the attorney general's office. The law takes effect in six months. Medical mistakes kill an estimated 3,000 people in New Jersey each year. George James

Father of Robert Jr., (Jean Smith), Margaret Minnick (Jeffrey), Richard (Eileen Kelly), Patricia Cochran (David), Douglas, and Eleanor Clark (Walton). It was around 11:30 a.m. on a Tuesday at the offices of The New Yorker, the appointed time at which, for the better part of 50 years, cartoonists have shown up for the ritual submission of their rough drawings to the magazine's cartoon editor -- these days, Robert Mankoff. Mr. Diffee crossed paths with an older cartoonist emerging from Mr. Mankoff's office, looking as though he'd seen a ghost. Mr. Mankoff, the cartoonist confessed, had given him an ultimatum: no more fedoras in his cartoons.

title: ONE-YEAR BAN FOR KING
description: The Casino Control Commission has banned Don King from promoting boxing matches in Atlantic City for a year. Though the Division of Gaming Enforcement had recommended a five-year ban for Mr. King, the commission decided at its Wednesday meeting to give Mr. King a one-year penalty, but to also close a loophole that has allowed him to promote fights in Atlantic City while his license application was pending before the commission. The commission has been trying to question Mr. King about his ties with Robert W. Lee Sr., the founder of the International Boxing Federation, who was sentenced to 22 months in prison in 2001 for bribery. Mr. King was an unindicted co-conspirator in the case. Mr. King had applied for a license twice, promoted fights reported to have earned him as much as $6 million, and then withdrew the applications before the commission could question him. The ruling makes Mr. King ineligible to apply for a license again until April 28, 2005, but will not also let him promote fights until the commission completes any investigation concerning him. Robert Strauss

title: Unpacking Skinner's Box
description: It's sad to see an interesting writer go off the rails, but last month that is what seemed to have happened to Lauren Slater. After publishing some genre-twisting memoirs, Slater, a psychologist, wanted to celebrate landmark psychological studies as ''stories -- absorbed, reconfigured, rewritten.'' The result, in her new book, ''Opening Skinner's Box: Great Psychological Experiments of the Twentieth Century,'' is a wayward and powerful blend of science, autobiography and imagination. Writing, for example, about Stanley Milgram's famous investigation at Yale, which revealed students' willingness, under orders, to administer what they believed were painful electric shocks to other people, Slater uses the second person to convey the point of view of one of the obedient torturers, a literary choice that nails her point: we all think we wouldn't turn up the voltage, but Milgram's results showed that 65 percent of us will.

title: First, Flay a Squirrel
description: The thesis of Torgny Lindgren's charming new novel sometimes seems to be: life isn't in the details -- it's in the entrails. Lindgren is a prominent novelist in his native Sweden; he also turns out to be a first-rate food writer, rapturously describing the flavor of ''various organs and body parts,'' ways to cook squirrels after you've flayed and gutted them and the best method for dispatching a pig's head. Big chunks of this book, which has been adroitly translated by Tom Geddes, could be dropped verbatim into Gourmet magazine. HASH (Overlook, $23.95) is set in postwar Sweden, where an eccentric newspaper reporter is banned from his trade when his editor discovers that the reports he's been filing for years are ''completely devoid of any basis in fact.'' When the editor dies half a century later, the unnamed reporter, now 107 and living in a nursing home, picks up his pen again, returning to his apparently true story of two strangers, a schoolteacher and a fugitive Nazi war criminal, who arrive in the tuberculosis-stricken village of Avaback to reinvent themselves. Will the writer, this time, finish the story of what happens when these two become so infatuated with the local version of a meat, offal and grain delicacy that they wind up scouring the country in a potentially fatal search for the ultimate version of the stuff? As the narrative alternates between the stir an unreliable reporter creates in his rest home and his tale of unlikely allies on a culinary quest, Lindgren delivers a story that's a clever sendup of the conceits of storytellers and a bittersweet meditation on life and the pleasures that bind us to it. Lindgren's characters understand that the secret to life isn't so different from the secret to good hash: both are best when ''just about everything goes into it.'' Mary Elizabeth Williams

title: Bulgaria's Venerable Second City
description: We approached Plovdiv from Istanbul across the sad monotony of eastern Thrace. Once across the Bulgarian border everything changed: the landscape became more varied and interesting, and in the small towns and villages there were no raw, concrete apartment blocks (the norm in Turkey), only low, red-brick houses with red-tiled roofs and withering vines. The road was lined with metal shacks selling alcohol in all its forms, cigarettes and candy; there were stalls piled with bags of walnuts and tired-looking cabbages; there were cheerfully scruffy Gypsy boys who importuned any vehicle that so much as slowed down, and flocks of geese waddling home in the fading light. Maples, oaks and willows overarched the narrow road, and banks of feathery white reeds bordered it, as did, at irregular intervals, the kind of monumental sculptures to which all authoritarian regimes seem to be addicted. There seemed to be no particular reason for them to be where they were, and there was nothing to indicate what they might once have been intended to symbolize. They were ghosts, emptied allegories.

title: ETHICS LEGISLATION
description: The General Assembly opened its review of the Democrats' long-awaited ethics legislation last week, in the first of four public meetings that leaders hope will answer growing complaints about political corruption. The committee meeting focused on eight bills that would tighten campaign-finance reporting requirements and bolster enforcement. The bills under consideration on Monday would require the reporting of all contributions of $100 or more, down from $400, and increase penalties for reporting violations. They would also require professional fund-raisers to register, prohibit political solicitation on state property, regulate the recorded telephone calls to voters and strengthen the Election Law Enforcement Commission, the agency that oversees elections. The next meeting, scheduled for Thursday in Trenton, will review financial disclosure and conflict-of-interest rules for legislators and regulation of lobbying. Laura Mansnerus

title: Unpacking Skinner's Box
description: It's sad to see an interesting writer go off the rails, but last month that is what seemed to have happened to Lauren Slater. After publishing some genre-twisting memoirs, Slater, a psychologist, wanted to celebrate landmark psychological studies as ''stories -- absorbed, reconfigured, rewritten.'' The result, in her new book, ''Opening Skinner's Box: Great Psychological Experiments of the Twentieth Century,'' is a wayward and powerful blend of science, autobiography and imagination. Writing, for example, about Stanley Milgram's famous investigation at Yale, which revealed students' willingness, under orders, to administer what they believed were painful electric shocks to other people, Slater uses the second person to convey the point of view of one of the obedient torturers, a literary choice that nails her point: we all think we wouldn't turn up the voltage, but Milgram's results showed that 65 percent of us will.

title: PRINCETON LIMITS A'S
description: The Princeton University faculty has overwhelmingly approved a new grading system intended to stem grade inflation. The proposal by the undergraduate dean, Nancy Malkiel, limits the number of A's, including A-pluses and A-minuses, given in any undergraduate department to 35 percent of students for all courses and 55 percent for those taking upper-level independent work. It takes effect next fall. A study of the Princeton class of 2002 showed that 65 percent of students graduated with an average of B-plus or higher and that a student with a B average would rank 923 out of a class of 1,079. Students had voiced concerns during debate over the proposal that limiting A's would unfairly jeopardize them in job and graduate-school applications, since it would lower their grade-point averages relative to other colleges that did not limit A's. Dr. Malkiel stressed that the new guidelines were ''expectations,'' not strict limits, and that specific cases will be viewed on their merits. Robert Strauss

description: It is one thing to attract the brightest and best of our students to local colleges and universities [''Getting the Best Students to Go Local,'' April 25], it is another to keep them here when they graduate. The ''brain drain'' is fostered as much by the lack of affordable housing on Long Island as by the selection of out-of-town schools. If young professionals, teachers, engineers, lawyers, etc. cannot afford to live here on the starting salaries they are offered, then they will be forced to leave.

title: A Rare And Stirring Mixture
description: What I love about Brooklyn is that it's impossible to get a handle on. It lacks anything approaching a center of gravity. Picture the combined populations of Atlanta, Boston, Miami, Cleveland and Seattle crammed into a space smaller than Cincinnati but with a downtown only as impressive as, say, that of Hartford, Conn., and you start to get the idea.

title: Waterfront Project Hinges on Asphalt Plant
description: WHEN developers working to rehabilitate an old industrial section of this village acquired a neighboring waterfront parcel occupied by an asphalt plant, it was considered a major coup. Ultimately the project will give the village new offices, a new public works garage and a new recreational center, making a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to remake a large swath of Hudson River waterfront near the border with Sleepy Hollow, as well as significant parts of the village.

title: Tenants and Building Security
description: Q. Some landlords are beginning to tell current tenants that they must submit to invasive security requirements to get a key card to enter their own buildings. Fliers posted all around my building are intimidating residents into supplying copies of their driver's license, electric bill and phone bill, having their photo taken and filling out a questionnaire. No current tenants in my building ever consented to such practices as part of their lease agreements. What information can the landlord require from someone who is already a tenant? . . . Seth Kaplan, Brooklyn.

title: End of the Trail For Camden's Finest
description: Moe, the most lovable cop in Camden County is out of a job.

title: Subterranean Heat
description: LEVEL V, the basement lounge at the new restaurant Vento in the triangular building that splits Hudson and Ninth Avenue, is a microcosm of what the meatpacking district has morphed into after a few years of high-end commercial development. The building, which formerly housed two gay nightclubs -- the Vault, with whipping posts and cages, and later the Manhole -- is now a candlelit lounge with predictable Top 40 hip-hop songs and a crowd that is uniformly bronzed, pedicured and blow-dried.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Lost, and Found, in Riga
description: FOR the past several months, the tabloid press in London, where I live, has been making wild predictions about the hordes of hopeful migrants who can be expected to descend on Britain now that the European Union is expanding.

title: Board Seats Coveted, Despite the Burdens
description: AS a partner in an international law firm, Celia Felsher expected to put in 15-hour work days.

title: On WBGO, Past and Present
description: Re: ''25 Years Straight Ahead -- A Radio Station Success Story'' (April 25): The article is incomplete. David Corcoran is dismissive of the early days of WBGO. Long before it became an all-jazz station, it performed a distinguished role. In fact, from 1949 and for many of the years that followed, WBGO served an effective purpose as an educational vehicle in the hands of the Newark Board of Education. With William Pfeiffer, and then, I believe, Marie Scanlon as teaching supervisors, and a very small staff of educational radio writers, this pre-television and pre-computer genre combined education and entertainment, and brought them into the classroom -- through radio. It was a forerunner of the wonderful television programs that later became standard fare for children.

title: Dutch Bunnies With Depth
description: THE small square, simple and easy for a child to hold, is the ideal shape for a book, says Dick Bruna, the Dutch artist and illustrator who created his first story about Miffy the rabbit nearly 50 years ago. And the square, in the form of a television, is also the format for one of Miffy's recent incarnations: stop-motion animation.

title: The Pizza Parlor Prodigy
description: ACCLAIMED cello soloists rarely come through Jackson, and when they do, they almost never perform at Soulshine Pizza. But a few months ago, on a small stage close to the counter, Matt Haimovitz sat with his 18th-century Venetian cello, pouring his rich, silken tone into the restaurant. The audience had not yet arrived, and Mr. Haimovitz was serenely warming up with solo Bach. The music was transporting, and one could almost forget the surroundings -- until the bartender burst in with news that the local rugby team was streaking nearby and that a brawl might be imminent.

title: Other Voices: Will the Paper of Record Please Stand Up
description: To deflect honest criticism of The New York Times's recent journalistic failure to be comprehensive, especially in the run-up to the Iraq war, you use one of the oldest tricks in the debater's book: exaggerate the opponent's position until it becomes ridiculous.

title: Corrections
description: Picture credits were reversed last Sunday with the continuation of an article about Clonie Gowen, a professional poker player. The large photograph showing her with a smile at a round table was by Jim Wilson of The New York Times. The small one in which she wore a serious expression was by Eric Jamison for The Times.

title: Page Two: April 25-May 1; Specter Squeaks By
description: Senator Arlen Specter, the four-term Republican from Pennsylvania, won a narrow 16,000-vote primary victory over Representative Patrick J. Toomey. Mr. Toomey, supported by anti-tax and anti-abortion activists from across the country, had attacked Mr. Specter as a liberal obstacle to conservative goals. But Mr. Specter had the backing of President Bush and Pennsylvania's conservative junior senator, Rick Santorum. Mr. Specter now faces the Democrat Joseph Hoeffel in the general election. James Dao

title: The Nose Knows
description: If there's no accounting for taste, it's true, too, that tastes develop and mature as we grow. Perfumes are no different from wine and music in that respect; it's impossible to fully appreciate a scent of magnificent complexity like Sisley's Eau du Soir when you're 12. The virtuosity of early Louis Armstrong will elude you, as will the subtle coffee, spicy oak and plummy nuances of a '99 Valderiz Ribera del Duero red. Part of the fun of growing up is figuring out what's wheat and what's chaff, why it's classier to wear Opium than to smoke it. As evolution hurls us from Etch A Sketch to Frank Auerbach, we find that education isn't only a matter of degree. There are auxiliary lessons in manners, dress and connoisseurship; if you think carnations from the corner deli are really, really special, you've got a ways to go.

title: The Sideman Is the Star: Percy Heath's New CD
description: HE has made hundreds of albums, but always as a sideman. Finally, the jazz bassist Percy Heath, who turned 81 on Friday, has stepped out front and center, headlining a new CD, ''A Love Song.''

title: The Universe at the Tip of His Ballpoint Pen
description: THE stars that shine brightest in Malibu are not the celebrities dotting the beachfront properties but the celestial bodies parading nightly over Russell Crotty's observatory high on a cliff above the Pacific. Since moving to this breathtaking spot 12 years ago (he and his wife were facing eviction from their downtown Los Angeles apartment when they heard that this 130-acre ranch house needed caretakers), Mr. Crotty has re-engaged with his childhood passion for astronomy. It has become the subject of meticulous ballpoint pen drawings in handmade books as large as 5 by 10 feet and on globes that hover at eye level in beautiful minimalist installations.

title: Assessing Lieutenant Rieckhoff
description: Lt. Paul Rieckhoff marched into the political picture this weekend with a tough assessment of Iraq based on his personal experiences there and encountered some criticism himself.

description: HORRIFIC SCENES FROM ABU GHRAIB International outrage erupted with the circulation of photographs of American soldiers laughing as they forced naked Iraqi detainees into humiliating positions.

title: All-Weather Attire
description: Spring and summer showers -- can wreak havoc on a suit, rendering jackets shapeless and turning trousers into a network of wrinkles. In an attempt to outsmart Mother Nature, Paul Stuart has created its first water-resistant men's suits. Made in shirt-weight cotton or in four-season wool, the suits are treated with a fluorocarbon spray that diverts water off the broadest shoulders. The price of dryness is $1,100 to $1,300 at Paul Stuart stores.

title: When Nonresident Hires Benefit Nassau
description: Several people quoted in ''Nassau Increases Nonresident Hires'' [April 25] suggested that there is something wrong with the idea of Nassau County hiring nonresidents when they are exceptionally qualified and when no local candidate with similar experience is available. As the county comptroller, I would argue that this is preferable to the practice of previous county administrations of hiring residents when they are unqualified but carry the right party affiliation.

title: Speaking No Evil Of Computer Associates
description: IN September 1997, Peter Goldsmith, the former economic development director of the Long Island Association, was planning the first meeting of a fledging organization, the Long Island Software and Technology Network, and was trying to figure out where to hold it. title: Celebrations of a New, Expanded Europe Are Clouded by Old Fears of Immigration
description: A celebration of fireworks, light shows, church bells and dancing rolled across Europe on Friday night toward a culminating ceremony on Saturday in the Irish capital, where the 15 nations of the European Union welcomed the largest expansion of its borders ever by taking in eight former Communist states of Eastern Europe and two Mediterranean countries.

title: Designing A Brighter Future for The Gap
description: IN a Chelsea nightclub, the lights were low, the music was pulsing and beautiful waiters with snug-fitting black pants were tempting the bored-looking wall-to-wall guests with trays of manhattans. It seemed, in other words, just like any other big-name designer's fashion show, only it wasn't. This was the Gap.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Judy Greer; Funny Girl
description: I'M always a bridesmaid, never a bride,'' Judy Greer said, slumping on the table in mock frustration. It was girls' night out at Cha Cha Cha, a gritty pan-Caribbean restaurant in Silverlake, and the subject at hand was not this 29-year-old comedian's love life (though that would come, too), but her career. ''I've played a lot of best-friend roles; I'm really good at it,'' she said, her eyebrows arching for emphasis.

title: Why Were Doctors Afraid to Treat Rebecca McLester?
description: Only in the United States could people buy a wild pet with an exotic disease, expect the medical community to swing into immediate, superior and expensive action and then complain that their child is left with a fear of doctors and hospitals. Those parents ought to replace the child's fear with gratitude by reminding Rebecca every day that the doctors and nurses risked their lives to save her life.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-04; God's Country
description: I remember my own family's Great Awakening back in the Jesus-haunted 1970's, when President Carter was advertising his piety and ''Godspell'' and ''Up With People'' were packing concert halls. In the same way that it does now, three decades later, religion seemed to be everywhere back then -- except in our house. We were secular suburbanites, prone to all of the usual middle-class miseries, and when one of us felt particularly low, we called a doctor, not a priest. But then one day two missionaries came knocking, and everything changed. They were Mormons, two crewcut, fresh-faced boys weighed down with books that they promised would save our souls -- souls that we weren't even certain we possessed. Reading the books enlightened us, however; we converted to Mormonism a few months later. And it worked -- for a time. The diffuse domestic gloom that had mysteriously settled on our home suddenly lifted. We let the sunshine in.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-04: Consumed; Unstained Masses
description: Jonathan Levine calls himself ''an aesthetic dentist.'' He has been in the business for 22 years, specializing in prosthodontics, which is the restoration and replacement of teeth. Over time, working in New York City, he gradually built up a list of famous clients; he is, in fact, what could be called ''a celebrity dentist,'' the kind who is quoted about Sarah Jessica Parker's teeth in USA Today. It was for such people, who basically look good for a living, that he began noodling around a few years ago with a method for portable tooth-whitening.

title: Transforming Life's Debris
description: ''Reduce/Reuse/Re-examine'' at Glyndor Gallery at Wave Hill is essentially a show about recycling, but most pieces in it don't seem especially civic-minded despite the political-sounding title. Differing from traditional Dada, the concentration is on the found object as revered and transformed.

title: Last of the True Believers
description: MOST New Yorkers, Deirdre Griswold concedes with a smile, probably think Marxism is, as she puts it, ''finished.'' It's enough to make an aging Socialist revolutionary chuckle.

description: THE MYTH OF MORAL JUSTICE

title: Low-Rise Resort Opens on Antigua
description: At Carlisle Bay, a resort on Antigua that opened in late December, the two- and three-story buildings are strung out along the beach, allowing it to accommodate nearly 200 guests while still feeling intimate. The furnishings of the 88 studio and three-bedroom suites, in neutral tones, are more urban than island, a nod to One Aldwych, its sister hotel in London. Along with a fitness center, a library and espresso makers in the rooms, there are cribs, high chairs, sand toys and baby sitters available.

title: Budapest Chefs Venture Beyond Paprika and Goulash
description: BUDAPEST'S Central Market is a vast building in the center of town not far from the banks of the Danube. As animated as any market in France or Spain, its stands display all sorts of fruit and vegetables, poultry, fish and, particularly, embroidered linen, sausages and paprika in every stage, from fresh to dried to powdered. On a recent visit, trestle tables were covered with fresh morels and bunched branches of pussy willow. The scene felt unchanged, from time immemorial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NIEMEYER, JOHN H.
description: NIEMEYER--John H., 95, died April 19 in the Florida Keys. Born in Scranton, PA; graduated from Hamilton College, Clinton NY, 1930; taught at Harley School, Rochester, NY 1934-46; Headmaster, Oak Lane Country Day School, Philadelphia, 1946-55; President, Bank Street College of Education, NYC, 1956-73. Honorary Doctorate from Bank St., 1990. Consultant and educational researcher into his 80's. title: As the Season Turns
description: IT'S May, and the shore is gearing up for another summer season. The signs are everywhere, from the tractors clearing winter flotsam off the beach to the planters full of pansies on the steps of B&B's. Those of us who live here year round watch all this activity with a mixture of excitement and dread -- sort of like the moment before you're caught, in a game of hide and seek.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-04: Page Turner; 'There is nothing melodramatic, let alone operatic, in her presentation . . . but her quietness is its own kind of charisma.'
description: There was a time, not long ago, when Italian movies -- and Italian movie stars -- arrived on our shores with pleasing regularity. That country's great actresses, in particular -- Anna Magnani, Monica Vitti, Claudia Cardinale, Sophia Loren, to commence a list that easily could fill this page - became international icons of Mediterranean womanhood, vivid embodiments of earthy sensuality, maternal passion, histrionic suffering and volcanic capriciousness. But since the 1970's, Italian cinema has turned inward, toward quiet domestic drama and solemn political inquiry, and it has, with the exception of the occasional sentimental crowd-pleaser (''Il Postino,'' for instance), slipped out of fashion.

title: Abigail Foster, Christopher Dunnigan
description: Abigail Karen Foster, the daughter of Paula S. Foster of Manhattan and James J. Foster of Boston, was married yesterday to Christopher John Dunnigan, a son of Linda M. description: What you expect at Harborview Terrace Houses, a public housing project for the old and disabled at 530 West 55th Street, are small moments in slow motion. A willowy woman equipped with a cane totters home with a small bag of frozen meals and a gossip magazine. A visiting attendant watches betrayal on the soaps with a woman in a wheelchair. At the senior center, two men work at a measured game of pool, a whoop rising as the nine ball dives into the corner pocket.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column of this section on Dec. 15, 2002, about the America's Cup, credited it erroneously with a precedent. It is the world's oldest sailing trophy, first awarded in 1851, but not ''the oldest trophy in sport.'' The Scorton Silver Arrow is considered the oldest, awarded annually in an English archery tournament since 1673. (The error also occurred in sports articles on Jan. 10, 2003; Dec. 22, 2002; May 10, 1992; Dec. 25, 1983; Sept. 27, 1983; Sept. 25, 1983; June 12, 1983; and Jan. 16, 1983; as well as editorials on May 19, 1992, and Jan. 21, 1987; also a Travel article on Sept. 4, 1983, and the Saturday News Quiz on June 18, 1983.) In their understanding, I found the encouragement, strength and hope that I needed to fight back to recovery.

title: Three Generations of Advice From Mothers to Daughters
description: Mary loves reciting the names of Franklin D. Roosevelt's cabinet members (this is Chicago, 1939) and has aspirations to be an artist, but she isn't much help in the kitchen. (Why can't the girl chop gefilte fish properly?) Her mother, Bessie (Anita Keal), from the old country, lives to give advice. "There are no girl artists," she tells Mary (Suzanne Toren). Also: Never leave the house with a button missing. Stay away from that girl whose parents are Communists. And don't even think about getting an education yourself; marry a man who has one.

title: Getting Their Math in Macaroni, and Their Spelling in Spinach

title: New Orleans
description: New Orleans is a town of nicknames: the City of Sin, the City That Care Forgot, the Big Easy. Waiting for a bus on Basin Street, I asked a woman if New Orleans's good-time reputation was deserved. ''If you got five people waitin' in line,'' she smiled, ''you likely to have a party.''

title: Why Were Doctors Afraid to Treat Rebecca McLester?
description: High praise should go to Linda Wildey, Kathleen Kelly, Michael and Stephanie Anderson and the other nurses and doctors who treated a child with monkeypox, despite risk to themselves and their families (Gretchen Reynolds, April 18). There might be many more doctors like Anderson and Kelly if the medical-school admission process focused more on psychological fitness and human (and humane) values instead of grades received in calculus and organic chemistry.

title: The World; How Qaddafi Became The Toast of Brussels
description: IT may defy a sense of fairness, but a time comes when the vow never to forgive or forget a terrorist crime is put aside to make a diplomatic bargain. How does that happen? The morphing of the Pan Am 103 case is instructive.

title: Halliburton-by-the-Sea
description: DAVID HALLIBURTON JR. twirled the steering wheel of his 1969 Ford Bronco as it bounded along a road with potholes the size of wild pigs. Mexican music blared from a tinny speaker as the Bronco, its engine spitting, came to rest on an overlook above a glistening coral and sand beach. ''The miraculous lower Sonora desert, the majestic Sea of Corts -- I wish people would think of this when they heard my family's name,'' Mr. Halliburton said, ''not Dick Cheney and his evil cronies.''

title: Azeri Loses

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TELSON, HOWARD
description: TELSON--Howard. On April 5, 2004 from cancer at age 49. Dr. Telson of New York City obtained his B.A. at Princeton and his M.D. at Yale. He was a Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at NYU School of Medicine where he trained as a psychiatrist and was on the faculty for 20 years. He developed several innovative programs at Bellevue Hospital that improved the mental health system, including the New York State outpatient commitment pilot program at Bellevue Hospital that was expanded statewide by Kendra's Law. He educated the nation about this program through interviews with many leading newspapers and appearances on CNN and ''60 Minutes''. Dr. Telson contributed to the medical and legal literature on forensic psychiatry, the history of psychiatry and the treatment of the homeless mentally ill. He was a Distinguished Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and served on the board of directors of the National Alliance of the Mentally Ill (NAMI) of NYC Metro. Dr. Telson's gift for healing improved the lives of innumerable patients. His broad knowledge of history, geography, politics, literature, architecture and art, and extensive world travels, informed his practice of psychiatry enriching countless psychiatrists, case managers and other mental health professionals whom he taught. All those who knew him were touched by his warmth and the profound humanity of his relationship with others. Dr. Telson is survived by his partner, Anand Pandya, M.D., his sister, Lynne Barsky, brother-inlaw, Michael Barsky, and nieces, Danielle and Sara. Donations can be made in his name to NAMI (www.nami. org). A memorial service will be held on Saturday May 8 at 11 A.M. at Farkas Auditorium, NYU Medical Center, 450 First Avenue near 30th Street in Manhattan.

title: Now Can We Talk About Health Care?
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton (April 18) is exactly right to insist that the American health care system must place the needs of the individual -- not the needs of the provider, payer or others -- at the very center of its concerns. Moreover, I could not agree more that a great place to start is by adopting a personal health record for every American that is owned and controlled by the individual. As we have seen in other parts of the economy, when individual Americans are empowered with good information and freedom to choose, they drive an astonishing level of innovation, technological and otherwise, that delivers increasingly better results at an increasingly lower cost. We should not be surprised, then, that we are starting to see this same pattern occur in health care. New information-age health improvements are allowing individuals to be better informed about their own health and how to be informed consumers of health services, and are thereby saving lives and saving money. We need to accelerate these trends so that all Americans can benefit from improved health and lower costs.

title: Is Neil LaBute Getting . . . Nice?
description: THE most recent work by Neil LaBute to appear in New York was a reading in March of five one-act plays, titled ''Autobahn'' and set in cars, that treated dark themes with uncharacteristic gentleness and humor. Foster parents are accused of impropriety by their ward; a boy is kidnapped by an older man; a graduate student struggles to break up with his putative stalker. And yet the audience laughed often. Mr. LaBute's last fully staged play, ''The Mercy Seat,'' set in Manhattan on the day after Sept. 11, 2001, is an unsparing drama about a man and a woman at the end of an affair, struggling to make a no-win moral decision. For the first time, a woman in a LaBute play got to vent at the man at length, even if she didn't get what she wanted.

title: BEYOND GLORY
description: ''BEYOND GLORY,'' adapted from Larry Smith's oral history of the same name (published by W. W. Norton), is the rare play that summons up the actual experience of fighting in a war. Most plays that touch on the subject -- the current ''Embedded,'' ''Mrs. Farnsworth'' -- are written from the perspective of a critic. But this solo docudrama features heroic stories from seven American veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam, all of whom have won the Medal of Honor. The actor Stephen Lang adapted the book and performs the monologues through May 31 in the theater of the Women in Military Service for America Memorial at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia. Among those portrayed are the former vice presidential candidate James B. Stockdale and Vernon J. Baker, an African-American soldier who, in the following excerpt, describes training and combat in World War II.

title: The German Question
description: It's not often that world leaders are bluntly contradicted in public by other world leaders, but that is what happened at the Bayerischer Hof, Munich's grand 19th-century hotel, where a bit over a year ago, in what came to be an almost epochal event in Germany, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld and Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, had a sort of clash of civilizations over the war in Iraq. The setting was the 2003 Munich Conference on Security Policy, an annual event attended by a who's who of European and American diplomacy, business and politics. At the time, Rumsfeld was at the height of his European unpopularity, thanks to his statements likening Germany to Libya and Cuba in their nonsupport of what was then the imminent Iraq war and his declaration that ''Old Europe'' was irrelevant. As Rumsfeld spoke, demonstrators led by Munich's mayor gathered on the snowy streets of the city.

title: Prince at 45: An R & B Recidivist
description: PRINCE -- Prince is feeling his age, 45, on ''Musicology'' (NPG/Columbia). The video for the title song (at www.mtv.com) is nostalgic for 45-r.p.m. singles, and in it Prince sings a fogy's credo: ''Don't you miss the feeling music gave you back in the day?'' He has given up trying to cross the hip-hop divide, and he spends much of the album skillfully rewriting his old songs. But on ''Life 'o' the Party'' he comes up with a brittle rhythm track to rival Timbaland. Meanwhile, who among his successors has both the political will to examine post-9/11 prejudice (in ''Cinnamon Girl'') and the lascivious sense of humor for songs like the premarital come-on ''On the Couch''? Yes, OutKast.

Not any old name, of course, but that of Cervantes, Spain s greatest writer who, like his contemporary Shakespeare, has bequeathed words of wisdom for every occasion. Little wonder, then, that when Spain's new prime minister, Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, recently opened a session in Parliament, he and his opponents fenced with Cervantes phrases. To this day, it seems, the imaginary world that Cervantes created in The Ingenious Knight Don Quixote of La Mancha is where Spaniards still try to work out who they are.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, BEN
description: ROSS--Ben. Died April 24 from complications of pneumonia. Photographer/gunner in the 8th Air Force Combat Camera Unit, WWII. Specialized in aviation photography and later as a free-lance photojournalist with work appearing in many books and magazines, including Look, Parade, People and Stern. His work is in many museums including The National Portrait Gallery/Smithsonian, International Center of Photography, The Brooklyn Museum, The John Lennon Museum, Tokyo, The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, Cleveland, and numerous private collections. In November 2000 the American Society of Media Photographers awarded Ross a Lifetime Achievement Award and in November 2002 the Photographic Administrative Inc. awarded him its Lifetime Achievement Award. During his 60 year career, he photographed many celebrities but he was most proud of his photojournalism work. Fear was not in his vocabulary. Memorial service at a later date.

title: ONE OF A KIND: TAHITi; Maison James Norman Hall
description: About three miles outside Papeete, the capital of French Polynesia, is a modest museum dedicated to the memory of a modest man: James Norman Hall. La Maison James Norman Hall is well worth a brief stop on your way to Point Venus or Matavai Bay, where Captain Bligh first anchored the Bounty in 1788, not only because of what you'll learn about the extraordinary life of a dashing, adventurous and courageous man, but also because the museum is testimony to what a few devoted family members -- ancestor worshipers, almost -- can accomplish in the face of bureaucratic ennui and political opposition.

description: When I first stepped into Mac's West Indian restaurant, I closed my eyes, listened to the chatter, smelled the food and nearly felt the breeze on my face.

description: Three of New York's most powerful unions -- the police, the firefighters and the teachers -- argued vigorously last week that the modest raises contained in District Council 37's deal with the city should in no way set a pattern for their members.

title: Unnatural Selection
description: Among all life forms, man alone has aspirations to mutate into something higher. Ancient myths -- be they Greek or Inuit -- swarm with demigods who are smarter, swifter, wiser and a lot better-looking than the dreamers who dreamed them. After Darwin published ''Origin of Species,'' and primeval skulls with prognathous jaws and small brainpans came to be identified as ancestors of man, the idea took hold that Homo sapiens was just one evolutionary stage toward an even brainier superhuman. In the century since Darwin brought forth his theory, even our closest relatives, the great apes, would be appalled by how the products of our highest civilization can behave with such savagery, and only the congenitally ignorant would argue that man has made any progress at all toward becoming a more intelligent, more compassionate animal.

title: Setting the Record Straight
description: In his March 14 column, Daniel Okrent used a quote from me to suggest that I was unwilling to give a reporter more time to check her facts ''because we're a newspaper.'' In fact, when -- over the course of a half-hour conversation -- he asked why we had not held the story for another day, I gave him three reasons. I said it was because the reporter said she had confirmed the story and the facts were not in doubt, because we thought it was competitive (other newspapers were also working on it) and ''because we're a newspaper.'' In omitting two of the three reasons, Mr. Okrent made it look as if I was endorsing slipshod journalism. It was an example of what he himself has railed against -- the partial quote.

title: Obsessed!
description: BY all accounts, the University Food Market at 115th Street and Broadway was hardly an epicurean paradise. The aisles were cramped and overcrowded, the Latina cashiers sassy. As for the stock, one regular described the produce as ''competent, not exciting,'' and though the organic meats were notable, the freezers occasionally short-circuited, leaving display cases empty and shoppers unsettled.

title: Democrats Tarred By the Same Brush
description: DEMOCRATS in Suffolk County struggled last week to distance themselves from corruption charges filed against a high-ranking Democratic Party official and a former Democratic county legislator, both of them former advisers to the county executive, Steve Levy.

title: Trenton's Fighting Words
description: ''AND now, a word from our sponsor.'' Hail the phrase that launched a thousand trademarks, from Continental Airlines to PNC Bank, and landed them on the great stadiums and stages of New Jersey. This week, a new candidate for corporate sponsorship surfaced from an unlikely source: the waters of the Delaware.

title: Page Two: April 25-May 1; Rising Casualties, One Falling Poll
description: After the bloodiest month in Iraq for American troops since the invasion more than a year ago, public support for the war has diminished and President Bush's approval rating has fallen, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The findings suggested that bad news from the front was beginning to alter public perceptions of the conflict and Mr. Bush's leadership. Only 33 percent of respondents said the war was worth the loss of life and the other costs, down from 44 percent in December. Fifty-eight percent said the war was not worth it, up from 49 percent in December.

title: Saving Lives In the Skies
description: MEDICAL emergencies may not be the first worry on an airline passenger's mind, but illness is a bigger risk than a crash; each year, more than 100 people are stricken for some health reason while flying on major American carriers, and die in flight or soon after, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. In most years that dwarfs the number killed in commercial airline crashes; in 2003, 19 passengers and 2 pilots died in an airliner crash, and the year before there were no passenger fatalities.

title: Page Two: April 25-May 1; Old Boys Upbraid Blair
description: Fifty-two retired British diplomats staged a revolt last week against Prime Minister Tony Blair over his Middle East policies. Former ambassadors to Israel, Egypt, Iraq and other points in the region criticized the failure of planning for a postwar Iraq, the excessive use of firepower in civilian areas and what they regard as the indulgence of Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, in his unilateral attempt to deal with the Palestinians.

They do not have anyone facing the prospect of life in prison and they do not have two future Hall of Famers who must rue the day they forsook millions of dollars for a season of dysfunction.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: NEW YORK BY SEA -- So it's not the Queen Mary 2. But the New York Water Taxi is much cheaper, especially with its new Two-Day Hop On/Hop Off Pass. For $15 a person -- which was the same price for the one-day pass this replaces -- you get unlimited rides over two consecutive days. The 54-foot catamarans, which are handicapped-accessible and have climate-controlled cabins, stop at various points around Manhattan and in Brooklyn and New Jersey. They can accommodate up to 74 passengers on two decks and can go up to 28 miles an hour, faster than a cab in a traffic jam. For information, call up www.nywatertaxi.com.

title: Holy Deadlock On the East End
description: CONSIDERING their product, not to mention their large tasting rooms in scenic settings, wineries are places where it seems as if a party could break out any minute. But as East End wine producers exploit that promise of merriment and increase their profits by holding wedding receptions, they are running into opposition from the catering halls, the traditional sites for such big-blowout festivities.

description: The Federal Communications Commission's well-publicized post-Super Bowl campaign against broadcaster ''indecency'' is misplaced, if not downright comical. While the F.C.C. is fining radio ''shock jocks'' for using language milder than what can be heard in most high-school parking lots, Americans can see graphic pornography on the Internet. It's time to consider a more radical approach to censoring pornography.

Widow of George Woloch (died 1964) and mother of George Michael Woloch (Mary C. Moffat) of Montreal. She was an enthusiastic Manhattan resident for almost 55 years and lived at the DeWitt Nursing Home for the last six. The family wishes to recognize the wonderful care given to her by her case manager and friend, Terry Woitach, and all of her team over the past six years, especially Kayla Thomas. The family also wishes to thank the DeWitt 16th Floor Staff for their patience and concern. There will be a memorial service 10 AM Monday, May 10, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. and interment with her husband later in Brooklyn. A contribution to the S.P.C.A. in remembrance may be made if desired.

title: Granada, Nicaragua: Its Fall And Rise
description: I'll start with this disclaimer: I love Nicaragua. I love the poetry of its pace, ox carts slowing traffic, shoeless boys playing baseball in vacant lots, men riding their lovers double on bicycles and the silhouettes of women reposed in doorways. I love its rum and cigars, rice and beans and green volcanoes towering over red-tile roofs and blue lakes. I even like the smell of horse manure and diesel exhaust, an occasional waft from an open sewer and broken sidewalks that force me to watch my step.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YOU may never see the bad stuff coming in Karen Moncrieff's intense, restrained, superbly acted BLUE CAR (2002). This is a drama about a teenage girl (Agnes Bruckner) suffocating at home, where her stressed, overscheduled divorced mother (Margaret Colin) rules. Then her little sister dies. Thank goodness there's a concerned, intelligent teacher (David Strathairn) who values her, especially her poetry talents, and takes time to work with her. But he gets too close. The hint should have been a line he writes on the blackboard: ''Do not believe that he who seeks to comfort you lives untroubled among the simple and quiet words that somehow do you good'' -- Tuesday at 2:30 p.m. on Starz.

title: Mary Beth Love, Michael Russom -- Featured in Vows, July 26, 1992
description: ''HAPPY families are all alike,'' Tolstoy wrote in ''Anna Karenina.'' In every way, Mary Beth Love and Michael Russom contradict that statement. When they married in July 1992, they were determined not to have a typical or unexamined marriage. It seems, 12 years later, that they have succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOMPERTZ, FRED
description: GOMPERTZ--Fred, 80, on April 29, 2004. Born in Germany, he escaped Nazi persecution and immigrated to New York in 1939. Under his professional name ''Mr. Fred'' he achieved recognition for his innovative fur fashion designs and frequently appeared in the media. His customers were a ''Who's Who'' of 1960's pop culturefashion models, politicians and actors. On September 11, 2001 he was trapped in his home across from the World Trade Center until being rescued by his son. Beloved father of Jeffrey and Ronald. grandfather of Minna. Previously married to Rita as well as Guojian. Uncle of Carole, Kenneth, Mark, Sheryl and Steven. Brother of Albert and the late Ralph.

description: Dawn April Urbont, a daughter of Rosalind and Jack Urbont of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Simeon Corman, a son of Judy and Avery Corman of New York. Cantor Ron A. Li-Paz officiated at Cicada, a Los Angeles restaurant.

title: 'Emma Brown'
description: We all seek an ideal in life. A pleasant fancy began to visit me in a certain year, that perhaps the number of human beings is few who do not find their quest at some era of life for some space more or less brief. I had certainly not found mine in youth, though the strong belief I held of its existence sufficed through all my brightest and freshest time to keep me hopeful. I had not found it in maturity. I was become resigned never to find it. I had lived certain dim years entirely tranquil and unexpectant. And now I was not sure but something was hovering around my hearth which pleased me wonderfully.

And this time, a mere hour after the final notes of each concert, fans can listen to the same performance all over again, thanks to a new distribution strategy that allows concertgoers to buy recordings of the event -- legal, band-sanctioned versions -- on the spot.

title: Unflappable New York, Wide-Eyed at Last
description: NEW Yorkers tend to pride themselves on their incapacity for astonishment. Don't let them fool you. This nil admirari pose is nothing more than that. This was proved last Sunday night when, by the thousands, New Yorkers who would not cross the street for a better look at P. Diddy crowded onto west-facing terraces and rooftops and playgrounds and parking lots and piers to watch two giant cruise ships, the Queen Elizabeth 2 and the Queen Mary 2, leave their Hudson River docks and sail off grandly into the sunset over Upper New York Bay, one after the other.

title: Into the Heart of Falluja
description: Movement to Contact. That was the name of the mission. And the moment we set off I knew it was dicey. It was 4 a.m. The sky was inky. I was outside Falluja, and 17 pumped-up marines were waiting for me in the back of a cargo truck. They were sitting on a pile of sandbags, bunched together, completely exposed. I squeezed into the middle. The truck lurched forward. The guys and their gear began to bounce around. I felt as if we were going on a hayride through a combat zone.

title: Lost Your Little Boy? We'll Make Another
description: WE might expect that a film about cloning people, especially a picture advertised as a horror movie and loaded with conventions of the genre, would directly demonize its subject. But in the new movie ''Godsend,'' the horrors do not arise from the biological dangers that have led responsible scientists and knowledgeable citizens to oppose human cloning. Horror flows instead from the malicious act of a diabolical doctor -- an act that, unlike cloning itself, lacks any significant scientific basis.

title: Amnesty Reports Sudan Fighting
description: CAIRO, May 1 (Reuters) - The human rights group Amnesty International said late Friday that fighting was persisting in western Sudan despite a cease-fire between the government and rebels, and that time was running out to avert a disaster among civilians before the rainy season.

title: Across the World, Images of Revolution
description: EVEN after a year of conflict, photographs and television footage of the Iraq war are spellbinding. Partly this is because of their subject -- the explosions, mob scenes and daily loss of life -- and partly it is because as viewers, we know that these photographers and news cameramen are documenting a revolution in progress. Their images reveal a country in the midst of radical social, cultural and political change, with all the attendant challenges.

title: Vengeance Is Ours, Says Hollywood
description: LAST weekend, the No. 1 movie in America was ''Man on Fire,'' a grisly and lugubrious action thriller in which Denzel Washington waged a one-man campaign of righteous payback against a diabolical gang of kidnappers in Mexico City. Joining Mr. Washington on the list of the top five money-makers (and separated from him only by the winsomely nonviolent Jennifer Garner in ''13 Going on 30'') were Tom Jane and Uma Thurman, the avenging heroes of ''The Punisher'' and ''Kill Bill Vol. 2.'' Mr. Jane's character, like Mr. Washington's, a former black-ops specialist for the United States government who struggles with a drinking problem, blows up half of Tampa, Fla., in his crusade against the baddies who wiped out his family. (That crime was itself an act of revenge for the accidental death of the chief villain's son.) In about the time it takes Mr. Washington's John Creasy to shoot, bludgeon and detonate a few dozen bad guys (two and a half hours, give or take), Ms. Thurman's Bride, showing impressive restraint, kills only two. But of course, if you add those loose ends to the legions of yakuza dispatched in a few minutes of ''Vol. 1,'' the Bride surely ranks as one of the most prolific onscreen practitioners of justifiable homicide in recent memory.
