title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, WARREN SANFORD
description: ADAMS--Warren Sanford, 2d. Was born September 4, 1910 in Cleveland, Ohio to Otis Howard Adams and Hermine Weis Adams, and raised in Framingham, Massa chusetts. He passed away peacefully at his home in Austin, Texas on Sunday, April 25, 2004. Mr. Adams was a loving father to his only child Cornelia Adams Foster and father-in-law to Mark Edward Foster, and a loving grandfather to Lucy Piper Foster and Warren Adams Foster. Mr. Adams lived in New York City for most of his adult life prior to retiring in 1976 from CPC International Inc. (formerly Corn Products Co.) for which he served as chief general counsel. In 1986, he moved to Austin, Texas. At the age of 15, Mr. Adams entered Princeton University where his nickname was ''Babe.'' He was a star ice hockey player on a stellar team in Princeton history and, but for a broken collarbone suffered in a practice, would have played on a U.S. Olympic team. He also played on the football team at Princeton. After graduating in 1930, he went on to Harvard Law School, graduating in 1934. In 1935, he joined the New York bar and was in private practice in New York City until 1940. In 1941, he received a J.S.D. from New York University. With the onset of World War II, he went to Washington, D.C. to serve in the War Production Board and later enlisted in the Marine Corps. He fought in the Pacific between 1942 and 1946, and achieved the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. Returning to New York in 1946, he went to work for Corn Products Co. For many years he served on the board of the Washington Square Fund and was a trustee of the Whitehall Foundation, Inc. He was also a member of the American Bar Association, The Pilgrims of the United States, The English Speaking Union, The Racquet and Tennis Club (NYC), the Metropolitan Opera Club of which he was a past president, the Princeton Club, Colonial (Princeton), Ekwanok Golf Club (Vermont), American Society of the Order of St. John (Knight), Royal and Ancient Golf Club (Scotland), Boodles (London), and the Union Club (NYC). He was a lifelong golfer and lover of opera. He survived four wives, including Eve Madsen Adams (medical illustrator and mother of Cornelia), Adele Thompson Adams, and Romaine Clinton Adams. (He was divorved from a first wife prior to World War II.) For most of his life he was a summer resident of a part of the New Hampshire coast called Little Boar's Head. In later years he was a summer resident of Manchester, Vermont, and, during his marriage to Romaine Adams, of Newport, Rhode Island. His family particularly wants to thank Ken Luebke and caregivers who became part of his life following a car accident in 2000; James Mendiola, Mike Arnold, Tigh Walters, and Alfredo Ruiz. A memorial service will be held in Austin, Texas at 11:00 AM on Monday, May 3, 2004 at St. Francis Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to Hospice Austin, 4107 Spicewood Springs Rd., Austin, TX 78759. A memorial service in New York is pending.

title: THE HAPPY MARILYN
description: You have never seen her like this before. Marilyn Monroe jumping up and down on the beach and splashing through the surf like a little girl. Marilyn devouring hot dogs at a street stand in Manhattan and sharing a Coke with her husband, Arthur Miller. Marilyn being so much in love she couldn't care less about these few extra pounds on her hips. More than 50 previously unpublished photos of her are on display for the first time at the chic Cafe Einstein in Berlin, just a few blocks east of the Brandenburg Gate. All the photos in the exhibition, ''Marilyn -- The New York Years,'' were taken from 1954 to 1957 by a favorite photographer, Sam Shaw, who also shot the famous ''Seven Year Itch'' picture, featuring her with a white dress blown upward by a subway ventilator draft. ''I didn't want to get into this clich of the depressive blonde again,'' said Thomas Lardon, who organized the exhibition and also published a book of the same title with 160 mostly unknown pictures of Monroe. ''Instead I wanted to show a very confident and strong woman who is simply at peace with herself.'' Until 1999, the year Shaw died, the pictures were stocked in a huge archive in New York. His son, Larry, found them and sold the rights to Mr. Lardon. The exhibition continues through May 31. KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHWATT, EDWARD A.
description: CHWATT--Edward A. On May 1, 2004. A powerful, loving, supportive and stable force in our lives was transformed by the sudden passing of our beloved husband, father, stepfather, brother, grandpa, uncle and friend. He was an adoring husband to Sara, whom he cherished. He was a fiercely devoted father to Mitchell, Sara, Jill, Eric, Nancy, Samantha and Jimm. Eddie was a loving brother and best friend to Robyn and Richard, with whom he shared an extraordinary and unbreakable bond. He delighted in spending time with his grandchildren Sammie, Justin, Corey, Nikki, Dana, Lauren, Kayla and Sierra, all of whom he adored. He loved his nieces and nephews Glenn, Lori, Suzy, Craig, Jaime and Evan. He prized his many friends with whom he shared priceless memories and strong ties. His love, energy, charisma, sense of humor and generosity touched many and as a result he enriched the world. He will continue to guide us, fill us with love and be an ongoing light in our lives. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, Wednesday, May 5, 2:30 p.m. Donations in his memory may be made to Congregation Schomre Israel, 18 Park Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603.

title: FRENCH AUTHOR TURNS FILM AUTEUR
description: Michel Houellebecq, the presiding enfant terrible of French literature, whose last two novels resulted in scandals, lawsuits and huge sales, has announced plans to direct a movie version of his next novel, provisionally called ''An Island.'' His publisher, ditions Fayard, said the novel would appear next year, while the movie will be produced by GMT Productions, which, like Fayard, is owned by the Lagardre Group. So far, of novels by Mr. Houellebecq (pronounced WELL-beck), left, only ''Whatever'' has been adapted for the screen. In an interview with Le Monde, Mr. Houellebecq, 46, who divides his time between Ireland and Spain, said that after completing his new novel he would write the screenplay for it. To direct a movie, he noted, would offer respite from the extreme solitude that accompanies writing a novel. He added that he also hoped to write a movie version of his last novel, ''Platform'' (Knopf), which, he said, would work better on the screen than ''The Elementary Particles'' (Knopf), the novel that made his name in France in 1999.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about executive compensation increases at Cablevision Systems referred incorrectly to the 2003 pay packages of Charles F. Dolan, the chairman, and his son James L. Dolan, the chief executive. (Dow Jones, which provided the article, transmitted a correction Friday evening, but The Times overlooked it.) According to a government filing, Charles Dolan received a salary and bonus of $6.4 million (not a pay package of about $12 million, excluding stock options). That compared with a salary of $1.6 million and no bonus a year earlier (not $2.2 million). James Dolan's salary and bonus totaled $4.4 million (not $16.4 million). That compared with a $1.6 million salary and no bonus a year earlier (not ''less than $2 million''). The article also referred incompletely to restricted stock granted to James Dolan. While he held restricted stock valued at $11.6 million, the majority of it consisted of previously held stock options that were exchanged in 2003.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Music Royalties At Issue
description: The European Commission warned 16 national collectors of music royalties on behalf of composers and lyricists from around Europe that an agreement they have with each other for online music distribution might violate European antitrust regulations. Under the agreement, broadcasters, including online music distributors, may buy the rights to play music only from the collection organization in its own country. The commission said the restriction might violate the European Union's antitrust rules because distributors cannot shop around for the best prices. The collection groups have 10 weeks to reply to the commission. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aide For Immigrant Affairs Quits

Ms. Bhojwani was appointed in April 2002 and was the city's first commissioner of immigrant affairs. In a prepared statement, Ms. Bhojwani said, ''In the past year, the administration has enacted groundbreaking policies that protect the rights of domestic workers, ensure the access of limited-English-proficient New Yorkers to city services, and enable immigrants to seek out services for which they are eligible without fear of being reported to federal immigration authorities.''

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Train Spills Fuel Into River

The train's two locomotives and five of its boxcars fell into the river, downstream from the city's tourist area, and five other rail cars fell onto a street below the elevated track. The authorities said the train, en route to Mexico from Houston, sideswiped another train that was traveling in the opposite direction. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Report On Ground Zero
description: A report on the exposure of workers and residents near ground zero to toxic dust and chemicals provided new details on health problems they face. The report, based on a study conducted by six research centers on behalf of federal and city government agencies, published in this month's issue of Environmental Health Perspectives, found that fragments of glass and pulverized cement, breathed first by firefighters and later by cleanup workers, had caused severe coughs and asthma. The report also said the exposure had increased the risk of mesothelioma, a type of cancer associated with inhaling asbestos. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHWATT, EDWARD A.
description: CHWATT--Edward A. Late Sunday afternoon I retrieved a phone message that started, ''I have bad news'' and the news was indeed very bad; not only had a valued client, but a friend, Ed Chwatt had suddenly died. The shock was profound. Ed is not a person one remotely associates with death. Being such a vital, energetic, humane and charming person, he belongs to that rare breed of individual that others refuse to acknowledge as mortal. On behalf of my accounting firm, H.J. Behrman and Company, LLP, as well as personally, my sincerest condolences are expressed to Ed Chwatt's wife, Sara; his children, Mitchell, Eric, Jill and Samantha; his brother, Richard; his grandchildren and the entire Chwatt family as well his extended business family and the staff at Chwatt Associates. From a business standpoint, Ed was fair, honorable and appreciative, a stand-up Brooklyn guy. His loss, however, is personally felt beyond a business relationship. After the initial disbelief, my feelings were automatically transformed to tears. My body was instinctively saying without words how I felt about Ed Chwatt. Once Ed suggested I consider what he had done by explaining to my elderly, infirm parents how much I loved them and appreciated what they had done for me. I told him my parents already intuitively understood how grateful I am. Ed responded, of course they do, but tell them anyway. They'll be glad you did and so will you. In that regard, I hope Ed intuitively understood that he was a respected friend of mine. Goodbye, friend. Neal Klinger

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 28 about Isaac Kleinerman, a producer and editor of television documentaries, misstated his role in editing ''Victory at Sea,'' as did a correction in this space on April 2. Mr. Kleinerman edited the original multipart series as well as a two-hour version for release to movie theaters. A later 90-minute condensation for television was edited by Silvio D'Alisera. The obituary also referred incompletely to Mr. Kleinerman's Emmy Awards. There were two -- in 1961, for ''The Twentieth Century,'' and in 1968, for ''The 21st Century.'' title: Technology Briefing | Software: Red Hat Expected To Disclose Desktop Plans
description: Red Hat, the leading seller of open-source software, was expected to outline today a push into the global market for desktop systems, an area where the grass-roots Linux software has so far failed to make a dent against Microsoft. Red Hat is the largest repackager and seller of the open-source Linux system, which has a growing following among companies and government agencies that want an alternative to Microsoft's dominant Windows software. But Linux is mostly used for heavy-duty back-office computers and has been criticized as being too complicated for the average personal computer user. Red Hat's announcement, scheduled to be made in London, was expected to include details of a trial that Red Hat has been conducting with the German insurance company LVM. The German company is evaluating whether to install 8,400 Linux-based desktop systems, said Red Hat's chief executive, Matthew J. Szulik. He said Red Hat would also outline plans with Wind River Systems, a California developer of software and hardware, to help corporate customers of Linux systems to integrate wireless devices. title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Raises 2nd-Quarter Profit Forecast
description: Adobe Systems, the maker of graphic design software, increased second-quarter profit and sales forecasts yesterday because of better-than-expected sales of products including its Acrobat document-processing programs. Profit in the quarter ending June 4 will be 39 cents to 44 cents a share on sales of $390 million to $410 million, Adobe said in a statement. The company had estimated as much as 39 cents a share in profit and as much as $385 million in sales. Sales are rising because of Adobe's strategy of selling Acrobat to large businesses, analysts have said. The Intelligent Document business, which includes Acrobat, produces more than 30 percent of Adobe's sales and has been the fastest-growing part of the company, which is based in San Jose, Calif. Adobe shares rose $2.50, or 6 percent, to $44. Adobe also said it had bought Q-Link Technologies Inc., a closely held business-software maker in Tampa, Fla., for undisclosed terms. Q-Link's technology lets companies create programs to track documents throughout their businesses. Its programs will be merged into Adobe's Intelligent Document product. title: Corrections

The obituary also referred incompletely to Mr. Kleinerman's Emmy Awards. There were two -- in 1961, for ''The Twentieth Century,'' and in 1968, for ''The 21st Century.'' title: National Briefing | Washington: Anti-Muslim Incidents Increase
description: Reports of bias incidents against Muslims increased by about 70 percent in the United States last year, according to a study by the Council on American-Islamic Relations, an advocacy group in Washington. The study showed that Muslims had reported 1,019 incidents of harassment, violence and discriminatory treatment in 2003, up from 602 in 2002. In many cases, the report said, complainants contended that laws were applied to them unfairly or they had been singled out by local and federal law enforcement authorities because of their religion or ethnicity. Among reasons for mistreatment, the report said, was ''a lingering atmosphere'' of fear since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. John Files (NYT)

title: MEMO PAD
description: SUMMER AIRPORT CROWDING PREDICTED -- Along with the rebound in world airline traffic, domestic traffic is showing steady growth this year. One consequence could be longer airport security lines this summer as vacationers add to the traffic and not enough screeners are on duty to expedite lines after layoffs by the Transportation Security Administration. ''The good news is we're coming back to pre-9/11 levels,'' said James C. May, the president of the Air Transport Association. ''This summer, we're looking at loads of roughly 65 million passengers a month for a sustained time,'' he said. ''But we're also looking at 6,000 fewer screeners. We're worried to death about lines and the usual hassle factor concerns.'' He said his group, the airline industry's main trade organization, was speaking with T.S.A. officials to try to ''find ways to expedite the process.''

title: An Innkeeper Falls for a Tenor
description: Throughout the 20th century, opera composers wrestled with ways of bringing their venerable art form into the modern age. Some set modern stories to contemporary music (Strauss's 'Intermezzo'). Some wrote avant-garde departures that shook off narrative conventions altogether (Stockhausen's 'Licht' cycle). And some produced throwbacks, vintage libretti set to contemporary, basically tonal music: Roberto Gerhard's 'The Duenna,' set to Richard Sheridan's play, or Bohuslav Martinu's 'Mirandolina,' a setting of a play by Carlo Goldoni.

Last month, the police found a huge arms cache under a house in a Rio slum. The arsenal belonged to a drug-trafficking gang, and investigators are trying to determine whether the weapons were stolen from the military.   (Agence France-Presse)

title: 1904:Charging With Bayonets : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: SEOUL: The evening of April 30 found a pontoon bridge across the Yalu completed by Japanese engineers and covered by infantry previously landed on the Manchurian bank. Between daybreak and seven o'clock yesterday [May 2] the Russian artillery posted on the heights north-west of Kiu-Lien-Cheng was silenced by the combined fire of the Japanese artillery and river gunboats. When the main body of the 1st Army Corps crossed the bridge to the Manchurian bank, it charged the heights at the point of the bayonet, capturing the fortifications and driving the enemy from its position. The Russians were in full retreat, and the Japanese in complete possession of Kui-Lien-Chang and the surrounding heights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, JANE E.
description: BROWN--Jane E. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System mourns the passing of Jane E. Brown, a devoted supporter of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset who inspired her husband, Dayton Brown Sr. to become a member of the Board of Trustees, where he served with distinction until his death in 1978. Mrs. Brown was an associate trustee and her son, Dayton T. Brown Jr., is a current member of the North Shore-LIJ Health System Board of Trustees. Mrs. Brown was the first volunteer at North Shore Hospital when it opened in 1953. She served in the Auxiliary for over 35 years. Through the generosity of Jane and Dayton Brown Jr., The Jane and Dayton Brown Sr. Laboratory for Viral Diseases was founded at the hospital, specifically to advance our knowledge of and programs for AIDS. In addition, Mrs. Brown and her son established the endowment for the Jane and Dayton T. Brown Professorship in Medicine (Infectious Disease) at North Shore University Hospital. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mrs. Brown's family. She will be greatly missed. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman Michael Dowling President & CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

As he sinks onto a couch, he sits strategically so he can hear out of his good ear. He is eager to talk, his hands squeezed together. And it does not take long to realize that he is quite shy.

title: Golden Towers
description: Gov. George Pataki is circling in on a $1 billion-plus contract -- the largest technology contract in state history -- to build communications towers across the state. No one doubts the need for good communications in an emergency. Nevertheless, full public scrutiny of a contract that expensive is critical. Our concern certainly hasn't abated since learning that the lobbyist pushing this contract is none other than former Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's friend and mentor.

title: F.D.A. Wants More Study on 2 Drugs for Anemia
description: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that more study would be needed to determine whether Amgen's and Johnson & Johnson's widely used anemia drugs for cancer patients can actually make their cancer worse. But the committee did not discuss placing any restrictions on the use of the drugs or additional warnings on their labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, ENID H.
description: BAKER--Enid H., 90. Of Sea Cliff, N.Y. On May 2, 2004. Beloved mother of Charles E. & the late Valerie D. Memorial contributions may be made in her memory to the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, Inc., 99 Hudson St, New York, N.Y. 10013. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Who Needs Plain Vanilla When There's Wattleseed?
description: Don't look for vanilla in Katrina Markoff's new line of ice creams at Vosges Haut Chocolat, above, at 132 Spring Street (Greene Street) in SoHo. But you can have red fire chocolate (dark chocolate gently fueled with cinnamon and chili). Charles Speight, a shopper who works for a digital consulting company nearby, sampled it and found it pleasingly subtle. ''The flavors don't beat you over the head, and it's not too sweet,'' he said. There is also mellow Australian wattleseed, a flavor that suggests the taste of an old-fashioned waffle cone. Pandan, the color of concrete, has a hint of vanilla from Thai pandan leaf. And though golden naga, seasoned with white chocolate, curry and coconut, is billed as a sorbet, it is richly creamy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBKIN, VIRGINIA, M.D.

Attending surgeon in the Department of Ophthalmology since 1945, Dr. Lubkin was a pioneer in the field; a gifted clinician, teacher and researcher; and founder and director of the Infirmary's Aborn Center for Eye Research. She was an inspiration to all. We extend our deepest sympathies to her entire family. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman of the Board Joseph B. Walsh, M.D., Chairman, Dept. of Ophthalmology Joseph P. Corcoran, President and CEO

title: Ambushes by Taliban Gunmen Kill 10 Policemen and Soldiers
description: Taliban gunmen have killed at least 10 Afghan policemen and soldiers in two ambushes in southern Afghanistan in the last 24 hours, government and Taliban officials said Tuesday. The attacks are part of a surge of violence by the Taliban and other insurgents that has killed at least 40 Afghan policemen and soldiers and one American soldier in the last two weeks.

"Welcome," it says, "to the house that Catfish, Reggie, Rollie, Big Mac, Eck, Rickey, Hudson, Mulder and Zito built." There is no mention of the man with the highest batting average in Oakland history.

The change, from simply ''Van Wilder,'' occurred before the film was released in theaters, not for the DVD release.

title: Playing Soon on Broadway: Republican Delegates
description: Forget about ''Assassins,'' the Broadway show that focuses on presidential killers. Don't even think about ''I Am My Own Wife,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning play about an East German transvestite. Even ''Avenue Q,'' with its irreverent use of puppets, seems a bit too risqu. When the Republican delegates arrive in Manhattan this summer, the city wants to send them to wholesome Broadway musicals on their first evening.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retailer Names Board Chairman
description: KarstadtQuelle, Germany's largest department store operator, plans to make Thomas Middelhoff, the former chief executive of Bertelsmann, the chairman of its supervisory board, succeeding Hans Meinhardt. Mr. Meinhardt will step down in a few months after helping Mr. Middelhoff settle in his new job, he told shareholders at the company's annual general meeting.

Spain has its tapas, the Middle East its mezze, Russia its zakouski, Korea its anju and so on. But Americans? Supersize this!

description: Construction of Freedom Tower, the office high rise at the site of the World Trade Center that its developers say will be the world's tallest building, will break ground on July 4, Gov. George E. Pataki said today.

title: Mother's Day Every Day For the Family Inside I Trulli
description: ''I WAS born on Mother's Day,'' said Domenica Frankland, ''so as far as I'm concerned, my mother has been working from the day I was born.'' Her mother, Dora Marzovilla, nodded -- the kid had a point -- while her brother Nicola told the family story about the night before she was born. Mrs. Marzovilla had a craving for fresh mozzarella -- this was in 1969 when the family still lived in Rutigliano, a small town in southern Italy -- but there was no place open to buy it, so her husband went to the local pizza place and paid for six pies to get enough cheese.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airline Acquisition
description: Air France completed its acquisition of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, creating an airline group that will be one of the world's largest. Air France completed the purchase -- valued at more than 784 million euros ($948 million) when it made the offer last year -- after KLM investors tendered 89.22 percent of their stock, the airlines said. The carriers, which will continue operating under separate brands, may save as much as 495 million euros a year through joint purchasing and sales, Air France estimated. Voting control over KLM will remain with Dutch investors until 2007 to let the airline keep rights to fly intercontinental routes serving the Netherlands. Air France is based in Paris, and KLM in Amstelveen, the Netherlands.

title: Report Warns Of Infiltration By Al Qaeda In U.S. Prisons
description: Groups promoting extremist brands of Islam have gained a foothold in American prisons, and counterterrorism officials believe Al Qaeda are likely to try to use the prisons ''to radicalize and recruit inmates,'' according to a Justice Department investigation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Closed After Asbestos Is Found
description: City officials closed Public School 132 in Washington Heights yesterday after discovering asbestos in the building on Monday night. The shuttering of the elementary school disrupted the administration of the fourth-grade statewide mathematics exam, scheduled for yesterday, today and tomorrow. The exam was postponed to May 7, 10 and 11. Officials said the school would remain closed today for additional environmental tests. The asbestos apparently came from falling plaster dislodged by water from outside. Students were sent to schools within walking distance. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Time to Raise Rates
description: Alan Greenspan had enough evidence to justify an interest rate increase yesterday: economic growth was strong for the last two quarters of 2003 and is estimated to exceed 4 percent for the first three months of 2004. Price pressures have been building, and the most recent employment report showed a resumption in hiring -- tentative though that may turn out to be.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Private Schools Shut Over High Fees
description: The government closed 46 private schools, idling up to 30,000 students, after Education Minister Aeneas Chigwedere accused them of illegally raising their tuition in a ''racist'' attempt to prevent black students from attending the institutions. He said some of the schools had quadrupled and quintupled fees without government approval, raising tuition to as high as about $5,350 a year. ''They are all former white schools -- all racist,'' he said. Zimbabwe has the world's highest inflation rate, now averaging more than 580 percent a year. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Spokesmen for Bush condemn abuse and call it very limited : Criticism rises over prisoners held in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON:  Outrage over the alleged abuse of Iraqi prisoners is continuing to spread around the world, even after seven U.S. soldiers received reprimands, the first punishments meted out in the matter.

title: Infants in Chinese City Starve on Protein-Short Formula
description: The containers were sealed in plastic, each filled with baby formula that Zhang Linwei and his wife fed to their tiny daughter. Over time, as the baby ate more formula, her cheeks grew fat as balloons, seemingly a sign of good health. Only later did her parents learn it was a sign of starvation.

title: The Torture Photos
description: It seems gloomily possible that in years to come, when people in the Middle East recall the invasion of Iraq, they will speak not of lost American lives or the toppling of a brutal dictator. The most enduring image of the occupation may be those pictures of grinning American soldiers torturing Iraqi prisoners. This is the kind of outcome no one wanted, although one that the Bush administration should have worried about long ago, and taken far more care to avert. Now all the president and his top officials can do is clean up the mess and express the country's deep regrets. So far, they have accomplished neither.

title: Cities Enriched Pensions, but Now Struggle to Pay
description: A few years ago, the city of Houston decided to sweeten its workers' retirement benefits. Along with their traditional pensions, city workers nearing retirement were offered special accounts, fed with money from the city pension fund. Although the accounts would pay generous returns, a study showed that the cost to the city would be modest.

The electee, Michael K. Zierler, received 444 votes, and his opponent, Rick J. Remsnyder, received 306, according to the village clerk and treasurer, Jean P. Gallucci. ''Remsnyder got his answer to a campaign he ran as a referendum for New Paltz on the job I was doing as mayor,'' Mr. West said. Thomas Crampton (NYT)

title: Bush, at Campaign Stops in Ohio, Chides Kerry on Protecting U.S.
description: President Bush rolled through small towns across Ohio on Tuesday with mocking attacks on Senator John Kerry's approach to national security, arguing that the Massachusetts senator would take pre-emptive action against countries that threatened the United States ''only if other countries do not object.''

title: Out of Chaos, A Variety Of Accounts
description: Out on Beverley Road, a short block from where a news helicopter crashed on a Brooklyn rooftop yesterday evening, curious onlookers mingled with people who had been evacuated from their apartments, making a social occasion of the chaos.

title: Bloomberg Silent on Report Of Antimissile Devices on Jets
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has repeatedly declared that he does not live in fear of terrorist threats, and that all New Yorkers should live their lives normally. But he was curiously silent yesterday about a televised news report that he had installed antimissile systems on airplanes he often uses for official and personal use

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Lawmaker Pleads Not Guilty
description: An Indiana congressman caught with a loaded pistol at Louisville International Airport last month pleaded not guilty to a misdemeanor charge of carrying a concealed deadly weapon. The airport police say the congressman, John Hostettler, a Republican, tried to pass through a checkpoint with a Glock 9-millimeter in a carry-on bag. Mr. Hostettler's lawyer declined to comment. Andrew Tangel (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Colleges Announce Bulk-Buying Plan
description: A group of private colleges in the state plans group purchases, much like hospitals. The group, the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, announced an agreement with I.B.M. yesterday, the first of what it hopes will be many such bulk-buying agreements, including purchases like health insurance. Under the I.B.M. deal, the 105 colleges in the consortium, their students, faculty members and alumni will be eligible for discounts of $400 to $600 on four to six computer models with list prices ranging between $1,200 and $2,100. Eligible machines will change and equipment besides computers will also be available. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: A Rustic Retreat Became A Vineyard
description: BLAME the drunken cows. If not for them Ben Feder might be a cattleman today. On a very small scale. Instead, he is a wine man on a very small scale. He is the owner and general factotum of Clinton Vineyards, an improbably beautiful little wine estate two hours north of Manhattan in what its well-heeled denizens call rural Dutchess County.

title: ARMY DISCLOSES CRIMINAL INQUIRY ON PRISON ABUSE
description: In the last 16 months, the Army has conducted more than 30 criminal investigations into misconduct by American captors in Iraq and Afghanistan, including 10 cases of suspicious death, 10 cases of abuse, and two deaths already determined to have been criminal homicides, the Army's vice chief of staff said Tuesday.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN'S NET INCOME FALLS 8.3%
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation's first-quarter net income fell 8.3 percent from a year ago, when discontinued operations increased earnings, the company said yesterday. Northrop Grumman, which makes combat aircraft and warships, reported net income of $232 million, or $1.27 a share, in contrast to $253 million, or $1.34 a share, in the quarter a year ago. Last year's figures included the company's Component Technologies businesses and TRW Automotive, which was sold in February 2003. Excluding those units, profit was $1.25 a share, up from 91 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue climbed to $7.11 billion, from $5.87 billion, as each of Northrop Grumman's operating units posted sales growth of more than 10 percent. Northrop Grumman is based in Los Angeles.

title: A Long Goodbye, Lushly Sentimental And Defiantly Fierce

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Protests Housing Aid Cutback
description: Mayor Bloomberg said yesterday that any cutbacks in a federal housing program would greatly imperil the city's efforts to house homeless families. He called Alphonso R. Jackson, the secretary of housing, to express displeasure over a recent regulatory change on Section 8 vouchers -- the government's primary housing program for poor Americans -- that would cost the city $55.5 million in subsidies this year. ''Section 8 vouchers are one of the reasons Linda Gibbs has been able to find housing for so many people,'' said Mr. Bloomberg, referring to the commissioner of Homeless Services. ''This city uses federal programs the way the programs were designed to be used, and when they get cut back because we've done a good job of availing ourselves of whatever services there are available and whatever monies are available, it hurts.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: To Go to the Moon and Mars, NASA Is Told It Must Change

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Begins Faster D.S.L. Service
description: Verizon Communications yesterday introduced faster digital subscriber line or D.S.L. services in a bid to compete more aggressively against its cable rivals. The company said that it would raise the upload speed for its basic D.S.L. plan to 384 kilobits per second from its current 128 kbps, while maintaining up to 1.5 megabits per second for downloads. The plan will still cost $34.95 a month as a stand-alone service and $29.95 a month when bundled with local and long-distance phone service. Verizon also said that it would unveil a faster plan this summer that will offer 3-mbp download and 768-kbp upload speeds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRINCIPE, FRANCIS J.
description: PRINCIPE--Francis J. Passed away quietly on Monday morning May 3, 2004 at the very caring St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn. Considered ''Mr. Maspeth'' for his lifelong civic activism. Mr. Principe, a civil engineer, was a maverick in the concrete industry through the development of its standard acceptance throughout New York and the nation. Beloved husband of the late Virginia Anne. Devoted father of Lee James and Virginia Herman. Cherished grandfather of Douglas, Gary, Christopher and Jonathan. Reposing at Papa Vero Funeral Home, 7227 Grand Ave., Maspeth on May 5, 6 and 7 from 2-5 and 79PM. Funeral procession along Grand Avenue Saturday May 8 at 10AM. Funeral Mass St. Stanislaus Church 10:30AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Maspeth Town Hall in his memory.

title: Police Station Is Hit by Bombs in Athens
description: ATHENS, May 5  Three time-bombs exploded outside a heavily guarded Greek police station in Athens today, causing serious damage and calling into question security preparations for the Summer Olympics here, just 100 days away.

Our hearts go out to his mother Barbara, his brother Christopher, his bride of ten days, his step father Arnie and his sister-in-law Sue. All of you are in our thoughts and Andy will live in our memory forever. Havva, Reed, Shamil & Cynthia Idriss

The chief executive, Gail Kelly, said an increase in business loans contributed to the increase. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Sudan Regains Human Rights Seat
description: Sudan was elected to another three-year term on the United Nations' Commission on Human Rights, but the United States delegation, citing allegations of ethnic cleansing in Sudan's western Darfur region, walked out of the meeting before the vote. The deputy representative of Sudan, Omar Bashir Manis, accused the United States of ''shedding crocodile tears,'' and said American forces had committed atrocities against prisoners and civilians in Iraq. Sudan ran uncontested, as one of four nations chosen by the African Regional Group to fill four allotted vacancies on the commission. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

description: Richard S. Strong is working with regulators to settle an investigation into mutual fund trades he made, paving the way for a sale of his stake in the investment firm he controls, Strong Capital Management, according to people briefed on the negotiations. The potential settlement could involve a substantial payment by Mr. Strong, these people said.

description: ''The truth is we were not terrorists. We were not insurgents. We were just ordinary people. And American intelligence knew this.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WISE, ETTA
description: WISE--Etta, 87, of New York, died May 2, 2004. She was preceded in death by her husband, Irving Wise. Survivors include two daughters, Jane Shear, of Binghamton and Alice Marshall, of Richmond, Virginia; six grandchildren; three great - grandchildren, and one on the way; one sister; and many wonderful friends and relatives. Mrs. Wise was a long time member of the Great Neck Choral Society. She was also an avid bridge and Scrabble player. She loved her family, music, and laughter. Her credo was, ''Never make a left if you can make three rights''. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the National Gaucher Foundation, 5410 Edison Lane, Suite 260, Rockville, Maryland 20852-3130.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Hospital Aide Accused Of Sexual Assault
description: A security officer at Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn has been charged with sexually assaulting a 16-year-old patient, the police said. The arrest follows two other major breaches of security at New York hospitals in April: the rape of a 13-year-old girl and the arrest of a patient-care assistant with a criminal record on charges of selling cocaine and guns at a hospital. The Woodhull security officer, Juan Leon, 25, of Long Island City, was charged on Monday with third-degree sexual abuse, endangering the welfare of a minor and two counts of forcible touching, the Brooklyn district attorney's office said. Mr. Leon, who had worked at the hospital for nine months with no complaints on his record, was immediately dismissed, the Health and Hospitals Corporation said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Fed Toughens Rate Hints, Seeing a Rise As 'Measured'
description: Correction Appended

title: The Jets and Jordan Talk
description: LaMont Jordan, the Jets' backup running back, and his agent met with team officials for about 90 minutes yesterday, but the sides made little progress toward a resolution of Jordan's future. Jordan and his agent, Alvin Keels, told the Jets they want a contract extension past this season that would pay Jordan as a No. 1 running back, not as a backup. If they cannot have that deal, they want the Jets to trade Jordan, Keels said last night.

title: Italian Official Warns Alitalia Unions to Accept Job Cuts
description: Italy's industry minister warned on Tuesday that Alitalia, the country's flagship airline and a national icon, would be forced into liquidation if its unions did not agree to a plan to cut 3,300 jobs, 15 percent of the work force.

title: Libya to Open 8 Oil Projects To Bidders
description: A senior Libyan oil official said yesterday that his country planned to hold an auction by the middle of the year to draw foreign investment into eight oil and gas projects, the first opportunity for American oil companies to do new business in Libya since President Bush eased sanctions 10 days ago.

title: Iraqi Detainees Protest as Media Tours Prison
description: ABU GHRAIB, Iraq, May 5  A guided tour of the American military prison here today got off to an unexpected start.

title: Where the Reader and the Rubber Meet the Road
description: Lucas Mast, the editor of a new magazine about Nascar, used to motor happily around the cubicles of the Cato Institute, the libertarian research group, cranking out white papers on Internet access and telephone regulation.

title: Screening Begins at Maryland Train Station
description: It was not quite the full airport treatment, but on Tuesday passengers boarding Amtrak and commuter trains here just outside Washington began walking through a machine that sniffs for explosives, and putting their bags through an X-ray unit that looks for bombs.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Senator Quitting Post
description: Senator Blanche Lincoln announced that she would withdraw as chairwoman of a charity fund-raising event honoring Southern senators at the Democratic National Convention in Boston. The event, called Rockin on the Dock of the Bay, is being organized by Aflac, an insurance company based in Georgia. Groups pushing to limit the influence of money in government said the event appeared to be a creative maneuver around new campaign finance laws that seek to prevent large donors from buying access to federal officials. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, BETTY
description: MILLER--Betty. On May 3, 2004. Actress of stage, film and TV for the past 60 years. Survived by son Frank Askin and her many loving friends.

description: In an ominous and early echo of the blazes that descended on Southern California last fall, wildfires forced the evacuation of hundreds of homes Tuesday as 2,700 firefighters battled flames on half a dozen fronts.

description: Sales of several popular large sport utility vehicles, including the Chevrolet Suburban, Ford Expedition and Cadillac Escalade, tailed off in April, but automakers generally insist that high gas prices are not changing the purchase decisions of customers.

Paid Notice: Deaths   DIBBELL, HELEN HOPE
description: DIBBELL--Helen Hope. On May 3, 2004. Born in Chelsea, MA on January 21, 1908. Devoted wife of the late Charles Dibbell, loyal sister of Quentin Hope and the late Henry Hope, Harvey Cecil Hope, and Florence Messing, beloved mother of Sandy Dibbell-Hope, Joy Harvey, Carola Dibbell and Adam Dibbell, remembered fondly by nine adoring grandchildren, four fascinated great-grandchildren, and almost everyone else who ever met her. Hope graduated from Barnard College in 1928, did graduate work at the University of London and Yale University, and proceeded to use her gifts to nurture and entertain her family and friends. She died as she lived, keenly interested in the world around her and deeply concerned for the well being of others.

title: Aleksandr Y. Bovin, 73, Who Twitted Kremlin
description: Aleksandr Y. Bovin, one of the most colorful and daring commentators of the late Soviet period and for more than five years Russia's ambassador to Israel, died during the night of April 27-28. He was 73.

description: A judge in Manhattan has ruled that a convicted pedophile serving time in a Pennsylvania prison is responsible for the death of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old SoHo schoolboy whose disappearance in 1979 haunted New York City, drew national attention and helped galvanize the missing-children's movement.

title: Higher Fees And Trading Help Double UBS Income
description: UBS, Europe's biggest bank, had its highest quarterly profit ever, driven by fixed-income and equities trading and higher fees from wealth management.

title: CLAYTON WILLIAMS ACQUIRING SOUTHWEST ROYALTIES
description: Clayton Williams Energy, which searches for and produces oil and natural gas, has agreed to buy Southwest Royalties, which is closely held, for $187.8 million to add its oil and gas reserves. Southwest Royalties is estimated to own 177 billion cubic feet of proven reserves as of March 31, and has an additional 53 billion cubic feet of probable reserves, Clayton Williams said. Clayton Williams, based in Midland, Tex., wants Southwest's reserves to complement its riskier exploration efforts, the company said. The acquisition is expected to close by May 21 and to add to earnings in 2004 and 2005.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Friday about gonorrhea treatment for gay and bisexual men referred incompletely to the drugs that the government said should no longer be the standard antibiotic. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended against fluoroquinolone antibiotics in general, not just Cipro, for men who have sex with men. (A corrected article from The A.P., transmitted on Thursday, was overlooked at The Times.)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: La-Z-Boy Inc., Monroe, Mich., a manufacturer and retailer of home furnishings, said it would take a pretax charge in the fourth quarter, citing import competition from China. The company said the charge would be $71.9 million, $55.9 million net of tax, or $1.04 a share.

title: Telfair Will Skip College For Chance to Join N.B.A.
description: Sebastian Telfair walked to the podium at the ESPN Zone in Midtown yesterday, an 18-year-old high school senior from Brooklyn about to grow up in a hurry.

She will be missed very much, especially by her husband and her dog Alfie. Services Thursday 11:30 AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIDDING, NELSON
description: GIDDING -- Nelson, distin guished novelist (''End Over End'', 1946) and screenwriter (many feature credits, including: ''I Want to Live'', 1958;''Odds Against Tomorrow'', 1959; ''The Haunting'', 1963; ''Nine Hours to Rama'', 1963; ''The Andromeda Strain'', 1971; ''The Hindenburg'', 1975). One of a kind, inimitable and unforgettable, a native New Yorker, husband of Hilde (first wife), Chunling (second wife), father of Josh, father-in-law of Diane, and grandfather of Zachary (who is so much like him!). Died on Sunday, May 2 in Santa Monica, CA, of congestive heart failure. Private services in Pacific Palisades, CA. ''Come, my friends, 'tis not too late to seek a newer world.''

title: A Fish In the Garden
description: THERE is a classic European spring preparation known, in England at least, as peas '' la franaise'' (though I have had the dish in Italy). It simply combines some of the best vegetables that appear early in gardens: peas, lettuce, spring onions and mint. It is a lovely combination, but one that was probably more popular when the cook could get someone else to shell the peas.

title: French Police Investigate Chemical Theft
description: The French police were scrambling Tuesday to locate 1,100 pounds of fertilizer that could be used to make a powerful bomb, after the material was discovered missing on Monday in northern France.

title: German Security Plan Falters as Qaeda Suspect Faces Trial
description: Even as the long-awaited terrorism trial of an accused operative of Al Qaeda opened in Berlin on Tuesday, a two-year effort by this country to make it easier to imprison or expel suspected supporters of Islamic terrorism seemed to collapse because of opposition from one of the junior partners in the government coalition.

description: The commander of American forces in the Middle East, putting on hold the goal of reducing troops in Iraq, plans to keep at least 135,000 soldiers there through 2005, Pentagon and military officials said Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Telecom Profit Steady
description: Telecom Italia Mobile, Italy's biggest mobile phone company, said first-quarter profit was little changed as it began amortizing costs for its license to provide faster wireless services and paid higher taxes. Net income increased to 481 million euros ($581 million) from 480 million euros a year earlier, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SABIN, CHARLES
description: SABIN--Charles. The partners, associates and staff of Sabin, Bermant & Gould are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved former senior partner, mentor and friend, Charles Sabin. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife Ruth, daughters Alix and our partner Liz, as well as the entire family. His leadership is the foundation upon which the firm stands today, a legacy of which his family may be justly proud. We will all miss him and cherish his memory forever. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 7 at 11:15AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel 76th And Amsterdam Avenue. At his family's request, contributions may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486-3395.

title: 'Aida' to Close In September After 4 1/2 Years
description: After almost four and a half years the musical ''Aida'' will end its run at the Palace Theater on Sept. 5, making it the first Disney musical on Broadway to close.

title: IRAQ SHIITES URGE CLERIC TO DESIST
description: Representatives of Iraq's most influential Shiite leaders met here on Tuesday and demanded that Moktada al-Sadr, a rebel Shiite cleric, withdraw militia units from the holy cities of Najaf and Karbala, stop turning the mosques there into weapons arsenals and return power to Iraqi police and civil defense units that operate under American control.

title: U.S. Begins First Major Assault on Iraqi Militia Led by Cleric
description: KARBALA, Iraq, May 5  The American military launched its first major assault against insurgents led by Moktada al-Sadr, a rebel Shiite cleric, striking early this morning at militia enclaves in this holy Shiite city and in another city in southern Iraq in an effort to retake control of those areas.

title: For Cinco de Mayo, Gyros Take Tacos for a Spin
description: The gyro spit of Turkey, Greece and the Middle East is the engine that also drives the tacos al pastor of Mexico. Chefs like Julian Medina, right, substitute pork for lamb or chicken, pop a hunk of pineapple on top for juice and flavor and shave off shards of crisp-edged meat to pile on small tortillas. This week, for Cinco de Mayo and until the end of the month, Mr. Medina, the chef at Zcalo, 174 East 82nd Street, is making authentic tacos al pastor (''shepherds' tacos'') swiped with serious red sauce, tomatillo salsa and a shower of fresh cilantro and onion. A tad less authentic, but no less delicious, are his gringas al pastor: melted Goudalike Chihuahua cheese and avocado in a big flour tortilla. The tacos al pastor are $8 for two, with a side of crispy Chihuahua cheese rolls called chicharones de queso; the gringa al pastor is $8.

title: Factory Orders Were Up 4.3% in March
description: New orders at factories rose 4.3 percent in March, the biggest increase since July 2002, as an accelerating economy lifted demand for machinery, metals and petrochemicals, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Economists had predicted a 2.4 percent gain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Gambling Ring Broken Up, Prosecutor Says
description: Ten people have been arrested and accused of running a $12 million gambling ring, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, announced yesterday. The ring conducted illegal sports betting in Westchester and the Bronx, the district attorney said. The arrests followed a six-month investigation that included electronic eavesdropping. Thirty-six search warrants were used on Monday to seize gambling records, cash, computers, cellphones, a gun and drugs. Eight defendants were charged with enterprise corruption, a felony punishable by up to 25 years in prison. Thomas Crampton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBROTH, MILDRED
description: LUBROTH--Mildred on May 4 in Madrid, Spain. Adored grandmother and mother of Guy, Claude, Adam and Juan, loving sister of Josephine Moonves and Cecile Waltzer. Her art, exhibited in all major museums of the world, will live on forever.

title: Wife Heads for Reunion With Escaped Captive
description: LANDSTUHL, Germany, May 5  Kellie Hamill has endured many long nights since her husband, the Mississippi dairy farmer Thomas Hamill, was taken prisoner nearly a month ago in Iraq before fleeing his captors as a convoy of American Humvees rumble past his mud shack north of Baghdad last weekend.

title: To Cut Smog, Los Angeles Places a Bounty on Mowers
description: In the smog capital of the nation, it seems that no effort to reduce pollution is too small.

title: Kerry Holding Infrequent News Conferences
description: Before Senator John Kerry took questions from reporters here in Los Angeles today, he had gone 20 straight days without a news conference  a sign, perhaps, that, now that he is the presumptive Democratic nominee, he is getting into a kind of presidential rhythm.

title: Tension in a Michigan City Over Muslims' Call to Prayer
description: To hear people in this blue-collar city tell it, things were fine until the al-Islah Islamic Center petitioned to broadcast its call to prayer, or azan, over an outdoor loudspeaker.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Schlumberger Selling Shares In Unit
description: Schlumberger, the oil field services company, plans to raise as much as 689 million euros ($833 million) by selling its smart-card unit, Axalto Holding, in a share offering that began yesterday. The company offered 27.86 million Axalto shares, or 70 percent of the company, at 14.8 euros and 17.2 euros each. The number of shares may be increased to 100 percent of the stock, depending on investor demand, Axalto's chief executive, Olivier Piou, said at a presentation in Paris.

title: A New Concept for Britain: Summer Camp
description: It's around this time of year, as families begin making plans for summer, that British parents like Merryl Docker may envy their American counterparts.

title: Basque Chefs, Sharing the Glory
description: IT is Easter morning. Here among the hardy Basques, famous for their prowess as shepherds in their hilly homeland and also as migrs in the American West, paschal lamb for lunch seems inevitable, and the inevitable comes to pass.

title: The Comeback Likudnik
description: I have not spoken to Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon since a majority of half the members of his Likud Party -- about 1 percent of Israel's population -- expressed their displeasure with his plan to withdraw the most vulnerable settlements from Gaza and the West Bank. Here is what I imagine Arik is thinking.

description: WASHINGTON, May 5 - Following is a transcript from President Bush's interview Wednesday on Al Arabiya Satellite Television Network, as recorded by Federal News Service, a private company.

title: Officials Vote for the Closet at Hunt High
description: JARRED GAMWELL, a 17-year-old junior at Hunt High School, lives up a country road that is miles from the nearest town. His mother, Michelle, is a housewife. His stepfather, Mike Keech, works a swing shift at the Firestone plant here, operating a high-temperature press that molds rubber into finished tires. They're Roman Catholics. The first thing a visitor walking in the front door sees is a big portrait of Jesus on the living room wall. Smaller portraits, blessing their family, cover the refrigerator door.

title: Witness Tells of Dual Accounting at Adelphia
description: Top executives at the Adelphia Communications Corporation knew that its published financial results were misleading because they regularly received reports that compared those figures with the company's real financial condition, a former Adelphia official testified yesterday.

title: Microcredit's Limits
description: The reports of the success of microlending around the world sound like the small miracles that many actually are. Women in particular have been able to tap into this modest source of self-empowering credit to improve their lives. Often all it takes is buying a couple of chickens to start a business.

title: INSIDE
description: A Desperate Kind of Food for Ever More Desperate Haitians

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State To Raise Foster-Parent Stipends
description: New Jersey, which has suffered repeated scandals in its child welfare system in recent years, announced yesterday that it would speed up plans to increase support payments to families that care for foster children. The state currently lags far behind federal standards for foster care payments, and this year, officials announced that they would gradually increase the amounts to meet federal recommendations in 2007. Federal guidelines call for a family in the northeast with one foster child to receive $795 a month, but New Jersey foster families receive between $425 and $525. John Sullivan (NYT)

title: Mrs. Rowland Paid by Insurer That Got Work From the State
description: A week after the House impeachment inquiry committee pressed Gov. John G. Rowland for more detailed financial records, he filed forms on Monday disclosing that his wife had received income from a Greenwich insurance company that had paid for him to attend a conference in Florida and that had received a $16 million state contract.

title: National Briefing: South
description: KENTUCKY: LAWMAKER PLEADS NOT GUILTY An Indiana congressman caught with a loaded pistol at Louisville International Airport last month pleaded not guilty to a misdemeanor charge of carrying a concealed deadly weapon. The airport police say the congressman, John Hostettler, a Republican, tried to pass through a checkpoint with a Glock 9-millimeter in a carry-on bag. Mr. Hostettler's lawyer declined to comment. Andrew Tangel (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg May Visit Athens
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would likely attend the Summer Olympics in Athens for a day or so. Mr. Bloomberg would like to see New York win the right to be host city of the 2012 Summer Games, but said yesterday that he would be careful not to tout the city's virtues while in Greece, in order not to violate any rules that prohibit cities from lobbying the committee making the decision. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Gaza Pullout Is Endorsed, With Proviso, By Envoys
description: Senior envoys of the United States, Europe, Russia and the United Nations gave a qualified endorsement on Tuesday to the stated intention of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel to withdraw from Gaza and parts of the West Bank in spite of the rejection of that plan by his own Likud Party.

title: Critic's Notebook; The TriBeCa Film Festival Still Struggles to Be Serious
description: In one of those sad coincidences in which a movie resonates uncomfortably with recent headlines, John Furse's ''Blind Flight,'' playing tonight at the TriBeCa Film Festival, tells the hellish true story of two prisoners -- Brian Keenan (Ian Hart), an Irish nationalist, and John McCarthy (Linus Roache), a British journalist -- who were kidnapped and held hostage by Arab militants in a series of prisons in Beirut. That their four-and-a-half-year ordeal took place more than a decade ago doesn't take your mind away from pictures of Iraqi prisoners being humiliated by American soldiers.

title: Iraqis Line Up, Hoping to See Jailed Relatives
description: Peering over the barriers and barbed wire, Iraqi women shook their fists in anger on Tuesday as a crowded bus pulled away from them at a checkpoint and lurched along a dirt road, headed for the gates of the prison here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, SYDELLE (WINDT) LIST
description: GROSS--Sydelle (Windt) List, 88, of Manhattan on May 4, 2004. Devoted wife of the late Martin J. List and the late Sidney L. Gross and devoted mother to the late Lawrence I. List. Sydelle's whole life was dedicated to her family. She is deeply loved and will always be admired by her surviving family, brother, Robert S. Windt of Brooklyn, daughter-in-law Bobye G. List, granddaughters Dr. Deborah G. List and Mali List Mayer and sons-in-law, William Mayer and David Schwartz, all of New York City. Funeral service will be held on Thursday, May 6, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC. The family suggests contributions in memory of Sydelle can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue, 131 Remsen St., Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bid For Land Concern
description: The Singapore government's investment arm, Temasek Holdings, made an unsolicited bid reportedly worth more than $400 million for United Overseas Bank's controlling stake in the property company United Overseas Land. Temasek offered to pay 2.06 Singapore dollars ($1.21) a share for the 48.9 percent of United Overseas Land owned by the bank. The bank, which is one of Singapore's last family-run banks, last week offered to sell 36.9 percent of United Overseas Land to shareholders for 1.58 Singapore dollars a share, a move that angered minority shareholders and set off a 6 percent decline in its share price. The price rebounded yesterday, gaining 8 percent before trading was suspended. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds Doesn't Give An Inch, As Usual
description: TO the suspicious minds that cannot fathom his cartoonish might, for the Mona Lisa eyes that follow him wherever he goes, Barry Bonds offered his own version of a screening test for drugs last night.

description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Is Blocking Distribution of Film That Criticizes Bush
description: The Walt Disney Company is blocking its Miramax division from distributing a new documentary by Michael Moore that harshly criticizes President Bush, executives at both Disney and Miramax said Tuesday.

title: On the Road
description: The dirty little secret of President Bush's bus tour is that he didn't spend much time on the bus .

title: Poking at the Glass Ceiling With a Conductor's Baton
description: On a drizzly Tuesday in mid-April, the conductor Marin Alsop made a 24-hour pit stop in Manhattan. She had arrived on the 6 a.m. red-eye from Denver, having recently been named music director laureate of the Colorado Symphony Orchestra after a decade at that ensemble's helm. By 10 a.m. she had begun an all-day rehearsal with Kristin Chenoweth and Patti LuPone at Riverside Church, amid the frenetic clatter of a roomful of assistants and handlers, only one of them hers. At 6:30? Dinner and an interview, then a stamina-building workout. And finally, after several hours' sleep, an early-morning departure for Baltimore, one stop in a spring season packed with gigs in Atlanta, Los Angeles, Cincinnati, Minneapolis and St. Louis.

title: No Plan to Hurt 9/11 Detainees, Ex-Jailer Says
description: The former warden of the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, where the Justice Department and a new lawsuit say Muslim detainees were physically abused after Sept. 11, 2001, said yesterday that there had been no organized effort to mistreat the detainees or to ''soften up'' those being questioned by federal investigators.

title: Just the Subsidy Cuts, Please
description: What started out as Congress's urgent obligation to resolve a trade battle with the European Union has degenerated into an embarrassment as lawmakers and business lobbyists vie in a costly frenzy of corporate handouts. The task was simple: to repeal a $5 billion annual subsidy for American exporters that two years ago was found to be illegal under international trade practices. Initially, a bipartisan remedy was proposed to do just that and to create limited tax breaks to spare exporters pain. Included in the bill were ambitious curbs on some of the Enron-style corporate abuses. Once this worthwhile approach was approved last fall in the Senate Finance Committee, however, the bill quickly doubled in size into another budget-busting juggernaut: 146 amendments were tacked on as separate business sweeteners with dozens more in the works.

title: Fixing the Mistakes Is the Nets' Priority
description: The Nets' team plane touched down in New Jersey just before 2 a.m. Tuesday, a flight that lasted just long enough for Coach Lawrence Frank and his staff to watch the tape of the Game 1 fiasco. As players scattered to their cars to head home for some sleep, Frank went to work.

title: Fox TV Studio Creates a Unit To Produce Cheaper Shows
description: Saying the economics of the television production business has reached a crisis point, the 20th Century Fox television studio announced yesterday the creation of a separate unit specifically designed to generate new shows at much lower cost.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHWATT, EDWARD A.
description: CHWATT--Edward A. On May 1, 2004. A powerful, loving, supportive and stable force in our lives was transformed by the sudden passing of our beloved husband, father, stepfather, brother, grandpa, uncle and friend. He was an adoring husband to Sara, whom he cherished. He was a fiercely devoted father to Mitchell, Sara, Jill, Eric, Nancy, Samantha and Jimm. Eddie was a loving brother and best friend to Robyn and Richard, with whom he shared an extraordinary and unbreakable bond. He delighted in spending time with his grandchildren Sammie, Justin, Corey, Nikki, Dana, Lauren, Kayla and Sierra, all of whom he adored. He loved his nieces and nephews Glenn, Lori, Suzy, Craig, Jaime and Evan. He prized his many friends with whom he shared priceless memories and strong ties. His love, energy, charisma, sense of humor and generosity touched many and as a result he enriched the world. He will continue to guide us, fill us with love and be an ongoing light in our lives. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC, Wednesday, May 5, 2:30 p.m. Donations in his memory may be made to Congregation Schomre Israel, 18 Park Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603.

title: CONVERGYS ACQUIRING ENCORE FOR ABOUT $68 MILLION
description: The Convergys Corporation, which provides billing and other services for phone and cable companies, has agreed to buy Encore Receivable Management for about $68 million as part of a plan to offer accounts-receivable management services. The acquisition is part of Convergys's plan to expand its outsourcing services. Encore, which is closely held and has about 1,100 employees, as well as two facilities in Kansas City, Kan., and one in Las Vegas, is expected to have 2004 revenue of about $68 million, according to Convergys. Encore, based in Olathe, Kan., specializes in collecting past due or delinquent accounts for large clients in the bank card, telecommunications, retail and automotive industries. Convergys is based in Cincinnati.

title: Those Friendly Iranians
description: Finally, I've found a pro-American country.

title: Lesbian Remains a Methodist Cleric, for Now
description: The United Methodist Church's supreme court ruled Tuesday that it lacked the authority to reconsider the case of a lesbian pastor who was permitted to remain in ministry by a local church court in Washington State.

title: TV Helicopter Crashes on Brooklyn Rooftop
description: A television news helicopter covering a triple shooting in Brooklyn spun out of control and crashed onto the roof of a Flatbush apartment building last night, snapping in two but sparing the three people on board any serious injuries.

title: In Athens, an Olympic Scramble
description: The Summer Games open here 100 days from Wednesday, and much work remains to refurbish Olympic Stadium. The surrounding area is a moonscape. Seventy-five thousand seats must be installed. One curve of the track is not yet in place. One wonders whether athletes in next month's Greek track and field championships will have to compete in hard hats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SNYDER, MARTIN F.
description: SNYDER--Martin F. 94, of NYC and Miami, Fla on May 3, 2004. Cultured, elegant and a veteran traveler, he enjoyed fifty years operating Martin Snyder Travel and taking special audiences to theatrical events around the world. Survived by his sister Sylvia Zimmerman, nieces, Ellen Zimmerman, Marcy Gran and nephew Charles Zimmerman. Arrangements entrusted to Frank E. Campbell, the funeral chapel. 212288-3500. Interment Friday May 7, 1PM at Montefiore Cemetery, Philadelphia, PA.

title: Shares Are Up as Fed Implies Rate Rise Will Be Gradual
description: Stocks rose modestly yesterday after the Federal Reserve's interest-rate-setting panel said that any increase in short-term interest rates would be ''measured,'' though it declined to say again that policy makers would be patient in raising rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STAVIS, FRANK
description: STAVIS--Frank. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Frank Stavis, beloved father of Robert Stavis and Patricia Dweck; father-in-law of Amy Stavis; cherished leaders of the New York Jewish community. We are privileged that Frank's legacy to the Jewish community continues through the abounding efforts of his children: Robert, a member of the Board of Directors of UJA-Federation and president elect of Westchester Jewish Community Services; and Patricia, a leader in the Scarsdale Women's Campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Reeva; to his children Robert and Amy; Patricia and Michael; Susan and Eric; to his grandchildren; and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Off the Menu
description: The restaurant in the renovated Museum of Modern Art, which is to open by the end of the year, has a name and a chef. It will be called THE MODERN, and the chef will be GABRIEL KREUTHER, who is now at ATELIER in the Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South. The restaurant, being developed by Danny Meyer's Union Square Hospitality Group, which will run it, will have its own entrance on West 53rd Street. It will be open to the public, not just to museumgoers. Mr. Kreuther, who will leave Atelier in June, will not be involved in the two cafes that Mr. Meyer's group will also run in the museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CULLMAN, JOSEPH F.
description: CULLMAN--Joseph F., 3rd. The Atlantic Salmon Federation mourns the loss of our dear friend, former Chairman and longtime Board Member. Joe's passion for Atlantic salmon fishing inspired his involvement as a leader in the conservation movement. His great determination to save the wild Atlantic salmon was matched by his generosity and he supported many programs invaluable to the salmon's survival. The salmon greatly benefited from his vitality and resourcefulness, the same characteristics that made him a leader of industry in the United States. His expertise and support greatly assisted the Atlantic Salmon Federation in achieving recognition as the leading Atlantic salmon conservation organization in the world. Joe Cullman was a remarkable man who lived an extraordinary life. We shall greatly miss this man who excelled as business leader, a sportsman and a conservationist who considered himself to be ''A Lucky Guy.'' Donal C. O'Brien, Jr., Chairman, ASF (US) Michael Meighen, Chairman, ASF (Canada) R. William Taylor, President and CEO, ASF

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Cross-Dressing Car Thieves
description: The Birmingham police said a group of cross-dressing men had been stealing cars from dealerships in Alabama and perhaps Tennessee to drive to cross-dresser pageants across the Southeast, then abandoning the vehicles. They said the men, sometimes dressed as women, would distract salesmen while an accomplice stole keys to cars on the lot. Three people were charged with receiving stolen property. The police said they had recovered about a dozen cars, some with women's clothing or pageant trophies in them. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Hewlett And BT Group Announce Pacts
description: Hewlett-Packard and the BT Group announced an outsourcing deal yesterday, valued at $1.5 billion over seven years, and an alliance to seek new business in computing and telecommunications services. BT will manage Hewlett-Packard's phone and data networks and its product support call centers in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. Hewlett-Packard will manage the 100,000 desktop personal computers of BT's workers in Britain and most of BT's server computers. The companies will also work together in seeking outsourcing contracts from corporate and government customers. Hewlett shares rose 23 cents, to $19.88. BT shares rose 25 cents, to $32.25. Steve Lohr (NYT)

description: LONDON -- The practice of armies putting the prisons of the barbaric regimes they topple to new use has a history. The Soviet Army, for example, employed the Nazi Buchenwald camp to grim effect for several years after 1945.

title: A Clip Plus a Napkin Equals a Bib
description: Kipiis bib clips are efficient little gadgets that instantly convert a napkin or even a clean diaper into a bib. They would be handy for a family dining out with toddlers on Mother's Day or a must for the child who wants to try a finger painting or another messy creative activity to thrill mom or grandma. They are adjustable, thanks to a simple slide clasp in the back, so you might buy a number of them in red and, with some fresh dish towels, protect grown-up lobster or rib eaters this summer. The clips are $12 a pair from www.kipiis.com.

title: Tax Protester Is Convicted
description: A California woman who earned more than $8 million selling bogus ''pure trusts'' to thousands of people seeking to escape income taxes has been convicted along with six associates of tax fraud.

title: Discovery Pushes Back Date of 'Classic' Maya
description: A discovery of monumental carved masks and elaborate jade ritual objects in 2,000-year-old ruins of a city in Guatemala is raising serious questions about the chronology of the enigmatic Mayan civilization. In many respects, the city appeared to be ahead of its time.

title: Outpatient Services Are Making Medical Offices Hot
description: The 14-story building on the main campus of Swedish Medical Center, the largest hospital in Washington State, has a spacious lobby adorned with abstract art, a fast-food restaurant, a chain pharmacy and light and airy corridors with sleek wood trim.

title: Guerrero Wasn't Ready To Be Prime Time Player
description: It was never a cinch that Lisa Guerrero would succeed as the sideline reporter for ABC's ''Monday Night Football.'' She had never been in an equivalent hothouse atmosphere, had never had a national stage as large as this and carried the baggage of twice posing seductively for FHM and Maxim magazine.

title: General Will Trim Inmate Numbers at Iraq Prison
description: The American commander in charge of military jails in Iraq said Tuesday that he had decided to reduce the number of prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison sharply. The move comes after a military investigation into photographs and other evidence of prisoner mistreatment identified overcrowding as contributing to an abusive and chaotic atmosphere.

title: Spaetzle and Schnitzel, Unclouded by Foam
description: WHEN Walls, an Austrian restaurant on West 11th Street, opened in 2000, it presented itself as a brave outpost on a residential frontier far from pedestrians' reach. It seemed an appropriate station for Kurt Gutenbrunner, Walls's chef and owner, who is outspoken and gruff, a rebel in a city full of media-groomed chefs.

title: Rumsfeld assails jail mistreatment as 'un-American'
description: WASHINGTON:  Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld on Tuesday vigorously denounced the abuse of Iraqi prisoners by U.S. troops as "totally unacceptable and un-American," and said that "appropriate steps" would be taken.

title: British Official Vows A Thorough Inquiry
description: The government said Tuesday that it had accepted ''at face value'' as possible evidence of a crime photographs that seem to show British soldiers beating and humiliating a hooded Iraqi prisoner, ''unless there is evidence to the contrary.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: Appeal Against Altered-Food Aid
description: Some 60 groups representing environmental, farm, consumer and development interests issued a letter demanding that the World Food Program and the United States Agency for International Development stop pressuring African nations to accept donations of genetically modified food for their malnourished populations. Angola most recently banned imports of genetically modified grain unless it was first milled. Experts say the ban will drastically reduce food aid because Angola lacks the capacity to mill more than a small amount of the thousands of tons of food aid it receives. The groups say alternatives are available. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: A federal judge ordered the accounting firm of KPMG yesterday to turn over names and related documents of tax-shelter clients within 10 days. The firm said through a spokesman that it was ''reviewing the order and the opinion of the court.''
