Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 19; the full text is online at theater.nytimes.com. The play reopened last night on Broadway at Circle in the Square.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Snapple Deal To Help Athletics
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that the city would be able to create 120 new athletic teams at 76 public schools using $500,000 in proceeds from the city's deal giving Snapple exclusive rights to sell canned beverages from vending machines in the schools. The 120 new teams will be in 17 different sports, Mr. Klein said. Mr. Klein said the city had used money from the Snapple deal for other athletic initiatives, including a program called CHAMPS, which provides sports programs in 40 middle school. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Getting Inside a Nightmare; The Stars of 'Frozen' on Fire, Ice and Ordinary People
description: Toward the end of Bryony Lavery's powerful play ''Frozen,'' a grieving mother played by Swoosie Kurtz visits a prison to talk to the man who had kidnapped, raped and murdered her 10-year-old daughter.

title: For Mother, Or Perhaps Auntie Mame
description: Frivolous yet enchanting, this bright boa-wrapped reusable flowerpot holds a sack of edible daisies in pastel shades. They are made of white chocolate and given personality with a touch of mint crunch. The flowerpot is from Moonstruck, a high-end chocolate company in Portland, Ore.; it is $20 at www.moonstruckchocolate.com. Overnight shipping is extra. The Web site offers other Mother's Day choices including boxes of the company's excellent decorated truffles, $9 and up.

title: Record Labels Must Pay Shortchanged Performers
description: David Bowie may not need the extra money, and Elvis Presley will not be able to spend his windfall. But under an agreement announced yesterday by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, record companies will be sending out checks for outstanding royalties owed to them and thousands of other artists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBS, WILLIAM JAY
description: JACOBS--William Jay. On Friday, April 30 in Greenwich, Connecticut. Dr. Jacobs was a teacher and writer of history and biography for young readers. He was associate professor of social studies education at Hunter College, and director of Teacher Education at Ramapo College of New Jersey. From 1975 until his retirement in 1993, ''Dr. J'' was chair of the History Department at Darien High School. In 1978 he visited the People's Republic of China with a group of Darien High School students in a pioneering effort to promote SinoAmerican relations. Dr. Jacobs wrote more than thirty biographies and textbooks. A sign over his desk reminded him that he was writing for ''a very special audience: young people searching for models, trying to understand themselves.'' He enjoyed playing baseball with his grandson, Max and his seven other grandsons by marriage. He will be deeply missed by his wife Susan, daughter Catherine, son Adam, and all his grandsons. Services and burial private. Donations may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union, 125 Broad St, 18th Floor, NY, NY 10004.

title: Massachusetts Shifts a Bit on Gay Marriage
description: In the face of protests from cities and towns around the state, the administration of Gov. Mitt Romney appears to be softening its approach to excluding same-sex couples of other states from marrying in Massachusetts.

title: Revulsion at Prison Abuse Provokes Scorn for the U.S.
description: Across the Arab world and beyond, the tormenting of Iraqi prisoners by their American guards shredded already thin support for Washington's invasion of Iraq and its vow to install democratic values and respect for human rights.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Maserati Executive Named
description: Ferrari, the sports car maker controlled by Fiat, named Martin Leach, left, the former president of the European unit of Ford Motor, to be the head of its Maserati brand. Mr. Leach, 47, will take the job June 1, succeeding Antonello Perricone, who is taking an unspecified position within the Fiat group, Ferrari said. Mr. Leach, who left Ford in August, was Fiat's first choice to lead its Fiat Auto division. Ford, however, refused to release Mr. Leach from a contract that prevented him from going to a competitor.

description: India may be "shining," in the description of a government publicity campaign, but it is also struggling to generate jobs.

description: Having given damaging testimony against three members of the Rigas family who ran the Adelphia Communications Corporation, the government's star witness yesterday implicated the other former company executive on trial in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OZER, HARRIET
description: OZER--Harriet. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of its longtime member, Harriet Ozer, beloved wife of Jerome Ozer. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi Stuart Himmelfarb, George Bean and Barry Zeveloff, Presidents

title: Bobby Short, Displaying A Little Bit Of Soul
description: ''Romance in the Dark,'' a sexy, blues-flavored swing song written by Lil Green, may not yet be a familiar popular standard. But if Bobby Short has anything to say about it, that will change. Mr. Short has made it a signature song in his musical arsenal comparable to ''Georgia on My Mind'' in Ray Charles's. And at Tuesday's opening-night show of his 36th spring season at Cafe Carlyle, Mr. Short carried it to a new level of soulful exuberance that brought to mind singers like Mr. Charles.

title: Here Come European Banks, Looking for Deals
description: The $10.5 billion acquisition of Charter One Financial, announced this week by a unit of Royal Bank of Scotland, could be the first in a string of American buyouts by cash-rich European financial institutions that are looking across the Atlantic for growth after failing to do deals on their own turf, bankers and analysts say.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: GRAND CANYON FIRE SPREADS A prescribed burn intended to reduce fire danger at the Grand Canyon jumped a containment line, blanketing some of the park's busiest visitor spots with heavy smoke. The fire spread to within a half-mile of park employee housing, a park spokeswoman said. Access to the canyon's South Rim, the most frequently visited section of the park, was cut off for several hours Wednesday while the east entrance remained closed Wednesday night. (AP)

title: On Baseball; Advertising Casting Its Web Over Young Fans at the Park
description: FIRST the conference-call operator asked for the password.

title: The Ad Council adopts an 'upfront' strategy to secure donations from media companies.
description: THE Advertising Council has often depended on serendipity to shepherd its public service campaigns to the right audiences. With no budget to buy commercial time, print ads or billboard space, the group distributes campaign materials to media outlets nationwide -- and then hopes the campaigns are used.

title: Low-Tech or High, Jobs Are Scarce in India's Boom
description: Two years ago, with the employment market in his drought-stricken rural district as dry as the earth, Bhaliya made his way to this high-tech capital in southern India and found salvation in a low-tech straw broom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSON, SONIA
description: WASSON -- Sonia. Beloved matriarch of the Wasson and Brooks families. Sonny was a cherished friend of dozens of Scrabble, handball, tennis and card players who migrated together from Castle Hill Beach Club to Florida. Her strength, wit and energy-and her opinions--will be missed. She is survived by her husband Albert; her children Jeffrey and Phyllis; and her grandchildren Sophie, Sam, Rachel and Mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, HELEN M.
description: KELLY--Helen M., April 25, at the Montreal General Hospital. Widow of the late Dr. Jerome J. Kelly. Mother of Dr. Suzanne Dickinson (Dr. Jack Goldberg).

title: Rep. Nethercutt Goes to Bat Against Spiderman Ads
description: Sometimes in politics you have to step up to the plate. Just ask Representative George Nethercutt .

title: McGreevey Won't Receive Communion
description: Bowing to pressure from New Jersey's increasingly outspoken Roman Catholic bishops, Gov. James E. McGreevey said Wednesday that he would no longer receive holy communion during Mass because his support for abortion rights and other social causes contradicts church doctrine.

title: Neighbors' Fears Realized in a Fatal Fire
description: When a 95-year-old woman died in a fire in her apartment on the East Side yesterday morning, the police said that she had most likely dropped her cigarette while sleeping. But some neighbors were not surprised -- they had long noticed that the elderly woman on the 10th floor was too frail to be left alone safely but too stubborn to accept more supervision.

title: BUSH, ON ARAB TV, DENOUNCES ABUSE OF IRAQI CAPTIVES
description: President Bush went on Arab television on Wednesday in an effort to limit the diplomatic damage from the abuse of Iraqi prisoners by American soldiers, offering no direct apology but saying the mistreatment ''does not represent the America that I know.''

title: U.S. Troops Start Major Attacks On Shiite Insurgents in 2 Cities
description: The American military has begun its first major assault against Shiite insurgents, striking at their enclaves here and in Diwaniya in an effort to regain control in southern Iraq.

title: Leadership Changes At Foote Cone Chicago
description: The Chicago office of Foote Cone & Belding, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is reorganizing its executive ranks a week after losing its president and chief executive, Dana Anderson, to a competitor.

title: Council Bill Extends Domestic Partner Rights to Companies Working for the City
description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday that would require private companies that have contracts with the city to offer the same benefits to the domestic partners of their employees as they do to spouses. The bill was opposed by some religious groups and by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who plans to veto it.

title: 2 Decades Later; Let Down by Academia, Game Pioneer Changed Paths
description: MARY ANN BUCKLES heard from a friend in her amateur choir that her 20-year-old dissertation on a video game was now considered a classic. ''I thought, classic dissertation?'' Ms. Buckles recalled. ''They hated my dissertation.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWLING, JOHN L.
description: DOWLING--John L. 66, on May 4, 2004, died at his home in Boca Grande, Florida. Beloved husband of Hebe S. Dowling. Devoted father of Meaghan, John and Peter Dowling. Cherished father-inlaw of Michael Chorske and Rebecca Dowling. Loving grandfather of Jack Chorske. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, May 9, 7-9 PM. A funeral mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue at 51st Street on Monday, May 10 at 10:30 AM.

title: Picasso Work From Rose Period Sets Auction Record for a Painting
description: A rare Picasso, painted when the artist was just 24, became the most expensive painting ever sold at auction when an anonymous buyer purchased it for $104.1 million last night at Sotheby's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday about the Bush administration's response to the abuse of prisoners in Iraq misattributed the announcement that the president would give interviews to two television networks that broadcast to Arab nations. It was made by Scott McClellan, the White House spokesman. (Dan Bartlett, the communications director, had spoken of the interviews earlier but had not specified when they would be, or for which networks.)

title: A Singer Expecting the Worst, Never Being Disappointed
description: What did you expect? Morrissey has been asking and answering this question for more than two decades, chronicling a world of dashed hopes and peculiar dreams. In his lyrics there is nothing more honorable or more glamorous than foolish consistency, and his songs are full of defiant characters struggling to hold on to their illusions.

title: I.R.S. Gives Shelter Users A Deadline
description: The Internal Revenue Service yesterday gave thousands of wealthy investors until June 21 to disclose their use of an abusive tax shelter that cost the government billions of dollars in taxes. Those who do not turn themselves in will face bigger fines and, possibly, the agency in court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERSTEIN, STUART

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Election Violence

title: The Internet's Wilder Side

In a room called Prime-Tyme-Movies, users offered free pirated downloads of ''The Passion of the Christ'' and ''Kill Bill Vol. 2.'' In the DDO-Matrix channel, illegal copies of Microsoft's Windows software and ''Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time,'' an Xbox game, were ripe for downloading. In other chat rooms yesterday, whole albums of free MP3's were hawked with blaring capital letters. And in a far less obtrusive channel, a hacker may well have been checking his progress of hacking into the computers of unsuspecting Internet users.

title: Paris: Trying To Defuse Protests
description: Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres moved Tuesday to dissuade angry French actors and technicians from disrupting next week's Cannes International Film Festival. He proposed an emergency plan to settle a 10-month-old dispute over unemployment benefits. Under the plan the government would create a $24 million ''special provisional fund'' to compensate for losses claimed by some 100,000 self-employed actors and technicians after changes were made in the unemployment system last June. Those changes led to protests that forced the cancellation of most of France's summer arts festivals last year. With the dispute unresolved throughout this winter, the Communist-led General Labor Confederation last month began threatening to disrupt the Cannes festival to apply pressure on the government. The initial reaction of representatives of the actors and technicians suggested they were not happy with Mr. Donnedieu de Vabres's offer. One labor spokesman called it a provocation and added that ''no one should be surprised if there are disturbances in next week's festivals.'' Meanwhile the festival's organizers have offered the protesters a forum at the festival, which runs May 12-23. ''We do not expect the Palais des Festivals to be taken by storm,'' Vronique Cayla, general director of the festival, told the left-of-center daily Libration. ''But we can't control everything.'' ALAN RIDING

description: BOMBAY: Riots and communal clashes between religious groups here which reached their height yesterday [May 4] afternoon have left twenty dead and more that 200 injured, an official Government communique stated late today. Today was quiet, following the assaults of yesterday, and the police and military had the situation under control and the increase in the death toll came today from death by injury. Heavily reinforced police and military last night carried out the curfew order issued as an urgent measure and the carrying of weapons was prohibited and the ban enforced as well. More than 300 have been arrested since the clashes started late Friday night and blazed through the weekend. A party of Mohammedans, besieged in a house by a chanting crowd of Hindus, were saved from certain death by the military, which hurriedly rushed to the scene and dispersed the attacking forces at the point of bayonets.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.T.C. Takes First Action On Registry Enforcement
description: The Federal Trade Commission has accused a California credit-repair service, the National Consumer Council, of violating the national ''do-not-call'' registry and deceiving customers who sought help in reducing their debts. The enforcement is the first of its kind in the government's crackdown on telemarketers. The group posed as a nonprofit organization to avoid complying with the list, the commission said in a lawsuit filed last month in federal court in Los Angeles and announced by the agency yesterday. The registry took effect in October to help block unwanted telephone solicitations from businesses. Nonprofit groups are exempt from the registry's rules. A judge in the case has frozen about $22 million in assets held by the defendants, an agency lawyer, Jennifer Larabee, said. The authorities shut down the group on Monday, The Los Angeles Times reported Tuesday. Nilou Salimpour, an outside publicist for the National Consumer Council, which is based in Santa Ana, Calif., said the group had helped thousands of consumers with debt problems. The organization contacted the commission to ask how to comply with the do-not-call list and never heard back, Mr. Salimpour said. The National Consumer Council refers consumers to profit-making affiliates that finance the group's operations, said a Los Angeles lawyer, Michael Mallow, who is representing the defendants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKST, IRA
description: BAKST--Ira, of Randolph, NJ, originally from Brooklyn, NY, passed away April 28th, 2004. He recently celebrated his 60th birthday. Ira was a family man that brightened every room he entered. His humor and unparalleled zest for life will be forever missed by his family and friends. Ira attended Jamaica High in Queens, NY, and graduated from Syracuse University in 1965. Ira co-founded Storis Management Systems in 1989. His energy and vision in building the company earned him national acclaim in the home furnishings industry. His success garnered him recognition by Ernst & Young in 2002 as a leading entrepreneur in the New York metropolitan area. Ira was preceded in death by his father, Benjamin Bakst. He is survived by his wife, Joan, mother, Sylvia, sister, Rosalyn, and sons, Eric, Jim, and Brendan.

Another follows a writer as she works her way through various shades of lavender for the bedroom and red for the kitchen.

description: Four days after the expiration of their contract, Hollywood screenwriters said Wednesday that the studios' latest offer for a new three-year contract was unacceptable and that they wanted to consider a one-year deal unless a better offer was forthcoming.

description: Two American Supreme Court justices and other international experts advised a group of Iraqi judges on Wednesday on how to build an independent judiciary.

title: News Corp. Says Net Profit Jumped 69 Percent in Quarter
description: Driven by strong performance at its television and cable units, News Corp. said today that its third-quarter sales rose 19 percent, to $5.2 billion, and that its net profit after unusual items jumped 69 percent  to $465 million, or 31 cents a share, from $275 million, or 23 cents a share.

title: Darrell Johnson, 76, Is Dead; Managed Red Sox to '75 Series
description: Darrell Johnson, who managed the Boston Red Sox to the brink of the 1975 World Series championship in a dramatic seven-game duel with the Cincinnati Reds, died on Monday at his home in Fairfield, Calif. He was 76.

description: JAKARTA - Indonesia held parliamentary elections last month that few could complain about: There was an enthusiastic turnout and fraud was kept within reason.

description: A prominent Canadian researcher is facing claims that data in his widely reported study of a nutritional supplement's effects on thinking and memory in the elderly are so flawed as to have no real value.

title: National Briefing | The Rockies: Colorado: Modern-Day 'Bonnie' Pleads Guilty
description: A woman who along with her boyfriend formed a duo called the modern-day ''Bonnie and Clyde'' has pleaded guilty in federal court to armed robberies in three states in the late 1990's. The woman, Nova E. Guthrie, 30, will be sentenced on July 14 and faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for robberies in Durango, Colo.; Aztec, N.M.; and Bend, Ore. Ms. Guthrie and her boyfriend, Craig Michael Pritchert, were fugitives for years. He is awaiting trial on federal bank robbery charges in Arizona. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: A federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant a new trial for Martha Stewart and her former stockbroker, rejecting arguments that a juror in their case was biased and provided false information about his background.

description: From Maine to Hawaii, fans are gearing up to say goodbye to the NBC series "Friends" tonight, with viewing parties at bars, restaurants and even, in Manhattan, a pier.

Beloved wife of John, dedicated mother of Lynn, William and Stephen, adoring grandmother of Tian, Seana and John. Graduate of Bronxville High School, Wellesley College and Columbia Law School. description: An index of mortgage applications rose for a second week, suggesting forecasts of higher interest rates may be prompting some people to buy homes, an industry report showed.

title: Pataki Backs New Tunnel Under the East River
description: Gov. George E. Pataki threw his political weight yesterday behind a plan to dig a new tunnel under the East River as part of a $6 billion rail link from downtown to Kennedy Airport and points east along the Long Island Rail Road.

title: LOCKHEED WINS BIG U.S. MISSILE CONTRACT
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation has won an order to develop and build a common missile for the Army, Navy and Marine Corps, a program the company estimates could entail spending of as much as $5.5 billion over 20 years. Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., beat Boeing and Raytheon in the competition, which is initially worth as much as $1.6 billion, to develop the Joint Common Missile. The order also covers the first two production batches, or as many as 2,700 of 55,000 missiles, the Army said. The military wants to cut costs by fielding a common missile. The new 70-inch missiles would be launched from Army helicopters, Navy fighters and unmanned spy planes, and would replace Raytheon's Maverick and Lockheed's Hellfire missiles. Unlike the old missiles, the new ones would not have to be guided by pilots to their targets.

title: A Tough Sell: Japanese Social Security
description: With almost 40 percent of young workers skipping out on their social security payments, Japan started an advertising campaign featuring a popular actress, who sternly lectured subway riders: ''So you don't mind crying in the future? Pay now. Or later, you don't get paid.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POOL, J. LAWRENCE
description: POOL--J. Lawrence. We note with sadness the passing of Dr. J. Lawrence Pool, Professor Emeritus of Neurological Surgery at Columbia University's College of Physicians & Surgeons and former Chairman of the Department of Neurological Surgery at the Neurological Institute of New York of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Dr. Pool was one of the greatest neurosurgeons of the 20th century. A masterful and innovative surgeon, he paved the way for many advances in the care of neurosurgical patients. He possessed a brilliant intellect, a keen wit, and an abundance of charm. He was multi-talented: erudite, intellectual, a superb athlete, an excellent water colorist and a thoughtful and interesting author, having written many books on subjects as varied as fly fishing to Revolutionary War history. He was a superb teacher and mentor to countless students and young doctors. His unique combination of talents, wide range of interests, and multiple accomplishments in many fields made him truly one of the most remarkable and inspiring individuals one could ever hope to meet. Our condolences to his family. The Department of Neurological Surgery New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia Univ College of Physicians & Surgeons

description: MONTANA: A VICTORY FOR DARWIN Two advocates of teaching evolution in public schools were elected Tuesday to the school board in Darby, Mont., a town of 754 people that became a focus in a national debate over religion and science. They defeated candidates who endorsed a proposal by a local Baptist minister, Curtis Brickley, to incorporate criticisms of Charles Darwin's theories of evolution into the science curriculum and created a new majority on the board opposing Mr. Brickley. Jim Robbins (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Files Suit Against Rivals
description: Rambus, a designer of computer memory chips, has filed a lawsuit that claims that Micron Technology, Hynix Semiconductor and Infineon Technologies conspired to fix prices and keep it out of the memory chip market. The three companies already face lawsuits in which Rambus accuses them of infringing patents after they refused to sign licensing agreements. Each in turn has accused Rambus of fraud in obtaining patents to get royalties from an industry standard. The suit opens a new front in a battle that has lasted for years by the Los Altos, Calif.-based Rambus to collect royalties on its technology. The claims in the new suit are based on evidence the company obtained in defending itself against a Federal Trade Commission fraud case. The lawsuit was filed in California state court in San Francisco.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Convention Fund-Raiser Canceled
description: Aflac, the Georgia insurance company, announced that it had canceled a charity fund-raiser honoring Southern senators during the Democratic National Convention in Boston. The cancellation came as groups seeking to limit the influence of money in politics criticized the event as a creative maneuver to get around campaign finance laws that seek to prevent large donors from buying access to federal officials. One day earlier, Senator Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, withdrew as chairwoman of the event. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Somerset: Killer Meets Investigators
description: The former hospital nurse who has claimed that he killed 30 to 40 patients and pleaded guilty to killing 13 met for the first time with Pennsylvania investigators yesterday about possible homicides in their state. The former nurse, Charles Cullen, has agreed to 13 life terms in prison for homicides in New Jersey in return for prosecutors' not seeking the death penalty. He also agreed to provide details of any crimes he committed in Pennsylvania. In Somerset, N.J., he met with the authorities for six and a half hours, a Pennsylvania prosecutor, James B. Martin of Lehigh County, said. Jason George (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARUSO, ENRICO
description: CARUSO--Enrico. June 22, 1919-April 30, 2004. Enrico Caruso, 84, died April 30 in Fort Lauderdale, FL of complications related to heart disease. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Mae; his three children, Michele, Enrico, Jr. and Michael; his brother, Julius; and two grandchildren, Christina and Pamela. Enrico enjoyed a celebrated career as a world renowned hairstylist in the beauty and fashion industries. During the course of his career, he worked with such celebrities as photographer, Richard Avedon and the Beatles. His international clientele included Marilyn Monroe, Audrey Hepburn and Grace Kelly. Enrico was born and raised in New York City. After serving his country as a World War II public relations photographer for the Air Force, he returned to Manhattan where he opened his hairstyling salon, Enrico Caruso Parrucchiere in 1954 which he operated for 20 years. Enrico and his wife became full time residents of Fort Lauderdale in 1983. Enrico's love of art and creativity took the form of oil painting and photography in his personal life. He had a passion for sailing and spent many summers on New York's Long Island Sound racing his Pearson yacht. He was well known for his wit and incisive intelligence. His integrity, strength of character and love for his family will be remembered and cherished.

title: Restoring Our Honor
description: We are in danger of losing something much more important than just the war in Iraq. We are in danger of losing America as an instrument of moral authority and inspiration in the world. I have never known a time in my life when America and its president were more hated around the world than today. I was just in Japan, and even young Japanese dislike us. It's no wonder that so many Americans are obsessed with the finale of the sitcom ''Friends'' right now. They're the only friends we have, and even they're leaving.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Pleads Guilty To Sex Attacks
description: A man has admitted to a string of sexual assaults and robberies last year, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced yesterday. Alberto Duque, 27, of Sunnyside, Queens, pleaded guilty Tuesday to charges of rape, sodomy and burglary in State Supreme Court. The attacks occurred between May and November 2003. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: 'Garden of Good and Evil' Is Set on Locking the Gate
description: This genteel, moss-draped city is well known for its ability to turn fighters into admirers. After burning his way across the state, Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman was so enchanted by Savannah that he spared the city and spent the next month enjoying the charms of its vanquished citizenry.

description: WHEN Kevin Garnett was presented the Maurice Podoloff Trophy for winning the Most Valuable Player award in Minneapolis on Tuesday night, he called on his teammates to leave the bench and join him at center court.

title: Bush Says He's Sorry for Abuse of Iraqis, Then Backs Rumsfeld
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  With the King of Jordan standing beside him, President Bush said today that he was "sorry" for the abuses inflicted on Iraqi prisoners by American military guards. But Mr. Bush rejected calls for the resignation of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld despite a rising wave of criticism.

title: Wal-Mart's Big-City Plans Stall Again
description: Less than a month after voters in Inglewood Calif., rejected Wal-Mart's effort to build a store there, Wal-Mart was dealt another blow on Wednesday when the Chicago City Council postponed a vote on zoning changes that would have allowed it to open its first two stores here.

title: Hate at the Local Mosque
description: Not long ago in my little mosque around the corner from a McDonald's, a student from the university here delivered a sermon. To love the Prophet Muhammad, he said, ''is to hate those who hate him.'' He railed against man-made doctrines that replace Islamic law, and excoriated the ''enemies of Islam'' who deny strict adherence to Sunnah, or the ways of Muhammad. While he wasn't espousing violence, his words echoed the extremist vocabulary of Wahhabism, used by some followers to breed militant attitudes.

title: F.B.I. Papers Describe Role Of Young Kerry Against War
description: A confidential F.B.I. memorandum dated April 29, 1971, on a just-concluded antiwar march on Washington by Vietnam Veterans Against the War concluded that the group's nominal leaders had been overshadowed by ''a more popular and eloquent figure, John Kerry,'' who was ''glib, cool and displayed best what the moderate elements wanted to reflect.''

title: Grand Jury Indicts Parents Accused of Starving 4 Boys
description: A grand jury on Wednesday indicted a Collingswood couple accused of starving their four adopted sons.

title: Red Cross Says It Urged U.S. to Act on Iraq Prison Abuse
description: GENEVA, May 6  Staff members of the International Committee of the Red Cross were fully aware of the full spectrum of abuses of Iraqi prisoners by American soldiers at the Abu Ghraib prison in Baghdad and had repeatedly urged the United States to take corrective action, a spokesman for the humanitarian organization said today.

title: Repligen and M.I.T. Sue ImClone Over Cancer Drug
description: The Repligen Corporation, a developer of treatments for autism and immune system diseases, filed a lawsuit yesterday demanding that ImClone Systems pay royalties on sales of the cancer treatment Erbitux.

description: Robert Greenhill's investment bank and asset management company raised $87.5 million yesterday in an initial public offering.

title: Instead of a Firebird, a Little Child Shall Lead Them
description: Succeeding against all odds, Pascal Rioult's new dance treatment of ''The Firebird'' is a compelling reinvention, even rejection, of the exotic beauties of Stravinsky's famous ballet score.

title: Impress Your Future Intended: Say It With a Chandelier
description: You can receive text messages on a cellphone. An organizer. At least a couple of wristwatches. And now, as the universe of connectivity continues to expand, you can even get them on light fixtures. A chandelier has been wired to receive and display text messages sent from any cellphone that happens to be in the room.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Data On Abortions
description: Gov. Haley Barbour signed into law a bill that requires doctors to report for state statistics any patients they treat for complications they believe to be ''primary, secondary or tertiary'' results of abortion. The patients' names and identifying information are to be withheld. Last week, Mr. Barbour signed a bill making it a felony for a doctor who performs a failed abortion to allow the child to die. Ariel Hart (NYT)

description: Following is a transcript from Prime Minister Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero's interview with The New York Times.

title: Another Vision of Iraq
description: Given the almost uniformly disastrous news coming out of Iraq lately, a presidential challenger might have been tempted to mark last week's anniversary of President Bush's ''mission accomplished'' stunt with point-scoring sound bites. To his credit, Senator John Kerry instead offered ideas for rescuing American policy in Iraq from the rapidly deteriorating military and political situation.

title: A Design for a Higher Calling Brings an Earthly Reward
description: Merrill & Pastor Architects of Vero Beach, Fla., has won an Arthur Ross Award for excellence in the classical tradition from the Institute of Classical Architecture and Classical America in Manhattan. The firm designed the Seaside Chapel in Seaside Fla., above, in 2001. Scott Merrill, a partner, said it combined the classical Seaside look with ''this backwoods church tradition of board and batten.'' Jaquelin Robertson, a partner at Cooper Robertson & Partners in Manhattan and chairman of the jury, said, ''Their work is contemporary, well-proportioned and historic.'' Merrill & Pastor is at (772) 388-1600 or www.merrillpastor.com.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Mining Acquisition
description: A copper mining company, Inmet Mining, said it had agreed to buy Aur Resources, another mining company, for 600 million Canadian dollars ($438 million), creating a producer with seven mines in Canada, Chile, Finland, Papua New Guinea and Turkey. The combined group, to be known as the Aur Mining Corporation, is expected to produce about 380 million pounds of copper this year. Inmet's shareholders will own about 55 percent of the new company and Aur's shareholders the rest. The two companies are based in Toronto. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Majiazhuang Journal; Faith Sprouts In Arid Soil Of China
description: They gathered under a blazing midday sun, raptly observing as four men in skullcaps held down the bull in preparation for its sacrifice. Little girls stood wide-eyed, while boys tried to appear unfazed, and the wizened grandmothers who, having seen such things countless times, were abuzz instead about the rare appearance of foreigners in their hamlet.

title: Why Not Go Pro?
description: The decision by Sebastian Telfair, the basketball star from Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, to enter the N.B.A. draft is being met with the predictable finger-wagging. Following the Supreme Court's rejection of a plea by the football player Maurice Clarett to be allowed to enter the N.F.L. draft after his sophomore year at Ohio State, it's bound to strengthen the resolve of David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, to enact a minimum age requirement of 20 for his draft. ''The reason I'm in favor of an age limit is not because young players can't play,'' Stern has said. ''But I think it's better for them to stay in school.''

title: Credit Suisse Says Earnings For Quarter Rose Sharply
description: Buoyed by brighter global markets, the Credit Suisse Group said Wednesday that first-quarter profit was more than six times the earnings in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Children's Blood Pressure Levels Climb, Indicating Added Cardiac Risks, Report Says
description: As health officials struggle to control the growing rate of childhood obesity in the United States, children and adolescents' blood pressure levels have been climbing, a new study finds.

title: In Court Filled With Stars, Spurs' Parker Stands Out
description: The move was scintillating enough to bring street-ball fans to their feet with a roar. Tony Parker, isolated in the left corner against an overmatched Devean George, executed a crossover dribble that nearly removed George from his sneakers.

title: The Blog Generation Takes Up Its Trowels
description: AS the manager of an indie-rock band fronted by an accordion player, Camille Acey, 23, is used to uphill battles. So when Ms. Acey and the band, Movers and Shakers, decided to build a ''rock garden'' on the roof of a loft building in Long Island City, Queens, they solved the obvious problem with 175 pounds of neutral-tone buttons from a company that donates surplus materials to artists.

title: Simulated Prison in '71 Showed a Fine Line Between 'Normal' and 'Monster'
description: In 1971 researchers at Stanford University created a simulated prison in the basement of the campus psychology building. They randomly assigned 24 students to be either prison guards or prisoners for two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLIOT, DAVID A., MD.
description: KLIOT--David A., MD. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of David A. Kliot, MD, former clinical professor of OB/GYN, and a graduate of the College of Medicine in 1959. Dr. Kliot will be remembered for his many years of service to our institution and to the people of Brooklyn. We are especially grateful for his dedication to the College of Medicine Alumni Association and his years both as president and as an active board member. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family and friends. John C. LaRosa, MD, President Eugene B. Feigelson, MD, Sr. Vice President for Biomedical Education and Research, and Dean of the College of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REELY, MARY PACKARD
description: REELY--Mary Packard. Died at her home in Saranac Lake, NY on May 3, 2004 after an extended illness. She was born in Saranac Lake, NY on December 25, 1925 to Edward Newman Packard Jr, MD and Mary Bissell Betts Packard. She graduated from St. Margaret's School, Waterbury, CT, in 1943, attended Our Lady of the Lake University, San Antonio, TX, and Mills College in NYC before graduating from Adelphi University, Garden City, NY in 1948. She taught in NYC at the Bank Street School. She married John Benjamin Reely in 1954. They moved to Minneapolis, where she taught kindergarten. Mr. Reely died in 1961. Mrs. Reely returned to NY in 1962 and taught in the Horace Mann School for nursery years, retiring in 1988. Mrs. Reely has lived in Saranac Lake, NY since her retirement. She has been active in many community organizations. She is survived by her brother, John M. Packard, MD of Birmingham, AL; her sister, Mrs. A.T. Ladd of Oxford, MD and seven nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held at 2:00 PM on Friday, May 7 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Saranac Lake, NY. Family requests memorial contributions be made to a favorite charity.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Banker Moves Up Resignation
description: The chairman of National Australia Bank, Graham Kraehe, left, moved up his planned resignation in a bid to defuse a boardroom brawl over 360 million Australian dollars ($263 million) of currency trading losses at the company, the country's largest lender. Mr. Kraehe, 61, said he would name two new nonexecutive directors shortly, allowing Ken Moss and Ed Tweddell to resign within three months. Mr. Kraehe, who said a month ago he would retire in the next few years, will leave no later than mid-2005.

title: U.S. Looking At Citigroup's Accounting In Argentina

title: Corporate Tax Legislation Remains Stalled in the Senate

title: A Lonely Bear Resists Increasing Optimism on Jobs

title: Surfacing the Forgotten Music of Ernst Krenek
description: Look at a gallery of German art from the early decades of the last century, and you see brilliant color, elan, energy crackling off the canvases. You hear the same things in music of the German-speaking world, which was less interested in Arnold Schoenberg than in the smash-hit opera of the late 1920's, Ernst Krenek's stylistically diverse and wildly popular ''Jonny Spielt Auf.'' But that energy, those colors, that irreverence were wiped out by the Nazi proscriptions of the 1930's and literally in the concentration camps.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW'S Profit Rises
description: The luxury carmaker BMW posted a higher profit for the first quarter, helped by the rollout of new models, but fell slightly short of analysts' expectations. Net profit rose 2.5 percent, to 523 million euros ($632 million), compared with the first quarter a year ago. The start of BMW's 6 series and X3 sports utility vehicle increased car sales, which rose 3.2 percent, to about 270,000 vehicles, including 48,000 cars of BMW's Mini brand. BMW, based in Munich, reiterated its forecast of record earnings for the year, exceeding the results of 2002. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, suggested on Wednesday that he might share with American Olympic and anti-doping officials evidence developed by federal prosecutors about elite athletes' dealings with a laboratory that is at the center of a steroids scandal.

description: The program at Symphony Space on April 30 was simply and accurately titled Paul Matteson and Friends: In Concert. It was an unpretentious evening by people who enjoyed dancing together and sharing their dances with others.

description: The fans flocked to see one superstar at Shea Stadium last night and wound up celebrating another.

title: FINANCE CHIEF RESIGNS FROM JEWELRY RETAILER
description: Friedman's, the jewelry retailer under scrutiny because of its accounting and financial reporting practices, said its chief financial officer, Richard Cartoon, had resigned, effective immediately. Mr. Cartoon was named finance chief in December, before the company said it would delay its fiscal 2003 annual report because of government accounting inquiries. The company, based in Savannah, Ga., said last year that it would restate results back to 2000. John E. Cay III, named last week as chairman of the corporate-governance committee, was removed from the company's board, Friedman's said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrests In Shooting
description: The police arrested three people last night who they said were involved in a shooting a day earlier in Flatbush. . Two of them, Ernest Normil, 17, and Jimmy Weeks, 23, were wounded when narcotics detectives shot them just after 5:30 p.m. on Tuesday. Both Mr. Weeks and Mr. Normil were carrying guns, the police said, when two pairs of narcotics detectives confronted them and fired, hitting one in the shoulder and the other in the leg. The police also arrested Alex Weeks, 18. The men had fled an earlier shooting in which a 17-year man was injured after two groups confronted each other on Flatbush Avenue. The confrontations were the ones that a news helicopter that crashed on a Brooklyn rooftop was covering. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Flotilla Is Beijing's Message To an Unsettled Hong Kong
description: Eight Chinese warships sailed slowly down Victoria Harbor here on Wednesday, a rare show of force that comes as democracy advocates say they face growing intimidation.

description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. said yesterday that it was postponing its annual meeting to June 29 from next Wednesday because it was ''considering strategic alternatives.''

title: US Airways Debt Downgraded, Stirring Doubt on Jet Financing
description: The credit rating of the US Airways Group was downgraded one level by Standard & Poor's yesterday, casting doubt on the airline's financing from the General Electric Company for new smaller jets that would reduce costs.

title: MGM BACKS AWAY FROM RAISING BID FOR WEMBLEY
description: MGM Mirage, the Las Vegas hotel and casino company, said yesterday that it would not increase its bid for Wembley of Britain, clearing the way for a $559 million takeover by BLB Investors. Raising its $555 million bid ''would not be the best use of our resources,'' MGM's chief executive, Terry Lanni, said in a statement. Wembley, which owns dog tracks in five towns in Britain and in Colorado and Rhode Island, is attracting outside buyers because of proposed changes in Britain's gambling laws. BLB is led by Starwood Capital, the real estate firm based in Greenwich, Conn. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: White House Asks G.O.P. in Congress to Add $25 Billion to Military Budget
description: The Bush administration, which once said it had enough money for the military's role in Iraq through 2004, asked Republican leaders of Congress on Wednesday to add $25 billion for the military beginning Oct. 1.

title: House Approves Curb on Minimum Tax
description: The House on Wednesday approved legislation that would curb -- for one year only -- the alternative minimum tax, which was meant to prevent the wealthy from taking unfair advantage of tax breaks but has affected many middle-income families.

title: When One Man's Video Art Is Another's Copyright Crime
description: Jon Routson's exhibition of videos at the Team Gallery in Chelsea is a kind of last hurrah, a farewell performance. It is also a small eddy in the increasingly roiled waters where art meets the United States' rapidly expanding copyright laws.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Reserve Bank of Australia said that its benchmark interest rate would stay at 5.25 percent, a level set last December. Analysts said the central bank's decision reflected a recent moderation of a three-year boom in housing loans and prices that had threatened to increase the 2 percent inflation rate. The International Monetary Fund warned last month that the housing bubble and record growth of consumer credit were inflationary risks for Australia. The monetary fund forecasts that the Australian economy will grow 3.5 percent this year and next. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Lights Left On? A Virtual Valet Can Check
description: AFTER dropping off his 3-year-old daughter at school, James Sentman can't always remember if he turned off the heat at home. But rather than worrying or driving back to check, Mr. Sentman delegates the issue to his personal assistant: an Internet-connected cellphone.

description: THE seasonal flurry of show houses and house and garden tours offers visitors a chance to peek behind closed doors and garden gates, and sample ideas from proud renovators, backyard horticulturists and interior designers. The following listing includes events in the Northeast. Unless otherwise noted, the tours are self-guided.

title: GRAPHIC PACKAGING TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 400 JOBS
description: The Graphic Packaging Corporation, formed by a merger last year of two packaging makers, will close two folding-carton plants, eliminating about 400 jobs, to cut production expenses. Plants in Bow, N.H., and Clinton, Miss., will be shut by the end of 2005, Graphic Packaging said. Operations in Fort Smith, Ark.; Mitchell, S.D.; and Lumberton, N.C., will be expanded. The moves will save as much as $15 million a year, the company said. Graphic Packaging, based in Marietta, Ga., was formed in August 2003 by the merger of Riverwood Holding and the Graphic Packaging International Corporation.

He will always be with us.

But two physicists at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California have developed a new way to preserve the contents of old discs and wax cylinders: they take pictures of the groove instead of dropping a needle into it.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit For Bertelsmann
description: The media company Bertelsmann, earned 31 million euros ($37.5 million) in the first quarter, reversing a loss in the period a year ago as write-downs fell and as its music business benefited from rising demand. Sales fell to 3.79 billion euros, from 3.93 billion euros, after the dollar's drop against the euro and after Bertelsmann sold a publishing unit. Bertelsmann's BMG music group, which plans to merge with a unit of the Sony Corporation, is trying to emerge from a four-year industry slump caused by illegal song downloads from the Internet and higher consumer spending on products like video games. Bertelsmann, based in Gtersloh, Germany, lost 397 million euros in the period a year earlier.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Voting Machine Executive Retracts Endorsement
description: A spokesman for Diebold Election Systems, which makes voting machines, said that his company's chief executive regretted saying he would help win the election for President Bush. Walden W. O'Dell, the executive, sent out a fund-raising letter last summer saying he was committed to ''helping Ohio deliver its electoral votes for the president next year.'' At a hearing in Washington on the election process, Mark Rudke, Diebold's marketing director, said that Mr. O'Dell regretted his statement and that he had ''pulled back from all fund-raising activities.'' Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Nichols's Defense Set To Begin
description: Lawyers for Terry L. Nichols will begin their case today for his acquittal in the bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building by calling the first of an expected 200 witnesses. Mr. Nichols, 49, is on trial in a state court for 161 counts of first-degree murder, and the state is seeking the death penalty. Mr. Nichols is already serving a life sentence for his conviction in a federal court involving the 1995 bombing. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: Coxsone Dodd, the record producer and entrepreneur who helped invent the Jamaican music industry, died on Tuesday night at his studio in Kingston. He was 72.

title: Many Iraqis Are Skeptical of Bush TV Appeal
description: At a coffee shop on Karada Street here just before 8 p.m., eight men sat on plastic chairs around a crudely hewn wooden coffee table or alongside metal stands just big enough for a tea glass. They sat cross-legged, prayer beads in hand, their eyes glued to the television set, waiting for the American president to speak about the abuses of Iraqi prisoners at the Abu Ghraib prison.

title: Rebuilding Lower Manhattan
description: Gov. George Pataki announced plans yesterday for a July 4 groundbreaking for the tallest tower to be built at the World Trade Center site. For New Yorkers who have been suspicious that the saga of ground zero would be central to the Republican Party's convention in the city in late August, this was good news. The initial work on the grand tower can now begin on behalf of the larger community affected by Sept. 11, and not be used as a backdrop for one campaign or political party.

title: FORD AND CHRYSLER RAISE LIGHT TRUCK INCENTIVES
description: Ford and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler have increased incentives on light trucks after Toyota and Nissan gained market share last month. Ford is offering $1,000 and no-interest 60-month loans on Explorer sport utility vehicles, Excursion and Expedition S.U.V.'s and Freestar minivans, a spokesman, Jim Cain, said. Chrysler added $2,000 to incentives on the Durango sport utility, to a total $3,500, a spokesman, Kevin McCormick, said. General Motors has offered similar incentives since April 1. The American automakers' share of the light truck market in the first four months of this year slid to 71.9 percent from 73.8 percent a year earlier.

title: 36 Hours | Nashville
description: LONG before Nashville became Music City, it was known as the Athens of the South, its aspirations exemplified by the construction of a replica of the Parthenon for Tennessee's centennial in 1896. That Athens became the country music capital hasn't always sat well with its citizens, who are right when they say there is more to Nashville than country. But most would acknowledge that if you have only a weekend, rootsy music of all types is what the city does best. Don't expect the country you hear on the radio; mainstream stars rarely play at home. Instead, expect real-deal crooners, soulful singer-songwriters, A-list session players and bluegrass virtuosos. TAYLOR HOLLIDAY

description: CONTEMPORARY sculpture knows no boundaries. There is no material or technology, from dirt to video, that sculpture won't pick up and exploit for its own ends, and there are no formal parameters like, say, the flatness of painting to constrain it.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The strike at the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Terminal lasted for 112 days this winter and spring, and received about as much attention as a series of poetry readings in Yonkers. It was not a particularly boisterous action. There were only eight pickets each day. Indeed, it was entirely possible, even in the bleak days of February, to make a lunch date there and find oneself practically across the restaurant's threshold before realizing that to enter would be to cross Local 100's line.

title: U.S Troops in Heavy Fighting Around 2 Shiite Holy Cities
description: KARBALA, Iraq, May 7  American soldiers killed at least two dozen insurgents over a 24-hour period, officials said today, as fierce fighting broke out in parts of this holy city controlled by militiamen loyal to a rebel Shiite cleric.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Brewer
description: Asahi Breweries Ltd., Japan's biggest brewer, said it returned to profit in the first quarter as new brands bolstered sales and helped win market share from rivals. Asahi said it had net income of 2.35 billion yen ($21.6 million), or 4.71 yen a share, in the three months ended March 31, in contrast to a loss of 5.07 billion yen, or 10.17 yen a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to 277.2 billion yen from 273 billion yen, the company said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Army Lashes Out At Education Reform Plan
description: In a rare public statement, the military criticized government plans to allow religious high school students access to a broader range of university programs, fearing their future influence in society. Although the Islamic-rooted government insisted that the new law would enhance opportunities for a wider range of high school students, political analysts said the plan was part of an unspoken government policy to promote Islamists in the secular work force. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Plan For Online Medical Journal
description: The Public Library of Science, which publishes free scientific journals online, said it would add a medical journal to its lineup in the fall. The journal, PLoS Medicine, will report on medical research, epidemiology and public health, as well as controversial medical topics after experts have reviewed them. The library, in San Francisco, says it intends to make reliable scientific and medical information public. Subscriptions to some traditional journals exceed $10,000 a year. The group (www.plos.org) published its first online journal, PLoS Biology, last fall. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Creepy Space, With Rats, Just $10,000 a Day; New York's Rare Alleyways Become Hot Spots for Filmmakers
description: The movie is called ''Xtacy,'' a modern film noir that was being filmed around Manhattan a few weeks ago, and like many noirs it ends with a murder. The question facing the producers was simple: where's the most cinematic spot in Manhattan to kill someone?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SABIN, CHARLES
description: SABIN--Charles. The partners, associates and staff of Sabin, Bermant & Gould are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved former senior partner, mentor and friend, Charles Sabin. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife Ruth, daughters Alix and our partner Liz, as well as the entire family. His leadership is the foundation upon which the firm stands today, a legacy of which his family may be justly proud. We will all miss him and cherish his memory forever. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 7 at 11:15AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel 76th And Amsterdam Avenue. At his family's request, contributions may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486-3395.

title: A Night to Give The Young And Talented Their Due
description: Building a career in classical music can be tricky, to say the least, even for young musicians with ample talent. Young Concert Artists is an organization that identifies gifted instrumentalists, singers and composers through yearly auditions; it presents the musicians in concerts and helps manage their careers. title: Losing Our Technical Dominance
description: The United States remains the pre-eminent scientific and technological power in the world, but there are signs that it is losing ground to foreign competitors. To some extent this is inevitable -- and even desirable. The greater the diffusion of scientific capabilities, the better off the world will probably be. Still, the situation in the United States is worrisome. Fewer and fewer young Americans seem interested in technical careers, and fewer young foreigners will be arriving to take their places. If this trend is not reversed, the pool of trained scientists and engineers in this country will shrink, and the shortfalls may harm economic growth and the technical underpinnings of national security.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Supreme Court Gains First Arab
description: A judicial committee chose Salim Joubran, a longtime judge, as the first Arab Israeli to be appointed to a permanent position on Israel's Supreme Court. Mr. Joubran, 57, a Christian from the northern city of Haifa, was named to the Supreme Court on a temporary basis last year. He was one of four judges to receive permanent appointments. Mr. Joubran, who has a law degree from Hebrew University, has served on lower courts dating back to 1982 and has taught at the University of Haifa. Israel's 1.3 million Arab citizens account for close to 20 percent of Israel's population. They vote and have seats in Parliament but often complain of discrimination. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Profit
description: Singapore Telecommunications said it would buy back 3 billion Singapore dollars ($1.78 billion) worth of its shares after reporting a sixfold increase in net profit for the first three months of 2004. The company, known as SingTel, said it earned 1.96 billion Singapore dollars in its fiscal fourth quarter, lifted by an exceptional pretax gain of 2 billion Singapore dollars from the sale of its stake in a Belgian operator, Belgacom. Profit for the year ended March 31 tripled to 4.49 billion Singapore dollars. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Interrogation Methods in Iraq Aren't All Found in Manual

Most effective of all, however, is ''the direct approach'' -- the direct questioning of a prisoner without resorting to coercion of any kind, according to the last military intelligence manual to be made public, dated May 8, 1987.

It was there that the Bush administration began building up a worldwide military detention system, deliberately located on bases outside American soil and sheltered from public visibility and judicial review. It presumed that suspected agents of terrorism did not deserve normal legal protections, and it presumed that American officials could always tell a terrorist from an innocent bystander.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harlem: Man Found To Have Died Of Asphyxia
description: When the worried family of Jose Irizarry, 41, restrained him with tape as he was in the throes of a drug-induced frenzy last month, they played a role in his death later that day, the police said yesterday. On April 6, the police arrived at an Eighth Avenue address in Harlem to find Mr. Irizarry taped and unconscious on the floor, while his mother-in-law explained the behavior that led to his being subdued, the police said. He died hours later at Harlem Hospital Center. An autopsy has determined that Mr. Irizarry died of asphyxia from neck and chest compression as he was restrained while experiencing ''acute cocaine intoxication,'' a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office said. No charges have been filed against any family member, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Going to Glacier? You Should Hurry
description: ON the white-knuckle drive up and over the Continental Divide on Going-to-the-Sun Road in Glacier National Park, each new view -- emerald-colored lakes, knife-edge peaks and vast open valleys -- outdoes the last. The narrow two-lane road hugs the cliffs, rising in a series of switchbacks as it climbs to Logan Pass at 6,646 feet. No wonder this park, in the remote northwestern corner of Montana, claims the nickname Crown of the Continent. Its eye-popping grandeur drew 1.9 million visitors last year to camp, hike, kayak and gawk.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Houston Extends Youth Curfew
description: The Houston City Council extended for three years a curfew on young people, citing a significant decrease in juvenile crime since the ordinance was adopted in 1991. The police reported a 6 percent decline in the number of juvenile arrests and a 17 percent drop in the number of juvenile crime victims in a recent two-year period with intensified enforcement of the curfew. It prohibits residents 18 and younger from being in public from midnight until 6 a.m. and during classroom hours during the school year. State law requires that the curfew be reconsidered every three years. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Bush and King of Jordan Ease Tensions Between Them

No shelf life. Now, with the play 11 weeks into a critics-immune run that has had three extensions and may get a fourth, a discerning audience of high school kids is coolly taking the 45-year-old auteur to task in a post-matinee Public Theater ''talkback session.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Film Studio Loses Appeal
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Stapleton Studios, a start-up film production studio on Staten Island run by the actor Danny Aiello and a group of businessmen, did not have the legal right to fight the city over an eviction. The court said that the city's 2002 decision not to renew Stapleton's permit to occupy vacant city-owned land on Staten Island's waterfront was not ''subject to judicial review.'' The vote reverses an earlier State Supreme Court decision allowing Stapleton to legally oppose the city's move to evict it from the 36-acre property. title: The Roots of Abu Ghraib; My Life as a Guard

When I looked at the photos, I noticed something more: I couldn't take my eyes off the American soldiers. I couldn't stop trying to imagine the scene as one of the photos was set up: ''Hey, let's put 'em in a pyramid. And now, you -- get over there and give me the thumbs-up.''

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Orders Review Of Power Plan

Scherer, near Forsyth, northwest of Macon, that violates the Clean Air Act. The court said that ''without considering the issue at all,'' the E.P.A. assumed that it could consider only the parts of the Scherer plant that Oglethorpe owned and disregard the other parts, which are the polluters. title: 1904:Port Arthur Cut Off : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: ST. PETERSBURG It has just been announced that the Japanese are masters of Port Adams and the surrounding district. The telegraph line and the railroad are cut. Port Arthur, therefore, is completely isolated. The departure of Admiral Alexeieff and the Grand Duke Boris from port Arthur was hastened by the fear the railroad would be cut. Although it is not officially confirmed, it is believed that the obstruction of the mouth of Port Arthur harbor is sufficient to prevent the passage of large warships. Yesterday [May 6], the Japanese began to land at Petsevo, and on the coast near Cape Ferminal, under cover of artillery fire. At this moment about sixty transports were observed bearing down upon the whole front, and posts were retired from the shore. The Russian inhabitants abandoned the town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POOL, J. LAWRENCE
description: POOL--J. Lawrence. We note with sadness the passing of Dr. J. Lawrence Pool, Professor Emeritus of Neurological Surgery at Columbia University's College of Physicians & Surgeons and former Chairman of the Department of Neurological Surgery at the Neurological Institute of New York of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Dr. Pool was one of the greatest neurosurgeons of the 20th century. A masterful and innovative surgeon, he paved the way for many advances in the care of neurosurgical patients. He possessed a brilliant intellect, a keen wit, and an abundance of charm. He was multi-talented: erudite, intellectual, a superb athlete, an excellent water colorist and a thoughtful and interesting author, having written many books on subjects as varied as fly fishing to Revolutionary War history. He was a superb teacher and mentor to countless students and young doctors. His unique combination of talents, wide range of interests, and multiple accomplishments in many fields made him truly one of the most remarkable and inspiring individuals one could ever hope to meet. Our condolences to his family. The Department of Neurological Surgery New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia Univ College of Physicians & Surgeons

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: COURT ORDERS REVIEW OF POWER PLAN A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit decided that the Environmental Protection Agency had acted "arbitrarily and capriciously" in ruling that Oglethorpe Power could receive a building permit for a power plant near Franklin in Heard County when it owns part of another plant, Robert W. Scherer, near Forsyth, northwest of Macon, that violates the Clean Air Act. The court said that "without considering the issue at all," the E.P.A. assumed that it could consider only the parts of the Scherer plant that Oglethorpe owned and disregard the other parts, which are the polluters. The Georgia Power division of the Southern Company is a co-owner. The Sierra Club, which sued, said the plant was under the owners' common control. Oglethorpe did not respond to a request for comment. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERNBERG, IRMA KAD MON
description: STERNBERG -- Irma Kad mon. The Board of Directors and staff of the International Rescue Committee note with great sorrow the passing of our dear retired colleague, Irma Kadmon Sternberg, on May 5th at Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, NY. Irma came to the United States during World War II as a refugee from Nazi-occupied Europe and joined the IRC as a caseworker in New York in 1945. For many years she served as director of refugee resettlement programs before retiring in 1985. With kindness, dignity and respect, she helped thousands of refugees from all parts of the world begin new lives in the United States. Her beloved husband of 53 years, Charles (Carel) Sternberg, former executive director of the IRC, died in 2003. We extend our condolences to Irma's friends and loved ones. Winston Lord and James C. Strickler, M.D. Co-Chairmen of the Board George Rupp, President

title: S.&P. CUTS RATING OF DISABILITY INSURER
description: Standard & Poor's cut the credit rating of the UnumProvident Corporation yesterday to a level below investment grade after the company, a disability insurer, reported a $562 million first-quarter loss. Standard & Poor's lowered UnumProvident's senior debt rating to BB+ from BBB-. The company had $2.8 billion of long-term debt at the end of 2003. The downgrading follows a year in which UnumProvident fired its chief executive, recognized $894 million of reserve shortfalls, sold foreign units and stopped renewing its least profitable policies. title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Six Foreigners Condemned Over H.I.V. Outbreak
description: Five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor were sentenced to death by firing squad on charges of deliberately injecting more than 400 Libyan children with H.I.V-contaminated blood in 1997-98. A Bulgarian doctor was given four years in prison. The suspects, who have been in prison since 1999, pleaded not guilty and said they would appeal. Libya initially accused the C.I.A. and Israeli intelligence of plotting the epidemic but later accused the foreigners of infecting the children as a part of an experiment to find a cure for AIDS. European governments and human rights groups criticized the sentence and said the outbreak was probably caused by unsanitary practices in the hospital before the suspects arrived in Libya. title: The Roots of Abu Ghraib; When Liberators Become Tyrants
description: Fifty years ago today, at dawn on May 7, 1954, after 56 days of battle, silence fell upon the hills of Dien Bien Phu. The French had named the hills Dominique, Batrice and Isabelle, sweet and feminine names, evocative of the mists of the northern Vietnamese countryside. They had been taken and lost, and taken again, and their shell-plowed soil was drenched in sweat and blood. For years to come they would deliver up fragments of human bodies and muddy jungle boots. This once calm mountain valley had become the symbolic graveyard of the 60,000 French soldiers who died in the Indochina war.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: NEW MEXICO: INQUIRY FINDS NURSING HOME PROBLEMS A report to Gov. Bill Richardson by undercover state investigators found improprieties at three nursing homes. The study said that in one home the dogs of staff members routinely urinated and that in another an evaluator posing as a patient with Alzheimer's disease was incorrectly left in an unlocked room. The inquiry also found nursing shortages, improper instructions for medication and inadequate review of records. Mr. Richardson, a Democrat, ordered an audit of all state nursing homes. He said in a statement that nursing homes were providing "tight-fisted care" despite receiving an average of $5,000 a month per patient in public and private financing. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: The New Iraq Crisis; Donald Rumsfeld Should Go
description: There was a moment about a year ago, in the days of ''Mission Accomplished,'' when Donald Rumsfeld looked like a brilliant tactician. American troops -- the lean, mean fighting machine Mr. Rumsfeld assembled -- swept into Baghdad with a speed that surprised even the most optimistic hawks. It was crystal clear that the Defense Department, not State and certainly not the United Nations, would control the start of nation-building. Mr. Rumsfeld, with his steely grin and tell-it-like-it-is press conferences, was the closest thing to a rock star the Bush cabinet would ever see.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Profit At Alcan
description: The aluminum maker Alcan Inc. reported a $106 million profit in the first quarter as prices rose and sales almost doubled after the purchase of Pechiney of France in February. Net income was 28 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $27 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier, Alcan said. Sales rose 93 percent, to $6.2 billion. Alcan benefited from an 18 percent increase in the average price of aluminum on the London Metal Exchange in the quarter, spurred by growing demand from China and an improving global economy. The chief executive, Travis Engen, above, said he expected worldwide aluminum demand this year to increase 8 percent, greater than the forecast of 6 percent growth in aluminum production and supply. Excluding the effects of foreign currency translation and costs for acquisitions and restructuring, profit was 50 cents a share, short of the 57 cents analysts expected. Alcan's share price fell 4 percent.

title: An Art Form Not Confined To the Borders
description: Next month, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art opens its exhibition of about 150 works by the American Impressionist painter Childe Hassam, frames he designed will be at center stage along with his bright canvases and works on paper. The gallery text will note whether a frame was made for a specific work and by which maker. The 440-page catalog will include a scholarly essay on Hassam's approach to frames and how he considered them objects of beauty as well as the packaging that sold the product.

''We appreciate your support,'' the message continued ''in helping us retain a few surprises for summer moviegoers.'' And I appreciate this request, so if you must know exactly what happens in the noisy, digitally souped-up final half-hour of ''Van Helsing,'' which opens today nationwide, you will have to see for yourself.

For he flourished a century ago and gradually faded from musical sight after a heart attack in 1918. Not that he was totally idle in later years. He continued to tinker with his music -- perhaps even, it has been suggested, inserting bold strokes calculated to make earlier works seem more innovative than they actually were.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Marriage Motion Dismissed

In its ruling, the court said the issue had already been raised by other parties and decided. Raymond Flynn, the former Vatican ambassador and mayor of Boston, has filed a similar motion in Suffolk Superior Court in Boston, and it will be heard May 12. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of drug regimens for new AIDS patients misstated its findings about two drug combinations, or cocktails. The one that the researchers termed ''clearly inferior'' -- a mixture of AZT, lamivudine and abacavir -- suppressed the AIDS virus in 74 percent of patients after 48 weeks, not 79 percent after 32 weeks. The more successful cocktail -- AZT, lamivudine and efavirenz, which suppressed the virus in 89 percent of patients -- was also measured after 48 weeks, not 32.

The group operates 36 studios outside of London, including one with a water tank that holds one million gallons for use in the Bond movies. It plans to build one million square feet of studio space over the next 10 years. The company sold 41.7 million shares at 180 pence each. Its stock climbed 20.5 pence, to close at 200.5 pence. title: AMERICA ONLINE BUYS 7.4 MILLION SHARES OF GOOGLE
description: Time Warner said yesterday that its America Online unit bought 7.4 million shares of Google Inc. for $22 million. America Online exercised a warrant this month that allowed it to buy preferred shares of Google, owner of the Internet search engine, Time Warner said in a regulatory filing. America Online's preferred shares of Google will convert to Class B common stock when Google sells shares to the public. Google sold the warrant to America Online two years ago, when it also agreed to provide its search service and advertising for America Online's Web site. America Online now holds about a 3 percent stake in Google, which said last week it would sell shares to the public. America Online's stock may be worth $1.3 billion after Google sells shares to the public.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Slows
description: Inflation in Brazil eased to a five-month low in April, bolstering bets that the central bank would cut interest rates for the third month in a row when it meets in two weeks. The government's statistics institute said that its consumer price index rose 0.37 percent last month, down from 0.47 percent in March. That brought the accumulated inflation rate over the last 12 months to 5.3 percent, below the central bank's year-end target of 5.5 percent. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Alitalia's Share Rally
description: Shares in Alitalia, the Italian airline, rose 19 percent yesterday, a day after the Italian government fired the company's board and said it would seek private investors to invest in the company. The government, which owns 62 percent of Alitalia, named Giancarlo Cimoli, above, on Thursday as the new chief executive and chairman. Mr. Cimoli has led the country's state-owned railway for the last eight years and helped the company become profitable. The airline said this week that it lost 300 million euros in the first four months of the year and had just 200 million euros in cash and liquid assets. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POOL, J. LAWRENCE

Lawrence Pool, devoted alumnus, professor emeritus of neurological surgery, and former chairman of neurosurgery. His innovations in neurosurgery included introduction of the microscope in operations on cerebral aneurysms and development of the myeloscope to pinpoint lower spine problems. He also was two-time National Squash Racquets Champion. His generosity to P&S resulted in an endowed professorship in neurosurgery and a new squash court. description: The nation's employers added hundreds of thousands of jobs for the second month in a row, the Labor Department reported yesterday, offering clear evidence that the pace of hiring is finally picking up speed in response to the strengthening economy.
