title: The Empire Strikes Out
description: This week the world learned that the United States Army has been investigating more than 30 claims of prisoner abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan since December 2002. So far, officials have found a catalog of ''sadistic, blatant and wanton criminal abuses'' at the hands of American captors. This horrible scandal represents the most serious crisis for the coalition since the war on terrorism began. Occupation inevitably creates resentment; but humiliation fosters outright rebellion, and winning back the moral high ground after this calamity is far more important than reasserting control in Falluja or in the Taliban-controlled areas of Afghanistan.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Grave Desecrated A Second Time
description: The grave of James Byrd Jr., whose murder by three white men in 1998 attracted international attention as a hate crime, has been desecrated a second time, the authorities said. Racial slurs were scratched into Mr. Byrd's headstone, which was overturned, said Stanley Christopher, the police chief of of Jasper, a small city 115 miles northeast of Houston. Shortly after Mr. Byrd's burial, vandals stole a small metal nameplate from the grave. Mr. Byrd was 49 when three men chained him to a pickup truck and dragged him to his death. Two of the men were sentenced to death and the third to life imprisonment. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Russian Oil Stake Considered
description: The French oil group Total, which announced quarterly results, said it would consider buying a stake in the Russian oil company Sibneft if Sibneft were to end its merger plan with Yukos, another major Russian oil company. In a conference call to discuss the group's quarterly results, Total's chief financial officer, Robert Castaigne, responded to recent speculation that the two companies were discussing such a stake by saying that Sibneft would have to part ways with Yukos first. Total reported that its quarterly earnings were down 8 percent at 2 billion euros ($2.4 billion) for the first quarter of 2004, while sales dropped 2 percent to 28 billion euros ($33.8 billion). The company said its weaker results were caused by the weakness of the dollar relative to the euro and the rise of hydrocarbon prices, among other factors.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Prime Minister Resigns
description: The royalist prime minister resigned, signaling that after five weeks of violent street protests, King Gyanendra may be willing to reach a compromise on demands for a return to democracy. The king, who took control in 2002, issued a statement saying that a search had begun for a replacement to head a ''broad-based'' government that will conduct general elections before April 2005. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Barney Kessel, 80, a Guitarist With Legends of Jazz, Is Dead
description: Barney Kessel, a guitarist who was both a celebrated jazz soloist and a ubiquitous but anonymous studio musician, died on Thursday at his home in San Diego. He was 80.

title: A Beaten Path Back to Prison
description: Until just a week ago, Lerome Hilson seemed to be in better shape than most of New York City's other parolees. He had been out of prison for 14 months, and now had his own apartment and a full-time job at a Manhattan restaurant. He showed up regularly for his appointments at the parole office and had passed his most recent drug test.

So was the chamber group playing Renaissance music. But the main attraction on Monday night at a benefit for the Theater for a New Audience, a Shakespeare-oriented theater company, was the food, all updated versions of Elizabethan recipes. There was, unsurprisingly, rack of lamb as well as spinach and a salad of baby greens.

They are disturbing images, but so far only one person has complained: the head of catering services at the academy.

title: Liberty, Technology, Duty: Where Peace Overlaps War
description: Disagreements about the nature of government, culture and freedom -- once matters of abstract theory -- have recently become all too urgent. What sort of government is ideal? What are the connections between a culture and its ideas of freedom? And how is freedom to be balanced with the rule of law? The fates of nations at war rest on such questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RESNICK, LAWRENCE M., M.D.
description: RESNICK -- Lawrence M., M.D. The American Journal of Hypertension, Ltd. sadly announces the passing of its Co-Executive Editor, Lawrence M. Resnick, M.D., on Thursday, May 6. Dr. Resnick was an integral part of the American Society of Hypertension and of the American Journal of Hypertension since the Journal's inception in 1987, where he recently became its Executive Editor. Dr. Resnick was a distinguished research scientist in his chosen fields of internal medicine, hypertension and endocrinology. He was world recognized for his research on the calciotropic hormones and on the renin system, in high blood pressure and for his contributions to the treatment of high blood pressure. He was an astute clinician, beloved by the many patients for whom he provided medical care in his role as Professor of Medicine at the New York Presbyterian HospitalCornell University Medical Center. Larry's warm persona, his quick, engaging wit and skillful use of words enabled him to reach out to his colleagues and make important contributions to the science of medical practice that will be long remembered. The membership and staff of the American Society of Hypertension and the American Journal of Hypertension mourn his loss along with his wife, Molly, their three children, his mother and brother. John H. Laragh, M.D. Editor-in-Chief

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Japan Airlines
description: Japan Airlines System, Asia's largest carrier, posted a record annual loss after the SARS and bird flu epidemics deterred air travelers. The company said it expected business travel to improve and help it return to a profit. Japan Air, based in Tokyo, said it lost 88.6 billion yen ($807.2 million) in the year ended March 31, in contrast to a profit of 11.6 billion yen a year earlier. Sales fell 7.3 percent, to 1.93 trillion yen, dragged down by the slump in international travel. International passenger revenue fell 18 percent while sales from domestic travel rose 6 percent.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Member Of Parliament Killed
description: Gunmen opened fire at a political rally held by Bangladesh's main opposition party in the capitol of Dhaka, killing a senior opposition member of Parliament and at least one other person, Reuters reported. The gunmen escaped. Hundreds of members of the opposition Awami league gathered to protest the killing, and were dispersed by police officers wielding batons and tear gas. David Rohde (NYT)

description: The federal Education Department has cautioned New York that an effort to force public universities to steer students away from direct federal loans and toward loans administered through banks would violate federal law.

description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld offered an unambiguous apology Friday to Iraqis abused by their American military jailers. He said he accepted full responsibility for the misdeeds of soldiers on his watch but would not resign simply to quiet partisan critics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMANN, ERNST FEDOR
description: HOFFMANN--Ernst Fedor, a longtime member of the German Department at Hunter College, CUNY, died on April 15, after a brief illness. His career at Hunter and the CUNY Graduate Center spanned over twenty-seven years. He was born in Munich in 1928, the son of Iphigenia (nee Gysis) and Ernst Lothar Hoffmann, and came to the US in 1950 as an exchange student at Cornell University. After studies in Munich and Vienna he returned to the US, where he taught at the Army Language School in Monterey, California. He received his MA and in 1962 a PhD from Yale University. Before coming to Hunter, Professor Hoffmann taught at Yale and Columbia universities. He is survived by his partner, Kathleen Luhrs. Donations to an award in his name may be made to the German Department at Hunter College. Information regarding May 13 memorial service may be obtained by calling 212-772-4980.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Weighing Defendant's Competency
description: Maria Angela Camacho is competent to stand trial in the decapitation of her three children but only because of anti-psychotic drugs, her lawyers told a judge at Brownsville. Ms. Camacho, 24, and John A. Rubio, 23, were arrested last year after police found the bodies of their three children, ages 3, 1 and 2 months, in the couple's apartment. A hearing in a state court has been scheduled later this month to determine whether Ms. Camacho is mentally retarded. Mr. Rubio was convicted of capital murder and sentenced to death. I became a primary-care doctor in the 1970's because I, like Dr. Sanders, value relationships. I agree that patients want to be heard, and I believe all of the arts (literature, painting, music, theater and dance) have something to teach physicians about the human condition, suffering and healing. But as long as the corporate model dominates health care, the lessons of narrative medicine will remain with other dim memories of medical school.

title: PLAN TO EASE CONGESTION
description: Governor McGreevey announced a plan last week to create one-way tolls on the Garden State Parkway at the Raritan and Asbury Park plazas to ease congestion, improve air quality and cut down on accidents. The plan is expected to go into effect in September, when toll barriers in the southbound lanes of the Asbury Park Plaza and those in the northbound lanes through the Raritan plaza are demolished. Tolls will be doubled to 70 cents for northbound drivers passing through the Asbury Park toll booths and southbound drivers at the Raritan plaza. Express E-ZPass lanes, which allow motorists to drive through a plaza at 55 miles per hour, will be installed at both plazas as well as in both directions of the Toms River plaza. Express E-Zpass is now in operation at the Pascack Valley plaza and the 18W interchange of the New Jersey Turnpike, both in Bergen County. George James

title: The War's Lost Weekend
description: JUST when you've persuaded yourself yet again that this isn't Vietnam, you are hit by another acid flashback. Last weekend that flashback was to 1969. It was in June 1969 that Life magazine ran its cover story ''The Faces of the American Dead in Vietnam: One Week's Toll,'' the acknowledged prototype for Ted Koppel's photographic roll-call of the American dead in Iraq on ''Nightline.'' It was in November 1969 that a little-known reporter, Seymour Hersh, broke the story of the 1968 massacre at My Lai, the horrific scoop that has now found its match 35 years later in Mr. Hersh's New Yorker revelation of a 53-page Army report detailing ''numerous instances of 'sadistic, blatant and wanton criminal abuses' at Abu Ghraib.'' No doubt some future edition of the Pentagon Papers will explain just why we restored Saddam Hussein's hellhole to its original use, torture rooms included, even as we allowed Baghdad's National Library, a repository of Mesopotamia's glorious pre-Baath history, to be looted and burned.

title: Marxian Madness, Western Hoo-Hah And a Great Escape
description: MASQUERADE (MGM, June 15) -- This elegant romantic thriller whooshed through movie theaters in 1988 before anyone saw it. The American director, Bob Swaim, had made a name for himself in France directing the policier ''La Balance.'' But ''Masquerade'' is the work he should have been acclaimed for. The movie is a remarkably assured film noir version of Henry James's ''Washington Square'' set in the indolent summer swankiness of the Hamptons. The cleverly plotted and well-observed script -- by Dick Wolf, the creator of ''Law and Order'' -- is like what might have resulted had James M. Cain collaborated with John O'Hara. The characters seem to hope their greed and lust won't look so tawdry if they are presented in the finery of Town and Country layouts.

title: Fabrice Luchini
description: A FAVORITE with the best French directors, Fabrice Luchini is the sort of actor who can do just about anything -- except make a lasting impression on audiences here. One hopes Patrice Leconte's ''Intimate Strangers'' will change all that, because Mr. Luchini's witty way with understatement, particularly in comic roles, is something to savor. Mr. Leconte's latest film is a subtle romantic comedy with a farcical premise and a melancholy streak. Mr. Luchini is its straight man, playing a successful but solitary tax lawyer who is mistaken, by an unhappily married woman (Sandrine Bonnaire), for the psychiatrist down the hall. Assured that they have an appointment even though it's not in his book, Mr. Luchini settles back to listen to his new client's financial woes. As she hesitantly begins to describe her husband's alarmingly unpleasant sexual predilections, Mr. Luchini goes as still as a mouse and as alert as one, too, his bright eyes widening just enough to reveal his shock and fascination.

title: Those Strangers on a Train, Nine Years Later
description: ''BEFORE SUNRISE,'' Richard Linklater's charming 1995 comedy starring Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy, ended with a promise: the two characters, Jesse and Celine, would meet in Vienna six months later to continue the romance that began with a chance meeting on a train. Only a modest success at the time of its release, the film has become a dorm-room classic (much like Mr. Linklater's first two films, ''Slacker'' and ''Dazed and Confused'') with its portrait of reluctant adults torn between the cynicism of the day and the romance of their youth. Now Mr. Linklater, Ms. Delpy and Mr. Hawke have collaborated on ''Before Sunset,'' which picks up the story nine years later when Jesse and Celine meet at a Paris bookstore where Jesse is promoting his first novel, based on the night they spent together. The three share screenwriting credit on the film, which is dialogue heavy and packed with stirring monologues and grown-up revelations. In March, ''Before Sunset'' played at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Mr. Linklater's hometown. He joined Ms. Delpy and Mr. Hawke to talk with Sarah Hepola about their collaboration.

title: The Best Live Footage You May Never See
description: 'MC5: A TRUE TESTIMONIAL' -- During their supernova ascension and decline, the members of the late-60's Detroit band MC5 became famous for draping themselves in American flags, replicating the free-jazz frenzy of late Coltrane through rock 'n' roll and preaching peace, love and, um, armed revolution. In this new documentary film by David C. Thomas and Laurel Legler (Future/Now Films), the three surviving band members tell their stories with vigorous honesty, almost as if they had never been asked before. The film has been screened at many festivals and can currently be seen at New York's Cinema Village, but its DVD release -- which was to have been last Tuesday -- has been held up, perhaps permanently, by legal disputes between the band's guitarist Wayne Kramer and the filmmakers. It's a shame that few people will see it: when the band is at its brief, brittle peak, the live footage is extraordinary. In one sequence, a gig identified onscreen as ''Media Conference, Buffalo, N.Y., March, 1969,'' a stageful of hippies -- band members, audience, all mixed together -- whirl in and out of contortions. The Buffalo hippies join hands to form a train and tear around the theater; people clutch each other in exhaustion, throw their hands in the air as if they've just caught the last fly ball of the World Series. It's the rock show at its absolute best: highly refined chaos.

title: Corrections
description: The Your Home column last Sunday, about renting out an apartment in a house, referred imprecisely to the effect of antidiscrimination laws. While city and state laws against discrimination apply to buildings with three units or more, and to single-family homes offered for rent, the laws do not always apply to two-family buildings. In New York City, a two-family house is exempt from the city's Human Rights Law if occupied by the owner or a member of the owner's family and if the rental is not offered to the general public. Outside the city, a two-family home is exempt from the state's Human Rights Law if the building is owner-occupied unless local laws are more restrictive.

Recipient of awards from the Baltimore Museum; Argent Gallery; Silvermine Guild; National Academy of Design; American Art Heritage Show; and of the Cramer Prize and others. Listed in Who's Who of American Women; Who's Who in American Art; Who's Who in the East; Fellow, International Institute of Arts and Letters; Dictionary of International Biography: Two Thousand Women of Distinction; Who's Who of Women. title: Marxian Madness, Western Hoo-Hah And a Great Escape
description: SHOWGIRLS V.I.P. EDITION -- (MGM, July 27) There's been much debate over whether Paul Verhoeven's sleazy 1995 fable about an ambitious tootsie named Nomi Malone (Elizabeth Berkley) is a good, bad or good-bad movie. Another question: Did Mr. Verhoeven know what he was doing when he laid on the seamy glitz, or did he set out to forge a serious expos of ruthless showgirl shenanigans in Las Vegas? Nomi's nails -- glittery enameled pincers laced with sparkly sun-ray designs -- give the whole game away. These are serious nails -- the sort of thing to which a filmmaker must give some thought. And with these tacky talons, Mr. Verhoeven winks a message at us: none of us is immune to tales of decadence, fame and ruthless ambition. With ''Showgirls,'' Verhoeven resurrected the show-biz melodrama. The movie's brazenness is poisonously delicious, particularly the scene in which Nomi, a mere chorus girl, discreetly sends the lead dancer (Gina Gershon) tumbling down a set of steps, knowing she's next in line to take her place. Some of the extra features here, particularly a lap-dance tutorial by the dancers of the ''gentleman's club'' Scores, are gimmicky in a way the movie isn't. But this set does come with a fine pair of sequined pasties, which do fall into the ''so bad they're good'' category. STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

title: 'The Hamilton Case'
description: Aname is the first story that attaches itself to a life. Consider mine: Stanley Alban Marriott Obeysekere. It tells of geography, history, love and uncertainty. I was born on an island suspended midway on the golden trade route between East and West-a useful bauble, fingered and pocketed by the Portuguese, Dutch and British in turn. In 1902, when I was born, Sir Alban Marriott was Governor and he agreed to be my godfather. How could he refuse? He had been in thrall to my mother ever since she sent him the skin of a leopard she had shot, along with a note. I shall call on you between five and six this evening. The skin is for the small blue reception room, which is ideally suited to fornication and whatnot. Her name was Maud and she was a great beauty. Also a first-rate shot. In Scotland she had stalked deer with the Prince of Wales; his performance, she reported, was mediocre. He presented her with a brooch fashioned from an eagle's talon mounted on silver and onyx. Mater dismissed it as monumentally obvious and palmed it off on her stewardess in lieu of a tip on her voyage home.

title: Celebrating The Green
Marxian Madness, Western Hoo-Hah And a Great Escape
description: DUEL IN THE SUN (MGM, May 25) -- When the producer David O. Selznick decided to outdo his ''Gone With the Wind,'' the result was this galumphing slab of western hoo-hah, which springs equally from the hothouse and the nut house. Jennifer Jones, thrashing and sneering and flashing her eyes (all the more noticeable because she's in dark pancake), plays a half-Mexican hottie who wants to be good but who can't resist the charms of an evil wrangler (Gregory Peck). The humid, lascivious atmosphere that the director, King Vidor, whipped up is so effective that even Peck manages a sexy performance. Epic kitsch, the movie plays like one long paroxysm -- especially Dimitri Tiomkin's ludicrously overwrought score (and there's nearly 15 minutes more of it in this DVD, which includes the composer's prologue and exit music). But the picture, from 1946, is often startlingly gorgeous to look at. The painted backdrops of Texas throb with bleeding color so intense that it looks as if the Surrealists and the Sierra Club had collaborated on a series of particularly lurid postcards. CHARLES TAYLOR

Even some fans who had deliberately sought the document out regretted reading it. What fun was watching if you already knew everything that was going to happen?

title: Corrections
description: The Your Home column last Sunday, about renting out an apartment in a house, referred imprecisely to the effect of antidiscrimination laws. While city and state laws against discrimination apply to buildings with three units or more, and to single-family homes offered for rent, the laws do not always apply to two-family buildings. In New York City, a two-family house is exempt from the city's Human Rights Law if occupied by the owner or a member of the owner's family and if the rental is not offered to the general public. Outside the city, a two-family home is exempt from the state's Human Rights Law if the building is owner-occupied unless local laws are more restrictive.

title: Marxian Madness, Western Hoo-Hah and a Great Escape
description: SHOWGIRLS V.I.P. EDITION (MGM, July 27) There's been much debate over whether Paul Verhoeven's sleazy 1995 fable about an ambitious tootsie named Nomi Malone (Elizabeth Berkley) is a good, bad or good-bad movie. Another question: Did Mr. Verhoeven know what he was doing when he laid on the seamy glitz, or did he set out to forge a serious expose of ruthless showgirl shenanigans in Las Vegas? Nomi's nails  glittery enameled pincers laced with sparkly sun-ray designs  give the whole game away. These are serious nails  the sort of thing to which a filmmaker must give some thought. And with these tacky talons, Mr. Verhoeven winks a message at us: none of us is immune to tales of decadence, fame and ruthless ambition. With "Showgirls," Verhoeven resurrected the show-biz melodrama. The movie's brazenness is poisonously delicious, particularly the scene in which Nomi, a mere chorus girl, discreetly sends the lead dancer (Gina Gershon) tumbling down a set of steps, knowing she's next in line to take her place. Some of the extra features here, particularly a lap-dance tutorial by the dancers of the "gentleman's club" Scores, are gimmicky in a way the movie isn't. But this set does come with a fine pair of sequined pasties, which do fall into the "so bad they're good" category. STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

title: The Last Word on Haydn's
description: WHETHER or not Haydn's ''Seven Last Words'' was, as friends quoted the composer, ''the very finest of my works'' or ''one of my most successful,'' he was reluctant to let it go. Commissioned for Holy Week in Cadiz, Spain, in the mid-1780's, the seven adagios for orchestra were soon followed by a version for string quartet. A decade or so later, this remarkable music still occupied Haydn's imagination, and he produced one more version with vocal solos, chorus and an added section for wind band. A solo piano version, approved though not made by Haydn, was also published.

title: 'Little Black Book of Stories'
description: There were once two little girls who saw, or believed they saw, a thing in a forest. The two little girls were evacuees, who had been sent away from the city by train, with a large number of other children. They all had their names attached to their coats with safety-pins, and they carried little bags or satchels, and the regulation gas-mask. They wore knitted scarves and bonnets or caps, and many had knitted gloves attached to long tapes which ran along their sleeves, inside their coats, and over their shoulders and out, so that they could leave their ten woollen fingers dangling, like a spare pair of hands, like a scarecrow. They all had bare legs and scuffed shoes and wrinkled socks. Most had wounds on their knees in varying stages of freshness and scabbiness. They were at the age when children fall often and their knees were unprotected. With their suitcases, some of which were almost too big to carry, and their other impedimenta, a doll, a toy car, a comic, they were like a disorderly dwarf regiment, stomping along the platform.

title: Marking History, In Big Letters

The sign, married to the slogan ''Good to the Last Drop,'' stood for more than 50 years, until the plant closed in 1992. All that remains is a last 12-foot-high drop that was donated to the city's historical museum, home these days to pictures from the film ''On the Waterfront,'' set on the city's coastline when it was still an industrial stronghold.

title: Poverty's Palette
description: In our mind's eye, much of the past exists in black and white. This is particularly true of Depression-era America, in large part because of the unforgettable monochrome images created by the New Deal-sponsored photographers who traversed the country in the 1930's and early 1940's, chronicling the lives of its citizens. About 160,000 of their pictures are collected in the archives of the Library of Congress. Less well known are the roughly 1,600 of these photographs that were shot in color -- most notably by the photographers Russell Lee and Jack Delano -- using Kodachrome film, which Kodak introduced in 1936. This month, the Library of Congress and Harry N. Abrams are making a substantial collection of these images available for the first time in a book called ''Bound for Glory: America in Color 1939-43.'' As the writer Paul Hendrickson notes in his introduction to the volume, these photos give us more than just blues and yellows and reds -- they offer ''a new and complementary way of comprehending our national identity.''

title: Julie Delpy
description: IN Richard Linklater's ''Before Sunset,'' a young Parisian named Celine (Julie Delpy) informs an American writer, Jesse (Ethan Hawke), who's heading back to New York, that she's turned her back on romance. ''I have still a lot of dreams, just not in regard to my love life any more,'' she says briskly. ''It doesn't make me sad, it's just the way it is.'' Those last words come out in a subdued shriek, as if she's daring him to contradict her. Three minutes of verbal dueling later, Jesse is planted on her sofa looking anguished and joyful. She sits on the bed, strumming a guitar and singing him a waltz she wrote about a long-ago ''one-night thing'': theirs. The lyrics are light and rueful, like Ms. Delpy's voice. Then she reaches the punch line. ''My heart will stay yours until I die,'' she sings; and because neither her tone nor her expression changes, the nakedness of the declaration takes your breath away.

title: 'American Desert'
description: THAT THEODORE STREET WAS dead was not a matter open to debate. The irony of his accidental death went unobserved as no one knew that Theodore was on his way to commit suicide when he was, shall we say, interrupted. Now the irony is lost amid the confusion created by Ted's death, departure, demise, dissolution and further by the fact that Ted chooses to relate his own story in third person, an unusual (the occasional politician and athlete aside), but acceptable device, given that, in a most profound way, he stood-or stands even-outside himself, not so much on the parapet of consciousness but of life itself, it being perhaps the case that neither entails, necessarily, the other. But regardless of where Ted stood, or stands, he was on his way to the beach where he had every intention of marching into the ocean until it was over his head and taking a deep, lung-filling breath of water which, according to his limited knowledge of human physiology, would result in a termination of his life, barring the interference of some lifeguard or Boy Scout or Girl Scout, though he had never found Girl Scouts to be terribly overzealous or meddlesome. He was driving at a respectable clip along Ocean Boulevard when a fat man chased his nails-painted poodle out into the street before a UPS truck, causing the driver of the huge, brown block to swerve and slide into a lane of oncoming traffic, the oncoming traffic in this case being Ted Street in his 1978 Lancia coupe. The truck and the Lancia met violently and whereas his vehicle halted quite abruptly, Ted did not, but continued in the same direction he had been traveling through the already cracked windscreen. Remarkably, Ted's face suffered not a single scratch and neither did his body break about the ribs, clavicles, arms or legs, but his head did become rather cleanly detached from the rest of him. It was a jagged but complete wound around his neck that left one seasoned police officer vomiting by the accordioned front fender of the Lancia while the young rookie on patrol with him stood, mouth agape, staring at the head lying on the asphalt. Unlike the stories of beheaded Frenchmen stealing one last, pitiful look at their cast-off bodies, Ted had no such perception. He died instantly and, in a manner of speaking, completely. The UPS man was beside himself, so much so that he would later attend Ted Street's funeral and subsequently take a civil service examination in order to change his profession. The coroner's wagon came with a representative of the coroner, not the coroner himself, and the young man observed Ted's head from his wagon door and was satisfied that he was dead, making the requisite marks on his clipboard, but having to call his office to ask whether head and body should be placed in the same or separate bags. Ted's head was placed under his left arm, the fingers of his hand falling over his mouth which was frozen partly open, and the cool vinyl bag was zipped from bottom to top. The ride in the coroner's wagon to the morgue was protracted, the medical examiner's assistant stopping at a fast-food restaurant, his mother's house, a comic-book store and a remote parking lot where he charged gang thugs a dollar each to "see the stiff."

title: Risen From Dresden's Ashes
description: The Church of Our Lady (Frauenkirche in German), a Protestant church constructed in Dresden under the rule of the Catholic Dukes of Saxony, symbolized 18th-century religious tolerance. The bell-shaped dome and unusual elevated choir produced legendary effects. Richard Wagner had the premiere of his ''Love Feast of the Apostles'' there in 1843. A masterpiece of German Baroque architecture, the church defined Dresden's skyline from 1743 until Feb. 13, 1945, when Allied bombers leveled most of the city. The 12,000-ton sandstone dome collapsed after two days of intense fires, and destroyed the famous ''Christ in Gethsemane'' altarpiece designed by Johann Christian Feige and an organ that Bach had played.

His selection of images -- of the horrors of war, portraits of Picasso and Cartier-Bresson, of treasures of the Kremlin, actors on the set of the film ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' and of his beloved dog, Thor -- blends into his account of ''waiting . . . for that fleeting touch of magic on the face of life itself.'' Duncan joined the Marines and photographed World War II, then shot fishing expeditions on the Miskito coast of Nicaragua, landscapes in Ireland and Afghanistan, Palestinian refugee camps in the Gaza Strip and marines in Vietnam. He was an outspoken opponent of the war (''beardless children fought wars for combat innocent tycoon-politicians who hijacked America's military -- camouflaged their agendas and ambitions then sold them to a trusting nation through media extravaganza''), but his images of combat should not overshadow others, particularly his series of Berbers in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco; they are quiet yet stunning and rich in color, and no less powerful. This is an important reform, but unless it is done right, provisional ballots could actually disenfranchise many of the voters they were intended to help.

He is also a character, which means he sometimes talks to himself -- that is, the real Mario, playing the fictional Melvin, talks to the fictional young Mario. A conversation about their work sounds like a pitch meeting for a new ripped-from-the-headlines TV series: ''L.A. Law and Order.'' The stories go on literally for hours, and, well, you couldn't make this stuff up, which is ostensibly why the best-selling crime novelist Michael Connelly is here in the squad room, a stuffy, essentially characterless enclosure with a few desks pushed together. He's just starting a new book, and on this January morning he's foraging for material.

title: Marxian Madness, Western Hoo-Hah And a Great Escape
description: IN AMERICA -- (Fox, May 11) With ''In America,'' the director Jim Sheridan -- along with his co-writers, his daughters Naomi and Kirsten -- tells a version of his own life story: in the early 80's he moved, with his wife and two children, from Ireland to New York to pursue a theater career. This delicately calibrated picture is proof that even if there really are no new stories, there will always be new ways to tell them. Mr. Sheridan tells his, largely about adjusting to life in a place that is sometimes not so welcoming, through the faces of his actors, Paddy Considine, Samantha Morton, the sisters Emma and Sarah Bolger and Djimon Hounsou, as a neighbor who becomes part of their clan. In his seductively conversational commentary track, Mr. Sheridan breaks stride every so often to exclaim over one of his actors' faces. Of Ms. Morton: ''I love that woman's eyes! How can you not?'' Noting a particularly striking shot of 5-year-old Emma Bolger, whose unstudied performance is one of the picture's marvels, he blurts out, ''Look at that face!'' as if he were seeing it for the first time. ''In America'' is bracingly generous, the kind of movie you get when a filmmaker is more in love with his actors than he is with his own story. STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

In later comics, the rechristened Catwoman donned a giant feline mask, but the figure-hugging catsuit didn't show up until the mid-60's -- about the time that my Catwoman, Julie Newmar, made her slinky entrance into the painfully campy TV series opposite Adam West's milk-drinking, model-citizen Batman.

title: Mistaken Ashes

They started biting humans, and soon London was overrun by rage-virus-crazed zombies killing one another. There is a heavy ''Night of the Living Dead'' element in the first half of this thriller, but otherwise it's original end-of-the-world sci-fi. Jim escapes to the country with three new friends, but when they finally make contact with an organized group of uninfected humans, they seem more dangerous than the zombies -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:05 a.m. on HBO.

The brokenness of the world has had cataclysmic effects, which includes the weather getting bad. But a natural disaster does not mean that God says, 'Today I think I'll kill some twins in Arkadelphia and rip their bodies apart.'"

title: Fighting Anxiety Over Peril in the Sky or on Land

title: And You Thought Art in New York Was a Jungle
description: EARLIER this year I discovered, by chance, one of the most enchanting cultural sites in Latin America. While walking the streets of Belize City last January I ducked into an art gallery called the Image Factory, hoping to escape the midday heat. There I struck up a conversation with Gilvano Swasey, a slight, unassuming 29-year-old artist and curator. He filled me in on the Factory and its owner, Yasser Musa, a dynamic 33-year-old impresario whose gallery has nurtured an impressive flowering of Belizean contemporary art. Mr. Swasey ended our conversation with an invitation to see a sculpture park hidden in the jungle. ''Not many people outside of Belize know about it,'' he said. ''You ought to drive out and see.'' A few weeks later, in early March, I talked Mr. Swasey and Mr. Musa into joining me.

title: Page Two: May 2-8; SHARON'S DILEMMA
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon remains committed to his proposal to withdraw Israel from the Gaza Strip, though his own Likud Party overwhelmingly rejected the plan in a referendum a week ago. The ballot was nonbinding, yet Mr. Sharon faces a dilemma as he plots his next move. If puts the same plan to his cabinet, it could again face rejection. If he dilutes the proposal, and tries to keep some Israeli soldiers and settlers in Gaza, he could lose the backing of Israelis who currently support the move. Opinion polls show that 60 percent or more of Israelis favor a full withdrawal from Gaza. Yet Mr. Sharon, the leading advocate of settlement building for decades, has been unable to win over his traditional right-wing allies. He needs their support to keep his coalition government intact. But from their perspective, handing over Gaza to the Palestinians would be a ''reward for terrorism.'' Greg Myre

title: A Tip of the Hat to Maurice Chevalier
description: SEASON after season, the fashion seers attempt to intuit what the man of tomorrow will want. In truth, though, many men prefer yesterday to tomorrow. Even the farthest seeing prophet might do well to look back to the Great Plains sage E. W. Howe, who summed up the matter pretty well nearly a century ago. ''When a man buys a new hat, he wants one just like the one he had before,'' he wrote. ''A woman isn't that way.''

title: Marxian Madness, Western Hoo-Hah And a Great Escape
description: THE MARX BROTHERS COLLECTION (Warner Home Video, May 4, five discs) -- The Marx Brothers' glory years at Paramount produced such classics of American dada as ''Duck Soup'' and ''Horse Feathers.'' What followed -- all of it, save for ''Love Happy'' -- is collected in this five-disc set. The movies range from the heights of ''A Night at the Opera'' and ''A Day at the Races'' to the doldrums of ''Go West'' and ''The Big Store.'' These last two appear here on a single disc. Another single disc features the similarly uninspired ''At the Circus'' and ''Room Service.'' As it happens, the set's best titles are also available individually.

title: Alan King, Comic With Chutzpah, Dies at 76
description: Alan King, the stand-up comedian who parlayed a borscht-belt sense of humor, a tummler's cheek and a big appetite for the limelight into a thoroughgoing show business career that lasted more than half a century, died Sunday morning at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Kings Point, N.Y.

title: The Rites of Spring
description: As the school year draws to a close, graduation season begins again -- a time for girls in white dresses, misty-eyed grandparents, bromidic speeches and plenty of gift-giving. Below are some of the season's best commencement offerings, both for students wondering what to wear and well-wishers wondering what to give. Let the pomp and circumstance begin.

title: Hi, Honey, I'm At the Airport
description: THE great 18th-century architectural engraver Piranesi didn't have John F. Kennedy International Airport in mind when he drew his famous, dread-inducing sketches of gaping halls, dark chambers and narrow stairs sweeping nowhere. But he probably would have recognized the purgatories that are today's international airports.

title: BENEFITS
description: Preserving the Arts

title: Scary
description: There used to be a column in Spy magazine, Ten Years Ago in Spy, which featured astonishing and, of course, completely fictitious acts of journalistic foresight. ''NASA's enthusiasm notwithstanding, the space shuttle is a potentially deadly hodgepodge of untested technologies,'' ran one breathless article. ''High on the list of suspected components are the enormous flexible gaskets. . . . ''

title: The Odd Donor Couple
description: THE press agent who gave Neil Simon a kidney is at first reluctant to be interviewed. Bill Evans, boyish looking at 54, is a press agent of the old school, trained in the notion that the publicist's name stays out of the paper. He is a fellow accustomed to keeping his emotions in control, who jokes that Mr. Simon is now working on a play about growing up in a reserved WASP household in Ohio. Jokes are fine. His kidney loves living on Park Avenue, Mr. Evans will write in a note a few weeks after the surgery, but it's really looking forward to Bel Air in a couple of months.

title: An Award for Midler, A Slap at Robert Moses
description: Moses may have made some mistakes in his building of Long Island's parks and roads, but, on the whole, he was a genius who enabled the lower and middle classes of the metropolitan area to have easy access to the beaches. Perhaps Ms. Midler, having been brought up in Hawaii, does not realize the impact of not being able to use the beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, SONIA
description: ROSENBERG--Sonia. Passed away on Friday, May 7th, 2004. Survived by her loving daughter, Susan, dear son-inlaw, Stuart, and beloved grandchildren, Darin and Danielle. She was the former president of the Sunny and Abe Rosenberg Foundation, lifelong trustee of the Charles Guttman Foundation and generous benefactor to countless philanthropic organizations in Israel, Palm Beach and New York City. Graveside service Wednesday, May 12th at 2:45PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Ave, Glendale NY. For directions, please call the cemetery at 718-821-0200. The Shiva will be directly after the burial on Wednesday until 9PM at her home, 980 Fifth Ave., apt 21A (corner of 79th Street)

Haldeman, now president and chief executive of the company's Putnam Investments unit, at the left; Mr. Haldeman was promoted last November from senior managing director.

description: HOCHBERG--Frances Helfont Herwitz, 96, on April 30th, 2004 at her residence in Miami Beach, FL. Graveside services will be held on May 17, 10 AM at Mt. Nebo Memorial Gardens, Miami, FL.

title: The Life of the Party?
description: Because his state has a rather small population and because he has served in public office since 1982, Bill Richardson is fairly visible in New Mexico, but the crowd at Palacio Bar was still surprised when he popped in during a late-night pub crawl last month. The governor was at the tail end of a supersaturated day in Las Cruces -- morning press conference, power lunch, three speeches, two dinners, a fund-raiser, 39 constituent meetings at five minutes a pop -- but 16 hours later, at 10:30 p.m., he was still rippling with the energy of a fire hose. ''I'll have your best tequila,'' Richardson shouted as he walked in the door. At 56, he was older than most of the startled patrons by a coefficient of two. A biker walked by. ''Qu pasa, muchacho?'' the governor asked.

title: A Backyard Bluesfest With Talent Front and Center
description: TOMORROW morning at 10:30, Toni Braxton, Macy Gray and India.Arie will lend their voices to cartoon images of themselves in ''Bluestock,'' a half-hour ''Blue's Clues'' special on Nickelodeon in which Joe, Blue and their perky sidekicks hold a backyard jam session. The show combines ''Blue's'' trademark tunes, a few nursery rhymes and a live-action segment of They Might Be Giants performing a song from their children's album, ''No!'' The result is an energy-filled medley fit for a grown-up. Ms. Braxton lends her smoky contralto to a bluesy rendition of ''The Planets Song'' with Tickety; Ms. Gray adds her raspy pizazz to ''The Dance Song,'' with Periwinkle at her side; and India.Arie and Mailbox turn ''Mailtime'' into a virtual reggae anthem.

title: Hell From the Air: California's Toxic Landscape
description: RIDING in a steeply banking Cessna four-seater three years ago, David Maisel leaned out into a clamorous, icy wind and photographed the toxic, desiccated surface of Owens Lake. ''You feel like you're descending into these layers of hell,'' he says of the plane's dive from 3,500 feet. ''You're a disembodied eye and the lake bed has this corporeal aspect. It's like a body that has undergone surgery, with red veins that seem internal.''

title: Casting a Gang Member? Call Suspect Entertainment
description: THE real gang member had every reason to feel disrespected. This was his park, after all, and the five fierce-looking thugs lounging around a picnic table were sporting enemy tattoos and making gang hand signs he did not recognize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, DWIGHT F. III.
description: DAVIS--Dwight F. III. The grandson and namesake of the donor of the Davis Cup, died at age 68, on May 7, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering, in New York. Following graduation from Harvard College in 1959, Mr. Davis began a long career in advertising. He served as a Board member and director of the US Tennis Association's Education Foundation. Mr. Davis is survived by his wife Anne Marie, and three children, Daphne Bazer, Dwight F. Davis IV, Christopher Davis, and seven grandchildren. His wit and intellect will be missed by his family and friends. A funeral service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave. and 71st St., at 1 PM, on Friday, May 14.

title: The Week Ahead; POLITICS
description: According to John Kerry's official campaign calendar, this week is health care week. Mr. Kerry is planning to travel the country, giving speeches fleshing out his plan to expand health care coverage for Americans. Even as Mr. Kerry's aides were putting the final touches on his health care speeches and forums, they seemed resigned to the likelihood that his time will be spent dealing with other issues than health care, given the cascading events in Washington and Iraq. Not surprisingly, that did not appear to particularly distress the Kerry camp.

I am a flight attendant and I have to disagree with Mr. Stephens and his observation of flight attendants standing idly by and ''chatting'' while the customers ''struggle to get heavy bags in the overhead compartment.''

description: THINK it's tough finding a plumber when you need one? Ask Clinton C. Kershaw, the owner of Mr. Rooter Plumbing in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., about 90 miles north of New York City. His business, fixing toilets for $90 or septic systems for $7,000, is doing so well that its 15 plumbers are having a hard time keeping up with the work.

title: Cricket Players' Wish: Just a Patch of Grass
description: COMING to America entails countless challenges for immigrants: how to find work, where to live and how to recreate a life uprooted from the language and past you are most familiar with. But for some immigrants there is a concern that exists not too far outside of all these: where do you have to go to find a decent game of pickup cricket?

title: Editorial Observer; A Meeting of Cattlemen From Two Cultures on the Mexican Border
description: In modern, industrialized agriculture, the benign cow sometimes looks like a nightmare creature, a carrier of human fears about E. coli, environmental degradation, mad cow disease and dire concentration in the meatpacking business. But none of this is the cow's fault. And in a few places, the cow is still something more than a warm-blooded economic integer or a plague on the hoof. In those places cattle still anchor a way of life, a grassland culture of great subtlety and beauty. Not long ago, I visited a windswept region in New Mexico and Arizona, along the Mexican border, with representatives from two of those cattle cultures: a coalition of local ranchers and scientists, called the Malpai Borderlands Group, and a group of Masai from Kenya and Tanzania.

title: Page Two: May 2-8; Cast Your Vote, Get a Souvenir
description: AFTER the Florida debacle in the 2000 presidential election, several states rushed to buy A.T.M.-like electronic voting machines. Millions of Americans are expected to be using them this November.

description: COONEY--Carol A. On May 6, 2004. Daughter of James and the late Viola. Former wife of Bernard. Sister of James, Peter and Maureen. Loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. Funeral from the Hanley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, Monday 8:30AM. Mass 9:30AM Our Lady of Pity Church. Interment to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery. Visiting 2-4 and 7-9 Saturday and Sunday. In lieu of flowers donations to Pax Christi Hospice would be appreciated.

title: Gaspard Ulliel
description: GASPARD ULLIEL is French cinema's rising star, repeatedly honored in the category of most promising actor. But playing his first leading role, opposite Emmanuelle Bart in Andr Tchin's ''Strayed,'' he seems fully arrived, showing us the facets of a complex and mercurial character like a blackjack dealer shuffling a deck of cards.

title: Getting Away From the Job, But Keeping a Hand in It
description: After 34 years as a dentist, building a 5,000-patient practice, Dr. Robert S. Kull is ready to retire. Except, he can't. ''I have four kids who went to private schools and colleges and some of them went on to get advanced degrees,'' he said, and he spent money on their educations rather than putting it in his retirement fund.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE FUTURE OF FREEDOM: Illiberal Democracy at Home and Abroad, by Fareed Zakaria. (Norton, $14.95.) In updating Tocqueville's critique of American democracy and extending it to the rest of the world, the editor of Newsweek International argues that liberty is actually threatened by an excess of democracy, both in the United States and abroad, and that a ''simple-minded populism'' has thrown the American political system out of whack. Last year our reviewer, Niall Ferguson, found this a ''brave and ambitious book'' that ''deserves a wide readership.''

title: The Nation: Exit Options; They've Apologized. Now What?
description: A MILITARY defeat is a damaging thing, and Iraq remains a tense battleground. But a moral one may be more devastating and more enduring for a power like the United States that has long held that its actions are driven, at least in part, by the desire to be a force for good with a liberating mission for all humanity.

title: Mogul vs. Mavericks: A Search for Heroes
description: IF it's true, as President Calvin Coolidge famously declared, that the business of America is business, then the national conversation about where business is going says a lot about where the country is going. And the business conversation has changed much over the last few months. Our obsession with villains -- Martha, Frank, et al. -- has begun to fade, what with nearly all of them being investigated, tried or convicted, or awaiting sentencing. How long can a country's blood boil?

title: In a Kid-Glove Neighborhood, a Call for Clenched Fists
description: THE bottles of pinot grigio and cabernet sauvignon stood at attention on the bar, each with a napkin knotted at its neck. A man in a black bow tie played a Steinway in the marble rotunda. It was April 29, and Defenders of the Historic Upper East Side, a new preservation group, was having its inaugural celebration at the Kosciuszko Foundation, an East 65th Street town house that once belonged to Mrs. John Jacob Astor 3rd's socialite son-in-law.

title: Word for Word/Rumsfeld v. Padilla; The Supreme Court Asks: Who Will Guard the Guardians?
description: ON April 28, hours before CBS broadcast the photographs of Americans abusing Iraqi prisoners, the United States deputy solicitor general, Paul D. Clement, stood before the Supreme Court arguing the case of Rumsfeld v. Padilla. He was defending the administration's open-ended military detention of Jose Padilla, an American arrested two years ago on suspicion of conspiring with Al Qaeda to detonate a ''dirty bomb'' in the United States. Another American citizen, Yaser Esam Hamdi, was captured in Afghanistan and like Mr. Padilla has been labeled an enemy combatant; his case is also before the court.

title: Willing Trout Are a Lure to Idaho
description: Cutthroat trout were once the dominant trout species of the western United States. Robert Behnke, a fisheries historian and professor emeritus of fisheries and conservation at Colorado State University, says that the original distribution of cutthroat trout is greater than that of any other form of North American salmon or trout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREZNER, LOUIS
description: DREZNER -- Louis. 101 blessed years, passed away on May 7, 2004. Devoted husband to the late Sadye Hirsch Drezner, dear brother to older sister Shirley Rodkinson, treasured father to Susan Drezner Ultan, Leslie Barry Ultan, M.D., Alan David Drezner, M.D., and Esther B. Drezner. Loving grandfather to Robyn, Robert, William and Lisa Ultan, Daniel, Erika and Benjamin Drezner. Proud great-grandfather to Matthew and Emily Ultan, and Samuel Drezner. Admired uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Loyal and trusted friend and employer to E. Lois Marshall for 63 years. Founder and President of Illustrators, Inc., and Central Photographic Studio, accomplished gardener and landscape designer, skilled woodworker and model ship builder, a master Mr. Fix-it, a man of great curiosity, intelligence with a lifelong respect for education, of a strong ethical and moral character. A wonderful role model for his family and friends. How dearly we will miss him. Services Monday, May 10, 12 noon, at Parkside Chapel, at 98-60 Queens Blvd and 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: The Week Ahead; CANNES KICKS OFF
description: On Wednesday night, the 57th Cannes Film Festival will commence with a screening of Pedro Almodvar's ''Bad Education.'' In the 12 days that follow, hundreds of films will be shown in the festival's competitive program, in its various sidebars and satellites and in the bustling market that takes place in the bowels of the Palais des Festivals and at theaters around the city. Ten years after ''Pulp Fiction'' won the Palme d'Or (the festival's top prize), Quentin Tarantino returns at the head of the jury that will crown this year's winner. Perhaps to dispel the sour aftertaste of last year's event, thought by some to be the worst festival ever, the organizers have tried to make this one more eclectic, more hospitable to American films and perhaps also more populist. A.O. Scott

title: The Very Soul Of Beaujolais
description: Beaujolais is synonymous with joie de vivre, and the 2002 Jean Descombes Morgon, a highlight of the exporter Georges Duboeuf's portfolio, is the very soul of Beaujolais. Expect gamay-grape vivacity, tea-roses aroma and the dense raspberry-strawberry flavor of confiture in tiny jars found in fancy Paris hotels. If cellared three years, the wine will resemble a Burgundy. K&D, 1366 Madison Avenue (96th Street), charges $10. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

description: On April 27, nearly 400 faithful members of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay met for more than three hours at the parish church I serve [''Anger Swirls at St. Dominic's Meeting,'' May 2]. Having been denied use of their own church, they requested use of these facilities to share their concerns, questions, agony, and mostly the pain and hurt that the recent church sexual scandal has brought to their congregation.

title: Mussina and Yankees Hang Mariners Out to Dry
description: There was a whimsical skit on the scoreboard at Safeco Field on Saturday night. The Mariner Moose, needing a fresh cleaning, contorted himself to fit in a clothes dryer and spun around and around. When the cycle finally stopped, a person opened the dryer door and pulled out a miniature stuffed doll. The mini-Moose then appeared on the warning track, scooting around in a remote-control car.

title: Medicine 2004
description: Now that malpractice lawyers know about narratives and parallel charts, licensed physicians should be aware that such personal writing may be used against them. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RESNICK, LAWRENCE M., M.D.
description: RESNICK -- Lawrence M., M.D. The American Journal of Hypertension, Ltd. sadly announces the passing of its Co-Executive Editor, Lawrence M. Resnick, M.D., on Thursday, May 6. Dr. Resnick was an integral part of the American Society of Hypertension and of the American Journal of Hypertension since the Journal's inception in 1987, where he recently became its Executive Editor. Dr. Resnick was a distinguished research scientist in his chosen fields of internal medicine, hypertension and endocrinology. He was world recognized for his research on the calciotropic hormones and on the renin system, in high blood pressure and for his contributions to the treatment of high blood pressure. He was an astute clinician, beloved by the many patients for whom he provided medical care in his role as Professor of Medicine at the New York Presbyterian HospitalCornell University Medical Center. Larry's warm persona, his quick, engaging wit and skillful use of words enabled him to reach out to his colleagues and make important contributions to the science of medical practice that will be long remembered. The membership and staff of the American Society of Hypertension and the American Journal of Hypertension mourn his loss along with his wife, Molly, their three children, his mother and brother. John H. Laragh, M.D. Editor-in-Chief

title: Presenting a Chapter of American Fare
description: ON looks alone, Clemens in West Redding easily deserves a visit. Ensconced in a free-standing house near the railroad station, the charming dining room has not changed much -- except for the large paintings of giant pears, apples, peaches and red currants on two walls -- since its previous days as first a French restaurant and then an Italian one.

title: U.S. PRESSES U.N. ON ROLE IN IRAQ FOR POLITICIANS
description: The Bush administration is pressing the United Nations envoy to change his proposal for a transitional Iraqi government once self-rule is returned on June 30, Iraqi and administration officials say.

title: The Chrome-Shiny, Lights-Flashing, Wheel-Spinning, Touch-Screened, Drew-Carey-Wisecracking, Video-Playing, 'Sound Events'- Packed, Pulse-Quickening Bandit
description: When Anthony Baerlocher makes his monthly visit to the Atlantis Casino Resort in Reno, Nev., he always starts with a ritual he calls ''taking inventory,'' walking several laps around the casino's sprawling 32,000-square-foot gambling floor and noting which machines sit unloved, vainly burping out their come-hither sounds, and which machines have captured players' attention. The Atlantis is home to more than 1,400 slot machines, but so vivid is the mental snapshot that Baerlocher, 35, carries in his head that he immediately registers the presence of a new machine on the floor. Although Baerlocher is a trained mathematician, his interest is far from academic. He is the chief game designer for the country's largest maker of slot machines, International Game Technology of Reno. At the first sign of a new slot machine from a competitor, he goes into action. ''Give me 30 minutes and $60,'' he says, ''and I can tell you pretty much anything you want to know about another company's machine.''

description: AND ALSO LOOK FOR -- A two-disc version of ''Saving Private Ryan'' (DreamWorks, May 25) to coincide with the 60th anniversary of D-Day, including documentaries on the making of the film. . . . From Warner Home Video, a collection of MGM's six glorious Tarzan and Jane movies featuring Johnny Weismuller and Maureen O'Sullivan, some of the sweetest adventure films ever seen (June 8). . . . A restored version of the revered 1978 BBC mini-series ''Pennies From Heaven,'' starring Bob Hoskins (BBC Video, July 27). . . . ''The Godfather'' (Paramount, May 11), making its debut as a single disc, with the next two installments in Francis Ford Coppola's trilogy following later. . . . The final installment of Peter Jackson's ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, the Oscar-laden ''Return of the King,'' with extras including three documentaries, six ''featurettes'' and 30 -- count 'em, 30 -- animated menus (New Line, May 25). . . . John Irvin's wonderful ''Robin Hood,'' starring Patrick Bergin and Uma Thurman, which was kept out of theaters here so as not to compete with Kevin Costner's pallid version. This is shorter than the European theatrical cut, but 'twill do (Fox, May 11). . . . And a 15th-anniversary edition of ''Field of Dreams'' (Universal, May 8), released in the hope that if they market it, you will come.

title: In Artsy Hastings, A Cone Shimmers
description: IT is a narrow, shining cone, lolling around on its wide end, lilting in the breeze. A 25-foot-tall compass point, a thorn, a spawn of the Space Needle: in some towns, it would be a lightning rod for some good old-fashioned don't-mess-with-my-property-values controversy. But in this village of 7,650, which is known for its artistic esprit, the response has been more of a welcome than a whimper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNNER, EVA
description: DUNNER--Eva. Died peacefully, her children by her side in Groton, Massachusetts on April 17, 2004. Born to Ernestine Bauer in 1916, raised in Germany until leaving for Palestine in 1932. After marriage to Hans Ruben, she married film producer/director Lasar Dunner in 1944 to whom she was married until his death in 1994. She lived in Israel for over 20 years before immigrating to the US in 1958. Eva was a self-educated intellectual with an unconventional spirit, love of books, travel and a hilarious sense of humor. She will live on in her children, Yaela, Naomi and Ilana, her eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. naomi@testwiz.com

title: Modern Dance's Cabinetmaker
description: ART, the way Lar Lubovitch sees it, is the province of other choreographers. ''Calling yourself an artist is a big accolade,'' he mused after a day of rehearsals and costume checks, fidgeting over his coffee cup. ''That's why I call myself a craftsman. My dances are like a good cabinet: the seams are tight, it stands up, it has balance, it has function. Artistry is something beyond one's own understanding.''

title: New County Penitentiary Opens in Valhalla

The new penitentiary is expected to ease crowding in the county jail, which is also on the county's property in Valhalla and serves prisoners awaiting trial.

title: A Festival Of Sleeves
description: A spring coat with a difference, four sleeves, is worn here by Louise Doktor, an executive secretary at a Midtown merchant banking firm. Since the 1960's, Ms. Doktor has worn and collected avant-garde fashions, beginning with Pierre Cardin, Rudy Gernreich and Courrges. The four-sleeved design, by the house of Martin Margiela, was deconstructed from two classic beige balmacaan coats, one with set-in sleeves, one with raglan sleeves. Ms. Doktor's husband, Terry Doktor, used to her penchant for the exotic, said, ''It's right up your alley.'' But he was flabbergasted when she bought a second one in navy.

title: Cellphone Tax Produces Little For 911 Help

title: Brooklyn's Museum Under Glass
description: The Brooklyn Museum spent the last century as a shadow of its original ideal. As envisioned in the 1890's, it was to be the largest museum in the world, about three million square feet -- a ''monument to chutzpah,'' in the words of its current director, Arnold Lehman. Then Brooklyn was folded into New York City, leaving the superlatives in Manhattan. The museum came to house the second-largest art collection in the country -- behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan -- but in a facility only one-sixth of the original planned size.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, ALAN
description: KING--Alan. The Officers, Governors and members of the Friars Club are deeply saddened by the passing of their esteemed Abbot and dear friend Alan King. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Actor, comedian, raconteur--Alan was the epitome of show biz. A Friar for more than half a century, he was a loyal and dedicated member long before he was offered the Club's highest position, that of Abbot. Alan succeeded Frank Sinatra in 1997 and his leadership greatly influenced the direction of the Friars Club into the new millennium. Alan's support and participation at our Roasts and Testimoial Dinners is legendary. He was an extraordinary talent who brought laughter to millions. He helped to preserve the rich theatrical roots of the Friars Club and his name joins the legendary and immortal Friars like Jack Benny, Milton Berle, George Burns, George M. Cohan, Cary Grant, George Jessel, Dean Martin and Frank Sinatra. Along with these giants in entertainment he shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. All the Friars tip their hats skyward to salute the man who made their days a little brighter and their hearts a little fuller. There may be an empty bar stool at the corner of the Friars Club bar, but the rich legacy of wonderful stories and jokes that Alan left behind for us will be heard and laughed about till the end of time. For Friars there is no greater gift than that. Services will be held on May 11, at 11:45 am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76h Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Freddie Roman, Dean Sally Jessy Raphael, Prior Fred C. Klein, Treasurer Stu Cantor, Scribe Jean-Pierre Trebot Executive Director

title: Killing Off Housing for the Poor
description: The Bush administration's tax cuts for the well-to-do have taken a heavy toll on the nation's most important social programs for the poor and working class. The program provides rent subsidies for two million of the country's most vulnerable families and encourages private developers to build affordable housing.

Three men and three women approached Mr. Lowe outside the Capri Whitestone Motel on Hutchinson River Parkway about 2:25 a.m. Saturday. They demanded Mr. Lowe's chain, and when he resisted, one of the six shot him and took it, the police said. The six fled in a green Ford Expedition. The police asked anyone with information about the shooting to call (800) 577-TIPS. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: The Arid West
description: Even in May, an extraordinary number of Westerners -- especially those who live in the Rocky Mountain states -- are still talking about March. In many places, it was an unusually warm month without precipitation. March put an end to the hope -- a well-worn hope by now -- that the weather would return to normal in a region that is now entering its fifth year of drought. Every indicator is grievous. Ranchers have radically destocked the range. In Arizona and New Mexico, more than a million acres of pinyon and ponderosa pine have died off. Critical reservoirs, like Lake Powell, are holding less than half their capacity. The Rio Grande is a trickle. The entire drainage of the Colorado River -- the ultimate source of water for much of the metropolitan West -- is at risk.

title: Church, State and Dinner
description: Catholic leaders of the New York Archdiocese are considering whether Senator John Kerry should be barred from the Al Smith dinner, one of the city's grand political events, because Mr. Kerry, a Catholic, supports abortion rights and other views at odds with church teachings. This would be regrettable since the Al Smith dinner, at its best, exemplifies pluralism and tolerance. For more than 50 years, it has provided a venue for the main presidential contenders to make generous, witty speeches, not to be vetted and spurned for individual religious beliefs. Al Smith himself, the New York governor who was the first Catholic to run for president, epitomized this ideal.

title: WEST END OPERA STUMBLES
description: Barely a month ago, it seemed like a great idea: the world's most popular operas presented in a West End theater in London at reasonable prices for audiences who love a good tune but might feel intimidated by the grandeur of Covent Garden. The new Savoy Opera at the 1,100-seat Savoy Theater on the Strand seemed to start well enough last month, with some good reviews and loads of publicity for its first two productions, Rossini's ''Barber of Seville'' and Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro.'' But Raymond Gubbay and Sir Stephen Waley-Cohen, the two impresarios who each invested $4.5 million on the gamble, are also businessmen. On Friday they announced that ticket sales did not justify continuing after the first two productions end their run on June 19. In a statement they said they would be reviewing their plans, but for the moment scheduled presentations of ''Carmen,'' ''L'Elisir d'Amore,'' ''La Traviata'' and ''La Belle Hlne'' are off. ''We'll see what can be done, but it won't be immediately,'' Sir Stephen said. Asked where he and Mr. Gubbay had miscalculated, Sir Stephen added: ''We don't have answers. If we had an answer, it would be easy.'' ALAN RIDING

title: An Astrophysicist Goes Missing, And His Children Search the Stars

A passionate three-hour production, dense with special effects, the movie, based on the near-sacred 1962 text by Madeleine L'Engle, proceeds from the novel's ingenious premise: a father who leaves his family is a cosmic traitor. With some malign sorcery, covered over with lies, he shatters peace, leaving in its place a terrifying new universe: ''The Broken Home,'' as James Merrill titled a great poem of domestic dissolution in 1966.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Study Faults Clinics On Contraceptives
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller, joined by Councilman Eric N. Gioia and Councilwoman Gale Brewer, left, released a report Saturday saying that many of the city's health clinics are violating a law requiring them to provide emergency contraceptives to women free of charge. The report was based on telephone calls from Council investigators to three dozen health clinics, of which only half responded. The report found that of those that responded, 10 clinics said the emergency contraceptives were available. Several said they charged $45 to $90 for them. City health officials said that they had not yet seen the report, but that their policy was to comply with the law. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Dies After Stabbing
description: A woman who authorities said was stabbed repeatedly by her son died Saturday after being taken in critical condition to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. The son, Kevon Stewart, 21, was arrested shortly after the attack, which occurred on Friday morning, and charged with assault and weapons possession. A spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday that the assault charge was likely to be upgraded to homicide or murder. Neighbors said that the woman, Yvonne Stewart, 46, had given up her job to take care of Mr. Stewart and a younger son, who were mentally retarded, and that she had frequently called the police because of problems with Mr. Stewart. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

Most loving father of Mark & Kerri and David & April. Very proud grandfather of little Eleanor Jane. Loved by dear brother Denis and deceased brothers: John, Brian & Thomas and their wives. A retiree of Consolidated Edison, Human Resources. Former resident of Mineola, NY, for 30 years. Also survived and loved by 28 nieces and nephews, 42 grandnieces and ne phews, and four great-grandnieces and nephews. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Law On Leftover Dry Cleaning
description: Short on cash for dry cleaning? Never liked that cloth coat anyway? Or just plain forgot about it? Gov. George E. Pataki has signed legislation that allows dry cleaners to dispose of clothes when they are left longer than six months. Under the law, which takes effect in August, dry cleaners can donate such clothing to charity. Dry cleaners have complained that orphaned clothing deprived them of critical storage space, but cleaners could do nothing about it. A customer once successfully sued a cleaner for disposing of a garment that had been left for several years, said Kori-Ann Taylor, a spokeswoman for State Senator Thomas P. Morahan, the Rockland County Republican who sponsored the bill. Under the law, notice must be given on the receipt and in the store. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Republicans for Stem Cell Research
description: The Bush administration's restrictions on federal funds for embryonic stem cell research are so potentially damaging to medicine that they are encountering opposition even among the administration's own conservative supporters. The latest sign of conservative misgivings came at a fund-raising gala sponsored by the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation last Saturday, when Nancy Reagan made a public plea for support of stem cell research. Although she did not specifically criticize the Bush policy, Mrs. Reagan described movingly how Alzheimer's had taken her husband ''to a distant place where I can no longer reach him.'' She expressed hope that stem cell research might provide new treatments for many diseases. ''I just don't see how we can turn our backs on this,'' she said, adding, ''We have lost so much time already, and I just really can't bear to lose any more.''

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Electronic Data May Cut Dividend
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the seller of computer services, may cut its dividend by 67 percent to help raise more than $1 billion and keep its investment-grade credit rating. The company may also sell stock to raise money, it said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Electronic Data, which has about $5.8 billion in long-term debt, is rated Baa3, one level above junk, by Moody's Investors Service. Standard & Poor's rates the company BBB-, one level above junk. Electronic Data has lost out on new contracts amid an accounting investigation by the commission and as a money-losing $6.9 billion Navy contract consumes cash. Electronic Data, based in Plano, Tex., had a $38 million first-quarter loss from continuing operations on costs from the Navy order, as sales increased to $5.2 billion. Electronic Data shares fell 28 cents, to $17.51.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I2 Technologies To Settle Shareholder Suits
description: I2 Technologies, the software maker that last July restated results for the previous five years, said yesterday that it would pay $84.9 million to settle shareholder class-action and derivative lawsuits relating to allegations it misled investors about its financial condition and future earnings. The agreement includes $43 million that will be covered by insurance policies and $41.9 million that the company will pay, said I2 of Dallas. I2's restatement reduced sales by $359.7 million and increased its net loss by $207.1 million. The company will finance $22 million of the $41.9 million through the sale of common stock. The chief executive, Sanjiv Sidhu, will buy $20 million of the shares and an unidentified defendant will buy the $2 million balance, an I2 spokeswoman, Melanie Ofenloch, said. Ms. Ofenloch said the $84.9 million settlement applies to anyone who bought I2 shares from March 22, 2000, through July 21, 2003.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Charter School Group Chooses Leader
description: Stefan Pryor, chief of staff for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, has been appointed chief executive of a nonprofit organization created to support and open charter schools in New York City, officials said yesterday. Mr. Pryor, 32, previously oversaw educational programs at the Partnership for New York City, a business consortium, and was a co-founder of Amistad Academy, an acclaimed charter school in New Haven. The nonprofit, the New York City Center for Charter School Excellence, was announced last fall by Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, who sits on its board, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The center is being financed by $41 million from private foundations and will help fulfill Mr. Bloomberg's plan to open as many as 50 charter schools in the city. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOBLER, MARGARET H.
description: HOBLER--Margaret H. 83, died peacefully with her children beside her on Mother's Day in Yarmouth, ME. Born Margaret Garrison Hildeburn in New York to William L. and Charity H. Hildeburn. Her father headed the Trust Department of the Chase National Bank. Her uncle, Lindley M. Garrison, was Wilson's Secretary of War. Grew up in Summit, NJ, graduated Kent Place School and from Smith College in 1942. Married Wells A. Hobler 1943; divorced 1953. Received degree from New York School of Interior Design 1960, worked as a designer at C.V. Starr Co. (now AIG). 1987, at 66, earned Master's in Art History from Hunter College. Docent at Metropolitan Museum. Member ASID and the Cosmopolitan Club. Diagnosed with Alzheimer's, 2001, and moved to Maine. To the end of her life she maintained the dignity and grace for which she is remembered. Survived by brother William L. Hildeburn Jr. of San Marino, CA, daughter Linnard Hobler of St. Louis, and son Edward Hobler of Portland, ME. Memorial service at the Cosmopolitan Club, date to be announced. Donations in her memory to the Hillyer Art Library, Smith College, Northampton, MA 01063.

title: With the Clotheshorses Of the Backstretch
description: Francisco Costa, the designer at Calvin Klein, does not ordinarily go to Belmont Park on a Wednesday, but it was opening day, and John De Stefano Jr., a horse trainer who has been his companion for 14 years, had horses running in the eighth and ninth races. So last Wednesday, around noon, Mr. Costa put on a coat and tie, shined his shoes and went out to Belmont. Considering all the parallels between horse racing and fashion, beginning with the obsessiveness about weight and grooming and going from there to the paraphernalia, the boots, the silks, which are called the colors -- considering all that, an afternoon at the track was not quite playing hooky.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Posts Loss; Will Cut 7,500 Jobs
description: MCI, the long-distance telephone company, which completed the biggest bankruptcy reorganization in history last month, posted a first-quarter net loss yesterday of $388 million as sales plummeted because of increased competition for corporate customers. The company said it would cut 7,500 jobs, or about 15 percent of its work force. The net loss at MCI, formerly WorldCom, was $1.19 a share, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. In 2003, it had net income of $52 million. Sales at MCI fell 13 percent to $6.30 billion from $7.23 billion. MCI's chief executive, Michael D. Capellas, said in a statement that the company would accelerate its cost-cutting amid heightened competition that has driven down phone and data prices. The company's shares fell $1.10, or 7.7 percent, to $13.15.

title: Tourists and Torturers
description: So now we think we know who took some of the photographs at Abu Ghraib. The works attributed to Specialist Jeremy Sivits are fated to remain among the indelible images of our time. They will have changed the course of history; just how much we do not yet know. It is arguable that without them, news of what happened within the walls of that prison would never have emerged from the fog of classified internal memos. We owe their circulation and perhaps their existence to the popular technology of our day, to digital cameras and JPEG files and e-mail. Photographs can now be disseminated as quickly and widely as rumors. It's possible that even if Specialist Joseph M. Darby hadn't gone to his superiors in January and ''60 Minutes II'' hadn't broken the story last month, some of those pictures would sooner or later have found their way onto the Web and so into the public record.
