title: The Risks and Demands of Pregnancy After 20
description: Biologically speaking, the ideal age at which to have a baby is between 18 and 20. That mother would then live another 10 or so years to help out with the grandchildren, fostering the perpetuation of the species.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Arrests In Patronage Scandal

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Luxembourg: Profit For Steel Maker
description: Arcelor, the steel maker, posted a quarterly profit and said second-quarter earnings would rise further as steel prices stay close to nine-year highs and demand improved. First-quarter net income rose 22 percent, to 234 million euros ($277 million), or 49 cents a share, from 192 million euros, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales were little changed at 6.9 billion euros. Arcelor said it planned to raise third-quarter prices 15 percent for flat carbon steel used to make cars, about twice the rate of increases in January and April. Steel makers have been raising prices to cover the cost of raw materials. Some raw materials, like coke, sometimes are not available at any price because of demand from China, the chief executive, Guy Dolle, above, said. ''I don't anticipate any major positive change for customers in the coming quarters regarding raw materials,'' he said, ''and prices will continue to increase.''

title: Town Set to Defy Governor On Same-Sex Marriage Issue

The move contradicts a directive by Gov. Mitt Romney, who has said that no same-sex couples residing out of state would be allowed to marry here.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Suit Over Scalia Tapes
description: The Associated Press and The Hattiesburg American sued the United States Marshals Service in Federal District Court in Jackson for taking their reporters' tapes of a speech by Justice Antonin Scalia and demanding that they be erased. The news organizations are asking for $1,000 each, a declaration that the marshals' actions were unconstitutional and an order forbidding the service from seizing recorders from working reporters. The agency said its actions were based on Justice Scalia's policy that his speeches not be recorded. The justice apologized to the reporters and said that his speeches could be taped by print reporters to help ensure accuracy. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LA VINE, KENNETH NETTLETON
description: La VINE--Kenneth Nettleton of Vero Beach, FL died at his home on May 9, 2004. He was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1911, a son of the late Louis and Irene (Nettleton) La Vine. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1932 and from Yale Law School in 1935, where he was a member of the Yale Law Journal and was elected to the Order of The Coif, the national honorary legal society. Mr. La Vine joined the law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle in New York in 1935 where he remained until the outbreak of World War II. During the war, Mr. La Vine served in the U.S. Army 77th Division and ''Ultra'' in Army Intelligence in Washington, DC. On his return from the Army, Mr. La Vine rejoined the law firm and was a partner from 1950 until his retirement in 1981. For many years, Mr. La Vine was a director of Carlisle Corporation, Dover Corporation, The Leach Corporation and a number of other companies. During that time, Mr. La Vine lived in Forest Hills, NY. After his retirement, he and his wife, the former Mary Virginia Dailey, relocated to Florida. In 1998, they moved to Vero Beach, FL, where he was a parishioner of St. John of The Cross. An avid tennis and platform tennis player, he was a longtime member of The West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, NY. Mr. La Vine was predeceased by his daughter, Carol A. Coogan. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, his son Kenneth N. La Vine Jr. and his wife, Angel, his daughter, Linda Johnson and her husband, John, his son-in-law, James M. Coogan; five grandchildren, and one great grandson. Mr. La Vine will be reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. NYC on Wednesday, May 12, visiting hours 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM. A Funeral Mass will becelebrated at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York, on May 13 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to the Hudson Valley National Foundation, 21 Scarsdale Road, Yonkers, NY 10707 in memory of his daughter, Carol A. Coogan, or to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70th St., NY, NY 10021.

Baugur, based in Reykjavik, is teaming with Goldsmith's managers to buy the company, which operates 165 stores and has annual sales of 160 million. The chief executive of Goldsmiths, Jurek Piasecki, will cut his stake to 15 percent from 50.5 percent, but will continue to run the company.

description: President Bush will be going to three college commencements in coming weeks -- but not those of his twin daughters, Barbara and Jenna.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA POSTS A $10 MILLION LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, the company controlled by the cable-television investor John C. Malone, had a first-quarter loss of $10 million as some investments declined in value and profit fell at its Starz Encore movie networks. The loss of less than 1 cent a share compares with net income of $132 million, or 5 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Reported sales jumped more than fourfold, to $2.4 billion, because Liberty is now including the results of the QVC shopping network, which it has owned in full since September. Starz Encore's operating income fell 41 percent as the unit spent more to market its network and license some films. Revenue rose 1.3 percent; costs rose 34 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Softbank Posts a Loss
description: The Softbank Corporation, the broadband Internet service provider, said its net loss widened for the year just ended as a costly marketing campaign more than offset growing revenue. Softbank, which also invests in Internet companies and owns a share in Yahoo, said its net loss grew to 107 billion yen ($953 million) for the year ended March 31 from a loss of 100 billion yen a year earlier as revenue grew 27 percent, to 517.39 billion yen. Softbank has been spending heavily on marketing in a bid to expand its Yahoo BB Internet service to six million customers by September 2005 from about four million. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about new and forthcoming Hollywood movies -- and their preoccupation with honor and heroism -- misidentified the country where the former National Football League player Pat Tillman was killed last month while serving as an Army Ranger. It was Afghanistan, not Iraq.

title: Ex-Director of Tyco Testifies He Learned Late About Bonus
description: A former director of Tyco International, testifying yesterday as the first government witness in the trial of Mark A. Belnick, the company's former general counsel, said he did not learn of a $17 million bonus paid to Mr. Belnick in 2000 until two years later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORSE, JOANN RYAN
description: MORSE--Joann Ryan. Died Sunday May 9th. A graduate of Vassar College and Yale University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, she retired from the Barnard College faculty in 1995 as a Professor of English after almost 40 years of teaching. She is survived by her husband, Dean Weber Morse, of New York City, her sister Maureen Ryan Willson and numerous nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass Wednesday, May 12, 10AM at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121 St, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Friends of Liturgical Music at Corpus Christi Church.

title: About New York; A Path Of Glory, So Fleeting
description: HERE, covered by a few brown leaves, was the plaque for Bernie Kopell, whose claim to fame is that he played Dr. Adam Bricker on the ''Love Boat.'' There, partially hidden by a rhododendron, was the one for Abe Vigoda: Fish, from ''Barney Miller.'' Is that show even in reruns anymore?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ALAN J.
description: COHEN--Alan J. The most loving and devoted father to Alison, whose spark, determination and daily accomplishments gave him immense joy. Beloved Husband of many years to Louise Cohen. Cherished brother of Ronnie and Bill Lane, uncle to Craig and Anna, Drew and Samantha, great-uncle to Claudia, Arden, Lily and Simon. Longtime caring and loving boyfriend to Ms. Daryl Stieglitz. Devoted for his lifetime to his parents, the late Phyllis and Jules Cohen. Humble to the core, he always put the needs of his family and friends above his own and would give anything to make someone else happy, asking nothing in return. He maintained his elegance and dignity to the end and never complained. Services today at 12:30 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

title: Investment Fund Files for Offering Of $500 Million
description: Eric Gleacher, the former head of mergers and acquisitions at Lehman Brothers Holdings and Morgan Stanley, has filed to raise $500 million in an initial public offering of an investment fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARPLES, ARTHUR
description: SHARPLES--Arthur. February 9, 2004. With your love and humor you made a beautiful difference in so many lives. You are forever in my heart. I miss you. Basia.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''Super Size Me,'' a documentary on fast food and obesity, attributed a distinction erroneously to Texas, one of the places to which the filmmaker traveled. It is not the largest state in the union; Alaska is. (The most populous state is California.) The review also misstated the type of diabetes associated with poor nutrition and being overweight. It is Type 2; juvenile diabetes is an autoimmune disorder, now known as Type 1.

title: A Trusted Troubleshooter, and Overseer of Intelligence Efforts at the Defense Department
description: Stephen Cambone may have more influence over intelligence matters at the Pentagon than anyone who has previously tried to oversee that enterprise, so his words carry some weight.

title: Kidd Finds Scoring Touch and Nets Pull Even
description: It came first with Jason Kidd's long 3-pointer. Then he made a jumper from on the 3-point line. He came down the next time and pulled up his dribble 10 feet from the rim. He turned to fake a pass, then effortlessly spun back toward the basket, leaving the Pistons' Richard Hamilton in his wake, and banked in a short jumper.

title: Group Says Europe Is Lagging in Global Recovery
description: The United States and Asia are leaving Europe behind in an accelerating, but uneven global economic recovery. That was the assessment of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development when it released its semiannual outlook at its headquarters here on Tuesday.

title: La Caravelle, a French Legend, Is Closing After 43 Years
description: ADD another name to the list of venerable New York restaurants to close in recent months: La Caravelle. This elegant Midtown temple to French gastronomy offered a pampering, Paris-in-Manhattan experience to food enthusiasts and the A-list of American society for more than 40 years.

title: Israeli Soldiers Ambushed as Dispute Continues Over Bodies
description: GAZA CITY, May 12 — An Israeli military vehicle exploded in an ambush today in the southern Gaza Strip, killing at least five Israeli soldiers, news agencies reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMOLS, WILLIAM, M.D.
description: AMOLS--William, M.D. The Department of Neurology of Columbia University deeply regrets the death of William Amols, M.D., on April 20. Dr. Amols trained in neurology at the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and was chief resident in 1952-1953 before joining the neurology faculty. He retired in 1982 from the Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital, a major teaching affiliate of Columbia University, as clinical professor of neurology. Dr. Amols gained an international reputation for introducing the use of drug therapy for trigeminal neuralgia, a form of facial pain. He was a skilled and devoted clinician and a popular teacher. We extend our condolences to his wife, Jacqueline, and his children. Timothy A. Pedley, M.D. Chairman, Department of Neurology Columbia University Lewis P. Rowland, M.D. Chairman Emeritus, Department of Neurology

title: Cisco Profit For Quarter Slightly Beats Estimates
description: Cisco Systems, the multibillion-dollar maker of Internet networking equipment that is considered a technology bellwether, reported a quarterly profit on Tuesday that narrowly exceeded investor expectations. But the company gave Wall Street a broader reason for optimism by suggesting that corporate spending on technology appears to be gaining momentum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POTASH, SARAH BENNETT
description: POTASH--Sarah Bennett. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected and compassionate member of the Jewish community, who enacted many deeds of loving kindness. She was the wife of the late Henry Potash and cherished mother of Robert Bennett Potash, as well as the adored sister of YU Benefactor, Carl Bennett, and Henry Bennett and Esther Brandwein. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: A Flurry Of Diplomacy In Asia on Eve Of Arms Talks
description: Tokyo is abuzz with reports that the prime minister of Japan is planning a visit to North Korea. Meanwhile, South Korea and North Korea are organizing a meeting of army generals, the highest level inter-Korean military meeting in decades.

title: 'The Politics of Truth': Don't Tread on Joseph Wilson
description: THIS is a riveting and all-engaging book. Not only does it provide context to yesterday's headlines, and perhaps tomorrow's, about the Iraq war and about our politics of personal destruction, but former Ambassador Joseph Wilson also tells captivating stories from his life as a foreign service officer with a long career fostering the development of African democracies, and gives us a behind-the-scenes blow-by-blow of the run-up to the 1991 Persian Gulf war. As the top American diplomat in Baghdad, Wilson was responsible for the embassy, its staff and the lives of other Americans in the region - not to mention the freeing of hostages in Kuwait. He goes on to relate his eye-to-eye encounter with the wily sociopath Saddam Hussein; his return home to be greeted as a ''true American hero'' by President George H. W. Bush; his stint advising America's top military commander in Europe; and his time as head of the African affairs desk of Bill Clinton's National Security Council, where he assembled the president's historic trip to Africa while the ''Starr inquisition'' into the Monica Lewinsky affair developed. Along the way he fell in love with and married a C.I.A. covert operative - a ''willowy blonde, resembling a young Grace Kelly.''

title: 200,000 Employees Awaiting Clearance to Work for Military
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 - A government investigation shows that even as the military has grown more reliant on private contractors to serve in highly sensitive positions in Iraq, the Pentagon has a backlog of nearly 200,000 people working for those and other contractors who are still awaiting security clearances.

title: Yankees' Long Night Ends With A Long Ball
description: Last night was a school night in May, and not even the promise of a Yankees comeback against the hottest team in the big leagues could keep most fans at Yankee Stadium through two rain delays. The ballpark nearly emptied, an odd sight nowadays.

title: Who Really Cooks Your Food?
description: HERE'S how it was supposed to work: Thomas Keller, star chef of the Napa Valley, temporarily shutters his renowned restaurant, the French Laundry, and opens a feverishly anticipated restaurant in New York. Per Se opens in the Time Warner Center in a burst of glory, with Mr. Keller in the kitchen. Once the New York team is up to speed, the chef de cuisine, Jonathan Benno, takes the reins at Per Se, freeing Mr. Keller to fly back to California and reopen the French Laundry with its chef de cuisine, Eric Ziebold. Finally, with two acclaimed restaurants thousands of miles apart, Mr. Keller joins the international corps of red-eyed chefs who shuttle between multiple kitchens, with well-honed chefs de cuisine holding down the fort at each end.

title: Kerry Gathers Tales of Health Cost Burden
description: After his health insurance costs shot up 75 percent over five years, Bruce Cohen, a master plumber here, switched plans, leaving his employees with a $2,500 deductible ($7,500 for a family). Elias Estephane, owner of a local grocery store and pharmacy, recently began paying prescription co-payments for his 47 workers so they would stop choosing less-expensive -- and less-effective -- drugs.

title: Foreigners Try to Melt an Inhospitable Japanese City
description: David Aldwinckle, a bespectacled native of Geneva, New York, braced himself for confrontation when he walked into Joy, a restaurant that, like many establishments here, posted a sign that was a variation on a popular theme here: ''Japanese Only.''

title: Global Warming Ignites Tempers, Even in a Movie
description: Any studio that makes a $125 million movie about global warming is courting controversy. But 20th Century Fox does not seem to have fully anticipated the political firestorm being whipped up by its film ''The Day After Tomorrow.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Ex-Soldiers Among Plot Suspects
description: The head of Colombia's army, Gen. Martn Carreno, said that at least 26 of the nearly 100 Colombians arrested on Sunday in a purported plot to oust Venezuela's president, Hugo Chvez, left, had once served in Colombia's armed forces. The revelation came two days after Venezuela's government announced that Colombian right-wing paramilitaries, who often work in tandem with rogue Colombian army units, had been training on a farm outside of Caracas in a plan hatched by Mr. Chvez's Venezuelan adversaries to end his tumultuous presidency. Opposition leaders in Caracas ridiculed the government's assertion, calling it subterfuge aimed at discrediting them, while a Colombian paramilitary commander, Salvatore Mancuso, also denied his group's involvement. The Venezuelan police, meanwhile, continued to search for people said to be ring leaders, including Robert Alonso, the Cuban-born owner of the farm. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: A Promising Rotation Deteriorates for the Mets
description: PHOENIX, May 11 - For hours upon hours during spring training, Mets coaches and executives gathered in meeting rooms to discuss the back end of the starting rotation and review pitchers they had advertised as quality candidates for major league spots.

title: Here to Amuse You, Right on This Very Screen
description: Doing magic on television presents problems. With the camera mercilessly manipulating the viewer's eye, and editors able to lend impeccable sleight to any hand, television is always openly trompe l'oeil. For old-school magicians to try to re-enchant television viewers, whose disbelief is permanently suspended, is perhaps more awe-inspiring than sawed ladies or even disappearing bridges.

description: Inching toward levels more common for older masters than for newer artists, Christie's last night scored its first sale of postwar and contemporary art that topped $100 million.

title: LEVI STRAUSS SEEKS TO SELL DOCKERS BRAND
description: Levi Strauss & Company is exploring the sale of its Dockers casual-clothing brand as it seeks to reduce debt and focus resources on its Levi's and Levi Strauss Signature brands. The maker of Levi's jeans said it had retained Citigroup to help with the potential sale of the Dockers business. Dockers accounted for $1.4 billion of Levi's $4.09 billion in sales for 2003. The new Levi Signature brand, introduced last July, contributed $105 million, or 11 percent, of the company's first-quarter sales of $962 million. The brand's success offset some losses from Dockers and other brands. Levi Strauss has been under pressure to cut costs and debt after years of sagging sales, which have fallen from a peak of $7.1 billion in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIBSOHN, DAVID
description: LIBSOHN--David, in the 87th year of his life and in the 60th year of our glorious marriage. Cherished husband of Mitzi. Adored father of Pauli Rose. Destiny put us together when we met by the beautiful sea. We believed in the unbelievable and in a moment of madness we wed. Like SooYin and Mark we found a love that was indeed a manysplendored thing. Good night, sweet prince and thank you for the moon. Mitzi Visiting today 11 AM, services 12 at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, L.I. Burial at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Pine Lawn, L.I.

title: Education Law Will Stand, Bush Tells Its Detractors
description: President Bush answered the growing number of critics of the ''No Child Left Behind'' education law that he made a centerpiece of his domestic agenda, declaring in a school gymnasium Tuesday that ''we're not backing down'' to those who say the federal government is setting unrealistic academic standards.

title: Off the Menu
description: Spring cleaning, for most people, means cleaning closets. ALAIN DUCASSE has tackled two of his kitchens. At ALAIN DUCASSE AT THE ESSEX HOUSE, the collaboration between Mr. Ducasse and his new executive chef, CHRISTIAN DELOUVRIER, will result in a new menu next week. Mr. Delouvrier's influence is evident in dishes like sauteed foie gras with lemon marmalade and suckling pig with mustard sauce. A new menu at MIX IN NEW YORK, devised by Mr. Ducasse and DAMON GORDON, above, the restaurant's new chef de cuisine, will also have its debut next week. There are many new dishes, like vegetable vichyssoise with a savory meringue, a casserole of snails with tomatoes and lobster caesar salad.

title: U.S. general links prisoner abuse to 'lack of discipline'
description: WASHINGTON:  The abuse of Iraqis at the Abu Ghraib prison was caused by "lack of discipline, no training whatsoever and no supervision," according to the army general who investigated the scandal, but he said he had found no evidence of any direct order or policy decision authorizing maltreatment by American guards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, MARILYN K.
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Marilyn K. (1948-2004), beloved wife of 28 years to Mark, cherished mother of Maxine and Michael, loving sister of David and Susan, died May 8th, of complications from lymphoma. With a degree in business and a marketing career, she devoted her life to her family. Loved by all who knew and admired her for her tremendous strength, she was passionate in all of her endeavors--most recently studying yoga and the Torah. In the peak of her physical health, she was an avid swimmer, equestrian and bike rider. Marilyn was a spiritual being to whose soul we will continue to look for guidance. She believes in angels and she is ours. We will always remember her and love her past the infinity bump. Services were held on May 9th at The Jewish Center of the Hamptons. Shiva Wednesday and Thursday, 6-9 PM, at the family's NYC home. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Youth and Education Fund at The Jewish Center of the Hamptons.

Sachs. Also survived by niece Kathryn A Carver and nephews Ian B. and Blake H. Carver, and their families. Her love and wit will always be remembered. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

description: Stocks gained yesterday on optimism that a growing economy will limit the effects of rising interest rates, recovering from a drop the day before that sent benchmark indexes to their lows for 2004.

title: A City of Quitters? In Strict New York, 11% Fewer Smokers
description: In the wake of huge tobacco tax increases and a ban on smoking in bars, the number of adult smokers in New York City fell 11 percent from 2002 to 2003, one of the steepest short-term declines ever measured, according to surveys commissioned by the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOX, RUTH D.
description: KNOX--Ruth D. Died Sunday, Mother's Day, May 9, 2004 in Westwood, NJ. Born and raised in Manhattan, she moved to Bayside, Queens after marrying, where she raised three children. Ruth was a member of the Bayside United Methodist Church and the Bayside Women's Club. She also was a Den Mother of Pack 110, the Bayside branch of the Cub Scouts of America. Ruth had also resided in Cape May, NJ and most recently, New Paltz, NY. Her memory will continue to bring great joy to her daughter, Shannon Fitzgerald of Saddle River, NJ, her sons, Wallace Ruiz of Miami, FL and Jeffrey Ruiz of New Paltz, NY and her four grandchildren, Jens and Erik Ruiz, Gillian Fitzgerald and Hannah Ruiz. Funeral Service Thursday 11 AM at the Grace United Methodist Church, 555 Russell Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. Private cremation will be held. Visiting Wednesday 7-9 PM at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: For the Coolest Vibes: Accentuate Acoustics, Eliminate City Noise
description: Only an acoustician would have second thoughts about getting a new home with floor-to-ceiling, 50-by-90-foot windows overlooking Central Park. Those windows, at the center of the fifth and sixth stories of the Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle, will be both the public face and the most serious acoustical challenge for Jazz at Lincoln Center's new home, the Frederick P. Rose Hall.

title: Nielsen Offers Results Of Ratings Test
description: Nielsen Media Research, responding to critics of its plans to change the way it measures television ratings in New York, released results yesterday of the most recent test of the new system. The company said the results showed increased viewership for many programs popular with blacks and Hispanics.

title: Mexico in Midtown, Traditional and Nuevo
description: IT is no secret in the industry that many restaurants treat lunch as a dress rehearsal for the real performance -- dinner. Serving lunch helps keep the lower-ranked cooks' culinary muscles limber while they prep for the chef's dinner service. It also makes the restaurant a bit of extra money.

title: India's Ruling Coalition Shaken by Election Defeats
description: India's ruling Hindu nationalist party was rocked Tuesday when its largest coalition partner lost badly in regional elections, suggesting a public rejection of economic reform and the possibility of a divided Parliament.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman's Death Ruled Natural
description: An elderly woman who the police initially believed had been beaten to death died of natural causes, the city medical examiner's office said yesterday. On Monday evening, the body of the woman, Pena Hristova, 77, was found in the basement of her apartment building in Sunnyside, Queens, by her daughter-in-law, the police said. Shortly after the body was found, a law enforcement official said that Ms. Hristova had suffered severe head injuries. But an autopsy found that she had died of a heart attack. Investigators now believe that the woman collapsed, injuring her head as she fell, a police official said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: New York Tops List of Winners at Beard Awards
description: IN the annual James Beard Foundation awards, devoted to honoring chefs and restaurateurs, New York City is again at the top of the list.

title: Conservatives Have Their Own Senate Candidate
description: The chairman of the New York State Conservative Party said Tuesday that the party would run its own candidate for United States Senate this year, abandoning the presumptive Republican nominee, Assemblyman Howard Mills, in his uphill battle to unseat Senator Charles E. Schumer.

title: Afghan Gives Own Account Of U.S. Abuse
description: A former Afghan police colonel gave a graphic account in an interview this week of being subjected to beating, kicking, sleep deprivation, taunts and sexual abuse during about 40 days he spent in American custody in Afghanistan last summer. He also said he had been repeatedly photographed, often while naked.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi's Profit Rises
description: The Japanese trading company Mitsubishi Corporation said full-year profit rose, helped by sales from energy trading and mining operations. Mitsubishi had group net income of 115.4 billion yen ($1 billion) for the 12 months ended March 31, compared with 62.3 billion yen a year earlier, it said. The company said sales rose to 15.2 trillion yen from 13.3 trillion yen from the previous year. Mitsubishi, which operates a variety of businesses around the world, said profit from its mining and metal operations rose 29 percent, to 31 billion yen, while net income from energy trading rose 28 percent, to 30.6 billion yen.

title: Daimler Is Said to Reach Deal To Sell Its Stake in Hyundai
description: DaimlerChrysler has reached an agreement to sell its 10.5 percent stake in Hyundai Motor and will announce the deal today, a person close to the situation said yesterday.

title: Makers of Drug-Coated Stents Fight For the Hearts of Cardiologists
description: Johnson & Johnson is in danger of once again becoming an also-ran in a market it pioneered. Having introduced in the United States a promising new drug-coated device to treat heart disease nearly a year before anyone else, the company has already lost its lead, analysts say.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Brooklyn; Effort to Revive Retail Plaza Gains in Bedford-Stuyvesant
description: While prices for brownstones in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn have doubled in the last five years to an average of $600,000, rents at Restoration Plaza, the retail and cultural center at the heart of the neighborhood, lag far behind.

title: Tax Breaks For Business Are Approved In the Senate
description: After months of delay and relentless corporate lobbying, the Senate voted, 92 to 5, on Tuesday for a bill that would create $170 billion in new tax breaks for business while trying to crack down on a variety of tax shelters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINNERMAN, ROBERT H.
description: WINNERMAN--Robert H., 83. A memorial service will be held at 10 A.M. Friday in the Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston, NJ. Mr. Winnerman, who died May 1, was founder of US Home. During WWII he was a bombardier and was awarded 10 combat citations. In 2000, Mr. Winnerman published his autobiography entitled ''Winner Man: Babes, Bombs & Billions.''

title: Six Named By Pataki To Overhaul Authorities
description: As criticism mounts that New York State's sprawling system of quasi-public authorities and corporations is doing the work of government without sufficient public oversight, Gov. George E. Pataki said Tuesday that he had appointed a six-member committee to develop plans to make them more accountable.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the poverty in Haiti since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was forced from power on Feb. 29 referred incorrectly to Jean Panel, a man shown selling biscuits made of dirt. Mr. Panel is a resident of Fort Dimanche, a former political prison. He is not himself a former prisoner.

title: The Abu Ghraib Spin
description: The administration and its Republican allies appear to have settled on a way to deflect attention from the torture of prisoners at Abu Ghraib: accuse Democrats and the news media of overreacting, then pile all of the remaining responsibility onto officers in the battlefield, far away from President Bush and his political team. That cynical approach was on display yesterday morning in the second Abu Ghraib hearing in the Senate, a body that finally seemed to be assuming its responsibility for overseeing the executive branch after a year of silently watching the bungled Iraq occupation.

title: U.S. Olympic Team to Invite Marbury to Play
description: Knicks point guard Stephon Marbury is among three players who will be invited to join the United States Olympic basketball team, the Knicks' president, Isiah Thomas, confirmed Tuesday night.

Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 23 about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's transformation from antiwar protester in the Vietnam years to strong supporter of the Iraq war referred incorrectly to a commencement address she criticized at Wellesley College in 1969, her graduation year, by Edward W. Brooke, then a Republican senator from Massachusetts. (The error also appeared in articles in 1992 and 1993.) The text shows that although the speech criticized student protests of the 1960's, Senator Brooke did not urge support for the Vietnam War.

title: Labor Dispute Clouds Opening of Cannes
description: The Cannes International Film Festival, which usually counts on big-name stars and underdressed starlets to provide the excitement, will open on Wednesday under a cloud, as thousands of French actors and technicians prepare to carry a bitter dispute over unemployment benefits to this ritzy Cte d'Azur resort.

title: Is Europe Ready for Turkey? Muslim World Is Waiting
description: ISTANBUL  Where Europe ends, and with it presumably the European Union, has long been a vexed question. Just how vexed will be demonstrated over the next seven months as the EU grapples with a critical decision: whether to begin negotiations leading to Turkish membership.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Teenagers Charged In Grave Desecration
description: Two white teenagers were charged with desecrating the grave of James Byrd Jr., the black man who was dragged to his death in 1998 near his home in Jasper. The teenagers, Joshua Lee Talley, 19, of Jasper and John Matthew Fowler, 18, of Call were each accused of one count of criminal mischief. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinians Hold Israeli Bodies Hostage

title: Senate Republicans Propose Plan for Health Insurance
description: After six months of work, Senate Republicans on Tuesday proposed a wide range of tax credits, subsidies and discounts to provide health insurance to millions of Americans and to improve health care for those who remain uninsured.

title: 10 Years Past Apartheid, Wine Industry Thrives
description: Correction Appended

title: Catering to Present-Day Gents, Not Laddies
description: BUT of course, David Granger, the editor of Esquire, is proud as a peacock about the four National Magazine Awards his publication collected last week, a first for this 71-year-old granddaddy of all men's magazines, a glossy allegedly dabbling in obsolescence when he took over seven years ago. But he's not going to preen about the turnaround. Genuine Esquire men -- icons of the species being cover boys like Colin Farrell, Robert De Niro and Jack Nicholson -- are allowed a little arrogance, but they don't preen. Too gauche, too GQ.

title: As the Storm Rages, Rumsfeld Is a Lightning Rod
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing in the Lap of Luxury; At New Upscale Clubs, 'Stripper' Is a Dirty Word
description: The chairs come in plush velvet or leather. There are main rooms, dining areas, private nooks and alcoves scented by candles. The multiple stages are bathed in high-tech lighting, Champagne flows, and the women, the main attraction, sparkle in glittery gowns -- that is, until they strip down to their G-strings for a $20 lap dance.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about fruit certified by the Fair Trade movement, which seeks to improve the lives of farmers in developing countries, misstated the sales policy of the Whole Foods Market chain. While it has no plans to carry the fruit, it does indeed sell other Fair Trade products, like coffee, tea and cocoa.

title: Trojan Fever Breaking Out, Both Seriously And Less So
description: Fittingly perhaps the A&E documentary ''Troy: The Passion of Helen'' is a Trojan horse. Hidden inside a shell of historical inquiry and feminist revisionism lies a movie trailer for the latest sword-and-sandals epic, ''Troy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, SONIA
description: ROSENBERG -- Sonia. The Nutrition Program mourns ''Sunny'' Rosenberg's passing. With her daughter, Susan Goldstein, she generously supports research for more than 25 years through the Guttman & Rosenberg Foundations. We will miss her warmth, charm and wisdom. Richard S. Rivlin, M.D., Sr VP Inst. for Cancer Prevention

title: Phil Gersh, a Leading Agent In Hollywood, Is Dead at 92
description: Phil Gersh, the last of the Hollywood agents who dominated the talent business in the 1940's and 50's and represented some of the great stars and filmmakers of Hollywood's golden age, died on Monday at his home in Beverly Hills, his family announced. He was 92.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firms Named For East River Plan
description: A renowned British architectural firm, the Richard Rogers Partnership, and an emerging Manhattan firm, SHoP/Sharples Holden Pasquarelli, have been chosen to prepare a master plan for the redevelopment of the East River waterfront in Lower Manhattan, it was announced yesterday. The plan, being developed by the Economic Development Corporation and the City Planning Department and scheduled to be completed in 2005, covers an area from Battery Park to East River Park. Public meetings are to begin next month. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Loss Narrows
description: Italy's largest manufacturer, Fiat, reported its fourth consecutive quarter of narrowing losses, helped by the sale of assets and demand for new models. The first-quarter loss narrowed to 194 million euros ($230 million) from 681 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Sales fell to 11.2 billion euros from 12.3 billion euros because of the disposal of units including FiatAvio.

title: Brazil's Leader Reaffirms Plan to Expel Times Correspondent
description: Opposition leaders, press associations and legal and judicial groups in Brazil today protested the government's decision to expel a New York Times correspondent for a report critical of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, but Mr. da Silva said he would not consider revoking the action.

title: Sony Cuts PlayStation 2 Price To Compete With Nintendo
description: The Sony Corporation cut the price of its PlayStation 2 video game machine to $150 Tuesday to match the competition from Microsoft's Xbox as it moved ahead with its plans to challenge Nintendo as a maker of hand-held game players.

title: Corrections
description: The Wines of The Times column on April 28, about Iberian albarios, referred incorrectly to one of the wines, a 2001 Quinta do Dorado, from Portugal. It is not representative of the small percentage of albarios aged in barrels of new oak, and that process is not evident in its taste; like most albarios, it is stored only in stainless steel before bottling.

title: What Do Women Want? A Pill, or Much More? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Finished, Finally! Recreation Center Planned in the 70's Opens in Chelsea
description: It was the depths of New York City's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, and one of the lesser-known casualties was a half-built public recreation center for the residents of Chelsea. It had been designed to give the children in the neighborhood's brownstones and public housing a place to splash, shoot baskets and escape the scorching asphalt of summer.

title: Preparing Culturally Competent Leaders
description: Increasingly, demands on school leaders in Oregons public schools have escalated in response to changing demographics and pressures for high levels of student achievement. At the same time, programs that prepare those leaders have come under increasing scrutiny. The public wants assurance that schools can serve diverse communities and expects culturally competent leadership from principals and superintendents.

title: Candidates Face Sprawling and Complex Electoral Map
description: President Bush and Senator John Kerry are pouring resources into more than 20 states in a struggle to master what both sides describe as one of the largest and most complex electoral playing fields in nearly 20 years.

title: HSBC will consolidate its worldwide marketing under WPP, dealing a blow to Interpublic.
description: IN one of the largest recent consolidations of a worldwide marketing account, HSBC Holdings, the London-based bank, decided yesterday to unite its disparate assignments at agencies owned by the WPP Group in London. HSBC spends about $600 million a year on advertising, direct marketing and other methods of communicating with current and potential customers.

title: Mustard Isn't So Yellow Anymore
description: BRIVE-LA-GAILLARDE, France

title: Srichaphan Tries For Three In A Row
description: Paradorn Srichaphan of Thailand will return to Long Island in August looking to etch his name into the record books by winning his third consecutive TD Waterhouse Cup. Srichaphan will attempt to match the five-time winner Ivan Lendl (1984-86, '89, '91) as the second player to win the tournament three straight times.

title: What Do Women Want? A Pill, or Much More?
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Oh, Great One! May We Address You Such?

title: 9 Students at School for Deaf Say They Were Abused by Nuns
description: Nine former students of a now-closed Massachusetts school for the deaf filed a lawsuit on Tuesday saying they had been sexually, physically and emotionally abused by the Roman Catholic nuns who operated the institution.

title: Undisguised Pleasures Of a Former Critic
description: WHEN Mimi Sheraton was growing up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, back when she was still Miriam Solomon, she had great plans. She wasn't sure what they were, she recalled recently over lunch at her Greenwich Village home, but she confided to her mother: ''One day, Mom, I'm going to have a very big job. But I don't know what.'' Her mother considered. ''Maybe you'll wash an elephant,'' she replied.

title: An Exiled Pakistani Returns And in 90 Minutes Is Ousted
description: The opposition leader Mian Shahbaz Sharif was deported to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday almost immediately after he arrived here from more than three years of exile.

title: Man Accepts a Plea Deal In Case of Wife's Suicide
description: A Norwalk man whose troubled wife killed herself with a gun he had left in her dresser told a judge here Tuesday that he would not contest the state's charge of second-degree manslaughter in exchange for a suspended sentence.

title: U.S. Strikes Mosque Held by Iraqi Cleric's Militia
description: The American military attacked a mosque in this holy city on Tuesday in its largest assault yet against the forces of the rebel Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, even as the first signs emerged of a peaceful resolution to the five-week-long standoff with him.

title: Two More U.S. Soldiers to Face Courts-Martial for Iraq Abuse
description: Two more American soldiers will face courts-martial related to the abuse of Iraqis at the Abu Ghraib prison, the United States military announced in Baghdad today.

title: Editors' Note
description: Because of production difficulties, the Dining Section today is missing the articles on Page F2. All the articles in the section are available online at www.nytimes.com/dining.

title: Toyota Yearly Profit Up 55% On Sales and Cost-Cutting
description: Profit at the Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's second-largest carmaker, increased 55 percent in the fiscal year that just ended, thanks to growing sales in all major markets and aggressive cost-cutting.

title: DEAN FOODS IN SETTLEMENT TALKS WITH S.E.C.
description: The Dean Foods Company, the country's largest dairy producer, is in settlement talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission over accusations that it helped a customer inflate its revenue. Dean Foods said late Monday in a quarterly regulatory filing that it did not expect the investigation or the settlement to have a ''material adverse impact'' on its business. Dean, based in Dallas, was one of several food suppliers that were notified in November that the S.E.C. was considering civil lawsuits over the role they might have played in helping a grocery distributor, the Fleming Companies, exaggerate reported revenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airline Adds Fuel Fee
description: British Airways said it would add a surcharge of 5 ($8.89) to every round-trip fare on its British flights as a result of the rising price of oil. Outside Britain, fares will increase by $4 per flight sector. Airlines in the United States have tried to add fuel surcharges several times this year, but dropped them when their competitors did not match the fees. British Airways said it would review the charge on ''a regular basis with a view to adjusting it when appropriate.'' Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: A.C.C. to Announce New TV Deal
description: The reconfigured Atlantic Coast Conference, which will add Miami and Virginia Tech from the Big East next season, will announce a new seven-year football television contract with ESPN and ABC Sports today that is worth $258 million, an industry executive said. The deal also calls for the A.C.C. to hold a title game in 2005, when Boston College, also from the Big East, will join to make it a 12-team conference.

title: Survey Says Special Education Isn't as Troubled as Critics Claim
description: The special education system in the New York City public schools is not as troubled as previous reports have claimed, according to the results of a systemwide survey that the Department of Education released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKLAVER, LAURIE BASS
description: SKLAVER--Laurie Bass. The Board of Directors of Women At Risk express our heartfelt condolences to the Sklaver family. Laurie's work as a Board Member and Board President was an inspiration to all and she will be remembered in our hearts forever.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Surges
description: Industrial production in Brazil rose 11.9 percent in March from the year-earlier period, providing fresh evidence that Brazil's economy, the largest in South America, is gaining steam after shrinking in 2003 for the first time in a decade. Output in March rose 2.1 percent from February, helped in large part by a booming export sector, according to data released yesterday by the government's statistics agency. In the first quarter, industrial production rose 5.8 percent over the first three months of 2003. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Bryant and O'Neal Lead Lakers' Second-Half Surge
description: Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal may have their differences off the court, but when they are working together on it, nothing in the N.B.A. can compare. Not the pick-and-roll game of Tim Duncan and Tony Parker, and hence, not the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Wednesday about Homer Avila, a dancer who was undeterred by the amputation of a leg, misstated the date of his death. It was April 25, not April 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRAAD, RITA R.
description: FRAAD--Rita R., 88, on May 9th, 2004 at her home. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Fraad, Jr. Cherished mother of Sara Henderson and Martha Haffey, both of New York City, loving grandmother of six and great-grandmother of eight. No services. A later gathering will be announced. Contributions in memory of Rita R. Fraad to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; Reclamation Is Far From Certain for Brown's Latest Project
description: LARRY BROWN went to Detroit this season to coach the Pistons, in large part, because Allen Iverson didn't play there. After walking the thinnest of coaching lines in Philadelphia, Brown was suddenly free of the daily dramas, the spontaneous combustion, the demands of always having to operate from too close to the eye of a star player's storm.

title: Citigroup Settles Round 2
description: It's appropriate that the man running Citigroup these days, Charles Prince, is a lawyer. Despite the $2.65 billion settlement it reached with WorldCom investors on Monday, Citigroup still faces plenty of legal headaches for its prominent role in a slate of bubble-era corporate scandals. Even as it announced the WorldCom settlement, Citigroup also said it was adding billions more to a reserve fund to cover the potential costs of other litigation, including Enron-related lawsuits.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Even the person who came to explain it to us didn't understand it.''

title: Giants Check Out Warner. Warner Checks Out Giants.
description: The Giants' quarterback story included Kurt Warner, or at least the possibility of Kurt Warner, in its cast of characters when he was in East Rutherford, N.J., for dinner and a physical in the latest and most unusual twist in a drama that shows no signs of ending.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 23 about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's transformation from antiwar protester in the Vietnam years to strong supporter of the Iraq war referred incorrectly to a commencement address she criticized at Wellesley College in 1969, her graduation year, by Edward W. Brooke, then a Republican senator from Massachusetts. (The error also appeared in articles in 1992 and 1993.) The text shows that although the speech criticized student protests of the 1960's, Senator Brooke did not urge support for the Vietnam War.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Retailer's Sales Fall
description: Royal Ahold, the retailer, said first-quarter sales fell 11 percent, hurt by price reductions and the dollar's drop against the euro. Sales slid to 15.4 billion euros ($18.3 billion) from 17.3 billion euros a year earlier, said Fritz Schmuhl, a spokesman for the company, based in Zaandam, the Netherlands. Revenue also fell at the company's United States retail unit, which is the company's biggest and includes Giant and Stop & Shop supermarkets. Revenue dropped as Ahold cut prices on products ranging from beer to meat to compete with companies like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in the United States and Laurus in the Netherlands.

title: Shareholders In Italy Begin To Accept Role Of Inquisitor
description: The season of shareholders' meetings is in full swing, and in this town on the southern outskirts of Milan, investors in Telecom Italia took advantage of their once-a-year opportunity to voice complaints and compliments directly to management.

title: Accord Near for 9/11 Panel To Question Qaeda Leaders
description: The leaders of the commission investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks revealed on Tuesday that they were close to an agreement with the Bush administration that would allow the panel to submit questions to captured Qaeda leaders who are believed to have been involved in planning the attacks.

title: More Charges in Theft of Lockheed Files
description: A former manager of the Boeing Company was charged on Tuesday in a federal court with using documents stolen from the Lockheed Martin Corporation to help Boeing win a Pentagon rocket contract in 1998.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Capitol Internships May Be Revamped
description: Speaker Sheldon Silver of the State Assembly said yesterday that his chamber's internship program would be examined as part of a continuing review of Assembly policies. The move follows a police investigation of a motel encounter between Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV, above, and a 19-year-old female intern. Democratic lawmakers will report their findings and make recommendations so that new rules regarding interns can be developed as appropriate, said Charles R. Carrier, a spokesman for Mr. Silver. Mr. Silver has expressed concern about allegations that Mr. Powell, 42, gave alcohol to the intern on May 4 at a motel in Colonie. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Suit by Former Employee Charges Promotion of Drug's Off-Label Use
description: Before she ran afoul of her bosses, Joan Gallagher says, she was a top saleswoman for a small California biotechnology company. Now she is suing the company, saying it fired her last June for refusing to join an illegal effort to sell the company's main drug for an unapproved use.

title: IRAQ TAPE SHOWS THE DECAPITATION OF AN AMERICAN
description: An Islamist Web site posted a videotape on Tuesday showing the decapitation of an American in Iraq, in what the killers called revenge for the American mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FALL, JERRY J.
description: FALL--Jerry J. On May 9, 2004. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Fredricks) Fall. Loving father of John A., Peter A. and Jerry. Devoted brother of Mildred Kyrmes and Ann Frieze. Grandfather of nine. Reposing Thursday 24 PM only, at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Development Dept. at Montefiore Medical Center for the benefit of The Oncology Dept., 111 East 210th Street, Bronx, New York 10467, would be appreciated.

title: Warning in Afghanistan
description: The commander of American forces in Afghanistan, Lt. Gen. David W. Barno, warned Tuesday of more attacks from Taliban and Al Qaeda guerrillas, but he promised a relentless military response.

title: New Best Friends: Al Sharpton and Mark Green
description: Over the last two years, the Rev. Al Sharpton's criticisms of Mark Green, formerly the New York City public advocate, were so stinging that Mr. Sharpton often boasted that he had been a key factor in Mr. Green's loss to Michael R. Bloomberg in the 2001 mayoral race.

title: Judge Vacates Guilty Plea In Yemeni Case
description: For several years, a group of Yemeni men linked to a Park Slope ice cream shop have been the focus of a federal investigation that has included shadowy claims about the financing of terrorism in Brooklyn. Prosecutors have said the shop also was an illegal money transfer business and have suggested, without formally charging, that the little shop may have provided millions of dollars raised in the United States to international terrorist organizations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about fruit certified by the Fair Trade movement, which seeks to improve the lives of farmers in developing countries, misstated the sales policy of the Whole Foods Market chain. While it has no plans to carry the fruit, it does indeed sell other Fair Trade products, like coffee, tea and cocoa.

title: Hartford Journal; Rowland And a Roar Of Whispers
description: ''He's toast,'' say some. ''They're going to have to drag him out of there,'' say others.

title: 73 Options for Medicare Plan Fuel Chaos, Not Prescriptions
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the poverty in Haiti since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was forced from power on Feb. 29 referred incorrectly to Jean Panel, a man shown selling biscuits made of dirt. Mr. Panel is a resident of Fort Dimanche, a former political prison. He is not himself a former prisoner.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City and Union In Tentative Pact
description: The Bloomberg administration announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative three-year contract with a union representing 7,000 municipal middle managers and front-line supervisors. The deal with Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America calls for no raise but a $1,000 one-time payment in the first year; a 3 percent raise in the second year; and a 2 percent raise in the third. The agreement, modeled after an agreement with District Council 37, would provide an additional 1 percent raise in the third year if the city and union agreed on productivity savings to finance it. The agreement also calls for reduced pay, vacation and sick leave for newly hired workers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Winson Hudson, a pioneer of the civil rights movement in Mississippi, misstated the year in some copies for the killing of the rights worker James Chaney, who had been warned by her husband against going to Philadelphia, Miss. It was 1964, not 1963.

title: Foreigners Control Fifth of Mineral Wealth in American West, Study Shows
description: About 20 percent of the mineral wealth of the American West is claimed by foreign companies, most of them Canadian, according to a new analysis and online database released Monday by an environmental organization.

title: Putin Visits a 'Horrible'-Looking Grozny
description: In a rare visit to a war zone that has become Russia's quagmire, President Vladimir V. Putin made a quick trip on Tuesday to Chechnya, and said its bombed and battered capital, Grozny, looked ''horrible.''

title: Some Critics Of Wal-Mart Joining Forces To Change It
description: Correction Appended

title: Children's Welfare Chief Quits; Helped to Overhaul the System
description: William C. Bell, the city's commissioner of children's services, who helped institute a nationally regarded overhaul of the city's child welfare system, unexpectedly announced his resignation yesterday.

title: Meaty Excerpts And Novelties Open a Season
description: American Ballet Theater lite vied with Ballet Theater deep on Monday night in a gala performance that opened the company's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Now Pittsfield Stakes Claim to Baseball's Origins
description: A generation ago, the popular belief was that baseball was invented in 1839 in Cooperstown, N.Y., by Abner Doubleday. That belief was later refined, with the birth date shifting to 1846, in Hoboken, N.J. Still later, a New York University librarian found two newspaper references to some form of ''base ball'' in 1823 in New York City.

title: Executive Calls Vote-Machine Letter an Error
description: Walden W. O'Dell, the chairman and chief executive of Diebold Inc., said on Monday that it had been a ''huge mistake'' for him, as the head of a voting machine company, to express support for President Bush's re-election in a fund-raising letter last year. Mr. O'Dell also said the company was working to address computer security problems and build voter confidence in its wares.

title: Why the Polls Don't Add Up
description: You can hardly blame the Democrats if they seem a bit confused. After all, as the situation in Iraq has worsened over the past six weeks and national polls have shown a steep decline in President Bush's job-approval ratings (some, including the latest CBS/New York Times survey, have him registering well below the 50 percent mark), John Kerry can't seem to pull ahead of the president the national horse-race polls.

title: A Hall With Jazz on Its Mind; Basing a Season On Performers And New Works
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center's first season in its $128 million new home in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle will be a dialogue between the music and where it will be played. It's a program -- starting in the fall and to be announced today -- that has been carefully thought out from the moment the organization began to conceive the hall's physical space six years ago.

title: Kerry Sees McCain as a Possible Cabinet Member
description: John Kerry just cannot get enough of dropping John McCain's name.

title: Bush Imposes Sanctions on Syria, Citing Ties to Terrorism
description: After months of debate within his administration, President Bush imposed economic sanctions against Syria on Tuesday, charging that it has failed to take action against terrorist groups fighting Israel and halt the flow of foreign fighters into Iraq.

title: Iraq Videotape Shows the Decapitation of an American
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 11  An Islamist Web site posted a videotape on Tuesday showing the decapitation of an American in Iraq, in what the killers called revenge for the American mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison.

title: Adelphia Investor Tells of Talk About Loans
description: A mutual fund executive testified yesterday that Timothy Rigas, the former finance chief of Adelphia Communications, said in 2001 that ''outside investors'' had helped the Rigases buy company stock and debt.

title: Body in Trash Was Canadian Woman's
description: Investigators believe that a Canadian woman found dead on Monday in a garbage truck in Queens had been dropped at the home of her fianc's parents by a taxi driver on Friday morning, law enforcement officials said yesterday after interviewing the driver. But the police still have not determined whether she actually entered the house or who killed her, authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WALSHON, CAREN (NEE GREENBERG)
description: WALSHON -- Caren (nee Greenberg). Rest in peace in Heaven on your birthday. You had everything but good luck. .Mom, Arthur and Jay

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 23 about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's transformation from antiwar protester in the Vietnam years to strong supporter of the Iraq war referred incorrectly to a commencement address she criticized at Wellesley College in 1969, her graduation year, by Edward W. Brooke, then a Republican senator from Massachusetts. (The error also appeared in articles in 1992 and 1993.) The text shows that although the speech criticized student protests of the 1960's, Senator Brooke did not urge support for the Vietnam War.

title: Human Rights Riddle
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: A.F.L.-C.I.O. President To Visit China
description: After years of criticizing working conditions in China and the exodus of American jobs to there, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, John J. Sweeney, announced that he had accepted the invitation of China's Vice Premier, Wu Yi, to visit and examine factory conditions there. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Lie, and the Voters Will Believe
description: Americans like to say they are not influenced by campaign commercials, but then many people plainly believe the attack ads that President Bush and John Kerry are hurling at each other.

title: Nurses Urge Blair To Help Colleagues
description: The International Council of Nurses appealed Tuesday to Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to intervene on behalf of five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor who have been condemned to death in Libya.

title: Culturally Competent Leaders for the 21st Century
description: From its inception, the public school system has attempted to create unity from diversity. In doing so, states have often adopted policies that emphasize unity over diversity, creating school systems that are unfriendly to student populations outside of the cultural and racial mainstream. These policies are not only damaging to children and their families, but they result in a tragic loss of talent to the economy and to civil society. Excellence requires equity if we are to draw on the broadest talent pool available in the future.

title: Kerry's Wife Releases Some Financial Data and Promises More
description: Teresa Heinz Kerry earned more than $5 million from investments last year and paid more than $587,000 in federal income taxes, the presidential campaign of her husband, Senator John Kerry, said Tuesday.

title: 2 Big Mortgage Agencies Pressed To Buy More Low-Income Loans
description: An obscure rule intended to promote affordable housing has become the Bush administration's latest weapon in its effort to tighten the rules on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the giant mortgage finance companies.

title: EUROPE GIVES APPROVAL FOR J.P. MORGAN TO BUY BANK ONE
description: J.P. Morgan Chase & Company received European Union approval to buy the Bank One Corporation for about $55 billion. The combination, announced Jan. 14, will create a bank with $1.08 trillion in assets to challenge Citigroup, the world's largest financial-services company. ''The deal has no significant impact in Europe because there are only a limited number of overlaps,'' the European Commission, the competition watchdog based in Brussels, said.

title: Creating the Infrastructure to Develop a Culturally Competent Educator Leadership Workforce
description: Holly Zanville is associate vice chancellor for academic affairs at the Oregon University System. Yvette Webber-Davis is the director of diversity planning and special projects in the Oregon University System. \ Implications for a University System: Creating the Infrastructure to Develop a Culturally Competent Educator Leadership Workforce Holly Zanville, Ph.D., Associate Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs, Oregon University System Yvette Webber-Davis, Ph.D., Director of Diversity Planning & Special Projects, Oregon University System

title: Long Island Sound Is at Center Of a Power (and Gas) Struggle
description: For anyone keeping score in the utility wars being waged across Long Island Sound, here is the latest tally: The underwater power cable is now turned off, the proposed natural gas pipeline is inching forward, and combatants on both sides are preparing to launch a volley of lawsuits.

title: What Do Women Want? A Pill, or Much More?
description: To the Editor:

title: As the Storm Rages, Rumsfeld Is a Lightning Rod
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, DWIGHT F. III.
description: DAVIS--Dwight F. III. The Board of Directors and staff of the USTA Tennis and Education Foundation mourn the loss of our much respected board member Dwight F. Davis III. His dedication and enthusiasm toward improving the lives of disadvantaged children will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Anne Marie and the entire Davis family. Pam Shriver, President Alan Schwartz, Chairman, President, USTA Karen Martin-Eliezer, Exec. Dir. USTA T & EF

title: NBC AND VIVENDI UNIT EXPECT TO COMPLETE MERGER TODAY
description: The NBC unit of General Electric is expected to announce the completion of its merger with Vivendi Universal Entertainment at a news conference today that will introduce the top management of the new company. Most of the details of the new structure have been known for some time. Robert C. Wright, the NBC chairman, will lead the combined entity, to be called NBC Universal. Under him, Jeff Zucker and Randy Falco will share duties leading the NBC unit, while Ron Meyer will keep his position as the chief executive of the Universal division. But some new aspects of the deal are expected to be announced today, one senior NBC executive said. The news conference will be held in the studio that houses ''Saturday Night Live,'' at the NBC headquarters in Rockefeller Center. The merger will necessitate some layoffs, though they are not expected to be widespread. As few as 500 of the combined company's 15,000 employees are expected to be laid off: most of these are expected to be Universal employees. Bill Carter (NYT)

title: Taking On Exuberance With Vigor, Not Exaggeration
description: The dynamic American conductor David Zinman has been the music director of the eminent Tonhalle Orchestra of Zurich for almost 10 years. But only in recent seasons has his energizing effect on the ensemble started to gain wider attention. So there was great anticipation for the orchestra's two concerts at Carnegie Hall on Friday and Saturday nights. Critics from Switzerland and television crews from Zurich were on hand. That each program featured the superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes in a concerto -- Mozart's K. 271 on Friday and Brahms's First on Saturday -- lent further excitement to the events. Both programs were deeply satisfying.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on May 4 about proposals to mine coal and drill for natural gas in the Flathead Valley of British Columbia, north of Glacier National Park in Montana, misstated the origin of the International Joint Commission, which recommended against a previous coal proposal, in 1988. The commission was established by the 1909 Boundary Waters Treaty between the United States and Canada, not in response to it.

title: Wild Boar, the Other Prosciutto
description: With its boldness, wild boar prosciutto is to sweetly delicate Parma ham as muscular Pacific king salmon is to the milder farm-raised kind. Even the color of this ham, from animals in northern Ontario, is more intense. The flavor suggests bitter chocolate, black pepper, salt and port. Melon fades alongside it, so instead serve it with a rhubarb compote or a salad of roasted beets in a sherry vinaigrette. It is $35.95 a pound at Fairway, right. It also comes in 1.3-pound portions, unsliced, for $50 plus shipping, from D'Artagnan at (800) 327-8246 or www.dartagnan.com.

title: A Hall With Jazz on Its Mind
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center's first season in its $128 million new home in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle will be a dialogue between the music and where it will be played. It's a program  starting in the fall and to be announced today  that has been carefully thought out from the moment the organization began to conceive the hall's physical space six years ago.

title: Witness Says Tyco Chief Couldn't Grant Bonus
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, did not have the authority to grant a $17 million bonus for the company's general counsel, Mark A. Belnick, according to testimony yesterday from a former director.

title: A Thriller, Yes, a Thriller, All About Tortoises and Evolution
description: Michael Hollinger's ''Tooth and Claw'' may be a play about tortoises, but it sweeps along at a bracing pace more often seen in hares, bringing the momentum of a thriller to the sometimes dry arena of science plays.

title: Dreaming of Cuba in an East Village Breeze
description: FROM around the world, immigrants come to New York seeking new lives. As a glorious fringe benefit, they replenish and infuse the New York restaurant stew with all sorts of new flavors, direct from home. But a few countries are left out of the mix -- Cuba, for example.

title: Israeli Soldiers Search for Remains After Bomb Kills 6
description: Israeli troops conducted a grim house-to-house search for their comrades' remains here Tuesday night after Palestinian militants blew up an Israeli troop carrier and then said they had made off with body parts of the six soldiers killed inside.

title: Corrections
description: The Boldface Names column yesterday, about the premiere of ''Coffee and Cigarettes'' at the TriBeCa Film Festival, gave a misspelled name in some copies for the rap group whose members appear in the movie. title: Culturally Competent Leaders for the 21st Century
description: From its inception, the public school system has attempted to create unity from diversity. In doing so, states have often adopted policies that emphasize unity over diversity, creating school systems that are unfriendly to student populations outside of the cultural and racial mainstream. These policies are not only damaging to children and their families, but they result in a tragic loss of talent to the economy and to civil society. Excellence requires equity if we are to draw on the broadest talent pool available in the future.

description: Brazil said on Tuesday that it would expel a New York Times correspondent who wrote on Sunday of publicly expressed concerns about the drinking habits of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH GAINS EDGE IN QUEST FOR HARBIN
description: The American brewer Anheuser-Busch won support from the Chinese city of Harbin to buy the city's 29 percent stake in the local beer maker Harbin Brewery Group, gaining an advantage over the company's other investor, SABMiller. Harbin Brewery shares rose 6.3 percent, to 4.68 Hong Kong dollars (60 cents), after the mayor designated Anheuser-Busch as his preferred partner for Harbin, the maker of Hapi beer. SABMiller, based in Britain, and Anheuser-Busch, based in St. Louis, each own 29 percent of Harbin.

He has traveled the country, showing his unfinished documentary, ''The Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till,'' mostly at colleges, and has met with law enforcement officials, urging them to reopen the case.

title: Attacks Drive Price of Oil to $40 a Barrel
description: The price of crude oil surpassed $40 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Attacks on oil facilities in Iraq and Saudi Arabia in recent weeks have largely been responsible for driving up the price, industry experts said.

description: Kenyon Martin reasserted himself at Continental Arena on Tuesday night, which is a major reason the Nets are headed back to Detroit tied at 2-2 with the Pistons in their four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: Understudies for a Star Vintage
description: TO think of Bordeaux is to enter the world of wine stereotypes and clichs. ''Ah, yes, a very good year, more structured than the 83's, yet more open than the 78's,'' the wine snob murmurs, red-veined nose pressed deep into the tilted glass, a New Yorker cartoon without a punch line. No doubt, he is referring to Bordeaux, which, by way of the Mdoc's easy-to-figure hierarchical system of classification and the region's straightforward scorecard of vintage ratings, satisfies the neat-freak in any wine lover.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Warlord's Auction Fails
description: The regional strongman is gone, but nobody seems to want his stuff. Georgian television reported that there were no takers at an auction of the luxury cars, antique furniture, oil paintings and prized pure-bred dogs left behind last week by Aslan Abashidze, left, when he was forced to flee his fief, Ajaria, for Russia in the middle of the night. Georgia's president, Mikhail Saakashvili, who had vowed since his election in March to bring Ajaria under government control, said proceeds from the auction would have been spent on social projects for the province. The government said an election would be held on June 20 to replace Mr. Abashidze. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Blooming Grove: Marine Recruiter Accused
description: A recruiter for the United States Marine Corps has been accused of having sex with an under-age girl who wanted to enlist, the police said. The recruiter, Sgt. Shedrick Hamilton, 34, who is stationed in a Middletown office, has been recruiting high school students from neighboring Sullivan and Orange Counties for about three years, said Detective Sgt. John Heppes of the Blooming Grove Police Department. He said that between February and April, Sergeant Hamilton had sex six times with the 16-year-old girl, a student at Washingtonville High School. Detective Heppes declined to comment on whether the acts had been consensual. Blooming Grove is 53 miles northwest of New York City. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Rumsfeld Aide And a General Clash on Abuse
description: The Army general who first investigated abuses at Abu Ghraib prison stood by his inquiry's finding that military police officers should not have been involved in conditioning Iraqi detainees for interrogation, even as a senior Pentagon civilian sitting next to him at a Senate hearing on Tuesday disputed that conclusion.

title: For the Coolest Vibes: Accentuate Acoustics, Eliminate City Noise

Those windows, at the center of the fifth and sixth stories of the Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle, will be both the public face and the most serious acoustical challenge for Jazz at Lincoln Center's new home, the Frederick P. Rose Hall.

title: Almost 10% of All Prisoners Are Now Serving Life Terms
description: Almost 10 percent of all inmates in state and federal prisons are serving life sentences, an increase of 83 percent from 1992, according to a report released yesterday by the Sentencing Project, a prison research and advocacy group.

title: W.H.O. Sets AIDS Goal
description: The World Health Organization says in its annual report, due next week, that AIDS was the leading single cause of death worldwide for people ages 15 to 59. In 2003, three million people died of AIDS and five million people were infected with H.I.V., the agency reported.

title: Indian Voters Turn a Cold Shoulder to High Technology
description: As India's stock markets slumped further on electoral uncertainty Tuesday, the resounding defeat of a state leader who avidly courted multinational technology companies seemed to underscore a wider discontent among those whom India's economic boom never touched.

title: We Need to Know Our History
description: Iwill begin my answer to the question of why cultural competence has risen to the level that it has in the Oregon legislature and Department of Education with a statement that was made by a high school student at a recent community forum in Portland. The meeting was one of several convened by community members in the wake of a spate of other gang-related violent crimes that included the shooting of a 14-year old girl.

title: Virginia Capers, 78, Actress Who Won a Tony for 'Raisin'
description: Virginia Capers, an actress and singer who won a Tony Award in 1974 for her role in ''Raisin,'' the musical version of ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 78 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Derby Success Tinged With Sadness
description: Before there was Smarty Jones, there was an idea. It came from the trainer Robert Camac, who wanted to breed a mare to a relatively inexpensive and untested stallion, one with potential, one that might prove to be a bargain. That's what Camac told the owners Roy and Pat Chapman to do, and they listened. They always listened to Camac; he was smart, a good trainer, honest and a friend.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Heidrick Says It Received Google Warrants
description: Heidrick & Struggles International, the executive search firm that recruited Eric E. Schmidt to run Google, said it received warrants that allow it to buy 1.19 million Google shares for 30 cents each. Heidrick & Struggles disclosed the holding in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission as Google, the world's most-used Internet search engine, prepares for an initial public offering of stock. The company said its consultants who worked with Google, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., will receive about 50 percent of any gains from the warrants. The warrants would let Heidrick & Struggles pay about $357,000 for a 0.5 percent stake, based on the number of shares outstanding that Google reported last month. After the public offering, Heidrick's stake could be worth more than $85 million, based on analysts' estimates that the value of Google will be at least $17 billion. Shares of Chicago-based Heidrick & Struggles rose $1.56, to $27.01.
