title: What Happened to Emmett Till?
description: Younger Americans find it difficult to believe that black people in this country were once murdered in plain public view for seeking the right to vote or testifying against a white person in court. This was still the case in 1955, when civil rights lawyers canvassed the Mississippi countryside for witnesses to the murder of 14-year-old Emmett Till, a black boy who was kidnapped by white men at gunpoint three days before his bloated, mutilated corpse was pulled from the Tallahatchie River.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Scotland: 4 Killed In Factory Blast
description: A powerful explosion leveled a four-story plastics factory in Glasgow, killing at least 4 people and injuring 40 others. In scenes of drama akin to the aftermath of an earthquake, firefighters used sensitive instruments to locate survivors, some of whom managed to call out on mobile telephones to tell relatives they were trapped under steel and concrete but still alive. It was not known how many factory workers were trapped, but at least seven survivors were pulled out. The cause of the blast was not immediately known, but several employees told officials that a likely cause was one of four large gas-powered ovens on the ground floor of the building. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LA VINE, KENNETH NETTLETON
description: La VINE--Kenneth Nettleton of Vero Beach, FL died at his home on May 9, 2004. He was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1911, a son of the late Louis and Irene (Nettleton) La Vine. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1932 and from Yale Law School in 1935, where he was a member of the Yale Law Journal and was elected to the Order of The Coif, the national honorary legal society. Mr. La Vine joined the law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle in New York in 1935 where he remained until the outbreak of World War II. During the war, Mr. La Vine served in the U.S. Army 77th Division and ''Ultra'' in Army Intelligence in Washington, DC. On his return from the Army, Mr. La Vine rejoined the law firm and was a partner from 1950 until his retirement in 1981. For many years, Mr. La Vine was a director of Carlisle Corporation, Dover Corporation, The Leach Corporation and a number of other companies. During that time, Mr. La Vine lived in Forest Hills, NY. After his retirement, he and his wife, the former Mary Virginia Dailey, relocated to Florida. In 1998, they moved to Vero Beach, FL, where he was a parishioner of St. John of The Cross. An avid tennis and platform tennis player, he was a longtime member of The West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, NY. Mr. La Vine was predeceased by his daughter, Carol A. Coogan. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, his son Kenneth N. La Vine Jr. and his wife, Angel, his daughter, Linda Johnson and her husband, John, his son-in-law, James M. Coogan; five grandchildren, and one great grandson. Mr. La Vine will be reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. NYC on Wednesday, May 12, visiting hours 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM. A Funeral Mass will becelebrated at St. Thomas More Catholic Church, 65 East 89th Street, New York, on May 13 at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to the Hudson Valley National Foundation, 21 Scarsdale Road, Yonkers, NY 10707 in memory of his daughter, Carol A. Coogan, or to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70th St., NY, NY 10021.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Cassel: Garbage Truck Kills Worker
description: A trash company worker died yesterday when a garbage truck struck him, the Nassau County police said. The victim, Josaphat Pierre-Louis, 71, was working at a Long Island recycling yard for the Jamaica Ash and Rubble Removal Company yesterday morning when he stepped behind the truck. The truck's hydraulic arm, which is used to maneuver Dumpsters, struck him in the head, the police said. The driver, not realizing that Mr. Pierre-Louis lay injured, continued backing up, Detective Ray Birney said. Mr. Pierre-Louis, a 20-year employee, was pronounced dead at the scene. Detective Birney said the incident was ruled an accident. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Summertime Rooms Without Walls
description:
By MARIANNE ROHRLICH
It's getting hard to distinguish the living room from the garden, now that garden furniture comes in so many styles and materials.

title: Barneys Makes It Its Business to Outfit the House as Well as You
description: Department stores seem newly fashionable as places to buy furniture. In March Parisians flocked to Lafayette Maison, a five-story store devoted to the home. Last Saturday Barneys New York (680 Madison Avenue at 61st Street) opened its new housewares department, having enlarged the old Chelsea Passage. Tracy Edwards, the vice president in charge of Chelsea Passage, said Barneys is introducing kitchenware and expanding glass and textiles.

title: An Incandescent Friend Recalled
description: In her story of a tender and undying friendship between budding writers, Ann Patchett often invokes the fable of the grasshopper and the ant. She presents herself as the dutiful, hard-working figure and draws another writer, Lucy Grealy, as the more glamorous and flamboyant one. The only thing wrong with this formulation is that Ms. Patchett's latest novel, the gorgeous "Bel Canto," had nothing antlike about it. It was the dazzling performance of a butterfly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POTTER, WILLIAM S.
description: POTTER--William S. On May 11, 2004. Beloved husband of Rita. Father to Donald. Grandfather of Eileen. Greatgrandfather of Katherine and Elizabeth. Served in the British Navy during WW II. Constable in London. Resident manager of Peter Cooper Village/Stuyvesant Town. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. on Thursday and Friday, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10AM at Epiphany R.C. Church, 22nd St. and 2nd Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: For McDonald's, the 'I'm lovin' it' phrase of its new campaign has crossed over into the mainstream.
description: EVER since McDonald's introduced ''I'm lovin' it'' as its first global advertising theme last September, some people have wondered whether the message would fail, suggesting that anything from cold fries to sluggish service could undermine its authority.

title: Deal Complete, NBC Is Planning To Cross-Market
description: NBC formally announced the completion of its acquisition of Vivendi Universal's entertainment operations yesterday, promising a new entity that will aggressively cross-market its television, movie and theme park properties to drive profits while avoiding the pitfalls of previous media mergers.

title: Dancing Alone
description: It is time to ask this question: Do we have any chance of succeeding at regime change in Iraq without regime change here at home?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Livery-Cab Rates To Rise
description: Livery-cab passengers will be charged $1 more for a city ride and $5 more for transportation to an airport, in a fare increase that takes effect on Monday, a taxi federation announced yesterday. The increase, which does not require the approval of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, will affect about 20,000 livery cars, said Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers. The increase comes after the Taxi and Limousine Commission's decision to raise the rates for yellow cabs by 26 percent. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Studies in Subtlety Punctuated by Sparkling Crystals
description: Richard Alston has returned to New York from London, after 17 years, with a new company and an old choreographic style. Meticulously organized, with tightly woven patterns and an inherent joy, the three dances presented by the Richard Alston Dance Company on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater were an exquisite balm for tired eyes and souls.

title: Trade Gap Widens to $46 Billion on Oil Imports
description: The United States' trade deficit jumped sharply to a record $46 billion in March, propelled by a surge in oil imports and oil prices as well as strong demand for imported consumer goods, the Commerce Department reported on Wednesday.

title: Chip Off the Old Block, Only Not Quite So Dim
description: Despite their many advantages, screw-in fluorescent bulbs are often too big and too dim for vintage fixtures. Rejuvenation, a period lighting manufacturer, re-engineered its Grand Avenue fixture ($259), above, to accommodate two 42-watt fluorescents. They are bright enough to light a kitchen, and the sockets have pins so that ''Joe the maintenance man can't put in an incandescent bulb,'' said Jeff Shay, a company engineer. Rejuvenation, 2550 NW Nicolai Street, Portland, Ore. 97210; (888) 401-1900 or www.rejuvenation.com.

title: Mishaps Plague Reading Test; This Time It's the Makeup One
description: Put in multiple-choice form, the question for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday might have gone like this: Which of the following mishaps occurred on this year's citywide reading test? (A) Some teachers wrongly used last year's test for practice, giving children a peek at questions repeated on this year's exam. (B) Some questions were shown on television, forcing a postponement of makeup exams. (C) The answer sheet for yesterday's makeup test did not match the test booklet, causing widespread confusion, or (D) All of the above.

description: To the Editor:

title: Our Next Contestant Is a Retired General From Arkansas ...
description: Most of Senator John Kerry's vice presidential selection process is a tightly guarded secret, barely whispered about among even senior staff members at his Washington headquarters. But in the very public beauty contest taking place out on the campaign trail, retired Gen. Wesley K. Clark was the latest to stride down the runway.

title: The Open House: Mobs and The City
description: IN January, Eileen Foy, a real estate broker with Douglas Elliman in Manhattan, took two prospective buyers to see a one-bedroom apartment in an Upper East Side building. As she escorted them to the elevator, the superintendent chastised her for staging an open house, which had been recently forbidden by the building's co-op board.

title: Afghanistan Still Stirs A Housewife
description: Anyone who met the Homebody in the late fall of 2001 has surely been missing her since. It was in December 2001 to be exact -- only weeks after the events of 9/11 forever transformed New York's sense of itself -- that she was introduced to Manhattan audiences as the title character of Tony Kushner's ''Homebody/Kabul.'' For many of us this graciously awkward woman of flighty, elliptical speech and ineffable convictions offered warming comfort in a world that had taken on a newly aggressive chill.

title: Study Finds No Dire Need To Replace Tanker Fleet
description: In a setback for the Boeing Company, a Pentagon-commissioned report concludes that the Air Force does not need to replace its aging tanker fleet immediately, a conclusion that could spell the end of a $20 billion lease proposal by the Air Force and Boeing.

title: FILM: CALM AT CANNES
description: The sky was cloudy and the opening film dark, but relative calm reigned yesterday at the opening of the Cannes International Film Festival on the French Riviera. Threatened protests by a union representing actors and other entertainment workers angered by cuts in unemployment benefits were called off, though union members were allowed to express their discontents. The Spanish director Pedro Almodvar's ''Mala Educacin,'' a bleak story of child abuse by the Roman Catholic Church, provided a sharp contrast to the light fare that usually begins the festival. A. O. SCOTT

description: Arms flailing, hair flying and a scowl fixed on his face, Randy Johnson showed the Mets on Wednesday night how he became one of the best left-handed pitchers of his era.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Investor Increases Stake In Global Crossing
description: The investor Richard Rainwater increased his stake in Global Crossing Ltd. to 14 percent in the weeks after the company, a communications network provider, announced an earnings restatement that sent the shares plunging. Mr. Rainwater has acquired 2.61 million shares of the company, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, for $24.4 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The shares, down about 70 percent since the company came out of bankruptcy in December, rose as much as 16 percent yesterday. Mr. Rainwater joins the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hel in investing in Global Crossing, whose chief executive, John J. Legere, is seeking to increase revenue by selling a wider range of services on the company's 100,000-mile fiber optic network. Mr. Rainwater bought most of the shares after Global Crossing said last month that its financial statements were unreliable. Mr. Rainwater, who first bought shares on the open market on March 17, will not comment on his investments, a secretary at his office in Fort Worth said. Global Crossing shares rose $1.30, or 14 percent, to $10.70.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Vote On Restructuring Pension Agreements
description: Mayor Bill White said that Houston's principal pension plan for municipal workers has unfunded liabilities of $1.9 billion and its police retirement fund has an $846 million shortfall, both nearly double previous estimates. Voters on Saturday will consider Mr. White's request to invoke a state law allowing the city to restructure its pension agreements, which he has said cannot be met without issuing bonds or drastic austerity measures. An actuarial firm hired by the city blamed structural miscalculations rather than poor returns on the city's investments for the projected deficits. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Disney Will Sell Rights To Movie It Shunned
description: The Walt Disney Company will sell the rights to Michael Moore's controversial film ''Fahrenheit 9/11'' back to Bob and Harvey Weinstein, the co-founders of the Miramax division, who can arrange for the movie's distribution in North America, though not under the Miramax name, executives at the companies said on Wednesday.

title: A Jewel In the Moss
description: THERE is an old concrete frog perched on the top of a terrace at Greenwood Gardens. It once spouted water into seven pools cascading down the steep slope as if an Italian Renaissance garden had suddenly woke up in New Jersey.

title: SIEMENS IS BUYING MOST OF U.S. FILTER FROM VEOLIA
description: Siemens, Germany's largest engineering company, said yesterday that it planned to buy most of the U.S. Filter Corporation for $993 million in cash to expand in equipment for water treatment and supply, a business growing faster than most of its other units. The purchase, from the French water company Veolia Environnement, adds U.S. Filter units with $1.2 billion in annual sales, more than double the revenue Siemens gets from the industry now, the company said. The acquisition is the largest by Siemens, which is based in Munich, in three years. Veolia, based in Paris, bought U.S. Filter in 1999. U.S. Filter will keep its headquarters in Palm Desert, Calif.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Debt Rating Raised
description: The ratings agency Standard & Poor's raised the outlook for its rating on Indonesia's foreign debt, citing the government's improving fiscal position and its lower debt payments. The agency revised its outlook on Indonesia's long-term foreign currency rating to positive from stable, suggesting that it was considering upgrading the rating. Indonesia's rating is still below what the agency considers investment grade, and it is well below the ratings for Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand. The decision by Standard & Poor's helped lift Indonesian stock prices, pushing the benchmark stock index up 3.62 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Economic Growth
description: France's economic growth unexpectedly accelerated in the first quarter, expanding at the fastest pace in two years, as consumer spending helped offset slowing exports. Gross domestic product, the value of all goods and services, grew 0.8 percent from the fourth quarter, when it expanded a revised 0.6 percent, the national statistics office said. Economists had predicted growth of 0.5 percent, according to the median of 31 forecasts. The statistics office said that the growth was in line with an increase in household spending.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Boy, 4, Falls Four Stories
description: A 4-year-old boy was in critical condition last night after falling four stories from the window of an apartment building in the Bronx, the police said. The boy, whose identity was not released by the police, was being watched by a cousin in an apartment at 2420 Prospect Avenue in Belmont yesterday afternoon. The cousin left the apartment, the police said, and when he returned, found the boy in a courtyard. The cousin, Jose Portillo, 17, was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: SYNGENTA AND FOX PAINE TO BUY DUTCH SEED SUPPLIER
description: Syngenta, the world's biggest maker of crop chemicals, and Fox Paine, a buyout firm, said yesterday that they had agreed to buy the seed company Advanta B.V., which sells the Garst corn and soybean brands, for 400 million euros ($475 million). Syngenta, based in Basel, Switzerland, will pay 239 million euros for Advanta's North American corn and soybean business, the company said. Fox Paine, based in San Francisco, will pay 161 million euros for Advanta's operations outside North America and businesses other than corn and soybeans in the region. Advanta, based in the Netherlands, is a joint venture of AstraZeneca, the drug company, and Royal Cosun, the Dutch sugar maker.

description: An article on Tuesday about the discovery of a Canadian woman's body in a trash bin in Queens misspelled her surname in some copies and misstated her age. She was Stacy-Ann Sappleton, not Stapleton; her age was 26, not 27. The article also misspelled the surname of a branch manager at the insurance company for which Ms. Sappleton worked. She is Christy Bacik, not Black.

title: Disney Profit Increases 71%; Economy Cited
description: With a return of vacationers to theme parks and an increase in advertising revenue in its cable network business, the Walt Disney Company surprised investors on Wednesday with a better-than-expected second-quarter profit. The earnings were welcome news for Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive, who has been under pressure to improve performance or risk losing his job.

title: Manhattan Store Owner Accused of Underpaying and Sexually Harassing Workers
description: Three immigrant women yesterday filed a federal lawsuit that accused a Manhattan store owner of paying them far less than the $5.15-an-hour minimum wage and telling them he would not grant them raises unless they had sex with him.

title: Just in Time For Gin and Tonics
description: It is disappointing when a favorite design goes out of production. The secret of many a host -- the simple, thin-walled and inexpensive barware called Tempo from Crate & Barrel -- is being discontinued. But for the moment 10,000 of each of the two sizes (above, $1.95 each) are available. To restock, visit stores or www.crateandbarrel.com or call (800) 967-6696. This summer the glasses will be back as the Marta line, and available at CB2, a Crate & Barrel spinoff in Chicago. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Rancher Has Change Of Heart
description: Wally Klump, an Arizona rancher who spent the last 13 months in jail for refusing to remove 28 cows from federal land has been freed. Mr. Klump, 71, contends that federal land-use policies are invasive, illegal and tyrannical, and he had vowed to spend the rest of his days behind bars rather than bend to the will of the government. With his health failing, though, Mr. Klump had a change of heart. He promised a federal judge this week that he would no longer graze his livestock on the disputed land and that he would not shoot any federal agents. In return, Mr. Klump was granted his freedom and $65,000 in fines were waived. Mr. Klump could not be reached for comment, though his brother Wayne said, ''He says he's got a whole new meaning for the word freedom.'' Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: Panel Urged To Hear More From Mayor About Terror
description: Bob Kerrey, a member of the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, said yesterday that New York has unique status as the only city in the country to be a repeat target of foreign terrorists and that the panel should hear from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg when it meets here next week.

title: Corrections

It is the Index of Leading Environmental Indicators, not Economic Indicators.

description: A judge in Memphis has terminated the parental rights of a Chinese couple who say they were tricked into giving up their daughter, now 5, to foster parents when she was a baby.

description: PICASSO'S ''Boy With a Pipe (The Young Apprentice)'' sold at Sotheby's last week for $104.1 million, setting a record for a painting purchased at auction. But another notable development came with the first lot of the sale, when a 13-year-old boy waged a spirited bidding war for a Degas horse drawing.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Thomson To Buy DirecTV Set-Top Unit
description: Thomson, a provider of digital cable and satellite set-top boxes, will pay about $400 million to the DirecTV Group for its Hughes Network Systems set-top box manufacturing assets to help reinforce its video networks unit. DirecTV, the nation's biggest satellite television service, will receive an initial payment of $250 million in cash when the sale closes in the second quarter, Thomson said in an e-mail statement. Thomson, which is based in Boulogne-Billancourt, France, will develop new set-top models with DirecTV. It expects the acquisition to add to earnings from 2005 and to more than double annual revenue from DirecTV, a spokesman, Jean-Georges Micol, said. Thomson's revenue from DirecTV is about $300 million, two Goldman Sachs analysts, Tim Boddy and Robert Maclean, said in a note sent to investors. Thomson declined to disclose the amount of sales through DirecTV, its largest broadband client.

title: U.S. Discloses Wal-Mart Fine Of $3.1 Million

He was taken to Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, where he was pronounced dead. The police were looking for the driver last night. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

As the Yankees were completing an unsightly 11-2 loss to the Anaheim Angels, Posada was having surgery for a fractured nose.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: India's industrial output rose 6.9 percent in the fiscal year that ended in March, helped by ample rainfall across the country. According to figures released by the government's Central Statistical Organization, industrial output was more than the 5.7 percent growth recorded last year. In March, industrial output rose to 6.7 percent, compared with 5.9 percent in the month last year. The ample rainfall helped the economy by improving rural demand, and output of consumer durables, items like refrigerators and televisions, grew 20.3 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURRAY, SAMUEL J.
description: MURRAY--Samuel J., 85, of Winter Park, FL and Greenwich, CT, beloved husband of Evelyn Hardart, died April 28. Born December 7, 1918 in Cincinnati, OH to William and Anna Ahearn Murray. Graduated Georgetown U. 1941, Columbia Law School 1947. Served US Army 1942-47, 2nd Infantry Div. in France and Belgium. Wounded in Battle of the Bulge, January 17, 1945. Awarded Distinguished Service Cross, 2 Bronze Stars and 4 Purple Hearts. Associate with NY law firm Davis Polk to 1955. From 1951-53 took leave of absence when Gov. Dewey named him Special Assistant State Attorney General and Sr. Asst. Counsel, NY State Crime Commission, Waterfront Investigation. Partner with Forsythe, Decker, Murray & Hubbard, NY until 1979, then Greenwich with Murray & Rossmoore until 1983. Along with his wife he is survived by a brother, John F. of Scarsdale; three daughters: Margo of Santa Fe, Marcia of Winter Park, Evelyn McGowan of Litchfield, CT; three sons: Samuel J. Jr. of New Canaan, Frank H. of Greenwich, and Stephen C. of Hamden, CT, and seven grandchildren. Memorial Service Friday, May 14, St. Michael's, 469 North St., Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations to Disabled American Veterans Memorial Program, Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH 45250 or Catholic Charities.

title: For Summertime, Rooms Without Walls
description: IT'S getting hard to distinguish the living room from the garden, now that garden furniture comes in so many styles and materials. Some of the latest ideas for outdoor rooms are on view at Benchmark, an exhibition of 50 garden benches, through Sept. 12 at LongHouse Reserve, the East Hampton, N.Y., home of Jack Lenor Larson, the textile designer, which is open to the public on Wednesdays and Saturdays from 2 to 5 p.m. ($10). For information, (631) 329-3568 or www.longhouse.org. The exhibition includes Spirit Song Bench, above, which can be ordered in many sizes from Diamond Teak, (877) 874-8325.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Lufthansa Posts a Profit
description: An increase in travel and the sale of assets helped Lufthansa post a profit in the first quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss. But the result fell short of analysts' expectations, and the stock fell 5 percent. Lufthansa, based in Cologne, said it earned 62 million euros ($74 million), as revenue rose 5.2 percent to 3.9 billion euros. Excluding one-time items, the airline lost 116 million euros, an improvement from a 419 euro loss a year earlier. The sale of a stake in Amadeus, a global travel distribution system, contributed 292 million euros to its bottom line. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: European Union Eases Rule On Deficits for Six Entrants
description: In a pragmatic gesture to countries that struggled to become market economies in preparation for membership in the European Union, the European Commission granted 6 of the union's 10 new entrants a reprieve from budget deficit rules on Wednesday.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And, for Once, It Wasn't Us

title: Construction of Times Building Is Scheduled to Start in Summer
description: The New York Times Company and its partner plan to begin construction this summer of a long-awaited 52-story skyscraper at Eighth Avenue and 40th Street, where workers are now dismantling the vacant buildings on a two-acre site.

title: The March of Folly: History's Lessons, Unlearned

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Auto Stake Sale
description: DaimlerChrysler confirmed that it had agreed to sell its 10.5 percent stake in the Hyundai Motor Company, ending a four-year alliance. The move is another pullback by DaimlerChrysler from its Asia strategy. In mid-April, the company said that it would stop injecting funds into its ailing Japanese partner, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. Kim Dong Jin, vice chairman of Hyundai Motor, said Daimler would sell the stake, valued at $860 million, to several unidentified investors.

title: Election Panel Won't Impose New Spending Limits on Groups
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  The Federal Election Commission today refused, for now, to put limits on independent political groups that collect and spend millions in unlimited contributions, opening the way for advocacy groups supported by Democrats and Republicans to play a dramatic role in the 2004 elections.

title: With Addition of Coach, The Mets Focus on Health
description: Starting this season, the Mets have sent their legion of wounded players to Port St. Lucie, Fla., the team's spring training home and supposed health spa. Rarely have their injured returned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORTON, PAUL ALLEN
description: NORTON--Paul Allen. The Boy Scouts of America, Greater New York Councils acknowledges the passing of Paul Allen Norton, and extends its sincere sympathy to his son Richard, his daughter Carolyn and his many friends. Mr. Norton's leadership in the insurance industry was well known. His support for his church and his community as well as his efforts on behalf of boy scouting made a postive difference. The Greater New York Councils pay tribute to Mr. Norton as a wonderful supporter and a true friend. He will be missed. John F. McGillicuddy, President Charles E. Rosser, CEO

title: Warily, a Religious Leader Lifts His Voice in Politics
description: James C. Dobson, the child psychologist who is widely regarded as one of the nation's most influential evangelical leaders, has always sought to keep his public persona at a safe distance from the battlefield of partisan politics.

title: General Took Guantnamo Rules To Iraq for Handling of Prisoners
description: When Maj. Gen. Geoffrey D. Miller arrived in Iraq last August with a team of military police and intelligence specialists, the group was confronted by chaos.

title: NORTHROP, OPTIMISTIC ABOUT 2005, PLANS STOCK SPLIT
description: Northrop Grumman, the world's largest builder of warships, said yesterday that it expected sales to climb 7.1 percent next year as military spending rises. The company raised its dividend and will split its stock for the first time since 1984. The company, based in Los Angeles, forecast at least 10 percent growth in 2005 earnings per share on sales of $30 billion. First-quarter sales at Northrop's integrated-systems unit rose 39 percent, lifted by demand for the Global Hawk unmanned spy plane and the E-2 Advanced Hawkeye airborne early-warning aircraft. The stock split is payable June 21 to holders as of May 28. Investors will get an additional share for each one owned.

title: Clash of Civilizations
description: Testifying before the Senate yesterday, General Richard Myers admitted that we're checkmated in Iraq.

title: Finding Iconoclastic Playmates For Ives, That Musical Loner
description: By now the music of Charles Ives has become sufficiently well known that its radicalism should not take concertgoers by surprise. But on Tuesday night, when the dynamic American conductor David Robertson led the first program in the New York Philharmonic's Ives festival, I was stunned all over again by path-breaking and utterly idiosyncratic daring of Ives's music. The festival, which commemorates the 50th anniversary of Ives's death and runs through May 29, is subtitled ''An American Original in Context,'' and context was everything on this program, which also offered works by Debussy, Copland and Varse. It will be repeated tonight.

title: Manhattan Now and Then
description: In the art of surviving on Manhattan Island, it always helps to reimagine its possibilities. ''They were aware that they were shouldering a new world, impossibly dark, utterly unknown, of imponderable dimension,'' Russell Shorto writes of Henry Hudson and his crew. He conjures their sailing up the pristine Atlantic coast almost four centuries ago to turn for the first time into the grand harbor of what, in the title of Mr. Shorto's fascinating new history, became ''The Island at the Center of the World.'' His narrative distills rich archives from Manhattan's unsung Dutch pioneers, who planted crucial seeds of the island's cosmopolitan grit. It is a tale that makes a modern Manhattanite pause and wonder at the island's kaleidoscopic durability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, RUTH
description: WHITE--Ruth. You brought so much happiness into our father's life once again. We will forever be grateful. Alison and David Amy and Billy Susan and Neil

title: Explorers Still Seek El Dorado in the Mountains of Peru
description: It was just a sparkle on the horizon, where the sun hit what appeared to be a flat plain on an otherwise steep, untamed mountain in the Peruvian Andes. But Peter Frost, a British-born explorer and mountain guide, surmised that the perch would have made a perfect ceremonial platform for Inca rulers.

title: Q & A
description: Q. My Windows XP computer repeatedly reboots. What causes this?

title: Police Complaint Board Finds Some Strip Searches Improper
description: The independent city agency that investigates accusations of police abuse said yesterday that it had found evidence suggesting that officers may frequently be conducting inappropriate strip searches. It also said that officers and their supervisors are often unaware of Police Department procedures governing such searches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, ALAN
description: KING--Alan was a very good friend, Somebody I loved and respected for many years. We will miss him. My love and warmth at this time go to his lovely wife, Jeanette, and all their family. Mariana and George Kaufman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, RUTH LISBETH FRIED
description: KAUFMAN -- Ruth Lisbeth Fried, philanthropist, died Thursday, May 6th, 2004. Mother of Susan, Charles, Lloyd. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Norwalk Hospital, 34 Maple St., Norwalk, CT 06856. You are kindness, loyalty, decency personified. You are Moo.

title: Taking the Game War To a Second Front
description: A man in dark jeans and a Super Mario T-shirt slipped behind a pillar on the upper floor of Nintendo's 42,000-square-foot outpost at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the giant annual video-game trade show also known as E3. Unseen, he made his presence known with a handwritten message zapped onto an unusual new hand-held gaming system called the Nintendo DS.

title: Americans united in shock over beheading
description: WASHINGTON:  Americans on Wednesday reacted with shock and anger to widely disseminated images of the beheading of Nicholas Berg at the hands of extremists in Iraq, but were divided on how the United States should respond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRAAD, RITA R.
description: FRAAD--Rita R., 88, on May 9th, 2004 at her home. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Fraad, Jr. Cherished mother of Sara Henderson and Martha Haffey, both of New York City, loving grandmother of six and great-grandmother of eight. No services. A later gathering will be announced. Contributions in memory of Rita R. Fraad to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707 would be greatly appreciated.

title: For Smarty Jones, Post Seven and a Tall Order
description: The trainer John Servis has always believed in Smarty Jones, and now, so does just about everybody else. The colt is no longer the unproven underdog with somewhat suspect credentials. He is the undefeated Kentucky Derby winner and the star attraction of Saturday's Preakness at Pimlico, where he was installed Wednesday as the 8-5 morning-line favorite before drawing post seven for the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Unfurling on Your Dashboard, Every Ribbon of Highway
description: Global Positioning System locators can help you navigate an unfamiliar town, provided that you have downloaded detailed mapping data for the city involved. Garmin saves drivers a step with the StreetPilot 2620, which comes out of the box with detailed maps for the United States and parts of Canada -- no downloads necessary.

title: Kennedy to Run New York
description: Bob Kennedy, the United States' outstanding 5,000-meter runner of the 1990's, announced yesterday that he would make his marathon debut Nov. 7 in the New York City Marathon.

title: Showroom Guilty in Counterfeiting Case
description: IT took Nancy Corzine nine years and $900,000 in legal fees to prove that a showroom in Florida was counterfeiting her furniture. On March 29, Judge James Cohn of Federal District Court in Miami ruled in favor of Ms. Corzine, a designer with 16 luxury showrooms in the United States, and against Turner Greenberg Associates, which sold her furniture at its showroom in Dania Beach, Fla.

title: Fixing Taxes in New Jersey
description: It looked for a while as if Gov. James McGreevey might complete his first term without attending to the built-in inequities of New Jersey's tax system. As every resident must know, its property taxes are highest per capita in the nation, and the state's combination of local sales, income and property taxes is painfully regressive, socking the least able to pay with a rate that amounts to twice that of the wealthiest. Unfortunately, state leaders have regarded tax reform as a wooden stake that would kill their political fortunes, since it inevitably involves tax increases -- albeit increases counterbalanced with tax cuts.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit last Thursday with an article about energy-efficient design in lower-income housing misstated the photographer's surname. She is Meg Henson, not Hanson.

title: Dollars Without Borders
description: In the last five years, the age-old practice in which industrious folk send money from foreign lands to their families back home has become recognized as one of the most promising new ways to fight poverty. Unlike all of the other money flows from outside a country, these remittances go directly to poor people. The sums are huge. The $13 billion-plus that Mexicans send home from the United States in a year has surpassed tourism and oil as Mexico's largest source of income.

title: What the Nazis Stole, Museums Tend to Keep
description: PARIS -- For almost half a century, Europe overlooked the art treasures that were looted from Jewish homes by the Nazis and were never returned. Then, as mid-20th-century European history resurfaced in the 1990s, the political climate changed. Suddenly, missing art became a moral issue and red-faced governments, museums and auction houses hurriedly promised to make amends. In the glare of publicity, no one wanted to be seen profiting from the Holocaust.

title: Hello, Pay Phone Information? Enthusiast Provides the Answer
description: It started as an art project. Blue spiral notebook in hand, Mark Thomas spent afternoons walking the streets of Manhattan, compiling the numbers and locations of public pay phones. He posted them on his Web site in the hope that people would call them.

description: FROMIA--Jeanette F., on May 11, 2004. Retired from North American Philips Corp. Adored sister of Robert Fromia. Dear cousin of Gloria Johnson, Lorraine Novak, Maureen Duane, Adrienne Ellson, George D'Amato, Catherine Spier, Rose Sclafani, Catherine Pagliarulo and Peter Tavera. Reposing at Martin A. St. Mary's Cemetery.

description: AFTER the disaster of Sept. 11, there was a widespread conviction that the world had changed. One supposed change was a new sensitivity on the part of rich nations to the plight of the world's poor, and a new respect for ''nation building,'' even on the part of the Bush administration.

title: The Do-It-Yourself Cineplex
description: WHEN we decided to convert our garage into a small refuge for our teenage son, I had an epiphany. It wasn't a profound insight on the order of, say, special relativity. It was more on the level of ''even organic produce needs to be washed.'' But it was an epiphany nonetheless.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Support For Convention Protest
description: A group struggling to find a site for a demonstration on the eve of the Republican National Convention found support yesterday among some City Council members, who called on the Bloomberg administration to grant protesters a permit to rally in Central Park. The group, United for Peace and Justice, had applied for permits for a march and a rally of 250,000 people on the Great Lawn. But park officials denied the application last month, saying the space could not hold more than 80,000. The group has appealed, and officials have until Monday to respond. Councilman Bill Perkins, above, of Manhattan said he planned to convene a hearing in the next few weeks. Winnie Hu (NYT)

description: MORE ON IRAQ

title: In Big Blackout, Hindsight Is Not 20/20
description: As the electric grid approaches its season of peak strain, engineers say they still cannot answer the central question of how a power failure in Ohio on Aug. 14, 2003, became the biggest blackout in North American history.

title: The Competition; From Sony, a Hand-Held Entertainment Center
description: In moving to extend its reach into the lucrative mobile-gaming arena with the introduction of the PlayStation Portable, Sony is emphasizing what makes its hand-held the un-Game Boy.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Juvenile Justice Post Filled
description: Gov. Jeb Bush has named Anthony Schembri, a former New York City corrections commissioner, to run Florida's embattled Department of Juvenile Justice. Mr. Schembri, left, a member of the Florida Corrections Commission, resigned from the New York job in 1995 during an inquiry into whether he met residency requirements. The investigation later found he had violated city law by living outside the city during his tenure and by improperly spending more than $4,000 in overtime costs for drivers and tolls. Florida's former juvenile justice secretary, Bill Bankhead, has been on medical leave since February. The agency has been under fire since Omar Paisley, 17, died of a ruptured appendix in a Miami detention center last year, after going three days without medical care. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Pfizer to Pay $420 Million in Illegal Marketing Case
description: Pfizer Inc., the world's biggest drug company, has agreed to settle criminal and civil charges and pay fines of more than $430 million, the Justice Department and federal prosecutors in Massachusetts said today. .

title: Kerry's Few Words on Iraq Are Too Many for G.O.P.
description: Trying to stay focused on health care and education, Senator John Kerry has spoken only sparingly this week on Iraq, but his words have been pointed. He renewed a longstanding call for Defense Secretary Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld's resignation, said higher-ups must be held accountable for the abuse of Iraqi prisoners and condemned the beheading of an American civilian.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Corpse's Identity Remains A Mystery
description: The body of an Asian man that washed ashore in Atlantic Beach on Sunday night remains unidentified. The body, which had no hands or feet, was thought to be that of a sailor missing from a tanker that sank off the Virginia coast in late February, but the Nassau County police said yesterday that the assumption was wrong. Sgt. Richard Laursen of the homicide squad said the disfigurement might have been caused by its nearly three-month submersion. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Google to Sell Type of Ad It Once Shunned
description: Google, the Web search engine which attracted a loyal following in part because its simple Web site is uncluttered by obtrusive graphical banner ads, has now decided to sell the sort of ads it once scorned.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Supreme Court To Review Tobacco Case
description: The State Supreme Court said it would review an appeals court reversal of a $145 billion judgment against the five biggest tobacco companies. The decision is a setback for cigarette makers; last year, the state's Third District Court of Appeals overturned the record award that had been issued in 2000 in a suit brought by smokers who claimed to have been misled about the effects of smoking. The appellate court also decertified the class action. The plaintiffs' lawyers asked the state Supreme Court to review the case. In a statement posted on its Web site, the court said that it would hear arguments in the case on Oct. 6. The defendants are Philip Morris USA, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings, Lorillard Tobacco, the Brown & Williamson unit of British American Tobacco; and Liggett Group. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

description: NEW DELHI, May 13  The opposition Indian National Congress scored a resounding victory in parliamentary elections today, forcing Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and his governing coalition to resign.

Rumsfeld, the man at the center of the furor over American soldiers' abuse of Iraqis at the Abu Ghraib prison, spent last Sunday in the backyard garden of his elegant Washington home, poring over Pentagon documents piled 10 inches high in his lap. Mr. Rumsfeld barely listened as his wife chatted with a visiting friend.

title: For Walls That Lack Character, A Clay That Thinks It's Plaster
description: American Clay Plaster, above, can imitate rough Provenal plaster or Venetian plaster, said Croft Elsaesser, its inventor. His clay-plaster formula combines marble dust, pigment and clay, but no cement or acrylic. The powder is shipped in 50-pound buckets or sacks. Mixed with water, it is easily troweled over almost any primed surface, including textured ceilings and old paint. Twelve standard colors are 65 cents a square foot, including shipping. Other colors (custom samples are $50) add slightly to the price. A soy-based sealant will make it washable. American Clay Plaster, 2601 Karsten Court SE, Albuquerque, N.M., 87102; www.americanclay.com or (866) 404-1634.

title: Many Who Served on 9/11 Press Fight for Compensation
description: It is in places like Judge Mark Solomon's workers' compensation courtroom in Brooklyn that lingering questions about the health consequences of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center are fought over day after day.

title: Odom Gets 22 Points And the Heat Gets Even
description: The Indiana Pacers do not lose two straight games often, but they lost their second straight Wednesday night when the Miami Heat, buoyed by another frenzied home crowd, evened its four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal series at 2-2.

title: Els Planning to Stay Busy Leading Up to U.S. Open
description: If Ernie Els feels fatigued at the United States Open next month, he will have only himself to blame.

title: British Inquiry Says Paper's Prison Abuse Photos Were Faked
description: LONDON, May 13  The British government said today that its investigation into a series of published photographs showing the brutal mistreatment of an Iraqi prisoner has concluded that the photos were not taken in Iraq and, therefore, must have been faked.

title: Shiite Leaders Reporting Progress in Talks on Najaf, But the Fiery Cleric Balks
description: Shiite leaders reported progress Wednesday toward an agreement that would end a five-week-old standoff with the radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr in the holy city of Najaf, but Mr. Sadr himself vowed to fight on and gun battles continued between American forces and his followers.

title: Judge Allows Peek Into Challenge to Antiterrorism Law
description: In a ruling Wednesday, a federal judge in Manhattan widened the public's glimpse into a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union challenging some terms of the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act, after the government sought to keep virtually every detail of the case under a court seal, or secrecy order.

title: Interrogation Methods Violated Geneva Rules, General Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  A top general acknowledged today, in a long and often angry Senate hearing, that interrogation techniques used by American guards in an Iraq prison violated the Geneva Conventions, and he said he did not know who had approved them.

title: Op-Chart; Where the Jobs Are
description: Job jitters are vexing America. Not even the striking gains in employment over the last two months have put an end to hand wringing over work being ''outsourced'' to low-wage countries. Americans had become used to shedding factory jobs, but the technology and service jobs now at risk were supposed to be secure, the guarantee of our future. So we're left to wonder: what will Americans do?

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Energy Dept. To Develop Supercomputer
description: The Department of Energy said yesterday that it was planning to begin financing the development of a new science-oriented supercomputer in an effort to wrest back the world's fastest computer crown from the Japanese. According to Spencer Abraham, the energy secretary, the agency has committed $25 million annually in initial spending to develop a Cray supercomputer to be installed at Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee. The goal is a machine capable of sustaining 50 trillion calculations a second on scientific problems. Currently the world's fastest supercomputer is the Earth Simulator, based in Yokohama, Japan, and built by the NEC Corporation. That computer has been rated at 35.8 trillion calculations a second. Second place is held by a weapons-oriented supercomputer, the ASCI Q machine, capable of 13.8 trillion calculations a second. It is based at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Newman Day Called Cruel Joke by Actor
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 12 - Paul Newman, who lost a son to drug abuse, says that naming a day of drinking at Princeton University after him is a "cruel joke."

title: Our Next Contestant Is a Retired General From Arkansas ...
description: Most of Senator John Kerry's vice presidential selection process is a tightly guarded secret, barely whispered about among even senior staff members at his Washington headquarters. But in the very public beauty contest taking place out on the campaign trail, retired Gen. Wesley K. Clark was the latest to stride down the runway.

title: Drivers Find an Ally in a Road That's All Eyes
description: ABOUT 12 years ago, Martin Dicks was trapped in dense fog during a harrowing four-hour commute to his job as a firefighter in central London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMINSKY, EDWIN
description: KAMINSKY--Edwin. Temple Beth-El of Cedarhurst records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Edwin Kaminsky. We grieve with the family on their loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Sotheby's Tops Estimate With 100 Percent Sale Result
description: Riding on the coattails of Christie's $102.1 million sale, which set a record on Tuesday night for postwar and contemporary art, Sotheby's scored 100 percent last night. While the offerings were not as strong as those at Christie's and the $65.6 million total was not nearly so impressive, the auction showed further evidence of a blossoming market. Price levels rose for works from every period, from a classic 44-year-old painting by Clyfford Still to a year-old canvas by Takashi Murakami.

description: The videotaped beheading of Nicholas Berg, the young American civilian, by Islamic militants received widely divergent treatment in the Arab press on Wednesday, with most papers playing it up but some ignoring it.

title: Preakness 2004: 10 Rivals Out to Get Smarty
description: Six survivors of the Kentucky Derby and five fresh horses have been entered in the 129th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, although the status of The Cliff's Edge is unclear. Frank Carulli, the oddsmaker at Pimlico Race Course, set the morning line; Joe Drape listed the horses in order of preference and provided the comments.

title: In Cannes, This Festival of Film Lives Up to Its Purpose
description: CANNES, France, May 13  People who have never been to the Cannes Film Festival like to imagine that it is a nonstop, two-week orgy of cinema and celebrity, awash in Champagne and movie-star glamour, illuminated by a million paparazzi flashbulbs. People who have been there, on the other hand, like to pretend that it isn't. In recent years, especially, some of us have returned home with a litany of complaints. The films are disappointing. The pace is grueling. The security guards are unfriendly. The schedules are hard to read. It sometimes rains. Boo-hoo.

title: MOODY'S SAYS IT MAY LOWER DELTA'S DEBT RATINGS
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it might lower the debt ratings of Delta Air Lines, which this week said it might be forced into bankruptcy protection unless it was able to cut costs. Moody's, which already places Delta's senior debt six steps below investment grade, said it was reviewing ratings on $11.8 billion in borrowings. Standard & Poor's Ratings Services yesterday changed its outlook on the airline to negative, also indicating the possibility of a downgrading.

title: Hearing Transcript Shows Rumors of Prison Abuse Before Investigation
description: A transcript of a hearing into the scandal at Abu Ghraib shows that there were rumors and suspicions of abuse among personnel before the formal investigation started in January.

title: Another Cartoon Canvas Of Neurotic New York
description: On a recent sunny afternoon Roz Chast, the New Yorker cartoonist, was standing in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in front of its new ''Dangerous Liaisons'' exhibition, an impressive collection of some of the most sumptuous costumes, gowns and wiggery that 18th-century France could create.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUEBEN, STANLEY
description: RUEBEN--Stanley. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Stanley Rueben, treasured friend and colleague, who selflessly served as Director of Administrative Services until his retirement in 1989. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Jeri; to his children Leonard and Karen; and to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Keeping the Road to Princeton in Leafy Shade
description: TWO rows of arching elm trees line Washington Road to Princeton. The trees, their branches casting leafy shadows over the black surface, testify to the endurance of a hardy stock that has withstood the hand of God and man. The elms, unlike most, survived the nationwide scourge of Dutch elm disease, and more recently the threat of a road-widening project that was abandoned.

His playing, with its commanding, ancient-sounding chords and the kind of arm power that gets a roar out of the piano's bass clef, has remained powerful. I am a product of our district and the city, and I wanted to be a part of their future.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Cadence Names Chief Executive
description: Cadence Design Systems, the world's No.2 maker of computer chip design software, yesterday named Michael J. Fister, a former Intel executive, as chief executive to replace H. Raymond Bingham, who was elected chairman. The former chairman, Donald L. Lucas, will remain a director, Cadence, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said in a statement. Mr. Fister was also named Cadence's president. Abhijit Talwalkar, 40, will succeed Mr. Fister at Intel, which announced the change in a separate statement and is a Cadence customer. Mr. Fister, 49, joins Cadence as it works to regain its lead after losing sales to Synopsys Inc. Chip makers have yet to increase spending on design programs, and Mr. Bingham has said he does not expect sales to rise until the second half. Cadence had a first-quarter net loss of $8.76 million on $265.7 million in sales. At Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, Mr. Fister was a senior vice president and general manager who ran the server-chip business. That unit's flagship processor, Itanium, has been slow to catch on, gaining 5 percent of the market since its introduction three years ago, the market researcher Gartner said.

description: China's economy continued to barrel ahead in April despite a series of measures by Beijing to slow growth, a raft of statistics showed on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELISLE, DENNIS R.
description: BELISLE--Dennis R. Beloved husband of Catherine, devoted and loving father of Nicole and Michael, cherished son of Florence and Raymond. Also survived by a host of many uncles, aunts, nieces, nephews, cousins and other relatives and friends. Graduate of LaSalle Academy in Providence, RI; attended Boston College, received MBA from Columbia University; over thirty years in Investment Banking/Brokerage in NYC, with Morgan Stanley, KTC Brokers, Solomon Brothers, Prudential Securities, and AIG, former member NY Athletic Club, Bradford Bath and Tennis Club, longtime member and second home of University Club. Visitation will be held Sunday May 16th from 2-4 and 6-8PM at the Fournier & Fournier FuneralHome, 463 South Main St, Woonsocket, RI. Funeral will be held Monday May 17th at 9 AM from the funeral home with a Mass at 10AM in St. John's Church, Church St, North Smithfield, RI. Burial to follow in parish Cemetery. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, May 19th at 6:30PM in St. Caspian Church, 190 Lorraine Ave, in Upper Montclair, NJ. Family receiving friends in Church reception hall following service. All above services open to friends and family. Loved and cherished by his family, friends, and business associates. ''We will all miss your stories, Rest in Peace, dear Dennis.'' In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Belisle Children's Trust Fund, c/o Mark Dessauer, Esq, PO Box 3740, Kingsport, TN 37664.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBI, RUTH
description: JACOBI--Ruth, 82, died peacefully in her sleep at home on May 12th, 2004. Beloved wife of Lou Jacobi. Dear sister of Estelle Dubin Steiger and aunt of many loving nieces and nephews. Ruth devoted much of her life to Jewish causes, including serving as National V.P. of Hadassah and speaking on behalf of UJA and Israel Bonds. After marrying Lou, Ruth dedicated herself to his career in the theater, film and television. A true New Yorker, Ruth brought a lust for life and a passion for people wherever she went. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM, ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. Donations in her memory to Jewish Federation, C/O Sam Asher, Exec V.P., Jewish Federation of Delaware, 100 W. 10 St., Suite 301, Wilmington, DE 19801.

title: Baseball Analysis; From Coast to Coast And No Middle Ground
description: Several Anaheim Angels were hunched over a picnic table in the clubhouse before their game yesterday with the Yankees, a pile of newspapers spread in front of them. The Angels were searching for remarks from the Yankees, then repeating some of those comments and, perhaps, cataloging them for future reference.

title: Paterno Gets a 4-Year Extension at Age 77
description: Penn State yesterday extended the contract of Joe Paterno to coach the football team through the 2008 season, when he will be approaching his 82nd birthday.

At home in major ballet companies, on Broadway and with his modern-dance troupe in unconventional performing spaces, he is now pouring whirlpools and waves of passionate movement into his new ''Pentimento.''

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Jury Will Hear About McVeigh
description: Jurors in the trial of Terry L. Nichols may hear testimony regarding the extremist political views of Timothy J. McVeigh, his co-conspirator in the bombing of the 1995 Oklahoma City federal building, Judge Steven W. Taylor ruled. Lawyers for Mr. Nichols are trying to demonstrate that antigovernment tracts that the police found in his home were left there by Mr. McVeigh. Mr. Nichols, 49, is on trial in a state court on 161 counts of murder, and prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. He is already serving a life prison sentence for his conviction on federal charges arising from the bombing. Mr. McVeigh was convicted in a federal trial and executed in 2001. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Execution Of Mexican Is Halted
description: In the first case to put in effect a sweeping ruling by an international court in the Netherlands concerning Mexicans on death row here, an Oklahoma appeals court yesterday halted the execution of one of those inmates, Osbaldo Torres. He had been scheduled to be executed on Tuesday.

Served in the British Navy during WW II. Constable in London. Resident manager of Peter Cooper Village/Stuyvesant Town. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. on Thursday and Friday, 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 10AM at Epiphany R.C. title: Bishop Would Deny Rite For Defiant Catholic Voters
description: The Roman Catholic bishop of Colorado Springs has issued a pastoral letter saying that American Catholics should not receive communion if they vote for politicians who defy church teaching by supporting abortion rights, same-sex marriage, euthanasia or stem-cell research.

title: How the Feds Got Their Men
description: It is early in May. As cherry trees blossom along the Potomac, members of Congress are castigating the Federal Bureau of Investigation for its inability to reign in heavily armed attackers who have struck at the heart of America. Critics say the bureau is incapable of discerning where the attackers may strike next, unwilling to work with rival agencies and unfit to fight what appears to be a new kind of modern war. Some call for its wholesale reorganization. The embattled director of the bureau pleads for more resources to combat the rising threat.

title: Police Wonder If Cabby Erred Before a Killing
description: Officials investigating the perplexing case of a Canadian woman found dead in a garbage truck in Queens now believe that a taxi she took from La Guardia Airport dropped her off on the wrong block, leaving her disoriented and vulnerable to strangers, a police official said yesterday. The body of the woman, Stacy-Ann Sappleton, 26, showed signs of a fierce struggle with an attacker, the official said.

title: Metal Detector Before the Matre d' at the Rainbow Room
description: The Art Deco richness and panoramic views of the Rainbow Room may soon be complicated by more utilitarian features: metal detectors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Sex Offender Gropes Boy, 6
description: A 6-year-old boy was sexually assaulted by a convicted sex offender in a Bronx drugstore yesterday afternoon, the police said. They said that the boy was in the store, at 950 Southern Boulevard, when a man approached him about 3:30 p.m. and touched him inappropriately. Security guards detained the man, identified by the police as Virerio Franceschini, 35, of the Bronx, and called the police. Mr. Franceschini was arrested and charged with sexual abuse, the police said. He has been arrested 12 times and convicted twice for sex-related crimes, they said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Jean-Jacques Laffont, Economist, Dies at 57
description: Jean-Jacques Laffont, an economist known for developing mathematical models to estimate what something is worth in situations of deep uncertainty, died on May 1 in Toulouse, France. He was 57.

title: Wachovia Field Announced
description: The organizers of the Wachovia cycling series announced yesterday that their three races next month had attracted the riders Mark McCormack, Fred Rodriguez, Bobby Julich and Chris Horner of the United States; Gabriele Balducci and Mirko Celestino of Italy; and Henk Vogels of Australia.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Profit Rises
description: The insurance and banking concern ING said that its first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, to 1.2 billion euros ($1.4 billion), helped by its strong life insurance business in the United States and its Internet banking division, ING Direct. ING earned 902 million euros a year earlier. Income at ING's banking operations rose 13 percent, to 3.3 billion euros.

title: Food, Wine and San Luis Obispo
description: IN a state (California, of course) noted for sun-drenched easy living and eccentricity, San Luis Obispo stands out with its ambitious restaurants, funky shops and sprawling vineyards. Not to mention a historic Spanish mission, a nearby ocean beach -- and a wall decorated with wads of chewing gum. Page 4.

Rumsfeld, entering the heart of the global furor over the mistreatment of Iraqi detainees, walked inside the faded yellow walls and razor wire of Abu Ghraib prison on Thursday to pledge that the world will see America mete out punishment openly and freely to any soldier guilty of abuse.

description: Senate Democrats and Republicans attacked Bush administration officials on Thursday for submitting a vaguely worded request to add $25 billion to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan beginning on Oct. 1.

title: Report Calls for Accountability and Services to Deal With Sexual Assaults in Military
description: The Defense Department called on Thursday for more accountability, more education and more services to deal with sexual assault cases within the ranks of the United States armed forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOLOKER, PAULINE
description: BOLOKER--Pauline. Loved by all that knew her. Admired by her children. A loving mentor to her grandchildren. She will be terribly missed byall her nieces & nephews who grew up at her knee. Her sister Honie and brothers Paul and Jerome Berko will treasure her memory forever.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Less Cellphone Number Switching Than Expected
description: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that rules allowing consumers to keep cellphone numbers when switching carriers had a weaker impact on the industry than expected. But the new rule, which became effective last November, has increased competition among carriers. John B. Muleta, chief of the commission's Wireless Telecommunications Bureau, said more than two million numbers had been transferred since last November, far fewer than the 12 million some industry analysts had predicted. The rule has caused a shift in market share among carriers, Mr. Muleta said, without providing specifics. Company reports show AT&T Wireless had the most defections by customers in the first quarter, while Verizon Wireless had the fewest. Number portability has only been available in the 100 largest markets since November. On May 24, number portability will become available in the rest of the country. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Needle in The Database
description: Intelligence is the lifeblood of America's war on terrorism, but many question our ability to manage it. How did we not know about those 19 hijackers? How could we have identified weapons stockpiles that didn't exist, overstated Qaeda ties to Saddam Hussein and misinterpreted Iraqi support for an American invasion? How could we have lost Osama bin Laden altogether?

title: The Schwarzenegger Game Plan: Bypass the Politicians and Strike a Deal With the People
description: A few weeks ago, while on vacation in Hawaii, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger mused about how nice it would be if California had a part-time, rather than a full-time, Legislature.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: East Northport: Fireman Accused Of Arson
description: A volunteer firefighter from Suffolk County was charged with setting three fires in East Northport over the last two years, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The firefighter, Michael Meyer, 29, of East Northport, was arrested on Wednesday afternoon and charged with third-degree arson, the police said. Mr. Meyer is accused of burning down a partly constructed house in September 2002 and setting fire to two businesses last month. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Where Neon Meets The Road
description: YOU can't miss the blur of colors streaking toward you. The motorcycle -- a 2000 Honda CBR600F4 sport bike -- screams bright yellow. The rider pops out of the landscape in brilliant red -- a ketchup-colored space-age-nylon riding suit with reflective panels. Light glints off her silver helmet.

title: India Shifts Course
description: In a stunning political shift, Indian voters have decisively rejected the governing Hindu nationalist party and the coalition partners that have kept Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee in office since 1998. Liberalizing economic policies carried out under Mr. Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party governments have given India statistically impressive economic growth. Yet in a country where poor people vote in large numbers, most of them remain unimpressed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 10 about the presidential election in Algeria referred incorrectly to the recent history of multiparty elections there. (The error also occurred in an article on April 6.) Multiparty presidential elections were held in 1995 and 1999, and multiparty local and parliamentary elections in 1997 and 2002. The most recent voting, in which President Abdelaziz Bouteflika won a second term, was not the first multiparty presidential election since a military coup in 1992.

title: DILLER OF INTERACTIVECORP SELLS VIVENDI UNIVERSAL STAKE
description: Barry Diller, who controls the Internet commerce company InterActiveCorp, sold his personal stake in Vivendi Universal Entertainment for $275 million after Vivendi Universal exercised a call right. Vivendi, which completed the sale of its media assets in the United States to the General Electric Company's NBC on Wednesday, bought Diller's 1.5 percent stake, Vivendi's chief operating officer, Jean-Bernard Levy, said on a conference call with investors. InterActiveCorp will keep its 5.4 percent in the entertainment unit, which is being folded into NBC Universal, he said.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Smallpox Vaccine Complications
description: Heart complications from smallpox vaccinations administered to American troops are occurring at a higher rate than expected, according to a review of the program. About 16 people of every 100,000 given a smallpox vaccine for the first time between December 2002 and September 2003 developed myopericarditis, an inflammation of the heart muscle or the sac surrounding it, said Dimitri Cassimatis, a cardiology fellow at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, who was the lead author of the paper, published in the journal of the American College of Cardiology. The Defense Department resumed smallpox vaccinations to protect against possible bioterrorist attacks. ''Myopericarditis has occurred more frequently than we'd expected,'' Dr. Cassimatis said. ''If these results are generalizable to the general public, and if there were ever a need for mass vaccinations, then we could potentially see thousands of cases.''

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees View Clemens From a Long Distance
description: AS National League batters have discovered, Roger Clemens's fastball is exploding for the Houston Astros now. But his 7-0 record and 1.99 earned run average have appreciative admirers in the Yankees' clubhouse, where he spent the previous five seasons. Derek Jeter and Jorge Posada send him e-mail messages or call him occasionally. And from the television highlights that Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach, has seen, the 41-year-old Clemens is in ''the same groove'' that he was in the 2001 season, when he was 20-3.

Velella of the Bronx, a powerhouse in city and state Republican politics, plans to plead guilty to a felony charge stemming from a bribery case as part of a deal that will send him to jail for up to a year and force him to resign his Senate seat, two Republican officials who were told of his plans said Thursday.

title: Teenagers at Drinking Party Lock Doors as Police Arrive
description: In a twist in the continuing saga of under-age drinking in Westchester County, police officers who responded to a noise complaint at a house party recently got an unusual reception: The high school students at the party closed the doors, turned out the lights and hunkered down for three hours.

title: Multiple Characters in a Human Kaleidoscope
description: New Yorkers know that bars are like neighborhoods. Hostile or incompatible groups are separated by bar stools instead of streets and apartments. Christopher Shinn's new play, ''Where Do We Live,'' which opened Tuesday night at the Vineyard Theater, begins in a bar like this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'DONNELL, GWYNNE (NEE LARGE)
description: O'DONNELL--Gwynne (nee Large). On May 12, 2004 of Katonah, NY. Beloved wife of the late John F. O'Donnell, former general counsel of TWU. Devoted mother of Patricia, Sean, Eileen Sheehan and Cathleen Paprocki. Dear sister of Everitas Houghton. Also survived by eight grandchildren and 12 great grandchildren. Friends may call at the Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, on Friday 2-4 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be held in St. Mary's Church, Katonah, on Saturday at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Columban Fathers are requested.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Wednesday about the extension of the Jackie Hoffman comedy show ''The Kvetching Continues'' at Joe's Pub in Manhattan included erroneous times and dates supplied by a publicist for next month. Peformances will be at 7:30 p.m. on June 7, 21 and 28, not every Monday in June at 9:30.

title: Thrown Together Amid War, They Slowly Grow Together
description: Andr Tchin's taut, swift wartime drama ''Strayed'' is the second French movie in recent months to portray the panicked mass exodus from Paris in 1940 on the eve of the German occupation. The first, Jean-Paul Rappeneau's ''Bon Voyage,'' which opened in March, was an epic, multi-character farce (and nostalgic 40's movie tribute) whose ebullient surface half-camouflaged its far from silver lining.

title: Nicholas Berg's Death
description: It's easy to say he should not have been in Iraq, but Nicholas Berg was a type familiar to all danger zones: an adventurous and nave young man who was perhaps keen to do a bit of business, but keener yet to test himself; old enough to understand the danger, but young enough to defy it. It is impossible not to feel grief, and horror, at his terrible end.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Council Lawyer Resigns
description: The City Council's top lawyer, Thomas L. McMahon, resigned yesterday, but he said that his resignation was not related to allegations that the Council had mishandled sexual-harassment complaints against a Queens councilman. His lawyer, Richard Emery, also released a report by an independent arbitration firm that found no evidence of wrongdoing by Mr. McMahon, who has served as the body's general counsel since 2002. Mr. McMahon, 49, said that he would join an Albany-based government-relations firm at the end of this month. A female lawyer has said that Mr. McMahon and Speaker Gifford Miller did not act quickly to address her complaints about Councilman Allan W. Jennings Jr. Winnie Hu (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: In Politics, Book Tours Take Place In TV Studios
description: When Bob Woodward turned up on ''Larry King Live'' to promote his Bush-invades-Iraq book, ''Plan of Attack,'' first he took a call from a viewer in Hartford, then from a viewer in Cleveland, then from Prince Bandar bin Sultan -- the Saudi ambassador who figures prominently in the book as the man who knew about the president's decision to go to war even before Secretary of State Colin Powell did. In a move that might have seemed wacky if the subject weren't so serious, Prince Bandar called the show to spin his story. He flattered Mr. Woodward, said that the president hadn't really decided on war when he got the news, and along the way demonstrated how powerfully the intersection of television and books helps drive the country's political conversation. (An hour before, Prince Bandar had also phoned in and gotten his call on ''Paula Zahn Live,'' and that's not even a call-in show.)

title: Israel Ready to Widen Patrol Zone in Gaza Near Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, May 14  Israel will substantially widen an Army-patrolled zone at the southern end of the Gaza Strip near the Egyptian border, a step that will involve demolishing many Palestinian buildings, a senior Israeli official said today.

description: There is a scene in the film ''Hoosiers'' in which Gene Hackman takes his small-town team to a large, sparkling arena in Indianapolis for the state final. To allay the fears of his wide-eyed players, Hackman pulls out a tape measure and reassures his players that the rim is still 10 feet above the floor and the dimensions of the court are the same as in their band-box gym.

title: An Eye Close to New York's Pulsing Heart
description: Murders and fires, said the tabloid photographer Arthur Fellig (1899-1968), better known as Weegee, were his two ''best sellers,'' his ''bread and butter.'' Probably no one snapped them more often or candidly than he, with the aid of police radios kept by his bed and in his car, his 4 by 5 Speed Graphic with flash attachment and his insatiable need to be first at the scene of the crime.

title: RAYTHEON TO CUT EARNINGS BY $335 MILLION TO SETTLE SUIT
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it would reduce earnings by $335 million in the second quarter to settle a class-action lawsuit from 1999 that accused the company of misleading investors. The case, filed in the Federal District Court in Massachusetts, accused the company of failing to provide full information concerning its financial performance in a period when its shares fell 58 percent. In March 2002, the court certified the class as investors who bought Raytheon stock from Oct. 7, 1998 to Oct. 12, 1999. Raytheon, based in Waltham, Mass., suffered a series of delays and cost overruns on several defense and engineering contracts, and slowing sales of its products, which caused it to record $638 million of costs in the third quarter of 1999, and reduce its earnings forecasts for 1999 and 2000. The settlement includes a cash payment of $210 million, and warrants for Raytheon stock with a value of $200 million.

Devoted grandmother of Dani, Tom and Gaby Dioguardi. New York Times crossword puzzle afficionado! We'll miss you mom!

title: A Living Laboratory For Olmsted's Designs
description: THE first thing visitors see when they reach Fairsted is a high wooden fence -- a rustic-looking row of spruce poles surrounding the property. The fence continues in an arch over the driveway, framing the view: a giant hemlock tree, some shrubs, the beginnings of a lawn and just a sliver of house. It's obvious from the start that the focus here, at the Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site, is on the landscape.

description: KARA--Sona. On May 4, 2004 at home. Loving sister of Christina Zambakian, beloved aunt of Linda Yates and Marsha Watson, greataunt of six children. A graduate of Juilliard School of Music and former opera singer; music was her life. Memorial services will be held Saturday, May 22, 10:30, St. Vartan's Church, 630 2nd Ave.

title: Craven Referees of Politics
description: In a shameful decision that will unleash a fresh torrent of unregulated donations to pollute the presidential election, the Federal Election Commission has declined to control the new ''shadow party'' attack groups that are evading the campaign finance law. The commission voted yesterday not to rein in puppet Democratic operations that are already spending scores of millions in big unregulated donations from unions and fat-cat partisans.

description: ''Helter Skelter,'' helter, shmelter. The three-hour CBS movie on Sunday night about one of the most brutal killing sprees in Los Angeles history is a big bore.
