description: Sports have nearly disappeared from Bob Costas's HBO program, ''On the Record,'' this season, a peculiar situation akin to Ted Koppel's leaving politics and foreign affairs out of ''Nightline'' for a week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Report On Helicopter Crash
description: Federal investigators issued a preliminary report yesterday on last week's crash of a television news helicopter in Brooklyn, describing chaos in the cockpit but drawing no conclusions about the crash's cause. The National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates crashes, typically issues conclusions long after an accident, sometimes a year or more. The three people aboard the WNBC-TV helicopter were not seriously injured. In the report released yesterday, the pilot, Russell C. Mowry, was quoted as saying that the first problem he recalled was the helicopter's nose facing down, and that ''the helicopter was not responding to his control inputs 'the way it should be,' and he attempted to land on a rooftop.'' According to the report, records showed that the helicopter was last inspected on April 19. Michael Brick (NYT)

The passage, which said limitations on such protests violate the First Amendment, was written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Scalia dissented separately, on similar grounds.

He is a deputy assistant secretary of defense for legislative affairs, not a deputy secretary of defense. A picture caption with the continuation misidentified the senator who left the session with Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison. He was John Cornyn, not Saxby Chambliss.

title: An Episodic Ride Full of Serial Sipping and Smoking
description: You would expect a movie called ''Coffee and Cigarettes'' to be leisurely, even indolent. To grab a smoke or a cup of coffee, after all, is the preferred way to take a break -- from work, from the stressful routines of ordinary life, from the rush of indistinguishable moments that make up our days. Or at least it used to be, before we starting sipping our lattes on the run out of cardboard cups and before smoking changed from an indoor, social vice into a furtive, solitary sidewalk indulgence.

title: Lamar Peterson -- 'Milk and Cookies'
description: Deitch Projects

title: Lightning Gets Back on Track Quickly Against Flyers
description: With one flick of his stick, Philadelphia center Keith Primeau made Tampa Bay goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin look vulnerable and lifted the Flyers back into the game. Nearly 20,000 fans made as much noise as they could as the Flyers cut the Lightning's lead to 2-1.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 766 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Resolute Bay Journal; Undaunted Arctic Couriers, Coming In With the Veggies
description: Takeoff is delayed for several minutes when the Global Positioning System locks up, apparently from the cold. Once the plane is airborne, the terrain below is a white swirling desert, sculptured of snow and ice. Then a sudden fog settles in.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Reuters To Sell Yankee Group
description: The Reuters Group has reached a deal to sell the Yankee Group, a Boston research and consulting company, to private investors. Reuters bought the Yankee Group, a telecommunications- and technology-focused concern, for $72.5 million in cash in 2000. It declined to disclose financial terms of the sale. The investor group was led by the private equity firm Monitor Clipper Partners. It includes Ted Philip, former chief financial officer of Lycos.

title: Japan's Love Affair With the Postcard Made the Medium the Message
description: In perhaps the largest mail drop in art history, Leonard A. Lauder gave 20,000 postcards to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston in 2002. ''Art of the Japanese Postcard'' displays 350 of them, dating from 1900 to 1940. Two things are striking about them other than their range, wit and beauty: how slyly self-referential many of them are and how many ways they find to be self-referential. But first, some history.

title: Regulators Fine Riggs $25 Million
description: Federal regulators fined the Riggs National Corporation, the parent company of Riggs Bank, $25 million yesterday for failing to report suspicious activity, the largest penalty ever assessed against a domestic bank in connection with money laundering.

title: Accused Soldier Paints Scene of Eager Mayhem
description: When a fresh crop of detainees arrived at Abu Ghraib prison one night in late October, their jailers set upon them.

title: Corrections
description: A film review yesterday about ''Slaves of the Sword: Ariel Sharon'' and ''The Junction,'' documentaries on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, misidentified the group that filled the power vacuum in Lebanon after the Palestine Liberation Organization was driven out by an Israeli invasion under Mr. Sharon. It was Hezbollah, not Hamas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHARFE, LUBA
description: SCHARFE--Luba of Ft. Lauderdale, FL on May 11, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving step-mother of Charlotte Hildebrandt and the late Charles Jr. Devoted sister of Sophia Shera. Cherished aunt of Dahl and Douglas. Dear grandmother of seven, great grandmother of 16 and great aunt of three. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Religious service 8:00 pm Sunday. Burial Monday Cypress Hills Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Posts Gain
description: The French bank Socit Gnrale said profit rose 65.8 percent, to 801 million euros ($953.4 million), in the first quarter, helped by strong results in its core businesses, low provisions for bad loans, and capital gains. The bank's corporate and investment banking division reported its best performance since the first quarter of 2000 with income of 329 million euros, up 66.2 percent from the year-earlier period. Socit Gnrale said it earned 127 million euros from the sale of its stake in the property company Sophia and set aside 48 million euros for bad loans, down from a quarterly average of 130 million euros in 2003. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: A.H. Green? You Could Sit on It
description: SOMETIMES, tilting at windmills is not the quixotic adventure it's cracked up to be. Once in a while, the windmills turn out to be giants, just as that La Mancha fellow believed. And now and then, mirabile dictu, they topple.

title: Chad Rebel Group Says It Holds Qaeda-Linked Terrorist
description: A rebel group in Chad says it is holding one of North Africa's most powerful terrorists and wants to turn him over to the United States or any of its allies.

title: A Moving Church Visit
description: Three visions of dance and the spirit combined comfortably on May 7 at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The Washington Reflections Company, directed by Fabian Barnes, conveys its messages through modern dance. M'bewe Escobar/M'word! adds feminism to the mix, and A Time to Dance communicates through church or gospel dancing.

title: U.S. Forces Push Fight in Najaf, and Clashes Erupt in Karbala
description: American forces stepped up their fight against militants loyal to the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr today, sending tanks and helicopters into the center of the holy Shiite city of Najaf and pounding positions held by Mr. Sadr's Madhi Army.

title: Inside a Notorious Prison, Fires of Rage and Regret
description: The human life teeming through ''Carandiru,'' Hector Babenco's sprawling portrait of Brazil's criminal class crowded within a notorious So Paulo penitentiary, exudes a throbbing flesh-and-blood intensity so compelling that it's impossible to avert your eyes. Watching this messy epic is a little like being jammed into an unair-conditioned subway car on a steamy summer night as it rattles through an urban wasteland. At any second things could explode. And eventually they do.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOELTERHOFF, OLGA CHRISTINE

description: Dia:Beacon, the gargantuan museum opened last spring by the Dia Art Foundation in a renovated factory overlooking the Hudson River here, is a feat, but it is not without flaws.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Wins Contract From BellSouth
description: Lucent Technologies won a three-year contract from the BellSouth Corporation for equipment that will provide Internet calling services for businesses. A Lucent spokeswoman, Denise Panyik-Dale, declined to disclose terms of the agreement.

title: Cannes the Festival, Cannes the Fantasy
description: PEOPLE who have never been to the Cannes Film Festival like to imagine that it is a nonstop, two-week orgy of cinema and celebrity, awash in Champagne and movie-star glamour, illuminated by a million paparazzi flashbulbs. People who have been there, on the other hand, like to pretend that it isn't. In recent years especially, some of us have returned home with a litany of complaints. The films are disappointing. The pace is grueling. The security guards are unfriendly. The schedules are hard to read. It sometimes rains. Boohoo.

title: Manuals Ignite New Conflict In School Promotion Policy
description: The city's Education Department unveiled a 48-page manual for teachers yesterday and a 27-page manual for principals that offer step-by-step instructions for carrying out Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's new promotion policy for third graders.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Mayor, Under Investigation, Kills Himself
description: Mayor Ben Stewart of Union Point was pronounced dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound just as a grand jury convened to consider a racketeering and securities fraud indictment against him, the Greene County prosecutor, Fred Bright, said. Police officers found Mr. Stewart, who had been mayor for 24 years of the small town about 75 miles east of Atlanta, after he called the chief of police and told him he intended to kill himself, the Greene County sheriff, Chris Houston, said. Mr. Stewart, 55, had filed for bankruptcy, and was accused of taking some $38 million from investors in a pyramid scheme. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: 1929:Plans To Cut Visa Fees : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: PARIS: The complaints which have been more or less loudly expressed against the passport and visa nuisances on both sides of the Atlantic since the war have at last borne fruit in an agreement between France and the United States, announced yesterday [May 13], by which visitors from one country to the other will pay but $2.00, or the equivalent in francs, for their visas, beginning June 1. The charge of $10 for an American visa imposed on Europeans visiting the United States has been a sore point with European governments and resulted in a semi-retaliatory measure in European currencies on Americans visiting Europe. Whereas, however, a European visiting America had to pay $10 once, an American tourist crossing the Atlantic to see a little of the Old World usually had $50 worth of visas attached to his passport before he left New York.

title: Shopping List | Gear
description: SOME say there is an element of narcissism in motorcycling -- bikers like to be seen. But it is not always to show off. Motorcyclists are using an array of devices and garments to increase their safety by helping them stand out in traffic. Here is a sampling. ANN FERRAR

title: A Transplanted Music Festival Keeps Its Spirit of Adventure
description: The Mata Festival, once presented at the Anthology Film Archives (the name is an acronym for Music at the Anthology), has migrated from the East Village to Chelsea, but its freewheeling spirit has remained intact. This year's programs, which run through tomorrow, include 16 premieres for forces ranging from mechanical and electronic instruments to a cello duet, various chamber configurations and a choir.

title: The Spurs Win ... No, Wait, the Lakers Win
description: With fans standing a few feet away screaming, ''It ain't good, it ain't good,'' three referees and a host of players gathered around a television monitor Thursday night at the SBC Center. One of the greatest finishes in National Basketball Association history, and perhaps the deciding moment in this Western Conference semifinal series, was at stake.

title: The Trans-Atlantic Divide Is Growing Ever Deeper
description: BERLIN - It has to be one of the more painful paradoxes of recent history that a few American soldiers have inadvertently furthered a goal that Osama bin Laden could only have been dreaming of in such gestures as his offer of a "truce" to Europe of a few weeks ago. With their behavior in the Abu Ghraib prison they have shaken the sense of moral solidarity that has always been at the core of the trans-Atlantic alliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERNBERG, ANN
description: STERNBERG--Ann, on May 13. Amazing mother to Julia Sternberg Lindner and sister to Joan Patsy Ostroy. Devoted and loving friend and colleague. A beautiful, vibrant woman full of spirit, music and love. She will be remembered always. Service Friday 10AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: War Crimes Complaint Filed By a Lawyer Against Britain
description: A French lawyer said Thursday that he had filed a war crimes complaint against Britain at the International Criminal Court in The Hague for abuse of prisoners in Iraq. But there were immediate questions about whether the court would ever have jurisdiction in the case.

title: A Highly Choreographed After-School Special
description: The magical rapid transit of dance brought young people from four New York City boroughs to St. Mark's Chuch in the East Village on May 8. They gathered in a program called ''NYONY 2004: The Subway Series,''presented by the church's Danspace Project in cooperation with the Puffin Foundation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Orders for new machinery fell 3.2 percent in March from February, tempering some of the recent optimism about the strength of Japan's economic recovery. The decline was unexpected, as economists were forecasting a moderate increase in the figure, an important though sometimes volatile statistic. The drop was partly a result of weakness in orders from telecommunications companies and other nonmanufacturers. The government still expects orders to rise over the long term, an official said.

title: Quick Wits Along With 70's Hits
description: Self-effacing modesty is a quality so rarely encountered among performers that your first instinct when coming across it is not to believe your ears. But the songwriter and singer Paul Williams, who is appearing at Feinstein's at the Regency through tomorrow, relishes cracking serious jokes about his accomplishments.

title: First Loan Of Ex-Lawyer For Tyco Is Recalled
description: Mark A. Belnick received a company loan as part of his first employment contract when he took a job as general counsel for Tyco International in 1998, a former law partner testified yesterday at Mr. Belnick's criminal trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOLOTOWSKY
description: BOLOTOWSKY -- Meta Co hen, of NYC. February 11th, 1922--May 9th, 2004. Ferociously funny, valiant and brave for all of her life.

description: Ending a decade-long conflict, Fordham University announced plans yesterday to tear down a radio tower that has marred views from the New York Botanical Garden and build a new antenna on top of a residential building much farther away.

title: Stronger Sales Bolster Dell, But Its Operating Margins Dip
description: Dell Inc. reported record earnings for its first quarter yesterday, citing surging international sales and the strongest demand from United States corporations in more than three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ALAN J.
description: COHEN--Alan J. Dad, you are my world. My entire life is filled with memories of your love which will remain in my heart and soul forever. Your unparalleled values will continue to guide me throughout my life. I am so proud and lucky to be ''Alan Cohen's daughter.'' I love you with all my heart. Alison

description: Conceding that he is an a "tough race" to win re-election, President Bush told a group of supporters in Missouri today that he deserves to be given another term because "we have a war to win."

title: Constitutional Court Reinstates South Korea's Impeached President
description: South Korea's nine-member Constitutional Court ruled Friday to dismiss the impeachment case against President Roh Moo Hyun, restoring full powers to the president, in a case that had tested the nation's fledgling democracy.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Bill Requires DNA From Felons
description: The State Senate has passed a bill to require all convicted felons to submit to DNA testing so that their genetic material can be compared with evidence found at crime scenes. The bill, which was passed Wednesday, is headed to Gov. Bob Holden. A similar bill passed the state House Tuesday. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: DOW CHEMICAL DROPS '95 LAWSUIT AGAINST MONSANTO
description: The Dow Chemical Company's AgroSciences unit dropped a 1995 lawsuit that accused a rival, the Monsanto Company, of infringing a patent for genetic technology to protect plants against insect damage. Dow AgroSciences agreed to dismiss the lawsuit after the United States Patent and Trademark Office ruled in February that Monsanto, the world's biggest developer of genetically engineered crops, was the first to invent the technology. Dow, based in Midland, Mich., is appealing the patent office's decision in federal court. The dispute focuses on a race between the two companies to obtain patents related to genetically enhanced crops. Monsanto is based in St. Louis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Settlement For Deaf Patients
description: Parkway Hospital has agreed to aid deaf patients after being sued by the federal government and an advocacy group. In consent decrees reached last month, the hospital agreed to install an audio-video interpretation system, supply live interpreters upon request, and pay $125,000 to the family of a deaf patient. The hospital did not admit any liability. Parkway, a 250-bed hospital in Forest Hills, admitted Sarah Posner, 77 and deaf, in 2001. To communicate with Mrs. Posner, the hospital staff exchanged notes with her husband and son, who are both deaf, and relied on a staff therapist with limited sign-language training. In 2002, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest and the United States attorney's office filed separate suits alleging the abridgement of Mrs. Posner's civil rights. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: JUDGMENT AGAINST JOHNSON & JOHNSON VOIDED
description: Johnson & Johnson has persuaded the Mississippi Supreme Court to throw out a $100 million jury award to users of the Propulsid heartburn medicine in the first case involving the drug to go to trial. Mississippi's high court concluded late yesterday that a judge in the September 2001 trial improperly combined the accusations of 10 consumers that the drug caused an irregular heartbeat. The company halted pharmacy sales of Propulsid in July 2000, after the drug was linked to at least 300 deaths. Jurors in a state court in Port Gibson, Miss., found that a Johnson & Johnson unit sold Propulsid knowing that some users experienced dangerous side effects when taking it with other drugs and awarded the former users $10 million each. The judge in the case had already slashed the total award to $48 million. Lawyers for the former Propulsid users said they intended to retry the cases separately.

title: Drinking, Driving, Crashing and Surviving, but Damaged
description: The accidents are surprisingly similar. A car so contorted none could look worse; it seems there's no metal left to twist. Medevac, a gurney, a body gone white. ''Is he dead?'' ''That's the medication.'' Months of erratic rebirth -- the rolled eyes, slurred words and lurches into tears. A spike of optimism around physical therapy. The retreat of doctors. And then years of the gothic: something is not quite right about him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda's Profit Rises
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation said its net profit rose 40.5 percent, to 33.9 billion yen ($299.8 million), for the year ended March 31, helped by strong sales of the Axela sedan and other new models in Europe. Mazda posted a 23 percent increase in revenue for the year, to 2.92 trillion yen. The strong performance comes after years of restructuring under the guidance of Ford, which owns a third of Mazda and is using Mazda technology in many of its newest cars. However, Mazda forecast profit would remain about the same for the year ahead. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Contemporary-Art Prices Keep Rising at Auction
description: For the third consecutive night, prices for contemporary art continued to rise so high that even some of the most seasoned dealers began to wonder if it was too much of a good thing.

title: France and Germany Jointly Criticize Abuse of Iraqis and Express Horror at Beheading
description: President Jacques Chirac of France and Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany on Thursday criticized the abuse of Iraqi prisoners by American soldiers and expressed horror over the beheading of an American civilian.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Profit Slips
description: Deutsche Telekom said it earned 169 million euros ($201 million) in the first quarter, short of market forecasts, as sales increased 3 percent, to 14 billion euros. The chief executive, Kai-Uwe Ricke, said the weak German economy hurt results and sales at its German fixed-line operation, its biggest unit, fell 6 percent. Income was also hurt by expenses for a venture with DaimlerChrysler that is developing a system that will use satellites to charge truck tolls on German highways. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Weekender | Fire Island Pines, N.Y.
description: AS the ferry from Sayville on Long Island's South Shore moves out onto the Great South Bay, the scenery changes from weathered restaurants, work boats and islands of reeds to open water. There are always lots of men on the ferry, given the predominantly gay makeup of the community at Fire Island Pines, and often a surprising number of dogs, many with their noses in the air catching the salty, crabby smell of sea air. In the distance is the narrow 32-mile-long sand dune that is Fire Island, and as you near it, the late-20th-century bayfront homes of the Pines become clear. As you land, the smell of pine trees fills your head.

title: British Editor Fired in Uproar Over Fake Iraq Abuse Photos
description: LONDON, May 14  The editor of The Daily Mirror tabloid, which had published photographs purporting to be of a hooded Iraqi being beaten, kicked and urinated on by British soldiers, was dismissed today by the newspaper's owner, Trinity Mirror.

title: Proclaiming Your Status From the Top
description: ''Humans are the only animals that wear hats,'' said Thomas Murray, a dealer who specializes in artifacts from Indonesia and island cultures. ''In fact, wearing hats is what makes us human. It's a fundamental commonality to our human-ness.''

title: Capturing Qaddafi's Gun-Toting Women on Film
description: IT is anyone's guess what will become of Rania Ajami's filmmaking career. But Ms. Ajami, who is 25 and a New York University graduate film student, certainly knows how to get attention. Her first feature documentary, spun out of a class assignment, is about the elite female corps of bodyguards assigned to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

A spokesman for Mr. Aristide said he could arrive in South Africa as early as next week. He is expected to live in Pretoria, the capital, under heavy security and at government expense. title: The Wrong Direction
description: Watching President Bush and Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld this week, it was hard to avoid the sinking feeling that they had already moved on from the Abu Ghraib prison mess and were back to their well-established practice of ignoring all bad news and marching blindly ahead as if nothing unusual had happened. That was the impression that emerged from Mr. Bush's disconnected performance on Monday, when he viewed photos and video stills of the atrocious treatment of prisoners by soldiers under his and Mr. Rumsfeld's command, and then announced that the defense secretary was doing a ''superb job.'' It was stronger than ever yesterday, during Mr. Rumsfeld's road trip to Iraq, where he drew a curious parallel between himself and Ulysses S. Grant and announced his approach to the prison scandal: ''I've stopped reading newspapers.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDWATER, CAROL K.
description: GOLDWATER--Carol K., 92, of NYC died April 21 at home. Born Mt. Vernon, NY, daughter of Ferdinand and Johanna (nee Loeb) Kuhn, beloved wife of the late James L. Goldwater, devoted mother of son Alan and daughters Joan, Lynn Pollack and Anne Landis, proud grandmother of six, great-grandmother of four, and generous friend. A 1933 graduate of Barnard College, she worked as research associate at the Council of Jewish Federations & Welfare Funds. She later served as president and 20 year board member of the Ossining Children's Center, and as mental health researcher at Phelps Memorial Hospital. She loved music and was a long time supporter of the Metropolitan Opera & Lincoln Center for the Arts. A lady in the fullest sense of the word, she was beloved by all who met and knew her. Memorial gathering private. Contributions to Ossining Children's Center, 90-92 Highland Ave, Ossining, NY 10562 and VNA Hospice, 1250 Broadway, NY, NY 10001.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Optimistic Outlook
description: Japan's two-year recovery appears to be on solid ground as a result of government efforts to tackle some of the worst of the country's economic troubles, according to John B. Taylor, left, the under secretary for international affairs in the United States Treasury Department. ''We learned a lot about what we think is a more sustainable recovery than has existed for a long time in Japan,'' Mr. Taylor said after meeting government officials and economists in Tokyo on Thursday. He praised Japan's progress in dealing with deflation and bad bank loans. Mr. Taylor said he was optimistic that Japan's recovery would continue because of recent indications that consumer demand is picking up. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Adequate Summer Electricity Predicted
description: New York state has enough electricity to survive a hot summer, and the state is taking the right steps to accommodate growing demand in the next several years, the group that manages the state's power grid said yesterday. The group, the New York State Independent System Operator, titled its new report ''Power Trends,'' instead of the previously titled ''Power Alerts'' to reflect a lessened state of urgency, the group's president, William J. Museler, said. The group said that the state had installed an additional 3,000 megawatts of in-state energy generation since 2001, but that 2,000 to 4,000 more megawatts should be added by 2008 to be within safe limits. New York city is within regulatory limits since it currently has the capacity to produce more than 80 percent of its own electricity. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Scientists Say Crater Is Result of a Killer Meteor

It was that meteor, they went on, that caused the largest mass extinction in the Earth's history.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Long-Time Defense Minister Retires
description: Gen. Mustafa Tlas, Syria's defense minister since 1972, took an uncommon step for an Arab minister and retired. General Tlas, 72, who played a major role in bringing the Baath Party to power, will retain a seat on the party's central command. He was replaced as minister by Gen. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Luxembourg: Economic Growth Accelerates
description: Economic growth in the dozen euro nations accelerated to the fastest pace in three years in the first quarter as exporters benefited from rapidly growing demand in the United States and Asia. The economy expanded 0.6 percent in the first three months, the Luxembourg-based Eurostat agency said. Fourth-quarter growth was revised to 0.4 percent from 0.3 percent. Demand from abroad is helping the $8.5 trillion economy recover from the slowest growth in a decade last year. The European Commission left its forecast for the second quarter unchanged, saying growth will be 0.3 percent to 0.7 percent.

title: Columbine: Parents Of a Killer

Tom objected to the column, but the striking thing about his note was that while acknowledging the horrible crime his son had committed, Tom was still fiercely loyal toward him. Which prompts this question: If your child commits a crime like that, what do you do with the rest of your life?

title: METLIFE SAYS UNIT MAY FACE S.E.C. SUIT OVER TRADING
description: MetLife said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was likely to sue one of its units over trading involving variable insurance contracts. The S.E.C. sent a so-called Wells notice to the General American Life Insurance Company, a company subsidiary, MetLife said. The S.E.C. sends Wells notices when it has determined there is enough evidence of wrongdoing to warrant civil charges. MetLife, which will have the opportunity to respond before S.E.C. personnel make a formal recommendation, had disclosed that the S.E.C. was examining late trading and market timing in contracts sold by the General American division, based in St. Louis. MetLife said it didn't know of any systemic problems that would hurt its finances, and is cooperating with the investigation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: DoCoMo Names President
description: The mobile phone company NTT DoCoMo named a senior executive vice president, Masao Nakamura, left, as its new president and chief executive. Mr. Nakamura, who has spent most of his career with DoCoMo or its parent company, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, succeeds Keiji Tachikawa, who was widely expected to step down after six years in the posts. Mr. Tachikawa oversaw DoCoMo's development of Internet services on mobile phones as well as a series of largely unsuccessful overseas investments in mobile phone companies. Mr. Nakamura, 59, takes over as the company expects revenue to decline amid intensifying competition to lower monthly phone charges. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Review Of Mercury Rule Development
description: The inspector general of the Environmental Protection Agency is examining how the agency developed a proposal to reduce mercury emissions after Senator James M. Jeffords, independent of Vermont, and six Democratic senators complained that the E.P.A. gave too much consideration to utility companies. The proposal would allow power plants to buy and sell the right to emit mercury, with a goal of reducing emissions by 70 percent by 2018. Environmental groups argue that the Clean Air Act calls for strict plant-by-plant controls by 2007. The rules are to be made final in March. The inspector general, Nikki L. Tinsley, is expected to complete her report before then. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Forget Lonely. Life Is Healthy At the Top.
description: If you want to get a sense of how social status affects health, then take a ride on Washington's metro system. Start in the blighted southeast section of downtown. For every mile traveled to tony Montgomery County in Maryland, life expectancy rises about a year and a half. By the time you get off, says Sir Michael Marmot, a British epidemiologist who has been studying the link between social position and health, you will find a ''20-year gap between poor blacks at one end of the journey and rich whites at the other.''

''Just look at those keystrokes,'' Mr. Gil says proudly, shaking his head as the star pupil, Carlos Ramrez, 11, works his German-made Hohner. ''It is amazing how hard he plays, like an adult. The smell of overcooked hot dogs still consumes the concession stand. And the ride still ends with the groan of massive vessel meeting wooden slip, the sound of journey's end.

title: America Adrift in Iraq
description: Six weeks of military and political reverses seem to have left the Bush administration doing little more in Iraq than grasping at ways to make it past November's presidential election without getting American troops caught in a civil war. The lowering of the administration's expectations might be therapeutic if it produced a realistic strategy for achieving a realistic set of goals. Unfortunately, there appears to be no such strategy, only odd lurches this way and that under the pressure of day-to-day events. That pattern heightens the danger of an eventual civil war or anarchy, the two main things that American forces are ostensibly remaining in Iraq to prevent.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Insurance Unit Sold
description: The Dutch international financial services group ING sold its general insurance operations in Australia to its local partner, QBE Insurance, for 765 million Australian dollars ($527 million). ING Asia-Pacific's manager, Peter Smyth, said that his company would retain its funds management business in Australia in a venture with ANZ Bank Ltd. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Battles in Najaf and Karbala Near Shiites' Religious Sites
description: Fighting erupted Friday in Najaf when American tank troops and soldiers battled militiamen loyal to the rebel Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr in a centuries-old cemetery near the revered Shrine of Imam Ali.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the 11th Duke of Devonshire on May 5 misspelled the title of his son and successor, Peregrine. He was the Marquess of Hartington, not Harrington.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Wireless Carrier
description: The Telus Corporation made a 1.1 billion Canadian dollars ($790 million) bid to acquire Microcell Telecommunications Inc. and create the biggest wireless phone carrier in Canada, setting off a 49 percent gain in Microcell's share price. Telus made the bid, which amounted to $29 a share, late Thursday and Microcell's shares rose 10.45 Canadian dollars, to 31.70 dollars yesterday. Telus is the No.3 wireless company in Canada and Microcell of Montreal ranks No. 4, based on the number of subscribers. The surge in Microcell's shares shows investors expect another phone company to submit a competing offer, analysts said. Claire Fiset, a Microcell spokeswoman, declined to say whether other companies had made offers. Microcell said Thursday that it would not respond until it reviewed the offer.

title: Rita R. Fraad, 88, a Collector And Patron of American Art, Dies
description: Rita R. Fraad, a collector and patron of American art, died on Sunday at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y. She was 88.

title: Saving Wild Salmon
description: One of the great virtues of the Endangered Species Act -- and the main reason for the bitter opposition the act has engendered over the years -- is that in the interests of saving species, it requires the protection of the habitats where the species live. That usually means constraining human behavior in ways that help preserve a healthier environment all around. Humans themselves often come to appreciate that intervention, though not always. In the case of wild salmon, for instance, commercial interests have long resented the restrictions on logging, farming and development necessary to protect the fragile watersheds where salmon spawn.

title: Impeachment Committee Offers Rowland Invitation; A Subpoena May Be Next
description: The House committee investigating Gov. John G. Rowland will ''invite'' the governor to appear as its first witness in public hearings to begin on June 7, setting the stage for the governor to decide if he will publicly address questions of corruption that have prompted an impeachment inquiry into gifts he received from state contractors and employees.

title: State Senator Quits in Deal Over a Bribery Indictment
description: Guy J. Velella, the veteran Bronx Republican, resigned from the State Senate on Friday, ending a tumultuous 31-year career in the Legislature.

title: American Values and Abu Ghraib
description: To the Editor:

title: TYCO EXECUTIVES SUBPOENAED OVER ADT UNIT
description: Tyco International said some current and former executives received subpoenas from the Securities and Exchange Commission to testify about past accounting practices at its ADT unit. The S.E.C.'s enforcement division has been investigating accounting practices under the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, since his ouster in June 2002. Under Edward Breen, hired as chief executive in July 2002, Tyco changed the way ADT accounts for security accounts purchased from third-party dealers, taking more than $1.6 billion in charges in 2003 to conform to S.E.C. requests that moved the costs to different periods. A Tyco spokesman, David Polk, declined to comment beyond the disclosure, which was made in a report filed with the S.E.C.

title: Nancy Reagan, Trailblazer (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Must Clarify Role in Inquiry
description: A federal appeals court has demanded that Justice Department prosecutors explain their ''arguably inconsistent'' statements about their involvement in the interrogation of captured terrorists of Al Qaeda who might provide valuable information to lawyers defending Zacarias Moussaoui, according to a court order made public Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HYMAN, BEATRICE
description: HYMAN--Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Charles (Elizabeth) and Paul. Cherished grandmother of Claire, Catherine and Gregory. Dear sister of Ruth Sinreich. Services Sunday, 11:30 am, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Axa, Paris, the insurer, said it had increased its stake in Textron Inc., Providence, R.I., the maker of Cessna business jets, by 34 percent during the first quarter.

title: British Editor Fired for Use Of Fake Photos Of Iraq Abuse
description: The editor of The Daily Mirror, Piers Morgan, who published photos that the paper contended were of a hooded Iraqi man being beaten, kicked and urinated on by British soldiers, was dismissed today by the board of directors of Trinity Mirror, the newspaper's owner.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Gay marriage is not a lightning-rod issue here. For the most part when people call the city council they're calling about local issues -- noise, road work, things like that.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the federal airline loan guarantee program referred imprecisely to the circumstances under which America West revised covenants of its loan guarantees. While the government agreed to let America West keep some proceeds of an equity sale, rather than apply all of them to its outstanding loan, the change was not prompted by financial trouble at the airline.

title: Bush Campaign Plays Up Pro-Israel Stance
description: President Bush's Middle East policy may or may not help bring peace between Israelis and Palestinians, but at home it is giving Republicans a chance to make inroads among a crucial element of the Democratic base: Jewish voters and donors.

title: Hedge Funds Sell Stewart Holdings
description: David Rocker's hedge funds sold their 6 percent stake in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc. in the first quarter, the period when Ms. Stewart, the founder of the media company, was found guilty of obstructing justice.

title: Nine Rivals Out to Get Smarty
description: Five survivors of the Kentucky Derby and five fresh horses have been entered in today's 129th running of the Preakness Stakes. The Cliff's Edge, the No. 4 horse, was scratched yesterday. Frank Carulli, the oddsmaker at Pimlico Race Course, set the morning line. Joe Drape listed the horses in order of preference.

title: French Seize 2 Algerians in Terrorist Inquiry
description: The French antiterrorism police have arrested two Algerian men in an investigation of an Islamic terrorist cell that is accused of developing chemical and biological weapons before it was disrupted more than two years ago.

title: Nancy Reagan, Trailblazer
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa Is Favored to Win Cup Bid
description: For the first time, the world's most popular sporting event, soccer's World Cup, will be awarded to an African country today. Officials are set to choose among South Africa, Morocco, Egypt and Libya.

title: COMMANDER BARS COERCIVE TACTICS IN INTERROGATION
description: Under a barrage of international and domestic criticism, the top American commander in Iraq has barred virtually all coercive interrogation practices, like forcing prisoners to crouch for long periods or depriving them of sleep, the Pentagon said Friday.

title: Clemens and Pettitte Keep Up With Yanks
description: On a weekend during which they will face the New York team they have never pitched for, Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte held separate news conferences on Friday, more than an hour apart.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Profit Rises
description: The French bank Crdit Agricole said first-quarter profit rose 68 percent on gains in consumer lending and asset management. Revenue growth lagged analysts' forecasts, and the shares fell. Net income rose to 506 million euros ($597 million) from 301 million euros a year earlier, the bank said. Revenue rose 6.4 percent, hurt by declines in investment banking. Corporate and investment banking revenue declined 6.3 percent in the first quarter, to 1 billion euros. The capital markets division will continue to show a lackluster performance in the second quarter, the chief financial officer, Gilles de Margerie, said on a conference call with analysts.

title: After a Violent Week, Israel to Step Up Gaza Patrols
description: Israel will substantially widen an army-patrolled zone at the southern end of the Gaza Strip near the border with Egypt, a step that will involve demolishing many Palestinian buildings, a senior Israeli official said Friday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Producer Turns From Footlights To Football
description: Martin Richards, who has produced scores of plays and movies in his 40-year career, finally has a starring role in an action drama that has sundered the theater world and is rocking the West Side of Manhattan. Title it ''Bullets over Broadway.''

title: Puzzling Medicare Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Parents Protest End of Standardized Testing at Private School
description: Parents at a private school in Queens are protesting the elimination of standardized tests in the lower grades and optional testing without in-class preparation for middle schoolers, fearing that their children will be at a disadvantage, particularly in applying to selective public high schools.

title: Top Fund-Raising Post Unfilled For Ground Zero Foundation
description: After being turned down by several top business executives, Gov. George E. Pataki is struggling to find someone prominent to lead the campaign to raise as much as $600 million for a memorial and cultural buildings at the World Trade Center site.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about reading recommendations from three authors of business books misstated the price paid by Yahoo for Yoyodyne, a direct-marketing company founded by one of the authors, Seth Godin. It was $30 million in stock, not $250 million.

title: State Finds Impasse in Talks for Police Contract
description: The New York State Public Employment Relations Board, the agency that has been handling contract negotiations between the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the city, said yesterday that talks between the two sides had reached an impasse.

title: Nets Survive a Game of Fouls and Wills
description: The arms were exhausted, like a boxer struggling to throw a punch or protect himself in the final rounds. By the time the final shot reached the rim in the third overtime Friday night, eight players had fouled out. Jason Kidd stood on the court, blood running down the side of his nose.

title: LeRoy Myers, 84, Tap Dancer With the Copasetics Ensemble
description: LeRoy Myers, a dancer who was one of the last of the Copasetics veteran tap ensemble, died on April 26 in Manhattan, members of the troupe said. He was 84.

title: Soldiers and 'Do-Gooders'
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Buy Director Quits
description: The Best Buy Company said yesterday that a director, Mark C. Thompson, resigned from its board on May 4, citing a conflict of interest.

description: Nets Win in Third Overtime For a 3-2 Lead Over Pistons

description: To the Editor:

title: Two Friends Are Vying For the Lead After 2nd Day
description: They are best friends and neighbors. Tiger Woods and Mark O'Meara often eat together, go to movies together, practice together and travel together.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Charges In Inmate Beating
description: Four guards at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Albuquerque were charged in the beating of three shackled inmates, which was recorded on the jail's videotaping system. As many as 20 jail personnel were involved in the assault on Feb. 24, and 8 have resigned or been fired, Sheriff Darren White said. He said that the F.B.I. had joined the investigation. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: 2nd Hong Kong Democracy Figure Leaves Hastily
description: Correction Appended

title: Win or Lose, a Place to Show; For Regulars, Betting Sites Double as Social Clubs
description: By noon throughout the city, the faithful find their way to faded green storefronts. They are mostly men, and they have some thing things in common: time on their hands, money in their pockets, and the willingness to spend both trying to pick a winning horse.

title: Busy Rumsfeld Keeps Working At Both Ends Of Whirlwind
description: The sands of Abu Ghraib prison clung to everyone's shirts and boots and scalps, the kind of grit from a grim experience that does not easily wash away. Back aboard the Air Force jet that ferried him home on Friday from Iraq, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld traded in his dusty blue blazer for a clean Army windbreaker.

title: Marbury Is Happy to Carry Torch for U.S. and the Knicks
description: Stephon Marbury associates the best moments of his life with the city of his birth, the city that gave him a high school championship, a crossover dribble and a job as point guard of the Knicks.

title: Prices in April Rose a Bit; Energy Costs Stir Concern
description: Consumer prices crept up in April, rising by only 0.2 percent, the smallest monthly increase this year, the government reported yesterday. But the report also suggested that inflation had probably accelerated in May, as gasoline prices began rising sharply again.

title: Nascar Moves Races West, and a Fabled Track Is Sold
description: Nascar eliminated a troublesome lawsuit and a historic racetrack yesterday in yet another watershed day of change for a sport determined to reach beyond its Southern roots to a growing national fan base.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRICE, KAREN
description: PRICE--Karen, 42. Chevy Chase, MD and Scarsdale, NY. Cherished daughter of Ruth and Marvin Price. Loving sister of Ellen (Craig) Rosenberg and devoted aunt of Tyler and Allie. Services 12 Noon Sunday May 16, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Before Games, U.S. Athletes Shrug Off Fears
description: MAKING the Olympics is not quite the joy ride it used to be. Jessica Mendoza, a member of the American softball team, discovered that the other day.

title: S.E.C. STEPS UP INQUIRY ON CARDINAL HEALTH
description: Cardinal Health Inc., a drug wholesaler, said federal regulators formalized an inquiry into the company's accounting, allowing investigators to issue subpoenas for documents or testimony. The Securities and Exchange Commission began an informal investigation in October that included inquiries into how Cardinal accounted for $22 million recovered from vitamin makers accused by the company of overcharging. The S.E.C. has requested financial and other information, Cardinal said. The money is part of a settlement the company reached after wholesalers sued vitamin makers contending anticompetitive activities, including price fixing. A shareholder charged in a lawsuit that Cardinal improperly accounted for settlement payments in December 2000 and September 2001. Cardinal, based in Dublin, Ohio, began its own inquiry into the accounting matter in April, said Jim Mazzola, a company spokesman.

title: Powell Says U.S. Will Withdraw Troops From Iraq if New Government Makes Request
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was joined by the foreign ministers of Britain, Italy and Japan on Friday in declaring that they would honor any request by Iraq's new government to withdraw foreign troops after June 30, when it is to receive limited sovereignty.

title: Kerry Ties Prisoner Abuse To Bush's Handling of War
description: After viewing pictures of prisoner abuse in Iraq, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts escalated his criticism of the Bush administration's prosecution of the war on Friday, saying that the Abu Ghraib prison scandal ''shows a kind of indifference that allowed thing to get out of control.''

title: American Values and Abu Ghraib
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a settlement of accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Warnaco Group improperly accounted for an overstatement of inventory in the late 1990's referred incorrectly to the company's actions in that period. Warnaco did indeed restate its results for 1996, 1997 and 1998.

title: City Agencies Agree on a Coordinated Response to Disasters
description: The Bloomberg administration announced yesterday that its emergency agencies had reached a formal agreement that details how they plan to coordinate their responses to major disasters, including everything from building collapses to biological attacks by terrorists.

title: Dissolving the Border Between CD and Live
description: What changes when a live performance is recorded? And what changes when a recorded performance is brought to life? The hip-hop DJ and producer RJD2 stacked those changes on top of one another on Thursday night at the Bowery Ballroom, collapsing four generations of musical transmission into one performance.

title: Grand Jury Subpoenas Documents From Nortel
description: A federal grand jury in Texas has subpoenaed financial documents from Nortel Networks as part of a criminal investigation, the latest inquiry into accounting irregularities at the company, the Canadian telecommunications giant.

title: 2 Admit to Stealing Rent Payments
description: A former Housing Authority employee and a Harlem-based real estate broker have pleaded guilty to conspiracy and theft for leasing city-owned commercial property and keeping the rent -- more than S90,000 -- for themselves.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT Profit Rises
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation said its profit nearly tripled for the year ended March 31, to 643.9 billion yen from 233.4 billion yen a year earlier, helped by the strong performance of its mobile phone affiliate, NTT DoCoMo. NTT said, however, that it expected profit growth to slow this year as DoCoMo, in which NTT holds a 63 percent stake, comes under pressure to lower mobile phone rates. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Head Of Exile Church In First Visit
description: Metropolitan Laurus, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church Outside of Russia, which broke from the Russian Orthodox Church as a consequence of the 1917 Revolution, arrived for his first official visit to Moscow and talks expected to touch on terms of a possible reunion. He met immediately with Patriarch Alexy II. It is the first time a leader of the New York-based migr church has come to Russia. A meeting in New York last year with President Vladimir V. Putin gave impetus to the reconciliation. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: A Gay Boomtown Is More Mainstream And Less the Clich
description: By the mid-1990's, this small, once comfortably middle-class city just north of downtown Fort Lauderdale had its share of woes. Crime, drugs and prostitution blighted various neighborhoods. The local Piggly Wiggly supermarket needed security guards before it shut down completely.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Mcveigh Warned Sister Of 'Something Big'
description: Days before the Oklahoma City Federal Building was destroyed by a terrorist bomb, Timothy J. McVeigh advised his sister by letter that ''something big is going to happen,'' the sister, Jennifer McVeigh, testified. Ms. McVeigh testified under a grant of immunity as a witness for Terry L. Nichols, 49, who is on trial for murder as Mr. McVeigh's co-conspirator. Ms. McVeigh said her brother rarely mentioned Mr. Nichols. The state is seeking the death penalty against Mr. Nichols, who already is serving a life sentence in federal prison in the bombing case. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Shares In Snacks
description: An Irish snack food and beverage company, C&C, began selling shares to institutional investors on the Dublin and London stock markets in only the second public offering on the Irish exchange since 2001. The company sold 55 percent of its equity at 2.26 euros a share, for a total market capitalization of 723 million euros ($855 million). Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Ohio Groups Question Justice's Trip On Utility Jet
description: A power plant company based in Ohio with a dozen cases in federal courts is flying Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to Columbus so he can deliver a speech on Saturday at the dedication of a judicial center.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Arrest May Be Linked To Shooting
description: The police said that a man arrested in a drug raid in southern Taiwan had homemade guns and 33 homemade copper and lead bullets similar, but not identical, to those believed to have been used in the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian the day before his re-election in March. Mr. Chen and the vice president, Annette Lu, were both slightly wounded. The police said the man owned a bar close to where the shootings happened in Tainan but moved to another city, Kaohsiung, where he was arrested along with his girlfriend and bodyguard. Taiwanese television reported that all three had denied any connection to the shooting. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Smarty Jones Adds Preakness Title to Derby Win
description: BALTIMORE, Md. -- Kentucky Derby winner Smarty Jones remained undefeated, dominating the 10-horse Preakness field at Pimlico on Saturday. (MORE)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERSTEIN, SYLVIA (NEE SELNICK)
description: SILVERSTEIN--Sylvia (nee Selnick), of Woodcliff Lake, NJ. Wife of William B., mother of Joel and Robert, grandmother of Ben, Adam, Joshua and Erica. Services Sunday, 1:30 PM, ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. Contributions to Hadassah would be appreciated.

description: Adiagram yesterday with an article about lucrative financial partnerships between the family of Gov. George E. Pataki and Richard A. Hayden, a real estate investor and college friend of the governor, referred incompletely in some copies to transactions involving the family's farm in Peekskill. Sales of parts of the farm through 2003 netted about $1 million, not $795,000. In some copies the diagram also misstated the year they sold their Washington County farm. It was 2002, not 2001. ( Go to Article )

title: Dynegy Ruling Set Aside
description: Dynegy Inc., an owner of natural gas processing plants in Louisiana, New Mexico and Texas, said that a judge set aside a $3.2 million jury award to the Apache Corporation in a contract dispute.

title: What India's Upset Vote Reveals: The High Tech Is Skin Deep
description: As India prepared to vote this spring, strategists from its ruling party mapped the country's first modern electoral campaign.

Hayden, a real estate investor and college friend of the governor, referred incompletely in some copies to transactions involving the family's farm in Peekskill. Sales of parts of the farm through 2003 netted about $1 million, not $795,000. In some copies the diagram also misstated the year they sold their Washington County farm. It was 2002, not 2001.

title: Yankees Turn Free Passes Into Victory
description: It was something of a referendum on the hoary baseball premise that a walk is as good as a hit. The Seattle Mariners got a lot of hits at Yankee Stadium last night. The Yankees drew a lot of walks. The team with the walks won easily.

title: Former Cendant Executive Agrees to Pay $14 Million
description: Federal regulators said yesterday that they had reached a $14 million settlement with a former executive at Cendant, a travel, lodging and real estate company involved in one of the largest frauds ever.

title: Mayor Takes Blame for Error With Citywide Reading Test
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has repeatedly said that he wants to be judged by how well he does on his signature issue of education, took the blame yesterday for what he called an ''embarrassing'' mistake on a citywide reading test that drew sharp criticism from parents and teachers this week.

title: Nancy Reagan, Trailblazer
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Bid for History Is Not a Race Against Time
description: THE early morning scene at Pimlico Race Course was timeless: at 5:30, we're all like so many fireflies moving in shadows between stables.

title: China Prices Soar, Prompting Curbs on Loans
description: Consumer prices in China rose last month at their fastest pace in seven years as retail sales also leaped, prompting officials to broaden their restrictions on bank lending to many more fast-growing industries and causing yet another plunge in mainland stocks traded here.

title: John D. LaPorta, 84, Clarinetist-Composer
description: John D. LaPorta, a classically trained clarinetist who performed with the stars of early modern jazz before beginning a long teaching and composing career, died here on Wednesday, his family announced. He was 84.

title: Will Europe Heed a Call to Forget About Laissez-Faire?
description: Having evidently failed in his first effort to force a merger, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany has joined with the president of France to call on Europe to work to create ''national champion'' companies.

title: Floyd Puts On a Healthy Display of Power Hitting
description: By the time the Mets arrived in Houston at 5 a.m. Friday, the two tornados circling the city had moved on and the violent thunderstorm drenching East Texas had mercifully passed.

title: A Quiet Victory for Civil Rights
description: Fifty years ago this month, the Supreme Court handed down a landmark civil rights decision, the first under the newly seated Chief Justice Earl Warren. Brown v. Board of Education, involving African-Americans and segregated schools, came two weeks later. Unlike Brown, the case called Hernandez v. Texas has been mostly relegated to legal footnotes. But this decision, which protected Mexican-Americans and the right to fair trials and helped widen the definition of discrimination beyond race, deserves more attention.

title: More Youths Opt for G.E.D. Tests, Skirting the Hurdle of High School
description: A testing system created more than half a century ago to help World War II veterans earn the equivalent of a high school diploma has increasingly become a way for teenagers to short-circuit high school.

title: Brazil's Government Drops Its Threat to Expel a Times Reporter
description: The government of Brazil last night restored the visa of Larry Rohter, The New York Times bureau chief in Rio de Janeiro, effectively dropping its threat to expel him from the country for an article he wrote critical of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: Two Guests Uncover a Different Side of Balanchine
description: George Balanchine's ballets are danced throughout the country and the world. Nothing shows this better than the current season's guest artists at New York City Ballet, epitomized by the fabulous performance of Lorna Feijo and Gonzalo Garcia on Wednesday night. Their repeat performance, on Tuesday, in Balanchine's ''Ballo Della Regina'' at the New York State Theater is not to be missed.

title: Derby-Winning Jockey Turns Away From His Past
description: Stewart Elliott, an obscure jockey from Philadelphia Park until he won the Kentucky Derby aboard Smarty Jones, has discovered that fame can come at a price.

title: BOEING REACHES SETTLEMENT IN A DISCRIMINATION CASE
description: Boeing said yesterday that it had reached a financial settlement with female workers who contended the company knew men were paid more and received better promotions than women. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed, and Boeing said on its Web site that it was still trying to resolve other aspects of the dispute. The case was scheduled to go to trial Monday in Seattle. The class-action lawsuit represented about 28,000 employees, who were seeking $450 million in back pay and more than $1 billion in punitive damages.

description: THE MYTH OF MORAL JUSTICE

title: Fisher With a Reminder: Lakers Are Still Big Shots
description: For the Los Angeles Lakers of Shaquille O'Neal, Kobe Bryant and Phil Jackson, the difference between a championship and failure has often hinged on one shot. When they have been reeling, one astounding basket in the Western Conference playoffs has served as a giant pick-me-up. When they have been rolling, one miss has buried them.

description: To the Editor:

title: Was a Tyrant Prefigured by Baby Saddam?
description: It is no surprise to Jerrold M. Post, the founder of the Center for the Analysis of Personality and Political Behavior at the C.I.A., that Saddam Hussein grew up to be one of the world's most dangerous dictators and a member of President Bush's axis of evil.

title: Man Convicted for Providing Fake ID's and Driver Licenses
description: A federal jury convicted a Manhattan man yesterday on charges of bribery, identification fraud and the transport of illegal immigrants in a two-year scheme that prosecutors said involved the purchase of more than 900 fake drivers' licenses.

title: Suit Over Meadowlands Bids Yields Mixed Ruling
description: A state appellate panel ruled on Friday that the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority was within its rights in awarding a $1.4 billion contract to develop a huge entertainment complex at the Continental Arena site at the Meadowlands.

title: Religion Journal; The First Church of Cyberspace: Services Tomorrow
description: Richard Chartres, Anglican bishop of London, is not used to having congregants wandering around in front of him swearing as he preaches. Then again, he does not normally transform himself into a three-dimensional computer image in an imaginary sanctuary as he did Tuesday to deliver a sermon to animated representations of churchgoers.

title: Revenge-Minded Tarver Tugs on Jones's Cape Again
description: LAS VEGAS, May 14 — The end of an era is approaching: Roy Jones Jr., a k a Superman, will soon take off his cape and go home to play with his chickens.

title: Police Seek Man In a Break-In
description: The police said last night they were searching for a man who robbed an apartment yesterday afternoon on the Upper East Side.

title: AVAYA TO PAY UP TO $10 MILLION FOR HARDWARE PROBLEMS
description: Avaya Inc., a maker of office telephone equipment, agreed to pay as much as $110 million in cash or credits to clients who sued over problems related to the year 2000. Customers who bought certain Avaya products from 1990 to 1999 are eligible to receive part of the settlement, the company said. The credits are valid for three years and could be used for discounts of up to 45 percent on Avaya products or services. The suit centered on concerns that certain equipment might not be able to process date functions correctly when their internal clocks switched to Jan. 1, 2000, Avaya said. Avaya, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., denied any wrongdoing. Lucent Technologies, which spun off Avaya in 2000, is responsible for a portion of the costs in excess of $50 million, Avaya said.

description: Citing Drop in Stock Price, Oracle Cuts PeopleSoft Bid

title: Earlier Jail Seen as Incubator for Abuses in Iraq

title: The Rule of Law and the Rules of War
description: With questions being raised regarding the treatment of detainees in both Guantnamo Bay and Iraq, it is important to revisit the origins of what has been a consistent and humane policy by the United States on this matter.

title: Venezuela Threatens to Expel Foreign Election Monitors
description: Political turmoil in Venezuela is rising just two weeks before signers of a petition to recall President Hugo Chvez are required to stand by their signatures.

title: Corrections
description: A TV Watch article on May 6 about the end of the NBC series ''Friends'' and ''Frasier'' misstated the political backdrop of the economic recession that preceded the good times that were the setting of ''Friends.'' It occurred during George H. W. Bush's presidency, not also during Ronald Reagan's. The article also misstated the number of television actors who have matched Kelsey Grammer's record of playing the same character for 20 years. Besides James Arness, who played Matt Dillon on ''Gunsmoke,'' Milburn Stone played Doc Adams on that show for 20 years.

title: Vatican Discourages Marriage With Muslims for Catholic Women
description: In an official church document released Friday, the Vatican discouraged marriage between Catholics and Muslims, especially Catholic women and Muslim men.

title: American Values and Abu Ghraib
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Cello Player'
description: There was no cemetery as far as the eye could see. The taxi driver, a heavy, sullen man with a bird face, made a vague gesture with his right hand in response to my question about where I should go, but without speaking; he was silent now, having spent the entire ride addressing with growing impatience a radio show and the tattered, rattling voice of the dispatcher. I should have asked the friendly taxi driver who had brought me from the Budapest airport to the hotel an hour earlier to wait after all. He had offered me everything-young women, nightclubs, gypsy music: You say, I get. But I'd wanted to rest for ten minutes before the funeral, so I sent him off. Where is the cemetery? I implored the bird man, from the backseat, while he calmly lit another cigarette on the stub of the old one, sending a shower of sparks onto his loosely knit sweater. He had stopped under a tree whose sooty leaves hung limply from its branches; behind the tree was a dilapidated square where an old car without wheels was sulking; in the distance were a few cowering houses. No people and no graves in this wasteland. Fortunately, the hotel porter had written down the address of the cemetery for me, so now, with the driver gazing at me suspiciously, I looked for the slip of paper as I sat in the oppressive, cramped vehicle, which was full of smoke and incomprehensible sounds. I was beginning to sweat. I had assumed as a matter of course that taxi drivers in this part of the world cheated their fares-an assumption that the hotel porter had confirmed by pocketing a sizable tip-still, the thought that this deadly driver would abandon me in this no-man's-land simply for his own amusement was more than I could bear. And yet, I couldn't afford to annoy him, for there were hardly any other cars in the area, let alone taxis; but above all, there was no cemetery. I looked for the note; the man kept smoking and coughing, then he opened the car door and spat a heavy glob of phlegm on the dusty ground. The situation was so outrageous and humiliating that I was just about to shout the name of the hotel at the man and demand that I be taken back to my starting point when I finally found the note crumpled up in the breast pocket of my suit and triumphantly held it out to him. Here, the address of the cemetery, I urged the laconic fellow, who peered at the unprepossessing document out of the corner of his eye and nodded thoughtfully. He started the car and again began a steady muttering and carrying-on, as if he had put the ignition key into his speech center. The view outside the cab did not improve, particularly as a fine rain began to fall, covering the dreary neighborhood with a gray mist. Any hope I'd had of arriving at the cemetery a half-hour before the burial-not only to get a sense of where the grave was but also to explore possible escape routes-dissolved as I rode in my smoky cage. I wondered if we would ever arrive. Then the driver pulled into a gas station, shouting and snorting, and stopped beside a pump that did not look especially promising. He got out, fumbled at the back with the tailgate, and then disappeared for some time. I finally caught sight of him behind the car, tearing large chunks from an enormous sandwich he held in one hand and guzzling a cloudy liquid, probably cider, from a bottle he held in the other. As he stood there chewing and drinking in front of the radiator, I noticed that the left side of his face was disfigured by a red, frayed patch of eczema that spread over his eye and ran down his neck under the collar of his greasy sweater. As he made no effort at all to fill the tank, and no attendant put in an appearance, I energetically pushed my coat, suit, and shirt-sleeves from my wrist and tapped several times on my watch with my right index finger, assuming this gesture must be recognizable anywhere in the world. Not a twitch of comprehension in his face. But once the last of the sandwich had vanished into his maw and the bottle had been stowed in the trunk he decided it was time to fill up his tank. When at last the counter on the pump had come to a halt while there was still a chance of reaching our destination, for which we had set out more than an hour ago, the man tore open the door on my side and barked furiously at me. That could only be about money, I thought. So I pulled out the bundle of bills that a tired woman in the hotel had given me in exchange for my hundred marks, and put a medium-sized bill into the outstretched palm. But the hand did not close on the bill. Nor did it close after I had put two more on top of the first. By then, a group of ragged people had stepped closer, forming a half-circle around the driver and watching the silent transaction. Among them was a woman with a pom-pom hat who shamelessly thrust her shaggy head into the car and reached out her hand to snatch one of the bills. I had no idea how much money I had handed over or how much I was still holding, nor did the hostile maneuvers I found myself subjected to give me time to figure it out. I had to act. The only way out of this situation was to attack. I pulled myself out of the backseat with the bundle of remaining money firmly in hand, stood up, legs apart, in front of the group of people gathered around the taxi driver, paused for a moment, then screamed as loud as I could: If I am not taken to the cemetery at once, I'll have the police throw all of you in jail! And as I kept on screaming, rousing myself with the worst profanities and proud of the courage I never knew I had, I butted my fist into the chests of the flabbergasted men and, with a swipe, knocked the shameless pom-pom hat from the woman's head. Even the driver seemed impressed. Don't stop now; don't drop the reins. In my mounting rage, I was about to go for the throat of the crimson bird-head when a little oil-smeared man stepped between us and, in excellent German, asked about the cause of this violent confrontation. I want to go to the cemetery, I yelled; where the hell is the goddamn cemetery this idiot refuses to take me to, even though he has already taken wads of money from me! It's a scandal for a visitor to be treated like this; the simplest rules of hospitality have been violated; all of Hungary is being infiltrated by scoundrels who are entirely ignorant of the laws of civilization....

title: The Greening of the City
description: Even the most startling cultural and economic developments do not arise out of thin air. They are always built upon prior developments and upon a certain amount of serendipity and chance. And their consequences are unpredictable, even to their originators and the pioneers who believed in them and initiated them. After all, the first financially successful railroad in the world was an amusement ride in London. Many of us remember when plastics were useful for little except toys, kitchen gadgets and decorative touches that taste-makers derided for their vulgarity. That was before strong, lightweight plastics, reinforced with fibers of glass, boron or carbon, replaced metals in the making of springs and joints. These plastics transformed serious spectacle frames like mine. At last I have frames that never hurt my nose and ears and that last for years without weakened joints. These plastics were originated by the makers of tennis rackets and of rods for surf and sport fishing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PASSIN, HELEN LATHAM
description: PASSIN--Helen Latham. On May 7 at age 82, of complications following pneumonia. After serving in the Army during World War II and making (only!) one parachute jump that she never tired recounting the horrors of, Helen fled her frigid New England roots for the infinitely more cosmopolitan and romantic surroundings of her beloved New York City. She led a successful and varied career in the media and the fashion world, working as a researcher and interviewer for The New Yorker and NBC's ''Today Show'' and ''The Tex & Jinx Show.'' She later served as director of public relations for Best & Co., Franklin-Simon and Lord & Taylor. For most of the 1960s, she was a principal in her own firm with partner and former supermodel Muriel Maxwell, directing the promotional efforts of such designers and accounts as James Galanos, Arnold Scaasi, Kislav Gloves, London Fog and Marcel Rochas. She also served as Fashion Editor for American Weekly, where she worked extensively with leading fashion photographer (and lifelong friend) J. Frederick Smith. She was married for more than 40 years to renowned Japanologist and Columbia University professor Herbert Passin, who pre-deceased her in 2003. It was from the couple's extraordinary Garment Center penthouse loft in the shadow of the Empire State Building that Helen truly established her credentials as an entertainer, friend and mentor to the famous, would-be famous and not-so-famous. With the ease and dexterity of a bartender at the Ritz, she mixed brilliant academics with sixfoot tall fashion models, and futurologists like Herman Kahn and writers like Leo Rosten with musicians, vagabonds, journalists, visiting professors, earnest young graduate students and even, occasionally, impoverished undergrads. It was always a combination of refined elegance and down-to-earth humor. In the process, Helen took many friends, both young and old, under her wing, dispensing advice, wisdom and -- always -- strong opinions wherever she went. When the Passins later moved their base to a sprawling apartment in Morningside Heights, the views of Manhattan may have suffered, but not the personal and family friendships. A large group of admirers gathered there one last time this past week to toast her extraordinary life. She is survived by a son, Scott Latham; three step-children, John Latham, Katharine Butler and Tom Passin; and five grandchildren, Victoria Latham, and James, Laura and Mark Passin, and Luke Butler. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Tel: 212794-9200.

No matter how distracted he gets, however, Mr. Cleese, 64, has never strayed too far from show business, even if he's heard and not seen: For instance, in ''Shrek 2,'' which opens on Friday, he's the voice of King Harold, a narrowly rational potentate who tries to foil the marriage of his daughter, Fiona (the voice of Cameron Diaz) to the title character (Mike Myers). A few weeks ago, Jennifer Senior spoke on the telephone with Mr. Cleese about the crimes of American television, the pleasures of animation and his plans to launch his own blog.

What Ignatieff recommends is that we act more like the Israelis. But have such methods made them more secure in the last 30 years?

title: The Constant Gardener
description: It is probably safe to say that for most people, landscape architecture -- specifically, the design of large private gardens -- is the province of the wealthy, or at least the well-off. Even for the most avid amateur gardener, the idea of bringing in big machines to alter the contours of the earth, planting avenues of trees or trimming boxwoods into topiary conjures a world in which sweat equity is small change. We are grateful to be able to wander through masterpieces like Andr Le Ntre's majestic landscapes at Versailles and Vaux-le-Vicomte, Capability Brown's romantic park at Blenheim or Beatrix Farrand's intimate series of gardens at Dumbarton Oaks, but they were made for kings and dukes, finance ministers and ambassadors -- not for the likes of us.

title: How to End Grade Inflation
description: Michael Brub (The Way We Live Now, May 2) sees ''nothing inherently wrong with grade inflation'' and suggests a convoluted cure that is ''confusing as hell.'' But the issue is serious and the solution simple. Grade inflation conflates excellence with mediocrity, thereby obscuring merit. The remedy, which has been adopted at a number of colleges, is for transcripts to include not only a student's course grade but also the average grade of all students in the course. In this way grade inflation is publicly exposed and its unfortunate effects dissipated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOSTER, JOHN P.
description: FOSTER--John P. A retired diplomat, FEMA public affairs officer and broadcaster, died at age 75 of a brain tumor in Washington, DC on May 5, 2004. Retired to NH after a 23-year career in the Foreign Service, Foster continued working with State's International Visitors Program and FEMA. Interment in Haverhill, NH will be announced later this summer. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Foster was educated by the Marist Brothers at St. Ann's Academy in New York City, graduated from Fordham University, and pursued postgraduate studies at Columbia. Foster served at embassies in Athens, Tehran, Kabul, Saigon, Accra, New York (UN), New Delhi, Amman, Manila and Durban. He was described as ''the most reasonable man you'll ever know...in the most unorthodox sense of the word.'' A master networker, he was in touch across the globe. Foster is survived by his wife Jody, three children, Kent, Jamie, Mary Claude, and seven grandchildren. Memorial contributions in his name may be sent to: Marist Brothers Retirement Fund c/o Brother Hugh Turley, FMS, 4200 West 115 St., Chicago, IL 60655.

title: Tyranny Of the Minorities
