The big question in both Iraq and Israel today is also similar: Will the silent majorities in both countries finally turn against these extremist minorities to save their future?

They were the abandoned orchards and grassy hillsides, oak groves and hidden creeks of my childhood wanderings. I wanted those places back.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DO all wonderful children's stories involve a parent's death? In FINDING NEMO (2003), Marlin (the voice of Albert Brooks), a clownfish who can't tell a joke, watches as a barracuda devours his wife and 399 of their 400 eggs. Understandably, when the one remaining egg turns into Nemo (Alexander Gould), Marlin becomes an overprotective single dad. This indirectly leads to Nemo being kidnapped by humans and Marlin swimming from the Great Barrier Reef to Sydney to bring him back. The star of the show is Marlin's traveling companion, Dory, a cheerful blue tang with an adorable case of short-term memory loss and the voice of Ellen DeGeneres. And the flora and fauna of this gorgeous underwater world make Paris in the spring look wan. Bob Peterson, David Reynolds and Andrew Stanton (who directed, with Lee Unkrich) wrote the tirelessly witty screenplay -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz.

description: Now that Larry Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, has lost his bid to double his insurance payout, it is not clear where the money to fulfill the master plan for ground zero will come from. The 1,776-foot-high Freedom Tower, which promises to become the tallest building in the world, is slated to begin construction this summer. But many of the other large office towers planned for the site may need to be scaled back; it is possible that they will not be built at all. The future of one of America's most significant public spaces has become unsettled.

title: Sudan's War on Itself; From Rogue State to Pariah State
description: IT is sometimes hard to figure out what Sudan's current status is in the war on terror. The Bush administration would love to enlist its Arab-led government as an ally in a critical part of Africa. But the more the dictatorship wages wars on its own citizens, the more impossible such an alliance becomes.

title: SECURITY FOR NEWARK AIRPORT
description: Senators Jon S. Corzine and Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrats of New Jersey, have asked the Federal Transportation Security Administration to beef up security at Newark Liberty International Airport. In a joint letter last week to the acting administrator, Rear Adm. David M. Stone, they called for 288 additional screeners, saying that the current number, 1,200, is inadequate to ensure air passenger safety. They said that federal officials rather than private companies should assume direct control for hiring screeners. And they called for better working conditions, including break rooms, for screeners whose turnover rate has been 17 percent. ''We ask baggage and personnel screeners at Newark Liberty International Airport to provide a vital layer of security for the traveling public, yet the conditions in which they are required to toil only contribute to skyrocketing stress levels,'' they wrote. Newark was one of the airports hijackers used on Sept. 11, 2001. George James

title: School Budgets Rise An Average of 8 to 9%
description: WHEN homeowners in the Middle Country school district go to the polls this week, they will be voting on a proposed budget that eliminates 36 teachers and 3 assistant superintendents and increases class size--and will still require a tax increase of 13.5 percent.

title: ABC, Get to Know Thyself
description: THE curse of Tutankhamen is easy to trace. So is the evil eye hovering over the Red Sox in October. It is harder to pinpoint exactly when ABC became the doomed network -- there are so many blunders to chose from.

title: Behind Bryant and O'Neal, Lakers Dethrone the Spurs
description: Many observers believed this Western Conference semifinal series would determine the next N.B.A. champion, and the fans at the Staples Center certainly seemed to be basking as if a title had been won Saturday night.

title: Prints That Pop
description: Women's fashion designers are embracing a big-picture approach this summer, elbowing aside wallpaper-inspired prints like chintz and checks for broader mural-like graphics. A cotton skirt by Odille, above, is printed with a still-life of an ice cream parlor counter, complete with soda spritzers and penny candies ($78 at Anthropologie); a strapless shift by J. Crew, right, features painterly pineapples, dragonflies and plants ($148 at J. Crew).

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 2 about the return of the jazzman Sal Mosca to the stage for the first time in 12 years misstated the affiliation of Bob Arthurs, who organized the concert. He is dean of students and faculty at the Music Conservatory of Westchester, not a teacher at Westchester Community College.

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: NONFICTION | FICTION

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz entry for Connecticut in the Summer Festivals listing on May 2 misstated the number of Ozzfest tours that have taken place. This year's will be the ninth, not the eighth.

title: Hanging Gardens
description: When the bloom is on the line.

title: With the Stars as a Canopy
description: SOMETIMES a person just needs to sleep outside. Drift off to sleep with the slowness of the movement of the stars. Wake up with a cold nose. Notice how most food, even the goofy camp variety, tastes better al fresco.

title: Licensed To Stand Still
description: THE video for Beastie Boys' ''Ch-Check It Out'' -- from ''To the 5 Boroughs,'' which in June will be the trio's first album in six years -- is a rat-a-tat montage of images ripped from cheesy 70's TV shows. The group has always been fond of Sansabelt-and-sideburns nostalgia, most notably in Spike Jonze's brazenly energizing 1994 video for ''Sabotage,'' which cast the Beasties as slick gunslingers from a ''Streets of San Francisco''-style cop show. ''Sabotage'' stands as the perfect metaphor for the Beasties' style, most notably their valiant fight to keep old-style rap from sounding, well, old. The Beasties have always looked both backward and forward; they know that by recontextualizing a rerun, you can make it new.

title: Taking Worship Outdoors
description: LARCHMONT AVENUE CHURCH, a Presbyterian church in Larchmont, N.Y., is one of many churches that are not air-conditioned, said the Rev. Bill Crawford, senior minister. When the old stone building absorbs too much heat as the summer wears on, his preaching robe comes off.

title: Elevator Musician
description: THE CELLO PLAYER

title: U.F.O. Tour
description: PULL ME UP

title: U.S. Steps In to Cut Flight Delays at O'Hare
description: COMPETITION as stiff as the wind off Lake Michigan made traveling through Chicago a nightmare for airline passengers this winter.Now, the federal government has taken a step to ease the spring skies over one of the nation's busiest cities.

title: That Spectator? It's Juror No.4
description: You might think she'd have had enough already. Ruth B. Jordan, the most famous member of the jury that endured the six-month case against two former Tyco executives, returned to New York Supreme Court last week for the latest Tyco trial -- but this time just for fun.

title: The Dog's Days of Summer
description: RORY brings in ticks. My wife, Ellen, picks or brushes them from his plump beagle body, but it's hopeless. She says it's O.K. because the ticks he carries are not the dangerous ones, the ones that cause Lyme disease. The dangerous ones, she says, are half the size of the tiny brown multi-legged ticks she tosses into the toilet bowl.

title: Rebecca Orfinger, Matthew Wexler
description: Rebecca Julie Orfinger, a daughter of Marilyn S. Orfinger and Mark P. Orfinger of Ardsley, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Matthew Eric Wexler, the son of Joan G. Wexler of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Marvin Wexler of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Billy Dreskin will officiate at the Fountainhead, a caterer in New Rochelle.

title: The Banal Faces Of Khmer Rouge Evil
description: THE Cambodian director Rithy Panh doesn't want to talk about the number of dead -- the 1.7 million of his countrymen (nearly one quarter of the population) who lost their lives from 1975 to 1979, under the murderous Khmer Rouge. And though his personal losses during that time were great, he would rather not speak of them. Americans today struggle to comprehend how a few seemingly normal people, stationed in Iraq, could have so cruelly abused the prisoners they oversaw. But Mr. Rithy Panh, looking back, is faced with the transformation of vast numbers of his fellow citizens into instruments of torture and death. He finds it resists understanding.

description: As a single parent, Rosa Fabian can barely afford the rent on her Bronx apartment, where nearby radios are always blasting and drugs, she says, are sold right outside her door.

title: Trying to Turn Risk Into a Safety Net
description: STOCKS are still awfully pricey, at least by historical standards. And with interest rates rising, bonds may be primed for a fall. That could add up to a nasty one-two punch for the average portfolio. So, many financial advisers say it may be time to start looking into alternatives like hedge funds as well as mutual funds that invest in real estate and commodities.

title: Italian Pop Star, Light and Pink
description: Mionetto, whose prosecco is ubiquitous, has rolled out Il Ros, a dry low-alcohol (10. 5 percent) strawberrylike Italian pop wine under a crown (soda pop) cap. Its light fizzy pinkness may be reminiscent of yesterday's Lancers or Mateus from Portugal. Deeply iced, this appetite-quickening rosato del Veneto is a bracing alternative to lager for pizza, picnics and aprs-tennis. Beacon, 2120 Broadway (74th Street), asks $10.99. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Dear Graduates: Wake Up, and Thanks for Stopping By
description: WITH me being a parent and assorted local high schools about to hold their graduations, it seems distantly possible that I will be asked to give a commencement address at one or another on that all-important day. The schools like to select parents with significant records of accomplishment who are held in high regard by the community and have served with distinction in it. However, sometimes those people aren't available, and a call goes out for anyone who can write quickly and owns a relatively new suit.

title: The Twilight of the Information Middlemen
description: THE newsstands at La Guardia Airport illustrate a basic problem of the ''information economy.'' You can pay $5 for a magazine when you walk into the terminal -- or, if you keep walking to the air shuttle gates, you can load up on free magazines. Publishers can theorize about why it makes sense to give away what they're also selling: they can attract future subscribers, and they count even the freeloading readers in their audience. But, mainly, they are struggling with the longstanding reality that it is harder to put an exact price on intellectual or creative effort than on, say, a bushel of wheat.

title: Don't They Know It's Time to Go?
description: Don't the Directors Know It's Time to Go?ELEVEN directors are up for election to the Xerox board at the company's annual shareholder meeting on Thursday in Philadelphia. Three of them, brushed by the company's accounting scandal during the late 1990's, should spare themselves the embarrassment and back down.

title: Powell Offers Abuse Apology and Israeli Rebuke
description: SHUNEH, Jordan, May 16  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, at a gathering of the Arab elite, offered a direct apology today to Iraqi prisoners in Baghdad abused by Americans and castigated Israel for demolishing Palestinian homes in Gaza.

title: Page Two: May 9-15; The Political Homefront
description: President Bush's re-election team knew that things might get rough this spring, but they didn't know how rough: The president's job approval rating has fallen to 46 percent in the latest Gallup poll. Most presidents who cruised to re-election (Reagan, Clinton) were above 50 percent at this stage; those who were defeated (Carter and the president's father) hovered around 40 percent. Mr. Bush gets relatively healthy marks for the war on terrorism, but his ratings on the handling of Iraq are plummeting. The Bush strategy so far: Talk tough, sound strong, show no signs of backing off. David E. Sanger

The 13-year-old wunderkind Magnus Carlsen of Norway added himself to the elite of the game by winning his third and final grandmaster norm at the Sixth Dubai Open Championship, which was held from April 18 to 28. He achieved this at an earlier age than all but one player in history, Sergey Karjakin of Ukraine, who did it at 12 years 7 months.

title: Powell, on Trip to Mideast, Vows Justice on Iraq Abuse
description: In a high-stakes attempt to restore the Bush administration's battered credentials in the Arab world, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell traveled on Saturday to the heart of a region roiled by American abuse of prisoners in Iraq, offering an emotional pledge that the United States would ''see that justice is done.''

description: EVERY few seconds a baby boomer turns 50, demographic experts say. That's a lot of potential midlife crises, and few things soothe middle-age angst better than a fast, low-slung, open-air sports car.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: THE ABERNATHY BOYS

title: A Not-Yet Train With a Quite Real Name
description: This much is true: If the Second Avenue subway is ever built, number-loving East Siders may be disappointed.

title: Skipping the Learning Curve at Third
description: Alex Rodriguez never budged from third base on shots drilled toward the pitcher's mound, properly figuring there was no way he could help corral a ball that was speeding in a different direction several feet from him. He thought he should remain anchored near third, a position he is still learning.

title: Edward Albee Returns to the Zoo
description: A GOOD marriage is not the first thing that comes to mind when you think of an Edward Albee script, but in the playwright's latest work, called ''Homelife,'' that's what you get, or seem to: a well-off, delicately balanced couple named Ann and Peter.

title: India's Communists Seek Capitalist Help
description: On a recent Friday morning, Buddhadev Bhattacharjee, chief minister of West Bengal State and a senior leader of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), met with an executive from an icon of American capitalism, the I.B.M. Corporation.

title: Keeping the Forces of Decrepitude At Bay
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Daphne Merkin's insightful and ultimately sensible article on cosmetic procedures available to women of a certain age (Style, May2). I was, however, disappointed by Merkin's failure to mention a basic truth: that aging, even gracelessly, is far superior to the alternative. Those forever young, e.g., Marilyn Monroe, Princess Diana or James Dean, are no longer with us.

title: Why the Saudis May Not Rescue Oil Markets This Time
description: SAUDI ARABIA'S oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, is not given to making bland comments about the price of oil. So, after he suggested last week that OPEC increase production in an effort to bring down the highest oil prices in 13 years, global energy markets scrambled to sort out the implications of what he had said.

title: Digging Pretty
description: For style-minded weeders and mulchers, W. Atlee Burpee, the seed company, has designed a line of fashionable garden gloves suited to every task. There are goatskin-palm models with oversize French cuffs for working in brambles and briars; high-tech stretchy latex-treated models for wet soil work; and rugged pigskin models in bright colors for other tasks. The gloves come in men's, women's and children's sizes and are available in stripes, florals and solids; some models have handsome vintage graphics from the 128-year-old company's catalogs and packets. Best of all, these accessories are just $5 to $12 at Wal-Mart stores.

title: Election-Year Shuffle On the Minimum Wage
description: FEW proposals are more popular than raising the minimum wage. Public opinion polls are clear on this point. But what voters want rarely translates into a higher minimum, even though Congress does pay extra attention in presidential election years.

title: Kickflipping Manhattan
description: THERE may be many places you can be introduced to, but some places demand that you introduce yourself. New York is one of these. Its plurality, the rhythm of order and disorder, the splendid chaos that make up the urban landscape, all are such that you just have to choose your own terms.

title: All Dressed in White, Emphasis on All
description: LOCAL brides who think they should be the ones blushing on their wedding day -- and not the priest -- are standing by a Catholic clergyman's decision to forbid scandalously revealing wedding gowns at Immaculate Conception Church in Waterbury.

title: Into Plein-Air
description: In his introduction to ''Ten Vineyard Lunches,'' Richard Olney writes that every meal, even the daily ones spent ''for the most part in solitude,'' is ''a celebration.'' But, he adds, ''the most wonderful are those of the summer months. . . . At the dinner hour, the terrace, laced with colored lights, is transformed into a funny little theater with a vaguely carnival atmosphere.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: John Hughes III; The Whole Menagerie
description: ''BUTTERFLIES do not bite,'' said the musician and producer John Hughes III, reading a sign at the American Museum of Natural History's butterfly conservatory two Tuesdays ago. ''I'm not really afraid of them biting me.''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Lotus Finally Lines Up a New Car for America; That English Patient Is Starting to Stir Again
description: THE newly Americanized Elise represents not just a successful return to the purist ideals of Lotus's founder, Colin Chapman. The Elise will once again make Lotus a presence on American roads while raising production to the highest levels in the 56 years since Chapman built his first car.

title: Grit Meets Gloss, And Catches a Few Eyes
description: The new world headquarters of Topic magazine are in a corner of David Haskell's apartment, on the second floor of a half-converted T-shirt factory in Williamsburg. The dcor is low-budget chic, with an exposed brick wall and two turntables by the door.

title: Living Up to His Own Hype, Tarver Knocks Out Jones
description: With a powerful straight left hand, Antonio Tarver lived up to his bragging Saturday night and ended the long reign of Roy Jones Jr. as boxing's best practitioner with a spectacular knockout at 1 minute 41 seconds of the second round.

title: And What Did the Teacher Do During Vacation?
description: TEACHERS have long been the envy of the working man, leaving work at about 3, summers off. But little is what it seems. Following, find 10 teachers and their summer adventures, from teaching on a trash heap and training all summer to teach in the fall, to avoiding bulls on Ireland's pathways and discovering the idiosyncrasies of endangered sea turtles.

description: SHARPLES--Arthur. February 9, 2004. I pray that after all your suffering you found deserved peace, happiness & love. You are forever in my heart. I miss you. Basi

title: 'I Am Not a Gerbil!'
description: The title of Michael Emberley's RUBY AND THE SNIFFS (Little, Brown, $15.95; ages 3 to 6) may sound like the name of an old Motown group, but the book is actually the latest adventure of the feisty little girl mouse created by Emberley in ''Ruby'' more than a decade ago. Her first adventure was an urban retelling of ''Little Red Riding Hood,'' and in this new installment, Ruby has her own ''Three Bears'' experience in the apartment of her neighbors, the Sniffs -- who are literally and figuratively a trio of complete pigs.

title: The Sculpture? It's Next to Home Depot
description: THE mallification of America the process by which downtown shopping districts are supplanted by enclosed centers -- is bad enough. But the demallification of America may be worse. All over the country, malls that fail to draw sufficient crowds are being turned into strip shopping centers, which cost less to operate. Brick or stone facades are giving way to cinder block and artificial stucco, in garish colors selected not by architects, but by tenants' marketing departments.

title: Prison Guard Calls Abuse Routine and Sometimes Amusing
description: In a sworn statement to investigators, Pfc. Lynndie England explained the mystery of why soldiers at Abu Ghraib took pictures of detainees masturbating and piled naked with plastic sandbags over their heads by saying, ''We thought it looked funny so pictures were taken.''

title: Lesser Evils
description: In broad terms, Michael Ignatieff's article (May 2) challenges persons on the left and right to think deeply about how we can maintain our safety without sacrificing our souls in confronting the evil of terrorism. Ignatieff deserves credit for framing the issue in the powerful way that he did, but nowhere does he exhibit recognition that terrorism is a weapon of the powerless and that our transgressive policies, smacking of hubris, foster its growth. Adding to the hazard of our missteps is the danger that the use of our superiority in technological weaponry on a population generates suffering that leads to the same sort of feeling of helplessness, sense of outrage and thirst for retaliation that the barbarism of 9/11 generated in us, further stoking the cycle of violence.

Cantor Jeffrey Saxe will officiate at Oak Ridge, a building on the grounds of Forest Park, in Queens.

title: Now Playing: Eisner and Me
description: EARLIER this month, Michael Moore ambled back into public view when the news came out that Disney was forbidding Miramax Films, which it owns, to distribute Mr. Moore's new documentary, ''Fahrenheit 9/11,'' a movie reputed to be highly critical of the Bush administration (imagine that.) The story broke (on the front page of The New York Times) just as the attention of the movie world was about to turn toward the Cannes Film Festival, where Mr. Moore's ''Bowling for Columbine'' won a specially created award in 2002 and where ''Fahrenheit'' happens to be in competition this year. Was this timing -- and the subsequent controversy -- primarily a result of Mr. Moore's appetite for publicity or of the timidity of Disney management? Both answers are entirely plausible, and one hardly rules out the other.

title: Three Cheers for Assimilation

More impudent questions: ''I hope you're not one of those Mayflower snobs.'' And ''Did you grow up in a WASP-y mansion in Connecticut with servants?'' Turns out he didn't. The gentleman showed remarkable restraint in not cutting off the interview at that point.

title: American With an Asian Spin
description: NEW restaurants are popping up on the East End like May flowers. Leading the bunch on the North Fork is Scrimshaw in Greenport. This brilliant newcomer is right on the water at Preston's Wharf.

title: THE WAY We LIVE NOW: 5-16-04: THE ETHICIST; Hiring Help
description: I need a paralegal for my small law office and have identified candidates who work at other businesses. May I cold-call them even though they've expressed no desire for a new position? Another factor: my wife feels that my doing this is ''beneath'' my position as head of the firm, and that I should simply post the job opening at an online paralegal site. Is she right? Robert Nagle, Phoenix

Maxx and Marshalls stores, died on April 24 in Charleston, S.C. He was 79 and lived in Hilton Head, S.C., where he moved from Wellesley, Mass., about 20 years ago.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Nutter in Glasgow
description: Before cracking open Anne Donovan's first novel, BUDDHA DA (Carroll & Graf, paper, $14), you are advised to converse at some length with a Scot -- or, failing that, to rent a copy of ''Trainspotting.'' ''Ma Da's a nutter,'' announces 12-year-old Anne Marie McKenna in the book's opening line, a taste of the somewhat labor-intensive reading to come. Anne Marie's ''Da,'' a goofy Glasgow housepainter named Jimmy McKenna, has ''turnt intae a Buddhist,'' to the consternation of his family. Instead of going to the pub on Tuesdays, he's begun frequenting the Buddhist Center, and what's more, lamas keep dropping by the house. The transcribed brogue and gag-rich premise initially lend ''Buddha Da'' a slapstick feel. But as Jimmy's engagement with Buddhism deepens, the novel matures into an astute exploration of Donovan's enormously appealing characters. (The language also becomes fluently readable and clearly indispensable to the book's flavor.) Chapters rotate between the first-person narratives of Anne Marie, Jimmy and Liz, his wife, and through these three perspectives, an intimate and comprehensive family portrait emerges. At the story's heart is the disruption of a loving but heretofore unexamined marriage: no-nonsense Liz increasingly has trouble assimilating her husband's commitments to meditation, vegetarianism and celibacy; Jimmy is a devoted, if self-absorbed, family man who ''always thought that wanst ah'd found whitever it was ah was lookin fur, well, ah'd just go back tae ma life.'' Inevitably, his own growth dislodges settled patterns, and the subsequent realignment is wistfully satisfying to behold. Rebecca Tuhus-Dubrow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCU, EVA D. (NEE GERSON), PH.D.
description: MARCU--Eva D. (nee Gerson), Ph.D. Died at the age of 96 on May 12th, 2004. She was born in Dahlem, Germany, and had an epic life both astounding, amazing and distressing. Her father was a Socialist and the kindest man imaginable. He was a philanthropist, giving his wealth to those who had less than he. He persisted in his altruism giving to so many and was betrayed in Marseilles by, it is believed, his driver, and sent to a concentration camp where he was slaughtered with millions of others. Eva married a Rumanian writer, Valeriu, who had left Bucharest quite early in his adult life for Berlin, where he met his future wife at her father's at one of his famed social revelries. Valeriu was always the life blood of any celebration and went to countless such evenings. Her brother was a gentle soul who died at their house in Grasse, in the South of France, where he lived after the war. He had been in British intelligence. With the threat of WWII, Eva and Valeriu moved to Nice, France where Valeriu helped Varien Fry liberate and help to emigrate thousands of artists. It was in Nice where the Marcu's gave birth to a girl, whom they named Miki. Eva and Valeriu, moved to the U.S. (with the help of significant writers given special visa for authors and other intellectuals) and escaped the Nazis. Valeriu died in New York some years later at the age of 40. Eva, therefore, lost the three most momentous men in her life within a few years of each other. She was always the most munificent person (inheriting her father's trait) and gave money, time and her enormous soul to those whom she also thought had less than she, at a time when she had very little. Her gifts were at all times anonymous. She had the soul of an angel, but too unassuming to ever understand or recognize compliments. Her curiosity was inexhaustible and her intelligence dazzling and incomparable. She was Professor of literature at various Universities (Columbia, Mannes, Rutgers), and wrote books and articles, the most significant of which are the maxims of Montaigne and her analysis on the injurious Nationalism of the 16th century and her hero of heroes. Mme de Sevigne (1646-1705), whose letters warmed Eva's heart. She was her hero of heroes. She cherished languages and spoke several. In her 80's and on, she forced herself to translate an hour of Latin each evening, thinking she would stave off Alzheimer's. She hated those hours, but made this bargain between the devil and her brain. In March 2003, afraid that her health was failing and that she would be a burden to her daughter, as the indomitable woman she was, without ever seeking advice or consent, decided to move to an independent living home at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, (coincidentally, the same city where her husband had died). After 8 months her leg was arterially so clogged that nothing other than amputation above the knee was possible. From then on her health declined and she went from her charming apartment overlooking the Hudson and the woods, to the hospital and rehabilitation home then back to her apartment. She quickly deteriorated. She was at all times grace under trauma. Despite her brilliance, modesty prevented her from recognizing how many people cared for her. While in the hospital and at home she received ca. 200 email letters and cards and telephone calls. Her daughter, so inestimably grief-stricken inconsolably mourns her.

title: HIGHLANDS BILL DELAYED
description: The Assembly and Senate environment committees again delayed passing a bill last week that would preserve the highlands in seven northwestern counties from which the state gets half its water supply. A vote originally scheduled for April had been postponed until last week so that members could review a set of amendments that were intended to appease critics. The bill's sponsors said at last week's joint session in the Trenton War Memorial that the vote would again be postponed until tomorrow to give time for a review of a second set of amendments. But two South Jersey senators, Stephen M. Sweeney, a Democrat from Gloucester, and John H. Adler, a Democrat from Camden, said afterward they had not been ready to vote. The Highlands Water Protection and Planning Act, a keystone in Governor McGreevey's environmental initiative, would severely restrict development near reservoirs and feeder streams in half of 800,000 acres across the northern tier of the state. A spokesman for the governor, Micah Rasmussen, promised that the administration would continue to press for passage. George James

title: Rescuing the National Parks
description: It is mainly the views that lure nine million visitors a year to Great Smoky Mountains National Park. The problem is that on some days no one can see anything. Over the last few decades, average visibility in summer months has shrunk from 77 miles to 15, and it is not at all unusual for visitors who climb to Look Rock, high on the park's northern edge, to find themselves cocooned in a uniform, whitish haze. This haze is not to be confused with the blue mists that arise after rainstorms and give the Smokies their name. It is man-made, consisting mostly of sulfates produced by coal-fired power plants upwind of the park. One administration after another has failed to deal adequately with this problem despite Congress's express mandate more than 25 years ago to do so.

title: A LEVEL PAY-FOR-PLAYING FIELD?
description: The Democrats who control the General Assembly opened public discussion last week on the crucial component of ethics legislation: the tradition of awarding government work to big campaign contributors. In the meeting, which lasted into the evening on Wednesday, the committee members heard from only a handful of citizens and good-government groups who had come to a center for the elderly in this suburb of Philadelphia. Even for many Assembly members, about a dozen of whom addressed the committee, the hearing was their first chance to publicly discuss the practice known as ''pay to play.'' The Assembly's Democratic leaders joined Senate leaders in pledging to enact sweeping ethics legislation by July 1. The overriding issue was whether a pay-to-play ban should apply only on the state level, as the Democrats propose, or whether it should also apply to the county party organizations that wield outsize influence in New Jersey. title: The Anti-Olmsted

The pipes that once water-cooled the pig-iron mills and siphoned off gases still snake and coil, but they are drained and lifeless. In 1985, as part of a wave of industrial shutdowns that changed the character of the Ruhr Valley, the Thyssen plant in Duisburg closed. The nightmarish hulks that remained -- almost mythic in their lurid grandeur -- stood stranded, presumed doomed. The notion that they would come back to life in the quintessential park of the early 21st century seemed about as probable as sighting a pterosaur in flight overhead.

But by the 1980's, the Grand Concourse in the Bronx had become more of a driver's paradise. Stoplights were timed to keep cars moving, some trees and pedestrian crossings had been removed, and perhaps most upsetting to long-time residents, dozens of bright green highway-style exit signs sprouted on its edges. Those signs, some said, encouraged drivers to forget they were on a residential street.

title: Page Two: May 9-15; Justice Delayed

New evidence uncovered by documentary filmmakers, suggesting that as many as 10 people may have been involved in the abduction, prodded federal prosecutors to join with Mississippi authorities in investigating the killing anew. Two white men were originally acquitted of the crime by an all-white jury. Eric Lichtblau

title: A TANGLE OVER AND CHURCH AND STATE
description: The Senate majority leader, Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hudson County, has announced that he is leaving the church entirely, in the wake of a letter published by Archbishop John J. Myers of Newark stating that it is dishonest for Catholic officeholders who favor abortion rights to receive communion. Mr. Kenny, above, had been active in SS. Peter and Paul Church in Hoboken for years. Senator Kenny said that after reading Archbishop Myers's statement, he asked for a meeting with his pastor. When told that he would be denied communion, the senator said Monday, he knew he could no longer continue practicing as a Catholic. The archbishop said last week on Fox TV that he had not meant to attack anyone in publishing the letter in the archdiocese's newspaper, but that he was pleased that his comments had brought attention to the church's unwavering opposition to the ''festering'' issue of abortion. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMAN, WALTER
description: NEWMAN--Walter. Passed away at his home in Briarcliff Manor, NY, on May 15 at the age of 86. Formerly of Bronxville, NY, and Lake Placid, NY, Dr. Newman was a graduate of Columbia College ('39) and P&S Medical School ('43M). Conducted research through the 40's and 50's as the Chief of Cardiology at the Kings County VA Hospital, co-authoring numerous articles on the diagnosis and treatment of cardiac disease. In the mid-50's he established a private practice in Yonkers, NY, and was appointed Chief of Cardiology at Yonkers General Hospital. Member of The Harvey Society, Alpha Omega Alpha, New York Academy of Sciences and a Diplomat of the American College of Cardiology. Dr. Newman was precedeased by his beloved wife, Elizabeth Curley, and is survived by his children, Walter, Jr., of Boston, MA, Michael of Pleasantville, NY, Joseph of Salem, MA, William of Saxton's River, VT, Richard of Brooklyn, NY, Sara Klett of Guilford, CT, and Carolyn Malmstrom of Milton, MA, as well as 10 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. title: Integration Day
description: Today is the day that gay citizens in this country cross a milestone of equality. Gay couples will be married in Massachusetts -- their love and commitment and responsibility fully cherished for the first time by the society they belong to. It is also, amazingly enough, the day of the 50th anniversary of Brown v. Board of Education, the Supreme Court ruling that ended racial segregation in schools across America. We should be wary of facile comparisons. The long march of African-Americans to civil equality was and is deeply different from the experience and legacy of gay Americans. But in one respect, the date is fitting, for both Brown and this new day revolve around a single, simple and yet deeply elusive idea: integration.

Clemens and Penny did not face each other in Game 4.

title: The Dark Side of America
description: The sickening pictures of American troops humiliating Iraqi prisoners have led inevitably to questions about the standards of treatment in the corrections system at home, which has grown tenfold over the last 30 years and now jails people at eight times the rate of France and six times the rate of Canada. Conditions vary widely from state to state and community to community. But as The Times's Fox Butterfield reported recently, some of the chilling pictures from Iraq -- such as the ones of inmates being paraded around naked -- could have been taken at some American prisons. And humiliation by prison guards is far from the first thing on most American inmates' list of worries.

title: Massachusetts Arrives at Moment for Same-Sex Marriage

title: A Visa Quagmire
description: Security measures enacted after the 9/11 terrorist attacks are impeding the inflow of scientific talent that helps energize American universities and industries. Heightened security reviews required before visas can be issued to foreign students, scientists and engineers have generated massive backlogs of applications and discouraged some of the best and brightest. If the red tape is not untangled soon, it could cause long-term harm to America's universities and high-tech industries.

title: Pistons Force the Nets To Ponder a Finale in Detroit
description: The Nets started walking off the court at the end of the game, only to be called back by the officials. A foul with two-tenths of a second remaining forced them to return, watch and think. As the crowd filed out of Continental Arena and as Pistons guard Lindsey Hunter's free throws put the finishing touches on an 81-75 Detroit victory Sunday night, the Nets could not defend, could not score. All they could do was think.

title: Stocks Plunge in India Over Fears of New Government
description: NEW DELHI, May 17  India's stock market took the biggest one-day drop in its 129-year history today before recovering, as confusion reigned over the course and composition of the new government to be led by Sonia Gandhi and her Congress Party.

description: Mired in their worst economic crisis in recent history, voters in the Dominican Republic came out in large numbers on Sunday to cast ballots for a new president. Numerous polls indicated they would bring back former President Leonel Fernndez.

Sales of used books, from mass-market paperbacks that sell for 50 cents to leather-bound first editions that sell for thousands of dollars, are increasingly being made online.

title: A Passion That's Just Beyond Reach
description: All-American, wholesome, Ivory-girl-next-door purity: it's not the typical notion of an opera singer, but it's very much the image of the soprano Dawn Upshaw. She has parlayed this image, in fact, into a distinctive niche in contemporary opera. Some of her biggest successes have come in what one could term virginal-white-dress roles, which call on her to make lovely, pure sounds: the soprano soloist in Osvaldo Golijov's ''Pasion Segun San Marcos,'' or the Angel in Messiaen's ''St. Francois d'Assise.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EVERETT, HENRY
description: EVERETT -- Henry. The Board and Staff of the New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend Henry Everett. Henry, with his wife Edith, brought joy, fun, and learning to hundreds of thousands of NYC schoolchildren and their families through the creation of the Everett Children's Adventure Garden. Henry was committed to fighting for the ideas, causes, and people he believed in. The Garden is honored to be a part of Henry's--and Edith's--wide ranging philanthropic interests and thoughtful advocacy, which include numerous anti-smoking initiatives, Teach for America, Columbia University's Teachers College, International Hillel, National Public Radio, Dance Theater of Harlem, and founding the Everett School in Hatzor, Israel. Henry, with Edith, created and nurtured the Everett Public Service Internship Program, helping nearly 2000 young people across the nation over the last 15 years discover rewarding careers in public service through summer internships, including 60 at the Garden alone. We shall miss Henry's graciousness and genuine warmth, generous and welcoming spirit, attentive creativity and abundant optimism. Our prayers go to his wife Edith and their children and grandchildren. Wilson Nolen, Chairman Gregory Long, President Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman Emeritus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EVERETT, HENRY
description: EVERETT--Henry. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) are deeply sorrowed by the passing of our esteemed Board member. Henry Everett's lifelong commitment to social justice and his desire to reach out and help those whose needs are often overlooked is shared with equal determination by his precious life-partner, Edith. Together they participated in the rescue of Ethiopian Jewry, serving as pioneering advocates on the community's behalf. They envisioned, founded and supported major educational initiatives that have benefited tens of thousands of Ethiopian-Israeli parents and children. And their firm commitment to helping Israel better the lives of all of its citizens led them to establish a pioneering effort on behalf of Israeli Druze. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Edith, David, Carolyn and the entire Everett family. Henry's life of righteous deeds is our challenge and inspiration. May his memory be for a blessing. Eugene J. Ribakoff President Jonathan W. Kolker Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Exec. Vice-President

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Jail Term Ends For Former Legislator
description: Former Representative Bill Janklow, left, who was convicted of second-degree manslaughter and resigned from office after killing a motorcyclist in a collision last August, was released from jail on Monday after serving 100 days. Mr. Janklow, a Republican, was found guilty in December of speeding, reckless driving and other charges in the death of Randy Scott, 55, who was killed on a rural South Dakota road on Aug. 16, 2003. Mr. Janklow, who resigned from the House of Representatives in January, has appealed his manslaughter and reckless driving convictions to the State Supreme Court. His law license has been suspended until that is resolved. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Siemens To Expand China Operations
description: The German engineering company Siemens plans to invest 1 billion euros ($1.19 billion) in China, its chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said. Siemens, which has invested more than 655 million euros in China to date, aims to increase production of cellphones by 40 percent by next year and double sales in the nation in five years, Mr. von Pierer said at a briefing in Shanghai.

title: 9/11 Panel Has a Question: Why Wasn't the City Prepared?

title: Israeli Army Moves on Rafah Refugee Camp in Gaza
description: Israeli armored bulldozers reinforced by helicopter gunships advanced early Tuesday into the Rafah refugee camp in the southern Gaza Strip after Israeli troops sealed the camp off for what the army called a large-scale operation to root out militants and weapons smuggling tunnels.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility Bid Rejected
description: The Pennon Group, the water utility for southwestern England, rejected a bid from investors led by Terra Firma Capital Partners, the investment fund founded by Guy Hands, as too low. The shares increased as much as 8 percent. Pennon, based in Exeter, England, has a market value of 915 million ($1.6 billion). The Terra Firma bid price has not been disclosed. The board unanimously rejected the bid, Pennon said. Pennon and Terra Firma are both trying to buy the British landfill interests of the Shanks Group, a waste-disposal company. Last year, the Hands interests bought the Waste Recycling Group, Britain's largest landfill operator.

description: For almost half a century Europe overlooked the art treasures that were looted from Jewish homes by the Nazis and never returned. Then, as mid-20th-century European history resurfaced in the 1990's, the political climate changed. Suddenly missing art became a moral issue, and red-faced governments, museums and auction houses hurriedly promised to make amends. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Outlook Raised

Gross domestic product is likely to expand by 5.5 percent to 7.5 percent, the ministry said, up from its previous prediction for growth of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent. Singapore's exports, excluding oil and other petroleum products, rose 15.1 percent in April compared with the month a year earlier. The news failed to invigorate Singapore's stock market, however. Concerns about rising oil prices and rising interest rates sent the benchmark stock index down 3.1 percent to its lowest in almost six months, part of a regionwide slump that hit Asian stocks yesterday. The lessons that DreamWorks derived (and distorted) from William Steig's sublimely dyspeptic picture book are reiterated: be yourself; love yourself for who you are. For myself I accept ''Shrek 2'' for what it is -- a slick and playful entertainment that remains carefully inoffensive beneath its veneer of bad manners -- but I don't really love it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Museum Wins Expansion Fight
description: A lawsuit that sought to stop the Metropolitan Museum of Art from its long-planned expansion was dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The suit pitted the museum against a group of wealthy neighbors known as the Metropolitan Museum Historic District Coalition, which says it fears that the Met expansion will draw more visitors to the museum and add to the taxis, school buses and carnival of performers along Fifth Avenue. The museum contends that the number of visitors, currently about five million a year, will remain unchanged. According to the Met, the museum's exterior will not be expanded, but the amount of available space inside will grow. The group argued that a 1971 agreement with the city restricted the museum's ability to expand. A lawyer for the group said it planned to appeal the suit's dismissal. Judge Marcy S. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABERBACH, JULIAN J.
description: ABERBACH--Julian J., 95, of New York City, New York, Southampton, New York, Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of 50 years of Anne Marie Aberbach, loving father of Belinda Aberbach Stevenson Agar, loving grandfather of Vanessa Stevenson, Elie Stevenson, Max Stevenson, Ezra Stevenson and Chloe Agar, passed away of heart failure in New York City on Monday, May 17, 2004. Julian J. Aberbach was one of the most respected names in American music publishing as well as music publishing around the world. Having emigrated to America from Austria, he served in WWII in the U.S. Army receiving his commission as Second Lieutenant and served as a multilingual liaison with officers of the Free French. He became interested in country music and developed a major music publishing enterprise along with his brother Joachim Jean Aberbach. Major names in Nashville music such as Red Foley, Ernest Tubb, Johnny Cash, Eddie Arnold, Bill Monroe, Left Frizzel and Hank Snow accounted for close to 75% of Hill and Range Songs' country music hits. One of the most significant publishing deals ever made by the Aberbachs was the acquisition of the exclusive publishing rights to the music of Elvis Presley in 1955. By the early 1970's the Aberbach business had become a worldwide music force. Julian Aberbach was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame on June 15, 2000. Julian and Jean Aberbach went on to develop as major figures in the art world as owners of the Aberbach Fine Art Gallery in New York City. He lost his brother in 1992. Additionally, Mr. Aberbach received the Legion of Honor in June 2003 in recognition of his unique contribution to French culture. He was dearly loved and he will be greatly missed. Services will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, NYC, at 10 A.M. on Wednesday, May 19, 2004. Interment will follow at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'BRIEN, MARY K.
description: O'BRIEN--Mary K. A beloved teacher, linguist, and story teller, Mary K. O'Brien died on Sunday, May 16th. From her mother she inherited a passion for teaching, and from her father the art of story telling. Laughter with an ironic twist was always the common denominator. Ms. O'Brien, the daughter of the late Frank J. and Agnes Ring O'Brien, was born in Cleveland, OH, and grew up in Meriden, CT. Ms. O'Brien, who taught French and the Classics for nearly 50 years, graduated from Albertus Magnus College with a major in Classics, entered the Dominican Sisters of Columbus, OH in 1943, received her MA in French literature at Fordham University, studied in France on a summer Fulbright grant, and taught in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, as well as at Mary Immaculate School in Ossining, NY, Dominican Academy and the Rhodes School, both in Manhattan. After leaving the Dominican community in 1973, she taught until 1987 in New Jersey's Morris Hills Regional school system where she relished deep friendships with colleagues and students for the rest of her life. While leading a student group to France in 1969, she met Mr. Jerry Berlin who has remained her dear companion and confidant until her death. Together, they welcomed friends and relatives to her New Jersey home. An avid world traveler who studied Spanish and Italian at an advanced age, she served as a lector and eucharistic minister in her parish until her recent illness. Deeply committed to peace, Ms. O'Brien deplored our country's preemptive war policy. In addition to Mr. Berlin of Manhattan, Ms. O'Brien leaves behind two sisters, A. Geraldine Sullivan of Wellesley, MA and Joan O'Brien of Carbondale, IL, a brother and his wife, Honorable Francis J. and Ann G. O'Brien of Meriden, CT, and numerous beloved nieces and nephews. The funeral will be held at Norman Dean Home for Services, 16 Righter Ave, Denville, NJ (www.normandean.com Light a Candle at website), on Thursday at 8:30AM for a 9:30AM Liturgy for Christian Burial service at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Mountain Lakes, NJ. Friends will be received Wednesday 2-4 & 79PM. Memorial donations to Atlantic Home Care and Hospice, 33 Bleeker Street, Millburn, NJ 07041.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LARKIN, FRANK YOAKUM
description: LARKIN--Frank Yoakum. Of Greenwich, CT & New York City. Beloved husband of June Noble Larkin, died on Sunday, May 16, 2004, in Greenwich, CT, of heart failure. He was a former Executive Vice President of The Putnam Trust Company of Greenwich, and was a graduate of Princeton University, Fordham University School of Law, and served as a Captain in The U.S. Army during World War II. He was a former Chairman of the Board of Greenwich Academy and former President of the Board of Greenwich Hospital. An ardent naturalist and ornithologist since childhood, he served as a Trustee of the Wildlife Conservation Society since 1973, and became a Life Trustee in 2000. In recognition of his life-long commitment to conservation he was awarded the Society's highest honor, its Gold Medal, which was inscribed ''Frank Y. Larkin-1998-His unique Understanding and Far-ranging Knowledge of Wild Creatures Provides a Special Leadership for us All.'' He also served as a Trustee of the American Museum of Natural History from 1974 to 2001, and became an Honorary Trustee in 2001. In addition, the Museum's education center, the Discovery Room, is named in his honor. As Vice Chairman of the Edward John Noble Foundation, and as President of the St. Catherine's Island Foundation, he stewarded the Foundation's environmental funding programs, focussing efforts on scientific research, education, and the preservation of endangered species. Brother of Mrs. Robert C. Wilson, New York City, father of Barbara Franklin, Washington D.C., Frank Larkin, Wooster, Ohio, Patricia Larkin, Washington D.C., and Edith Hubbell, Norwich, VT. Stepfather of Noble Smith, David Smith, Jeremy Smith, Bradford Smith. Grandfather of Jennifer Del Guercio, Lisa Topchik, John F. Franklin III, Sarah, Jay, and Andrew Hubbell. Great grandfather of Sara Topchik. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday June 3, 2004, at 6 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History. Contributions may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History, or the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York.

The Miami-Dade school board voted 7 to 2 to give Dr. Crew a four-year contract with an option for a two-year extension. The two board members who voted against hiring Dr. Crew said the district should not pay him so much at a time when its schools were facing budget cuts. The company had $185 million in sales in 2003 and has 2,000 employees. The acquisition is expected to increase earnings slightly this year and by 25 cents a share next year, the company said. Teleflex says it plans to use some of its $500 million revolving credit line and $300 million to $400 million in debt to finance the purchase.

title: Yankees Taking a More Daring Path on the Bases
description: Luis Sojo took over for Willie Randolph in the Yankees' third-base coaching box this season, but the team might have saved a little money by simply installing an E-ZPass scanner. After all, a familiar Yankees sight this season has been Sojo waving runners home with a left arm that looks like a propeller on a World War II bomber.

title: Two Ways to Pass the 'Bayadre' Aesthetic Test
description: As sheer spectacle on an opera-house scale, Natalia Makarova's 1980 staging of ''La Bayadre'' for American Ballet Theater triumphs over its 19th-century Orientalism and melodramatic plot. Murder, mayhem, poisonous snakes and a temple that comes crashing down are all part of the colorful big picture.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with the cover article in the Television section in the New York region, about the CBS series ''C.S.I.: Miami,'' seen last night, misstated the name of the actor seated between David Caruso and Gary Sinise. He was Carmine Giovinazzo. (Danny Messer is the character he plays.)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: First New High School In 40 Years
description: City and state officials, including Gov. James E. McGreevey, broke ground yesterday for a $63 million high school, Newark's first in four decades. At 300,000 square feet, Science Park High School will be five times the size of the current school and is scheduled for completion by 2006. Science Park is expected to serve about 1,200 students, double the current number. The center will also handle ballistics, toxicology, forensic photography and other forms of evidence testing. The new building will include facilities for building robots. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Rice and Palestinian Leader Optimistic on Gaza
description: Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, and Ahmed Qurei, the Palestinian prime minister, met for two hours in Berlin on Monday, and both said afterward that the Israeli prime minister's plan to withdraw from Gaza created a new chance to move toward a wider peace agreement.

title: No Concern of W.T.C. Collapse Among Fire Chiefs, Report Says
description: Barely half an hour before the South Tower of the World Trade Center collapsed at 9:59 a.m. on Sept. 11, 2001, none of the fire chiefs briefing the mayor and police commissioner at a meeting on a nearby street expressed concern that either 110-story building was in danger of falling, the staff of the 9/11 commission said in a report issued today.

title: Inquiry Widens; Insurance Brokers May Face Change
description: Correction Appended

title: XTO ENERGY TO EXPAND WITH $1.1 BILLION PURCHASE
description: XTO Energy agreed to purchase natural-gas and oil properties in New Mexico, Texas and five other states from ChevronTexaco for $1.1 billion in its largest acquisition ever. The reserves will help XTO increase output by 30 percent this year, up from a previous estimate of 20 percent, the company said in a statement. XTO plans a share offering to help pay for a total of $1.8 billion in acquisitions this year, the chief executive, Bob Simpson, 56, said during a conference call with analysts and investors. XTO's new acquisitions will strengthen its presence in Louisiana, Oklahoma, New Mexico and the Permian Basin of West Texas. It will add properties in South Texas and a coal-bed methane project in the Rocky Mountains.

title: F.D.R. Drive Taking Its Act to the River, for Three Years
description: For the next three years, a temporary roadway will divert traffic - and, it is hoped, avert huge traffic jams - over the East River, between 54th and 63rd Streets, while repairs are being made to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan. The detour is set to open at 6 a.m. on Sunday.

Survived by two daughters, Marjorie Cahn of MI and Dr. Lucy Goodenday of OH, a son, Paul Sherman of Morganville, NJ, seven grandchildren, and nine great grandchildren. description: John Berg, president for the last two years of Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners in New York, part of Havas, is leaving, the agency said yesterday, to open a marketing communications agency.

title: Tales of Fear And Quake, Of the Cleric And the Eel
description: On a flight I was on from Nassau to Miami on a Dash 8 turboprop, a fire broke out in one of its twin engines on takeoff. The pilot shut it down and we lost altitude, but were able to limp back to Nassau. Nobody was hurt, but the people around me, mostly Bahamians on a shopping flight, were screaming.

description: Correction Appended

title: Election Day, And Abuse By Athletes Is an Issue
description: For the past few weeks, the school board candidates Mary Ramo and John Rossi have been knocking on hundreds of doors in the Nassau County high school district of Bellmore-Merrick. They are happy to talk to voters about the two biggest issues of their campaign: tax rates and sexual abuse on the high school football team.

title: NBC REBOOKS 'THE RESTAURANT'
description: The restaurant is still in business, but ''The Restaurant'' is not doing quite enough business as far as NBC is concerned. The network's executives said yesterday that because of disappointing ratings, they decided to postpone the last three episodes of the reality series ''The Restaurant,'' which chronicles the ups and downs (mostly downs) of the chef Rocco DiSpirito, above, as he opened his dream red-sauce trattoria, Rocco's on 22nd Street. The show's first season, which was shown last summer, dominated its time period, and the network expected to gain viewers by moving the show into its Monday night lineup, just after the hit show ''Las Vegas.'' But instead -- even as legal battles between Mr. DiSpirito and his financial backer, Jeffrey Chodorow, have turned this season into an entertaining food fight -- the show has generated disappointing ratings. Jeff Gaspin, the executive vice president of alternative programming for NBC, said the network planned to show the final two episodes of ''The Restaurant'' sometime in the next few weeks, after the May sweeps weeks are over. RANDY KENNEDY

title: Prison Abuse Exceeded Directives, Guards Say
description: Interrogators from military intelligence and other government agencies told guards at the Abu Ghraib prison to deprive detainees of sleep and food, and would strip detainees and make them sleep naked in their cells, but their orders stopped well short of the abuse at the center of the prison scandal, guards and investigators have testified at a preliminary hearing for one of the soldiers accused of abuse.

title: Miller Gets Help From Lobbyist In Finding a New Chief of Staff
description: Council Speaker Gifford Miller has sought help from a lobbyist whose clients often have business before the City Council to fill a crucial position, the speaker's chief of staff. The role is traditionally that of gatekeeper and top adviser to one of the city's most powerful officials.

title: OOPS!
description: At the Drama Desk Awards on Sunday night, Joe Mantello, left, graciously accepted the award for best director of a musical for his staging of the revival of ''Assassins.'' He thanked Stephen Sondheim, John Weidman and the several actors in the ensemble in the Roundabout Theater's production. It was a fairly standard speech, as such things go. But there was one problem: Mr. Mantello had actually won for his work on ''Wicked,'' which was also nominated in the same category. ''We deeply regret this error and apologize to Mr. Mantello, the companies of 'Wicked' and 'Assassins,' the theater community and the public,'' said Les Schecter, the press agent for the awards, in a prepared statement. ''The confusion due solely to human error occurred when the names of the winners were transferred to the presenter envelopes.'' Incidentally Mr. Mantello is nominated for a Tony Award for his direction of ''Assassins,'' not ''Wicked.'' Mr. Mantello has subsequently issued a second acceptance speech to the press. ''Now I feel as though I've been given the opportunity to acknowledge both 'Assassins' and 'Wicked,' which pleases me greatly,'' he said. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Levine Leads Met Players in Some Brahmsian Calisthenics
description: For all the chatter and speculation about James Levine's health, he seems as disinclined as ever to slow down. Having closed the Metropolitan Opera season with Wagner's ''Gtterdmmerung'' on May 8, he took the Met Orchestra to Carnegie Hall to close out its series there with three concerts in a week, each with a different program and all of them substantial. At the first in the series, on Sunday afternoon, he conducted from a chair, as he has frequently done in recent years, but there was no lack of energy in his direction or in the players' response.

She is Trude Rittmann, not Rittman, and she was best known as a choral and dance music arranger, not as a choreographer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Current Account Grows
description: Japan's current account surplus grew 13 percent in March from the month a year earlier, for a ninth straight increase. The surplus rose to 1.83 trillion yen ($16 billion) as exports to China and other Asian countries increased. Over all, Japanese exports rose 13 percent, to 5.17 trillion yen ($45.3 billion), while imports rose 11 percent, to 3.83 trillion yen. Economists expect Japan's current account surplus will continue to grow on robust demand for Japanese goods in Asia. The current account is a broad measure of the flow of goods, services, investment and tourism. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: American Financial Realty Trust, Jenkintown, Pa., said it had bought 150 properties from Wachovia Corp., Charlotte, N.C., the bank, for $546 million.

description: I.B.M. and Cisco Systems plan to announce on Tuesday a joint development project to expand their reach into the Internet telephone market, with Cisco providing the phone and network technology and I.B.M. contributing software and integrating the systems.

Helped by a cost-cutting program, the airline said its full-year income rose 70 percent, to 230 million ($407 million) before taxes. description: The United States government has decided to halt monthly $335,000 payments to the Iraqi National Congress, the group headed by Ahmad Chalabi, an official with the group said on Monday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Legal Aid Gives Layoff Notices
description: Scores of lawyers who defend the poor in the city's courts will be laid off effective June 30 unless $11 million in new funds can be raised from government or private sources. The Legal Aid Society, the principal nonprofit organization providing representation for the poor, said yesterday that it had given layoff notices to 161 lawyers. Legal Aid has about 880 lawyers citywide, and the departure of 18 percent of them could slow the court system. An $11 million gap exists between what the organization estimates it needs to handle its 210,000 cases a year -- $77.5 million -- and what is allocated for it in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's budget. Pat Bath, a spokeswoman for Legal Aid, said that the organization hoped to rescind some of the layoffs if it obtained additional money. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Life in Ring Wears Champion Around the Edges
description: IT has been a few months since Emanuel Yarbrough, perhaps the most famous amateur sumo wrestler in the world, has been to the gym to train. He slips off his size 19 sneakers and maneuvers his 6-foot-8, 740-pound bulk onto the mat. His arms arch out at his sides because of his huge girth, sweat starts to drip down his forehead and, facing him, one feels pity for his opponents.

title: Front Row; For the Unbuttoned Man
description: In the midst of a renewal of interest in men's fashion, which has seen expensive dress shirts, suits and shoes flying out of stores, one key player has not been cleared for takeoff: the necktie, sales of which are flat as tarmac.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: School Financing Session Breaks Off
description: A special session of the Legislature charged by Gov. Rick Perry with restructuring the Texas public school finance system collapsed when both the House and the Senate adjourned two days ahead of schedule with no agreement in sight. Mr. Perry, a Republican, wanted to reduce property taxes and offset the lost revenue with higher levies on gambling and erotic entertainment. He also called for an end to a system in which taxes from affluent school districts underwrite schools in poor ones. Mr. Perry has said another legislative session to deal with school financing is inevitable. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: A suicide bomber killed the president of the Iraqi Governing Council and at least six other people on Monday at a checkpoint into the main headquarters for the American occupation forces in Iraq.

title: It's 'Streetcar,' But Blanche Has a Sly Side
description: Wry, dry and ruefully self-aware, Patricia Clarkson's performances stand out in current American film like crisp martinis in a soda fountain. Ms. Clarkson, nominated for an Academy Award this year for her unsentimental portrait of the terminally ill mother in ''Pieces of April,'' is now applying the same sardonic intelligence to an unlikely subject: Blanche DuBois, the fragile fantasist heroine of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' which has been revived as part of the Tennessee Williams summer festival at the Kennedy Center here.

description: A holdup near Heathrow Airport was broken up by the police on Monday, as eight would-be robbers tried to steal $140 million-worth of gold and cash.

title: Kerry Feels for Footing On Country's Role in Iraq
description: Senator John Kerry, on his way to a rally here with Howard Dean, who battered him for months for voting in favor of invading Iraq, acknowledged Monday afternoon that he was navigating a fine line on how to deal with the deepening crisis in Iraq.

title: How to Duck Swimmer's Itch
description: If you are unfortunate enough to come down with ''swimmer's itch,'' a parasite-caused irritation common to people in some lake areas, there is not much to do but wait -- and try not to scratch.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: East Harlem Woman Found Dead
description: A woman was found dead, apparently strangled, in her East Harlem apartment on Sunday night, the police said. The body of the woman, Michelle Coulibaly, 44, had a nylonlike material around its neck, the police said. A neighbor, Cynthia Pantojas, said that Ms. Coulibaly's body was found when her brother climbed the fire escape of the building at 12 East 108th Street and looked through the window. Investigators would like to question Ms. Coulibaly's husband, the police said. She leaves a grown daughter and two sons, 14 and 2, Ms. Pantojas said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Seeking Clues in a Vast Frozen Mystery
description: SUMMIT CAMP, GREENLAND, May 18  Two kinds of edgeless whiteness confront those who fly over the frozen, two-mile-high, 1,200-mile-long hump called Greenland: layers of low clouds and the horizon-to-horizon sprawl of the ice cap itself. It is important to recognize the difference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis. Age 58, unexpectedly and tragically passed away on Saturday, May 15. A man who traveled many diverse paths in his life, which came to its end much too soon. He will be missed by all those whose life he touched, most especially Elaine, his partner in life, and her children and grandchildren. Some people are measured by what they collect, most assuredly Lewis would be deemed wealthy by the count of those who will mourn his loss. Memorial service Thursday, May 20 at 4PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: U.N. Unit Sees Great Promise In Biotech Research on Crops
description: Genetically engineered crops hold great promise for helping the world's poor, the United Nations food agency said yesterday. But it said the promise was not being fulfilled because too little biotech research was aimed at the basic food crops grown in developing countries.

title: Gandhi Stakes Her Claim to Lead a Rattled India
description: Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born leader of the Indian National Congress party, will formally stake claim to be India's next prime minister on Tuesday, party officials said Monday night. The announcement came after the country's stock market recorded its biggest single-day fall amid concerns over the new government's approach to economic reforms.

title: The Global Battle Against AIDS; Opposition to Condoms
description: The Bush administration's enlightenment on AIDS treatment has not, alas, been matched in AIDS prevention programs. Spurred by the religious right, the administration and Congress have fenced off one-third of the nation's international AIDS prevention funds to be used for abstinence programs starting in 2006, even though such programs alone are insufficient.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Strike Authorized At Con Ed
description: Union workers at Consolidated Edison have authorized a strike when their contract expires at midnight on May 26. Steve Mangione, a spokesman for Local 1-2, Utility Workers Union of America, refused to provide details about the negotiations, except to say that the two sides had not reached an agreement on wages and health-care benefits. Last week, about 4,500 of the union's 8,600 members voted to authorize a strike, Mr. Mangione said. Union members hold various jobs, from meter readers to repair technicians. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: The buzz around Tampa Bay's net reached a desperate pitch Tuesday night as the Philadelphia Flyers, their goaltender pulled for a sixth attacker for the last 90 seconds, fought to tie Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Randy Johnson, 40, Hurls Perfect Game
description: Randy Johnson, who has been blazing pitches past blinking batters in both leagues since 1988, opened some more eyes last night. A 40-year-old left-hander for the Arizona Diamondbacks, Johnson retired all 27 batters he faced in pitching the 17th perfect game in major league history, beating the Braves, 2-0, in Atlanta.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: 7-Year Sentence For Obscene Calls
description: A man convicted of terrifying young girls with random telephone calls that threatened death if they did not submit to his sexual demands was sentenced to seven years in prison, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, announced yesterday. After his calls were electronically traced, the man, Philip N. Wald of Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to sexual abuse for a scheme in which he used prepaid phone cards to call numbers in Westchester. When a girl answered, Mr. Wald would tell her that if she did not perform certain telephone sex acts he would break into her home and kill her, the district attorney's office said. The office said he reached at least six girls ages 12 to 17. Thomas Crampton (NYT)

title: Youth Who Won Abuse Suit Is Held in Daughter's Killing
description: At 16, Yusimil Herrera won a suit against Florida's child welfare agency for churning her through foster homes where she said she was beaten, slapped, kicked and sexually abused from the time she was 2. At 19, Ms. Herrera, a plucky young woman with dark, thick curls, had not seen any of the $2.2 million jury award and had drifted in and out of homelessness.

title: Floyd Takes His Toys and Sends Cards Home
description: A big-league slugger strolled through the Toys ''R'' Us store in Times Square on Monday with his girlfriend and daughter, doing stretching exercises as he shopped. Cliff Floyd knew he must have been a strange sight.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Saturday about horses winning the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes only to lose the Belmont Stakes, and thus the Triple Crown, misstated part of the history of this phenomenon. In 2002 and 2003, for the first time in consecutive years, Triple Crown contenders failed to even place in the Belmont; it was not the first time contenders had lost outright two years in a row.

title: Two Comedies From Milne, Before He Dreamed of Pooh
description: Before there was Winnie-the-Pooh, even before there was Toad of Toad Hall, there were Carraway Pim and Oliver Blayds. In what is clearly a labor of love for the director Jonathan Bank, the Mint Theater Company is seeking to reintroduce New York audiences to A. A. Milne the playwright with spiffy new productions of ''Mr. Pim Passes By'' and ''The Truth About Blayds.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taxi Driver Released In Reported Rape
description: A taxi driver has been questioned and released in connection with the alleged rape of a 28-year-old woman in Manhattan over the weekend, the police said. The driver, whose identity was not released by the police, had been caught on a surveillance camera, a police official said, walking into the woman's apartment building in Lower Manhattan after dropping her off early on Sunday. A spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney's office, Barbara Thompson, said the office would not prosecute, because it was ''unable to establish the elements of a crime beyond a reasonable doubt.'' She did not say whether the office thought that the woman had consented to have sex. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Buick Field Forced to Focus on Accuracy
description: Although this year's Buick Classic will not have Tiger Woods, there will be no shortage of top players.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about immigrants who were refugees from torture overseas, and their reactions to photographs of Iraqi prisoners being abused by American soldiers, attributed a distinction incorrectly to the Center for Victims of Torture, in Minneapolis. Established in 1985, it is the oldest center in the United States for victims of torture. The world's oldest is the Rehabilitation and Research Center for Torture Victims, founded in Copenhagen in 1982.

title: New Creative Director For Chevrolet Account
description: One of the biggest, most important jobs in advertising -- creating campaigns for the Chevrolet division of General Motors at Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich. -- is changing hands. Bill Ludwig, the top creative executive on the account since 1981, is turning over the assignment to a longtime New York creative executive, Brent Bouchez.

title: Mayor's School Building Plan Is Assailed in Budget Hearings
description: The leaders of the City Council Finance and Education Committees sharply criticized the Bloomberg administration yesterday over its proposed $13.1 billion school construction plan, saying that the plan was not detailed enough and that the administration was not fighting hard enough in Albany for the money to pay for it.

title: Firm Names Tax Shelter Clients

title: The Curious Incident of the Boxes; A Tussle Over a Cache of Conan Doyle's Artifacts Ends With an Auction

But the auction this Wednesday of their contents, once belonging to Arthur Conan Doyle, the creator of Sherlock Holmes, has provoked another fight and a mystery almost worthy of Holmes himself.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Celebrates His 84th
description: Pope John Paul II turned 84, beaming as visitors sang ''Happy Birthday.'' He kept his regular schedule but set aside time for a cake with his closest aides. It was also the publication date for his latest book, ''Get Up, Let Us Go.'' In an open letter to John Paul, a group of 40 Swiss Roman Catholic theologians, priests and community leaders suggested that the ailing pope retire. ''These days, men and women live longer,'' said Xaver Pfister, a theologian and the spokesman for the group. ''When the custom of allowing the pope to stay in office until his death became prevalent, the situation was completely different.'' John Paul is to visit Switzerland on June 5, and the letter drew a sharp rebuke from the Bishop of Basel, Kurt Koch.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Flat TV Screens

With an expected annual capacity of 3 million displays, the plant would triple Matsushita's annual capacity for plasma display production to 4.5 million. The Plasma Display Panel Company, in which Matsushita holds a 75 percent stake, plans to begin production at the plant near Osaka, in November 2005. Todd Zaun (NYT)
