title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LARKIN, FRANK YOAKUM
description: LARKIN--Frank Yoakum. Of Greenwich, CT & New York City. Beloved husband of June Noble Larkin, died on Sunday, May 16, 2004, in Greenwich, CT, of heart failure. He was a former Executive Vice President of The Putnam Trust Company of Greenwich, and was a graduate of Princeton University, Fordham University School of Law, and served as a Captain in The U.S. Army during World War II. He was a former Chairman of the Board of Greenwich Academy and former President of the Board of Greenwich Hospital. An ardent naturalist and ornithologist since childhood, he served as a Trustee of the Wildlife Conservation Society since 1973, and became a Life Trustee in 2000. In recognition of his life-long commitment to conservation he was awarded the Society's highest honor, its Gold Medal, which was inscribed ''Frank Y. Larkin-1998-His unique Understanding and Far-ranging Knowledge of Wild Creatures Provides a Special Leadership for us All.'' He also served as a Trustee of the American Museum of Natural History from 1974 to 2001, and became an Honorary Trustee in 2001. In addition, the Museum's education center, the Discovery Room, is named in his honor. As Vice Chairman of the Edward John Noble Foundation, and as President of the St. Catherine's Island Foundation, he stewarded the Foundation's environmental funding programs, focussing efforts on scientific research, education, and the preservation of endangered species. Brother of Mrs. Robert C. Wilson, New York City, father of Barbara Franklin, Washington D.C., Frank Larkin, Wooster, Ohio, Patricia Larkin, Washington D.C., and Edith Hubbell, Norwich, VT. Stepfather of Noble Smith, David Smith, Jeremy Smith, Bradford Smith. Grandfather of Jennifer Del Guercio, Lisa Topchik, John F. Franklin III, Sarah, Jay, and Andrew Hubbell. Great grandfather of Sara Topchik. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday June 3, 2004, at 6 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History. Contributions may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History, or the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Admiral Convicted In Sub Deaths
description: A Russian admiral was convicted of negligence and carelessness in causing the death of nine sailors in the sinking of a decommissioned nuclear submarine in the Barents Sea last August. The admiral, Gennady Suchkov, left, was given a suspended sentence of four years. He was dismissed as commander of Russia's Northern Fleet after the rusting 40-year-old submarine, the K-159, sank as it was being towed to a scrap yard. Former Northern Fleet commanders told Russian television that the conviction was politically motivated. The sinking came three years after another submarine disaster in the same waters killed all 118 crew members. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sammy To Acquire Sega For $1.45 Billion

The new company would have sales of about 440 billion yen ($3.86 billion) a year. Sammy was already the largest Sega shareholder, with a 22 percent stake. Sammy's chief executive, Hajime Satomi, will lead the combined company. Until two years ago, Sega suffered a long streak of losses as it got out of the home game machine business so that it could focus on developing game software and arcade machines. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABERBACH, JULIAN J.
description: ABERBACH--Julian J., 95, of New York City, New York, Southampton, New York, Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of 50 years of Anne Marie Aberbach, loving father of Belinda Aberbach Stevenson Agar, loving grandfather of Vanessa Stevenson, Elie Stevenson, Max Stevenson, Ezra Stevenson and Chloe Agar, passed away of heart failure in New York City on Monday, May 17, 2004. Julian J. Aberbach was one of the most respected names in American music publishing as well as music publishing around the world. Having emigrated to America from Austria, he served in WWII in the U.S. Army receiving his commission as Second Lieutenant and served as a multilingual liaison with officers of the Free French. He became interested in country music and developed a major music publishing enterprise along with his brother Joachim Jean Aberbach. Major names in Nashville music such as Red Foley, Ernest Tubb, Johnny Cash, Eddie Arnold, Bill Monroe, Left Frizzel and Hank Snow accounted for close to 75% of Hill and Range Songs' country music hits. One of the most significant publishing deals ever made by the Aberbachs was the acquisition of the exclusive publishing rights to the music of Elvis Presley in 1955. By the early 1970's the Aberbach business had become a worldwide music force. Julian Aberbach was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame on June 15, 2000. Julian and Jean Aberbach went on to develop as major figures in the art world as owners of the Aberbach Fine Art Gallery in New York City. He lost his brother in 1992. Additionally, Mr. Aberbach received the Legion of Honor in June 2003 in recognition of his unique contribution to French culture. He was dearly loved and he will be greatly missed. Services will be held at the Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, NYC, at 10 A.M. on Wednesday, May 19, 2004. Interment will follow at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY.

Mr. Spadoni, the head of Triumph Capital Group of Boston, was convicted of offering the bribe to Mr. Silvester in exchange for the right to manage Connecticut's pension fund. Mr. Spadoni contends that the jury was misled when prosecutors said Mr. Silvester had pleaded guilty to accepting a bribe. title: MOSCOW: FABERG DISPLAY
description: The highlights of the Malcolm Forbes Faberg collection, purchased for well over $90 million by the billionaire Viktor Vekselberg were unveiled yesterday in the Kremlin. Mr. Vekselberg, an oil and aluminum tycoon with a fortune estimated at $5.9 billion who placed third in the list of wealthiest Russians released by the Russian edition of Forbes magazine last week, bought nine imperial Easter eggs and about 180 other Faberg works earlier this year. His purchase pre-empted their auction at Sotheby's. Speaking at a news conference in the Patriarchs Palace surrounded by glass cases displaying the glittering jewel-encrusted eggs including the Coronation Egg, below left, representatives of Mr. Vekselberg's Link of Ages Foundation said they are in negotiations for two more major purchases. They refused to specify what they might be, beyond describing them as items taken out of Russia after the revolution. They may be even more significant than the first purchase, said Vladimir Voronchenko, chairman of the foundation. The foundation's spokesman said that one of the deals is being negotiated in the United States. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Reports Of Apartheid Party's End
description: Leaders of the New National Party, the successor to the National Party that governed South Africa during decades of apartheid, scheduled a meeting to discuss ''future plans'' amid reports that it might be disbanded. The Cape Town newspaper Die Burger reported that party executives in Free State Province would urge that the party fold, but the group's national spokeswoman said that ''immediate disbanding'' was not an option. The New National Party collected just 1.7 percent of the vote in last month's national election, down from 6.9 in the previous vote, in 1999, and 20.4 percent in 1994, when it was still the National Party. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Posts $373.3 Million Profit
description: Applied Materials, the world's biggest maker of semiconductor-production equipment, said yesterday that it had net income of $373.3 million in its fiscal second quarter as it increased sales to chip makers. Net income was 22 cents a share, in contrast to a year-earlier loss of 4 cents a share, or $62.1 million. Results beat the average 19 cents forecast by 27 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Sales in the quarter that ended May 2 rose to $2.02 billion, the company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said. Applied is forecast by analysts to show its first annual sales increase since 2000 as chip makers buy machines to increase output of semiconductors used in products ranging from mainframe computers to cellphones. Applied Materials shares rose 40 cents, to $18.85.

title: Sonia Gandhi Steps Aside
description: Sonia Gandhi's decision yesterday to pass up her chance to become India's next prime minister was as sensible as it was unexpected. Only a day earlier, she had reluctantly bowed to pressure from senior Congress Party members to accept the job. But even after six years of steady campaigning to restore the Congress Party's political fortunes, she never warmed to life in the public spotlight. It surely did not help that the opposition Hindu nationalist politicians were shamelessly making an issue of Mrs. Gandhi's Italian birth, which could have further complicated the challenge of assembling a stable and politically coherent governing coalition.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Apple Creates iPod Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. has quietly reorganized its product development activities, creating a new division for its fast-selling iPod digital music players. Jon Rubinstein, an Apple senior vice president who has headed hardware engineering for Apple, will lead the new division. As part of the reorganization, Timothy D. Cook, an Apple executive vice president who has led Apple's worldwide sales and operations, will be in charge of a newly organized Macintosh division. Tim Bucher, currently in charge of Macintosh system development, will lead Macintosh hardware engineering. The reorganization was announced Monday in a companywide internal e-mail message sent by Apple's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs. The shift reflects Apple's intention to transform its successful iPod into a broader consumer products line, according to a person close to the reorganization. The company made the shift in an effort to improve its ability to focus resources more appropriately, according to an Apple spokeswoman. John Markoff (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Brewer's Profit Slips
description: Lion Nathan, a brewer and winemaker, reported that net income in the first half of the year fell 24 percent, to 84 million Australian dollars ($58 million), despite a 6 percent increase in sales. The chief executive, Gordon M. Cairns, said the company had increased the volume of its beer sales in China by 63 percent but it still had a loss there. The company also took a charge of 34 million Australian dollars in connection with the sale of unprofitable pubs and hotels in Victoria state. Excluding the write-down, Lion Nathan's profit rose 7 percent. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Boston Scientific Releases Stent Sales Figures
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, the world's largest maker of stents to keep open blood vessels that lead to and from the heart, said yesterday that it had sold about $78 million of its Taxus drug-coated version of the device in the first two weeks of May in the United States. Boston Scientific said in February that it expected 2004 worldwide coated-stent sales would be $1.7 billion to $2.2 billion, up from $195 million in 2003. The company, which is based in Natick, Mass., won approval on March 4 to sell its Taxus product in the United States and it began selling it on March 8. The latest sales extend the device to all 1,200 United States customer accounts that Boston Scientific had planned to reach, a Morgan Stanley analyst, Glenn Reicin, said in a note to investors. The company said that it had overtaken Johnson & Johnson as the nation's No.1 stent maker. Johnson & Johnson does not provide weekly sales figures. Shares of Boston Scientific fell 65 cents, to $38.98. Johnson & Johnson shares fell 7 cents, to $54.63.

description: Army officials in Iraq responded late last year to a Red Cross report of abuses at Abu Ghraib prison by trying to curtail the international agency's spot inspections of the prison, a senior Army officer who served in Iraq said Tuesday.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Escapes on Friday about motorcycling and another last Oct. 3 included comments on products by people who had undisclosed business ties to them. In the Friday article, about motorcyclists who wear brightly colored clothes for safety, Andy Goldfine, identified as a sales manager from Duluth, Minn., discussed the advantages of a bright lime-yellow Aerostitch jacket. A spokesman for Aerostitch says Mr. Goldfine is its sole owner. The October article, about customized motorcycles, identified Marjorie Charney as a Boston-based marketing consultant and the owner of a modified BMW R1100S motorcycle. She says she is a market sales operations manager for BMW Motorcycles.

title: Deal Ends Impasse Over Judicial Nominees
description: Just in time for the high political season, the White House and Senate Democrats struck a deal on Tuesday that ends for now the lengthy impasse over President Bush's judicial nominees.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Massachusetts: Mail Deliveries Are Briefly Suspended
description: The United States Postal Service briefly suspended delivery at the Bromley-Heath housing project in Boston after a recent spate of violence. Officials said a daylight shooting on Monday and a murder last week made the housing project unsafe for two postal carriers who deliver mail to 550 homes there. The Postal Service agreed to resume service after the police and local officials vowed to increase security and patrols. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Amendment On Same-Sex Marriage
description: The House of Representatives and Senate each passed proposed amendments to the state Constitution to ban same-sex marriage and the recognition of such marriages performed in other states. The bills are slightly different, and the two houses have to agree on a version to send to the voters for a referendum in the fall. The Human Rights Campaign, a group that advocates gay marriage, said five states face antimarriage amendment ballot measures this year: Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, Missouri and Utah. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit At Airline
description: Air France said it earned 13 million euros ($15.5 million) in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of 103 million euros a year earlier, helped by increased business on its longer flights and by reduced costs. The airline said its profit for the year fell to 93 million euros ($111 million), from 120 million euros a year earlier, as its operations were hit by severe acute respiratory syndrome and a strike by air traffic controllers. Air France, which recently agreed to acquire KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, will increase profit substantially this year if ticket prices are stable, the chief executive, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, above, said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Stake
description: PCCW, the telecommunications holding company, said that it was negotiating the sale of an equity stake in its main subsidiary PCCW-HKT Telephone, to a Chinese company in what would be one of the largest mainland investments yet in Hong Kong. The subsidiary is the primary operator of fixed-line telephone services in Hong Kong. PCCW is negotiating with the government-controlled China Network Communications Group, a large provider of fixed-line services in China. A deal appears to be weeks away, and PCCW did not disclose how large a stake it might sell or for how much. An alliance with a big mainland phone company could help PCCW enter the Chinese market. Mainland companies have taken only a few large stakes until now in Hong Kong companies, notably Citic Pacific's 25.7 percent holding in Cathay Pacific Airways. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Impeachment Proceedings To Continue
description: Gov. Brad Henry called a special session of the Legislature to allow a committee weighing impeachment proceedings against the state insurance commissioner, Carroll Fisher, to continue its work. The special panel could not otherwise meet beyond the Legislature's May 28 adjournment. Mr. Fisher, 64 and a Democrat, is charged with diverting more than $40,000 in state money to the bank account of an aide. The legislative committee is also studying Mr. Fisher's acceptance of furniture and artwork for his office from companies regulated by his department. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: SUMMER MUSIC
description: The SummerStage series in Central Park opens its 19th season tonight with a benefit concert by the Strokes, and will run through Sept. 19 with more than 30 events, including concerts, film screenings, dance performances and readings, most of them free, the City Parks Foundation announced yesterday. Among the highlights of the series, held in the park's Rumsey Playfield, are the British hip-hip duo Floetry on June 19; ''Blind Lemon Blues,'' a musical revue based on the life of Blind Lemon Jefferson, on July 16; the Spanish flamenco-hip-hop group Ojos de Brujo, with the local Latin group Si-Se, on July 25; a centennial tribute to George Balanchine on July 27 and 28; the Icelandic groups Vinyl and Jaguar, on July 31; readings by Toni Morrison and Edward P. Jones on Aug. 5, and Burning Spear with the New Birth Brass Band on Sept. 19. The City Parks Foundation also announced its series of 30 free concerts in all five boroughs, and the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, on Aug. 21 and 22 in Marcus Garvey Park and Tompkins Square Park, with Jimmy Heath, Kenny Garrett and Terri Lyne Carrington. BEN SISARIO

title: Increasingly, African-Americans Take Flight to Private Schools
description: Early on weekday mornings, as Lesley-Anne Jones implores her three sons to button their shirts and knot their ties and tie their dress shoes, they ask why they can't attend her school. If Ms. Jones wanted to be factual about it, she could say that the family lives just outside the boundary for Public School 158 in the East New York section of Brooklyn, where she teaches fifth grade. Instead, she tells them the deeper truth. ''I'm your mother, and I know what's good for you,'' she explains. ''And the public school won't be.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 11 Killed In Chechen Ambushes
description: Chechen rebels ambushed Russian military vehicles and killed at least 11 Russian servicemen and pro-Moscow Chechen policemen, Russian news agencies reported. The attack was the worst since the May 9 bombing that killed the Moscow-backed president of Chechnya, Akhmad Kadyrov, in Grozny, the capital. Russian television continues to report on the reconstruction of the region, where war has been waged on and off since 1994, when Russia first sent its forces in, but even President Vladimir V. Putin admitted after an aerial tour of the city last week that Grozny looked horrible. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Rocket Launcher Found In Station

Ms. Green said it had been used and did not represent an immediate danger to the public. The F.B.I. is investigating, she said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Internet Dissident Goes On Trial
description: The secret trial of an Internet dissident on subversion charges began, but his lawyer was unable to appear because government officials gave too short notice for the proceeding, a human rights group reported. The defendant, Du Daobin, is a civil servant who wrote online about politics and also criticized the government's arrest of other Internet writers. More than 100 lawyers, intellectuals and others have signed an online petition on Mr. Du's behalf, urging the government to define clearly the country's anti-subversion law. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bethpage: Man Arrested In Suspected Rape
description: A man was arrested last night for what the police said was the rape of a 9-year-old girl on a Long Island Rail Road train. The man was on a westbound train that had reached Bethpage when an off-duty sergeant of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority police called other officers after seeing what she said was the rape of the girl, who is believed to be the man's niece. The man, the girl and her 5-year-old brother were taken off the train. The man was arrested and the girl was taken to Nassau County Medical Center for evaluation, said Tom Kelly, an M.T.A. spokesman. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: LONDON, May 19  Prime Minister Tony Blair was pelted on the back by a ball of purple-colored flour today as he stood in the House of Commons, an episode that raised serious questions about security at Westminster.

title: SHELL NOMINATES EXECUTIVE AS A MANAGING DIRECTOR

If approved, Ms. Cook will take responsibility for Shell's gas and power division from Malcolm Brinded, who has been running the group's exploration and production group since its leader was ousted. description: A film review of ''Troy'' in Weekend on Friday misstated the site of its world premiere. It was Berlin; Cannes was the site of the French premiere.

title: Big Project Moves Forward on One-Acre Site
description: State and city officials are putting together more than $370 million in tax-exempt financing for a project in Lower Manhattan that is remarkable for the mix of uses on a single acre: an apartment tower, a business school, a dormitory, an art gallery, a hospital, a parking garage and a good-size store.

title: Cold Cuts, Haircuts And Hip-Hop; An Alternative to Music Stores: CD's at Bodegas and Barbershops
description: Some ambitious Latino hip-hop, dance and rock bands think they have found an alternative to selling their discs at music megastores or on the Internet: the corner bodega and the local barbershop.

title: THEATER: OBIE AWARDS
description: The Craig Lucas political drama ''Small Tragedy'' won an Obie Award for best American play of the season in a ceremony at Webster Hall in the East Village on Monday night. The drama, about an amateur theater troupe mounting a production of ''Oedipus Rex,'' also won an award for its ensemble of actors. Other actors who won awards are Viola Davis (''Intimate Apparel''), Lisa Emery (''Iron''), Jayne Houdyshell (''Well''), Sarah Jones (''Bridge & Tunnel''), Jefferson Mays (''I Am My Own Wife''), Zilah Mendoza (''Living Out''), Maude Mitchell (''Mabou Mines Dollhouse''), Brian F. O'Byrne (''Frozen''), Tonya Pinkins (''Caroline, or Change''), Lili Taylor (''Aunt Dan and Lemon'') and the acting company of ''Bug.'' Special citations were awarded to several artists and companies, including SoHo Rep for ''Molly's Dream,'' Martin Moran for ''The Tricky Part,'' Kyle Jarrow and Alex Timbers for ''A Very Merry Unauthorized Children's Scientology Pageant'' and George C. Wolfe for his stewardship of the Public Theater. Mark Russell, the departing artistic director of P.S. 122, won a lifetime achievement award. The Obie Awards, which honor Off Broadway theater, have been presented by The Village Voice since 1956. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Bush Panel Will Study Great Lakes Cleanup
description: President Bush created a task force on Tuesday to coordinate the federal government's policies toward the Great Lakes. He said the more than 140 federal programs dealing with Great Lakes issues, which are overseen by 10 government agencies, needed ''more systematic collaboration and better integration.''

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Schizophrenic Is Executed
description: Kelsey Patterson, a schizophrenic, was executed by lethal injection at a state prison in Huntsville after Gov. Rick Perry rejected a recommendation for clemency by the Texas pardons board and the United States Supreme Court refused to intercede. Mr. Patterson, 50, was sentenced to death for the murders of a Palestine, Tex., businessman and his secretary in 1992. Mr. Patterson's arrest record included four assaults before the killings, but because he was found to be psychotic he was sent to mental hospitals and later released. The Supreme Court has forbidden executing mentally retarded convicts but not mentally ill people who understand why they were sentenced. Mr. Patterson's lawyers contended that he was delusional. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Giuliani Mounts Spirited Defense of City's Response to 9/11
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a calm but spirited defense today of the role played by firefighters, the police, and their leaders after the attacks on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Richard Strong Is Not Expected to Face Criminal Changes
description: Richard S. Strong will not face criminal charges from the New York attorney general for rapid trades he made in and out of mutual funds, people briefed on the talks said last night.

title: Six Questions for Iran: Transcript
description: NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF. The first question is basic: Was the Islamic revolution a mistake? And in talking to Iranians today I've been amazed by the number who keep saying, yes, it was a mistake. Almost nobody really seems to have anything very nice to say about the revolution. IN THE TEAHOUSE KRISTOF. In Isfahan there is a lovely, lovely teahouse along the river right under the bridge and just a fabulous place. And I sat down and talked with a number of people there. One middle-age man was sympathetic in some ways to the revolution, but he acknowledged like everybody else that it had gone deeply astray. He wanted Iran to be united with the rest of the world again. IRANIAN MAN (captions). We'll never be able to go back to the time before the revolution in 1979. But the existing government should let people have a more relaxed and freer lifestyle. People should be free. But, the government is the government. The ideal would be to return to the root of it. The days right after the revolution. IN THE FIELDS KRISTOF. I had the idea that people in rural areas would be more conservative and maybe more supportive of the regime. And sure enough, they were very conservative socially. Initially, when I asked about the government they said: Oh, yeah, everything's great. IRANIAN MAN. [speaking Farsi] KRISTOF. It took about five minutes for them to say: Well, of course things were even better under the Shah. IRANIAN MAN (captions). If it were possible, I'd go back to the way things were before the revolution. Back then people were honest. They didn't have to pretend that they were religious. It wasn't as corrupt. KRISTOF. And it turned out that every one of them thought that things had really gone fundamentally downhill since the Islamic revolution. North of Isfahan we drove off the main road and spoke to a couple of farmers. And we asked them whether the revolution had been a, you know, a good idea or a mistake. And I was surprised by just how bluntly they said that it had been a mistake. IRANIAN MAN (captions). I hear the elders say that there is a chance that the Shah's son could return. Life in the villages was much better under the Shah. More attention needs to be paid to the needs of the villages and to the concerns of young people. KRISTOF. That question of the legitimacy of the revolution I think is something that fundamentally goes to the very nature of the regime today. IN THE MOSQUE KRISTOF. The one place in Iran where you would expect the Iranian revolution to be really cherished is the religious capital of Qom. In Qom, I sat down in the office of Ayatollah Montazeri, who's a grand ayatollah, one of the very leading clerics of Shia Islam. He was one of the architects of the Iranian revolution. For a long time he was designated to be the successor of Ayatollah Khomeini and the supreme leader of Iran. But these days he was just withering in his criticism. KRISTOF. What is the status of the Islamic revolution now, the health of it? Is it in good health? Is it sick? And if it's sick, is it terminally ill? AYATOLLAH MONTAZERI (captions). The full freedom in which all people participate in a democratic process has not been achieved. If the demands that the people made at the time of the revolution are not achieved, then it is possible that people will start shouting those demands again. Since the trend in the world today is not one of force and imposing things on people, you cannot force people to have religion. Either officials change their methods and give freedom to the people and stop fixing the elections, or the people will rise up once again in revolution. STILL THE GREAT SATAN? KRISTOF. So is America the great Satan? I've been asking Iranians that. And it's strange being an American in Iran. There are so few of us. And the propaganda is unrelentingly negative. The old U.S. embassy is now called the den of spies. And it's surrounded by vicious murals of the U.S. But everywhere you go people are incredibly friendly to you. I mean there is much more pro-Americanism evident in Iran than in just about any country you could possibly go to. Maybe most of all when you talk to Iranians about the slogans like ``Death to America,'' they're almost a little embarrassed by them. It's like if people ask America about our policies toward the Indians 200 or 300 years ago, there's just a sense that belongs to a very distant past, they're not responsible for it, that they don't want to be tied to that policy. Indeed, 60 percent of Iranians were born after the Iranian revolution. And for them America's really been something missing in their lives. It hasn't been an evil force. It's just been kind of a nonentity. DEATH TO AMERICA KRISTOF. There's another huge mural of the American flag with missiles for the stripes. And right in front of it I stopped some pedestrians and talked to them about their attitudes toward the U.S. And people would clearly like to have better relations with America. IRANIAN MAN (captions). I have no hard feelings toward the United States and I like Americans, but when President Bush says we're a wild country, that's very disrespectful. We have 5,000 years of history. It's offensive when that isn't respected. How much civilization do you have? KRISTOF. There's a real prickliness to the idea of being bullied by America or told what to do by America or told by the U.S.: Oh, you can't have nuclear weapons. That goes over very, very poorly. ADMIRATION FOR AMERICA KRISTOF. On the Iranian weekend, which is a Thursday and Friday, I went out to the hills outside of Tehran where people go hiking and spoke to a number of people. A 34-year-old woman, she emphasized that, you know, people now have their own sources of information. That times have changed and the government no longer has a monopoly on information. She said, you know, we go to the Internet. We watch satellite TV. And I think that that is very much behind the admiration for America. SECOND-CLASS CITIZENS. KRISTOF. Can women be equal in Iran? There's no question that women are second-class citizens right now in a lot of ways, but maybe not as much as Americans think. We see Iranian women swathed in black and we think that they must be weak and trod upon all the time. And yet underneath that chador they can be pretty strong. And the thing that Americans always comment on is the clothing requirements. But when you talk to Iranian women about that, some chafe at that clothing requirement, but there are an awful lot who say that those rules don't really make a difference. They would always cover their hair anyway anytime they went out. In Isfahan I talked to a bunch of students who, as part of the school requirement, had to wear a chador. And there were some who were frustrated by the clothing requirement. But they also said that they really had more serious issues. I mean that they were concerned by other areas of inequality like job opportunities. And that Americans shouldn't be quite so preoccupied about clothing requirements. I'm not entirely sure I buy that, partly because I think the degree to which you have a few mullahs imposing their clothing taste on the entire nation, in such an intimate way determining what every woman does every day every time she goes out, that seems to me symbolic of the whole fundamental question of the Islamic revolution. Which is to what extent can a very few people impose their religious and social beliefs on an entire nation? PLAYING TOGETHER. KRISTOF. In Tehran, on a beautiful weekend day, I went to a park and there was a basketball court. And I was struck by the way young women and young men were playing basketball together. And the women were playing in full Islamic dress. They had their manteau and their head scarves on. But they'd take a jump shot and, bam, off would come the head scarf. And they'd play for 10-20 seconds and then they'd finally readjust it. And that is an issue for the morals police. They do periodically go and say: Hey, men and women shouldn't be playing together - break it up. But they tend to be more concerned in terms of clothing requirements about the men who wear shorts and who sometimes show their knees. One of the reassuring things about watching those people play basketball was that these young men and young women play together very naturally. And, you know, the men pass to the women, the women grab the rebounds, they play competitively. And it was a real contrast to the segregated society of Iran. You get some feeling of hope that increasingly men and women are able to really work together and cooperate and march through life together in a way that had not been true in the past. LASTEST FASHION TREND KRISTOF. One of the best indexes of change for women's dress in Iran is the clothing sold in the bazaars. In the Tehran bazaar I talked to a couple of people who were selling head scarves for women. And they said that the styles today are so different from what was permitted just a few years ago. And they showed the fashionable scarves today that instead of concealing women's hair and deadening any sex appeal are just enhancing it. In the Southern city of Shiraz I spoke to a seller of manteau, the outer garments that women are supposed to wear over their clothes. And manteau have just been transformed by the market and by what young people want. Now, of course, women are wearing jeans or other clothes underneath. Ayatollah Khomeini would just be rolling in his grave if he realized that people are now using Islamic dress to make women look sexier rather than to smother their sexuality. IRAN'S BABY BOOMERS KRISTOF. One of the central questions about Iran's future is whether baby boomers will change Iran in the same way that they changed America in the 1960's. Ayatollah Khomeini ordered Iranians to have more children after the Iranian revolution. And now he's kind of getting his comeuppance because there are 18 million young Iranians between the age of 15 and 25. And already you can see the way they're transforming social mores in Iran. A lot of what we associate with Iran isn't coming from the government. It's deeply embedded in the culture. And I mean nothing is more central to that notion than segregation of young men and young women. And boy, that is changing quickly. Young people are holding hands. They're just living a very different life - and scandalizing their parents while they're at it. AN ABSENCE OF FUN. KRISTOF. I went one evening to a shopping center in northern Tehran, which is a magnet for young people on dates. I mean of course the whole notion of dates is a very new idea. In speaking to some of these young couples, what really struck me was that what they yearned for wasn't so much democracy and a sense of political changes or a different kind of government or even necessarily freedom of speech, although I think all those things are important to them. But what they really want above all else is fun. One young woman really left an impression on me. Because she was 20 years old and she was talking about her frustrations. And she said: We want fun. There's no joy here. And I said: Look at you. You're showing your hair through a see-through scarf. You're sitting next to your boyfriend. You're wearing nail polish. And you're not being flogged. I mean you're a living demonstration about all the change and progress that have happened. And she answered that: I don't compare myself with 10 years ago. I compare myself to what I could have and don't. And I think that's a very frightening message for Iran's leadership. And I think that that lack of fun is really causing tremendous dissatisfaction with the regime itself. LONGING FOR KHOMEINI KRISTOF. I've asked a lot of people what they think about Khomeini. And I've been a little bit surprised by the way young people, for example, actually have positive views about Ayatollah Khomeini, who they don't really remember. But I say how can you - you know, if you're against this regime, which has really moderated since Khomeini's time, then how can you be in favor of Khomeini? And they say: Oh, Ayatollah Khomeini was very honest. He was different. He was willing to change. He was open-minded. So they've managed in a very interesting way to still honor the principle of the revolution in some cases and to honor the ideal of Ayatollah Khomeini, while regarding the present rulers as betrayers of that revolution. DOES IRAN HURT ISLAM? KRISTOF. One of the most sensitive and controversial questions that I've been asking people about: Is the Islamic Republic hurting Islam? Strangely, an awful lot of young Iranians say that it is. One young man that I met in Tehran, he said that the Islamic regime is so unpopular that it has made Islam unpopular as well. He apologized for having a beard. And he was embarrassed by it because beards are associated with the government and with these hard-line ayatollahs. IRANIAN MAN (captions). I'm sorry, I've been extremely busy and I haven't had the opportunity to shave. I don't want you to think that I'm a religious fanatic. KRISTOF. Even Grand Ayatollah Montazeri, who's one of the most senior clerics in the Shiite world, an architect of the Iranian revolution, he expressed precisely that concern. KRISTOF. Do you fear that all those frustrations are turning young people away from Islam itself and from the idea of clerical rule rather than just from this particular regime? AYATOLLAH MONTAZERI (captions). All this repression happening here is being done in the name of Islam. And the young people are being turned off to Islam because of it. The style of the gentlemen running the country has caused this. HYPOCRISY OF THE REPUBLIC KRISTOF. I spoke in the countryside to an old shepherd who can't even walk after his sheep. He sits on his donkey all day, every day, rain or shine and fights off the wolves. And he's very conservative and deeply Muslim, deeply faithful to Islam. But he was not a supporter of the Islamic revolution as I expected. And he said that it had been very disappointing and it had been a mistake. It had been better under the Shah. And his reasoning was that public order and public behavior had actually gone downhill. IRANIAN MAN (captions). I'm almost dead, so it doesn't matter what I think. All I need is two meters of earth to rest in. The mullahs aren't the problem. It's the people who are the problem. People today lie, cheat and steal. It was better under the Shah. KRISTOF. It used to be that if you didn't believe in strict Islam then you wouldn't wear Islamic dress. But now everybody does. And there's a sense that just the way people live is all for show. WILLING TO CHANGE KRISTOF. The mullahs naturally reject this interpretation that the Islamic revolution has been bad for Islam. I spoke to a young mullah and he said that he's not troubled by the fact young women are trying to show off more hair or wear body-hugging manteaus kind of thing. IRANIAN MAN (captions). All over the world there are religious questions, debate and disagreements. Young people will do things that young people do, like date and fall in love. You shouldn't take their behavior as a rejection of religion or the government. KRISTOF. In a lot of ways I think he's right. I think that the young people who do push the envelope in the way they dress, in the way they behave, they don't see themselves as going against Islam. Overwhelmingly I think they really want to be good Muslims. They just don't think that to be good Muslims they have to like this regime or wear black all the time. AN ANCIENT SUPERPOWER KRISTOF. Two thousand five hundred years ago the Persian empire was the superpower of its day. Now Iran is a dinky little country deeply frustrated by its isolation in the world. So the question is can Iran come back in from the cold? The Persian empire that Persepolis represents is very important I think in understanding Iran today. There's tremendous pride in the Persian past. And also a frustration at Iran's place in the world today. I mean how can it be that a country that once dominated much of the world is now this weak, poor power that has very tense relations with most of the world? That creates I think a lot of problems for the leadership today because of the expectations that the leaders can never meet. It's a comparison that they'll always fall short on. It also creates problems for the West because we have to deal with Iran in a way that won't inflame that sense of patriotism. In talking to young Iranians you constantly feel that prickliness, that sense of, Hey, who are you to bully Iran? Why are you guys telling us what to do? LUST FOR THE BOMB KRISTOF. The most sensitive area of all in Iran-U.S. relations in the coming months and years may well be the question of nuclear weapons. There is growing evidence that Iran is going all out to build nuclear weapons. There's been abundant evidence that has emerged that Iran's nuclear program is much more advanced than we thought, and that it might be able to build its first nuclear weapon as early as by the end of next year. The idea of Iran's rulers, who have frankly gotten away with murder through terrorism, having nuclear weapons is very frightening. So what should the U.S. do in terms of policy toward Iran? I think the greatest danger is that hard-liners in the U.S. will end up bolstering it and rescuing the hard-liners in Iran, that if we push too hard that is exactly what the mullahs would hope for. That will create a burst of patriotism around them and will keep them in power and will just cut the legs out from under the reformers in Iran. But on the other hand the Bush administration is absolutely right that the nuclear issue is an important one and we have to raise proliferation. But I think that we can raise it without bolstering the hard-liners. Part of that involves communicating relentlessly with Iranians through the satellite television stations that are broadcast from Los Angeles. You know, we have to reach out constantly and make it very clear that our target is only the regime, and especially the regime's squandering the country's resources on a nuclear program that is backfiring and causing more poverty and isolation for the country. THE FUTURE OF IRAN KRISTOF. In the minds of the ayatollahs, the ultimate authority in Iran is the Koran. But in the hearts of Iranians it's probably poetry instead. Iranian poets are beloved by everybody and read constantly. And maybe nobody more than the poet Hafiz. There's a traditional sort of method of fortune-telling where a bird selects some lines from Hafiz and then you interpret them to tell you the future. And the question I asked was what is Iran's future? The bird chose lines of poetry that translated ``Flower next to me and wine in the hand and love is on the way.'' Well, if the future of Iran is about flowers and wine and love, then I don't think it's in the hands of the mullahs. I think it's in the hands of the poets and the people. The regime here is so bankrupt and exhausted that unless the U.S. inadvertently bolsters it I think we're much more likely to see a pro-American democracy in Iran well before we see one in Baghdad. These six questions are just a start for a much broader discussion that we need to have about Iran. To dig a little bit deeper I'd suggest you click on the resources box. If you want to read more columns on Iran or other subjects there's a columns link. To comment on them you can click on the forum link where people discuss and debate my columns. If you have some feedback we'd love to hear your feedback. I offer some reaction to the comments and some of the stories that don't quite make the column in my blog, ``Kristof Responds.'' For The New York Times, I'm Nicholas Kristof in Iran.

title: 'We Were Going to Evacuate the Building, Get Everybody Out ...'
description: Following are excerpts from the staff report on preliminary findings by the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks. A full text is at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Road Deaths Fall
description: The Transportation Ministry reported that road deaths dropped 21 percent last year with increased speed checks and alcohol tests. More than 5,700 people died in traffic accidents in 2003, down from more than 7,200 the year before. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: The Jewel Turns Down the Crown
description: So the mutiny is followed by the refusal of the crown. For six years, Sonia Gandhi -- the Italian-born leader of the Indian National Congress party, daughter-in-law of Indira Gandhi and widow of Rajiv Gandhi, both prime ministers -- had been in a bitter political struggle involving her foreign origin. Then, in her moment of triumph, after toppling the Hindu nationalist regime of Atal Bihari Vajpayee and his Bharatiya Janata Party, Mrs. Gandhi announced yesterday that she would forgo the office that was in her grasp.

title: New York's Olympic Bid
description: Champagne flowed yesterday as Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced that New York had joined Paris, London, Madrid and Moscow as a finalist for the 2012 Summer Olympics. If the city wants a shot at bringing out the bubbly again when the winner is announced in July 2005, it should quickly rethink its proposal to build a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Kerry Is Expected To Meet With Nader
description: Senator John Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, plans to meet Wednesday afternoon with Ralph Nader, whose independent bid for the White House has many Democrats worried about losing votes on their party's left flank.

title: This Is One Celebrity Chef You Won't Find on TV
description: Correction Appended

title: A Somali Author as Guide to a Dantean Inferno
description: ''I have been intellectually colonized for a number of years,'' Nuruddin Farah, who is sometimes called Somalia's first novelist, said with a smile in delicately accented English. Mr. Farah, who is balding, with tawny skin, and has one dark brown eye, the other blue-green, was wearing blue jeans in preparation for another plane trip on his book tour.

description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday about the success of conservative groups in shaping American politics referred incorrectly to a liberal political group financed by George Soros. It is America Coming Together, not Americans Come Together.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Man Gets Life For Two Killings
description: A Long Island man who admitted stabbing his girlfriend to death and strangling her 11-year-old son because he witnessed the crime was sentenced yesterday to life in prison. The man, Alex Casillas, 26, pleaded guilty in April to first- and second-degree murder charges in the deaths of Yesenia Lilly and her son, James. At yesterday's hearing, Judge James Hudson of Suffolk County Court said he would ensure that Mr. Casillas's sentence was as restrictive as possible, court officials said. After the killings, Mr. Casillas dumped the two bodies in an industrial zone and told family members that Ms. Lilly and her son had vanished. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Democrats Urge Bush To Act on Gasoline Prices
description: Seizing on record-high gas prices averaging more than $2 a gallon, Senator John Kerry and other Democrats on Tuesday made their most coordinated attack yet on President Bush's energy policy, saying he should immediately push OPEC to expand oil production.

title: Insurer Agrees to Buy Corporate Security Concern
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies, the giant insurance and financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $1.9 billion in cash for Kroll Inc., a leading corporate security business, as it sought to expand its fast-growing risk-consulting and advisory operation.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Aluminum Spinoff Planned
description: Alcan, the aluminum and packaging group based in Montreal, said it would spin off to shareholders the bulk of its rolled products business, creating one of the world's biggest producers of aluminum foil products. The new company, yet to be named, will have 10,000 employees and annual revenue of $6 billion. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Elvin Jones, Jazz Drummer With Coltrane, Dies at 76
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCHHORN, ALEXANDER
description: HIRSCHHORN -- Alexander. 86, Son of the late Rae and Bernard Hirschhorn, Justice of the Peace in Randolph Township, NJ, on May 18, 2004. He is survived by his brother Herbert Hirschhorn of Manhattan and three nieces, Nancy and her husband Craig Karlebach of Manhattan; Carol and her husband Saul Goodman and Lyn Cowan and grandniece Nicole.

title: Cleric Tells Fighters and Occupiers to Leave Sacred Cities
description: The country's most influential cleric called Tuesday for the withdrawal of all armies from two holy cities, Karbala and Najaf, in an effort to end days of bloody fighting and preserve the sanctity of Shiite shrines.

title: New York's Course To 2012 Olympics Takes Uphill Turn
description: New York advanced to the final stage of the selection process for the 2012 Summer Olympics yesterday when the executive board of the International Olympic Committee trimmed the nine candidates to a group of five cosmopolitan cities. But Paris emerged as the front-runner in a field that includes three other European capitals: London, Madrid and Moscow. The winning city will be named on July 6, 2005.

title: Trade Deal Opens Australia To U.S. Manufactured Goods
description: The United States and Australia signed a free trade agreement on Tuesday, and the Bush administration says it hopes Congress will pass the measure this summer.

title: Gasoline Hysteria
description: With the election season moving into full swing as Americans start thinking about their summer travel plans, it's sadly predictable that politicians will try to curry favor with voters by playing silly blame games and proposing simplistic quick fixes for rising gasoline prices, which are averaging more than $2 a gallon. A case in point is the demand made yesterday by 20 Senate Democrats that the government release as much as 60 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve over the next two months.

title: WASHINGTON POST BUYS SPANISH-LANGUAGE PAPER
description: The Washington Post Company, the owner of Newsweek magazine, acquired El Tiempo Latino, a weekly Spanish-language newspaper in the Washington, D.C., area. Terms were not disclosed. The company acquired it from the Farragut Media Group.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Manhattan; Bigger Home For Pfizer Takes Shape
description: Last June, a month after the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer announced that it would be adding 1,000 jobs to its Manhattan headquarters within a year and spending $400 million to buy and renovate office space, the company purchased the building at 685 Third Avenue as part of its expansion.

title: REMODELING AND TRACTOR SALES LIFT HOME DEPOT
description: Home Depot, the home-improvement chain, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 21 percent as the remodeling of older stores and demand for John Deere lawn tractors helped sales. The company raised its annual profit forecast. Net income increased to $1.1 billion, or 49 cents a share, from $907 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue in the quarter, which ended May 2, climbed 16 percent, to $17.6 billion.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Here Comes The Judge: Take Cover, Would-Be Idols
description: Simon Cowell, the imperious judge of Fox's call-in talent show ''American Idol,'' was raised just north of London, in a manor house called Abbots Mead. His father was on the board of the record company EMI; after graduating from high school, Mr. Cowell worked in the company's mailroom. He went on to create novelty musical acts of professional wrestlers, the Power Rangers and celebrities like David Hasselhoff. Mr. Cowell made pop stars, in other words, out of athletes, toys and actors.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about enthusiasm among Democrats for John McCain as a vice-presidential running mate for John Kerry misstated Senator McCain's age. He is 67, not 68.

title: Survey Finds More Corporate Attention to Climate Change
description: Many of the world's largest companies appear to be paying greater attention to the business risks and opportunities posed by global warming and climate change, according a group of institutional investors who will release their second annual survey on the subject today.

title: A Day of Pain, Detachment And Everything in Between
description: People wept and people seethed and people ruminated and people quibbled. This happened uptown and downtown and in Brooklyn and in Queens, at home and at work and on the street. People did what they normally did on a Tuesday in May, or at least most of them did, but they also did this.

title: Mustard Isn't So Yellow Anymore
description: WHEN Elie-Arnaud Denoix and his father, Louis, dusted off the family's recipe for moutarde violette -- mustard mixed with grape must -- in 1986, the only other person here in the Limousin region making this ancient preparation was ''one very old woman who just made a little bit,'' Elie-Arnaud Denoix said. ''We knew that when she died, that would be it for moutarde violette -- unless we started making it again,'' he said.

title: TIFFANY OPENING STORES DEVOTED TO PEARLS
description: Tiffany & Company said yesterday that it planned to open stores that would sell only pearls and pearl jewelry. It will open two stores, which will be called Iridesse, this year, and four in 2005. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Falls

Last December, expectations had climbed to 73.4 index points, a three-and-a-half year high. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMANN, STEVEN N.

Steven was a wellknown and respected men's fashion industry executive and leaves behind many colleagues and friends in both America and Europe. Services will be held at 11 AM, Friday, May 21, at Congregation Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th St., in New York. title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Bomb Scare Near Oympics Complex
description: Security concerns revived in Athens after the police foiled a bomb attack against a British car dealership near a major complex for the Olympic Games in August. The police said they blew up a suspicious box and its explosive contents in a controlled blast in the lot of a Land Rover dealership. Two anonymous callers had telephoned a string of newspapers to warn of the bomb. The incident came a week after an extremist group calling itself Revolutionary Struggle claimed responsibility for a bombing outside an Athens police station on May 5 to protest security measures for the Games that it said was turning Athens into a ''fortress.'' Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: 1929:Deadly Stampede : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: NEW YORK: A man and a woman, both as yet unidentified, were crushed to death in the Yankee Stadium this afternoon [May 19] beneath the feet of thousands of fans who staged a panicky rush for shelter under the grandstand when a sudden storm thundered out of the sky just after the Yankees had taken the field at the beginning of the sixth inning. Scores were injured. "Babe" Ruth rushed to the open bleacher in an effort the stem the wild rush for shelter. Fighting and pushing his way through the crowd he found the woman crushed beneath the trampling feet. He fought his way back to the field but the woman died in his arms before aid could arrive.

The Milan show dazzled with experimental projects like Quicnic, above, a modular cafe seating system by German design students, and projects from Front, a Swedish design team, including wallpaper gnawed by rats and a table eaten by beetle larvae (beautiful and not at all gross). The Brooklyn show, in its third year, had nothing quite so daring, but still shone with clean, clever and readily available products.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Justice Dept. Accuses Detroit Bank Of Bias In Lending
description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit against the Old Kent Financial Corporation and the Old Kent Bank of Detroit, accusing the bank of racial discrimination in its lending practices. The department said that Old Kent, owned by the Fifth Third Bank Corporation, had unlawfully avoided making business and residential loans in predominantly African-American neighborhoods and opened up a Detroit branch only after the department started an investigation of its lending in 2000. The Fifth Third Bank filed a settlement immediately, saying it would open three new Detroit branches and provide $3 million for a loan subsidy program in the city. Ben Lefebvre (NYT)

Members of the group boarded a ship in 2002 to protest what they said was an illegal shipment of mahogany from Brazil. Prosecutors had charged the group with violating an 1872 law meant to keep people from boarding ships to tempt sailors with promises of prostitutes and liquor. The judge ruled that the government had failed to prove that the law applied to what Greenpeace said was routine civil disobedience. Adam Liptak (NYT)

description: Cardinal Health, a drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Alaris Medical Systems for $1.62 billion. The price will be $22.35 a share, 18 percent more than Alaris's closing price on Tuesday. Alaris makes a computerized system that controls how much of a drug a patient receives intravenously. Cardinal, based in Dublin, Ohio, said it would assume $384 million in Alaris debt. Alaris, based in San Diego, employs 3,000 people and makes products in four plants in the United States and Europe. Cardinal does not expect any job cuts in the near term because the companies have complementary businesses, a spokesman said.

title: The Humble Laptop Tote Gets a Fashion Upgrade
description: If, as the old fashion saw goes, what separates humans from animals is the ability to accessorize, then it simply won't do to complement a Chanel suit with a humdrum black nylon computer case. For the laptop-toting woman who has everything but can accommodate more, Talene Reilly offers fashionable computer bags in exuberant purple wool tweed or pomegranate or lime cotton-polyester. Even the linings add fun to function, with purple flowers, aqua dots or Popsicle-bright stripes. But these bags don't rely on good looks alone: they have multifunctional pockets for power cords, discs and a cellphone.

title: In Appalachia, a Chinese Pastorale
description: THE historian William Howard Adams was concerned last week about his tree peonies. He has about 35 of them growing against a limestone outcropping in front of his Federal house at Hazelfield, his country place about 60 miles northwest of Washington. The long, cool spring had produced hundreds of buds, and in mid-April Mr. Adams suggested that I come see ''the grand performance.''

title: VISION FESTIVAL RECONVENES
description: The ninth annual Vision festival, an omnium-gatherum of musicians from the aesthetic outskirts of jazz as well as poets, dancers and visual artists, will open on Tuesday for a run through May 31 at the Center, in Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, 268 Mulberry Street at Prince Street. Still operating without a commercial sponsor and occupying only one large space, the festival has become a weeklong social hub for a certain kind of jazz-centric, post-hippie, Lower East Side culture. It has also become something like the un-JVC jazz festival. The 32-performance schedule includes such highlights as the Sun Ra Arkestra directed by Marshall Allen on May 25; a new trio led by the bassist Henry Grimes, above, who resurfaced last year after a long absence from performing, and including the pianist Marilyn Crispell, on May 26, and Matthew Shipp's trio and Amiri and Amina Baraka's Blue Ark on May 27. Details are at www.visionfestival.org, and advance tickets ($25 per night or $140 for a seven-day pass) may be purchased at Downtown Music Gallery. Information: (212) 473-0043. BEN RATLIFF

''One of the things we're going to be doing is making some decisions about what documents we really want to interview the governor about,'' said Representative Arthur J. O'Neill, the Republican co-chairman of the bipartisan 10-member committee. The committee is investigating the governor for his acceptance of gifts from state employees and contractors. This week, the committee issued a subpoena demanding that the governor testify at the hearings, but his lawyers have said they want the committee to clarify what it will ask Mr. Rowland before he decides whether to testify. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSON, JULES L.
description: GERSON--Jules L. On May 18, 2004 in Bal Harbour, FL at the age of 100. Born in Russia in 1903 he was the son of Rachel and Harry Garzick the oldest brother of eight. The family immigrated to New York where Jules became a self taught jeweler and founder of Goldstein & Gerson Jewelers and the Fiancee Ring Co. He was elected the president of the Jewelry Makers Union and eventually the president of the Jewelry Manufacturers Association. Loving husband of Sylvia Radler and the late Esther Lila Friedler. Predeceased by his son Martin Arnold Gerson. He leaves his loving daughter and son-in-law Harriette and Dr. Fred Schecter and his youngest sister Ida Altman. He was the adoring grandfather of Suzanne Schecter and Julianne Karsten (Russell) and the most recent lights of his life, great-grandsons Van and Calvin Karsten. How he will be missed. Services private. Contributions may be sent to Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach, FL & Miami Jewish Home for the Aged at Douglas Gardens.

title: NEW KENNEDY CENTER CHAIRMAN
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington announced yesterday that Stephen A. Schwarzman, president and chief executive of the Blackstone Group, a global investment and advisory concern in New York, had been named chairman. Mr. Schwarzman will assume his position immediately, the center said. He is on the board of the New York City Ballet, the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the New York Public Library; Mr. Schwarzman is also a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and has been an adjunct professor at Yale School of Management. He succeeds James A. Johnson, who stepped down in January. Mr. Johnson played a leading role in the center's $650 million project to design two new buildings and a sweeping pedestrian plaza and fountain that will link it to the national monuments around it. The new buildings are to have three large rehearsal halls, office space for the center's tenants, including the Washington Opera, and classrooms and exhibition space for its annual arts education program. Mr. Schwarzman will have to pick up where Mr. Johnson left off, raising money for the effort. Congress authorized $400 million, but the center is seeking to raise the estimated $250 million needed for the rest of the decade-long project. JOHN FILES

Bart Bettencourt, a Brooklyn furniture designer and cabinetmaker, makes refined pieces in laminated bamboo. ''I use environmentally sustainable materials but make them look elegant by using simple geometry and clean lines,'' he said. The dining chair above ($650, in natural; amber also available) is from his new collection, which includes a table ($3,000), armoires, dressers and sideboards. The pieces have a linseed oil finish. Mr. Bettencourt also sells bamboo plywood and wheat and soy composite board; (718) 218-6737 or www.bettencourtwood.com.

description: The China Life Insurance Company, which raised $3.47 billion in the world's biggest public share sale last year, plans to expand into asset management, banking and brokerage, its chief executive, Wang Xianzhang, said at a conference in Beijing. ''We are striving to build an insurance group,'' said Mr. Wang, who did not give details of the expansion plans. China Life Insurance had a loss of 1.43 billion yuan ($174 million) in 2003 reflecting unprofitable policies that the company handed to its parent before its share sale. The company lost 2.25 billion yuan in 2002.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer's Profit Surges

Net income climbed to $702 million, or $4.86 a share, from $134 million, or 94 cents a share, a year earlier, when the insurer had $927 million in write-downs on investments. Premiums rose 6 percent, to $14.3 billion. Property and casualty premiums rose 14 percent, to $11.1 billion. Net income in the property and casualty unit, which accounted for more than three-fourths of premiums in the first quarter, rose 42 percent, to $458 million. Life insurance gross premiums and policy fees fell 14 percent, to $3.1 billion after the company sold some units and reorganized its group pension business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LARKIN, FRANK YOAKUM
description: LARKIN--Frank Yoakum. Of Greenwich, CT & New York City. Beloved husband of June Noble Larkin, died on Sunday, May 16, 2004, in Greenwich, CT, of heart failure. He was a former Executive Vice President of The Putnam Trust Company of Greenwich, and was a graduate of Princeton University, Fordham University School of Law, and served as a Captain in The U.S. Army during World War II. He was a former Chairman of the Board of Greenwich Academy and former President of the Board of Greenwich Hospital. An ardent naturalist and ornithologist since childhood, he served as a Trustee of the Wildlife Conservation Society since 1973, and became a Life Trustee in 2000. In recognition of his life-long commitment to conservation he was awarded the Society's highest honor, its Gold Medal, which was inscribed ''Frank Y. Larkin-1998-His unique Understanding and Far-ranging Knowledge of Wild Creatures Provides a Special Leadership for us All.'' He also served as a Trustee of the American Museum of Natural History from 1974 to 2001, and became an Honorary Trustee in 2001. In addition, the Museum's education center, the Discovery Room, is named in his honor. As Vice Chairman of the Edward John Noble Foundation, and as President of the St. Catherine's Island Foundation, he stewarded the Foundation's environmental funding programs, focussing efforts on scientific research, education, and the preservation of endangered species. Brother of Mrs. Robert C. Wilson, New York City, father of Barbara Franklin, Washington D.C., Frank Larkin, Wooster, Ohio, Patricia Larkin, Washington D.C., and Edith Hubbell, Norwich, VT. Stepfather of Noble Smith, David Smith, Jeremy Smith, Bradford Smith. Grandfather of Jennifer Del Guercio, Lisa Topchik, John F. Franklin III, Sarah, Jay, and Andrew Hubbell. Great grandfather of Sara Topchik. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday June 3, 2004, at 6 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History. Contributions may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History, or the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bankruptcies Decline
description: The number of companies filing for bankruptcy fell in April for the 16th consecutive month as troubled companies were helped by a recovery and government aid to small businesses, according to a research company. For the month, 1,189 companies filed for bankruptcy, 22 percent fewer than in April a year ago, while debts left by bankrupt companies fell 32 percent, to 612 billion yen ($5.36 billion), according to the research company Teikoku Databank. Japanese companies are benefiting from robust growth this year, led by strong exports and consumer spending. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Housewares, One Layer at a Time, Hot Off the Machine
description: A project called In Dust We Trust, an exuberant collision of technology and design, was seen in Milan this year. Sponsored by the Italian company One Off, the project asked 20 designers (shown above, top, on the cover of the manifestolike catalog) to design objects that could be made with a rapid prototyping machine. The machine takes a computer file of a three-dimensional image and builds it, layer by layer, out of a mixture of plaster and glue. Then a resin coating is applied for strength. (Table lamps, like Tim Boyce's O's and X's, above, about $1,400, require wiring.) Costanza Calvetti, owner of One Off, sees the project as a first step toward a new on-demand manufacturing process. The items will be manufactured as they are ordered. The manifesto (showing all of the designs) is available in English at www.industreal.it; prices are in euros.

It was the deadliest airline terrorist attack prior to September 11, 2001. Much of the evidence heard over the past 13 months has focused on discussions the defendants, Ripudaman Singh Malik and Ajaib Singh Bagri, had with witnesses about plans to check luggage onto Air India flights at the Vancouver airport. The case has been one of the most complex criminal investigations in Canadian history and has been hampered by lost wiretap evidence, the death of a main witnesses and the long delay in bringing the accused to trial. title: ART: THE WYNNS' NEW SARGENT
description: The Las Vegas casino owner Stephen A. Wynn and his wife, Elaine, spent $8.8 million at Sotheby's yesterday for one of John Singer Sargent's best-known portraits. ''Portrait of Robert Louis Stevenson and His Wife,'' from 1885, the second of three Sargent paintings of Stevenson, the Scottish novelist and poet, is unlike the more formal commissions that the artist is known for. It shows him in a velveteen jacket walking as he tweaks his mustache; his wife in Indian dress sitting in a chair may be glimpsed at the right of the canvas. Sargent gave the portrait to the Stevensons, who hung it in the living room of their house in Dorset, England. The painting comes from the Greentree Foundation, which has been selling portions of the fabled art collection first formed by Payne and Helen Hay Whitney and their son, John Hay Whitney, the financier and ambassador to Britain and his wife, Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney. Records show that Mrs. Payne Whitney bought the painting at a sale of Stevenson's estate in 1914 and left it to her son. Mr. Wynn said yesterday that he planned to hang the painting in his new casino, the Wynn Las Vegas Resort and Country Club, scheduled to open in 2005. CAROL VOGEL

title: Making the Difficult Look Easy, Part 2

The ovation from the audience that packed the hall that night was as ecstatic as Messiaen's mystical music.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telephone Plan Opposed
description: Nine months of talks among the nation's major telecommunications companies aimed at ending costly fees for connecting each other's phone calls faltered yesterday when Verizon Communications and BellSouth withheld support for a final proposal. A group of 19 telephone service providers had hoped to present federal regulators with a plan that would eliminate the fees the companies pay each other but raise consumers' line charges. Company officials worry that consumers would see the jump in line charges and not realize that they are paying less for long-distance and local calls. They are also concerned that the plan would be impossible to enact when voters are already upset about the rising cost of consumer goods.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Bomb Alert At American School
description: A bomb hoax forced the police to seal off an American school near Athens that is to serve as a training camp for United States athletes in the Olympic Games. Police officials said an anonymous caller warned an Athens newspaper of an attack at the school, in the northeastern suburb of Agia Paraskevi. Explosives experts searched the site and found nothing suspicious, a police spokesman said. The incident came a day after the authorities foiled a bomb attack at a British car dealership that further stirred concern about the Games. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Telecom Concern Halts Sales Slide
description: The BT Group, Britain's biggest phone company, stemmed a nine-month sales decline as increases in high-speed Internet hookups and computer services contracts made up for shrinking revenue at the fixed-line unit. Sales were little changed at 4.79 billion ($8.5 billion) in the three months ended in March, BT said. BT's sales from new services like broadband and network contracts, including those with the British health service, grew to more than a fifth of the group total for the first time. Fourth-quarter income fell to 303 million from 1.65 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank May Sell Unit
description: One of Japan's top banking groups, UFJ Holdings, is considering selling its investment trust unit to Sumitomo Trust and Banking, the companies said. A sale of the UFJ Trust Bank would help the UFJ group raise funds to cover expected losses from bad loans in its mainline banking business. Reports in the Japanese news media said the deal would be worth about 300 billion yen ($2.6 billion). The companies refused to comment on the terms. If the sale goes through, it would create Japan's largest investment trust bank, ahead of the current leader, Mitsubishi Trust Banking. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: A Free-Wheeling Footware Fad?

Now Dada Supreme, the sneaker maker known for such innovations as wood grain side panels on its Cdubbz line of shoes, has introduced a shoe with wheels. Dada has teamed up with Latrell Sprewell to offer "Sprees" for the feet that include a spinning wheel in their structure. "Latrell Sprewell, known to be the originator of the rim called the spinners," Dada reports, "has moved his invention to the footwear world. The rim actually spins as you walk and/or run."

description: A bomb exploded in a parking lot of a McDonald's restaurant in Istanbul. It caused no injuries but damaged two cars. In his hands the Haggard song ''Crazy Moon'' becomes a slow-burning honky-tonk lament as sinewy as anything written by Willie Nelson. It fits right into the far-reaching repertory he is performing through June 12 at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: EchoStar Begins Broadcasting Sirius Programming
description: Sirius Satellite Radio said that EchoStar Communications began broadcasting Sirius's 110 channels of radio programming on EchoStar's Dish satellite television network yesterday. Subscribers to premium Dish services, which account for a majority of the 9.7 million Dish subscribers, are receiving the radio service free in place of Muzak programming previously provided. Basic Dish service subscribers will be able to sample Sirius on the Dish preview channel. Plans for the new service and a joint marketing effort including promotions through Radio Shack were first announced in February. Sirius's goal is to get Dish subscribers to buy satellite radio subscriptions for their cars, boats, home audio systems and portable radios. Sirius shares fell 8 cents, to $3.10. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Candidacy Set For Velella Seat
description: Assemblyman Stephen B. Kaufman, a Bronx Democrat, announced his candidacy yesterday for the State Senate seat vacated by Guy J. Velella. Mr. Velella, a veteran Bronx Republican, resigned last Friday and pleaded guilty to charges of taking bribes. Mr. Kaufman, who was a New York City councilman from 1974 to 1982, was first elected to the Assembly in 1988. Mr. Velella's district, which stretches up the eastern Bronx into Westchester and down into Riverdale, does not include Co-Op City, one of Mr. Kaufman's two bases of power. Al Baker (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Vote For A New Leader
description: Charges of irregularities did not stop voters from turning out en masse for Malawi's third democratic elections, in which a newly chosen Parliament will select a successor to the retiring president, Bakili Muluzi. Mr. Muluzi's 10-year tenure ended three decades of dictatorship. Malawi's poverty and corruption have only worsened, but human rights and some political freedoms have been restored, and experts said Mr. Muluzi's United Democratic Party was likely to win a majority in the legislature. Final results are expected this weekend. Mr. Muluzi agreed to step down after failing to amend the Constitution to allow him to seek a third five-year term. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Vonage To Contest Ruling On Its Status
description: The Internet phone service provider Vonage Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it would object to a ruling this week by the New York State Public Service Commission that classified it as a telephone company, making it subject to some state regulations. The ruling, which was made Wednesday, gave Vonage 45 days to file for a state telephone license. ''We're disappointed, we're concerned and we're incensed,'' a Vonage spokesman said yesterday. ''Obviously,'' he added, New York ''didn't get the memo from Minnesota.'' He was referring to a ruling last fall by a federal judge in Minnesota that Minnesota was not to regulate Vonage's voice-over-Internet service and that Vonage was not a phone company but an information provider using the phone network.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Miners' Hunger Strike
description: More than 160 miners in the Siberian region of Khakassia have resumed a hunger strike that was started by dozens of miners in April to protest months of unpaid wages at their privately run mine. The miners are owed about $7,000 each. Two miners have been hospitalized in grave condition, and criminal proceedings have begun against the mine administration, RIA-Novosti, the government's information agency, reported. The situation was described as scandalous by Boris V. Gryzlov, speaker of the Parliament, and is to be addressed at a plenary session today. The failure to pay wages was a common problem in the mid-1990's and still occurs despite Russia's officially booming economy. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)
