title: Nesting Season
description: About a month ago, a phoebe began building a nest of moss on a light fixture under the eave above our kitchen door. It looked like futility. Every time the door opened, she fluttered away, and there always seemed to be as much moss on the threshold as there was on the nest. But now the nest is done, and she broods happily, only her beak and tail visible. Sometimes on a still evening, her mate perches on a stone pillar at the edge of the deck, tail dipping up and down. He looks over at me where I sit, and then flutters upward to take a bug in midflight. When I go in after the bats are on the wing, I look up at the nest just above my head. I close the door as quietly as I can.

title: Why We Built the Ivory Tower
description: After nearly five decades in academia, and five and a half years as a dean at a public university, I exit with a three-part piece of wisdom for those who work in higher education: do your job; don't try to do someone else's job, as you are unlikely to be qualified; and don't let anyone else do your job. In other words, don't confuse your academic obligations with the obligation to save the world; that's not your job as an academic; and don't surrender your academic obligations to the agenda of any non-academic constituency -- parents, legislators, trustees or donors. In short, don't cross the boundary between academic work and partisan advocacy, whether the advocacy is yours or someone else's.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Ordered To Explain E-Mail Policy
description: A federal judge yesterday ordered Microsoft to search a company computer to help explain why Vice President James E. Allchin told employees in 2000 to eliminate e-mail messages. Judge J. Frederick Motz of United States District Court in Baltimore issued the order in an antitrust and patent suit by Burst.com Inc., which has accused Microsoft of stealing its technology for broadcasting sound and video over the Internet at high speeds. Burst.com charges that Microsoft destroyed e-mail that may help the smaller rival win its case. Judge Motz told the company to search a legal department computer for any evidence that Microsoft lawyers advised Mr. Allchin and others to adopt a policy of scrapping e-mail. A written policy circulated in 1997 by company computer operators advised employees not to save e-mail for more than 30 days ''due to legal issues.'' ''I want to know as much as I can how 'due to legal issues' got in there,'' Judge Motz told a Microsoft lawyer, John W. Treece, at a hearing.

He served on the Board of Directors of the Dysautonomia Foundation, and the Board of Directors of Temple Shalom in Norwalk. Last fall, he was recognized for his many contributions through Norwalk Community College, where he established several scholarships, and was also involved in the renovation of the West Campus of the college. Mark was an active member of Rolling Hills in Wilton and the Hamlet Country Club of Delray Beach, FL. He is survived by his wife, Ellen Sue Hattenbach; a son, Charles Matthew Hattenbach; daughter-in-law, Laime Vaitkus Hattenbach, and two grandsons, Alexander and Theodore Hattenbach, all of Norwalk; father, Monroe Hattenbach, and stepmother, Muriel Hattenbach. He is predeceased by his mother, Nadine Hattenbach; his son, Bernard Hattenbach, and brother, James Hattenbach. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 23rd, at 3:00 p.m., at Temple Shalom, 259 Richards Avenue, Norwalk, CT. Memorial donations may be made to the Dysautonomia Foundation, 633 Third Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, NY 10017; the Norwalk Community College Alumni Scholarship Fund, 188 Richards Avenue, Norwalk, CT 06854; the Bennett Cancer Center at Stamford Hospital, 34 Shelburne Road, Stamford, CT 06902.

The rock here was tortured by nature, having at various times been uplifted, tilted and eroded. As a result, the land looks like a giant staircase, with each step several thousand feet higher than the next. And it is riddled with deep, narrow canyons -- ideal territory for the sport of canyoneering.

title: G.M. TO MOVE SAAB UNIT TO DETROIT AND CUT SOME JOBS
description: General Motors said yesterday that it would move the United States sales unit of its Saab division to Detroit from near Atlanta and that it might cut more than half the unit's 80 jobs to reduce costs. The move will be completed by Sept. 7, the unit, Saab Cars USA, said. About half of the unit's staff members will be offered a chance to relocate to the new offices at General Motors' headquarters, a Saab spokesman said. General Motors is cutting expenses and introducing new vehicles to try to halt losses at Saab, which has posted only two annual profits since G.M. bought half of it in 1990. G.M. acquired the rest in 2000.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Prison For Bombings Investigator
description: Mikhail Trepashkin, a former state security agent, was sentenced to four years of hard labor for revealing state secrets while working with liberal legislators to investigate three apartment bombings in 1999 that killed 243 people. The bombings -- two in Moscow and one in the southern city of Volgodansk -- led to the second war in Chechnya and swept Vladimir V. Putin, a former K.G.B. agent, to power. Mr. Trepashkin had worked for the K.G.B. and its successor, the F.S.B. Working as a private investigator for the legislators, he said he found evidence linking a former security agent to the bombings. Government investigators closed their investigation last year, but suspicions linger that the F.S.B. was involved. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
36 Hours | Oxford, Miss.
description: WILLIAM FAULKNER was born over in New Albany. But locals claim him as their own, for he honed fictional Yoknapatawpha County from the people and places of surrounding Lafayette County. Named for Oxford, England, in a successful bid to lure Mississippi's liberal arts university, this town of 12,000 sprawls out from the courthouse, described in Faulkner's 1951 novel, ''Requiem for a Nun,'' as ''brooding, symbolic and ponderable, tall as cloud, solid as rock, dominating all.'' Faulkner still matters here. A majestic bronze statue of him, resting on a bench, pipe in hand, flanks the entrance to City Hall. The local temple of intellect, Square Books, stocks what seems like every blessed thing he wrote. And his home, Rowan Oak, is soon to reopen for tours after a multimillion-dollar refurbishing. Though the courthouse square he knew -- ringed by hardware stores and barbershops -- is now the domain of dress boutiques and cigar botes, the local underclass of writers, artists and graduate students remains a vigilant steward of the town's reputation as a velvet ditch for ne'er-do-wells. JOHN T. EDGE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Bars Have Cleanest Air, Survey Shows
description: The level of air pollution in New York City bars is 82 percent lower than in bars in six other major cities where smoking is still permitted, according to a study released yesterday. The study, which was paid for in part by the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids, an antismoking group, found that New York City had the lowest level of pollutants, as measured by micrograms per cubic meter of air. Within that group of cities, Washington had the highest levels. Indoor air quality was assessed in 53 bars and restaurants in seven cities in March and April, using aerosol monitors that electronically sniffed the air. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: State's Asian Population Doubled
description: New Jersey's Asian-American population nearly doubled between 1990 and 2000, largely because of the waves of well-educated immigrants coming to fill high-tech and scientific jobs in the state, according to a new study. In the 2000 census, 527,594 people in the state identified themselves as Asian-American, up more than 95 percent from the level in the 1990 census, according to the Asian-American Federation of New York. Asians were concentrated largely in Hudson, Bergen and Middlesex Counties. The largest concentration percentage was in Palisades Park, where Korean-Americans represent 43 percent of the population. title: A Rare Consensus on Clean Air
description: After more than three years of steady criticism for its regressive policies on air pollution, the Bush administration is enjoying well-deserved praise for a new regulatory initiative that will greatly reduce harmful emissions from diesel-powered construction equipment and other off-road machinery. The rule will apply to engines in more than six million pieces of equipment, like bulldozers, tractors and airport baggage trucks. Off-road diesel engines account for a quarter of the smog-producing pollutants and more than half of the soot from mobile sources. They are believed to be responsible for 12,000 premature deaths annually as well as hundreds of thousands of respiratory illnesses.

Steel Dynamics has been passing on higher costs for raw materials like scrap metal to customers and is raising its base price for steel to take advantage of growing demand.

title: Fishnets, Race and Religion In an American Hodgepodge
description: With a running time of 6 hours and 42 minutes, ''Star Spangled to Death'' is the magnum opus of the independent filmmaker Ken Jacobs. Begun in 1957 as a backyard bohemian romp starring the avant-garde legend Jack Smith -- an amazing proto-drag performer who later directed his own underground classic, ''Flaming Creatures'' -- the project grew over the years to incorporate huge chunks of appropriated material, including, for example, the entirety of Richard M. Nixon's 1952 Checkers speech and what seems like most of an early 30's documentary on what was then known as ''darkest Africa.'' For this provisionally definitive version, which opens today for a one-week engagement at the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village, Mr. Jacobs has brought his film up-to-date with topical references to the war in Iraq and the Bush administration.

title: Reflecting on a Runaway Cat And the Bigger Issues of Life
description: About a decade ago Mary Chapin Carpenter, now 46, quietly volunteered for a job few songwriters want: to speak for a generation. She had hits in the 1990's about the ups and downs of romance, but with songs like ''Stones in the Road,'' from 1994, she summed up baby boomers' experiences of growing up and settling down, and since then she has done as much philosophizing as storytelling.

title: Dozens Indicted in Crackdown on a Brooklyn Drug Ring
description: Dozens of suspected members of a violent drug ring that the authorities say has virtually held a Brooklyn housing project hostage for the last several years have been indicted on conspiracy and attempted murder charges, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Mutiny by 4 Republicans Over Bush's Tax Cutting Forces Delay on the Budget Vote
description: Unable to a squelch a six-week mutiny over President Bush's tax-cutting agenda, Senate Republican leaders on Thursday conceded that they could not muster enough votes to pass a $2.4 trillion budget plan and abruptly postponed a vote until at least next month.

title: Taking the Slot Canyon Challenge
description: THE closest major airport to Zion National Park is in Las Vegas, about 150 miles southwest of Springdale, Utah. A smaller airport is in St. George, Utah, 46 miles to the west, which is served by SkyWest Airlines.

title: Stewart Stock Case Is Jolted by Charge That an Agent Lied
description: The case against Martha Stewart took a strange twist yesterday as the government charged that an important witness lied repeatedly at her trial.

title: Heading for Home
description: KANGERLUSSUAQ, GREENLAND, May 22 -- Most places have rhythms of sorts.

title: On Opening Day, Wall-to-Walleye Traffic
description: WILLIAM BATES slumped at the pump last Saturday morning at a gas station on State Highway 169, 70 miles north of his Minneapolis home, and disconsolately refilled his green Jeep Wrangler with $2.11-a-gallon gas. Still another 70 miles south of Minnesota's most hallowed angling destination -- 133,000-acre Lake Mille Lacs -- the lanky Mr. Bates then looked at the gridlock of cars hauling fishing boats on the road he had just pulled off of. ''I can't take it anymore, I'm turning around and going home,'' he said, paying no mind to the neatly arranged, unused fishing tackle in his car.

title: At Shows Painted With Sound, Be Prepared to See With Your Ears
description: Sound happens. In art as in life, in movies as in bars, it is increasingly diverse, unavoidable and at times severe. One of the notable benefits of this expansion is ''New Sound, New York,'' a sound-art festival overseen by the Kitchen and Cooper Union and presented by Time Out New York. It has recently reached critical mass in terms of what might be called listening-looking opportunities: two engagingly dovetailed exhibitions, complemented by two outdoor installations in Lower Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about a partnership between the TXU Corporation, the Texas power supplier, and Capgemini, the consulting company, referred to it imprecisely. It will provide information technology, finance and accounting services and other business functions, not just billing services.

title: Spitzer Will Return $21,000 In Donations From Trump
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said Thursday that he would return $21,000 in campaign contributions from Donald J. Trump after being criticized for accepting money from him while he had business pending before Mr. Spitzer's office.

title: 9/11 Hearings: What Was Learned?
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Mets Pay for the Errors Of Their Many Misplays
description: A soft ground ball tumbled to Mets first baseman Mike Piazza in the top of the ninth inning yesterday. He fielded it and flipped it to pitcher David Weathers for the out. Piazza was cheered, but not because he had made the play. These were mock cheers, tinged with acid, near the end of a game in which the Mets resurrected the fumbling image they are trying so hard to shed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Social Worker Accused Of Murder
description: A city social worker was charged yesterday with second-degree murder after the police found a body on May 18 in the basement of her Queens home that had been hidden there for as long as two months, the authorities said. Richard A. Brown, left, the Queens district attorney, said that the woman, Lorna Laidlaw, 42, of Queens Village, was an employee of the city's Human Resources Administration in March when she shot a co-worker, Jose Hernandez, 58, and concealed his body in a garbage bag in her basement. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Hollinger's London Paper Said to Draw $1 Billion Bid
description: About a half-dozen bidders, including the Barclay brothers of Britain, submitted offers of about $1 billion yesterday for The Daily Telegraph of London, the crown jewel of Conrad M. Black's publishing empire, Hollinger International, executives involved in the auction said.

title: DUPONT CREATES HERBICIDE-RESISTANT CROP TRAIT
description: DuPont, the largest corn-seed producer in North America, said yesterday that it had developed a genetic trait that could compete with technology from a rival, Monsanto, in the $2.2 billion global market for herbicide-resistant crops. The trait, developed from bacterial enzymes, allows crops to detoxify the herbicide glyphosate, according to a study in the journal Science. The trait was developed by DuPont's Pioneer Hi-Bred International unit and the Verdia unit of Maxygen. DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., will own the rights to market the trait in corn, soybeans and canola, a spokeswoman said. The trait is being tested in corn fields and should be available between 2008 and 2010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RANDALL, TONY
description: RANDALL--Tony. The entire staff of Newson & Haberman and Alvin Goldfine mourn the death of their friend and client Tony Randall whom we had the privilege of serving for many years. His integrity and dedication to many worthy causes have been an inspiration to us all. We express our heartfelt condolences to his devoted and beloved wife Heather and beloved children Julia and Jefferson.

title: HAIN AGREES TO BUY 2 FOOD BUSINESSES FROM HEINZ
description: Hain Celestial Group, an organic foods maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Ethnic Gourmet and Rosetto lines from H.J. Heinz, expanding its offerings of low-carbohydrate foods. Hain also said it had reached an agreement with Sesame Workshop to create natural foods under the Earth's Best brand using Sesame Street characters. Terms of the two transactions were not disclosed. With the purchase of the Heinz businesses, Hain, based in Melville, N.Y., will increase its frozen-foods sales to about $50 million a year. The company plans to introduce low-carbohydrate frozen dinners and pastas under the CarbFit and Rosetto brands.

title: In Miami, a Landlocked District Is Making a Splash
description: Correction Appended

title: Bush Still Has More Cash, But Kerry Leads Web Race
description: President Bush has now raised more than $200 million for this year's election, but has already spent more than $126 million of it, according to finance reports and statistics released by his campaign on Thursday.

title: Musicians Say Fisher Hall Isn't as Bad as All That
description: Correction Appended

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are so many parties going on you have to pick and choose the location and date rather early to try to lessen the competition. Competition will be great every hour of every day.''

title: Russia, on Path to W.T.O., Signs Trade Deal With Europe
description: MOSCOW, May 21  Russia moved a step closer to becoming a member of the World Trade Organization on today, signing a major trade deal with the European Union that could pave the way for Moscow's admission to the W.T.O. as early as this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KONNER, RUTH
description: KONNER--Ruth. The Partners and staff of Ross & Cohen, LLP wish to express our deepest sympathy to our Partner, Dennis Konner and his family on the loss of Ruth Konner, beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RATNER, MILTON B.
description: RATNER--Milton B. Of Tenafly, NJ on May 20, 2004 age 84. Dear husband of 57 years of Anne (nee Loeb) Ratner. Devoted father of Patricia, Judith and Steven; father-in-law of Kenneth Geller and Nancy Szabo; proud grandfather of Eric and Lisa Geller and Benjamin and Isabel Ratner. Brother of the late Robert S. Ratner. Funeral services Friday, May 21st at 10AM at Temple Emeth, 1666 Windsor Road, Teaneck, NJ. Family will be at home Saturday and Sunday, May 22nd-23rd, 25PM. Donations may be made to UJA Federation of Bergen County or a charity of your choice.

title: City Wins Right To U.S. Data On Firearms
description: New York City won a significant victory this week in its civil suit against the firearms industry, winning the right to information that could help prove its claim that the industry closes its eyes to the way guns get into the hands of criminals.

title: Rowland's Once-Rising Star Is Now Showing Its Descent
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, a once-rising star of the Republican Party, has relinquished a crucial platform of political power and influence within his party: leading the state re-election campaign for President Bush.

title: From a Visual Scavenger, A World Made of Fragments
description: You don't have to be a good artist to be an interesting artist. Erro, who is said to be Iceland's most acclaimed contemporary painter (with all due respect to Louisa Matthiasdottir fans), is a terrible artist on many levels. His Pop-style work is shamelessly derivative, technically facile, illustrative in the most obvious and superficial ways and completely without sensuous physical appeal. And yet despite your better judgment, you may find yourself engaged by the manic graphic activity, antic humor and promiscuous sampling from popular visual culture displayed in ''Worldscapes: The Art of Erro.'' This nearly 50-year retrospective at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University was organized by the gallery and the Reykjavik Art Museum.

title: Republicans and Democrats Clash on New York Drug Laws
description: One of the enduring mysteries here in recent years is why the state has been unable to overhaul the Rockefeller drug laws, which force judges to sentence drug offenders to lengthy prison terms that the three most powerful state officials, Gov. George E. Pataki and the leaders of both houses of the Legislature, agree are draconian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANLEY, MARGUERITE
description: MANLEY--Marguerite, beloved wife of her late husband, Otto, mother of Edward, John and Frances and daughters-in-law Maya and Susanne, grandmother of Alan, Audrey and Thomas Fritton, Jr., Cynthia and Thomas Baldwin, Catherine, Chris and Sarah, and greatgrandmother of Esme Fritton, we mourn your passing. Your pure and generous spirit believed in nothing but the good in each person you met and in each cause you supported. You lived a life of grace and unconditional love. A memorial service will be held at the Hitchcock Church in Scarsdale, NY, on Saturday, May 22, at 11:00 AM, followed by a private family burial. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Camphill Village USA, Copake, New York 12516, or Making Headway Foundation, 115 King St., Chappaqua, New York 10514.

title: Justice Memos Explained How to Skip Prisoner Rights
description: A series of Justice Department memorandums written in late 2001 and the first few months of 2002 were crucial in building a legal framework for United States officials to avoid complying with international laws and treaties on handling prisoners, lawyers and former officials say.

title: Bringing History to Life, and a Crime to Light
description: AS a defiant teenager in Baton Rouge, La., bent on annoying authority figures by making a habit of dating white classmates, Keith A. Beauchamp, whose as yet unreleased documentary, ''The Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till,'' was pivotal in the Justice Department's decision this month to reopen that landmark 1955 murder case, often left the house with a parental salvo ringing in his ears. ''Don't let what happened to Emmett Till happen to you,'' his mother warned.

title: To Garnett, Celebration Was Payback to Fans
description: Criticism is not something Kevin Garnett hears often in these parts. Minnesota Timberwolves fans revere him, which is why Garnett jumped up on the press table to celebrate with them after Minnesota defeated Sacramento in Game 7 of their Western Conference semifinal series Wednesday night. But for the second time in three days, Garnett faced scrutiny for something he did or said.

title: In the Back, the Knee And the Numbers, Pain
description: During a timeout with 2 minutes 26 seconds remaining in the game and in the Nets' season, Coach Lawrence Frank called Brandon Armstrong into the huddle, ending the night for Jason Kidd. He left without a word from the public-address announcer or any hugs or high-fives from his teammates.

title: Boston's Newfound Fascination With African Art
description: This city is having an African art moment. It's a serious one; it's long overdue; and I have the sense that it will last for some time. In April the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, introduced a revamped and expanded version of its gloomy old African installation -- it's as if someone suddenly opened a window and let sunlight in -- and hired a full-time curator to oversee it. Its inaugural celebration coincided with the opening of ''A Decade of Democracy: Witnessing South Africa,'' a survey of a new generation of post-apartheid artists, most exhibiting outside of Africa for the first time, at the National Center of Afro-American Artists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LARKIN, FRANK YOAKUM
description: LARKIN--Frank Yoakum. Of Greenwich, CT & New York City. Beloved husband of June Noble Larkin, died on Sunday, May 16, 2004, in Greenwich, CT, of heart failure. He was a former Executive Vice President of The Putnam Trust Company of Greenwich, and was a graduate of Princeton University, Fordham University School of Law, and served as a Captain in The U.S. Army during World War II. He was a former Chairman of the Board of Greenwich Academy and former President of the Board of Greenwich Hospital. An ardent naturalist and ornithologist since childhood, he served as a Trustee of the Wildlife Conservation Society since 1973, and became a Life Trustee in 2000. In recognition of his life-long commitment to conservation he was awarded the Society's highest honor, its Gold Medal, which was inscribed ''Frank Y. Larkin-1998-His unique Understanding and Far-ranging Knowledge of Wild Creatures Provides a Special Leadership for us All.'' He also served as a Trustee of the American Museum of Natural History from 1974 to 2001, and became an Honorary Trustee in 2001. In addition, the Museum's education center, the Discovery Room, is named in his honor. As Vice Chairman of the Edward John Noble Foundation, and as President of the St. Catherine's Island Foundation, he stewarded the Foundation's environmental funding programs, focussing efforts on scientific research, education, and the preservation of endangered species. Brother of Mrs. Robert C. Wilson, New York City, father of Barbara Franklin, Washington D.C., Frank Larkin, Wooster, Ohio, Patricia Larkin, Washington D.C., and Edith Hubbell, Norwich, VT. Stepfather of Noble Smith, David Smith, Jeremy Smith, Bradford Smith. Grandfather of Jennifer Del Guercio, Lisa Topchik, John F. Franklin III, Sarah, Jay, and Andrew Hubbell. Great grandfather of Sara Topchik. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday June 3, 2004, at 6 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History. Contributions may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History, or the Wildlife Conservation Society in New York.

title: After Revising Roster, Liberty Hopes to Make a Style Statement on Opening Night
description: Correction Appended

title: Lawyer Linked to Bombings Is Released
description: An Oregon lawyer arrested May 6 and held as a material witness in connection with the deadly Madrid bombings in March was released from custody on Thursday.

title: National Report | Midwest: Michigan: Zoo To Free Elephants
description: The Detroit Zoo said that for ethical reasons it intended to release its two elephants to a wildlife refuge. Pending approval by a regulatory group, the elephants will be sent to elephant sanctuaries in either California or Tennessee. The zoo's director, Ron Kagan, said that captive elephants generally displayed abnormal behavior, had difficulty reproducing and lived 20 years less than elephants in the wild. Ben Lefebvre (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Cannes, a k a Asia West
description: IT has become something of a journalistic clich to preface any mention of Wong Kar-Wai's ''2046'' with the words ''long awaited.'' Four years have passed since ''In the Mood for Love,'' with its elliptical story and fabulous clothes, set the critics swooning at the 53rd Cannes International Film Festival (and won its dapper male lead, Tony Leung, the award for best actor). Mr. Wong's new film was expected at the Cannes festival last spring, and then in Venice the following summer. It was not ready for either of those events. On Thursday the audience at the 57th Cannes festival, whose catalogs listed ''2046'' among the competitive entries, had to wait a bit longer than anticipated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOSTWICK, ELEANOR P.
description: BOSTWICK--Eleanor P., died May 18, 2004, seven days after her 100th birthday, at her home in Old Westbury, NY. She married her late husband, Albert C. Bostwick, in 1937. Mr. Bostwick died in 1980. She is survived by two sons and one daughter: Albert C. Bostwick, Jr. of Aiken, SC, Andrew G.C. Sage II of Wilson, WY and Eleanor S. Munger of Osterville, MA. She had seven grandchildren: Alexandra Bostwick, Gregg Sage, Sally Sage, Katherine P. Goldsmith, Richard L. Parker and Michael R. Parker. Nine great grandchildren also survive her. She was greatly interested in her family and was greatly loved by them. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM on Saturday, May 22, at her residence in Old Westbury, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; For Nets, the Season Is Now Over And the Transition Is Beginning
description: THE season will ultimately be remembered as lost last Sunday night, in New Jersey, for the want of a timely basket or two. By the time Jason Kidd and the Nets hit the road, they were running on empty. Or more to the point: not at all.

title: Issue at Guantnamo
description: Interrogators at the Guantnamo Bay prison camp received special Pentagon approval to use harsher interrogation procedures on a Saudi Arabian detainee who was believed to be the planned 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 terror plot, government officials said.

title: New York and 3 Other States Join Against Air Pollution
description: New York and three adjoining states began legal action yesterday against a Pennsylvania power company, accusing it of emitting air pollution that drifts across state lines and worsens smog, produces acid rain and causes respiratory problems for people in the metropolitan region.

title: N.C.A.A. Defends Right To Limit Scholarships
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, responding to a class-action suit that challenges its limits on football scholarships, said yesterday that several courts had confirmed its right to set its own rules.

title: Giddy at the Park, in the Spirit of Tar Beach
description: I saw this band on Wednesday night, and its front line was like a rock-museum hologram. There was Bob Dylan in 1965, with electroshock hair, narrow sports coat and Stratocaster. And Johnny Thunders of the 1978 Heartbreakers, slight and graceful, obscured by long, bushy tresses, with a jutting nose. The bassist was Phil Lesh of the Grateful Dead, from way back, when he wore a headband onstage. I couldn't place the singer: Ray Davies? Simon Le Bon?

title: National Report | Southwest: Texas: Report Faults Care Of Elderly
description: The state Adult Protective Services division is failing to stop or even respond to abuse and neglect of the elderly because of a ''total breakdown'' and should be restructured, a preliminary report by the state Department of Health and Human Services said. The audit, ordered by Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, said the El Paso office, for one, had not properly investigated more than a third of reported abuse cases. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Diary article on Wednesday about classical music in New York misidentified the pianist who accompanied the soprano Lucy Shelton on May 13 in Elliott Carter's ''Of Challenge and of Love'' at the Ethical Culture Society. He was Stephen Gosling, not James Goldsworthy.

title: Extra $150 Million Is Found to Pay for Housing for the Poor
description: The nation's top housing official told Congress yesterday that the federal government had unearthed an extra $150 million to help housing agencies absorb cuts to the government's main housing program for poor Americans.

title: A Couple Who View Risk As the Ultimate Romance
description: Only the French, those self-proclaimed sages of ''l'amour fou,'' would dream of concocting a surreal romantic allegory like Yann Samuell's grown-up fairy tale, ''Love Me if You Dare.'' This rococo fantasy, tricked out with animation and with actors sailing like little Supermen through toy cutout clouds, belongs to the same school of whimsical excess as ''The Umbrellas of Cherbourg'' and ''Amlie.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lakewood: Boy Dies In Parked Car
description: A 7-month-old boy died yesterday after being left in a parked car by his father for several hours, the police said. Detective Capt. Robert Lawson said that the father, Aryeh Katzman, 25, of Lakewood, had driven from his house to a baby sitter's house, then on to a yeshiva for classes. He later returned to the sitter's house. The baby was found dead in the car around 2 p.m., the police said. Detective Lawson told television reporters that Mr. Katzman realized that the child was still in the car only when he arrived at the sitter's house to pick him up. Mr. Katzman was charged with second-degree endangerment, and was released after posting $100,000 bail. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: An hour out of work and the sun still shining above them, beautiful women walked their muscular dogs through Tompkins Square Park. Over at Manitoba's bar on Avenue B there was an older fellow drinking beer, a punk rock pensioner beginning his night. And across the street at No. 1 Chinese, which Frank Prisinzano opened a few months ago to bring a little Nassau County nostalgia into the East Village, the kids were waiting for egg rolls, red-cooked ribs, the triumphant coming of General Tso.

title: Julian Aberbach, Music Publisher, Dies at 95
description: Julian J. Aberbach, who owned the publishing rights to Elvis Presley's music and set up a music publishing system that revolutionized the rock and country music industries, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 95 and lived in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Survey Tracks Behavior Of Students
description: The percentage of high school students who engage in risky social and sexual behaviors is falling, but their numbers remain high, according to a new study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Pentagon Approved Intense Interrogation Techniques for Sept. 11 Suspect at Guantnamo
description: Interrogators at the Guantnamo Bay prison camp received Pentagon approval to use special, harsher interrogation procedures on a Saudi Arabian detainee who was believed to be the planned 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11 terror plot, government officials said Thursday.

title: National Report | Washington: New Rail Security Rules
description: The Department of Homeland Security said it had developed the first federal procedures to protect rail passengers from terrorism. Asa Hutchinson, the undersecretary for border and transportation security, said rail companies would be required to designate security coordinators, conduct inspections and ask passengers and employees to report unattended property or suspicious behavior. Lawmakers have paid particular attention to the security of railways in the United States since the March bombings in Madrid that killed 201 people. John Files (NYT)

title: GILLETTE KEEPS STAGGERED ELECTIONS FOR DIRECTORS
description: Gillette said yesterday that it would continue to choose its directors in staggered elections despite majority support for a shareholder resolution recommending annual elections for board members. According to preliminary results, about 68 percent of the shares voting at the company's annual meeting yesterday supported a proposal for annual elections. The proposal, submitted by Walden Asset Management and several other institutional investors, was supported at the 2003 meeting, as well. Gillette's system mandates that a third of the directors stand for election each year.

title: Another Grande Dame Says Adieu
description: A WHITE-HAIRED man in a well-tailored gray suit wagged his finger at Rita Jammet. ''Mchante,'' he said. ''Bad girl'' is a reasonable translation from the French, given the context. He meant it more as a verbal hug than a rebuke.

title: A Court-Martial Exposes Weakness
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Camp Tweaks Kerry Over Unconventional Idea
description: The novel idea that John Kerry might not exactly accept the Democratic presidential nomination at the convention in Boston in July in order to preserve his ability to raise and spend private money had the political world buzzing this afternoon.

title: Reforming Mutual Funds
description: Prompted by a spate of recent scandals that signaled a need to protect individual investors, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been considering reforms in the way mutual funds are run. Chief among them is a requirement that fund boards be led by an independent director, rather than an executive of the fund's management, as is commonly the case. Not surprisingly, the mutual fund industry and its allies in Congress are opposing the reform.

title: IRAQIS AND G.I.'S RAID THE OFFICES OF AN EX-FAVORITE
description: American and Iraqi forces on Thursday raided and ransacked the headquarters of Ahmad Chalabi, the Iraqi leader who was a favorite of the Bush administration but who has fallen out with his former patron and become one of the sharpest critics of the occupation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EVERETT, HENRY
description: EVERETT--Henry. Human Rights Watch mourns the loss of a tireless advocate of the cause of human rights and justice. Along with his wife Edith, Henry Everett has been a longtime advisor to and trusted supporter of Human Rights Watch. His contributions to the cause of human rights will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences go to Edith and the Everett family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMANN, STEVEN
description: KAUFMANN -- Steven. DC Moore Gallery mourns the passing of our good friend Steven Kaufmann. We will always remember with pleasure his generosity of spirit, inimitable sense of humor and incomparable sense of style. Our deepest sympathies to his family and especially to Edward. Bridget, Suzanne, Heidi, Sandy & Brian

title: With Kidd Silenced, Nets Cry Uncle
description: They were all moving downcourt. Ten players, five of them defeated, five of them as spry as rabbits. So it was not surprising that after Detroit guard Mike James went to the rim and missed, it was a Pistons player who left the floor like a rocket to grab the ball.

title: A Statement Of Apology
description: Following is the text of a statement by Richard S. Strong, which was released with the announcement of the $175 million settlement between regulators and Mr. Strong and the Strong Capital Management Company:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Truck Recall
description: Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus, an affiliate of DaimlerChrysler and Mitsubishi Motors, said it would recall 180,000 trucks after determining that defective parts might have been a cause in a series of accidents, including a fatal one. The fatality, which occurred in 2002, is the second death linked to a defective Mitsubishi truck. Mitsubishi Fuso was a division of Mitsubishi Motors when the accidents occurred. Mitsubishi managers knew of the defects as long ago as 1996 and should have recalled vehicles then, said Mitsubishi Fuso's chief executive, Wilfried Porth, above, who blamed a culture of concealment among previous executives for the delay. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: OPEC Offers Little Hope On Fuel Prices
description: The president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said Thursday that there was little the group could do to lower fuel prices anytime soon, because OPEC's oil production quotas were not the main problem. His remarks contradicted statements last week by Saudi Arabia, the cartel's leading producer, calling for increases in the quotas to ease price pressures.

title: Robert Indiana -- 'Peace Paintings'
description: Paul Kasmin

title: Letter From the Middle East; Children Fill Ledger of Death, No Matter How, or How Many
description: Set in fields of white, pink and red carnations, the giant cooler here, which usually holds vegetables or flowers for sale to an Israeli company, has been turned over to the dead.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Outdoor Works Are Blooming

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Increases
description: Reflecting higher gasoline and electricity prices, Canada's consumer price index climbed 1.6 percent in the year to April, up from a 0.7 percent increase in the year to March, Statistics Canada reported. Accelerating inflation is expected to encourage the Bank of Canada to raise interest rates later this year, reversing recent declines. The federal government has reacted to growing public concern over spiraling fuel prices with a plan to spend a portion of windfall tax revenues from gasoline on improved public health care amenities. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Magic Johnson Signs On With Nascar
description: Magic Johnson has signed on to become the face of diversity for Nascar. Johnson, who won five N.B.A. titles with the Lakers, three M.V.P. awards and an Olympic gold medal, has agreed to become Nascar's co-chairman of its new Executive Steering Committee for Diversity. In his unpaid position, Johnson will advise and assist with programs to improve diversity and develop strategies to market the sport to minorities.

title: A Bolshoi Visitor in 'Bayadre'
description: ''La Bayadre'' is an extravagant ballet about two women, Nikiya and Gamzatti, who both love Solor, a handsome warrior. Their tale is told with the theatrical aid of tempestuous romantic battles, an opium vision and an eruption of divine fury. Yet this work of 1877 never grows silly, for Marius Petipa's choreography is often dramatically gripping and spectacularly beaufiful. ''La Bayadre'' again cast its spell in two recent performances by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Four Meningitis Cases
description: Viral meningitis has been diagnosed in four students at Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts in the past two weeks, the Department of Education said yesterday, adding that all four have recovered or are recuperating. Two of the students are back at school and two are at home, a department spokeswoman said. According to the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, viral meningitis is contagious but is not generally life threatening. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: A Teenager Adrift, a Tragedy And the Marines to the Rescue
description: The early scenes of ''Stateside,'' the muddled drama of a young marine and his obsessive relationship with a schizophrenic pop singer, make you fear that you are about to be plunged into a fill-in-the-blanks Hollywood fantasy of cut-rate redemption.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Four Sought In Knife Attack
description: A man who refused demands for money by four teenagers was stabbed shortly after midnight yesterday on a subway platform at West 181st Street, the police said. They said that one boy stabbed the man, Francisco Jimenez, 64, of Washington Heights, in the chest and in one hand, partially severing a thumb. The four fled, and Mr. Jimenez was taken to Harlem Hospital, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: From a Legend and a Pop Icon, Fragrance for Men
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAYNARD, DANIEL S.
description: MAYNARD--Daniel S. The Port Authority of NY & NJ was saddened to lose its colleague and friend, Dan Maynard. He provided astute and sensitive guidance on many regional issues, especially regarding the Port of NY/NJ. He was a knowledgeable and respected voice for our agency. We will miss his expertise, perspective and his distinctive laugh. We extend our deepest condolences to Richard, Barbara and Ken.

title: House Approves $447 Billion in Spending for Military
description: The House on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a $447 billion military package that includes the extra $25 billion sought by the Bush administration to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through early next year.

title: A German Violin Virtuoso With a Casual Attitude Toward the Violin
description: Over the last dozen years, the German violinist Christian Tetzlaff has become one of the most highly regarded violinists of his generation, and his performances have been praised as much for the intellectual rigor that supports his interpretations as for the beautiful, centered tone he produces.

title: Oracle and Microsoft Cut a Software Deal
description: Two longtime rivals, Oracle and Microsoft, announced a partnership yesterday intended to help Oracle's databases work better with Microsoft's Windows operating system.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about 48 Roman Catholic members of Congress who criticized threats by some bishops to deny communion to politicians who support abortion rights referred incorrectly to the number of bishops who oppose the denial. Of the American bishops, totaling some 300, 135 said in a recent poll that they did not agree with denying anyone the eucharist, or that it would be a last resort. The 135 represent a majority of the 154 who responded  not a majority of the bishops. ( Go to Article )

title: Eligibility Issue Disqualifies 13 Parent Council Candidates
description: City education officials said yesterday that they had disqualified 13 winning candidates for the parent councils that are replacing the city's local school boards, and that dozens more may be disqualified after a check for conflicts of interest.

title: Rock of Ages
description: It's just before Christmas last year, and the Philadelphia rock 'n' roll band Marah is halfway through a typically ferocious, chaotic and inspirational set when the doors to the right of the stage burst open and a young man staggers in, carrying most of a drum kit. My friends and I have the best seats in the house, a couple of feet away from Marah's frontmen, Serge and Dave Bielanko, but when the drummer arrives we have to move our table back to make room for him. He's not Marah's drummer (the band is temporarily without) but he's a drummer, and he owns most of a drum kit, and his appearance allows the band to make an even more glorious and urgent racket than they had managed hitherto. The show ends triumphantly, as Marah shows tend to do, with Serge lying on the floor amid the feet of his public, wailing away on his harmonica.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, EDITH
description: WILLIAMS--Edith. The Board of Directors and tenants/ shareholders of 1035 Fifth Avenue Corp. mourn the passing of Mrs. Edith Williams, a longtime resident and Director Emeritus of 1035 Fifth Avenue Corp. Mrs. Williams was a major contributor to the well-being of the building and its residents. She will be deeply missed by her fellow shareholders and staff.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bank Robber Gets Life Sentence
description: A man convicted of conspiring to rob a bank has been sentenced to life in prison under New York's three-strikes rule. In October 2002, a federal jury convicted the man, Vernon Snype, 43, in connection with an armed robbery at First Union Bank in Yonkers. Court records show that he was convicted of three armed robberies about 20 years ago, said Herbert Hadad, a court spokesman. Mr. Snype's lawyer, Kerry A. Lawrence, said the sentence was cruel in light of the number of years since the early convictions and the jury's deadlock on more serious charges Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Village Rentals To Be Co-ops
description: The 420-unit West Village Houses on Morton Street will be converted to a co-op next year through a tenant-sponsored, noneviction plan announced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The development is part of the Mitchell-Lama program, which provides moderately priced housing to middle-income New Yorkers. Under the conversion plan, more than half of the existing renters are expected to buy their units, while others will be allowed to continue renting at below-market rates. As part of the agreement, Mayor Bloomberg said, the city will forgive about $19 million in interest payments on the existing mortgage on the property. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Russia, on Path to W.T.O., Signs Trade Deal With Europe
description: MOSCOW, May 21  Russia moved a step closer to becoming a member of the World Trade Organization on today, signing a major trade deal with the European Union that could pave the way for Moscow's admission to the W.T.O. as early as this year.

title: Man Is Fatally Shot On Crowded Street By Diamond District
description: In a brazen attack, a man a police official said was indicted in an international money laundering case was shot in the back of the head and killed last night as he walked along a crowded Midtown street near the diamond district.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Citing Security, Subway Officials Seek Picture Ban
description: Citing the security of 7 million daily riders, 48,000 employees and its transportation network, New York City Transit yesterday proposed a ban on unauthorized photography, filming and videotaping on city subways, buses and Staten Island Railway trains. The press and businesses or individuals with permits would be exempt.

title: 'From the Classroom to the World' -- 'Hine, Ulmann, Strand, Arbus and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School'
description: New-York Historical Society

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP TO PAY $165 MILLION FOR TEXAS BANK
description: Southwest Bancorp of Texas said yesterday that it planned to buy Klein Bancshares for $165 million, adding branches in two Texas counties. Klein shareholders will receive $150 million in cash and $15 million in stock. Southwest expects to issue $45 million to $55 million in securities to buy Klein, it said. Southwest, based in Houston, said Klein, based in the Houston suburb of Spring, would become part of Southwest Bank. The purchase is Southwest's second this year. It bought Reunion Bancshares in February for $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELLER, MARY
description: HELLER--Mary. The Board and staff of American Jewish World Service mourn the passing of Mary Heller, the mother of our Board member, Linda Heller Kamm. Marty Friedman, Chair Ruth Messinger, Exec. Dir. American Jewish World Service

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Isuzu
description: The truck maker Isuzu Motors reported its first profit in five years as it benefited from a cost-cutting program and tougher Japanese emissions laws, which helped increase sales of new, cleaner diesel trucks. Isuzu earned 54.7 billion yen ($478 million) for the year ended March 31 compared with a net loss of 144.3 billion yen a year earlier. Isuzu is dropping its unprofitable line of sport utility vehicles in the United States and focusing on sales of commercial trucks in Japan and Asia. General Motors, which owns 12 percent of Isuzu, is helping the company reorganize. Isuzu expects net profit to decline 8.6 percent, to 50 billion yen, for the year ending next March. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: A Seat of Honor Lost to Open Political Warfare
description: By all appearances, Ahmad Chalabi reached the pinnacle of influence in Washington four months ago, when he took a seat of honor right behind Laura Bush at the president's State of the Union address. To all the world, he looked like the Iraqi exile who had returned home victorious, a favorite of the Pentagon who might run the country once the American occupation ended.

title: A Scene from the Ice Age
description: KANGERLUSSUAQ, GREENLAND, May 20 It could have been the tail end of the Ice Age, 13,000 years or so ago, and the scene would likely not have been different. A carpet of brushy shrubs, lichens and grasses, just showing the first green tinge of spring, ran up a U-shaped valley and over a ridge, ending just in front of the towering frozen walls marking the perimeter of this Arctic islands giant ice cap, two miles deep at its heart.

title: 'Gooks' To 'Hajis'
description: The hapless Jeremy Sivits got the headlines yesterday. A mechanic whose job was to service gasoline-powered generators, Specialist Sivits was sentenced to a year in prison and thrown out of the Army for accepting an invitation to take part in the sadistic treatment of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Warring Parties Find Unity (of Sorts) on Offshore Drilling
description: There is no immediate push to begin oil and gas production off Florida , North Carolina and other coastal states that have long resisted rigs, but that is not stopping either Republicans or Democrats from using the threat of drilling as a campaign issue.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday on perfect games in baseball included an incorrect date for one. Jim Bunning's perfect game in 1964 followed Cy Young's by 60 years, not 40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUDERMAN, BEATRICE
description: RUDERMAN -- Beatrice of Floral Park, and Boca Raton, FL passed away Thursday May 20, 2004. Formerly of Jamaica Estates, raised in New London, CT. Wife of the late Manuel Ruderman. Mother of Eric (Mimi) Ruderman and Annie (Bob) Gad. Grandmother of Ashlee Margolis, Max Gad and Nicholas Ruderman. Services Sunday 11:00 am May 23, 2004 Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale. For info Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLIS, ABRAHAM
description: ELLIS -- Abraham. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Medical Center note with sadness the passing of our cherished friend, devoted supporter and generous benefactor, Abraham Ellis. Abe's analytical mind and keen sense of humor were greatly valued by the members of the NYU Medical Center community. Alongside his beloved wife, Nan, Abe has played an important role in the life of NYU Medical Center in the past and has generously provided for its future. As with his many friends of a lifetime, we are grateful for the long association with this exceptional man. We send our sincere condolences to Nan and other family members. Robert M. Glickman, M.D. Dean, New York University School of Medicine CEO, NYU Hospitals Center

title: Bush Camp Tweaks Kerry Over Unconventional Idea
description: The novel idea that John Kerry might not exactly accept the Democratic presidential nomination at the convention in Boston in July in order to preserve his ability to raise and spend private money had the political world buzzing this afternoon.

title: HEALTHSOUTH BONDHOLDERS REJECT DELAYED PAYMENTS
description: A group of 13 HealthSouth bondholders said yesterday they had rejected a company offer to delay some payments and filings as the company tries to restructure $3.34 billion of debt. The investor group, which said it held most of the 6.875 percent notes due in 2005 and the 7 percent notes due in 2008, was not identified. Last week, HealthSouth said some bondholders had agreed to allow the company to delay some payments and filings in return for a payment. In a statement yesterday, the dissident bondholders called HealthSouth's offer inadequate. The company has said it needs flexibility to renegotiate debt while auditors finish inspecting its books and restating financial results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIL, ALINE P.
description: WEIL--Aline P. on May 20, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Mother of Nancy Rosenthal, loving grandmother of Bradley Alan, Kim, Andrew and Jonathan. Greatgrandmother of Bradley Thomas, David, Kevin, Amanda, Aaron, Lily, Sasha, Eli, Jami and Zoe. Service private.

description: "A Streetcar Named Desire," starring Patricia Clarkson as Blanche DuBois, has been revived as part of the Tennessee Williams summer festival at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

description: Some homes around the region that are priced at the approximate median for their area, or recently sold in that range.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Sets Election Date
description: Officials in Chechnya set Aug. 29 for an election for a successor to its Moscow-backed president, Akhmad Kadyrov, who was killed this month in a bomb attack in Grozny, the Chechen capital. He was elected in an internationally criticized vote last October. Sergei B. Abramov, the Kremlin-appointed prime minister of Chechnya, has taken over as acting president. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Bulletproof Vests Collected To Help a Son's Unit in Iraq
description: Before his unit shipped from Kuwait to Iraq in March, First Lt. Christian Boggiano, 23, made a special appeal to his mother, Mary, by e-mail message. Please, he asked, scrounge around for a few old police bulletproof vests and mail them to me.

title: Corrections
description: An article in sports on Thursday about the former gymnast Dominique Dawes, who is beginning a term as president of the Women's Sports Foundation, misspelled the name of her hometown. It is Silver Spring, Md., not Silver Springs.

title: Samuel Iwry, 93, Expert on Hebrew
description: Samuel Iwry, an expert on Hebrew who helped prove the antiquity of the Dead Sea Scrolls, died in Baltimore on May 8, Johns Hopkins University announced. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BACKSTEDT, LARRY
description: BACKSTEDT -- Larry. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend, Larry Backstedt. His generosity, wisdom, humor and kindness will be with us forever. Our hearts are with his loving wife, Roseanne, and cherished daughter, Simone. Gil and Michele Schaye and Family

While he used to conduct it at the summer Ravinia Festival, he does not conduct it regularly.

description: American Airlines, Continental Airlines and three other carriers dropped a fare increase of as much as $20 one way in some cities after a competitor declined to match the higher prices.

title: KERRY CONSIDERS STRATEGIC DELAY FOR NOMINATION
description: Senator John Kerry is considering delaying his acceptance of the Democratic presidential nomination until five weeks after the party's July convention so he may continue spending the tens of millions of dollars he has raised for the primary season, his aides said Friday.

title: 'Fahrenheit 9/11' Wins Top Prize at Cannes
description: CANNES, France, May 22 - At the awards ceremony that wrapped up the 57th Cannes Film Festival on Saturday night, the jury gave "Fahrenheit 9/11," Michael Moore's stinging critique of the Bush administration's foreign policies, the Palme d'Or, the festival's top prize and one of the most coveted honors in international cinema.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KREISLER, MARGARET
description: KREISLER--Margaret, age 92, on May 19. Wife of the late Kurt Kreisler, she lived in Pelham, NY before moving to Princeton, NJ in 1967. Funeral Mass 10AM Monday, May 24, St. James RC Church, Pennington, NJ. Interment private, Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, New Rochelle, NY

title: One Deal in a Big Charity Event Is a Chance for Experts Only
description: The world's most successful charity game celebrated its 41st birthday on Tuesday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. With most of the city's top players taking part, it raised more than $90,000 for U.J.A.-Federation.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO HIRE 325 ENGINEERS IN MICHIGAN
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it would hire 325 engineers in Michigan to do research for the Army's Future Combat Systems program of satellite-linked tanks and troops. The company will begin adding workers to its operations in Sterling Heights in August, a spokesman, Peter Keating, said. About $6.6 million will be invested in the expansion, he said.

title: Mayor Backs New Limits On Donations To Campaigns
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called yesterday for a law to prohibit individuals or companies that do business with the New York City government from making contributions to candidates for city offices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALSAM, JOY
description: BALSAM--Joy. We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Joy Balsam, a woman of extraordinary energy and spirit. Joy's passion for Jewish life, and her high standards of excellence, inspired us all. We will miss her. May her husband, Jerry Balsam, and the rest of her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Trustees and Staff of Avi Chai

title: National Briefing | Washington: Subpoena In C.I.A. Disclosure
description: A grand jury has subpoenaed a reporter for Time magazine, Matthew Cooper, in its inquiry into whether someone in the Bush administration disclosed the identity of a C.I.A. officer. Robert Novak, the syndicated columnist, first published the name of the officer, Valerie Plame. Time reported that government officials had identified Ms. Plame to it in interviews in an apparently in an effort to discredit her husband in a political dispute. Robin Bierstedt, deputy general counsel of Time Inc., said the magazine protected its sources and would move to quash the subpoena. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Conservative Group Amplifies Voice of Protestant Orthodoxy
description: Correction Appended

title: Turning Friend Into Foe in Baghdad
description: Thursday's raid on the Baghdad home of Ahmad Chalabi, the Iraqi Governing Council member who for more than a decade was America's staunchest ally among the Iraqi resistance, is the latest bit of madness in the bungled occupation of Iraq. Unable to protect the lives of the governing council members -- who, whatever one thinks of the body, are the only representative voices in Iraq -- the Coalition Provisional Authority has now apparently decided to humiliate any who have the temerity to criticize its plans.

description: To the Editor:

title: RESPIRONICS TO BUY PROFILE THERAPEUTICS OF BRITAIN
description: Respironics, a maker of treatments for breathing disorders, agreed to buy its British distributor, Profile Therapeutics, for about $44.6 million. Respironics will pay 50.9 pence (91 cents) for each outstanding share of Profile, the company said. The offering price is 16 percent more than Profile's closing price Thursday of 44 pence. Profile, based in Bognor Regis, England, has distributed Respironics' products in Britain for 15 years. The acquisition adds Profile's newest product, the Prodose treatment system for patients with cystic fibrosis, and is expected to boost Respironics' annual sales by $15 million to $20 million, the company said. Respironics is based in Murrysville, Pa.

title: A New Strategy Document Calls Attention to the Transition Between War and Peace
description: The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has approved a new national military strategy that makes clear to the nation's war planners that they must pay greater attention to preparing for the complicated and dangerous transition between the end of major combat operations and the return of civil authority.

title: Only a Few Spoke Up on Abuse As Many Soldiers Stayed Silent
description: Specialist Joseph M. Darby had just arrived at Abu Ghraib in October when his friend Specialist Charles A. Graner Jr. showed him a picture on his digital camera of a naked prisoner chained to his cell with his arms hung above him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trust Business Acquired
description: The Japanese banking company, Sumitomo Trust and Banking, agreed to buy UFJ Holdings's trust banking business for at least 300 billion yen ($2.68 billion), creating the nation's biggest provider of custodial and corporate pension fund services. Sumitomo Trust will take over UFJ Trust Bank's corporate pension and real estate businesses by March and its retail operations by the end of 2005. UFJ will hold a stake in a Sumitomo Trust company to manage the assets.

title: Are Saudis Using British Libel Law To Deter Critics?
description: ''House of Bush, House of Saud: The Secret Relationship Between the World's Two Most Powerful Dynasties'' (Scribner), Craig Unger's book about the tangled connections between President Bush and his circle and Saudi Arabia's royal family, became a best seller in the United States this spring, and is now being published in Germany, Spain and Brazil, among other places.

title: Patient-Abuse Charges Under Investigation
description: State health officials and the local police are investigating accusations that patients undergoing psychiatric or substance-abuse treatment at St. Vincent's Westchester Hospital in Harrison have been sexually abused or beaten by other patients, officials said on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 14 about psychological factors that motivate some people to resist wrongful orders misstated the title of Dr. Elliot Aronson, an expert on social influence at the University of California, Santa Cruz. He is an emeritus professor of psychology, not a professor.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Monsanto Wins Patent Case On Plant Genes
description: In a case central to the international debate over the right to patent gene-engineered organisms, Canada's Supreme Court ruled on Friday that a Saskatchewan farmer infringed Monsanto's patent on genetically modified canola, even though he said the seeds landed in his fields by accident.

title: Fire Chiefs Said to Be Angry Over New Rules
description: Senior fire chiefs are privately seething over the city's new protocols that establish the department's responsibilities at emergencies, and what they view as Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta's failure to protect the agency in the continuing turf war with the Police Department, fire union leaders said yesterday.

title: FAT SUBSTITUTE IS APPROVED FOR MICROWAVE POPCORN
description: The Procter & Gamble Company won approval yesterday from federal regulators for expanded use of its fat substitute Olean in microwave popcorn, the first time in six years a new product will have the ingredient. The Food and Drug Administration cleared Olean for use beyond a 1996 approval that limited it to ready-to-eat salty snacks, a company scientist, Greg Allgood, said. Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, gets about $50 million in annual sales from Olean, whose debut in 1998 was marred by customer concern it might cause cramping and loose stools. Olean, used in Procter & Gamble's fat-free Pringles chips and PepsiCo Inc.'s Wow! line of Frito-Lay snacks, can now enter the $1.3 billion market for microwave popcorn.

title: For Women, Plenty of Firsts At Olympic Wrestling Trials
description: Before she ever donned a singlet for her country, Tela O'Donnell worked on a drift net boat in Homer, Alaska, trolling for salmon in Kachemak Bay, connecting with the rhythms of her hometown.

title: 5 Afghans Die and 4 U.S. Soldiers Are Wounded in Clashes
description: Two Afghan policemen and a three other Afghans died in clashes in Afghanistan on Friday that left four American soldiers wounded. In a separate incident, Pakistani officials protested what they said was the second incursion by American forces into Pakistani territory in a month.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 3 about Harold H. Harmatz, an owner of Ratner's restaurant on the Lower East Side, omitted the names of former co-owners. They were the brothers Max and Louis Zankel, who shared ownership for many years with one of the restaurant's founders, Jacob Harmatz. They were succeeded by Max Zankel's son, Harry, who died in 1998.

title: Affordable Housing in Crisis
description: House Republicans who authorized cuts in federal housing subsidies for the poor are now fuming over the bad publicity about the cuts. It's strange that anyone was surprised at the negative reaction. The cuts place tenants in some cities at risk of losing subsidized housing, and financial institutions are beginning to express doubts about continuing to participate in the kinds of development projects that have built much of the nation's affordable housing.

title: AOL Rebounding From Subscriber Losses
description: America Online is ''stabilizing'' after losing subscribers for six consecutive quarters, Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive of its parent, Time Warner, said yesterday.

title: Urbanity Colors a Dark View of Life and Love
description: Stephin Merritt's voice isn't made for happy songs. It's low and somber, with glints of annoyance and melancholy, the sound of a morose witness to his own mishaps. Leading the Magnetic Fields, who started a two-night stand at Town Hall on Thursday night, he uses it for songs that teeter precisely between the droll and the doleful.

title: U.S. Preparing for Influx of Compensation Claims by Abused Iraqis
description: The Pentagon is preparing for an influx of compensation claims stemming from the charges of abuse at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, Defense Department officials said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAD, JAMES
description: GRAD--James, 85, on May 20, died after a long and courageous fight against cancer. Husband of the late Thelma (Lewis). Beloved and loving father of Adrian, Maxine and the late John. Devoted grandfather of Arlen Gaines, Rebecca Grad and Aaron Grad, Julia Adolphe, and Sophia, Noa and Elan Shems, and great-grandfather of Jaden Gaines. Cherished brother of Selma Edelstein and the late Anna Shaw. Best friend of Joyce Lowinson. Jim had a strong sense of principle and integrity and dedicated himself to enhancing the quality of life for others. His sweetness and strength were recognized by all who knew him. His departure leaves a void that can never be filled. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, May 25, at 1:00pm, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to New York University Law School.

title: Saudis Offer To Increase Oil Output By About 6%
description: In an effort to drive down record crude oil prices, Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer, offered on Friday to increase its output by at least 500,000 barrels, to 9 million barrels a day, starting June 1.

title: Europe Backs Russian Entry Into W.T.O.
description: Russia, with the last big economy outside the World Trade Organization, won support for membership in the group from the European Union on Friday and subsequently said it would support the environmental treaty on emissions known as the Kyoto Protocol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPPOCZY, NICHOLAS G.
description: LIPPOCZY -- Nicholas G. 1913-2004. Dearest father, loyal friend, we celebrate your generous life: Jurist, Ministry of Homeland Defense, Budapest; Founding Editor, ''Hungaria''; Editor-in-Chief, New York's ''Nepszava''; DYFS social worker; Chairman, American Hungarian Museum. Thank you for your enormous vitality, humor, and encompassing love. Sometimes a heart must break to free the soul. Live forever in our hearts. Sunday Mass, May 23, 11:00 AM, St. Stephen's Church, 223 Third Street, Passaic, NJ 07055. Donations to The Dr. Lippoczy Miklos Memorial Fund, C/O American Hungarian Museum, PO Box 2049, Passaic, NJ 07055. Susanna Lippoczy Rich Morton D. Rich Alexander Nagy & Family Your many, many friends

title: Google Revises Data in Public Offering and Adds 29 Underwriters
description: Google Inc. amended its $2.718 billion initial public offering on Friday, adding 29 underwriters and revising some of the financial information in the form.

title: A Cozy Family Ready to Kill One Another
description: ''The Lion in Winter,'' which appears tomorrow night on Showtime, is not by Shakespeare. Characters don't talk in iambs, or reach unerringly for eternal themes. The English royal court is here -- King Henry II of England, along with his sons, Richard, Geoffrey and John, and his wife, Eleanor of Aquitaine -- but its speech is not only not Shakespearean, it's infected with clichs and anachronisms.

title: Enron Gets $2.2 Billion For Gas Lines
description: Oscar S. Wyatt, the Texas oilman known for his dealings with Muammar el-Qaddafi and Saddam Hussein, is back in the energy business. Mr. Wyatt and a group of investors agreed to buy Enron's natural gas pipelines in North America for $2.2 billion, Enron's acting chief executive said on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the use of giant pouched rats to find land mines in Mozambique used an erroneous given name at one point for a man who breeds and conditions them -- cited earlier in the article as an originator of the project. He is Bart Weetjens, not Marc.

title: Attention, Bank Robbers: No Need to Case Austin. It's Already Taken.
description: In a city that congratulates itself on all its oddities, a torrent of bank robberies this year is giving new meaning to the local slogan, Keep Austin Weird.

title: Wrapping a Familiar Name Around a New Product
description: If you yanked open the drawers and cupboards of American kitchens in the consumer-crazy years after World War II, you would have found some of the same products in almost every home.

title: Laborer's Death Prompts Homicide Investigation
description: The job paid $90 a day with no benefits. It required heavy lifting while balancing on flimsy platforms three stories high, exposed to the elements but not to the knowledge that the work flouted safety rules and construction blueprints.

title: Arab Meeting Expected to Produce Mostly Criticism of U.S.
description: Arab leaders gathering for a summit meeting on Saturday and Sunday in this North African capital are expected to issue a collective criticism of the United States for the abuse of Iraqi prisoners and what they view as the anemic American effort toward ending the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Moving to Fuel Efficiency; Smaller S.U.V.'s Draw More Attention as Gasoline Prices Rise
description: At Village Ford, a dealership here in the backyard of the Ford Motor Company, one corner of the display window shows an Explorer, the sport utility vehicle that has been a stalwart of the company's sales for years.

title: A Gadfly Criticizes China's Powerful, Within Limits
description: FOR anyone interested in the debate over whether a Communist-ruled China is capable of evolving into a land of free expression, there are few more compelling cases than Zhou Meisen.

title: Weakening the Rules for Judges
description: The special commission weighing revisions to the American Bar Association's code of judicial conduct seems to have missed the lesson of Justice Antonin Scalia's notorious duck-hunting trip with Vice President Dick Cheney: Americans don't appreciate it when judges behave in ways that undermine the judicial system's fairness and integrity.

title: City Agencies May Be Asked To Hire Those On Welfare
description: City officials confirmed yesterday that the mayor's office was considering requiring all city agencies and vendors to consider welfare recipients for a limited number of entry-level positions.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about the perfect game pitched by Randy Johnson on Tuesday night and other exceptional performances this season by older baseball players misstated Johnson's earned run average. It is 2.43, not 2.83.

title: Stewart Stock Case Is Jolted by Charge That an Agent Lied
description: The case against Martha Stewart took a strange twist yesterday as the government charged that an important witness lied repeatedly at her trial.

title: U.S. Announces It Intends to Move Tons of Uranium From Sealed Baghdad Repository
description: The United States has informed an international agency that oversees nuclear materials that it intends to move hundreds of tons of uranium from a sealed repository south of Baghdad to a more secure place outside Iraq, Western diplomats close to the agency say.

title: Hernandez v. Brown
description: With commemorations from coast to coast to remind them, most Americans already know that this week was the 50th anniversary of Brown v. Board of Education. Unfortunately, what they don't realize is that the country missed an equally important anniversary two weeks ago, that of Hernandez v. Texas -- the perennially overshadowed antecedent to Brown that was decided on May 3, 1954.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Diplomat Hurt In Blast
description: A powerful bomb blast at a Muslim shrine in the northeastern town of Sylhet killed two men and wounded nearly 50 others, including the newly appointed British ambassador. title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN WINS $1.39 BILLION NAVY CONTRACT
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it won a $1.39 billion contract to prepare for construction of the Navy's next-generation nuclear aircraft carrier, the CVN-21. The award includes the continued design of the vessel's propulsion plant and efforts aimed at reducing weight and manpower requirements, Northrop said in a statement. Northrop's Newport News unit won a $304 million contract earlier to design the carrier. Construction is expected to start in 2007, with delivery in 2014. A production contract may be worth as much as $5 billion, the company said. The company bought Newport News, located in the Virginia city of the same name, in 2002 for $2.5 billion. Northrop is based in Los Angeles.

title: 'The Wisdom of Crowds': Problem Solving Is a Team Sport
description: Generations of advertisers and business gurus have banked on the premises of Sigmund Freud's ''Group Psychology and the Analysis of the Ego,'' a slender volume with a big argument: when people assemble en masse, all the raw material making up the individual psyche (libido, aggression, whatever) is also present, but on a gigantic scale. And the power for rational thought is thereby dwarfed. The crowd is considerably dumber than its smartest members. This explains, for example, Britney Spears, irrational economic exuberance and the occasional episode of public yearning for an authority figure to do the superego's job, whether by seizing state power (the fascist dictator model) or by going on television to say ''You're fired'' (the reality TV version).

title: TECUMSEH TO COMBINE OPERATIONS AND CUT 380 JOBS
description: The Tecumseh Products Company, a maker of lawn mower engines and air-conditioner compressors, said yesterday that it would consolidate some assembly and distribution operations and cut 380 jobs in Michigan and Missouri as customers move overseas. Compressor machining and assembly operations will be transferred from a factory in Tecumseh, Mich., where the company is based, to Tupelo, Miss. Its spare-parts distribution units in Clinton, Mich., will be moved to Tecumseh, the company said. The cuts will cost about $11 million to $14 million pretax, mostly in the second quarter. Tecumseh is also closing its electrical components plant in St. Clair, Mo., and eliminating 40 manufacturing and assembly jobs.
