title: An Abu Ghraib Investigation
description: It has been gratifying to see Senator John Warner, the Republican who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, lead a bipartisan effort to look into the abuse of prisoners in Iraq. The hearings have already done far more than the Pentagon ever intended to do in providing a public airing of the Abu Ghraib disaster. But with each day's horrible revelations, it seems evident that the hearings will not be enough. It is also hard to believe that the military's own investigations will yield much, given the shifting of blame offered up by top Pentagon leaders, who continue to insist that the nightmare at Abu Ghraib was an isolated case of unsanctioned behavior by a few sick soldiers.

description: KORET -- Samuel (Sonny). Born in Brooklyn, N.Y. and living in Houston, Tx for the past 28 years, passed away on May 20, 2004, two days before his 87th birthday. He was pre-deceased by Bernice, his adored wife of 51 years, and is survived by his loving son David, his devoted daughter Tia Pierce and her husband Mark and his only grandson Logan. He leaves a very close, extended family of cherished nephews - David and Leonard Glass, Neil Goldman, his niece Mina Goldberg and his remaining brother (in-law) Michel Goldman. He had a far-reaching business history that began with over 30 years as Principal of a handbag manufacturing business. He was in the textile import business in Hong Kong and the shoe import business in Florence, Italy. For the last 26 years of his life, Mr. Koret was the Vice President and Managing Broker for Helmsley-Spear, Inc. in Houston until the time of his death. In a lifetime of commercial experience that covered the globe, he leaves a legacy of devoted friends that were more like family than business associates. He served during WW II as Executive Officer of the Coast Guard Frigate Peoria. Services will be held on Sunday, May 23 at 1pm at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer at 114-03 Queens Blvd in Forest Hills, N.Y.

Verizon, which had $44.4 billion in debt at the end of March, is seeking to lower borrowings by selling assets. Carlyle, based in New York, manages $19 billion in assets. Sales of Dr. Pepper have increased 4 percent. ''Cadbury has made a good start to the year,'' said Andrew Saunders, an analyst at Numis Securities. ''There was concern last year the U.S. beverage business had started to mature but that doesn't seem to be the case.''

title: One Very Tangled Post- 9/11 Affair
description: It was the evening of Sept. 10, 2002, when John Zazulka, a New York City firefighter, sat down with his wife, Susan, in their Staten Island home and told her that their marriage of 19 years was over. At least that's how Susan remembers it, the eve of the one-year anniversary of 9/11, the last night of the worst year of their lives. John, on the other hand, says it might have been a few weeks before, or after, or who knows, maybe Susan even remembers it right, but so what -- if so, he says, it was just a coincidence, one of those things that everyone wants to see as a symbol of something more than it is. He isn't, he says, a big one for reading too much into things.

Buddy, the obsequious tabby cat, that day's edition of this newspaper, the evocative oil riverscape, the helmet-like brass lamp beneath it, the fly screens on the window, even the apartment itself, 500 square feet in a 1920's tenement on East 98th Street -- all were at one time or another somebody else's refuse, thrown out and subsumed into that riotous, rich landscape of trash that makes New York City the best picking ground in the world.

title: The Vet Wars
description: Two months ago, on the eve of the Georgia presidential primary, John Hurley was crisscrossing the state in a Ford Econoline van, looking for votes -- and for veterans. Hurley, a silver-haired 61-year-old Boston lawyer, is the veterans' coordinator for John Kerry's presidential campaign and like the candidate is a Vietnam vet. Together with five other veterans of that war -- including Max Cleland, the triple amputee and former Georgia senator, and two men who served on a Swift boat that Kerry commanded on the Mekong Delta 35 years ago -- Hurley formed what he called a Veterans Brigade for Kerry, which traveled to nine Georgia cities in four days. Along the way, at small rallies in restaurants and union halls, the brigade championed Kerry as a military hero and a steadfast leader. ''John Kerry saved our lives in Vietnam, and we saved his life,'' Del Sandusky, one of Kerry's former crewmates, told a crowd of about 20 people outside Macon's City Hall on a Sunday afternoon. ''We have a special bond, and we call ourselves the Band of Brothers.''

title: How Fast They Grew
description: IT'S that time again. Every year on an evening in June, the other faculty members and I at Mamaroneck High School put on our academic robes for the graduation ceremony, leading the march of new graduates. It is my chance to experience the exhilaration of stepping onto a football field in uniform to the sounds of a cheering crowd and the school band. For me, the occasion is just a yearly ritual, but for the graduates and their parents and family, it is a milestone.

title: FAST FOOD, THE VENETIAN WAY
description: WE landed in Venice with hearty appetites last summer, and knew exactly where we weren't going to eat. Camera-clickers bounced around tables in the Piazza San Marco like unwieldy bumper cars, and from restaurant terraces overlooking canals, diners suffered the gondoliers' ear-splitting serenades to floating fleets of package-tour grandes dames. La Serenissima it most definitely was not.

title: Four Designs Compete For Les Halles Makeover
description: TEARS were shed when the 19th-century iron-and-glass market known as Les Halles was torn down in the early 1970's, and before long weeping resumed, first over the giant hole that scarred the heart of Paris for a decade, then over the grim multifloor shopping mall and transportation hub that eventually filled it. In this city, at least, the ugliness of Les Halles today is matched only by that of the Tour Montparnasse, the single skyscraper in central Paris. Many here would love to see both demolished.

title: Sights of Silence
description: North Korea is a whisker smaller than my home state, Mississippi. But when I heard about the explosion last month at Ryongchon train station, I knew I was in for a long, hard drive. As the crow flies, it was 300 miles. But I was in the northeast corner of the country, near the Russian border, when I heard the news on the BBC. With North Korea's bumpy dirt roads and circuitous routes, our convoy of white Toyota Land Cruisers faced a three-day, 800-mile road trip. In March, I moved from Zambia to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea and took over the United Nations World Food Program mission, the largest foreign aid program in North Korea. Because I knew our office and staff 10 miles from the blast site at Ryongchon would be overwhelmed, I had to go.

title: An Excess of Democracy
description: LIKE we needed a reminder that the American electoral system is flawed. Millions of ''American Idol'' viewers vote, by phone and by text message, for their favorite contestants. But this season the votes have been so capricious, and have pushed the show so far from its stated purpose -- to find the best unknown singer and make him or her a star -- that even the panel of judges has disavowed the results. When La Toya London, a 25-year-old Anita Baker sound-alike, was voted out of the competition on May 12, Randy Jackson called it a ''travesty.'' In April, Simon Cowell, the most outspoken of the show's three judges (who pick the initial pool of contestants, but do not control the selection of a winner) told Entertainment Weekly, ''I'm over this year.'' And even Paula Abdul, the judge who never has a bad word to say, told Ellen DeGeneres during an interview that she cannot begin to predict who will emerge victorious on the season's final show, this Wednesday, because ''logic is thrown out the window.''

title: Larchmont Station To Get a Face-Lift
description: Metro-North Railroad has begun a $12.4 million improvement program at its Larchmont station, one of the busiest suburban stops. The station underpass at Larchmont and a portion of the inbound platform will be closed for about three months for the first phase of the work. Other planned improvements include: replacing the the overpass with one that is fully enclosed, heated and served by elevators; and building a new ticket office on the inbound platform with a restroom, air conditioning, concession stand and mosaic artwork. On the platforms, the canopy roofing will be replaced and the lighting improved. New benches, signage and a public address system will be installed, in addition to wheelchair access. The work is expected to take two years. Larchmont's original train station was torn down during the 1950's to make way for the New England Thruway, said Marjorie Anders, a spokeswoman. The last major work at the current station was the installation of a sound barrier two years ago to muffle noise from cars and trucks along Interstate 95.

After a few minutes my worried mind and eyes cleared to the degree that I could see that I was sitting on the edge of the grandest collection of white pine stumps that I had ever seen. They were simply immense, with several so large that three men with hands joined couldn't have encircled them. I had inadvertently discovered a stump shrine. I counted thirty. The soil must have been perfect for white pine and one could only imagine them rising a couple of hundred feet in toward the sky. My skin tingled though my heart and mind felt sore.

title: 'After'

His family would call that day, looking to comfort and to be comforted, and discover a woman who was not quite stable. The newspapers would also surely want a quote, some sort of quote, something to give to their readers the kind of cathartic release that only a stoic, grieving widow could provide. But she could no longer be stoic, nor grieving. Day by day, month after month, without her attending to it, her grief had subtly changed its shape, until what was left was not quite grief at all, but something she could only describe as desire. She ate with her fingers. She slept naked. Grocery boys aroused her.

I loved having this completely separate world from my life in Memphis. Once we went canoeing in Canada. It wasn't easy, portaging through the mud. I was this skinny, tiny little weakling but I loved it. At home, I was always the last one picked for basketball. At camp, I wrote clever, goofy skits. I tried new activities. I water skied. Water skiing at camp was the most fun I've ever experienced in my whole life. I would sob at the end of every summer as if my life were ending.''

They were married June 5, 1932 in New York. After moving to Miami Beach in 1935, Leonard founded Dade Millwork and Lumber Company. In the 1930's he built four hotels on South Beach. With the war raging in Europe, he sold his businesses to be ready for the draft. Eye problems kept him from serving. On Sunday, December 4, 1949 Leonard helped found, Mt. Sinai Hospital for which he and Marjorie had been raising funds since 1946. In 1984, Leonard gave a gift to found the Wien Center for Alzheimer's Disease and Memory Disorders at Mt. Sinai. This Center has helped more than 10,000 patients. On May 6th, Leonard celebrated his 95th birthday with by 150 family members and friends. He is survived by his children Carole Langer, Josie Kenin and Leonard A., Jr., eight grandchildren, and 14 greatgrandchildren. Services were held on Thursday in Miami.

description: WEINBERG--Dale. October 21, 1948, died May 13, 2004. Beloved mother, friend and mentor. Predeceased by her parents, Milton and Joyce Glaser and her brother Neil, she is survived by her daughter Tracy Joyce Weinberg. The Director of Operation Enterprise since 2000, she joined that organization in 1998 as a speaker and advisor. Prior to that, Dale ran Technically Write, a consulting practice which she formed in 1978. She wrote and edited more than 150 manuals for computer products/ systems. She was also a master scuba diver, avid skier, voracious reader, patron of the theater, and world traveler. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMMEL, DR. LESLIE M.
description: HAMMEL--Dr. Leslie M., on May 8th, 2004 in Palm Desert, CA. Born-October 5, 1911, Budapest, Hungary. An International Mining Geologist, received his doctorate in 1936 from the Royal Hungarian Joseph Nador University of Technical and Economical Sciences, in Budapest, Hungary. He authored a textbook and lectured extensively in his specialty of the coal industry. He was a member of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, and for 25 years, was the last General Manager of the Hungarian General Collierry Company, Limited. In 1956, the Government of Vienna, Austria recommended him to the Bureau of Mines in Washington, D.C. where he started his second career. This Bureau was the largest coal mining corporation and industrial enterprise in Central Europe. He made significant contributions in the development of coal, iron ore, and copper, in South America, Australia, and South Africa. His position as Vice President of Eisenberg and Company, a large international organization, took him to 19 countries on five continents, where he had a working knowledge of six languages. He was a member of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical, and Petroleum Engineers Society, Mining and Exploration Society, and a senior member of the Society of Mining Engineers. In 1983, he was listed in the Who's Who in Mineral Engineering. In addition to his personal and professional achievements, he was a sensitive, G-d-fearing and honorable man, who was kind, considerate, and the personification of a gentleman. He gave his love, time, and boundless energy to his family, where he was looked up to as a father figure. Dr. Hammel was also a very generous man, and was deeply committed to the Park Avenue Synagogue, where he was a member for over 40 years, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, the 92nd Street Y, and many other organizations which he supported anonymously. He is survived by his wife, Eszter Moritz Hammel, (his first wife of 49 years, Clara Rittersporn Hammel, passed away in 1996), his sister, Gabriella Noszlopi, his nephew, Prof. George Noszlopy, his great-nieces, Dr. Laura Noszlopy and Nina Noszlopy Williams, his great greatnephews, Matthew Noszlopy and Robert Williams, and the LeNard and Schweitzer families in Washington, D.C. A memorial service will be held today at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St., NYC, at 12 noon.

In a parallel universe, these acoustic-guitar laments and joyful digital dancehall tracks might reach beyond the reggae world, converting NPR listeners and XXL readers alike. As it is, this album is more likely to remain an underground hit, reaching fans who already cherish Ms. Stephens's pinched but expressive voice and earthy obsessions: one spoken-word piece describes a 10-second sexual encounter that ends in snores (his) and tears (hers). Still, Ms. Stephens deserves an award for recording one of 2004's best battle-of-the-sexes songs, ''Tek Him Back,'' in which a mistress realizes her mistake: ''Have a cute face, but him nah perform/ So tek him back, wifey tek him back.''

title: Witnesses of World War II
description: The harsh black-and-white images in MEMORIES OF WORLD WAR II: Photographs From the Archives of The Associated Press (Abrams, $40) hauntingly depict the horrific global struggle that cost millions of lives and transformed the geopolitics of the 20th century. The famous images are all here: Douglas MacArthur triumphantly striding through the surf in the Philippines; an intense Dwight D. Eisenhower giving last-minute words of encouragement to camouflage-painted American paratroopers before D-Day; and, of course, Joe Rosenthal's iconic shot of marines raising the flag at Iwo Jima. But it is the less heroic photographs that are the most moving, like those of an anguished Polish girl in a field mourning her bloodied sister, killed by German machine-gun fire; a Frenchman's face, etched in a tearful grimace, as he watches France's historic regimental flags being carried through the streets of Marseille on their way to Algeria for safekeeping; two dead marines lying in the soft volcanic ash of Iwo Jima. Each photograph is accompanied by a succinct, informative description, and the volume contains an incisive foreword by former Senator Bob Dole, a veteran of the war, and an introduction by Walter Cronkite, a war correspondent in Europe. Chris Patsilelis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONARD, CHARLES INMAN
description: LEONARD--Charles Inman, 80, of New York City, died May 6 at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He is survived by his wife Mary Anne Leonard, his daughter Christopher I. Silva, his son Kim W. Leonard and four granddaughters, Victoria, Rebecca, Christina and Sarah. He was born January 6, 1924 in Albany, Georgia. He joined the Boy Scouts in 1938, becoming an Eagle Scout in 1939 and attained the Order of The Arrow. A member of SAE while attending Georgia Tech, in 1942 he enlisted in the USAAC. He flew his first combat sortie as a wingman of the 33rd Fighter Group (Terry and the Pirates), 60th Fighter Squadron (Fighting Crows), against the Japanese in Burma on Armistice Day (11 November) 1944. He flew 123 combat sorties in P-47 Thunderbolts and P-38 Lightnings. His military decorations included Good Conduct, American Campaign, Asian Campaign with three Battle stars, Air Medal with Oak Leaf Clusters and the Distinguished Flying Cross. Following his military discharge and return to Georgia Tech, he spent five years in heavy construction in Morocco and eight years on Military Base construction in Spain, where he published ''Bullfight Handbook''. In 1962 he returned to New York and became an investment banker. He was a member of CBIVA, Burma Star, AFEES, P-47 Thunderbold Pilots Assoc., and volunteer at New York Veterans Hospital. In 2001 he was awarded the Conspicuous Service Award by the State of New York and in 2003 his name was inscribed on The National Aviation and Space Exploration Wall of Honor by the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum. A memorial service will be held at the VA Hospital on East 23rd St., NYC on Wednesday, June 23, in the Medical Center Chapel. The family asks that donations be made to the VA in his memory. Inurnment in Arlington National Cemetery is scheduled for July 12 at 9 AM. All attendees must provide their own transportation on the cemetery grounds.

title: MOUNTAIN IN THE SEA, BOUNTY ON THE SHORES
description: CORSICA, the stunning French island outpost in the Mediterranean, has become a favorite getaway for Parisians fed up with the crowds on the Riviera but is less known to Americans. Which is too bad, because in addition to its beauty, the island is home to some good eating, if you seek it out. Corsica has three quite different cuisines: lusty country cooking, generic French food with stylish ambitions, and very fresh seafood, simply prepared. Frequent Italian influences testify to centuries of occupation by the Pisans and Genoese. Home-made pork products, local cheeses and chestnuts are used in abundance. Seafood is often grilled over wood and scented with saffron or maquis, the native mix of mountain herbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARKINS, JOSEPH J.
description: HARKINS--Joseph J. A retired Executive Vice President of the Chase Manhattan Bank, N.A., died at St. Luke's Hospital in Jacksonville, Florida, Tuesday, May 11, 2004. The cause was a stroke suffered while at home in Ponte Vedra Beach. He was born in New York City in 1931 and attended Fordham Prep and Fordham University, graduating in 1952. He served in the U.S. Army attaining the rank of First Lieutenant, and received his M.B.A. from New York University. Mr. Harkins joined Chase in 1954 and held numerous posts before being named Executive Vice President. Mr. Harkins also served as Chairman and Director of Chase Commercial Corp. and Chase Manhattan Service Corp., prior to his retirement in 1990. Mr. Harkins served on the Boards of Director of various organizations including J.P. Morgan Funds, Blessings Corp., Jefferson Insurance Company of New York, Monticello Insurance Company and National Corporation. He was a member of the Association of Reserve City Bankers and a member of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. Mr. Harkins is a past member of Ridgewood Country Club in NJ, and has been a longtime member of the New York Athletic Club and Sawgrass Country Club and Plantation Country Club in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. He was predeceased by his grandson, Ryan, and is survived by his wife of 49 years, Dorothy, along with his sons, Brian J. Harkins and Joseph F. Harkins, both of Summit, NJ; his daughter, Jeanne I. Davis, of Stanford, CT, and seven grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial was held on May 15th at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Ponte Vedra Beach. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the following charities: Joseph J. Harkins Scholarship Fund, Fordham University, Office of Development, Attention: Bruno Santonocito, 113 W. 60th Street, New York, New York, 10023 or Mayo Clinic, Department of Development, Attention: Mike McNamara or Kathleen Walsh, Mayo Foundation, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, MN 55905.

title: My Nightmare, My Neighbor
description: TEN years ago this April, the most focused, intense and efficient campaign of genocide in modern history took place in Rwanda. In the space of a few months, 800,000 Tutsis and tens of thousands of Hutus died in an orchestrated campaign of violence, organized by Hutu extremists. Everyone from church workers to children became murderers. The killing even pitted members of the same family against one another. When the massacres stopped and the Hutu regime that sponsored them had been driven from power, Rwanda faced a task as least as complicated as mourning or forgetting -- the task of justice. The criminal justice system is so small that it would take many years to get through the entire caseload. So a system of local tribunals, or gacacas (pronounced ga-CHA-chas), was established, staffed by elders and people elected by their community and conducted in the open air of villages. Rather than focusing on retribution, these tribunals offered freedom or reduced sentences for those who confessed to their crimes.

description: EIGHT times a week, Idina Menzel, who plays the witch Elphaba in the Broadway musical ''Wicked'' at the Gershwin Theater, covers her face, hands and neck with green makeup, then puts on a matching bodysuit so that she is the color of a snow pea from head to toe. Some days, she forgets to grab a meal before making up. Her dresser, Joby Horrigan, has learned to ask, ''Idina, did you remember to eat?'' If the answer is no, Ms. Horrigan peels an orange for her, or unwraps a Power Bar. ''Eating is awkward when you have green fingers,'' Ms. Menzel observes.

title: Page Two: May 16-22; PETRO TURMOIL
description: Crude oil prices soared above $40 last week and stayed there as markets fretted about robust demand in China and the United States. OPEC signaled its desire to bring prices down ahead of an informal meeting in Amsterdam this weekend, but few analysts expected such talk to result rapidly in lower prices.

description: PARIS  Why is it that Mario Cipollini's endlessly colorful career often seems to have sprung from the movies? The jet-set lifestyle, the closets full of bespoke suits and shoes, the toga he dons at especially celebratory moments  who else but Fellini?

title: Little Italy, Times 50
description: JUST 17 percent of New Jersey residents say they have Italian roots, according to the last census, but if the street festivals that have become a rite of summer are any gauge, thousands more are Italian in spirit.

title: Quirky East Bay
description: To the Editor: Your East Bay travel article included a number of good suggestions on how to experience the often underappreciated culture and cuisine of the East Bay. Unfortunately, the lodging suggested, the Claremont Resort and Spa, has been engaged in a long-running labor dispute with the Hotel and Restaurant Employees International Union, is regularly picketed and is boycotted by numerous groups.

title: Margaret Johnson, Richard Wager
description: Margaret Ann Johnson, a New York City press officer, and Richard Clarkson Wager, who is handling external affairs for the 2004 Republican National Convention, were married yesterday. The Rev. James F. Quigley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Child's Mishap With Match Faulted in Fire That Killed 4
description: A thick, smoky fire that killed four people in a Brooklyn apartment on Friday night began after a child playing in the living room dropped a lighted match between two couch cushions, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Ideas & Trends: Staving Off Starvation; When Real Food Isn't an Option
description: ALL the mukhet bushes near the refugee camps in eastern Chad have been picked clean, the World Food Program warns in its latest appeal on behalf of more than 100,000 Sudanese who have fled fighting in their country and now face starvation. Mukhet berries are poisonous, and must be soaked for days to leach toxins out. After drying, they are ground up, but the flour has little nutritive value.

title: Page Two: May 16-22; Iraq: One Plea In, One Rogue Ally Out
description: WITH only five weeks to go until a transfer of ''limited sovereignty,'' American officials in Iraq struggled to deal with a variety of political and military crises. On Wednesday, Specialist Jeremy C. Sivits, a 24-year-old soldier from a small Pennsylvania town, pleaded guilty to charges related to the abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib. As part of an agreement to testify against the other soldiers charged in the case, he was demoted, sentenced to a year in prison and ordered expelled from the United States Army.

title: The Search For P.M.D.'s
description: Sometimes you don't know whether to laugh or cry. Time.com reported last week that the F.B.I. had alerted law enforcement offices around America to be on the lookout for possible suicide bombers. Police forces were told to keep an eye out for people wearing bulky overcoats in the heat of summer, people with electric wires sticking out of their clothing, or people smelling of chemicals. Personally, if I see someone trailing electric wires, I am definitely calling the cops.

title: When Seller Is a Tenant Of the Buyer
description: AT most residential real estate closings, the transaction culminates in a dramatic moment when the seller gives the buyer a handful of keys -- and the right to possess the house or apartment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 2 about the inflated residential real estate market misstated the scope of New York State's ''mansion tax,'' which is 1 percent on the total price of homes costing $1 million or more. Condominium and cooperative apartments are indeed subject to it.

title: The Specialists
description: IT takes a lot of men to make a gun, as Stephen Sondheim wrote in a lyric for ''Assassins,'' and he probably wasn't even thinking of the people who make that gun safe enough to fire on a stage. It takes several to turn a man-eating plant into an audience-eating plant, or to send an actor crashing through a window night after night. It takes an intrepid set designer to create a moving train on a stationary platform. And it takes one brave actress to open a play with a striptease on a trapeze, yet never utter a word through all of the ensuing action. Melena Z. Ryzik asked the technical experts from five Broadway productions how they made their shows' special effects truly special.

title: Dana Gliserman, Matthew Kopans
description: Dana Heather Gliserman, a daughter of Judy and Jerry Gliserman of Toronto, is to be married today to Matthew Joshua Kopans, a son of Barbara Kopans and Dr. Daniel Kopans of Newton, Mass. Rabbi John Moscowitz will officiate at the Holy Blossom Temple in Toronto.

title: Click and Eat On the Road
description: ON a late night in January, Ira Azulay was getting ready for a trip to Mexico from Chicago when he remembered that he'd failed to make dinner reservations for the next night in Los Angeles, where he had a layover. ''I knew I wanted to go to a restaurant called Koi, and I knew I'd forget to call the next day,'' said Mr. Azulay, who practices business law.

title: Bet on It
description: Yes, I understand that they call it gambling (Gary Rivlin, May 9). However, the use of a wheel (''Wheel of Fortune'') certainly implies -- to me at least -- equal chance across all positions on the wheel. To manipulate that to produce disproportionately more near-misses (and fewer hits) is good old-fashioned deception -- if not theft. What is the difference between this and, say, weighted dice?

description: MANES -- Morton (Morty). Suddenly on Tuesday, May 18. Beloved husband of Anita. Devoted father of Alison and Steven Krasner, Nikki Manes, Elizabeth Bedard, Ken and Debbie Baker and Mark Baker. Cherished grandfather of Charles, Michelle, Racquel and Joshua.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOTZ, RICHARD PAUL
description: KOTZ--Richard Paul, 63, passed away peacefully after a long and courageous battle with lymphoma on May 15th, 2004. Formerly of Wilton, CT, Basking Ridge, NJ and Manhattan, he relocated to Bonita Springs, FL in 1999. He was a Wealth Management Advisor at Merrill Lynch after a long career as a senior executive at corporations such as American Express and Chase Manhattan Bank. He is survived by his wife of nine years, Joan Strand Kotz; father, Paul Kotz, of Lindenhurst, IL; son, David (Lisa), of Far Hills, NJ; daughter, Julie Richie (Chris), of Dallas; brother, Phillip Kotz, and sister, Carol Hays; and six grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Susan Jacobs Kotz. A family memorial will take place in August in Gloucester, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 3350 Woods Edge Circle, Suite 102, Bonita Springs, FL 34134.

title: In Step With Marching Bands
description: NOTHING draws a crowd in Columbus, Ohio, like college football, a civic ritual that combines choreographed steps with seat-of-the-pants improvisation. Concert dance is a much harder sell, but faced with a tight economy, BalletMet, the local ballet company, is rewriting its playbook in a bid to win bigger, younger audiences.

title: North Korea and Japan Sign a Deal on Abductions
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi flew to North Korea on Saturday to meet with Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader. After promising to give North Korea millions of dollars of medical aid and thousands of tons of rice, Mr. Koizumi flew home with five children of Japanese citizens abducted by North Korea almost a quarter century ago.

title: Oh Lad, Poor Lad
description: A new genre of commercial fiction, lad lit, was recently pronounced stillborn by Publishers Weekly, a mere month after its arrival had been announced by The New York Times and The Associated Press. Nothing stings quite so bitterly as cold numbers, so when the magazine printed that Nielsen BookScan had detected sales of only 1,716 copies of Kyle Smith's ''Love Monkey,'' an ostensible leader of the well-publicized ''trend,'' it had to hurt. An events planner at a Chicago bookstore chain was quoted saying that lad lit might attract women readers interested in ''spying on the other side, getting a look into the locker room,'' but she had to admit that the 10 stores in the chain she works for hadn't sold a single copy of either ''Love Monkey'' or another exemplar of the genre, Scott Mebus's ''Booty Nomad.''

title: Nothing Comes Easy on an Ice Cap
description: SWISS CAMP, ON THE GREENLAND ICE CAP, May 21  The agile Twin Otter aircraft, a legend of the Arctic that can land across a runway in a strong headwind if need be, dipped onto the snow after flying for an hour over the white vastness.

title: Wal-Mart's Expansion Aided By Many Taxpayer Subsidies
description: Wal-Mart Stores collected well over $1 billion in state and local government subsidies during its decades-long expansion from a regional discount chain to the world's largest retailer, according to a report scheduled to be released today by a group that monitors job-subsidy programs.

title: Where Progress Is Being Made In Albany; At the Landmark Capitol, Repairs Are on Track
description: It is freely said in this city, from the staid legislative chambers to the bars of Lark Street: Albany's democracy is a defective dominion, a weedy patch in the patio of politics.

title: Tribal Warfare in Iraq
description: The three factions controlling Iraq long suspicious of one another -- are now on the brink of open tribal warfare. Not the Sunnis, Shiites and Kurds -- I mean the Pentagon, State Department and C.I.A.

title: Whiplash
description: Ronald Reagan's acting career was moribund long before he became governor of California, not to mention president, but he knew that most politicians had to beg for the kind of visibility that came his way naturally from his Hollywood days. So even though he was caricatured and satirized in just about every way possible, he never seemed to be tempted to sue anyone to prevent them from using his image. As a movie star, Arnold Schwarzenegger was still a going concern when he became governor of California last year. And if anything proves that he is still more actor than politician, it is the lawsuit he recently filed against the company that manufactures and sells a satiric bobblehead doll in his image. The grinning, head-wagging parody wears a business suit and a bandoleer and carries an assault rifle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DIIORIO, JULIO
description: DiIORIO--Julio. 63, born in the Bronx, father, friend and advertising creative. Lost his 18 month battle with emphysema on May 19, 2004, after a courageous fight. Through the most difficult of times, Julio never lost his charismatic wit, his willingness to laugh and his ability to deeply move those he knew. His bravery and love of life are an inspiration for his daughters Nicole and Mia, grandson Nicolas and his family, who he loved and supported until his death. Services on May 25, 11:30 am, The Immaculate Conception Church, Gunhill Road, Bronx, NY.

title: Though It Wasn't Pretty, Chvez Exits a Winner
description: The plumes of cigarette smoke hung for one last instant under the ring lights as Julio Csar Chvez waved farewell to a standing ovation from the crowd. The cloudy formations then vanished in a warm breeze, much like Chvez, a six-time world champion who vowed to retire here Saturday night at Monumental Plaza Mexico.

title: For Saab, Some See the Beginning of the End. Others See the Middle
description: Saab loyalists have predicted the worst ever since General Motors bought its initial 50 percent stake in the Swedish automaker, for $500 million, in 1990. But an announcement last week by Saab Cars USA  that it would relocate its home office from Norcross, Ga., to G.M.s world headquarters in the Renaissance Center in Detroit  was seen as the final bit of proof that the odd little automaker, an upstart not so long ago, has indeed been integrated into the worlds largest industrial company.

description: THE six big broadcast television networks will emulate Houdini for the 2004-5 prime-time season, promising viewers and advertisers plenty of escapist entertainment.

description: PARIS:  At the heart of the European Commission's review of the proposed merger of Sony Music and BMG, the recording company owned by Bertelsmann, is the search for a satisfactory response to one question: Where do music prices come from?

title: Paul F. Wehrle, 82, Vaccine Expert
description: Dr. Paul F. Wehrle, a pediatrician and researcher who helped diagnose and devise treatments for polio, smallpox and other infectious diseases, died May 11 in San Clemente, Calif. He was 82.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire In Correction Center
description: A fire in a fourth-floor vent sent smoke through several floors of the Metropolitan Correction Center on Park Row in Lower Manhattan yesterday. It burned for almost an hour before 60 firefighters brought it under control at 8:40 p.m. last night, the authorities said. Fire officials said the blaze was confined to debris in the vent, off a machine room, and there were no injuries. But they said the response of firefighters was complicated by barricades and other high-security measures that have been in place at the center, a high security, 12-story federal jail. The cause of the blaze remained under investigation last night, the officials said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CONCEPCION, RENE

Readers are invited to submit manuscripts to the following e-mail addresses: opedcity@nytimes.com (for the City section), opedli@nytimes.com (for the Long Island section), and opedwest@nytimes.com (for the Westchester section).

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 9 about the reaction of Richard A. Clarke to testimony by his former boss, Condoleezza Rice, before the congressional commission investigating the 9/11 attacks -- in which he said her interpretation was radically different from his -- referred incompletely to the interviews he gave on the issue. In addition to talking to a few print journalists and ABC News, he was interviewed by ''All Things Considered,'' on National Public Radio. NPR pointed out the omission the day the article appeared; this correction was delayed through an editing lapse.

title: Metro Matters; Politics Takes Back Seat To Illogic
description: THE Republicans are coming to New York City, which can be an inexplicable place even to people who live here. It's part of what makes New York New York -- not understanding half of what goes on, or why.

description: A 7-year-old girl was thrown to her death from a ride at the Playland amusement park here on Saturday after she somehow wriggled out from her seat's protective lap bar and turned around to wave to her friends, the Westchester County Police said Sunday.

title: Sports of The Times; For West, Thoughts Are Still With Lakers
description: BEFORE Game 1 of the Western Conference finals between Los Angeles and Minnesota, I asked Jerry West what he thought his old team, the Lakers, would do. Without a pause, West said: ''They're going to win that series. It wouldn't surprise me to see them win in four or five games.''

title: Coalition Promoting Drug Discount Cards
description: Lobbyists for the elderly, blacks and Hispanic Americans said on Sunday that they had begun a nationwide campaign to ensure that 5.5 million low-income Medicare beneficiaries receive drug discount cards, with a bonus of $1,200 in free medicine over the next 19 months.

title: Offerings From Aspiring Underdogs (and Swagger From a Top Dog)
description: On Friday night nearly a dozen aspiring pop stars gathered in the last place you would expect to find them: onstage at Madison Square Garden, at Zootopia, a concert sponsored by Clear Channel's Top 40 New York radio station, Z100. There was one ringer in the bunch: Avril Lavigne, whose debut, ''Let Go,'' was one of 2002's best-selling albums. Just about everyone else on the bill was an underdog; the concert felt like a long, weird episode of ''American Idol.''

title: In Age of Terror, Police Leader Gains in Access and Influence
description: Last Tuesday, after the city's former police and fire commissioners endured hours of withering criticism from the commission charged with investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, the current police commissioner presented his views on how the city deals with current threats.

title: General Says Sanchez Rejected Her Offer to Give Address to Iraqis About Abuses
description: The top American general in Iraq, Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, rejected a recommendation in January that the military make a public Arabic-language radio or television address to the Iraqi people to confront accusations of abuse at Abu Ghraib prison, the former head of the military police at the prison said in an interview on Sunday.

title: First for Glavine and Mets? No and No
description: Tom Glavine has never considered himself a candidate to pitch a no-hitter. He has frequently been masterly in his 17-year career, but he has never been overpowering, relying more on guile, pitch placement and having the batter put the ball in play, and that is rarely a recipe for flawlessness. His own pitching coach says he is a Picasso, not a power pitcher.

title: A Volatile Jet Is on Scout's Honor
description: Each day this spring, Josh Evans left the Jets' weight room and went to an office upstairs. There, he flipped on a computer and studied the snippets of film of the nation's best college football players, diligently noting the skills of the defensive linemen he watched. In the darkened room, Evans, a defensive tackle for the Jets, began to erect a wall between himself and his pockmarked past.

She is survived by her sister Anne O'Connor of Harbor Springs, MI, and two brothers, Harold of Easton, CT, an Dudley of Fairfield, CT. title: The Greening of John McCain
description: Six or seven years ago, when he was a conventionally conservative senator from a reliably Republican Western state, John McCain could never have expected to find himself where he is now, all alone in the political catbird seat. One day he's touted as a possible running mate for John Kerry. The next he's assaulted by his own party with the kind of sputtering outrage that makes the target look good and the attacker look silly. House Speaker Dennis Hastert was so flustered by Mr. McCain's criticism of President Bush's wartime tax cuts that he accused the Arizona senator, a former prisoner of war, of knowing nothing about the meaning of sacrifice. All of which must amuse (when it does not pain) a man who relishes irony, political combat and the maverick's role.

title: 1904:Divorce Granted : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: NEWPORT, Rhode Island: Mrs. Sybill Katherine Wetmore Hoffman was today [May 23] granted a divorce from her husband, Mr. John Ellis Hoffman, who is living in Paris. The action was brought on the grounds of willful desertion and non support. Mrs. Hoffman was given the custody of her daughter Audrey, aged five years, and Mr. Hoffman made no contest. She deposed that she was married in 1896, and that her husband, while he was kind for six years, deserted her two years ago in Paris and caused her much suffering.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Critically Wounded In Attack
description: Three teenage boys beat a 20-year-old Astoria man with baseball bats on Friday night in what appears to be a case of mistaken identity, the police said yesterday. The teenagers had been in an argument earlier that night with another group of young men in the vicinity of 70th Street and 34th Avenue in Jackson Heights. They left and returned half an hour later with the bats and attacked Fernando Rodriguez, 20, at 9 p.m., the police said. Mr. Rodriguez was hit several times in the head, but it appeared that he had not been involved in the original dispute, the police said. He was critical condition yesterday at Elmhurst Hospital Center, according to the police. Three teenagers were arrested at the scene by patrol officers from the 115th Precinct on assault and weapons charges. One was identified as Francis Calle, 16, of Jackson Heights; the identities of the two others were withheld because they are 15 years old. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: G.I.'s Report Killing 36 Insurgents Around Kufa Mosque That Held Arms
description: American troops attacked insurgents loyal to a rebel cleric around a mosque in the southern holy city of Kufa late on Saturday and early on Sunday, killing at least 36 fighters, military officials and witnesses said. Soldiers seized a cache of heavy weapons in the mosque afterward, the military said.

title: Mrs. Clinton and Lindsey Graham for 2008?
description: It is the talk of the capital  a presidential ticket featuring a Northeastern liberal Democrat and a Sunbelt Republican with a military background and an independent streak. Sure, they've had differences in the past, but they have moved beyond them at this point and might want to consider teaming up.

title: Limiting the Damage From Sharply Higher World Oil Prices
description: Executives and economists are wincing along with everyone else when they face the soaring tab for filling up the tanks of their cars. But when they put on their professional hats, many are anticipating surprisingly little pain from oil prices that have topped $40 a barrel. For now, it seems, consumers seem to be bearing the brunt of rising fuel costs.

description: Citing a misidentified fingerprint, a United States federal court in Portland today ordered that material witness proceedings be dismissed against an immigration lawyer who was being questioned in connection with the deadly Madrid bombings.

title: Hammon Has Right Moves in Home Opener
description: The Liberty limited Houston to 34.4 percent shooting from the floor, and Coach Richie Adubato said he would take that. The Liberty swarmed the Comets in rebounding, for an advantage of 37-30, and Adubato said he would take that, too.

description: Finance ministers from the United States and other major industrialized countries, hoping to affect the outcome of a battle within the Organization for the Petroleum Exporting Countries, formally demanded yesterday that oil-exporting nations raise production and lower prices to a level ''that is consistent with lasting economic prosperity.''

description: You may think of gout as a disease that afflicts wealthy, overweight middle-aged men who are prone to overindulgence. Known since antiquity as the patrician malady and a disease of kings, gout clearly had a penchant for people who could afford a life of gluttony and intemperance.

It was 276,101. (According to the United States Census, 610,000 was the population for Hudson County as a whole, not just Jersey City.)

description: Republicans, we hear, are frustrated by polls showing that the public has a poor opinion of George Bush's economic leadership. In their view, the good news about Mr. Bush's economic triumphs is being drowned out by the bad news from Iraq.

description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's address at the Army War College in Carlisle, Pa., yesterday evening, as recorded by The New York Times. A complete transcript is at nytimes.com/iraq.

title: The Indies of Perfumery
description: In the world of luxury fragrances, Vita is no ''Troy,'' an olfactory blockbuster lumbering onto the shelves of Nordstrom, Neiman Marcus or the vast global network of duty-free stores. Beth Terry, its maker, would more likely compare her confection of black currant, grapefruit and tea to an art-house product tailored to rarefied tastes. ''In my kind of business we have to have something not everyone is going to love,'' Ms. Terry said. ''That's the market that I cater to.''

Pictured in front of an airplane, Dr. Frist was at the left and Mr. Thune at the right. Senator Daschle was alone.

title: Grisly Crimes Described by Prosecutors as Mob Trial Opens
description: One man who had crossed Joseph C. Massino, prosecutors say, ended up in pieces stuffed in barrels in a New Jersey warehouse. Another was found in a shallow grave. A third tried a panicked escape from a hit in a Brooklyn social club, only to be punched in the head by Mr. Massino so the man would meet his fate in a blaze of gunfire.

title: C.I.A. Bid to Keep Some Detainees Off Abu Ghraib Roll Worries Officials
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's practice of keeping some detainees in Abu Ghraib prison off the official rosters so concerned a top Army officer and a civilian official there that they reached a written agreement early this year to stop.

title: Boston Ponders a Convention That Produces No 'Nominee'
description: First the city announced that a major commuter rail station, many downtown streets and a major highway would be closed to bolster security at the Democratic National Convention in the city's FleetCenter. Then the authorities said that nearly 40 miles of highways throughout the metropolitan area would be closed during the evening hours for the week of the convention for the same reason.

description: A Russian scientist at a former Soviet biological weapons laboratory in Siberia has died after accidentally sticking herself with a needle laced with ebola, the deadly virus for which there is no vaccine or treatment, the lab's parent Russian center announced over the weekend.

description: A coalition of advocacy groups charged yesterday that parent coordinators in New York City schools do not have enough translators to help the large number of parents who do not speak English.

description: A former convict raped his ex-girlfriend's 15-year-old daughter yesterday morning at her Staten Island town house and, after the girl ran and got help, barricaded the door with a sofa that he set on fire, the police said.

title: WICKS GROUP ACQUIRES THE DAILY RACING FORM
description: The Wicks Group, which invests in the communications, information and media industries, bought The Daily Racing Form, a newspaper that covers horse racing, from Alpine Equity Partners. The Daily Racing Form was founded in 1894 and publishes 30 editions daily, the Wicks Group said. The Wicks Group, based in New York, did not disclose the price paid. Steven Crist will continue as the chairman and publisher of The Daily Racing Form, the company said. Carl Fazio, previously the chief financial officer of Cygnus Business Media, will join the publication as its chief financial officer and chief operating officer.

description: ENGLANDER--Alan J. on May 24, 2004, at home. His wife Mary, daughter Diane, son-in-law Mark Underberg, grandchildren Andrew Englander Underberg and James Englander Underberg will always remember his gentle humor, intelligence and quiet affection. Memorial service will be held on June 4 at 3:30 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Loses Bid To Overturn Ruling
description: Microsoft yesterday lost a bid to overturn a judge's ruling on the validity of its Windows trademark before a trial begins in a lawsuit against Lindows Inc. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit declined to hear Microsoft's claim that a judge incorrectly ruled the validity of the Windows trademark could be based on how the term was used 20 years ago. Microsoft sued Lindows, a San Diego-based maker of Linux software, in 2001, saying the name Lindows confuses customers. Lindows said it was counting on the federal trial to show that Microsoft's trademark was not valid and help it fight similar lawsuits in Europe. Last month Lindows renamed its products Linspire to avoid penalties in Europe.

title: Hollinger International Agrees To Share Ex-Chief's Legal Costs
description: Hollinger International has agreed to advance Conrad M. Black, its ousted chief executive, half his legal costs, according to a recent court filing.

title: COINSTAR BUYS VENDING OPERATOR FOR $235 MILLION
description: Coinstar, which operates consumer coin-counting kiosks found in supermarkets, agreed to buy Wellspring Capital Management's ACMI Holdings for $235 million to gain the biggest operator of amusement vending machines. ACMI's American Coin Merchandising owns vending equipment that dispenses stuffed animals and other toys, as well as gumballs. ACMI has more than 167,000 machines in more than 18,000 locations, Coinstar said. Coinstar operates coin-counting machines, which allow consumers to convert their spare change to bills, as well as prepaid services, like credit cards and wireless telephone time.

title: Sharon Reportedly Will Avoid Bribery Charges
description: Israel's attorney general has decided against indicting Prime Minister Ariel Sharon on charges of accepting bribes from a real estate developer, Israeli television stations reported Monday night.

title: IRAQ UPDATE
description: BUSH VISION FOR IRAQ -- In a speech aimed at reassuring the world of Iraq's prospects for stable self-rule, the president outlined plans for the June 30 transfer of power, and said a United Nations envoy would announce leaders of the interim government this week. He said Abu Ghraib prison, where Iraqi prisoners were abused, would be demolished. [Page A1] Brig. Gen. Janis L. Karpinski was suspended as commander of the military police unit at the center of the abuse scandal. [Page 15]

description: ''I sent American troops to Iraq to defend our security, not to stay as an occupying power. I sent American troops to Iraq to make its people free, not to make them American. Iraqis will write their own history and find their own way.''

title: McGreevey Weighs Executive Order to Save His Highlands Project
description: Officials in Gov. James E. McGreevey's administration are scrambling to find ways to salvage his prized plan to protect water supplies in an 800,000-acre swath of the state. Among the options they are considering is an executive order to circumvent the Legislature.

They asserted in December that the prisoners are not fully covered by the Geneva Conventions; they did not rule out all protections for them.

description: It's not news that hospitals are full of sources of infection. But a study released yesterday found a new one: Almost half the ties worn by doctors in a Queens hospital proved to be carrying pathogens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, SAMUEL C.
description: JOHNSON--Samuel C. Cornell University mourns the loss of a devoted alumnus and trustee emeritus, Samuel C. Johnson, a visionary leader whose entrepreneurial spirit, deep commitment to his family, and loyalty to the University were extraordinary. A member of the Class of 1950 and a much - honored executive whose dedication to education and to the environment were legendary, he joined S.C. Johnson Inc. in 1954 and later became president and CEO. He championed policies of corporate philanthropy, community service, social responsibility, and a familyfriendly work life. He became a Cornell trustee in 1966 and served on numerous committees, and from 1990-1995 he co-chaired the campaign council during the University's capital campaign. He was a member of the Cornell University Council and served as a Presidential Councillor. In 1984, he and his family made the largest gift ever to a graduate school of business. As a result of his extraordinary generosity, the University named the Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management in honor of his great grandfather who founded the family business in 1886. He chaired the advisory council at the Johnson School and, among many other thoughtful and wise investments, endowed a professorship in sustainable global enterprise in 2003. He was a benefactor of Cornell's Laboratory of Ornithology and made innumerable gifts to support scholarships, campus life, and many other areas. Throughout the Cornell campus the Johnson name is synonymous with business education, the arts, and stewardship of natural resources. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Gene Powers Johnson, and to his daughters, Helen JohnsonLeipold and Winnie Johnson Marquart, and his sons, Curt Johnson and Fisk Johnson. Peter Meinig, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University Jeffrey S. Lehman, President, Cornell University

description: South Dakota is a pretty sparsely populated state with only three members of Congress, but right now it is the epicenter of the fight for control of the House and Senate.

description: Reggie Miller was coasting to the rim Monday night, a few steps remaining before he could reprise his role as the star of Game 1. The Indiana Pacers were trailing by 2 points in Game 2, having scored 4 consecutive points, and the clock was down to 17.9 seconds as Miller made the final step and rose for a routine layup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHANSON, DAVID
description: NATHANSON -- David. The Merrick Jewish Centre mourns the passing of our dear member David Nathanson, and extends heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Sue and family. We pray they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Linda Altman, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATTON, JOLANDA APREA
description: PATTON -- Jolanda Aprea, died at home in North Bergen, New Jersey on May 22, 2004. Her sense of vitality, strength and her unique artistry carried her through a life of extraordinary events both joyful and difficult. Born in Naples, Italy in 1911 into a family of painters and musicians. Growing up in Italy through two World Wars and the Great Depression. To America after the war to wed the now late Lowell Russell Patton, Jr. for 49 years of marriage. Bearing children, Lowell Russell Patton III and Cleonice Niki Patton and becoming grandmother to Briana Perry Patton. Creating a home, telling a story, singing, acting, teaching voice or Italian, refinishing a piece of furniture, sewing, simply talking--she was always compelling. Those who knew her were deeply attracted and affected by her astonishing passion for life. Her life was her art. Ah, Jolanda, you were greatly loved and you will be sorely missed--and now you are going home. Services will be held in Naples, Italy. Make donations to Hospice or a preferred arts organization if wished.

description: BERLIN  Why should busy executives be the only ones who get to reduce their commutes by flying?

title: A Translator's Long Journey, Page by Page
description: On Gregory Rabassa's crowded bookshelves is a first edition of ''Rayuela,'' the experimental 1963 novel by the Argentine novelist Julio Cortzar. Mr. Rabassa had just finished his Ph.D. in Portuguese in the mid-1960's when an editor at Pantheon -- who had noticed his work editing a failed literary magazine at Columbia University -- asked him to translate Mr. Cortzar's book from Spanish into English. Without having read what has been called a ''fiendishly esoteric'' novel, Mr. Rabassa sat down and typed a draft in English, word by word. In 1967 Mr. Rabassa's work, titled ''Hopscotch'' in English, won the first National Book Award for translation.

title: Assembly Vote to Address Tardy Budgets Is Too Tardy
description: ALBANY, May 24 - The State Assembly had intended to pass a bill on Monday to end the 20-year cycle of late budgets, but because of a technicality, the legislation will have to wait until the lawmakers return from their six-day Memorial Day holiday, which starts on Wednesday, to vote on it.

description: BRUEN--Edward F.L. The Board of Directors of Youth Foundation, Inc. notes with profound sorrow the passing of its distinguished Director Emeritus, Edward F.L. Bruen on May 23, 2004. title: SPIEGEL TO SELL CATALOG UNIT TO PANGEA HOLDINGS
description: Spiegel has reached an agreement to sell its flagship catalog business to a private equity firm, Pangea Holdings, after sales fell almost 50 percent last year. The deal is valued at $53.4 million. Pangea will pay $2 million in cash; honor an estimated $22 million in orders Spiegel made; and take on $29.4 million of debt, according to papers filed with Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York. Spiegel has been marketing its three divisions to raise money to repay creditors owed about $1.5 billion since the company filed for bankruptcy protection in March 2003. Pangea got approval last week to buy Spiegel's Newport News women's apparel unit for $28.6 million. Spiegel is in talks with prospective purchasers for its Eddie Bauer clothing chain, the largest of the three main units. Eddie Bauer had sales of $1.27 billion last year, a company spokeswoman, Debbie Koopman, said.

title: No Role in Shrine Damage, U.S. Says; Clash Kills 13 Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 25  For the second time this month, the shrine of Imam Ali, one of the holiest sites for Shiite Muslims, suffered minor damage today as clashes continued between United States forces and militiamen loyal to the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr in Najaf and in the adjacent city of Kufa. At least 13 people were killed in the last day, hospital officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: China Deal For Mine Company
description: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the world's largest iron ore producer and exporter, signed an agreement with the Aluminum Corporation of China to build a $1 billion aluminum refinery in northeastern Brazil. The plant is expected to be running by 2007, initially producing 1.8 million metric tons a year. Capacity should eventually expand to 7.2 million tons a year. C.V.R.D., as the Brazilian mining giant is widely known, also signed a separate agreement with the Yankuang Group, the Chinese coal producer, to mine for coking coal in China. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Rutherford: Soccer Match At Stadium
description: The first annual Fiesta Cup soccer match, between the national teams of Argentina and Peru, will take place on the night of June 30 at Giants Stadium. The exhibition match was put together by the Latin Media and Entertainment Commission, which was formed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York. Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium will be in use that day. Tickets, which begin at $25, can be had through Ticketmaster. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: HORMEL PROMOTES EXECUTIVE SEEN AS LIKELY NEXT CHIEF

Mr. Ettinger, 45, succeeds Mr. Johnson, who remains chairman and chief executive, Hormel said. Mr. Ettinger has been president and chief executive of Hormel's Jennie-O Turkey Store division since 1999. Mr. Johnson, 60, has been Hormel's chief executive since 1993 and said yesterday that he planned to retire in 2005.

title: The Search for the Perfect Year-Round Raspberry Leads to the Greenhouse

The raspberry, alas, is a highly perishable fruit that stops ripening as soon as it is picked and, when moist, becomes a fertile field for fungal growth.

title: BANK OF AMERICA PRESIDENT PLANS TO RESIGN
description: Bank of America said yesterday that its president, Eugene M. McQuade, would resign by the end of next month and get $25 million, including severance, after he leaves. Mr. McQuade, 55, was president and chief operating officer of the FleetBoston Financial before it was bought by Bank of America in April. He ''felt it was time to pursue different challenges and a new chapter in his career,'' the chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, said in a statement. Mr. McQuade joined FleetBoston in 1992 and became chief financial officer in 1993. In 2002, he became president and chief operating officer. The chief executive of Fleet, Charles Gifford, is now chairman of Bank of America. The units Mr. McQuade oversees at Bank of America will be realigned. Tim Arnoult, head of technology and operations, will report to Mr. Lewis. Michael Mitchell, the workplace and security executive, will report to the chief financial officer, Marc Oken.

description: African-American patients are 50 percent more likely to die of colon cancer as are whites, even when they receive the same treatment, according to a study released yesterday in the journal Cancer. For rectal cancer, the two groups died at the same rate, the report said.

The agents will give directions and answer questions about MetroCards and other aspects of the subway system, the agency said. In Manhattan, agents are at the stations at West 168th Street, under Grand Central Terminal, at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue, 34th Street and Herald Square, and Fulton Street. In the Bronx, at 149th Street and Grand Concourse and at 161st Street and Yankee Stadium; in Queens, at Woodhaven Boulevard; and in Brooklyn, at New Utrecht Avenue and 62nd Street. The train struck the person about 9:15 p.m. at the Smith Road crossing. The spokesman, Sam Zambuto, did not provide any details about the victim. Customers can add the walkie-talkie service, which enables them to talk at the push of a button rather than by dialing, for $10 a month, down from $15, Sprint said. The unlimited-use offer, when combined with the company's wireless-data service, will cost $20. Sprint, based in Overland Park, Kan., said it had signed up 275,000 customers since November for the service, called Ready Link.

description: The United States Anti-Doping Agency yesterday presented Marion Jones with evidence obtained from a federal investigation into steroids that could be used to bar her from the Summer Olympics. title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Lucent To Buy Telica For $295 Million
description: Lucent Technologies, the maker of telephone equipment, has agreed to buy Telica Inc. for $295 million in stock to add higher-capacity switches that use Internet technology to transmit calls. Lucent will pay 92.7 million shares and stock options for Telica, a closely held company based in Marlborough, Mass., and will pay as much as $18.5 million in cash to its employees, a Lucent spokesman, Bill Price, said yesterday. The transaction will be completed by September and will reduce Lucent's earnings in the 2005 fiscal year by 1 cent to 2 cents a share, the company said. Lucent's chief executive, Patricia F. Russo, is trying to win a bigger share of the market for Internet-calling gear, which is expected to more than triple by the end of 2008.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: New President Steps In, Opponents Speak Out
description: Malawi's new president, Bingu wa Mutharika, was sworn into office, while his opponents in the five-candidate election last week called the vote a fraud and their supporters demonstrated. Foreign election observers said the vote was flawed by media bias and irregularities in voter rolls. Mr. Mutharika, a 70-year-old Indian-educated economist who was the handpicked successor of the departing president, Bakili Muluzi, won 35 percent of the vote. The second-place finisher, John Tembo of the United Congress Party, had 27 percent. The No. 3 candidate, Gwanda Chakuamba, took 26 percent but said that he was the real victor and that the election had been stolen from him. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Opera: Works In Progress
description: For everyone involved in developing a new opera, it's invaluable to have a foretaste of the work, to hear at least some of it performed live and get a sense of what's working and what not. Starting tonight for the sixth year in a row, the New York City Opera is providing this opportunity through VOX: Showcasing American Composers, its free presentation of excerpts from new, unperformed American operas. The three-day event, offered by Symphony Space in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater and the Leonard Nimoy Thalia, starts with drinks at 6 p.m. and a program at the Thalia at 6:45. The City Opera's composer in residence, Mark Adamo, will introduce performances of opera excerpts and highlight the rest of the festival. Tomorrow and Thursday from 2 p.m. to 5:30, audiences can drop in and hear concert performances with the City Opera orchestra and full casts of singers in excerpts of works by the composers Tom Cipullo, Richard Danielpour, John Eaton, Jennifer Griffith, Daniel Felsenfeld, Donald Hagar, Elodie Lauten and Adam Silverman. There will also be evening events tomorrow and on Thursday. ANTHONY TOMMASINI

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Shell Revising Reserves Again
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group cut its 2002 oil and gas reserves for the fourth time, lopping 120 million more barrels off the number. The change comes as Shell prepares to refile its 2002 annual report on Friday after reducing its reserve levels by 20 percent in January. Shell's 2002 reserves now stand at 4.47 billion barrels, a 23 percent drop from the company's originally reported results. In a conference call, the chairman, Jeroen van der Veer, said the company's 2003 reserve replacement ratio, a measure of how quickly an oil company finds new resources as they are depleted, stands at 68 percent. Managing directors will not receive bonuses for 2003, a spokeswoman said during the call. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Rocket Attack Kills Norwegian Soldier

title: MEMO PAD
description: STANDBY TO STANDBY -- Aviation and government officials are sounding the alarm: With air traffic approaching pre-2001 levels, get ready for worsening airport delays. ''Even though we are not yet into the summer months, typically the busiest for the airlines, we are already seeing delays and congestion resulting from the rebound in airline traffic,'' Kenneth M. Mead, the Department of Transportation inspector general, told a Senate committee last week. Because of intense low-fare airline competition at major airlines' hubs, some airports with high delay rates last summer will handle even more flights this summer, a report by the agency said. For example, Kennedy Airport, where 25.1 percent of flights were delayed last summer, has 20 percent more flights scheduled this summer. Washington Dulles, where 22.5 percent of flights were delayed last summer, has 17 percent more scheduled flights this summer.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Seesawing Testimony In Pedophilia Trial
description: A woman at the center of a major pedophile case in northern France caused confusion in the courtroom by retracting the claim she made last week that she had made up much of the testimony that implicated more than a dozen other people for raping her four children and 14 others. ''My children did not lie,'' said the woman, Myriam Delay, left. ''I was there and I saw it all.'' Her statement contradicts her dramatic courtroom confession last week in which she insisted that most of the people she had accused of taking part in the abuse were innocent. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Detective Dies In Crash

The first car struck him from behind, throwing him from his Harley-Davidson. Detective Suppa, who worked in the Brooklyn South Narcotics Division, landed in the left lane of the parkway and was hit by another car, the police said. The state police said the driver of the second car, Jose Hernandez, 25, of Freeport, was drunk and fled the scene. He was arraigned yesterday on charges of driving while impaired and leaving the scene of an accident. The other driver was not charged. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Magazine Resurrected
description: The Oxford American, the Southern literary magazine born again more times than a backsliding Southern Baptist, has found salvation, and resurrection is expected in November. The University of Central Arkansas, at Conway, has bought the Oxford American, dormant since midsummer 2003, for $490,000 from the holding company headed by Marc Smirnoff, who will resume his duties as editor. The OA, as it is known, will switch from bimonthly to quarterly and will operate as a nonprofit entity, something at which it is experienced. The OA had the odd distinction of being the only magazine this year to win a National Magazine Award after it had closed. The magazine was founded in 1992 at Oxford, Miss., as a journal of Southern culture. Despite financial help from the best-selling author John Grisham, the OA failed to turn a profit and in 2002 was acquired by At Home Media Group. When subscriptions languished last year, the Arkansas concern closed the OA but transferred ownership to Mr. Smirnoff and his associates. STEVE BARNES

title: The President's Speech
description: If President Bush had been talking a year ago, after the fall of Baghdad, his speech at the Army War College last night might have sounded like a plan for moving forward. He was able to point to a new United Nations resolution being developed in consultation with American allies, not imposed in defiance of them, and to a timetable for moving Iraq toward elected self-government. He talked in general terms of expanding international involvement and stabilizing Iraq. But Mr. Bush was not starting fresh. He spoke after nearly 14 months of policy failures, none of them acknowledged by the president, which have left Iraq increasingly violent and drained Washington's credibility with the Iraqi people and the international community. They have been waiting for Mr. Bush to make a clean break with those policies. He did not do that last night. The speech reflected the fact that Mr. Bush has been backtracking lately, but he did not come close to charting the new course he needs to take. His ''five steps'' toward Iraqi independence were merely a recitation of the tasks ahead.

title: An Endangered State
description: Somehow, it's hard to imagine the lush, green state of Vermont overrun by a legion of yellow smiley faces. Yet that's the concern of the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Washington. The trust, which monitors the degradation of the nation's most historic sites, is alarmed about the possibility that Wal-Mart may create more than one million square feet of commercial blight in Vermont by building seven monster stores around the state. Thus, the trust has wisely declared Vermont -- the entire state of Vermont -- among the nation's most endangered historic sites.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: LIPA To Expand Power Supply
description: The Long Island Power Authority plans to expand its electricity supply by installing a 27-mile, 660-megawatt underwater cable from Sayreville, N.J., to Wantagh, N.Y. A review panel is recommending approval of a bid from Neptune RTS of Pittsfield, Me., to lay the cable and build a converter station. The project is expected to cost several hundred million dollars and to reach completion by 2007. LIPA, which is fighting Connecticut officials who won a shutdown of the Long Island Sound cable, says it anticipates no opposition. One LIPA consultant, Bob Kendall, called the cable ''basically an extension cord between Long Island and New Jersey.'' Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Unemployment Rises
description: Unemployment in Brazil rose for the fourth consecutive month in April to 13.1 percent, its highest level since the government's statistics agency began compiling monthly jobless figures in October 2001. The survey, which is conducted in Brazil's six largest metropolitan areas, also showed that the number of people looking for work rose 8.5 percent from April of last year and 3.2 percent from the previous month. Real wages fell 0.9 percent last month while the number of people working remained stable. The high unemployment rate has gnawed away at the popularity of President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, a former metalworker who came to office pledging to create 10 million jobs in his four-year term. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Fox Shuffles Cable Offerings

title: Vodafone to Pay $4.7 Billion to Buy Rest of Japan Unit

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: The Light and Siren Show
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told many city officials last winter that they had to give up the lights and sirens in their city-owned cars, the Queens borough president, Helen Marshal, had them installed in her three personal cars. Daniel Andrews, her press secretary, said she used those cars at night and on the weekends, and used the lights and sirens sparingly, if at all. Under city and state laws, the devices are to be used only by police and other emergency vehicles, or by those who have received special permission and have been trained in their use. ''I will talk to her,'' Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference yesterday. But Mr. Andrews said Ms. Marshall would remove the lights and sirens. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

She was the granddaughter of the famous painter Isidor Kaufmann, whose paintings are displayed in museums around the world. Through her boundless energy, she made significant contributions to the fields of advertising, marketing and publishing. She authored articles in social research, and was a past instructor at Queens College. She had a strong sense of principle and integrity. She was a high-quality person with much dignity. She enjoyed life and provided joy to her friends. Her memory and warmth will always be in our hearts. Her departure leaves a void in all of us. She was a bright light in our lives. We will miss her terribly. Services Friday 9:45 AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. title: Iraq May Survive, but the Dream Is Dead
description: It was high time President Bush spoke to the nation of the war in Iraq. A year or so ago, it was our war, and we claimed it proudly. To be sure, there was a minority that never bought into the expedition and genuinely believed that it would come to grief. But most of us recognized that a culture of terror had taken root in the Arab world. We struck, first at Afghanistan and then at the Iraqi regime, out of a broader determination to purge Arab radicalism.

title: BOB EVANS LOWERS FORECAST FOR 2005 EARNINGS
description: Bob Evans Farms Inc., which makes sausage and owns 559 restaurants, said yesterday that 2005 profit would be $1.80 to $2 a share, below its previous estimate, as sales fell in May and hog prices rose. Its shares fell 9.6 percent. Sales in May, the first month of fiscal 2005, will decrease about 5 percent from a year earlier at 484 restaurants open at least a year, the company said. Average menu prices are about 2.4 percent higher. Bob Evans operates namesake restaurants in the Midwest, Southeast and mid-Atlantic and Owens Restaurants in Texas. The company reduced its 2005 forecast from a range of $2.20 to $2.30 a share. Stock in Bob Evans, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, fell $2.73, to $25.67 a share.

title: Let's See, Who's the Patron Saint of 'Ooh'?
description: How do you say ''strawberry shortcake'' in French? One glorious translation is Saint-Honor aux fraises, as interpreted by Florian Bellanger, the executive pastry chef for Fauchon. Mr. Bellanger has added strawberries to the classic Parisian cake, named for the patron saint of bakers, which consists of a flaky pastry base, a filling of pastry cream blended with whipped cream, topped with a crown of puff pastry decorated with caramelized cream puffs. Strawberry preserves are layered in the filling, and ripe berries with more whipped cream decorate the top. This indulgence -- available as an individual pastry ($5.50), and in sizes to serve four to six ($28) or eight to 10 ($50) -- is sold at the Fauchon stores only on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays.
