title: When the Menu Says Chicken 'Legs' But Means 'Feet'
description: If you want to eat the way the Chinese do when you are in Chinatown but have no familiarity with Mandarin or Cantonese, how do you face the untranslated lists of dishes posted on walls or menus? ''The Eater's Guide to Chinese Characters,'' by James D. McCawley (University of Chicago, $15), a paperback edition of a book first published in 1984, could help. But this is not ''Chinese Menus for Dummies.'' It will take some serious study to recognize and understand the characters while you are waiting for your pot of tea, but in the end, you might be able to tell whether those stuffed buns are baked or steamed, and whether something called chicken legs is really chicken feet. Chinese characters are often more specific in describing dishes, and English translations are error-prone. For example, a dish called Two Crisp in English is actually pig tripe and dried squid. The book also has a rudimentary guide to pronunciation.

title: Education Memo; Good Teachers + Small Classes = Quality Education
description: The secret to quality public education has never been a big mystery. You need good teachers and you need small enough classes so those teachers can do their work. Period. After that, everything seems to pale, including the testing accountability programs, technology, building conditions. Even curriculum seems secondary, as our best public colleges demonstrate. We have West Point and we have Berkeley, and the question isn't which has the correct curriculum; the question is which curriculum is the best fit for the student and teacher.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Nobu is heading to Midtown. Next spring, NOBU 57 , a branch of the famous TriBeCa restaurant, which is owned by the chef NOBU MATSUHISA, ROBERT DE NIRO, DREW NIEPORENT and others, is to open at 40 West 57th Street. DAVID ROCKWELL will design the two-level, 13,000-square-foot space, now a drugstore and hair salon. ''The food will be like Nobu in TriBeCa,'' Mr. Matsuhisa said. He plans to add a Japaneses robata grill.

title: How to Make the Case Against Grasso
description: Recovering tens of millions of dollars from the former Big Board chief executive Richard A. Grasso will not be easy -- even for New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer.

title: Wilpon Will Help Mets If They Help Themselves
description: Meaningful games. The owner Fred Wilpon used his favorite words again yesterday as he talked about the suddenly plucky and interesting Mets. He claimed that other people had misinterpreted his definition of meaningful games, but he did not say who or how.

title: The F.B.I. Messes Up
description: The Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation ought to hang their heads in shame over the mistaken arrest and jailing of a Muslim lawyer in Oregon who was supposed to be a material witness in the Madrid train bombing case. The arrest turned out to be based on a faulty fingerprint identification by F.B.I. ''experts.'' That finding was ultimately retracted when more careful Spanish investigators concluded that the fingerprint had actually been left by a different man. Federal authorities apologized for the error and the unjustified jail time, but they still have a lot of explaining to do. The case smacks of a rush to judgment based on flimsy evidence. Clearly fingerprint analysis is not the gold standard it is cracked up to be. The method itself is not foolproof, and the analysts who provide the final judgment sometimes make the wrong call.

title: Gore Calls for Rumsfeld and Rice to Resign
description: In a scathing attack on what he called the White House's failed policies in Iraq, Al Gore demanded today the resignations of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and five other members of the Bush administration. "We cannot afford to further increase the risk to our country with more blunders by this team," Mr. Gore said.

title: Business Deal Is Examined For Rowland the Consultant
description: Federal prosecutors have a deposition that could shed a sliver of light on why John G. Rowland was paid $35,000 by a wealthy businessman before his election as Connecticut's governor.

title: FLEMING TO SEEK CREDITOR BACKING ON BANKRUPTCY PLAN
description: The Fleming Companies, a grocery distributor, won approval to seek creditors' backing of its plan to exit bankruptcy as a convenience-store supply operation. Judge Mary Walrath of United States Bankruptcy Court gave the company permission to seek votes on the plan at a hearing yesterday in Wilmington, Del. The plan would allow the company to reorganize around its Core-Mark International convenience-store supply operation. CVCMA L.L.C., a group of Texas executives that includes Bill Fields, a former vice president with Wal-Mart Stores Inc., said it would ask the court to end the company's exclusive right to file a plan and allow it to submit a competing plan that would include its $315 million offer for the Core-Mark unit.

title: Paris Wins Round in Alstom Rescue Effort
description: France has won a partial victory for its strategy of defending its national industrial champions, clearing the last hurdle to a deal with the European Union that will allow it to bail out Alstom, the financially troubled maker of trains, power plants and ships.

description: MTV Networks announced yesterday that, after a long delay, it intended next February to start the first cable television channel directed at gay viewers. But beyond the typical challenges facing new cable networks of finding distribution and advertisers, the new channel, to be called Logo, will have one unusual obstacle: outrage from conservative groups.

description: IT may sound obvious, but cold glasses of clean-tasting, somewhat bitter India pale ale are an excellent foil for Indian food, which offers fragrant, forceful, salty, oily, pungent and even sweet flavors.

title: Jersey City Mayor Remembered as Man of Pride and Wit
description: JERSEY CITY, May 26  A simple memorial of flowers and a color portrait of Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham sat atop a small table on the landing of the marble stairway arcing around the rotunda of City Hall here as scores of officials and average citizens gathered to mourn and remember the city's first African-American mayor, who suffered a fatal heart attack late Tuesday night.

Elsewhere the ear battles the eye's incredulity and in the happiest cases wins, with performers who don't resemble their characters at all, but sing divinely.

description: In an effort to keep the raw materials for nuclear bombs out of the hands of terrorists, the Energy Department will undertake a $450 million campaign to retrieve nuclear materials that the United States and the Soviet Union originally sent around the world for research purposes, the energy secretary will announce on Wednesday in Vienna.

title: Sunday in the Park With Pinocchio
description: Instead of paper and plastic, there is now wood for your picnic. Pic Woody's smooth lightweight plates, in a sandwich-and-salad size with a ruffled rim, and forks, spoons and serrated knives are made from beechwood from sustainable forests. The utensils can be washed and reused or tossed into the campfire. Plates are $1.29 each. A package of 10 forks and 10 knives is $2.59. They also come in sacks of 250, $19.99 each for the knives and forks and $25.99 for the spoons. At Fairway markets.

description: An Army summary of deaths and mistreatment involving prisoners in American custody in Iraq and Afghanistan shows a widespread pattern of abuse involving more military units than previously known.

title: Carter Family Guitar For Sale
description: A guitar with a vital place in country music history and American popular culture, the 1928 Gibson L-5 that Mother Maybelle Carter of the Carter Family played for 50 years and was passed on to her daughter Helen when Mother Maybelle died in 1978, went on sale this week in Nashville. The asking price is $575,000, with Gruhn Guitars of Nashville handling the transaction. Another of Mother Maybelle's three daughters, June Carter Cash, and her husband, Johnny Cash, both died last year. Now the instrument, above, which cost $275 in 1928 and had been on loan to the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, is being sold by an anonymous party whose family is facing immense medical expenses, Music Row insiders learned last week. Maybelle played the L-5 on classic Carter Family recordings from the 1920's, including ''Keep on the Sunny Side'' and the song now known as ''Will the Circle Be Unbroken.'' Victor Records producer Ralph Peer signed the Carter Family during a legendary series of auditions at Bristol, Tenn., in July 1927. He signed another American musical legend, Jimmie Rodgers, the Singing Brakeman, that same week. Those two contracts started the country music recording industry. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRADEN, WILLIAM
description: BRADEN--William. Died May 22 at home in Lloyd Harbor. He was 85. A retired vice president in the investment department of Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. in New York, Mr. Braden had run the bank's European investment operations in Paris from 196772. Mr. Braden was a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He was a Knight of Malta, and had served on the board of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith and other institutions. He was married to the late Lachlan Porter Braden and Adelaide Weld Braden. He is survived by a son, William Braden III, of Providence, R.I; a daughter, Maria Braden Clark, of Lexington, Ky; a stepdaughter, Hope W. Lapsley; a stepson, Robert Whitney, both of Long Island, and five grandchildren. He also leaves two sisters, Maruja Meirelles of New York, Patricia Clark of Pinehurst, N.C., and a brother, Spruille Braden, of Bethel, Conn. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated 9:30 A.M. Saturday St. Patrick's Catholic Church, 630 Main St., Huntington. Donations may be made in lieu of flowers to Visiting Nurse Service Suffolk County.

title: BIOGEN IDEC SEEKS EARLY APPROVAL OF ANTEGREN
description: Biogen Idec Inc., the biotechnology company, and its Irish partner, the Elan Corporation, filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration for approval of their Antegren multiple sclerosis drug. The companies said yesterday that they were asking for clearance a year earlier than analysts had expected, based on results from the first year of two-year studies. They asked the F.D.A. to complete its review of Antegren in 6 months instead of the standard 10. Biogen Idec, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., is counting on Antegren to make up for slowing growth of older medicines, like its top-selling Avonex drug.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
description: German business confidence fell slightly in May, reversing the previous month's rise, a monthly survey by the Munich-based Ifo Institute said. The overall index, based on a survey of 7,000 companies about the current business climate, was 96.1 in May compared with 96.3 in April. The companies' expectations for the next six months, however, rose to 97.8, from 97.7. These results ''speak for an ongoing, moderate economic recovery in Germany in the coming months,'' Ifo said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Williams Advances With Style
description: Despite wearing a midriff-baring fuchsia outfit that had spectators buzzing on Tuesday, Serena Williams managed to draw attention to her game in a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Iveta Benesova in the first round of the French Open.

title: Alex Woodley, 71, Coach Of Philadelphia Track Club
description: Alex Woodley, who coached and mentored many Olympic gold-medal sprinters in the 1960's and 1970's as head of the Philadelphia Pioneer Club, died on Saturday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 71.

title: Public's Help Is Sought to Prevent Terrorist Strikes
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft and Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. plan to begin a campaign of public vigilance on Wednesday, warning that terrorists still hope to strike inside the United States, law enforcement officials said on Tuesday evening.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: NextWave Settlement Approved
description: NextWave Telecom has won approval of a settlement with federal regulators that resolves a dispute over a $4.3 billion debt for airwave licenses purchased at government auctions. NextWave agreed last month to return most of its spectrum licenses to the Federal Communications Commission and either give back other airwave rights or pay $386 million out of proceeds from their sale. The accord, approved by Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, gives mobile carriers like Verizon Wireless another opportunity to buy the licenses. ''I have been before you a lot of times in the past six years and there have been a lot of twists and turns in this case,'' a NextWave lawyer, Deborah Schrier-Rape, told Judge Hardin. ''We are here to end the problem that has governed NextWave for the past six years.'' The legal battle between NextWave and the commission culminated in a United States Supreme Court decision last year that allowed NextWave to keep the spectrum that the government reclaimed in 2000. NextWave owed the commission $4.3 billion out of $4.8 billion for the licenses won in auctions in 1996 and 1997 and the debt remained an obstacle to its successful reorganization. The company expects to submit a reorganization plan by July, said Michael Wack, a NextWave lawyer and spokesman.

description: The history of creating British lords and ladies has been full of surprises, but the decision to award an honorary knighthood just now to the top American commander during the Iraq war is causing some ripples along the Thames.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Head Of U.N. Mission Resigns
description: The leader of the United Nations mission in Kosovo, Hari Holkeri, resigned, citing ill health, just nine months after his appointment and a little over two months after ethnic violence left 19 dead and more than 900 wounded in the province. Mr. Holkeri, a former prime minister of Finland, is fourth head of the mission to leave since the post was established five years ago. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

There were more than 7,678 nesting pairs last year in the lower 48 states, not nationwide. (Another 10,000 to 12,000 pairs are in Alaska.)

description: Stocks rallied yesterday as investors focused on economic strength and corporate profits rather than oil prices and Iraq.

description: FEDERAL standards for what foods can be called organic might have seemed like the final word on the issue when they went into effect two years ago. But the Agriculture Department's interpretation of the laws governing the National Organic Program has fed a fierce debate on what should be allowed in such products.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Trials May Be Moved
description: Prosecutors at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague have recommended that two former Croatian generals accused of war crimes during the 1991-95 war stand trial in their own country. It was the first such recommendation, part of a policy announced last year to refer more cases to local courts. The announcement followed the indictment of one of the Generals, Mirko Norac. He and Rahim Ademi, an ethnic Albanian, are accused of abuses against Serbian soldiers and civilians as they withdrew their forces from Medak in September 1993. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Deep-Fried and Bite-Size

Its timeworn counter is often unattended, and half-empty shelves display dusty canned foods. Neighborhood transplants cannot help wondering who is Joe? How does he stay in business? And why doesn't he replace the ''u'' in his sign?

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Energy Venture
description: Hopewell Holdings and the Shenzhen Energy Group have agreed to form a 5 billion yuan ($604 million) power venture in China, in what would be a return to the energy industry for Sir Gordon Wu, left, who founded Hopewell. Hopewell signed a letter of intent to develop 600-megawatt generating units in Heyuan city in Guangdong Province, with production starting in 2008, a Hopewell spokeswoman said. Sir Gordon left the industry eight years ago when Hopewell sold Consolidated Electric Power Asia to the Southern Company. The company, which agreed to a noncompete clause that banned it from re-entering the Asian market, received permission from Southern to invest again, Sir Gordon said last week. Hopewell, which plans to take a stake in the venture, is seeking Chinese government approval for the investment, the spokeswoman said.

Mr. von Trier, who appears frequently in this semi-documentary inquiry into the making and breaking of works of art, is certainly up to his old tricks, but this time at least he's picking on someone his own size.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Accused Plotters Ask South Africa's Help
description: Lawyers for 70 men accused of plotting the overthrow of Equatorial Guinea's president called for South Africa to block their extradition from a Zimbabwe prison, saying they faced unfair trials and ''the very real prospect of death'' if they are sent to Equatorial Guinea. Most of the 70 men, and 15 others held in Equatorial Guinea, are South Africans; they were seized in Harare, Zimbabwe, in March after flying there from South Africa, apparently to pick up weapons. title: Making Over the Oval Office? Couldn't Hurt
description: AS a nascent political animal, Steven Sclaroff, an interior designer with a knack for restoring 20th-century furniture and an eponymous Greenwich Street shop to display it, picks an odd soapbox from which to explain his conscription by Downtown for Democracy, a political action group mobilizing creative types to help eject the Bush administration. He's orating from a position familiar to populists everywhere: couch potato.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Offered To Settle
description: Computer Associates International Inc. offered $10 million to settle a two-year government investigation into its accounting practices, the chief financial officer, Jeffrey J. Clarke, said yesterday. The company recorded an expense for the potential settlement in its fourth-quarter results released yesterday, Mr. Clarke told reporters in Las Vegas. The company, based in Islandia, N.Y., said the government had not accepted nor rejected the offer. For the quarter, net income was $89 million, or 15 cents a share, bolstered by the sale of its Accpac International unit, compared with a loss of $106 million, or 18 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent, to $850 million. Earlier this month Computer Associates delayed releasing its results, saying it lacked enough time to compile them while investigating previous accounting practices. In April, the company restated its revenue in 2000 and 2001 by $2.2 billion after an internal investigation found sales were prematurely booked. The inquiry led to the firing of 14 executives. The chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, stepped down last month. Computer Associates said operating profit this quarter would be 17 to 19 cents a share, compared with analysts' average forecast of 19 cents, based on 14 estimates taken by Thomson First Call. Shares of Computer Associates fell to $24.93 in extended trading. Earlier, they were unchanged at $25.70 in regular trading.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Business Districts To Raise Fees
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill yesterday permitting five business improvement districts to raise their fees for services like trash collection, security guards and promotional campaigns. Under the new law, the improvement districts will negotiate an assessment increase with the property owners who operate businesses within their boundaries. The affected districts are: in Manhattan, 34th Street, 47th Street, and Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues; 82nd Street in Queens; and Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Land Quarrels Unsettle Ivory Coast's Cocoa Belt
description: In the fertile heart of the world's largest cocoa-producing country, a 20-month-long civil war has spawned an ugly ethnic feud over cocoa land.

title: A Guitar That Makes Beautiful Pasta
description: ASK chefs which kitchen tools they cherish, and you'll gain an honest glimpse into their personalities. Simpson Wong of Jefferson, for example, is never without his 16-inch metal chopsticks, which he maneuvers like more precise kitchen tongs. Bill Yosses, the pastry chef at Boi and at Joseph's, shoots his new infrared laser thermometer at everything in sight. And Anna Klinger, the chef at Al Di L in Park Slope, makes spaghetti with her beloved guitar.

title: A SoHo Brasserie, Now Authentically Worn
description: EVERY diner I know who has been to Balthazar has a story about being snubbed by the matre d'htel, hung up on by the reservationist, or ignored by a waiter tending to a more important guest.

title: FEN-PHEN USERS RETAIN RIGHT TO SUE WYETH
description: Wyeth, which has set aside $16.6 billion to resolve its diet-drug liability, cannot bar former fen-phen users from presenting evidence to try to show that the company mishandled the drugs, an appeals court ruled. The United States Court of Appeals in Philadelphia struck down a lower court ruling that prevented some former fen-phen users from introducing the evidence. The users had opted out of a $3.75 billion settlement of cases. They had planned to present accusations that the company ran a campaign to hide health risks of the drugs. Wyeth said in a statement that it would seek a rehearing of the decision. Stock in Wyeth, which is based in Madison, N.J., fell $2.66, to $34.65 a share.

title: Accounts
description: Callaway Golf, Carlsbad, Calif., dismissed its creative agency of seven years, Dailey & Associates, West Hollywood, Calif., and began a review for the assignment, with billings estimated at $40 million. Five agencies are taking part but Calloway declined to identify them. Dailey, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, continues to handle media planning and buying.

title: The Times and Iraq
description: Over the last year this newspaper has shone the bright light of hindsight on decisions that led the United States into Iraq. We have examined the failings of American and allied intelligence, especially on the issue of Iraq's weapons and possible Iraqi connections to international terrorists. We have studied the allegations of official gullibility and hype. It is past time we turned the same light on ourselves.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Clothier's Profit Rises
description: The Marks & Spencer Group, the British clothing retailer, said second-half profit rose 8.5 percent as it bought more cheaply from overseas suppliers and cut costs to fight faltering sales. Net income rose to about 320 million ($573.3 million) in the six months ended April 3, from 295 million a year earlier, a spokesman said. The company can only give approximate second-half figures because of changes in the way it accounts for pensions since it released first-half earnings. Full-year revenue rose 3.8 percent, to 7.3 billion, helped by a 53rd week in its accounting year and the addition of 49 stand-alone food stores, the chief executive, Roger Holmes, said. Sales at stores open at least a year fell 0.4 percent, including a 3.4 percent drop in the fourth quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, SAMUEL C.
description: JOHNSON--Samuel C. Cornell University mourns the loss of a devoted alumnus and trustee emeritus, Samuel C. Johnson, a visionary leader whose entrepreneurial spirit, deep commitment to his family, and loyalty to the University were extraordinary. A member of the Class of 1950 and a much - honored executive whose dedication to education and to the environment were legendary, he joined S.C. Johnson Inc. in 1954 and later became president and CEO. He championed policies of corporate philanthropy, community service, social responsibility, and a familyfriendly work life. He became a Cornell trustee in 1966 and served on numerous committees, and from 1990-1995 he co-chaired the campaign council during the University's capital campaign. He was a member of the Cornell University Council and served as a Presidential Councillor. In 1984, he and his family made the largest gift ever to a graduate school of business. As a result of his extraordinary generosity, the University named the Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management in honor of his great grandfather who founded the family business in 1886. He chaired the advisory council at the Johnson School and, among many other thoughtful and wise investments, endowed a professorship in sustainable global enterprise in 2003. He was a benefactor of Cornell's Laboratory of Ornithology and made innumerable gifts to support scholarships, campus life, and many other areas. Throughout the Cornell campus the Johnson name is synonymous with business education, the arts, and stewardship of natural resources. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Gene Powers Johnson, and to his daughters, Helen JohnsonLeipold and Winnie Johnson Marquart, and his sons, Curt Johnson and Fisk Johnson. Peter Meinig, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University Jeffrey S. Lehman, President, Cornell University

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Economic Growth Meets Forecasts
description: Indonesia's gross domestic product rose 4.5 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier, a government report said, as cheaper loans fueled consumer spending and business expansion. Economic growth in the three months to March 31 was faster than the previous quarter's 4.4 percent and in line with economists' forecasts. Manufacturing, the largest contributor to economic activity at about a quarter of gross domestic product, expanded 5.5 percent, which is the fastest pace in five quarters, the report showed. Retail trade, which accounts for about a sixth of economic activity, rose 6.1 percent, the fastest pace in a year.

title: As Police Extend Use of DNA, A Smudge Could Trap a Thief
description: If New Yorkers whose homes are burglarized despair of ever seeing justice -- much less their stereos and jewelry -- they have good reason. Less than 20 percent of property crimes in the city are ever solved. That is partly because evidence and witnesses are hard to come by, and partly because the bulk of the manpower and money is devoted to catching violent criminals. DNA testing, for example, is routinely done only in homicides, rapes and the most serious assaults.

title: 2 Hartford Detectives Shot; Suspect Is Killed
description: HARTFORD, May 25 - Two Hartford police detectives were shot by a man with a shotgun during a drug raid here on Tuesday, and a suspect was then fatally wounded, the acting police chief said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Landlord's Tax Charges Dismissed
description: Federal prosecutors moved to dismiss charges yesterday against a landlord accused of tax crimes. The landlord, Pablo Llorente, had been indicted on charges of filing false tax returns and understating rental income on several buildings. A spokesman for the United States attorney's office in Manhattan said that newly discovered business records caused prosecutors to question whether the charges ''could be proved beyond a reasonable doubt.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Madonna's Latest Self, a Mix of Her Old Ones
description: Madonna calls her new traveling show the Re-Invention World Tour, and, if anything, the name seems a bit too obvious. (You don't see John Kerry crisscrossing the country on a tour called Lots of Speeches.) For more than two decades she has stayed in the spotlight by shunning it every year or two, retreating to remake herself and then returning anew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COK, ANDRES
description: COK--Andres. Beloved husband of Violeta, revered father of Silvia and Vivian, respected father-in-law of Manny Wong, passed away on May 23rd in a swimming accident in Miami Beach, FL. He was 84. Andres was loved and respected by all those who were fortunate to know him during his full and interesting life. Happiest when surrounded by his five grandchildren: Olivia, Sabrina, and Marissa Wong, of Miami, FL; and Andrew and Jacqueline Chang, of Fresh Meadows, NY, he cherished his family and friends. Andres spent his early years in his hometown village of Toi San, in southern China. Fleeing the ravages of the Sino-Japanese conflict in 1939, he joined his brother Gustavo in Havana, Cuba. After finishing his studies and completing a stint as assistant secretary to the Chinese Ambassador in Venezuela, he returned to Havana where he established himself as an entrepreneur, owning and managing a food market in La Vibora, a suburb of Havana, and marrying Violeta Pons, the love of his life, with whom he shared fifty-one years of marriage. In 1960, Andres once again uprooted himself and his family to seek ideological and economic freedom away from Fidel Castro's oppressive regime, this time making one final and decisive journey to New York City. After a persistent and laborious start, he simultaneously built up a soy and rice products business, while developing a strong presence in NYC's Chinatown community. He served several terms as President of the CubanChinese Association as well as the Toi San High School Alumni Association, engaging their members in many charitable and communityoriented activities. Having touched the hearts and minds of many, Andres will be dearly missed. The family will receive friends at Wah Wing Sang Funeral Home at 26 Mulberry St. in New York City on Monday, May 31st. A graveside ceremony and burial will take place the following day at noon at Evergreen Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to one's favorite charity.

title: PRESIDENT OF SPORTS AUTHORITY RESIGNS
description: Sports Authority Inc., the sporting-goods chain, said Elliott Kerbis, its president and chief merchandising officer since January 2002, had resigned. The chief executive, Doug Morton, will oversee duties formerly handled by Mr. Kerbis. Sports Authority also reported first-quarter results and said its income fell to $4.07 million in the quarter ended May 1, down from $4.19 million a year earlier. Sales rose to $572 million, from $228 million. The first-quarter results reflect the performance of both Sports Authority and the Gart Sports Company, which combined operations last year. Sports Authority is based in Englewood, Colo.

title: NASDAQ TO ACQUIRE SUNGARD'S STOCK-TRADING NETWORK
description: The Nasdaq Stock Market Inc. will pay $190 million to buy Brut L.L.C., which operates an electronic communication network that links stock traders, from SunGard Data Systems. Nasdaq said acquiring Brut would give Nasdaq traders access to extra markets, which would improve liquidity. The move will help the exchange to comply with a recent Securities and Exchange Commission proposal meant to address national market structure. Nasdaq said it expected the deal to help its results in the next 12 months. Last year, the company lost $105.5 million, or $1.45 a share. Nasdaq's market share for volume in Nasdaq-listed stocks has fallen in recent years and has been surpassed by networks like Brut.

Surviving are her children, Helen Morris Scorsese, Christopher W. Morris (residents of New York) and James M. Morris, four grandchildren and one sister. title: World War II Remembrances
description: The Smithsonian's National Museum of American History in Washington will open two exhibitions tomorrow in conjunction with the new World War II memorial on the National Mall. Under the title ''So Proudly We Hail,'' the museum will display, together for the first time, four wartime flags, including the American flag raised on Iwo Jima; the first American flag to enter Berlin in 1945; a flag made from a captured Nazi flag, a blue dress uniform and some salvaged red fabric; and the 31-star flag carried when Commodore Matthew C. Perry entered Japan in 1853 and later brought aboard the battleship Missouri for the formal surrender of Japan in 1945. The exhibition will close on Labor Day. The second show, ''WWII Photographic Perspectives,'' features images from Robert Capa, Margaret Bourke-White and others. It will close in January 2005. The museum will also play host to a number of World War II-related public programs throughout the late spring and summer, starting on Friday and Saturday with the WWII Homefront Family Festival, featuring films, musical performances, special displays and activities. ELIZABETH OLSON

title: Architect Starts Study of Failure In Paris Airport
description: The French architect who designed the futuristic terminal building at Charles de Gaulle International Airport that partly collapsed Sunday visited the site on Tuesday. Airport officials said the damaged terminal could remain closed for up to a year.

description: Nicholas E. Berg had a distinctive strategy for soliciting work for his communications tower company: conduct free spot inspections, then offer to fix any problems. It has been set up at the outdoor cafe for Michael Jordan's: The Steak House N.Y.C., protected under the arches along Vanderbilt Avenue at 43rd Street. description: Afederal appeals court today rejected an effort by the Justice Department to block the only law in the nation authorizing doctors to help their patients commit suicide.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo First-Quarter Loss Widens
description: TiVo Inc., maker of a digital video recorder that can pause and replay live television programs, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss widened to $9.07 million as it spent more on research and development. Sales rose 21 percent. The net loss attributable to common shareholders was 11 cents a share for the quarter that ended April 30, compared with $7.88 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier, the company, based in Alviso, Calif., said. Revenue rose to $34.5 million, from $28.5 million. The chief executive, Michael Ramsay, is spending more to develop and promote TiVo-brand recorders as EchoStar Communications offers competing devices. The DirecTV Group, the nation's biggest satellite broadcaster, markets TiVo-brand recorders. The loss was smaller than the average estimate of 20 cents a share from 10 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. TiVo said it generated $25.2 million in revenue from licensing its technology and from its monthly subscription service that helps customers find programs to record. That was more than the average estimate of $23.9 million from seven analysts. The company's shares fell 10 cents, to $7.46, in extended trading after the company announced its results. Earlier they rose 16 cents, to $7.56.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on May 18 about bacteriaphage therapy, which harnesses viruses to fight bacteria, misstated the role of Dr. Ryland F. Young in researching the treatment. Dr. Young studied the way the viruses replicate and burst out of the host cell to invade other cells. His research group was also the first to delete genes in a bacteriphage, preventing the virus from bursting out of the cell after replication. But Dr. Young was not the first researcher to manipulate a phage genetically so that it killed bacteria without bursting out and infecting other cells. Scientists isolated mutant viruses with that property more than four decades ago.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Challenging Linux
description: Microsoft has begun an effort to produce a version of Windows for high-performance computing, a move seen as a direct attack on a Linux stronghold. For now, Linux has the upper hand, owing to its affinity with Unix -- the operating system environment the high-performance crowd is most comfortable with -- and the open-source model, which lets users turn directly to source code for answers to problems. But a Microsoft product would theoretically integrate better with Windows desktop machines, and if the company can serve up an impressive offering, Linux could be in for a tussle. High-performance computing once required massive, expensive, exotic machines from companies like Cray, but the field is being remade by the arrival of clusters of low-end machines. While the trend could be considered an opportunity for Microsoft, which has long been the leading operating-system company, Linux has actually become the favored software used on the clusters.

title: Henry Ries, 86, Photographer Who Captured Berlin Airlift
description: Henry Ries, a Berlin-born photographer who fled Hitler and returned to take evocative pictures of postwar Germany, most memorably his images of the Berlin airlift in 1948 and 1949, died on Monday at his home in Ghent, N.Y. He was 86.

title: Court Ruling Muddies Merger Scene In Europe
description: As the European competition commissioner Mario Monti prepares this week to defend his landmark veto of the 2001 proposed merger of General Electric and Honeywell, a representative of Europe's highest court issued a mixed opinion that will no doubt ripple through the proceedings.

title: F.D.A. SUSPENDS DYAX CANCER TREATMENT
description: Shares of the Dyax Corporation, a developer of drugs to treat cancer and inflammation, plunged after the company said its recombinant protein DX-88 had been put on clinical suspension by the Food and Drug Administration. Shares of Dyax, based in Cambridge, Mass., tumbled $4.15, or 29 percent, to $10.26 a share. The suspension will be in effect until the company answers questions related to results of animal studies, Dyax said. The company is developing DX-88 in a venture with the Genzyme Corporation for the treatment of hereditary angioedema, a genetic disorder that leads to swelling and inflammation in body parts. The protein is in the second of three stages of human testing for F.D.A. review.

title: Intelligence Indicates Al Qaeda Planning Attack, Ashcroft Says
description: Saying that law enforcement authorities have "credible intelligence from multiple sources" that Al Qaeda "intends to attempt an attack on the United States in the next few months," Attorney General John Ashcroft today issued a call for the public's help in stopping terrorists.

That said, this is one high-profile case Mr. Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, can't be relishing.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toray Wins Boeing Order
description: Toray Indusries said it received an order from Boeing worth 330 billion yen ($2.95 billion) over 18 years for carbon-fiber-reinforced plastics to make the wings, tails and floors of the 7E7 Dreamliner jets. Toray, Japan's largest maker of synthetic fibers, plans to expand production in Washington State, Alabama and Japan to supply materials for the aircraft, which is scheduled for delivery in 2008. Toray also hopes to win an order, expected to be worth 100 billion yen, from Boeing this year to provide carbon-fiber materials for the body of the 7E7. About a third of the 7E7 will be made by Japanese companies. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Cry No Tears for Martha Stewart
description: As you would expect of someone who has been a criminal defense lawyer for many years, I was disgusted to learn that the government has charged its own expert witness with committing perjury in the Martha Stewart trial. Yet the development is unlikely to overturn Ms. Stewart's criminal conviction. Its most lasting effect, rather, will probably be louder bleating from those who have insisted from the start that Ms. Stewart got a raw deal. And more's the pity, because that's hardly the case.

title: David Dellinger, of Chicago 7, Dies at 88
description: David Dellinger, whose commitment to nonviolent direct action against the federal government placed him at the forefront of American radical pacifism in the 20th century and led, most famously, to a courtroom in Chicago where he became a leading defendant in the raucous political conspiracy trial of the Chicago Seven, died Tuesday in a retirement home in Montpelier, Vt. He was 88.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Helicopter Stake Acquired
description: The aeronautics and defense company Finmeccanica said it would buy out its partner's half in a joint venture, the helicopter manufacturer AgustaWestland, for $1.9 billion. Finmeccanica, which is based in Rome, said it would pay for the deal by selling 50 million to 55 million shares in another joint venture, STMicroelectronics. Its partner in Agusta-Westland, the British manufacturer GKN, said it would use the proceeds to make acquisitions in the aerospace or automotive industries. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BCE To Buy Assets From 360networks
description: BCE Inc., Canada's biggest phone company, agreed yesterday to buy assets from the 360networks Corporation for 275 million Canadian dollars ($201 million) to help it win customers from rivals like Telus in Western Canada. The transaction will give BCE a fiber optic network for sending calls and data at high speeds, with operations in cities including Vancouver, Edmonton and Calgary, said BCE, based in Montreal. The purchase includes GT Group Telecom Services, acquired by 360networks last year. The Bell Canada phone unit of BCE is expanding in western provinces as competitors like Telus increase revenue in Bell Canada's home market in Ontario and Quebec. 360networks, which exited bankruptcy in 2002, made a ''big gain'' from the sale of GT Group, the financier Wilbur Ross, a 360networks investor and board member, said in a statement. He did not elaborate. The acquisition will be neutral or add marginally to earnings starting in 2005, BCE said. BCE said it would sell some of 360networks' operations in Eastern Canada to Call-Net Enterprises Inc., which provides telephone service under the Sprint brand, for an undisclosed price.

title: As Ashcroft Warns of Qaeda Plan to Attack U.S., Some Question the Threat and Its Timing

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew for the 10th consecutive month in April, expanding 30.3 percent from a year earlier to 1.08 trillion yen ($9.7 billion), as exports to Asia increased. Asia is becoming an increasingly important market for Japan; the nation's trade surplus with Asia jumped 63 percent, to 667 billion yen for the month. Japan's trade surplus with the United States fell 2.4 percent, to 553 billion yen. Robust export growth has been a factor driving Japan's two-year-old expansion. Over all, the value of exports from Japan rose 10.8 percent in April, to 5.11 trillion yen, while imports rose 6.5 percent, to 4.03 trillion yen. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Former Mayor Admits Stealing City Money
description: Former Mayor Reynaldo T. Gutierrez of Cactus and his wife, Lucia, pleaded guilty to charges of theft and tax evasion in the disappearance of $400,000 in money from the municipal treasury. Cactus, 60 miles northwest of Amarillo, has a population of 2,500. The shortage, which the indictment said covered a period of 28 months that ended last year, was discovered during an audit last year. Mrs. Gutierrez, a secretary for the city, was suspended. Mr. Gutierrez, who took office in 2001, resigned in March. He pleaded guilty to three felony charges of false entry on records. He was fined $1,500 and was ordered by a judge to pay $174,000 in restitution within five years or face a sentence of 10 years' imprisonment. Mrs. Gutierrez, who pleaded guilty to theft by a public official of more than $20,000 and less than $100,000, is to be sentenced Tuesday. She could be ordered to serve 2 to 20 years in prison. Steve Barnes (NYT)

Provincetown, along with Somerville, Springfield and Worcester, had initially defied Gov. Mitt Romney, who says all licenses issued to out-of-state couples who do not intend to move to Massachusetts are invalid based on a 1913 law that says Massachusetts cannot issue marriage licenses to couples who are living where those licenses would be void. He was a member of Lawrence Farms Golf Club, Saint Andrews Westchester, Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, and the Sharon Country Club. He was the father of David J. Moore and the late Millard H. Moore. He was the loving grandfather to David J. Moore Jr., Connie Moore Widmann, Jonathan W. Moore, and Marietta L. Reproductions like those above offer the feel and look of real coral without having to plunder a reef, and they bring the seashore to your coffee table. The pieces are convincing because the molds are taken directly from nature. Note, however, that the castings are not as porous as real coral, and so are heavier. The man, who was in his 40's and was not immediately identified by the police, was in stable condition last night at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. The man was holding a garden shovel and a hammer when officers approached him about 8:45 p.m. in response to a burglary call at 598 East 139th Street, the police said. title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: AIRPORT VICTIM HAD STOLEN PASSPORT The authorities said one of the people killed Sunday in the partial collapse of an airline terminal at Charles De Gaulle International Airport has not been identified because she was carrying a stolen passport. The woman had earlier been identified as a Czech, but the owner of the passport is alive and in Prague and told Czech police that her passport was stolen in January 2003. French authorities said they suspect the dead woman was Ukrainian because she was killed during a stopover from Kiev to Miami. The other three victims of the accident have been identified as a Chinese man, a Chinese woman and a Lebanese woman. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: 2nd Trial For Sniper
description: Prosecutors in Fairfax County are preparing for a second trial for John A. Muhammad, who was convicted and sentenced to death in Prince William County for his role in a sniper killing in 2002 in the Washington metropolitan region, a lawyer for Mr. Muhammad said. The lawyer, Jonathan Shapiro, said he and a colleague, Peter Greenspun, who both represented Mr. Muhammad in the first trial, had been notified that they had been reappointed to represent Mr. Muhammad. Prosecutors discussed seeking a second conviction if Mr. Muhammad was successful in appealing his first death penalty. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: GOODYEAR APPOINTS A CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Goodyear Tire and Rubber promoted Richard Kramer yesterday to chief financial officer, succeeding Robert Tieken, who will retire May 31 after a decade in the job. Mr. Kramer, 40, has been senior vice president for strategic planning and restructuring since August and joined Goodyear in 2000 from the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, Goodyear said. Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio, is trying to halt three years of losses.

title: JOINT VENTURE TO MAKE CHEMICALS FROM BACTERIA
description: The DuPont Company and Tate & Lyle of Britain have formed a joint venture to make synthetic fibers with genetically modified bacteria that convert sugar into chemicals, the first commercial use of the process. DuPont Tate & Lyle BioProducts plans to open a plant next year in Loudon, Tenn., that will ferment microbes in corn syrup to make as much as 100 million pounds a year of an ingredient for plastics, the venture's president, John Halberstadt, said yesterday. DuPont is trying to cut spending on oil and natural gas derivatives used to make chemicals. Tate & Lyle, based in London, and DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., each own half of the venture.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Beer Price Raised
description: The corporate parent of the makers of Guinness beer and a range of the world's top spirits, Diageo, will raise the price of a keg of beer in Ireland by about $7 next week, a move that is expected to push the price of beer up by 18 cents a pint. The increase will affect Guinness Ireland's namesake stout, which is brewed in Dublin for the Irish, British and American markets, as well as Budweiser and Carlsberg, which the company brews under license. In raising prices, Diageo cited higher marketing costs, as more people drink at home because of a nationwide ban on smoking in the workplace, including bars and restaurants. Sales of Guinness fell 7 percent worldwide in the six months to last December. The price of a pint of stout ranges from $4 in rural areas to $6 in Dublin. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: NEIMAN MARCUS EXPLORES SELLING KITCHENWARE BUSINESS
description: The Neiman Marcus Group, which operates luxury department stores and catalogs, said yesterday that it might sell its Chef's Catalog business, a retailer of professional-quality kitchen items. The company said that it had hired Elixir Advisors to help find a buyer or a partner for a merger or joint venture. Chef's Catalog accounted last year for about 15 percent of the $500 million that Neiman Marcus made from catalog and Internet sales, a company spokeswoman, Stacie Shirley, said. The Neiman Marcus Group acquired Chef's Catalog in 1998.

title: Putin Calls for Convertible Currency
description: The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, said in his state of the nation address on Wednesday that he wanted to make the Russian ruble fully convertible by 2006, moving up the target date from 2007.

title: Culture in Lower Manhattan
description: Ever since 9/11, there has been serious talk of including a strong cultural presence in the rebuilding at ground zero. It's worth remembering why. For all the gravity of the site itself, and for all the dignity of Michael Arad's memorial design, ground zero is about more than remembering the lives of those who died in terrorist attacks or the events that caused their deaths. It is also about the creation of new vitality. The emergence of a new cultural hub in Lower Manhattan is a way of going beyond memory, a way of enriching, fulfilling and reinterpreting the emotional context of 9/11 itself. We should visit ground zero to honor the victims and remember that day, but we should stay to celebrate life itself in a way that only the arts allow us to do.

title: In the Hamptons, a New Entry On the Show House Circuit
description: Most design ideas in the Hamptons are really recycled ones, like building shingled houses with diamond-shape panes. But not in the Idea House of Hamptons Cottages & Gardens magazine in Water Mill, N.Y., which opens for tours on Saturday. This is one of two houses on the South Fork built from scratch for magazines this year. (The other, sponsored by House & Garden, will open in Wainscott next month.)

title: Democrats Ask If Careful Path Is Best for Kerry
description: President Bush's political difficulties have prompted a debate among Democrats and aides to Senator John Kerry over how cautious his campaign should be on a variety of issues, from choosing a vice president to differentiating himself from Mr. Bush to responding to the turmoil in Iraq.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Rejects 4th Oracle Offer
description: PeopleSoft rejected Oracle's fourth offer yesterday, after Oracle's decision last month to lower its bid to acquire the rival software company to $7.7 billion from $9.4 billion. PeopleSoft reiterated its position that Oracle's offer undervalues the company and would probably be blocked by antitrust regulators. PeopleSoft also announced that it had settled a shareholder lawsuit related to its customer assurance program, in which PeopleSoft guarantees customer refunds of up to five times the sales amount in the event PeopleSoft is acquired and the new owner makes substantial changes to PeopleSoft products. Shareholders had sued to block the program out of concern it would prevent other suitors from attempting to acquire PeopleSoft. Under the settlement announced yesterday, the terms of the customer assurance program, if PeopleSoft decides to extend it after June 30, will be limited to actions by Oracle. The settlement will be moot if the Justice Department prevails in its suit to block the merger, which goes to trial on June 7. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: As Fire Season Approaches, Dread Grows in the West

But it frightened many of the seasoned firefighters who responded to it because it did not behave the way fires in the high Rockies in early May are supposed to.

title: Judicial Ethics Under Review
description: There was widespread outrage when word got out that Justice Antonin Scalia had gone duck hunting with Vice President Dick Cheney while Mr. Cheney had an important case pending in the Supreme Court. That outrage grew when Justice Scalia was allowed to remain on the case. Now Chief Justice William Rehnquist has appointed a committee to look broadly at federal judicial ethics. This has the potential to do some good, although the committee's skewed composition raises concerns about whether it will strengthen the rules or weaken them. Judicial ethics are too important to fall prey to self-protectionism or to partisanship. Congress and the public should watch closely and insist that any changes raise the standard of judicial conduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WRIGHTSON, GEORGE D. JR.
description: WRIGHTSON--George D. Jr. 83, Longboat Key, FL. Died May 25 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. Leaves his wife, Patricia, son, George III, daughters, Mary Boothby and Ann Wrightson. A graduate of Hotchkiss School, Class of '39, attended Williams College, and served in the artillery of the U.S. Army for 35 months. Grew up on Shippan Point, Stamford, CT. Predeceased by his first wife, Harriette. For many years he lived in the Hanover, NH area where he was actively involved in his community and St. Thomas Episcopal Church. Memorial service May 28, 2004 11 AM All Angels Episcopal Church, Longboat Key, FL. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Hanover, NH. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Hotchkiss School, All Angels Episcopal Church, Longboat Key or St. Thomas Church, Hanover, NH.

title: NEW NAME IN COUNTRY
description: Country music's largest annual gathering, Fan Fair, will have a new name when it opens on June 10 in Nashville. The four-day event will now be called the CMA Music Festival and will expand its musical offerings to include noncountry artists, like Kid Rock's longtime sideman Uncle Kracker, above, who have some connection to country music. The CMA is the Country Music Association, a pioneering trade organization founded in 1958. ''We recognized that Fan Fair was a brand with a 32-year history,'' the CMA executive director, Ed Benson, said in a statement at the end of last year's event, ''and the only brand with as much if not more equity was CMA itself and the awareness around the world of the annual CMA Awards.'' The name change has drawn a mixed response from country's extremely loyal fans and from Music Row. ''I hate the thought of the word fan being removed from Fan Fair,'' said Jeffrey Steele, Nashville's hottest current songwriter. ''Fan Fair is synonymous with Nashville.'' PHIL SWEETLAND

description: Tony Kuhn was named executive vice president and managing director on the GMC Truck account at Lowe & Partners Worldwide, New York, succeeding Susan Cantor, now president of the Lowe New York office. A colorful room divider and a sleep sofa will expand accommodations, and to perk up a drab room, there are paper wall ''tiles'' that go up quickly and can be decorated with a pot of paint.

title: Jack Lenor Larsen in Retrospect: A Fusion of Orange and Ethnic

Sir Christopher ran Vodafone, the world's largest wireless telephone company, for six years and stepped down last July. He will become the deputy chairman of GlaxoSmithKline on June 1 and will assume the chairmanship on June 1. Sir Christopher will be paid 240,000 in cash ($434,760) and 60,000 in GlaxoSmithKline shares for serving as deputy chairman, with the compensation rising to 400,000 in cash and 100,000 in shares when he becomes chairman. The United States later cut off assistance to the unit, and American diplomats successfully pressured President Alvaro Uribe's government to oust Gen. Hector Fabio Velasco, the Air Force chief accused of covering up the operation. Investigators are trying to determine the scope of involvement of an American company under contract to the United States, AirScan Inc. of Florida, which has been accused of providing the coordinates that permitted the Colombian pilots to zero in on the town. title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Vote On Loudspeakers At Mosques
description: Residents in Hamtramck, a city of 23,000 that is surrounded by Detroit, will decide whether to permit mosques to broadcast the Islamic call to prayer. On Tuesday, the City Council suspended the start of a noise ordinance that it passed last month to allow mosques to broadcast the call five times a day, from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., over loudspeakers. Opponents of the decision petitioned the council, with 630 signatures, to let the ordinance go before voters as part of a special ballot in July or at the regular elections in August. Councilman Shahab Ahmed said mosques would not be penalized if they broadcast the calls to prayer before a vote is held.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH WILL EXPAND ONE SITE AND CLOSE OTHERS
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it planned to expand an 88-acre site in Summit, N.J., for office and research use while closing other units in the state. The Summit campus will be Schering-Plough's second-largest center after its headquarters in Kenilworth, N.J. Operations at eight satellite offices will be moved to Summit to pare costs, and no job cuts are planned, a spokesman, Stephen Galpin, said. The company expects to have 1,700 workers in Summit by the end of 2005. Schering-Plough bought the Summit site from Novartis in November 2000.

title: National Briefing | Education: Teachers' Union President Won't Run Again
description: Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers since 1997, said she would not run for re-election in July. Ms. Feldman, 64, told a meeting of 200 union leaders that it would be hard for her to run again because of the challenges of treatment for breast cancer. She succeeded Albert Shanker as president. Under Ms. Feldman, the union grew to 1.3 million members from 940,000. From 1986 to 1997, she was president of the United Federation of Teachers, the 130,000-member union in New York. The secretary-treasurer of the national union, Edward J. McElroy, said he would run to succeed Ms. Feldman. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microchip Technology Expects Income Increase
description: Microchip Technology, whose computer chips are used in products ranging from toasters to cars, said yesterday that first-quarter net income would rise to 26 cents a share, more than its forecast, on record orders. Sales in the quarter ending June 30 will be as much as $212 million, the company, based in Chandler, Ariz., said in a statement. The average profit forecast of 17 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial was 25 cents a share, and 13 analysts forecast sales of $206.2 million. Microchip Technology has benefited from an expansion of global chip sales. Those sales are expected to surge as much as 30 percent this year on demand for consumer electronics including camera-equipped wireless phones and digital cameras, the market researcher Gartner Inc. has said. On April 22 Microchip Technology had forecast profit of as much as 25 cents a share on sales of as much as $207 million. In the year-earlier first quarter, the company reported net income of $13.5 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $161.3 million. Excluding some costs, the company would have had a profit of $33.5 million, or 16 cents a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Upholds Yukos Tax
description: A Moscow court upheld a tax ministry order that the Russian oil company, Yukos, pay 99.4 billion rubles ($3.4 billion) in back taxes and fines for the year 2000. Yukos said that it expected to appeal the ruling, which was handed down by the Moscow Arbitration Court. The company has a month to file the appeal and will have to start paying on the claim only if it loses its appeal. The tax ministry made the claim for the back taxes in December but Yukos maintained that the tax shelters it used in 2000 were legal. The company has said that the taxes and the arrest of its former chief executive, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, are politically motivated. Mr. Khodorkovsky's lawyer, Karina Moskalenko, said she would file a challenge to a court order that Mr. Khodorkovsky remain in jail. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Put On A Happy Face
description: Be nice, or else, Russian border guards have been ordered by their superiors. Visitors to Russia often complain of rude behavior by surly, scowling border guards. At airports that means no smiles and nary a word of welcome. At border crossings, it can mean guards are more interested in collecting bribes than encouraging tourism and cross-border business. The border guard service is part of the Federal Security Service or F.S.B., the successor of the K.G.B. ''Some people have objected that our border guards are not very smiley,'' an F.S.B. spokesman told Reuters. ''But now we hope that they will be more friendly.''

title: All-Weather Palm Trees Light the Way
description: Outside Waikiki Wally's, a kitschy Hawaiian lounge in the East Village, are two cartoonish illuminated palm trees, one tall, one stumpy. That tropical touch can be achieved at home with the palm trees, above, made with yellow and green rope lights on collapsible aluminum frames. They could light a spirited pool party, or they could just stand sentry in a child's bedroom. A seven-foot version (which is five feet wide) costs $149; a four-and-a-half-foot tree, center, is $79; both through Frontgate's catalog, (888) 263-9850 or www.frontgate.com.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cortland: Concern About Mercury Levels
description: New federal mercury standards could increase pollution in New York even if they reduce mercury levels nationwide, according to a report released here and in several other upstate cities yesterday. In January, the Bush administration proposed allowing coal-fired electric power plants, the primary sources of mercury pollution, to trade credits for mercury emissions. The report, by the New York Public Interest Research Group, said the plan could harm New York because instead of forcing all plants to reduce mercury emissions, it would allow upwind power plants to produce additional pollution if they buy credits from plants in other parts of the country that have cut their emissions. Anthony DePalma (NYT)
