title: Shoulda, Woulda, Can
description: I'm glad the president gave a sober talk about where we're going in Iraq and in confronting terrorism. But I can't say I found it reassuring. I still don't feel we have a broad, workable strategy. We currently have two national commissions looking backward -- one on how 9/11 happened, and another about why no W.M.D. were found in Iraq. Those are key questions. But what we really need is a bipartisan commission looking forward. I'd call it the National Commission for Doing Things Right. Its mandate would be simple: tell the country what U.S. policy would be if we were determined to do things right in confronting terrorism, no matter what the political costs -- so we don't have to have yet another commission looking backward two years from now. Here's what I'd like to see:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Town Agrees To Halt Unrest
description: The people of the southeastern Ilave, who lynched their mayor last month after accusing him of corruption, agreed to suspend weeks of unrest after the federal government said it would withdraw troops. Ilave and the highland region around it have been convulsed by tumult since the villagers killed Mayor Cirilo Robles on April 26 after the central government in Lima failed to heed warnings from angry townspeople. After seven political leaders were arrested on suspicion of having orchestrated the killing, the townspeople blocked roads and pelted journalists with rocks. The government says it will negotiate the town's demands. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: City Diverted $600 Million Set Aside for Low-Cost Housing
description: Fifteen years ago, New York City agreed to spend $600 million that it receives from the Battery Park City Authority on low-cost housing. But a report issued on Wednesday said that little if any of that money had actually been spent on housing, because the city had used it for general budget needs.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Payments In Cluster Bombing
description: A judge ordered Colombia to pay $700,000 in restitution to the families of 18 civilians killed in 1998 when the Colombian air force dropped an American-made cluster bomb on the eastern village of Santo Domingo during an anti-guerrilla operation. The United States later cut off assistance to the unit, and American diplomats successfully pressured President lvaro Uribe's government to oust Gen. Hctor Fabio Velasco, the Air Force chief accused of covering up the operation. Investigators are trying to determine the scope of involvement of an American company under contract to the United States, AirScan Inc. of Florida, which has been accused of providing the coordinates that permitted the Colombian pilots to zero in on the town. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Coming to the Internet, a 'Survivor' Parody of G.O.P.
description: Democrats are hoping that Americans  at least Democratic-leaning Americans  have not yet had their fill of reality television .

title: Hailing a Dream
description: New York City is auctioning off 300 medallions each year for the next three years, the largest expansion of the taxi fleet since the Depression. Hundreds of people, most of them immigrants, are scraping money together to bid on these precious aluminum slips, which represent freedom, security and, perhaps one day, wealth. This series followed several bidders through the auction process to the day when some received shiny medallions of their own on their taxis' yellow hoods. The series continues to be online at nytimes.com/metro.

title: A Stuffed Doppelgnger
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wells Fargo to Acquire Assets of Strong Financial

title: Study Faults Colleges on Graduation Rates
description: As growing numbers of Americans enter college, most colleges and universities have failed to ensure that those students will graduate, according to a study released yesterday by the Education Trust in Washington.

title: A Gas-Guzzler Tax? (It's Just a Thought)
description: To the Editor:

title: RULING UPHOLDS LAW AUTHORIZING ASSISTED SUICIDE
description: A federal appeals court yesterday upheld the only law in the nation authorizing doctors to help their terminally ill patients commit suicide. The decision, by a divided three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, said the Justice Department did not have the power to punish the doctors involved.

title: Metro Matters; Big Plans, Always Big, For West Side
description: FOR years, New York has dreamed up one plan after another for Manhattan's far West Side, from filling it with housing and skyscrapers (that was in the 1980's) to making it Yankee Stadium's new home (the 1990's). None of it happened.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters Criticize Emergency Rules
description: The union leaders representing city firefighters and fire officers sent a letter yesterday to Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge criticizing the city's new emergency protocol, saying it does not meet federal requirements, and asking for a meeting to discuss their concerns. The union leaders, Stephen J. Cassidy of the Uniformed Firefighters Association and Peter L. Gorman of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, called the protocol misguided because it makes the Police Department the primary agency at events involving dangerous materials, a departure from the rest of the nation, while giving the Fire Department the responsibility for saving lives and decontamination. ''It is impossible to be responsible for life safety and not be in command of the emergency from the outset,'' they wrote. Jarrod N. Bernstein, a spokesman for the city's Office of Emergency Management, which drew up the protocol, said it was in the best interest of the city and complied ''fully with the federal mandate.'' William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; The oil price spikes give new urgency to the debate over their consequences.
description: JAMES CARVILLE once mused that instead of coming back as the president or the pope or a .400 baseball hitter if there were reincarnation, he would rather come back as the bond market, because ''you can intimidate everybody.''

title: Sports Briefing
description: HOCKEY

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Guardian Sought In Starvation Case
description: New Jersey's child advocate asked the state's Superior Court yesterday to appoint the leader of a national child welfare group as the legal guardian for three boys whose adoptive parents are accused of starving them. The advocate, Kevin M. Ryan, asked that Marcia Robinson Lowry, executive director of Children's Rights Inc., be named guardian for three of the children adopted by Raymond and Vanessa Jackson. Ms. Lowry filed a lawsuit on the children's behalf charging the State Division of Youth and Family Services with civil rights violations. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Human Crematory Finds Home With the Holsteins
description: Most everything on Bob and Jackie Gaines's 200-acre dairy farm blends right into the pastoral setting: the 60 Holsteins, the tractors and heavy equipment, the wooden shack where a son makes maple syrup in the spring.

title: In Connecticut, a Trial On Pension Fund Losses Could Shake Wall Street
description: Away from the limelight of recent corporate trials, a six-member jury in a Connecticut hamlet will begin hearing a little-publicized case next week that could have far reaching implications for Wall Street buyout firms and the big-money investors and institutions that back them.

title: DDB Worldwide Tops Honors in Clio Awards
description: DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group , has won top honors at the 45th annual Clio Awards ceremonies.

title: Inventing a Menu to Provide Food for Thought
description: DURING Jorge Leon Collazo's career as a professional chef, he has braided strips of salmon and simmered veal stock so perfectly that he would gaze at it, transfixed. He was the executive chef for a premier Midtown law firm, his cuisine successfully competing with grand restaurants for the high-ticket lunch crowd. At a culinary institute, he taught ''History, Food and Culture/Food History and the Cultural Dynamic of Food.''

title: The SUV of Wheelbarrows: Jeep Comes to the Garden
description: Demolishing buildings or maintaining golf courses might not be in your near future, but the $179 model WB8PFF professional Jeep wheelbarrow, below, with an eight-cubic-foot polyethylene tub, might still be useful for the garden. Its double front wheels lend extra stability, the steel handles are extralong, and the solid polyurethane tires will never go flat. The steel front bumper lets you tip a load forward without damaging soft ground. They are available at Keough's Paint & Hardware in Ridgefield, Conn.; 1 Ethan Allen Highway; (203) 544-8379; other stores at www.jeepwheelbarrows.com.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Congressional concern over American correctional executives who were assigned to Iraq despite prior accusations of prisoner abuse misstated the name of an online magazine that carried a first-person account by one such person, Lane McCotter. It is Corrections.com, not Correction.com. ( Go to Article )

title: Kerry Abandons Plan to Delay Accepting Nomination
description: Senator John Kerry announced on Wednesday that he would accept the Democratic nomination at his party's convention in Boston in July, abandoning the idea of a strategic delay to narrow President Bush's substantial financial advantage.

title: Editorial Observer; A Film That Could Warm Up the Debate on Global Warming
description: Even as a summer disaster film, ''The Day After Tomorrow'' does not rank with the greats of yesteryear. Its dialogue is overwrought, its symbolism sophomoric, its subplots annoyingly irrelevant and its relationship to scientific reality tenuous at best.

title: Putin Accuses Critics of Working for Foreign Powers
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Wednesday that foreign ''political, economic and media pressure'' was being used in an attempt to weaken Russia's chances of competing globally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, DAVID C.
description: QUINN--David C., on May 25, 2004, in North Salem, NY. A trial lawyer, actor, rare book collector and aviator, he flew in World War II and the Vietnam War. Flying air-sea rescue in 1945, he made the first landing to pick up a downed pilot off the coast of Japan--a feat recorded in the book, ''High Honor.'' He is survived by his wife, columnist Jane Bryant Quinn, and five children, David P., Christopher, Justin, Martha Quinn Tarlow, stepson, Matthew Ostrowski, and seven grandchildren. He was much loved. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: A Little Bit of Nantucket Is an Island in SoHo
description: Sue Drabkin closed her home furnishings shop on Nantucket not long ago and opened another in Manhattan, Fleur de Lis SoHo, at 128 Thompson Street. Her furniture and accessories of 1920's, 30's and 40's style (some new) are suitable for summer homes. Dressers, many with their original paint and hardware, are $600 to $1,200; a blue wrought-iron sofa is $1,200, and a pair of matching armchairs are $1,200; new wire chandeliers for candles are $290; and old glass and wood buoys are $110 to $200. Fleur de Lis; (212) 473-0800.

title: Nigerian State Says It Will Vaccinate Against Polio
description: Ibrahim Shekarau, the Kano state governor whose eight-month moratorium on polio vaccinations has been blamed for the spread of polio widely across Africa, said in an interview on Tuesday that he was ready to resume immunizations.

title: Rebels Sign Pact With Sudan's Government to End 21-Year War
description: The Islamic government of Sudan and rebels in the Christian and animist south signed a pact on Wednesday pledging to end 21 years of war in which two million people have died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REDSTONE, GABRIEL ADAM
description: REDSTONE--Gabriel Adam, age 20, died tragically in an accident on Monday evening, May 24, 2004. Formerly of Boston, MA, where he attended Milton Academy, Gabriel was most recently a resident of Los Angeles and Rancho Mirage, CA. He was attending California State College in Northridge and he was scheduled to matriculate at Otis Art Institute this fall. He was a gifted artist whose generous nature changed the lives of many of his friends. Gabriel Adam is the grandson of Edward and Madeline Redstone of Rancho Mirage, CA. He is the son of the late Ruth Ann Redstone and the grandson of the late Leila Redstone. His brothers are Steven (Michele), Howard (Jennifer) and Larry (Jennifer) Sweetwood of New Jersey and his uncle is Michael Redstone of Massachusetts. Funeral arrangements are pending. Interment will take place in Massachusetts. Remembrances in his memory to the Eisenhower Medical Center, Rancho Mirage, CA.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: City Manager Resigns Amid Friction
description: Teodoro J. Benavides, the first Hispanic city manager of Dallas, who has experienced increasing friction with the mayor and the City Council, said he would retire, effective on Nov. 19. Mr. Benavides, 53, was hired in 1998 by Mayor Ron Kirk. He had enough backing on the council to survive two efforts by Mayor Laura Miller to dismiss him, but that support appeared recently to be waning. Mr. Benavides angered many residents when he fired the first black police chief in the city last summer and by approving salary increases for some city workers amid a wage freeze. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Pentagon Was Blindsided by Bush Pledge to Raze Prison
description: On Monday night, President Bush made the dramatic announcement that the United States would demolish Abu Ghraib prison and build a modern maximum-security center in Baghdad to replace it. But on Wednesday, Pentagon officials said the president's words had taken them by surprise, and they scrambled without success to come up with details of the plan.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Monday about the Who concert on Saturday misstated the charge on which Peter Townshend, the lead guitarist, was arrested in Britain last year. It was suspicion of possessing indecent images of children -- not possession of child pornography. (As the review noted, he was cleared but cautioned by the police.)

title: Agriculture Dept. Rescinds Changes to Organic Food Standards
description: Secretary of Agriculture Ann M. Veneman announced yesterday that she was rescinding changes her department made last month to federal organic food standards.

title: REGULATORS APPROVE SPINOFF OF ALCAN ASSETS
description: The aluminum producer Alcan said yesterday that regulators in the United States and Europe had approved its planned spinoff of rolling mill assets to satisfy antitrust concerns over its purchase of France's Pechiney. The agreements, with the Department of Justice and the European Commission, are an acceptable alternative to divesting operations in Ravenswood, W.Va., and selling plants in France and Germany, as the regulators initially ordered, Alcan said. Alcan's chief executive, Travis Engen, said last week that he wanted to keep assets he had agreed to divest as part of the 4 billion euro ($4.8 billion) Pechiney purchase in February.

title: Roger W. Straus Jr., Book Publisher From the Age of the Independents, Dies at 87
description: Roger W. Straus Jr., the brash and opinionated grandee who presided for nearly six decades over the book-publishing company that bore his name, the last surviving representative of the age of independent houses owned privately by gentlemen of literary taste, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: To Quiet a Whirring Computer, Fight Noise With Noise
description: THE constant drone of a computer cooling fan can be annoying. But a professor at Brigham Young University has taken an unusual step to mute this noise: more noise, produced in just the right quantities from tiny loudspeakers that surround the fan.

title: The Times and Iraq: A Mea Culpa, and a Debate (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Council Allows One Wal-Mart, Not Two
description: The City Council, after a long and cantankerous debate, approved zoning changes on Wednesday that would allow a Wal-Mart to be built on the city's West Side, but turned down a proposal for another on the South Side.

title: Lonely Democrat Helped by a Fellow Veteran (No, Not Kerry)
description: Tony Knowles , the former Democratic governor of Alaska running for the Senate seat there, looked as if he was on his own.

title: JONES APPAREL RAISES BID FOR MAXWELL SHOE
description: The Jones Apparel Group, maker of AK Anne Klein clothing and Nine West footwear, raised its hostile bid for the Maxwell Shoe Company by 13 percent yesterday, to $334 million in cash. Jones said that it had increased the bid to $22.50 a share from $20. If it has not bought enough shares or reached an agreement with Maxwell's board by June 21, Jones said it will end its takeover attempt. Maxwell said that its board would review the revised bid, and advised its stockholders to take no action. Jones made an unsolicited offer in February to buy Maxwell, a move that would expand its footwear lines and unite Maxwell's AK Anne Klein shoes with Jones's Anne Klein line. Maxwell rejected that proposal.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Man in California for Possible Terror Connection
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26 - One of the persons sought for questioning by the F.B.I. in connection with possible terrorist acts in the coming months is a young man raised in Southern California who converted to Islam as a teenager and has lived in Pakistan for most of the past five years.

title: TBWA Worldwide Gets Most One Show Awards
description: TBWA Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, won the most honors at the 33rd annual One Show awards ceremony, presented for creative excellence by the One Club for Art and Copy in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALEY, REV. TIMOTHY A. S.J.
description: HEALEY--Rev. Timothy A. S.J. on May 26, 2004. Beloved brother of Sr. Nora Healey O.P. and Kathleen Ryan. He was a teacher at Regis High School from 1963-1984 and later became a chaplain at Goldwater Hospital to the present. Friends may call at the Jesuit Residence at 53 East 83rd Street on Friday, May 28, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Saturday May 29, 10:30AM, St. Ignatius Park Avenue Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: Look Out, Antigone, Creon Still Means What He Says
description: We read Greek plays before we see them. We analyze structure and theme; we don't experience them as spectacles full of music and ritual. This primal whole is what Ellen Stewart creates with a vibrantly staged ''Antigone'' that opened on May 19 at the La MaMa Annex. What a fine way for the Annex to celebrate its 40th anniversary. Ms. Stewart is one of Off Broadway's great pioneers. And La MaMa is one of the few institutions that unfailingly welcomes theater that is experimental and international.

title: Anti-Doping Agency Enters a Gray Area
description: When the United States Anti-Doping Agency was created in October 2000 to oversee drug testing in Olympic sports, it was largely hailed as an independent body that would aggressively nab cheaters and dampen international allegations of foot-dragging or cover-ups on the part of American officials.

title: Escape From the Clutches Of a Counterfeit Web Site
description: The Internet can be a dangerous place, with every e-mail message a potential carrier of viruses, Trojan horses or come-ons from phishers -- thieves hoping to trick you into giving up passwords, credit card numbers or other personal information. Such e-mail often looks like a legitimate message from companies like eBay, PayPal or Citibank, but the links they provide lead to ''spoofed'' Web sites that look legitimate but are not.

title: Plea Agreement Is Reached in Pipe Case
description: A day after announcing a second indictment against McWane Inc., federal prosecutors disclosed Wednesday that a longtime McWane manager had agreed to cooperate with their investigation into environmental and safety violations at McWane, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of cast iron water and sewer pipe.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COWIN, DANIEL
description: COWIN--Daniel. Those who knew you well, still speak of you with kindness and admiration. Those who knew you best continually miss your wise counsel, quiet encouragement; your creativity, intelligence and taste. Would that you could return. Joyce

title: Survey Finds U.S. Agencies Engaged in 'Data Mining'
description: A survey of federal agencies has found more than 120 programs that collect and analyze large amounts of personal data on individuals to predict their behavior.

title: Spain May Loosen Iron Grip on Public TV
description: More than 25 years after Spain stepped out of Franco's shadow, one vestige of authoritarianism lives on here: every democratically elected administration since the late 1970's has used the government-owned television network, TVE, as a mouthpiece for its propaganda. In opposition, political parties bemoaned the manipulation. In power, they could not resist behaving in the same way.

title: A Real Following; The Ultimate Cable News Guru, When Not in Class
description: BRIAN STELTER had an important editorial decision to make. A reader had sent him a tip that CNN planned to offer a video news service on the Web. Mr. Stelter was waiting for verification or denial of the item. The CNN public relations people in Atlanta had promised to get back in touch.

title: Nichols Is Found Guilty In Oklahoma Bombing
description: Nine years after a homemade bomb ripped through the federal building in Oklahoma City, Terry L. Nichols was convicted on Wednesday of 161 counts of first-degree murder in the blast, and a state jury has to decide whether he should be executed.

title: Liberty Defeats Defending Champion
description: It is hard to say that the third game of the season could be a big one, but that was the case as the Liberty took on the defending W.N.B.A. champion Detroit Shock last night at Madison Square Garden. The revamped Liberty defeated Detroit, 64-52, behind a strong second-half performance from guard Becky Hammon and forward Elena Baranova.

title: Police Back Gun Lawsuit
description: To the Editor:

title: BMW Owner And Truck Do Slow Dance In Great Neck
description: Things had been downright cordial in the parking lot of a Waldbaum's, as a woman negotiated with the man about to tow her BMW. There was no yelling, the Nassau County police said. No screaming. No violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANTOBELLO, EMMA T.
description: SANTOBELLO--Emma T. Devoted wife of the late August L. Loving mother of daughters Connie & Louella, and son August, Jr. Died peacefully on May 25, 2004. Emma often brought back memories of her childhood with warm and entertaining stories about her family life. She will be missed by her surviving six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Visitation will be held at Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, 41-45 58th St, Woodside, NY, Thursday, May 27th, Friday, May 28th, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday May 29th at 9:45AM at St. Sebastian R.C. Church, 58th Street and Roosevelt Ave, Woodside, New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Airport Victim Had Stolen Passport
description: The authorities said one of the people killed Sunday in the partial collapse of an airline terminal at Charles De Gaulle International Airport has not been identified because she was carrying a stolen passport. The woman had earlier been identified as a Czech, but the owner of the passport is alive and in Prague and told Czech police that her passport was stolen in January 2003. French authorities said they suspect the dead woman was Ukrainian because she was killed during a stopover from Kiev to Miami. The other three victims of the accident have been identified as a Chinese man, a Chinese woman and a Lebanese woman. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: The Times and Iraq: A Mea Culpa, and a Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Clark Is Giving the Yankees a Presence at First Base
description: When Tony Clark was 11, he and his friends would spend all day playing pickup games at the Lemon Grove Little League park in San Diego. Clark was the best player by far, lifting towering home runs, and the only way the other kids could stop him was to make him bat left-handed.

title: France Gets Clearance To Give Aid To Alstom
description: Europe's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said Wednesday that he would approve France's aid to the ailing industrial giant Alstom, after getting a firm commitment from the French government to find privately owned partners for the company's main businesses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Buildings Dept. Cuts Response Times
description: The city's Buildings Department has improved its response times to complaints since the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attack, when the agency's emergency efforts, and a reduction in the inspection staff, led to longer response times, says an audit report to be released today by City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. But the report also cites continuing delays in responding to nonemergency complaints. Jennifer Givner, an agency spokeswoman, said that the agency was redeploying inspectors and hiring more of them. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Dieter Sues Atkins Estate and Company
description: A 53-year-old man sued the estate of Dr. Robert C. Atkins and the company that promotes his diet yesterday. The suit says following the Atkins diet for two years raised the man's cholesterol so much that his arteries became clogged and required a medical procedure to open them.

title: POLO AGREES TO BUY CHILDREN'S CLOTHING LICENSEE
description: Polo Ralph Lauren said yesterday that it had agreed to pay about $230 million in cash for its North American children's clothing licensee, a move that would help the company control distribution and production of its clothes. Polo said it expected revenue from the licensee, RL Childrenswear, would be more than $200 million in its first full year of operation in fiscal 2006. The company also said its fourth-quarter earnings rose 4.5 percent, helped by increased sales of its Lauren apparel line. Net income rose to $76.5 million, or 75 cents a share, from $73.2 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the quarter that ended April 3, including licensing revenue, climbed 18 percent to $818.8 million, the biggest gain in two years.

title: All the News Thats Fit to Blog
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Images From 'Painters of Reality'
description: A selection  of images from "Painters of Reality," now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Shutterbugs
description:
By STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM
Capturing the fleeting memories of summer has gotten easier, even for amateurs.

title: 'Union Square'
description: Directed by Stephen J. Szklarski

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day

title: Residential Real Estate; Lead-Paint Law Frustrates Plans for Low-Income Housing
description: Correction Appended

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Stieglitz and Modernism in America, From the Perspective of a Caricaturist
description: A small exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is getting the jump on next year's 100th anniversary of the founding of Alfred Stieglitz's Little Galleries of the Photo-Secession. Open from 1905 to 1917, the Manhattan gallery was called 291 because of its address, 291 Fifth Avenue, near 31st Street, and it was one of the birth chambers of Modernism in America.

title: Youth Hospital Should Close, Officials Agree
description: After at first resisting an order by a court-authorized panel, New Jersey child welfare officials agreed on Thursday to close a troubled, state-run psychiatric hospital for adolescents.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS DROP. Soybean prices tumbled the maximum allowed amid speculation that demand is declining in China. In Chicago, soybeans for July delivery fell 50 cents, or 5.7 percent, to $8.22 a bushel.

title: Hamilton Defies Trend By Hitting His Shots
description: Here in the Eastern Conference finals, where almost nobody seems to hit a jump shot with any semblance of regularity, Richard Hamilton has stood out like a beacon of light on a long, dark night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANSKI, BENJAMIN
description: MANSKI -- Benjamin. With great sadness and a keen sense of loss, we mourn the passing of our beloved husband, father, father-in-law, and grandfather Benjamin (Ben) Manski. In the 91 years of his life, he helped and supported many in Poland, Russia, Israel and the USA. His memory will be cherished with much love and respect. The Manski and Weinstein families.

title: Houses on Canals: Sit Back and Watch the World Float By
description: WHO -- Stephen Stoller, 59, an artist, shown with his wife, Francy Stoller, a poet, 56

title: Desert Detox
description: WHERE dude ranches once flourished, Wickenburg, Ariz., has found a new identity as a center for detoxification and other treatments. Once your psychological problems are under control, there are plenty of horses for riding into the sunset. Page 6.

title: An Inquiry in Treasury Chief's Debt Holdings
description: The Treasury Department inspector general's office will review Secretary John W. Snow's ownership of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac debt during a period when he was seeking to toughen regulation of the companies, the nation's two largest mortgage financiers.

title: A Real Nuclear Danger
description: While the Bush administration has been distracted by the invasion and occupation of Iraq, it has neglected the far more urgent threat to American security from dangerous nuclear materials that must be safeguarded before they can fall into the hands of terrorists. That is the inescapable conclusion to be drawn from a new report that documents the slow pace of protecting potential nuclear bomb material at loosely guarded sites around the world.

title: Prentice Marshall, 77, Federal Judge, Dies
description: Prentice H. Marshall, who as an activist federal judge in Chicago presided over cases that changed the makeup of the Chicago police force and sent the head of the Teamsters union to prison, died on Monday in Ponce Inlet, Fla., where he had lived for 14 years. He was 77.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMBERG, KAY SIMMON
description: BLUMBERG--Kay Simmon. Born in Berlin in 1909, came to New York in 1926. Graduated from NYU. Worked first as a German translator, then, after studying with Berenice Abbott, became a professional photographer, specializing in children but picturing whatever else came before her lens, in her wide-ranging travels and her favorite subject, New York. Happily married to Mike Blumberg who predeceased. Hopefully now photographing the angels with her little ''dinkies.''

title: Canoeing, Hawaiian-Style
description: OUTRIGGER canoes have long been identified with Hawaii, but they're showing up these days in unlikely places like Massachusetts, Texas and New York. Paddlers say the ''aloha spirit'' sets the sport apart from kayaking and conventional canoeing. Several cities around the nation have clubs for enthusiasts. Page 8.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Front Row column of the Fashion page on Tuesday about the designer Zac Posen misstated the date and place of a commencement speech he gave. The event occurred on Wednesday, not yesterday, at the Laboratory Institute of Merchandising (not Fashion Merchandising).

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Bond Rating Retained
description: Moody's Investors Service said that the state would retain the highest general obligation bond rating, Aaa, thus removing the threat of a downgrade that could have cost Virginia millions of dollars in added interest fees. Moody's had placed Virginia on a downgrade watch list last fall because of the weak economy and projections of budget shortages for years to come. Gov. Mark Warner had cited the threat as a central argument for his plan to overhaul the state's tax system, which included raising taxes. The legislature enacted much of that proposal after a bitter budget debate last month. James Dao (NYT)

title: G.E. Attacks European Ruling on Honeywell Merger
description: Lawyers representing General Electric made a stinging attack on the European Commission on Thursday during an appeal of the commission's veto of General Electric's $43 billion acquisition of the avionics company Honeywell in 2001.

title: Should U.S. Take Sides in Mideast?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: I.R.S. Asked To Investigate Diocese
description: Americans United for Separation of Church and State, an advocacy group based in Washington, has called on the Internal Revenue Service to investigate whether the Roman Catholic Diocese of Colorado Springs violated the law by endorsing political candidates. Bishop Michael J. Sheridan of the diocese wrote a pastoral letter warning that Catholics who voted for candidates who favored abortion rights, stem cell research, gay marriage or euthanasia were putting their salvation at risk and should be denied communion. Americans United said that the bishop's letter was effectively a command to vote for Republicans. The I.R.S. has a code prohibiting churches and other nonprofit groups from endorsing or opposing political candidates, but has sanctioned violators infrequently. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: A Speech That's No Joke
description: It has always been easy to make fun of Al Gore. But if there's any truth to the thunderous criticism he's turned loose on the Bush administration this week, it's time to dispense with the jokes and listen seriously to what the man is saying.

title: Sharon, in Reversal, Proposes Full Pullout From Gaza Strip
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, rebuffed today by right-wing members of his cabinet on his plan for a partial pullout from the Gaza Strip, has decided to reverse course and present ministers on Sunday with his original plan for a complete withdrawal.

title: 2 Relievers Are Seeking Work and Trust From Torre
description: Gabe White has considered talking to Manager Joe Torre about it, but he doubts the conversation would get anywhere. White, a left-handed reliever for the Yankees, wants to pitch more to stay sharp. But he knows he has not pitched well enough to earn Torre's trust.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Cortlandt: Sergeant Charged With Child Sex Abuse
description: A New York City police sergeant has been charged in Westchester County with sexually abusing a 12-year-old girl, the state police said yesterday. The sergeant, Paul Helbock, 43, who is with the Joint Terrorism Task Force, is accused of having sexual contact with the girl, a friend of the family, at her home in Cortlandt several times between last fall or early winter and May 20, said Tim Santiago, a state police investigator. The girl reported the contacts to school officials on May 21, and Sergeant Helbock, who lives in Putnam County, turned himself in to the state police on Wednesday, the investigator said. Sergeant Helbock has been charged with one count of first-degree sexual abuse. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A calendar listing in House & Home yesterday about the International Exposition of Sculpture, Objects and Functional Art, which opens with a preview on Wednesday, misstated the location. It is the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, not the 69th Regiment Armory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   URBAN, SARAH (SALLY)
description: URBAN--Sarah (Sally) on May 26, 2004. Beloved daughter of the late Ida and Louis Bursky. Cherished wife of Martin Urban, of blessed memory. Loving mother of Goldy and Arthur Fried and Lois and Gerald Kirsh. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and Michael Greenberg, Steven and Robin Fried and Roy Israel Kirsh. Adoring great-grandmother of Martin, Abagail, Gillian, Max and Nicole. Sister of the late Rose Bursky. We will miss her sharp intellect, keen humor and spunk. We celebrate her long life and pray that she rest in peace.

title: Should U.S. Take Sides in Mideast?
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Out of College and Onto Jobless Rolls in China
description: With China's leaders struggling to engineer a soft landing for the country's overheating economy, Zhao Guangxi and Zhou Ruidong face a problem more typical of a country mired in a deep recession. Neither man can find a job.

title: American Being Sought by the F.B.I. Found His Place in Islam, Relatives Say
description: Adam Yahiye Gadahn, the young man from Southern California sought by the F.B.I. for questioning in a global terrorism investigation, was a troubled youth from an unconventional background who was looking for a place in the world, relatives said.

title: World Briefings
description: AMERICAS

title: Delight Over Coup Is Evident in Transcripts
description: Five days after a bloody coup on Sept. 11, 1973, that toppled Salvador Allende Gossens, the Marxist leader of Chile, Henry A. Kissinger chatted on the phone with President Richard M. Nixon about the event, which had clearly delighted both men.

title: In Rural Utah, Students' School Day Stretches to 12 Hours (With 4 on the Bus)
description: The sky is still dark over the canyon lands of southeastern Utah at 5:30 a.m., but two dozen Navajo students are already preparing for school. Their bus driver, William Mustache, is circling his yellow rig, checking the running lights before setting out through the backcountry dawn to fetch them.

title: Bloomberg Defends Changes To Fire Dept.
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the New York Fire Department would buy 1,500 new air masks that protect firefighters from hazardous materials like nerve agents and other dangerous chemicals. The new masks, which Mr. Bloomberg described during a graduation ceremony for 233 probationary firefighters yesterday in Brooklyn, will cost $3.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REDSTONE, GABRIEL ADAM
description: REDSTONE--Gabriel Adam, age 20, died tragically in an accident on Monday evening, May 24, 2004. Formerly of Boston, MA, where he attended Milton Academy, Gabriel was most recently a resident of Los Angeles and Rancho Mirage, CA. He was attending California State College in Northridge and he was scheduled to matriculate at Otis Art Institute this fall. He was a gifted artist whose generous nature changed the lives of many of his friends. Gabriel Adam is the grandson of Edward and Madeline Redstone of Rancho Mirage, CA. He is the son of the late Ruth Ann Redstone and the grandson of the late Leila Redstone. His brothers are Steven (Michele), Howard (Jennifer) and Larry (Jennifer) Sweetwood of New Jersey and his uncle is Michael Redstone of Massachusetts. Services at Congregation Kerem Shalom, 659 Elm St. (off Rt 2 West) Concord, Ma on Sunday, May 30 at 12 noon. Following interment at Temple Israel Cemetery, Wakefield. A Memorial Observance will be held at the home of Ted & Cynthia Berenson at the Four Seasons Residences through Tuesday. In lieu of flowers rememberances in his memory may be made to the Eisenhower Medical Center, 39000 Bob Hope Drive, Rancho Mirage, Ca 92270. Brezniak-Rodman Levine - Briss 617 969-0800.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Sued In Harassment Case
description: A lawyer who says she was harassed by Councilman Allan W. Jennings Jr. of Queens filed a lawsuit yesterday against the City Council in Federal District Court. The lawyer, Saphora M. Lifrak, alleges that Council leaders did not take her complaints about Mr. Jennings seriously and that she was paid a lower salary than male lawyers for the Council. David K. Chai, a spokesman for Council Speaker Gifford Miller, said he had not yet seen the lawsuit but was confident that matters had been handled appropriately. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Carl Allen, 74; Raised and Raced Harness Horses
description: Carl Allen, who raised, raced and trained world champions in harness racing and whose horses earned almost $15 million, died Monday after a tractor accident at his Marion County farm. He was 74.

title: Busy Bryant Leads Lakers To a Victory
description: Kobe Bryant drove past Wally Szczerbiak in a blur, leaving the Minnesota Timberwolves forward looking like a statue. Up next was Michael Olowokandi, the 7-foot center who has been heralded lately for playing decent defense against Shaquille O'Neal.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Economic Rebound
description: Brazil's economy grew at a faster-than-expected annual rate of 2.7 percent in the first quarter, fueled by a drop in interest rates and booming exports, the government said. When compared with the previous quarter, gross domestic product expanded 1.6 percent, the third consecutive quarter of growth. Agricultural output led the surge, jumping 6.4 percent from the year-earlier period, while industry grew 2.9 percent and services, 1.2 percent. Household consumption also bounced back after a long slump, rising 1.2 percent. Most economists expect the Brazilian economy to expand about 3.5 percent this year. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Accused Of Raping Teenager
description: A Long Island man was charged on Wednesday with raping a 15-year-old girl whom the police said he had met over the Internet. According to Nassau County police, the man, Joseph Rizzo, 21, of Inwood, met the teenager online in early April and a week later arranged to meet her in front of a restaurant. At that time, the police said, the girl got into his car, and after driving around and parking at a railroad station lot, he asked the girl if she wanted to have sex. When she declined, the police said, he forced himself upon her. Mr. Rizzo's lawyer, Sandra Mattessich of the Legal Aid Society, did not return a call for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fetus Found Behind School
description: A fetus was found abandoned on the walkway behind Public School 140 on the Lower East Side early yesterday, the police said. It was found shortly before 6 a.m. behind the school, at 123 Ridge Street, between Stanton and Rivington Streets. ''It looked like a full-term baby,'' said Enrique Gonzalez, a school safety officer. ''The placenta was intact.'' The police made no arrests yesterday. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: For Capriati, Lackluster Match But a More Promising Outlook
description: Court Philippe Chatrier at the French Open was half-empty early Thursday and ''a little bit dead,'' as Jennifer Capriati put it.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inuit Vote For Autonomy
description: The Inuit of northern Labrador voted to accept a land claim agreement giving them governing rights in a territory that covers 28,000 square miles, almost the size of South Carolina. The new government of the Inuit region, called Nunatsiavut, would have some controls over resources and social services and the power to make its own laws. Three quarters of the 5,000 Inuit, or Eskimos, who live in Nunatsiavut voted in favor of the agreement. It was the last outstanding Inuit land claim in Canada. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Hundreds to Seek Clues in Park Where Body Was Found
description: Frustrated by a crime scene washed clean by rain and a decomposing body that provided few clues, detectives investigating the killing of a Juilliard student will get help today from 250 police recruits who will search the remote section of Inwood Hill Park where the woman's naked body was found.

title: Soup Kitchen Tries Feeding Hungry Minds
description: THE young man, Terry Corbett by name, riffled through a few paperbacks piled on the library table. He wanted something to read, but nothing in this short stack was grabbing him.

title: An Identity Crisis for Norman Rockwell America
description: WHO ARE WE?

title: Should U.S. Take Sides in Mideast?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COFFEE, DONN T.
description: COFFEE -- Donn T. The Trustees of the Columbia University Club Foundation mourn the loss of their friend and fellow Trustee, Donn Coffee. We extend our condolences to his wife, Toni, his family, and his brother Joseph, a longtime, loyal friend and former Trustee as well. Arthur M. Delmhorst, Pres. Bernd Brecher, Vice Pres.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 27 about the Bush administration's offer of emergency help to North Korea for victims of a train explosion misidentified the organization designated to administer it. (The error also occurred in an article on April 24 about North Korea's appeal for aid.) It is the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, which assists victims of natural and manmade disasters, not the International Committee of the Red Cross, which provides aid to victims of military conflicts. The Times was notified of the error on April 28; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: 'Soul Plane'
description: Directed by Jessy Terrero

title: Into the Uncommunicative Abyss
description: BalletMet Columbus from Ohio introduced itself on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater with three New York premieres, including two highly original works, both wacky and deep, by James Kudelka and Stanton Welch.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Army Factions Clash
description: Efforts to reunify the country after nearly five years of war took a blow when gunfights broke out in the eastern lakeside city of Bukavu between former enemy factions that are now officially part of a new national army. A leader of the Rwandan-backed ex-rebel group, Rally for Congolese Democracy, accused soldiers loyal to the Congolese president, Joseph Kabila, of trying to capture him and bring him to the capital, Kinshasa. A spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping mission, whose troops are already deployed in Bukavu, said there were at least three dead. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Never Rowed? Take a Free Ride
description: On the day Ohio State freshmen signed up for extracurricular activities like sororities, paintball and recreational badminton, Amanda Purcell heard a sales pitch. Two women on the university's varsity rowing team begged her to join.

title: Bills Seek to Rein In Con Ed After Woman's Electrocution
description: Four months after a young woman was electrocuted in the East Village when she stepped on a Consolidated Edison service box cover, four bills have been introduced in the State Assembly that aim to limit the way Con Ed operates.

title: After a Period of Brightness, Earth Dims, Researchers Say
description: Tracking the brightness of Earth by looking at its reflection on the Moon, scientists have concluded that sunshine on Earth brightened in the 1990's, then dimmed after 2000.

title: New Suitors Emerge in Gold Deal
description: It looked, back in late March, as if it would be a straightforward deal: Iamgold, a medium-size gold mining company based in Toronto, made a friendly offer to buy Wheaton River Minerals Ltd., a company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, that mines silver and gold, for $2.2 billion in stock. Wheaton shareholders were expected to approve the deal, which has declined in value somewhat, in a vote on June 8.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Suffolk Sues Connecticut
description: The Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, filed a federal lawsuit against the State of Connecticut yesterday, saying its opposition to a power line running under Long Island Sound amounted to a violation of the United States Constitution. Mr. Levy, left, said Connecticut officials had violated the interstate commerce clause and had hurt the region's economy by blocking the operation of the Cross Sound Cable, which runs 24 miles between Shoreham, N.Y., and New Haven. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Las Vegas in the Wee Hours, From 1958
description: The closest you may ever come in a nightclub to reliving the raucous all-nighters of Las Vegas lounges in the late 1950's is by savoring Keely Smith's new show, ''Las Vegas '58,'' which plays at Feinstein's at the Regency through June 5.

title: Carefree Days Interrupted by an Instant Family
description: Smiles that sell movie tickets can run in the family. Take the sweetly complicitous grin of Kate Hudson, which spreads across her face like a blush of sunrise. A softer variation of her mother Goldie Hawn's ferociously perky baring of choppers, it lends her character in ''Raising Helen'' a likability belied by her profession. Effusing manic efficiency every waking moment, Helen Harris is the scuffling gal Friday and Little Ms. Fixit to Dominique (Helen Mirren), the queenly chief of a New York fashion agency.

title: Newcastle Journal; Does Queen Get Her Mail on Time? You've Got to Wonder
description: Even by the shaky standards of today's British postal service, it seemed a bit excessive to Margaret Clare, not receiving any mail at all for three months.

title: South Africa Says It Deported 5 Terror Suspects Before Vote
description: South Africa arrested and apparently deported five suspected members of Al Qaeda days before national elections last month, a move that led to the arrests of terrorism suspects in Jordan and Syria, the nation's police commissioner said Wednesday.

title: Chilean Court Revokes Pinochet's Immunity From Prosecution
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 28  An appeals court in Chile today revoked the immunity from prosecution granted in 2002 to the country's former military dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The ruling reopened the possibility that General Pinochet may yet be brought to trial for human rights abuses committed during his nearly 17 years in power.

title: The Rights of the Terminally Ill
description: A federal appeals court handed the Justice Department a stinging rebuke this week, ruling that it had exceeded its authority when it tried to block Oregon's assisted-suicide law. The decision is an important victory for the terminally ill, and a blow to the administration's habit of letting an ideological agenda interfere with fair enforcement of the law.

title: Pakistani Links Military To Failed Plot To Kill Him
description: President Pervez Musharraf said Thursday that members of Pakistan's army and air force were among ''dozens'' of people who had been arrested in connection with two assassination attempts against him in December. He also said the man who planned the attacks was a Pakistani who remained at large.

title: Fighting Over Veterans on Memorial Day
description: The confluence of a war-time Memorial Day and the dedication of the new World War II memorial on the National Mall this weekend is raising the fight for the political allegiance of veterans to another level.

title: Company Discontinues Trial Of Hemophilia Gene Therapy
description: In what might be another blow to the field of gene therapy, a small biotechnology company is discontinuing its closely watched attempt to treat hemophilia, apparently because its trial ran into technical and safety problems.

title: Kerry Outlines Foreign Policy, Attacking Bush
description: Senator John Kerry mounted a broad new attack on the Bush administration's handling of national security on Thursday by accusing the president of undermining ''the legacy of generations of American leadership'' with a foreign policy that has abandoned the alliance-building of the post-World War II era.

title: Excerpts From Kerry Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on foreign policy that Senator John Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, gave on Thursday, as transcribed by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript and video are at nytimes.com/politics.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba And Mexico Agree To Return Ambassadors
description: Mexico and Cuba have smoothed over a diplomatic dispute, agreeing to return their ambassadors. Mexico withdrew its ambassador to Havana and expelled the Cuban ambassador from Mexico City on May 2, charging that statements by Cuba had constituted interference in Mexico's internal affairs. Mexico has long been an ally of Cuba, although the government of President Vicente Fox has become more critical of it rights record. The Cuban foreign minister, Felipe Prez Roque, announced the restoring of relations at an international meeting in Guadalajara. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Grief as Haitians And Dominicans Tally Flood Toll
description: Aid workers, soldiers and villagers struggled to save the living, find the lost and bury the dead in Haiti and the Dominican Republic on Thursday after floods that took everything in their path.

title: Safin Finishes Off Mantilla in French Open
description: PARIS, May 28  The big green door swung open at 2:43 p.m. today, and Marat Safin swaggered through it and onto Court One like a lumberjack heading back to the forest. His opponent, Felix Mantilla, shuffled discreetly in his wake.

title: A Landmark Bakery Closes in the Village
description: There was a time when its crusty whole wheat bread was fashionable without quite meaning to be, when the Greenwich Village crowds lined up, eager for still-hot loaves that had not been out of the venerable oven downstairs for more than a few minutes. There was a time, too, when it starred in a famous Depression-era photo.

title: White House Directs Agencies To Prepare Big Spending Cuts
description: White House budget planners have told many federal agencies to reduce their spending plans for domestic programs from education to veterans benefits.

title: Former Rite Aid Chief Gets 8 Years in Prison
description: The former chief executive of the Rite Aid Corporation, Martin Grass, was sentenced yesterday to eight years in prison for directing an accounting fraud that prompted the company to erase $1.6 billion in reported profit.

title: Kamala Markandaya, 79, Novelist Evoking Rural India
description: Kamala Markandaya, the novelist who helped forge the image of India for American readers in schools and book clubs from the 1950's through the 1970's, died on May 16 at her home in London. She was 79.

title: Yellow Brick Road Leads Show Tunes Down a New Path
description: THIS is the year when the popular art form most likely to leave you light-headed and foolishly happy -- the Broadway musical -- flew over the rainbow to visit the Land of Oz. But that enchanted haven dreamt of once in a lullaby isn't what it used to be. Nor do the clever but overblown songs in ''Wicked,'' the hit show bearing that message, stack up as classic show tunes.

title: Anton van Dalen -- 'The Living Room'
description: Adam Baumgold

title: Defense Chief Says Britain Will Expand Its Iraq Force
description: Britain will send 370 troops and extra firepower to Iraq while it continues to weigh whether to deploy thousands more soldiers to the area, Defense Minister Geoff Hoon announced Thursday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Move Against Mayor's Immunity
description: A panel in the lower house of Congress took the first step in a process toward stripping Mexico City's mayor, Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, of immunity from prosecution. Mr. Lpez Obrador, the overwhelming front-runner in the 2006 presidential race, has been charged with disobeying a judge's order to suspend building an access road on the city's outskirts. The immunity measure will now go to the full house. If convicted of the charges, Mr. Lpez Obrador would be barred from serving in public office. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: 'Wake'
description: Directed by Henry LeRoy Finch

title: Williamses Avoid Joining Upset Parade
description: So how does an underdog celebrate? This French Open is only four days old, but it has provided a surplus of research material: from Jrme Haehnel's understated pump of the fist after shocking Andre Agassi on Monday; to Tathiana Garbin dropping to her knees after beating the defending women's champion, Justine Henin-Hardenne, on Wednesday; to Igor Andreev thrusting both arms into the air after his crisply struck ace finished off the defending men's champion, Juan Carlos Ferrero, in just three sets on Thursday.

title: Iraqi With Close U.S. Ties Chosen to Be Prime Minister
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 28  Dr. Iyad Allawi, a secular Shiite member of the American-appointed Iraqi Governing Council with close ties to the C.I.A., has been chosen to be prime minister of Iraq's interim government, Iraqi and American officials said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Displaytech Files For Stock Offering
description: Displaytech, which makes display screens that are used in digital cameras and camcorders, registered yesterday for an initial public offering of up to $57.5 million of common stock, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The number of shares and the estimated price range for the offering were not disclosed in the filing. Displaytech, based in Longmont, Colo., said proceeds from the offering would be used to pay off debt; to finance research and development; and for general corporate purposes. The major shareholders before the offering include Fleming US Discovery Partners, with a 44.8 percent stake, and DTech Investments, with a 45.2 percent stake. Displaytech plans to list the shares on Nasdaq under the symbol LCOS. The $57.5 million valuation for the offering was estimated solely for calculating the registration fee, the filing said. Often, the eventual price terms of an initial offering differ substantially from the valuation in the first registration.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Flight Diverted
description: An American Airlines flight from Dallas/Fort Worth to Boston was diverted to Nashville when a flight attendant found a note warning of a bomb in the cargo hold. The plane landed at Nashville International Airport, where Air Force One awaited President Bush as he toured a local children's hospital and attended a fund-raiser. Agents with the F.B.I., the Department of Homeland Security and the Nashville police searched the plane while passengers were questioned. An airport police spokeswoman said ''a suspicious package'' was found. But investigators found that it contained nothing harmful or hazardous, Kelly Watson, a spokeswoman for Nashville International Airport, told The Associated Press. Amy Green (NYT)

title: My Life, My Mercedes CL500
description: WHO -- Dawn Staley, 34, professional basketball player, college coach and Olympian, Philadelphia

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nintendo Expects Sales Gain
description: The Nintendo Company forecast yesterday that its net income for this fiscal year would more than double from a year earlier because of demand for its new portable game machine and because of a weaker yen against the dollar. Profit will rise to 70 billion yen ($628 million) in the year ending March 31, 2005, from 33.2 billion yen a year earlier, the company said. Nintendo, which is based in Kyoto, Japan, will start selling the machine, the Nintendo DS portable console, this year. For the year that ended March 31, Nintendo said, sales rose 2.1 percent, to 514 billion yen, in line with its preliminary earnings statement last month.

title: Summer Travel: The Waiting Game
description: SUMMER hasn't officially kicked off, but you would hardly know it by looking at the crowds. A warm California spring sent visitors flocking to Yosemite National Park. In Washington, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial has already clocked one million more visitors than at this time last year. Freedom Trail tours in Boston are up by 30 percent. And Las Vegas was bursting with visitors this March, with 98 percent of hotel rooms booked on the weekends.

title: How Much Is Too Much?
description: Eliot Spitzer's lawsuit against Dick Grasso promises to be a jolly good fight. Mr. Grasso is the former head of the New York Stock Exchange whose compensation package of $139.5 million, $187.5 million or $209.2 million, depending on how you do the math, is at the center of the storm.

title: Trump Hotels Makes Payment On Its Debt
description: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. said yesterday that it made a crucial $73.1 million debt payment that was coming due this weekend, giving the company a temporary respite from financial struggles that still threaten to force it into bankruptcy.

title: A Luxury Liner of a Hotel Readies for Another Voyage
description: SPRING comes late to northern Michigan, where chilly rain and 45-degree afternoons can linger into June. So on the great lawn of the Grand Hotel on Mackinac Island last Friday, past the empty croquet court and the paths lined with still-furled ferns and pursed tulips, the lifeguard at the Esther Williams Swimming Pool, instead of corralling errant swimmers, was taking photos of bundled-up guests posing on lounge chairs in their sweatshirts.

title: Dirk Skreber
description: Friedrich Petzel Gallery

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a proposal to close a psychiatric hospital in New Jersey misspelled the given name of the chairman of the panel overseeing the overhaul of state child welfare services. He is Steven D. Cohen, not Stephen.

title: A Knuckleballer Finds His Pitch
description: In 2002 Charlie Zink threw a pitch that sent the team trainer to the hospital. Oddly enough, it may have changed Zink's career for the better.

title: George's Time With Titans Appears to Be Running Out
description: A few hours before Eddie George was to be a presenter for the Country Music Awards on national television Wednesday night in Las Vegas, he received the news: the Tennessee Titans' owner, Bud Adams, said George would most likely be cut on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRICE, GERTRUDE (TRUDY)
description: PRICE -- Gertrude (Trudy). Mother of Barbara, Peter, sister to Harry, grandmother of Suzanne, Steven, great grandmother of Benjamin. Services will be Friday, May 28, 2004, 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Last Out, Please Turn Off the Lights
description: In 1968, Gisela and Dieter Mller were among the first East Germans to move into Neustadt, a bustling neighborhood of five-story concrete apartment buildings built here for workers at the Schwarze Pumpe coal mine northeast of Dresden.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Brainy Boss's Proper Farewell
description: Like politicians who used to obsess over ''Who lost China?,'' television executives torture each other with the question ''Who passed on 'The Sopranos'?''

title: U.S. Embassy on a 'Sacrosanct' Hill? It's a Balkan Battle
description: At first glance, the northern tip of Gradiste hill here appears less than impressive. Old plastic bags pepper its grassy slopes. Dogs sniff for traces of food among discarded litter. Its only apparent saving grace is a view of this capital and the surrounding mountains.

title: Honoring Balanchine, a Russian Energized by America
description: The New York City Ballet's Balanchine Centennial Celebration continued Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with the opening of what the company calls its American Festival, a series of programs through June 6 featuring American music.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 27 about the Bush administration's offer of emergency help to North Korea for victims of a train explosion misidentified the organization designated to administer it. (The error also occurred in an article on April 24 about North Korea's appeal for aid.) It is the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, which assists victims of natural and manmade disasters, not the International Committee of the Red Cross, which provides aid to victims of military conflicts. The Times was notified of the error on April 28; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: The Other Sides Of Seuss

title: From Dudes to Detox in the Arizona Desert
description: WICKENBURG, Ariz., has a tradition of hospitality. For most of the 20th century it drew vacationing Easterners eager to taste the romance of the West. They rode horses into the desert, where they cooked and sang and camped beneath star-pierced skies. Wickenburg, about 60 miles northwest of Phoenix and hugging low hills near the Hassayampa River, proudly advertised itself as the dude ranch capital of the world.

title: Editorial Observer; One State or Two, Israelis and Palestinians Share the Same Economy
description: Mislam Alshwa, a butcher in Gaza City's central market, has seen his sales plunge by 90 percent since the intifada began in the fall of 2000. That's because, at a time of heightened tension, hardly anyone is being allowed to cross over into Israel to work. Israel has taken to importing Thai and Filipino laborers to replace the Palestinians it once hired.

title: In a Teenage Movie, a Religious High School Is High School Just the Same
description: ''Saved!,'' a teen comedy set in a Christian high school, is an admirable attempt to acknowledge some aspects of contemporary American social reality that many movies shy away from. It pokes satirical fun at the religious sentiment currently sweeping though the popular culture while at the same time partaking of some of the energy and idealism that the Christian youth movement has brought to the entertainment industry, especially pop music.

title: Fed Says City Leans Heavily On Income Tax
description: New York City's tax base has shifted over the last 30 years, leaving it increasingly dependent -- some say alarmingly so -- on income and corporate taxes, as well as vulnerable to the boom and bust fortunes of Wall Street, according to a study by the Federal Reserve.

title: Jim Richard -- 'Dcor'
description: Oliver Kamm/5BE Gallery

title: It Is 2030 And Oedipal Tensions Still Rage
description: Arrogant, idealistic and monstrously flawed, fathers are always finding themselves on trial in the plays of Jon Robin Baitz. From the time this morally fierce dramatist made his name in 1991 with ''The Substance of Fire,'' about a progeny-devouring publisher of uncompromising standards, it's been clear that the odds of Dad ever getting off easy are pretty close to nil.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 800 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 19 about a plaque in the new PATH station marking the surviving structure of the World Trade Center concourse misstated the timing of its installation. The Port Authority said it was installed some time last November, not recently.

title: A Political Sacrament
description: Abortion was not expected to be a major issue in this election year beyond its usual function as a rallying point for each party's core constituencies. But now the nation's Roman Catholic bishops and the Democratic Party appear to be headed for a politically charged collision over abortion.

title: U.S. and Bahrain Reach A Free Trade Agreement
description: The United States reached a free trade agreement with the tiny gulf kingdom of Bahrain Thursday, the first with a Middle East nation since President Bush announced his goal of creating a free trade area for the region.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Warning From Oil Company
description: The oil producer Yukos warned that it might go bankrupt by the end of 2004 if forced to pay billions of dollars in back taxes. ''If the tax ministry actions continue, we can talk of the high likelihood of bankruptcy by the end of this year,'' Yukos said a day after a Moscow court upheld a lower court decision ordering it to pay 99 billion rubles ($3.4 billion) in tax arrears and penalties. Yukos estimated that it should have $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion in cash and equivalents as of June 30, up from $800 million. Yukos has appealed the tax claim, and the court has said any attempt to collect the back taxes or fines must wait until Yukos has its hearing. That case is scheduled to begin today. Yukos also has 30 days to appeal the decision upholding the tax claim, which was returned Wednesday by the Moscow Arbitration Court. The chief lawyer for Yukos, Dmitri Gololov, said the company would fight the arbitration ruling.

title: Should U.S. Take Sides in Mideast?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rrrrrrrippp! Another Victim Of Armrests On the L.I.R.R.
description: Experts on two continents haggled in three languages over details of the design for the Long Island Rail Road's M7 cars. A group of Dutch ergonomics experts was paid to watch how Long Islanders sit on trains. There were rounds of meetings with the French Canadian company Bombardier, which built the cars. And riders were studied, questioned and prodded for ideas before the first cars were rolled out in September 2002.

title: TYCO PLANS $500 MILLION PENSION CONTRIBUTION
description: Tyco International Ltd., which has paid off more than $8 billion in debt since 2002, said yesterday that it would make contributions to its pension plan of at least $500 million and might have costs to repurchase convertible debt. The pension contributions will be made over the next six months, Tyco said. It might also incur charges if it buys back some of the $4.5 billion in convertible debt sold last year because Tyco stock is trading above the price at which the bonds can be converted. The company said it would keep a cash balance of at least $2 billion after the outlays. The repurchases might also include $738 million in accounts-receivable securitization programs, Tyco said.

title: 36 Hours | Walt Disney World
description: FOR parents whose taste runs more to South Beach than Blizzard Beach, there's probably no more frightening prospect than the seemingly obligatory ''but everyone else has been'' visit to Walt Disney World. But take heart. Though most of the 14 million people who come through Disney's Orlando, Fla., megaresort each year spend at least three days, you can cram a visit into a (relatively) painless long weekend. Not cheaply, however; Disney World is a place where time really is money, and doing speed Disney requires staying at one of the ''on-campus'' resorts, buying length-of-stay passes and renting a car. Expect to make liberal use of the Fastpass kiosks (the system, which is available on many of the most-popular rides and shows, gives you an assigned window of time in which to ride without waiting in line). And forget seeing it all. This itinerary, tailored to the tastes of a 5-year-old boy, takes in just three of the parks -- the Magic Kingdom, Epcot and the Animal Kingdom -- and skips many minor attractions. But, do you really want to see the Country Bear Jamboree? AMY VIRSHUP

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Offers Software To Counter Spyware
description: Yahoo, the owner of the second-most-used Internet search engine, is offering software to help customers keep their Web surfing private in an attempt to lure users from Google and from the MSN Internet unit of Microsoft. The Yahoo software will help consumers search for and purge their computers of so-called spyware. Spyware programs are downloaded to personal computers without their owners' knowledge. Companies use spyware to monitor Web sites visited, to display advertising and to redirect Web browsers to sites their users did not intend to visit. Yahoo, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is adding the feature to its toolbar, a row of boxes on users' screens that link to the search engine and other functions and also carry the company's logo. Yahoo is trying to persuade more people to install and use its toolbar. Google, the No.1 search engine, based in Mountain View, Calif., and Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., offer toolbars without spyware destroyers. Yahoo shares rose 45 cents to $30.56.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have nothing left. The river took everything, even the dead in the cemetery.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Seeking DNA Tests
description: Lawyers for Kobe Bryant, the Los Angeles Lakers star accused of rape, argued for DNA tests from a former boyfriend of Mr. Bryant's accuser to determine if she had sex shortly after her encounter with Mr. Bryant. The defense contends that the 19-year-old woman may have lied to investigators by not telling them she had sex with someone other than Mr. Bryant before she had a rape examination. The woman has denied this claim. Mr. Bryant, 25, says the sex was consensual and has pleaded not guilty. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Tobacco Payments
description: The state attorney general, Greg Abbott, filed a federal lawsuit against the Brown & Williamson unit of British American Tobacco, saying it had defrauded the state of $16 million in payments from the settlement of tobacco lawsuits by assigning sales of one of its products to another company. Mr. Abbott said that the company had masked the marketing in Texas of 7.5 billion cigarettes it produced for Star Tobacco and Pharmaceuticals of Richmond, Va. Brown & Williamson denied any wrongdoing. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Finale of 'Idol' Is Still a Hit, But Less So
description: ''American Idol,'' Fox's hit talent contest, finished its season Wednesday night with another impressive ratings performance, but the show's viewership significantly trailed that of last year's finale.

title: Rowland Sues to Avert Appearance at Hearing
description: Gov. John G. Rowland asked a state judge on Thursday to throw out a subpoena demanding that he appear in public impeachment hearings next month, a move that answered days of questions over how he would respond to the House committee considering whether he should be impeached.

title: UAL Posts a Loss in April
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, reported a loss of $137.3 million for April, including $28 million in reorganization expenses, according to a report filed Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: British Seize Radical Cleric Sought by U.S.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENT
description: Southwest Airlines, a low-fare carrier, said it is offering voluntary early retirement to most of its 31,522 employees to help reduce costs. The program provides three benefit packages based on years of work and is available through June 25, a spokeswoman, Linda Rutherford, said. The offers, to employees who have been with the company at least a year, include mixes of cash, health care benefits and travel privileges. Southwest has never laid off workers in its 33 years. The early-retirement offer was requested by workers, the chief executive, Jim Parker, said in a memorandum to employees.

title: Say 'Aaaah,' New Yorkers, It's a Citywide Health Checkup
description: New York City health workers will be knocking on doors across the five boroughs this summer to identify residents with diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol as part of what officials are calling the most comprehensive health survey in the city's history.

title: Another Consolidation, This One by Zurich Financial
description: In another consolidation of a large account with an agency company rather than a single agency, Zurich Financial Services has named the Publicis Groupe in Paris to handle worldwide marketing and communications on its accounts, which had been handled by various agencies country by country. Billings were estimated at $150 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Loss At Bombardier
description: The transportation equipment maker Bombardier reported a net loss of $174 million in the quarter that ended April 30, citing technical problems, cost overruns and restructuring charges in its rail car division. The company posted a $54 million profit in the same quarter last year. Revenue in the period, the first quarter of Bombardier's fiscal year, climbed 6 percent. Bombardier, based in Montreal, said that while deliveries of its Challenger and Learjet business aircraft had picked up, it planned to trim production of the 50-seat CRJ200, the smallest of its commuter jets. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend last Friday about musicians' reactions to renovation plans for Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center referred incorrectly to a concert hall whose acoustics were cited favorably. It is the Musikverein, in Vienna; there is no Konzertverein hall there.

description: Canada

title: Seeking a Familiar Face, Veterans Settle for an Ear
description: As Howard Cooper of Staten Island was telling his war stories on Thursday, Edward Foley of Berwick, Pa., was just a few feet away telling his. The men were not immediately aware of each other and certainly had no idea that their paths had crossed nearly 60 years ago in a small Italian town.

title: Adventurer | Outrigger Canoeing
description: ON a balmy Saturday morning, it's practice as usual for the New York Outrigger Club. What this group of outrigger canoe enthusiasts hears is not the crashing waves of the Pacific or the whistle of cool Hawaiian trade winds, but the shouts and calls of tourists who wave frenetically from the deck of the Intrepid at Pier 86 on the Hudson River in Manhattan. As the paddlers battle uptown against the current and pull up alongside the Intrepid for a midmorning stretch session, curious onlookers on the hulking aircraft carrier show increasingly noisy interest.
