description: Cardinal Bernard F. Law, who was forced to resign as leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston after a long and painful sexual abuse scandal involving clergy members, was chosen by Pope John Paul II on Thursday to head a basilica in Rome.

title: Seeing Through Blindfolds? Reading Minds? Why, It's Magic
description: Marc Salem is up to his old tricks.

title: Adelphia Kept Records of Deals With Rigases, Witness Says
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation kept records of all transactions it conducted with business entities operated by its founder, John Rigas, and two of his sons, a consultant to the company testified yesterday in the trial of the three men.

title: Mastering Disney World
description: TAKE Walt Disney World, add one small child (yours), stir in crowds and long lines and place under a hot sun. A recipe for disaster? Not if you strategize properly, learn the short cuts and make liberal use of the Fastpass kiosks. Page 3.

title: AEROLINEAS ARGENTINAS TO BUY 49 BOEING PLANES
description: Aerolineas Argentinas, the largest airline in Argentina, will invest $558 million in the next five years to buy 49 Boeing Company airplanes. The additional aircraft will allow a 50 percent increase in flight frequency, the company said. ''The acquisitions will be made with our own resources,'' said Jose Maria Llodra, a company director, at a news conference in Buenos Aires. Spain's Viajes Marsans bought Aerolineas from the Spanish government in 2001. Aerolineas expects to sell shares on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Former Juror Accused Of Lying
description: A man who was a juror in a drug case three months ago was arrested yesterday and accused of lying about having had a conversation with the defendant while the trial was under way. The juror, Jose Jimenez, was charged with perjury, criminal contempt and obstructing governmental administration. According to prosecutors, a security camera at a deli opposite the Centre Street courthouse recorded Mr. Jimenez approaching the defendant, Jorge Cruz, and having an extended conversation. Justice Edwin Torres of State Supreme Court declared a mistrial while the jury was deliberating. Prosecutors did not disclose what the conversation was about. Mr. Cruz was being tried on a drug sale charge. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Battles Flare, but U.S. Still Hopeful on Truce With Cleric
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 28  Battles broke out between American soldiers and insurgents loyal to a rebel Shiite cleric today in the holy city of Kufa, one day after the two sides said they had reached a ceasefire agreement.

description: As the United States spends billions of dollars to rebuild Iraq's civil and military infrastructure, there is increasing evidence that parts of sensitive military equipment, seemingly brand-new components for oil rigs and water plants and whole complexes of older buildings are leaving the country on the backs of flatbed trucks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPELMAN, JEAN R.
description: KOPELMAN--Jean R. Of New York City, on May 26, 2004. Daughter of Dorothy Ziegler Rapaport and Edmund Rapaport. Prede ceased by her two husbands Alvin L. Hollander, Jr. and Melvin Winn Kopelman. Survived by her sister Grace Butler, of Palo Alto, CA. and her children Alvin L. Hollander, III (Margaret Maynard) of Sag Harbor, N.Y.; Edmund D. Hollander (Wendy Powers) of New York City; and Elizabeth Sarah Kopelman (Oscar D. Kolodzinski) of Cresskill, N.J. Adored by her four grandchildren: Matthew, Renata, Sophia, and Zachary. A woman who lived life on her terms, first as a pioneering producer of television game shows, then exploring the Algarve in Portugal, and finally for the past 13 years as office manager and office mother of Edmund Hollander Landscape Architect Design P.C. A memorial service celebrating her life is planned and will be announced.

title: Valenzuela Is Not Sure If He'll Race at Belmont
description: All Patrick Valenzuela wants is a chance to ride Rock Hard Ten in the Belmont Stakes and deny Smarty Jones a Triple Crown. It seems like a simple request, but with the talented but burdened rider, nothing is ever that neat and easy. Valenzuela's troubles may cost him the mount in the June 5 race. His status will be decided next week.

title: NASA Spots New Youngest Planet, Just a Million Years Old
description: The newest NASA space telescope, with its ability to see past obscuring clouds of cosmic dust, has spotted what astronomers believe is evidence of the youngest planet observed so far, a gaseous body that could be less than a million years old.

title: Witness Says Ex-Tyco Lawyer Cooperated in S.E.C. Inquiry
description: Tyco International's former general counsel, Mark A. Belnick, cooperated with a 2000 Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the company's accounting, a witness told jurors yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Shot To Death
description: Two men were found dead with bullet wounds in their heads in an apartment in Longwood last night, the police said. The men, whose identities were not released, were said to be 19 and 20. They were discovered by a friend of the tenant of the apartment, at 755 Southern Boulevard, who was checking on the apartment while the tenant was in the hospital, the police said. When the friend entered the apartment, about 7 p.m., she found one body and called the police. The police then found another body in a bedroom, said Officer Louis Camacho, a Police Department spokesman. The police found no signs of forced entry, nor any traces of drugs, he said. ''It has everybody baffled because they were good kids,'' said Marcus Delgado, a neighbor. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nortel Names A Director
description: Nortel Networks, the communications equipment supplier being investigated for possible accounting irregularities, named John Manley, left, a former Canadian finance minister and deputy prime minister, to its board. Nortel, which is based in Brampton, Ontario, fired its chief executive and chief financial officer last month and is awaiting the outcome of an independent review of its financial statements. Earlier, the company appointed Manfred Bischoff, a former head of DaimlerChrysler's aerospace and industrial businesses, to its board.

title: U.S. Releases More Prisoners From Abu Ghraib
description: ABU GHRAIB, Iraq, May 28  Raising their voices in slow, melodic chants of "God is Greater," hundreds of Iraqis took over a highway in front of Abu Ghraib prison today to greet busloads of men freed from months of detention.

title: AMERICA WEST ORDERS $1.27 BILLION IN AIRBUS PLANES
description: America West Airlines said it ordered 22 Airbus SAS aircraft valued at $1.27 billion to support planned growth over the next three years. The airline, a unit of the America West Holdings Corporation, will buy 17 Airbus A320's and A319's, and sign leases for the rest, a spokeswoman, Elise Eberwein, said. America West, based in Phoenix, plans to increase flight capacity 10 percent this year and 8 percent to 10 percent in 2005 and 2006. America West joins other low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines and AirTran Airways in adding aircraft as they lure travelers from larger rivals. America West, which operates 139 planes, ordered 14 Airbus A320's, costing $59 million each, and 8 A319's, at $55 million each.

title: 'Strindberg and Helium,' a Sweet Flowering of Youthful Creativity
description: Strindberg looks rather like photos of that morose, visionary late-19th-century Swedish playwright and novelist, as rendered by somebody paying homage to the campily creepy cartoons of Edward Gorey. Helium is a little pink round floating balloon, with eyes and eyebrows and a red mouth with little teeth when she smiles and flipper-like wings and tiny feet tucked away like those of a bird in flight.

Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: LAZERUS -- Gilbert (Gil), passed away on May 24, 2004. Born June 24, 1912, in New York City. Son of Jacob and Bessie Lazerus. Married in 1940 to his late beloved wife, Judith Kaplan. Devoted father of Bruce, June and daughter-in-law Allison. Doting grandfather of Jackie and Amanda. Dear friend since 1981 of the Hon. Shirley Kram. Yale 1931. Columbia Law 1934. Joined Stroock, Stroock & Lavan in 1945; partner beginning 1955; later, of counsel. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

description: Bebe Neuwirth, who became famous as the denizen of a happy little bar called Cheers on television, is now hanging out at a different watering hole. This is no friendly place where everybody knows your name. Identities are blurry, conversation is harsh and memories are bitter. description: After a four-month search for a chief executive, Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing has turned to a relative unknown in the New York publishing world to help right a company reeling from overpriced acquisitions, a tempestuous court battle with a former partner and questions about the integrity of its magazines' circulation.

description: The two sisters had no inkling at first that work by Patrick Heron, their father and one of the most important 20th-century British painters, had been destroyed in a fire that leveled a warehouse full of contemporary art in east London earlier this week.

description: HOLTZMAN -- Lillian (nee Bratter). On May 27, 2004. Age 97, at home peacefully. Beloved wife of the late Louis R., loving mother of Julian and his late wife Joan, David and his wife Francine, adoring grandmother of Robert and his wife Debra, Elena and her husband Bruce, Beth and her husband Paul, Henry and his wife Nancy, David and his wife Barrie, Michael and his wife Sali. title: To Tell The Truth
description: Some news organizations, including The New York Times, are currently engaged in self-criticism over the run-up to the Iraq war. They are asking, as they should, why poorly documented claims of a dire threat received prominent, uncritical coverage, while contrary evidence was either ignored or played down.

title: Accounting for the Cost of War
description: The dominant clich in Congress is that the forthcoming Pentagon budget will not include a ''blank check'' for President Bush in Iraq. Such watchdog keenness, which would have been welcome from the start, must be attributed in large measure to election year polls. But it is still good to see that lawmakers sense the need to tightly vet the president's $422 billion military budget request.

title: Born to Charm: Dumpy, Waxy, Poisonous and, Yes, Jumpy
description: If fairy tales are windows into the secret heart of our culture, the one about the prince and the frog should worry us all. Frogs are one of the world's great treasures, as an exhibition opening tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History makes clear. And princes? Well, one word should answer that question. Charles.

title: MTV's Front Man on the Campaign Trail
description: GIDEON YAGO, the top political correspondent for MTV News, paints a bleak picture of the lonely, pathetic creature he was growing up in Forest Hills, Queens. King of the geeks, it seems. Yet it's hard to reconcile this image with the engaging journalist found in front of his computer in a dimly lit, cramped office in Midtown Manhattan. He stands up abruptly, sheepishly looking around at the messy clutter. ''My mother will kill me.'' Dressed in a seersucker blazer and jeans, he wears nerdy-cool, rectangular glasses and a neatly trimmed beard. He is 26.

title: Washington Talk; For House Democrats, a Whiff of Victory
description: House Democrats do not usually like to talk about 1994, the year of their exile into the minority. It has been a bad memory, best left undisturbed.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: RCN Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: The RCN Corporation, a provider of cable television, telephone and Internet service, filed yesterday for bankruptcy protection after failing to attract enough customers to pay the debts it incurred in expanding its networks. Service will not be interrupted as a result of the bankruptcy, RCN said. The company, its lenders and a group of bondholders agreed before the filing to a plan that would permit the company to cut up to $1.18 billion of debt and leave bankruptcy in several months. The plan would give bondholders and other unsecured creditors as much as a 98 percent stake in the revamped company. RCN's lenders would be paid fully and shareholders would get stock options for up to a 2 percent stake, court papers showed. RCN, based in Princeton, N.J., listed $1.49 billion in assets and $1.82 billion in debts in the filing in Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York. RCN has lost money in every quarter since it became a public company in June 1998.

title: The Ever-Shifting Selves Of Cindy Sherman, Girlish Vamp to Clown
description: For most of her remarkable career, Cindy Sherman has been the face of postmodernism, known for photographs in which she flaunts one assumed identity after another. She is among the most influential and productive members of the photo-appropriation artists who emerged in the early 1980's, and she is certainly the most famous. Since Ms. Sherman started dressing up for her camera in the mid-70's, her lead has been followed ad infinitum.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Chile Blocks Menem Extradition
description: A Chilean judge has rejected the Argentine government's request for the extradition of its former president, Carlos Sal Menem, who recently moved to Chile with his Chilean wife and child, claiming to be the victim of ''political persecution'' in his homeland. Mr. Menem is sought for questioning regarding corruption during the decade ending in 1999 that he was in power, but has ignored subpoenas ordering him to testify about undeclared Swiss bank accounts that he controlled. The Chilean judge ruled that his refusal was not a crime. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Report Links Oil Mergers To Slight Rise in Gas Prices
description: An extensive series of oil company mergers in the 1990's reduced competition in gasoline sales, but the resulting changes in wholesale prices were small, the General Accounting Office said on Thursday.

title: Where did young male viewers go? No one knows, but they're back.
description: THE case of the missing younger male viewers, which has vexed Madison Avenue during the most recent television season, may be nearing resolution, agency and network executives say. But like dogged detectives from ''77 Sunset Strip,'' ''Moonlighting'' or ''Without a Trace,'' they cautioned against declaring the case closed just yet.

title: Colorado Football Coach Reinstated After Scandal
description: The University of Colorado reinstated the football coach Gary Barnett and announced the restructuring of the athletic department on Thursday after an investigation into a recruiting scandal that included allegations of sexual assault by players and recruits.

title: Discovering a New World Of Beauty in Lowly Detail
description: DON'T trouble yourself too much with the minutiae around the premise of ''Painters of Reality'' at the Metropolitan Museum. Elaborating on a now obscure exhibition held 50 years ago in Italy, it stresses the northern Italian region of Lombardy, from the 15th century through the 18th century, as a source and hotbed of naturalism and humble subjects. The supposed contrast is with Venice, which is typically said to have had the franchise on color, and Rome, which looked back toward antiquity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REBENFELD, LUDWIG
description: REBENFELD -- Ludwig of Princeton, died May 26, 2004 at the University Medical Center at Princeton after a brief illness. Born in Prague, the Czech Republic, the son of Carl Rebenfeld and Martha Rebenfeld, he has been a Princeton resident since 1951. He was a graduate of the University of Lowell (Mass) with a B.S. in Chemistry and received his PhD in Chemistry at Princeton University. At the time of his death, Dr. Rebenfeld was the Editor of the Textile Research Journal of TRI/Princeton (formerly Textile Research Institute), having served in many positions over his 50 year career including Director and President. Between 1964 and until his retirement, he was a Visiting Lecturer in the Department of Chemical Engineering at Princeton University. He was a Life Trustee of the Philadelphia College (now University) of Textiles and Science, and was Chairman of the Board between 1974 and 1979. He was the President of the Association of Princeton Graduate Alumni, 1981-1983; received an Honorary Doctorate from Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science; and received the 1990 Distinguished Alumni Award from the University of Lowell. He was a member of various Societies and Institutes in the Chemical and Textile fields. His wife, Ellen Vogel Rebenfeld, died in 2002. There are no immediate survivors. Burial will be private. A Memorial Service is to be held at the Princeton University Chapel on Saturday, June 12, 2004 at 11:30am. For info Kimble Funeral Home, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the charity of the donor's choice or The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, PO Box 5193, General Post Office, NY, NY 10087

title: Criminal Case Opens Against Russian Oil Billionaire
description: MOSCOW, May 28  The politically charged criminal case against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia's wealthiest man, opened today, and, if convicted, he could face a sentence of up to 10 years in jail.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Narrows Its Loss
description: The entertainment and communications group Vivendi Universal said it narrowed its first-quarter loss to 6 million euros ($7.3 million) in the first quarter from 319 million euros a year earlier, helped by gains in all units except its VU Games videogame unit. Operating income at the telecommunications unit rose 19 percent. The company, based in Paris, said it had debt of 11.6 billion euros as of March 31, down from 35 billion euros. Vivendi has reduced debt further, to about 7 billion euros, since the end of the quarter by selling its entertainment operations in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a London fire that destroyed millions of dollars' worth of art misidentified the warehouse owner in some copies. It is Momart, a company that handles, stores and transports art and antiquities -- not Charles Saatchi, the collector, who owned dozens of the lost works.

title: Keeping the Faith as the Meter Runs; Even Muslims on the Move Stop at Prayer Time
description: You drive a cab, wafted across the city on the whims of your fares. But you are Muslim, and must pray five times a day -- which involves ablutions, facing east and a series of prostrations in submission to God.

description: In another consolidation of a large account with an agency company rather than a single agency, Zurich Financial Services has named the Publicis Groupe in Paris to handle worldwide marketing and communications on its accounts, which had been handled by various agencies country by country. Billings were estimated at $150 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARNOWITZ, JANECE
description: ARNOWITZ--Janece of Boca Raton, FLorida died Wednesday at the age of 68, surrounded by her family. Her husband of 40 years, William Arnowitz, predeceased her in 1995. She is survived by her four children, Deborah Ashe, Holly Arnowitz, Sherman Arnowitz (Pam), and Daniel Arnowitz (Susan), and her seven grandchildren Hannah, Nathan, Samantha, Alex, Isabel, Aimee and Jillian. Donations may be made to The Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice and The American Cancer Society.

title: Amtrak's New Station in Doubt Over Rent Issue
description: After years of delays, plans for a grand, new Pennsylvania Station built within the city's main post office building are being muddied by demands from Amtrak, the intended tenant, that it be allowed to use the space without paying any rent.

title: Shopping List | Shutterbugs
description: CAPTURING the all-too-fleeting memories of summer has gotten easier, even for amateur photographers who don't know an F-stop from an optical zoom. Among the newest gadgets are Canon's CP-330 portable photo printer, which weighs only 30.3 ounces and produces water- and fade-resistant prints, and Nikon's versatile D70 digital, which adjusts for speed, night shots and more. Happy shooting. STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM

title: NEC Unit Admits It Defrauded Schools
description: Criminal investigations into corruption and waste in the E-Rate program, a federal plan to bring Internet access to poor schools and libraries, yielded their biggest legal settlement to date on Thursday. NEC Business Network Solutions, a subsidiary of NEC, the computer giant, agreed to plead guilty to two federal felony counts, one for wire fraud and one for antitrust violation, and to pay $20.7 million in fines and restitution.

title: AGREEMENT BY U.S. AND REBELS TO END FIGHTING IN NAJAF
description: American forces and guerrillas loyal to the radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr agreed Thursday to quit fighting in Najaf, in a deal that signaled the possible end of seven weeks of fighting in the city, during which scores of Iraqis have died.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Stepping Back From Privatization
description: The new government announced its economic plan, reaffirming a commitment to spending on education and rural infrastructure and promising to deliver 8 percent growth rates for the next decade. It ruled out selling profit-making state companies, stalling the privatization program pursued by the outgoing government. The new plan even proposed the scrapping of the Privatization Ministry. Addressing the interests of the farmers and the rural poor who voted in the new government, the plan vowed to protect farmers and promised subsidies to the ''poor and truly needy.'' Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the proposed Jets stadium in Manhattan misstated the number of City Hall staff members at a May 16 news conference in support of a West Side location for it. There was just one -- Jennifer Falk, the City Hall spokeswoman on duty that weekend, who also serves as spokeswoman to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff, a supporter of the stadium. It was not several members of his staff.

title: Corrections
description: The Paris Journal article on May 20, about a plan by a town mayor, Nol Mamre, to conduct the country's first gay wedding, misstated the affiliation of the European Court of Human Rights, to which he said he would appeal if his plan was challenged. It is a body of the Council of Europe, not the European Union. The article also mistranslated a headline about the issue in Le Monde's weekly magazine. ''Marions-Nous'' means ''Let's Get Married,'' not ''Marry Us.''

title: Sharon Trims Gaza Pullout Plan to Just 3 Settlements
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon struggled Thursday to advance his plan to evacuate some Israeli settlements without a peace agreement with the Palestinians, proposing that the cabinet vote on emptying just three settlements in the Gaza Strip.

title: Oil Prices Fall on OPEC Hint of More Output
description: Crude oil prices fell to three-week lows yesterday, as the president of OPEC said that the cartel might increase production quotas by a significant amount.

description: CRG Gallery

title: Facing Opposition, Sharon Plans Debate on Full Withdrawal
description: JERUSALEM, May 28  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon plans a Cabinet debate this Sunday, and possibly a vote, on a full Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip. The move comes despite continued opposition from hardline ministers who have resisted even a scaled-down version of the plan so far.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODWIN, HARRY
description: GOODWIN--Harry, 85, of Monroe Township, died Wednesday, May 26, 2004 at Park Place Center, Monmouth Junction. Born and raised in the Bronx, NY, Mr. Goodwin lived in Plainview, NY for 29 years before moving to Cranbury 17 years ago. Mr. Goodwin was an officer in the US Army, took part in the Normandy invasion and was honored by the City of Antwerp after being injured in the Battle of the Bulge. He worked as an international textile broker for many years with Scheuer & Co. Mr. Goodwin is survived by his wife of 55 years, Renee, two daughters and sons-in-law, Laurie and Peter Stern, Woodland Hills, CA, Andrea and Doug Green, Dover, DE; brother and sister-in-law Bernard and Bernice Goodwin; sister-inlaw Ethel Trayne; three grandchildren, Sarah, Jeremiah and Rebecca, and nieces and nephew. Services Sunday, May 30, 11am, at Bloomfield--Cooper Jewish Chapels, Manalapan, with interment to follow at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Arrest In Adelphi Robbery Case
description: A man accused of robbing Adelphi University students in a dormitory was being held on six counts of robbery yesterday after being extradited from Puerto Rico, where he was playing semiprofessional basketball, Nassau County prosecutors said. The man, Sean Ramirez, 22, is accused of committing the crime last year with an unidentified accomplice who wielded a machete. They are accused of binding up the three victims and stealing cash, telephones and electronic games. Mr. Ramirez, a former Adelphi student, was held in lieu of $150,000 bail. His lawyer, Kenneth Ross of the Legal Aid Society, did not return a call seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: PFIZER WINS DIABETES DRUG LIABILITY CASE
description: Pfizer Inc. is not liable for liver illnesses that killed two people and injured a third after they took a now-withdrawn diabetes drug, a Los Angeles jury said yesterday. The plaintiffs claimed that the drug, Rezulin, made by Pfizer's Warner-Lambert unit, caused liver damage. The Los Angeles Superior Court jury delivered its verdict yesterday after about 10 hours of deliberations, a Pfizer spokesman, Bryant Haskins, said. Rezulin, a drug taken by about 1.9 million diabetics to help regulate insulin, was pulled from the market in the United States in 2000 after it was linked to at least 63 deaths from liver failure. In January, Pfizer announced that it had set aside $933 million to pay 35,000 Rezulin personal injury claims and cover cases in litigation. ''We've maintained from the very beginning that Rezulin didn't cause or contribute to'' the injuries suffered by these plaintiffs, Mr. Haskins said. Thomas Girardi, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, did not return a call for comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUS, ROGER W.
description: STRAUS--Roger W. On May 25th, age 87. Husband of Dorothea, father of Roger III, grandfather of Laura, Rachel and Tamara. Brother of Florence and Oscar. Founder, President and publisher of Farrar, Straus and Giroux. Funeral Friday, May 28th, 10:30 AM at Temple EmanuEl, 5th Ave at 65 St. Memorial service at a future date to be announced.

The 200 or so creatures in ''Frogs: A Chorus of Colors,'' including the waxy monkey frog, above, are not only colorful, they're also alive and a delight to hear.

description: A former governor of Alabama whose administration has faced numerous corruption probes has been indicted on bid-rigging charges, federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERTZBERG, LILIAN
description: HERTZBERG -- Lilian. May 26, 2004. Dr. Diane E. Meier, Director of the Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Dr. Albert L. Siu, Ellen and Howard C. Katz Chairman's Chair of Brookdale Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development Mount Sinai School of Medicine, members of the Advisory Board of the Hertzberg Institute, and the entire faculty and staff of the Institute who knew and admired her, mourn the loss of our friend, Lilian Hertzberg. A woman of extraordinary intelligence, culture, wide ranging interests and detemination, Lilian Hertzberg was a visionary benefactor who recognized the need for medical care focused on relief of suffering and support for best quality of life for patients with serious illness and their families by generously naming and endowing, with her late husband, Benjamin Hertzberg, the Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute. We will miss her. Funeral arrangements private. Donations in her memory may be made to Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Mount Sinai Medical Center, Box 1070, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, NY, NY 10029.

Albright, Samuel R. Berger, William J. Perry and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili. Richard C. Holbrooke joined his former colleagues via conference call from Tokyo.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Possible Bid For Retailer

Marks & Spencer said this week that revenue slipped in the fourth quarter, with sales at stores open more than a year falling 3.4 percent. Shares in Marks & Spencer jumped 19 percent.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Accord On Prison
description: The State Department of Corrections and the Southern Center for Human Rights agreed to a settlement in a federal lawsuit regarding the Limestone Correctional Facility, where the state houses its H.I.V.-positive inmates. The prison agreed to monitoring four times annually for two years by a medical consultant, and to other improvements, a lawyer for the center said. Audits found the rate of H.I.V.-related deaths at Limestone was more than double the national prison average. Ariel Hart (NYT)

Now, it has set its sights on New York City itself and is negotiating to transform a Staten Island industrial park into a major speedway on 440 acres of waterfront land near the Goethals Bridge.

Adored grandmother of Keith, Brett, Michele, Jonathan, Benjamin and Nathan Joshua. Services Sunday, May 30th, 1PM at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, N.Y. 11024. Contributions may be made to the Ackerman Memorial Fund at Temple Emanuel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 27 about the Bush administration's offer of emergency help to North Korea for victims of a train explosion misidentified the organization designated to administer it. (The error also occurred in an article on April 24 about North Korea's appeal for aid.) It is the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, which assists victims of natural and manmade disasters, not the International Committee of the Red Cross, which provides aid to victims of military conflicts. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, SALEM SEELEY
description: SHAPIRO -- Salem Seeley. Age 95, died at his home in Redding, CT Thursday night. Born in 1909 in Fort George, or, as he liked to put it, ''in a farmhouse on Manhattan Island,'' he lived to see a world of wonders from radio to the Internet, and reveled in every minute of it. An NYU graduate, a talented city planner and World War II veteran (a corporal), he moved to Connecticut in 1949 where he was Director of City Planning in Norwalk, and Director of Urban Renewal in Stamford. He was a loving husband for 56 years to Edith, who died in 1997. He is mourned by his daughter Amy Shapiro of Weston, CT; his son Walter of New York; his daughter-inlaw Meryl Gordon of New York; and his sister Myrtle Vinson of Albuquerque, NM. The funeral will be held on Sunday at 11:00 AM at Sharon Gardens/Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. The family will be receiving condolences Monday evening 6-9 pm, 8 Bridge Rd. in Weston, CT.

title: 1929:Talleyrand Heir Passes : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: PARIS: Howard de Talleyrand, Prince of Sagan, heir of the Duc de Talleyrand and son of the former Anna Gould, of New York, has succumbed to the consequences of his act of rashness a fortnight ago, having passed away at 3 o'clock yesterday [May 28] morning. Less than two weeks ago, Howard de Talleyrand, in a fit of despondency, pointed a pistol at his heart and fired. He had fallen in love while on the Riviera, but he interpreted his mother's advice that he was far too young to marry as a parental objection to the match.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUSSMAN, LAWRENCE
description: GUSSMAN--Lawrence, 88, of Scarsdale, NY, on May 28, 2004. Devoted husband of the late Catharine. Survived by brother Herbert Gussman of Tulsa, OK. Beloved father of William Gussman of Atlanta, GA, Margaret McCormack of Laurel Hollow, NY, and John Gussman of Hilo, HI. Adoring grandfather of Paul, James, Michael, Catharine, Stuart, Rachel and Catharine. Adoring great-grandfather of Katie, Jonathan, Thomas, Stephanie, Kelly, Scotty and Sara. Graduate of Columbia College Class of 1937, Columbia Engineering School Class of 1939. He was a recipient of the Egleston Medal for Distinguished Achievement from the Columbia Engineering School. Former President, Chairman and CEO of Stein Hall, Inc. from 1953 to 1971. He was Knighted a Knight of Malta in May, 1969 at the United Nations Chapel. Former Chairman of the Albert Schweitzer Fellowship. He was a member of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, authored ''A Personal Journey,'' a description of Central African Art. The Art is at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, NY. He was also a member of the Young Presidents' Organization and subsequently a member of the Chief Executive's Forum. Visitation from 5-7 PM, Saturday at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Services at the same location, 10 AM on Sunday followed by a private interment in Deep River, CT. For directions, call Ballard Durand at 914-949-0566.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Gambling Concern Accepts Bid
description: The gambling company Tab Ltd. accepted a takeover bid yesterday of 2.2 billion Australian dollars in cash and stock from a rival, Tabcorp, after Tabcorp raised its bid by 10 cents a share. Tabcorp, the largest listed gambling operator in Australia, raised its bid to 4.81 Australian dollars a share, 13 percent higher than its original bid, which Tab had rejected in November. The companies are involved in gambling at casinos and hotels and betting on horse and dog racing. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Lecavalier Wears His Number Well
description: The number on Vincent Lecavalier's uniform 4 -- is special in hockey but not often found on a forward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   URBAN, SARAH (SALLY)
description: URBAN--Sarah (Sally) on May 26, 2004. Beloved daughter of the late Ida and Louis Bursky. Cherished wife of Martin Urban, of blessed memory. Loving mother of Goldy and Arthur Fried and Lois and Gerald Kirsh. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and Michael Greenberg, Steven and Robin Fried and Roy Israel Kirsh. Adoring great-grandmother of Martin, Abagail, Gillian, Max and Nicole. Sister of the late Rose Bursky. We will miss her sharp intellect, keen humor and spunk. We celebrate her long life and pray that she rest in peace

title: Worker Electrocuted by Fixture Outside Manhattan Building

title: Garnett Needs Help for Wolves to Survive
description: With 31.5 seconds left in the third quarter of Game 4 Thursday night, Minnesota Coach Flip Saunders tried to do Kevin Garnett a favor. Garnett, the team's star forward, had played every minute of the game, and Saunders thought he would give him a brief rest.

title: Surprising Choice for Premier of Iraq Reflects U.S. Influence
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 28  After turning to the United Nations to shore up its failing effort to fashion a new government in Baghdad, the United States ended up Friday with a choice for prime minister certain to be seen more as an American candidate than one of the United Nations or the Iraqis themselves.

title: Surprising Choice Reflects U.S. Influence
description: After turning to the United Nations to shore up its failing effort to fashion a new government in Baghdad, the United States ended up Friday with a choice for prime minister certain to be seen more as an American candidate than one of the United Nations or the Iraqis themselves.

title: A Bummer, Man, for Sarcasm: High Times Rolls On
description: On Thursday evening the Great Lawn in Central Park was the site of a showdown that had been anticipated for months: High Times vs. The Onion. No, it wasn't to debate whether readers are more interested in irony or intoxication. Instead, a different sort of bragging right was at stake, one that was to be decided on the softball diamond. And for those who pay close attention to the softball standings of local magazines and newspapers, the opening pitch of Thursday's game on Field 6 had the drama of an October night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Calling All Ids: Freudians at War
description: Who owns psychoanalysis? That question is at the center of the most recent battle here in the Freud Wars, the epic (or as the man himself might say, interminable) struggle over the legacy of Sigmund Freud, pioneer psychotherapist, cartographer of the unconscious and former resident of Hampstead, the leafy corner of Northwest London where the concentration of therapeutic couches per square mile may be even higher than on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Good Yarboroughs and Bad: This One Took Three Tricks
description: In the days of whist in England, Charles Anderson Worsley Anderson-Pelham, the second Earl of Yarborough, used to offer 1000 to 1 against a player's picking up a hand with no card higher than a nine. There were few takers, perhaps because the true odds are 1827 to 1. But such a hand is still called a yarborough.

title: Brazil Resolves Complaint On Florida Juice-Import Tax
description: Brazil agreed on Friday to withdraw a two-year-old complaint at the World Trade Organization against a Florida state tax on Brazilian orange juice imports.

title: Kerry Redoubles His Attack Over the War
description: Senator John Kerry promised an occasionally tearful gathering of soldiers, veterans and their families here on Friday that as president he would bring the troops home from Iraq ''as fast as possible.'' He also attacked the Bush administration as insensitive to the human toll of the war.

title: A Search for Clues to a Student's Killing
description: Police recruits searched yesterday near an underpass in Inwood Hill Park for clues to the killing of Sarah Fox, a 21-year-old drama student. Her pink CD player, perhaps the most important clue yet, was found by a detective on Thursday night. Page B3.

title: Can Movies Teach Moral Philosophy?
description: Katharine Hepburn breaking Cary Grant's putter in two, Bette Davis describing herself as ''the fat lady with the heavy eyebrows,'' Ingrid Bergman puzzling over dimming gaslight, Clark Gable watching Claudette Colbert's underwear being tossed over a curtain. Philosophers begin their journeys from many unusual places, but have there ever been more eccentric choices than those made by Stanley Cavell, the distinguished emeritus professor at Harvard?

title: 3 Are Sentenced for Smuggling Chilean Sea Bass and Rock Lobster
description: A federal judge sentenced a father and son to prison yesterday for smuggling large quantities of Chilean sea bass and rock lobster from South Africa to the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about devastating floods in Haiti and the Dominican Republic misspelled the name of a Haitian district where as many as 1,000 people reportedly drowned. (An article and a picture caption repeated the error in some copies yesterday.) The district is Mapou, not Mopou.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reichmann Leaves Canary Wharf
description: The founder of the Canary Wharf Group, Paul Reichmann, stepped down yesterday as a director, a week after a group led by Morgan Stanley won control of the company, the London office developer, with a 1.7 billion ($3 billion) takeover offer. Mr. Reichmann, 73, sided with the losing bidder, the Brascan Corporation of Canada. Mr. Reichmann, whose resignation was effective immediately, still owns 9 percent of Canary Wharf.

title: Proposal to Adopt a Palestinian City as a 'Sister' Creates a Family Feud for Madison
description: Mayor Dave Cieslewicz said he thought his job would be limited to deciding issues like whether to build a municipal pool in this city of 215,000 residents or add a light-rail system. Instead he finds himself in the middle of a debate over Middle East peace.

title: After Ending Arms Program, Libya Receives a Surprise
description: In March, just as the Bush administration was showing reporters some of the secret nuclear equipment that Libya gave up after renouncing its arms program, the Libyans received a fresh shipment of illegal parts from the nuclear black market, according to a new report by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: South of Baghdad, a Road of Recurring Death Claims Two More Victims
description: It is considered by many to be the most dangerous stretch of road in Iraq, a place where numerous journalists, soldiers and contractors have been ambushed, robbed and, often, killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOPELMAN, JEAN R.
description: KOPELMAN--Jean R. Of New York City, on May 26, 2004. Daughter of Dorothy Ziegler Rapaport and Edmund Rapaport. Prede ceased by her two husbands Alvin L. Hollander, Jr. and Melvin Winn Kopelman. Survived by her sister Grace Butler, of Palo Alto, CA. and her children Alvin L. Hollander, III (Margaret Maynard) of Sag Harbor, N.Y.; Edmund D. Hollander (Wendy Powers) of New York City; and Elizabeth Sarah Kopelman (Oscar D. Kolodzinski) of Cresskill, N.J. Adored by her four grandchildren: Matthew, Renata, Sophia, and Zachary. A woman who lived life on her terms, first as a pioneering producer of television game shows, then exploring the Algarve in Portugal, and finally for the past 13 years as office manager and office mother of Edmund Hollander Landscape Architect Design P.C. A memorial service celebrating her life is planned and will be announced.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a smear campaign under way, and it is being perpetrated by the C.I.A. and the D.I.A. and a gaggle of former intelligence officers who have succeeded in planting these stories, which are accepted with hardly any scrutiny.''

description: Memorial Day

(An article and a picture caption repeated the error in some copies yesterday.) The district is Mapou, not Mopou.

title: Sharon to Face Cabinet Hard-Liners on Gaza Pullout Plan
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon plans a cabinet debate this Sunday on a full Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip, although it seems unlikely that the measure will come up for a vote, Israeli officials said Friday.

title: Record Company Can Sue Over Popular Singer's Death
description: Nearly three years after the popular singer and actress Aaliyah died in a plane crash in the Bahamas after shooting a video, a Manhattan judge has decided that her record company can sue the video production company to settle questions of negligence and damages.

title: Ground Zero Pay Dispute Is Simmering
description: Daniel Libeskind, the master planner for the World Trade Center site, and Larry A. Silverstein, the commercial leaseholder, are fighting over how much Mr. Libeskind should be paid for his work on the 1,776-foot Freedom Tower.

title: Kerry, in Show of Confidence, Plans $18 Million Ad Push
description: Senator John Kerry is starting an aggressive new round of advertising that will court traditionally Republican Virginia as well as African-Americans and Hispanics, his aides said Friday.

title: A Hollow Sovereignty for Iraq
description: President Bush said yesterday that he would transfer ''complete and full sovereignty'' to an interim Iraqi government in barely a month. But nothing even close to that is likely to happen. Recent developments suggest that this ''sovereignty'' will have little substance and that the president still has no coherent plan to create the security and political trust required to negotiate a constitution and hold fair elections. The sovereignty timetable remains driven by the American electoral calendar and growing Iraqi impatience with an incompetent and deeply unpopular occupation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Spending Rises As Economy Gains Strength

title: Colombians Urged to Drink More and Better Coffee (Their Own)
description: Colombia may assert proudly that it grows the world's best coffee, but Eva Celeita knows that most of her fellow Colombians do not know how to brew a decent cup.

title: Evidence From Balco May Implicate Indoor Champ
description: As the United States Anti-Doping Agency continues its attempts to bar track and field athletes who have not failed a conventional drug test, one target is Michelle Collins, the 2003 indoor world champion at 200 meters and a top 400-meter runner, according to several people with knowledge of the investigation.

title: On Mets' First Visit, Benitez Slams the Door
description: Armando Benitez lounged across two sofas Friday afternoon, a bandanna covering his head, long earrings dangling from each lobe.

title: Republicans Rush to Form New Finance Groups
description: After months spent trying to shut down Democratic advocacy groups that have raised tens of millions of dollars in unlimited contributions to support Senator John Kerry, Republicans are scrambling to set up similar organizations to collect donations to help President Bush.

title: EXILE WITH TIES TO C.I.A. IS NAMED PREMIER OF IRAQ
description: Iyad Alawi, an Iraqi neurologist known for his close ties to the Central Intelligence Agency, was chosen Friday to be the country's interim prime minister when the Americans transfer sovereignty here on June 30.

title: Silver Blamed for Albany Mess, but Job Seems Safe for Now
description: One member of the State Assembly is being investigated for taking an intern to his motel room. Two lawmakers have pleaded guilty to crimes. Few laws are being passed, the budget is late for the 20th straight year and legislators are being accused of taking favors from big business. As if that were not enough, state lawmakers have not been paid since they missed the April 1 budget deadline.

title: Object of Rowland Inquiry Could Fetch $25,000 in Rent
description: Gov. John G. Rowland can expect to receive $15,000 to $25,000 in rental income for his 1,200-square-foot Litchfield cottage this summer, local real estate agents said on Friday. That is, if he has not already waited too long to list it.

title: Consumer Spending and a Factory Index Rise
description: Consumer spending rose in April and a measure of manufacturing business in the Chicago area increased to the highest level in almost 16 years, adding to evidence that economic growth is strengthening.

title: Expat adviser : Foreign ownership of U.S. property
description: [Q.]My wife and I are British citizens. We looked at acquiring property near Tulsa, Oklahoma, only to find out well into the process that the Oklahoma Constitution does not allow aliens to own property for a period greater than five years. Can you help us find information on which U.S. states allow aliens to own property in perpetuity?

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on May 11 about Ethiopia's rise to power in distance-running events referred incorrectly to the record set by Abebe Bikila's victory in the 1960 Olympic marathon. Bikila became the first black African to win an Olympic championship, not the first African. (The first was a South African, Reginald Walker.)

description: AMERICAS

title: Den Of Dreams
description: Older readers will remember the golden era, long before every show on television was a makeover show. But that was before ''This Old House'' begat ''Trading Spaces,'' which begat ''While You Were Out,'' which begat ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,'' which begat ''Pimp My Ride'' (fixing up cars and bikes).

title: Chilean Court Revokes Pinochet's Immunity From Prosecution
description: An appeals court in Chile on Friday revoked the immunity from prosecution granted in 2002 to the country's former military dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, reopening the possibility that he may yet be brought to trial for human rights abuses committed during the nearly 17 years he was in power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAZERUS, GILBERT
description: LAZERUS--Gilbert. The partners of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan record with deep sorrow the passing of our retired partner and colleague, Gilbert Lazerus, an exceptional attorney and our friend of many years. We wish to extend our deepest sympathies to Gil's friends and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRLICH, IRVING
description: EHRLICH--Irving. On May 27, 2004, of Forest Hills and New City, NY. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Barbara, Karen and Scott. Cherished father-in-law of Dan. Loving grandfather of Julie, Larry, Gregg, Jessica and Jarret. Caring great grandfather of Jeremy and Justin. Owner and founder of Ehrlich Food Co., president of the Greater New York Wholesale Grocers Association for more than 45 years. Visiting Saturday, 7-10 PM at Schwartz Bros. Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Funeral Sunday 11:15 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERTIG, FLORENCE R. NEE REIFF
description: FERTIG--Florence R. nee Reiff, 68, of East Hampton and NYC, on May 27, 2004. She won the admiration and respect of all her colleagues in the advertising world. Beloved wife of Samuel. Loving mother of Beth Fertig of NYC. Dear sister of Eleanor Chandler of Great Barrington, MA. Also survived by nephews and nieces, Douglas, Larry, Barbara and Leigh Chandler. Memorial service Sunday, May 30, 12 noon, at the East Hampton Jewish Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about new details in the death of Sarah Fox, a 21-year-old Juilliard student whose body was found in Inwood Hill Park in Manhattan, misspelled the surname of the deputy police commissioner for public information. He is Paul J. Browne, not Brown. A map on Wednesday with an article about the discovery of Ms. Fox's body misspelled the name of a strait just north of the park. It is Spuyten Duyvil, not Duvil.

title: Syracuse Standout Aims To Be a Moving Target
description: Mike Powell knows that the bumps and bruises and stick pokes he receives every game are the price he pays for being perhaps the best lacrosse player of his day. He says he does not mind.

description: Belatedly, Nuclear Gear Comes to Light in Libya

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD BOARD BACKS BUYING BACK MORE SHARES
description: Hewlett-Packard, the world's second-largest computer maker, said its board authorized the company to buy back an additional $2 billion in shares after the stock slipped 8 percent this year. The buyback is a way to return cash to shareholders and offset dilution from issuing stock for employee compensation programs, Hewlett-Packard said. At Thursday's closing price, the buyback would account for about 3 percent of the 3.05 billion shares outstanding. Brian Humphries, a spokesman for the company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., said the company believed its stock was undervalued.

title: Rising Spending in Japan Fuels Economic Optimism
description: Consumer spending in Japan grew in April at the fastest pace in two decades, as the economy added jobs and manufacturing increased solidly, official data showed on Friday.

title: Floods Bring More Suffering to a Battered Haitian Town
description: Mapou is gone. So are a thousand people who lived here.

title: Smarty Jones Gives Opponents No Reason to Hope
description: Those searching for a reason Smarty Jones will lose the Belmont Stakes did not find one in the early morning hours at Philadelphia Park on Friday. In what was his lone workout between the Preakness and the June 5 Belmont, he worked seven furlongs in 1 minute 29 1/5 seconds. He did so with his usual fluid stride, completing a workout that was neither too slow nor too fast -- just right, his connections said.

title: A Different Era for Alternative Energy
description: Sales of solar power equipment are hot. Wind energy projects are sprouting up across the landscape. Methane that builds up in the garbage in landfills is being sold in growing quantities to generate power.

title: Overseas registration : Online campaigns gather steam to get Americans to vote
description: PARIS  First, they overflowed the caucuses and the conventions; now they're flooding cyberspace. Tens of thousands of overseas Americans are going online to register to vote  many for the first time  in the upcoming presidential election, lured from the shadows by the intensifying spotlight on Iraq and President George W. Bush. A raft of new Web sites has cropped up in recent weeks and months to motivate absentee voters to cast their ballots.

title: Cuba Base Sent Its Interrogators To Iraqi Prison
description: Interrogation experts from the American detention camp at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, were sent to Iraq last fall and played a major role in training American military intelligence teams at Abu Ghraib prison there, senior military officials said Friday.

title: Lost and Found
Old Soldiers, Fading Away At Grim Pace
description: Frank Janse was laid to rest here on Thursday. He won two Soldier's Medals for Valor in North Africa and in France in the big war, and a handful of campaign ribbons, but he left no family behind.

description: With the big-band era long gone and hip-hop music dominating radio charts and dance clubs, what's an old jazz master to do?

title: Sex and Romanticism? A Composer Dares All
description: The composer David Del Tredici was sitting in his studio in the West Village, surrounded by his eclectic collection of art, musical scores and various objets, talking about taboos. ''I didn't know you could actually consider it composing,'' he said. ''It was so forbidden.''

description: In percent

title: Fiery, Funny and Fortissimo, Still on the Lookout for Love
description: When Elaine Stritch, the actress who may now fairly be called ''legendary,'' appears on HBO tonight in the documentary about her one-woman show from 2002, ''Elaine Stritch at Liberty,'' she takes some getting used to. Bonneted in a garish Herms scarf, barking instructions and loping around in her spidery gait, she's not initially endearing. She comes on too strong. But the low-key filmmaking team of D. A. Pennebaker, Chris Hegedus and Nick Doob -- whose recessive vrit sensibility may be the opposite of Ms. Stritch's Broadway style -- don't get rattled; and they don't take their eyes off her. That loyalty pays off. This is a style of feminine power you don't see all that often.

title: Two Visions of Love, Family and Race Across the Generations
description: In his breakthrough 1986 hit, ''The Colored Museum,'' George C. Wolfe satirized ''A Raisin in the Sun'' in the form of a sketch called ''The Last Mama-on-the-Couch Play.'' In this hilarious piece Mr. Wolfe does a sendup of stereotypical images of blacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELKIN, MYRON
description: BELKIN -- Myron. Devoted and beloved husband of Janet Ehrenreich Belkin, cherished father of Lisa, Gary and Kira, and father-in-law of Bruce Gelb, Saul Fishman and Masha Schiller Belkin. Adored and proud grandfather of Evan, Alex, Annie, Emma, Talia, and Ruth (and Riley). He was kind and gentle, and everyone was his friend. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 30th at 11:00 AM, Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Cardiovascular Institute at The Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: PLATINUM EQUITY WILL BUY COMPUCOM FOR $254 MILLION
description: CompuCom Systems, which distributes computer-networking products, agreed to be acquired by a buyout firm, Platinum Equity, for $254 million. Platinum Equity said it would pay $4.60 a share for CompuCom. Platinum will also acquire the preferred stock held by Safeguard Scientifics, which owns 58 percent of CompuCom for $15 million. Safeguard invests in software start-up companies. The transaction valued CompuCom at a 5 percent discount to the Thursday closing price of $4.84 a share. CompuCom is based in Dallas.

title: Conservative Allies Take Chalabi Case to the White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Influential outside advisers to the Bush administration who support the Iraqi exile leader Ahmad Chalabi are pressing the White House to stop what one has called a "smear campaign" against Mr. Chalabi, whose Baghdad home and offices were ransacked last week in an American-supported raid.

description: With the United States fighting protracted wars in both Iraq and Afghanistan, its military faces a shortage of a basic necessity: ammunition.

title: Umberto Agnelli, Quiet Member of Fiat Dynasty, Dies at 69
description: Umberto Agnelli, who stepped into the limelight at Fiat, the Italian auto empire, after a lifetime in the shadow of relatives renowned for their flamboyance, died late Thursday in the family's villa, La Mandria, outside Turin. He was 69.

description: SUBIN--Charlotte. The Semel Society records with sorrow the passing in her 97th year of Charlotte Subin, our esteemed member for 67 years. Martin I. Semel, President

description: While Mariano Rivera was reaching a benchmark Friday night with his 300th save, the Yankees might have been reaching a benchmark for the season because Derek Jeter's swing is finally in full boom.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Bad Fuel Shuts Stations
description: More than 500 Shell and Texaco service stations in the New Orleans metropolitan region and Florida stopped selling gasoline on Wednesday after fuel from a distribution station in Kenner caused fuel gauges to malfunction, a spokeswoman for Shell, Helen Bow, said. A Shell refinery in Norco produced the gasoline with high levels of sulfur, Shell said. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Decades Waiting and Not a Day to Spare for Veterans at World War II Memorial
description: Thousands of people visited the new World War II Memorial here on Friday, the day before the official opening ceremony, to honor those who served in the war, they said, and the millions of others who labored at home in factories and fields and dockyards.

title: To Bolster Competitiveness, Dredging Is Planned in Bay
description: Hoping to gain a competitive edge in international shipping, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey signed an agreement on Friday with the Army Corps of Engineers to deepen channels around New York Bay to 50 feet to accommodate a new generation of extra-large cargo ships.

title: NORTEL GETS SECOND WAIVER FROM CANADA ON FINANCING
description: Nortel Networks, one of the largest makers of telephone equipment in North America, received a second waiver on a $750 million financing agreement from the Canadian government as it works on restating its accounts. The waiver will remain in effect until Aug. 30 or until Nortel files its 2003 and first-quarter reports with regulators in the United States, whichever is earlier, the company said. Export Development Canada can cancel its support from July 30, provided it gives notice. The extension removes an obstacle as Nortel reviews its accounts going back to at least 2001. Export Development Canada, a government-owned institution, has been acting as a guarantor for Nortel, which is based in Ontario, providing collateral to lenders so the company can use its $3.6 billion in cash for other purposes.

title: Tobacco deaths in Asia are expected to soar
description: MANILA:  Tobacco-related deaths in Asia are expected to increase four times by 2030 as the number of smokers in the region continues to grow, particularly among women and children, the World Health Organization has reported.

title: City Creates New Paths To a Diploma
description: Faced with embarrassingly high dropout rates, the New York City Department of Education is moving aggressively to expand or create alternative high school programs for students who are behind in their credits.

title: R. J. Prokopy, 68, Entomologist Who Focused on Pest Controls
description: Ronald J. Prokopy, a scientist whose research on fruit flies in apple orchards led to environmental pest-control programs using fewer pesticides, died on May 14 in Franklin Medical Center in Greenfield, Mass. He was 68.

title: After Interruption, Safin Returns to Finish the Job
description: The big green door swung open at 2:43 p.m. on Friday, and Marat Safin swaggered through it and onto Court 1 as if he were a lumberjack heading back to the forest, with Felix Mantilla shuffling discreetly in his wake.

title: Municipal Union Rejects Raise Financed by Reduced Benefits
description: Teamsters Local 237, the union representing hospital security officers and other New York municipal workers, announced yesterday that its bargaining committee had unanimously rejected the same accord accepted last month by the city's largest municipal union.

title: School District Lawyer Says She Advised Reporting Theft
description: A lawyer for the Roslyn School District said yesterday that she had advised school officials to report the embezzlement of $250,000 to the Nassau County district attorney, but that they chose instead to retain another lawyer who told them that the theft did not have to be reported if it was repaid.

title: Nielsen Media's Revised Ratings System Is Denied Accreditation by Industry Group
description: Efforts by Nielsen Media Research to change the way it measures television ratings in New York City have been dealt a setback by a leading industry association that audits ratings services.

title: To Frenzied Scenes, Abu Ghraib Frees 624 Prisoners
description: Raising their voices in slow, melodic chants of ''God is Great,'' hundreds of Iraqis took over a highway in front of Abu Ghraib prison on Friday to greet buses carrying out 623 men and one woman after months of detention.

title: DELTA PREPARES FOR POSSIBLE BANKRUPTCY FILING
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it had hired an investment bank, the Blackstone Group, while bondholders and vendors sought advice from Saybrook Capital in preparing for a possible Chapter 11 filing by the airline. Delta is working with Blackstone and other advisers to help ''with all aspects of our business reassessment and planning efforts,'' a spokeswoman, Peggy Estes, said. Saybrook Capital, advising United Airlines' creditors, was contacted by Delta debtors for guidance on the airline's finances, a Saybrook partner, Jonathan Rosenthal, said. Delta, based in Atlanta, said on May 10 that it might be forced to seek bankruptcy protection if it could not reduce costs, stem losses and raise capital. The company asked pilots, its only unionized work group, to take a 30 percent pay cut to help reduce costs.

title: Iraq Update
description: THE CANDIDATE A secular-minded Shiite, scion of a prominent family, former exile, member of the Iraqi Governing Council and player in the long effort to topple Saddam Hussein emerged as the choice for interim prime minister when sovereignty is handed back. In the choice of Iyad Alawi, the United Nations found itself appearing shoved aside by the United States.

title: Editorial Observer; What Adolescents Miss When We Let Them Grow Up in Cyberspace
description: My 10th-grade heartthrob was the daughter of a fearsome steelworker who struck terror into the hearts of 15-year-old boys. He made it his business to answer the telephone -- and so always knew who was calling -- and grumbled in the background when the conversation went on too long. Unable to make time by phone, the boy either gave up or appeared at the front door. This meant submitting to the intense scrutiny that the girl's father soon became known for.

title: Smarty Jones Could Buck Trend And Campaign as a 4-Year-Old
description: Smarty Jones could make history next Saturday by winning the Belmont Stakes and sweeping the Triple Crown, and his owners, Roy and Pat Chapman, are looking to buck recent precedent by having him race next year as a 4-year-old, thus delaying the colt's inevitable trip to the breeding shed.

title: Leadership Needed on AIDS
description: Intravenous drug users who are infected with H.I.V. by sharing needles with other addicts -- and can pass on the infection to sexual partners and unborn children -- have accounted for more than a third of the AIDS cases in the United States. Drug treatment and safe-sex awareness programs are crucial to fighting the epidemic. But so are common-sense programs that supply addicts with clean needles while they wait, sometimes for years, for treatment.

title: CD Player of Slain Student Is Found in Park Underbrush
description: A pink compact disc player belonging to a murdered Juilliard School student was discovered late Thursday by a detective searching the thick undergrowth in Inwood Hill Park about 50 to 100 feet from where her decomposed body was found. It was perhaps the most promising clue in the case so far.

title: Shopping tours : Antique hunting in China is no longer just for the intrepid
description: HONG KONG  Pam Shaw and her small but determined group left Hong Kong on a mission. After a few hours on a ferry, they arrived in Zhaoqing, in southern China, just before lunch. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORRESTAL, ROBERT P.
description: FORRESTAL--Robert P. The Board of Directors, officers, and staff of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta are deeply saddened by the loss of Robert P. Forrestal, former president and chief executive officer. He died of cancer on May 26 at the age of 72. A native of New York City and graduate of St. John's University, he studied in France on a Fulbright Scholarship in 1953, beginning an interest in international affairs that he applied throughout his career. He later served as an officer in the U.S. Naval Intelligence, with tours of duty in Morocco, Italy, and Great Britain. Upon discharge, he earned a law degree from Georgetown, and soon joined the Federal Reserve System, where he spent most of his professional life. After six years at the Board of Governors in Washington, DC, in 1970 he joined the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta as general counsel. He later served as first vice president and chief operating officer before becoming president and CEO from 1983 to 1995. Mr. Forrestal was a member of the Fed's monetary policy making body, the FOMC, and led the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta during a period of rapid change in the banking industry and the economy. To deal with these challenges, he strengthened the Altanta Fed's research and supervisory functions while maintaining the Bank's operational efficiency in processing checks, cash, and other payments. He also increased understanding of international economics and finance, giving numerous speeches around the U.S. and in Latin America and Europe, often in French, Italian or Spanish. Throughout his career he was active in community service, and served on numerous boards, including those of various hospitals, universities, and other nonprofits. To his wife, Wilma Anderson Forrestal, his daughter, Renee Spoerer, and three grandsons, Robbie, Nicholas, and Thomas, we extend our condolences. Jack Guynn President and CEO Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta

title: Saudi Commandos Free Hostages, Ending Standoff With Militants
description: KHOBAR, Saudi Arabia, May 30 - Saudi commandos in helicopters stormed an upscale residential complex in this oil center on Sunday, freeing most of the dozens of Westerners and other foreigners who had been trapped by four armed militants in the compound's hotel for 24 hours. The militants killed 22 people, the Interior Ministry announced, including one American. Twenty-five people were wounded, according to a ministry statement carried by the official Saudi press agency. It also said the militants began the siege of the compound by vaulting over a fence, after their attempt to drive a car booby-trapped with explosives into the compound had failed. The militants' leader was critically wounded and captured, the statement said, but three other gunmen - holding hostages at gunpoint - used them as cover to escape in a stolen car. It was unclear what happened to those hostages, but checkpoints set up on major highways around this city on the Persian Gulf were examining all cars. The attack on Saturday on the luxurious complex, known as the Oasis Residential Resorts, was the second brazen assault this month against the Saudi oil industry, which is heavily dependent on foreigners, and statements of responsibility attributed to Al Qaeda quickly appeared on Arab Islamist Web sites. Moreover, the attack came as Saudi Arabia is trying to increase production to ease pressure on record global oil prices. The psychological impact of the Oasis attack on the major oil markets in New York and London, which are closed on Monday, remained to be seen. In the tense finale of the Oasis attack, the Saudi commandos were shown on television leaping from helicopters onto the roof of a building in the compound. The victims included nine people killed in or around the Oasis residential resort, the luxurious guesthouse which includes amenities like an ice-skating rink. The militants had held the resort overnight, apparently picking off victims as they encountered them. ``They were found all over the place, some of them in the corridors and others near the entrance and some on the steps,'' said one Saudi eyewitness.. He said most appeared to be either Indian or Filipino, except for two Westerners. Details of the assault and the mopping up operation remained murky. The Saudi Interior Ministry statement said 41 hostages were rescued by the commandos, but a Western diplomat explained that they were not all held together in the hotel, a five-story building constructed around a courtyard swimming pool. The diplomat said some had been hiding to avoid being killed by the gunmen who seized the place. ``The gunmen were going through the compound and either shooting people or letting them go, they shot non-Muslims and they let the Muslims go,'' the Western diplomat said. The Oasis attack was the first large-scale assault in the heart of the kingdom's oil producing region along the Persian Gulf, and followed a similarly brazen assault on foreign oil workers in the Saudi city of Yanbu on May 1. Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi ambassador to the United States, and other senior government officials sought to reassure world oil markets that production continued uninterrupted. The Saudi oil minister, Ali al-Nuaimi, was reportedly meeting with Western officials and oil company executives to reassure them that the attacks would not affect oil supplies. ``The terrorists' goal is to disrupt the Saudi economy and destabilize our country,'' Prince Bandar said in a statement released in Washington. ``But they will not succeed. With every desperate act of violence, our effort and resolve to destroy the terrorists only grows.'' Prince Bandar also told Fox television news that seven Americans had been rescued from the compound. Diplomats in the kingdom said he was referring to seven American government personnel who lived on the compound and had managed to elude detection by the militants, although two of them suffered gunshot wounds that were not life threatening. The total of 242 people evacuated from the Oasis compound - also home to executives for such leading firms as Royal Dutch/Shell, Total and Lukoil - were taken to either hospitals or nearby hotels, depending on their condition. A group affiliated with Al Qaeda, the network whose founder, Osama bin Laden, has vowed to disrupt the close ties between the kingdom and the West, claimed responsibility for the attack through an unsubstantiated claim on a Web site associated with the militants. It threatened to drive all ``crusaders'' from ``the land of Islam.'' In a taped statement posted on Islamist Web sites, Abdulaziz al-Muqrin, a reputed leader of Al Qaeda in Saudi Arabia, promised that the coming months would be ``bloody and miserable for infidels.'' Saudi and other analysts suggest that it is likely that Qaeda admirers, rather than the organization itself, were responsible. Much like the bloody assault in Yanbu, which left six Westerners and a Saudi dead, the Oasis attack against compounds or office complexes used mainly by Westerners appeared designed to create maximum carnage. That suggests that the terrorists are getting weaker, rather than stronger, the analysts believe, because they are unable to attack anything substantial. A crackdown launched after three suicide bombing attacks killed 35 people in Riyadh last May, including the bombers, has seriously hampered their ability to organize. ``It reflects a late stage in the life of these groups because when they are very weak, they choose very easy targets with very bloody results,'' said Hassan Abu Taleb, an expert on Saudi affairs at the Al-Ahram Center for Political and Strategic studies in Cairo. ``They want something that causes the maximum propaganda and media impact to try to show that they are strong.'' Before hitting the Oasis complex, the attackers had opened fire at the Al-Khobar Petroleum Center building, which houses the offices of numerous Western firms, and shot their way through another building used by Apicorp, the Arab Petroleum Investment Corporation. An Egyptian schoolboy was among those killed there. ``These targets are not strategic, they did not attack oil fields for example, so it has no affect on the grip of the Saudi royal family,'' Mr. Abu Taleb noted. Such strikes mean that the level of violence may not drop any time soon, as there are literally thousands of places for anyone with a gun to shoot at Westerners in the kingdom. Expatriate residents of the Eastern Province, where the kingdom's oil production is centered, said they expect a large exodus of at least families once the school year ends. The American Embassy repeated its April 15 warning that all Americans should depart the kingdom. Many Saudis expressed revulsion over the attacks, but there were a few gloating messages on extremist Web sites that some of the militants had been able to elude capture. Khobar had been the site of a terrorist attack in 1996, when 19 American servicemen died from a massive truck bomb that sheared off the face of their apartment building. In hindsight it was labeled a Qaeda attack. Crown Prince Abdullah, the country's actual ruler in the face of King Fahd's longstanding infirmity, reiterated the kingdom's determination to stamp out the extremists. In the short run, analysts said, they are aided by the fact that each such attack tends to convince people to unite around the ruling family. But in the long run, police operations alone won't work because the extremists are rooted in the same Wahabi religious tenets as the family. ``The security solution is not enough, these are ideological groups who want to topple the regime itself,'' said Abdel Rahman al-Lahem, a Saudi lawyer and expert in Islamist movements. The tradition of leaving public discourse up to the religious alone has to be abandoned for a broader base, he suggested. The extremists were evidently returning to attacking Westerners because their recent attacks-including a car-bombing in Riyadh in April and an attack on a compound there last November-had mostly killed Saudis and other Muslims. The Saudi Interior Ministry said the dead included one American, eight Indians, one Briton, two Sri Lankans, one Egyptian child, one Swede, one Italian, one South African, three Filipinos and three Saudis. Barrie Peach, the spokesman for the British Embassy, identified the dead Briton as Michael Hamilton, 61, who had spent 25 years working in the region and was vice president for projects at Apicorp, one of the businesses attacked Saturday. The Italian foreign ministry identified their dead citizen as Antonio Amato, 25, who had arrived in the kingdom in recent weeks to work as a cook at the Oasis complex.

Katz Chairman's Chair of Brookdale Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development Mount Sinai School of Medicine, members of the Advisory Board of the Hertzberg Institute, and the entire faculty and staff of the Institute who knew and admired her, mourn the loss of our friend, Lilian Hertzberg. A woman of extraordinary intelligence, culture, wide ranging interests and detemination, Lilian Hertzberg was a visionary benefactor who recognized the need for medical care focused on relief of suffering and support for best quality of life for patients with serious illness and their families. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REBENFELD, LUDWIG
description: REBENFELD -- Ludwig of Princeton, died May 26, 2004 at the University Medical Center at Princeton after a brief illness. Born in Prague, the Czech Republic, the son of Carl Rebenfeld and Martha Rebenfeld, he has been a Princeton resident since 1951. He was a graduate of the University of Lowell (Mass) with a B.S. in Chemistry and received his PhD in Chemistry at Princeton University. At the time of his death, Dr. Rebenfeld was the Editor of the Textile Research Journal of TRI/Princeton (formerly Textile Research Institute), having served in many positions over his 50 year career including Director and President. Between 1964 and until his retirement, he was a Visiting Lecturer in the Department of Chemical Engineering at Princeton University. He was a Life Trustee of the Philadelphia College (now University) of Textiles and Science, and was Chairman of the Board between 1974 and 1979. He was the President of the Association of Princeton Graduate Alumni, 1981-1983; received an Honorary Doctorate from Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science; and received the 1990 Distinguished Alumni Award from the University of Lowell. He was a member of various Societies and Institutes in the Chemical and Textile fields. His wife, Ellen Vogel Rebenfeld, died in 2002. There are no immediate survivors. Burial will be private. A Memorial Service is to be held at the Princeton University Chapel on Saturday, June 12, 2004 at 11:30am. For info Kimble Funeral Home, Princeton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the charity of the donor's choice or The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, PO Box 5193, General Post Office, NY, NY 10087

title: 'The Body of Jonah Boyd'

Glenn Turner was usually one of these, as was Phil Perry (later to cause such grief and uproar), and a shadowy girl with bangs in a plaid skirt whose name, for the moment, escapes me. Also me. My name is Judith "Denny" Denham, and I was unique among the strays in that I wasn't any kind of graduate student. I was Ernest Wright's secretary in the psych department. Since the Thanksgiving about which I am writing-1969-thirty years have passed, which is as many years as I had then been alive.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a bill in the California Legislature to let oral and maxillofacial surgeons perform cosmetic facial surgery misstated the amount of training they receive in a four-year residency after they earn dental degrees. They spend a minimum of 30 months in clinical oral and maxillofacial surgery and at least 4 more months in other surgical practices, like general surgery -- not merely 18 months in surgical rotation.

title: Da Vinci Code

These trips, planned for Oct. 7 to 20, 2004, and May 16 to 29, 2005, will be led by two Franciscan Sisters and approach the content from a feminist perspective.
